title: England from the Wars of the Roses to the Glorious Revolution
reviews: Attend lectures, and do the readings with the future precept discussion in mind.
Definitely take the course! Just don't get behind on textbook readings and try to cram right before the tests.
Take if you have any interest at all in English history.
Take it!
Talk to your professor about expectations for the class and take lengthy notes during lecture.

This class was AMAZING. I went to lecture everyday because I actually enjoyed the material--I often called it my Game of Thrones class because of the political intrigue and similar concepts to the show/books (without the dragons...). I would recommend this class to anyone who enjoys history or wants to learn about an interesting time period/region of the world. There was quite a bit of work involved sometimes--weekly response papers and occasional papers assigned on top of that, plus a final research paper and an exam--but I found that I was actually interested in most things that we did. Prof. Hubbard also found ways to make precepts really engaging (one day we wrote with quills for precept) and course lectures were fascinating. All in all an amazing course that cemented my decision to concentrate in history!

This course is a lot more work than a normal history class. Especially for juniors- There is a 12-15 page research paper in addition to a full final that this year was 5 identifications, 5 short answers and 3 long essays which is way longer than most history classes that I have taken here

While I really enjoy this time period, I wish this class had gone deeper into its discussion of some of the topics. Also, I think the textbook should have been better incorporated into the class throughout the year whether in lectures or precepts.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: The two centuries between the Wars of the Roses and the Glorious Revolution saw the end of the feudal order, astonishing revolutions in church and state, a literary renaissance, two ruling queens and one executed king in a deeply patriarchal and hierarchical society, civil wars, the beginnings of the British empire, and the emergence of a recognizably modern society of newspapers, scientific experiments, and political parties. These extraordinary developments were, however, far from being natural or predetermined. This course will explore how such dramatic transformations took place in a society seemingly resistant to change.

title: History of Contemporary Science
reviews: A very, very good course, and interesting from both a historical perspective and a scientific one.  Take it if you have an interest in getting up-to-date on big scientific ideas or if you like good lectures.
As a science major who does not particularly like history, I can say that I truly enjoyed this course and learned quite a lot! Take this course! Really easy to take PDF

Be sure to try your best to get through the readings or to at least skim so that you can have something to contribute to lectures (they're fairly small, so it gets awkward when you don't have anything at all to contribute).
Best professor I've ever had in all my four years at Princeton.

Definitely go to lecture, they are really interesting and extremely important for writing the final, the midterm, and all the response papers. Also, don't be afraid to speak up in precept - these topics are fun and easy to discuss. Overall, definitely worth your time whether you are interested in science, history, or both.
Definitely take this course. It was probably the best I've taken at Princeton.

Every student "needs" to take a history of science course before they graduate. Not only because science has become such a dominant part of the contemporary world, but because it opens up the possibility for communication across disciplines and, more generally, between the sciences and the humanities (where communication is often lacking!) If you think there is no way that you could possibly find yourself interested in the material, Prof. Gordin will prove you wrong. He only speaks fast because he loves the subject, just as he loves answering difficult questions, meeting for office hours, and making jokes that are subtly strewn throughout his lectures.
Get good notes from classes and pay attention to your preceptor's feedback on your writing.

Get in Gordin's precept if you can.  He is an engaging and fair preceptor.  I looked forward to precept because most students were really engaged.  Great PDF class, as I worked hard for most of the semester out of interest, but then didn't have to worry about the final essays.  Readings are diverse and interesting.  I spent about 70 hours on the course this semester, including 20 hours on my midterm essay and the rest on responses/final/reading.
Go to lecture - it'll be super interesting and you'll learn a lot!
Go to lecture! Professor Gordin is great!
Go to the lectures. Prof Gordin has an amazing lecturing style. Fast-paced, content-packed but definitely worth going to.
Gordin is a great lecturer, really makes class fun. Material is interesting if you're into science or history!
Have fun!

I didn't know much about contemporary science and had no exposure to history of science-- but I loved this class and loved the introduction to a new way to think about science and discoveries. Not too much work, either. I even enjoyed the bi-weekly written mini-papers because they helped me get more out of my material
It is a valuable course to take if you have an interest in science and want to broaden your insights into the field.
Lectures are essential.
Professor Gordin is a great lecturer. The readings are sometimes boring but the material is new and relevant if you're a science or engineering student?would definitely recommend.
Professor Gordin is one of the best lecturers I've had at Princeton, and the subject material is interesting and really relevant to today.

Professor Gordin is probably the best lecturer I've had at Princeton.  The readings are generally pretty interesting.  Precept is precept.  You pretty much know what you're getting into, so take it if you're interested in the topic.

TAKE THIS COURSE. HIGHLY HIGHLY RECOMMEND. Professor Gordin is incredible. The man commands the stage and entrances a lecture like no other. Gordin deserves his own distribution requirement: MG. Kids, take my advice and do not go through Princeton without a dose of MG. He combines a deep, nuanced understanding of the field of history of science with an impeccable lecture style and a fun personality. Course covers the universe, structure of contemporary science, life, environment, and many other HIGHLY relevant fields that every young educated person ought to understand. Gordin will take you on an incredible journey, and it would be a huge huge travesty if you do not decide to embark. The course is magnificent in itself, but the man really takes it to another level. Take any course with Gordin, you will not regret it. TAKE!!!
Take for any and all reasons.
Take it
Take it if you like science and want to learn other aspects to the science world!
Take it if you need to. It's not a bad class but it's not amazing either.

Take it! Professor Gordin is awesome-- engaging, clear, and hilarious, as well as really supportive. The subject material is fascinating, and I really feel like I learned a lot over the course of the semester. The workload is also very manageable. If you're even vaguely interested in contemporary science, just take the class- you won't regret it!
Take it, Take it, Take it
Take time and care in writing the papers.

The take-home final exam claims to take 3-4 hours to complete, but 1500 words per essay means three 6-page research-style papers to be completed over 2.5 days in the middle of finals period.  A very engaging course, but be warned.

This is THE BEST CLASS that I've taken at Princeton. Professor Gordin is such an amazing professor that I would take any class taught by him, no matter the topic. Although all of the preceptors were great, try to get into Gordin's precept! Even if you don't think you're super interested in the material, Prof. Gordin is engaging and the course is always interesting. The workload is super manageable and reasonable. TAKE THIS CLASS. TAKE IT.

This is a really interesting course, and one of the few at Princeton that adeptly tackles contemporary issues. There is a lot of information to get down, so take notes with a laptop (even if you're a staunch take-notes-by-hand person like I am).
Would recommend.
Wow. Professor Gordin is such a great lecturer. Take this course!
perfect lecture class. good if you want a lecture that will motivate you to go to class and do the readings, but not take up all your attention and life.
take it!!!!
prereqs: None.
descrip: More science has been done since 1970 than in the history of the world before that date--- combined. This course traces a series of developments in contemporary science across a broad array of disciplines, with the goal of illuminating the historical processes that have brought them about and providing students with a set of tools to understand the particular position of the sciences in today's world. Topics covered include AIDS, nuclear power, string theory, evolutionary psychology, brain drain, and genomics.

title: The Media and Social Issues - Health and Science Journalism
reviews: Advice? Take the class, I suppose??
Definitely a good class - it is a bit more health journalism than science journalism, but that's not necessarily a bad thing.  Lots of freedom with the assignments and really cool guest speakers.

Especially if you're interested in the topic, this is a great opportunity to hone your skills and hear from people with a number of different perspectives on science communication. Be aware that Belluck's very interested in the human side of science--this is not at all a bad thing, but don't expect to write 4 papers on hard science theory.
I recommend this course. If you are a scientist it will really give you an appreciation for how to present science to laypeople.

If you're interested in any time of journalism, take this class. This was my first exposure to journalism and it was challenging and frustrating at times... but a great preview of what the field of journalism is like!
Professor Belluck is a great journalist who can open up your eyes to a lot of exciting things in her field, and help improve your writing a great deal. Definitely worth taking.
She is amazing, take this if you really want to figure out if journalism is for you.
Take this course if you are BOTH interested in how to present scientific information and if you enjoy actual journalistic reporting, i.e. calling and emailing a bunch of people for interviews.

This is a really great course! I'm not sure if Professor Belluck will teach it again, but it was a pleasure to have her, especially since she writes for the New York Times and had so many great connections! I think this was one of the more practical courses I've taken: it gave me a chance to develop non-academic writing skills and I also learned a lot about how journalism works and the craft of writing a journalism article.
prereqs: Enrollment by application - see course web address.
descrip: Transformation in medicine and science is occurring at a remarkable pace, making thoughtful, accurate journalism crucial. This seminar will discuss: finding, reporting and telling compelling stories; determining truth and relevance in scientific research; investigating issues involving ethics, research funding, politics and government oversight; using multimedia, interactivity and social media to enhance storytelling and reporting; combining data and anecdotes to produce meaningful, engaging journalism.

title: Aircraft Flight Dynamics
reviews: Aircraft are pretty tight, so in that sense this class was good.  Little too much focus on equation crunching though, and not enough on really gaining intuition about aircraft dynamics.
Do not take this if you haven't taken controls yet. You've been warned.
Don't worry if you don't follow anything going on in lecture-- it's not relevant at all for the assignments.
I only recommend taking this course if you are deeply interested in aircraft flight. If you are just doing this to graduate, you're going to have a rough time.
I wish I had engaged a little more with the material. I coasted and learned the minimum to do the assignments and it was not fun at all.

If you're really into airplanes and like working with Matlab code, decent class. I found Stengel's lectures to be terribly difficult to follow, he is, however, always willing to answer questions, so do that! SLOW STENGEL DOWN. ASK ALL THE QUESTIONS. If no one asks anything, he will just continue and continue and continue and assume everybody understands. FROM THE BEGINNING ON, ASK QUESTIONS ABOUT EVERYTHING THAT IS UNCLEAR IN LECTURE.
In general it's a required course, it's pretty math heavy but if you can get by that the material is really interesting.

Interesting subject and the history aspects are fascinating, but the lectures can be a little dry and the equations a little extensive (but you don't have to actually know all the equations) I'd take it again.
It's very interesting, but the lectures can be dry.
Lecture is a bit dry but the information and material of the course is fascinating!
Only take if you are an MAE major on the aero track.
Prepared for the extremely heavy workload, but it is worth it.
Start early on the reports. They are not easy.
Start the assignments early and read the books. This will help a lot with the assignments.
prereqs: MAE 206 and MAE 222 (or MAE 224)..
descrip: Introduction to the performance, stability, and control of aircraft. Fundamentals of configuration aerodynamics. Methods for analyzing the dynamics of physical systems. Characterization of modes of motion and desirable flying qualities. Case studies in aircraft stability and control.

title: Advanced General Chemistry: Materials Chemistry
reviews: A lot of self studying is required.
Always take the practice tests. They almost exactly mirror the actual test.

Ask your preceptor if you don't understand things! They're super helpful! Also, don't freak out if you feel like you don't know anything. The way the grades work, you can still get a B pretty easily even while doing poorly on the exams.
Attend lectures, they help a lot.
Be careful about the psets because they can end up hurting your grade a lot.
Be prepared for many tests.
Be prepared to cover a lot of material rapidly and seek out help when needed. A lot of learning takes place both inside and outside lecture.
Be prepared to spend a lot of time outside of class learning the material on your own.
Be used to being independent
Definitely go to lectures. The demos are awesome and the professors often give really useful hints that the text doesn't cover.
Definitely take it over CHM201 if you are an engineer. The labs are pretty easy and never take the full time. Lecture is helpful and often has more than the textbook.
Definitely take this over CHM 201. One chapter is skipped, but from talking to friends in 201, the 207 lecturers are more engaging and the 207 preceptors are more prepared.
Differently take this course over 201. Although it might have a slightly faster pace, the material is very interesting and the lecturers are amazing!

Do not take this class. This class made my first semester at Princeton rough and it will singlehandedly take up all of your time, particularly at the end of the semester. You might as well be taking 201 for the credit because this class is not only taught poorly, but the labs are boring and you don't learn much more, despite the advanced status. This was a waste of a potential good class at Princeton and has put me off chemistry at this school for good. Bocarsly is an awful teacher and not helpful at all when you need help. Cava is a great person, but definitely not suited to teach large lecturers. L'Esperance is a great professor, but he presents his information in a difficult way that makes the class difficult to enjoy due to his sardonic humour which makes him hard to approach.
Do the problem sets! And take advantage of office hours and TA's. See which works for you: doing  the readings before lecture or afterwards, but do the readings!
Don't take it unless you are an engineer or pre-med.
Don't take this course unless you are comfortable in a completely disorganized environment where you have no idea what you have to learn.
Find a good preceptor to explain problem solving. Take careful lecture notes and attend lectures because course material is not all covered in the textbook. Strong background in chemistry is helpful.
Get ready for gratuitous explosions. Once those are over, though, get ready more serious work.

Go to office hours. I realized it way too late, but Professor Cava and Professor Bocarsly are actually really nice and accessible, although they look really impressive and somewhat distant in lectures. The office hours were really helpful, for the lectures, but also particularly when it comes to the lab reports. Don't hesitate to ask questions, it's their job to answer them, and they will be happy to do so.
Go to precept.
Good class. Though not really sure why you would want to take the class if it wasn't part of your major.
I definitely advise taking the course: you will have great experience with chemistry.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in chemistry. I believe that it gives good background knowledge that can be used in other disciplines.

I would say that the single most important thing you can do to succeed in this class is read the chapters and really focus on your problem sets. If you do that, lectures will make more sense and exams will be nothing to stress over.

Also, in lab, don't be afraid to mess up! I see some people in there who get worried and become unsure of themselves, but that does nothing to help you succeed in lab. Relax, think things through a little, and (being safe still of course) just go for it. Oftentimes you were right about what to do all along. And if you're really stuck just ask the TA!

I would say to make use of the office hours, supplement your class notes with home notes, go to all the review sessions, and challenge yourself to come up with possible ways in which the professors could complicate questions. Also, go to Friday lecture!
I would strongly recommend this course. It's my lightest workload, but I feel like I'm learning a ton of information.
I would suggest taking an STL in physics instead, for the reasons described above.
I would tell other students to use the textbook to supplement the lectures because it is necessary.
If you can place out of it, do so. But if you have to take it, then don't worry. It's a good course with funny professors that make the class interesting.

If you don't have to take this class, don't. It is 7 hours a week, the equivalent of two classes, is poorly instructed and a lot of work. There is a huge curve overall, but the course itself is grueling.
If you don't have to take this course and you are not interested in Chem do not take it
If you took advanced high school chemistry and expect to know most of the content, the way in which the content of this course is taught will be frustrating for you.
If your choice is between this and regular general chemistry, take this course regardless of your intended major or opinions on chemistry.  This course is excellent.
Just do the readings and go to the classes and you will do fine.
Keep up with reading the book for each chapter covered. It will be significantly easier if the chapter is read before lecture
Keep up with the readings. Dont be discouraged if you are lost in lecture.
Listen in lecture because they can give exam answers and the lecture demos are also on exams. If you actually do the readings before lecture, things make more sense.
Listen to lectures very carefully. Read textbook. Know that much of the final exam is based on stuff that goes beyond the scope of the textbook material.

Make sure not to skip any of the lectures because the professors teach material that is not in the textbook. Make sure not to skip precepts because they are useful for problem sets and exam questions.
Make sure to keep up with the course's readings, since it is quite fast-paced.
Make sure you get a good precptor!

Make sure you have somewhat of an understanding of what is going to be taught in lecture because otherwise you will get lost quickly. Also be prepared to have questions on the test that require you to think at a much higher level than what is actually taught.

More engaging, but more difficult than CHM201 - lecturers were awesome, get a good lab time (not evening labs) and shop around the precepts. Study the text book before class - lectures make more sense that way.
Only take it if you have to, but you shouldn't dread it.
Only take this if you have to or if you like chemistry.
Prepare to do a lot of reading on your own. Lectures may get really boring.
Read as much as you can before going to lecture. If you don't understand something go to office hours.
Read the book and make sure you understand it very well.

Read the textbook before lecture, go to precept, do practice exams, take notes during lecture. Don't worry too much about demos as they are uploaded online, so sit back and enjoy the demos.  Do the problem sets.
Read the textbook very carefully and go to precept and lecture.

Read the textbook!! Do every single problem for the problem set over again before any examination. I would highly recommend this over CHM 201. I'm a pre-med student, non-engineer, and was told to take this because it's actually very interesting and the lectures are much more engaging. This is very, very true! Don't miss out.
Read the textbook.
Read your textbook, do all of the problem sets, and go to office hours!
Study hard and keep up.
Study the old exams.
Take 201 instead.
Take 201 instead. this course is very hard and the lectures are extremely fast paced, making it hard to learn anything. also the amount of precepts per lecture is way too low.
Take it if you are interested in chemistry.
Take it, generally heard it's a lot better than 201. Not too hard with a background in high school chem and a good first semester class for freshmen.
Take the time to know what you're doing before lab and attend all your precepts.

Take this course if you have space for it or if you're required to! It's relatively painless and actually quite enjoyable. But if you're running out of space in your schedule, I wouldn't make it a priority.
Take this course if you need it for your department or are very good at Chemistry, if not I would not suggest it.
Take this over 201 for sure
The class is actually quite interesting and definitely would recommend over 201 if you're an engineer. Stay on top of your work and ask the TAs and professors for help.

The class was fairly straight forward. Go to lecture, read the textbook, do the problem sets... It does take up some time just because you have the lectures lab the class and then problem sets every week. There isn't all that much actual homework though. If you do end up taking the course, I would try to do the homework (or at least start the reading) before your class period so that you can ask questions and clear up any information that ins't clear to you. 
There are lots of demonstrations which make the lectures much more interesting.
The practice exams/midterms are very easy whereas the tests will be hard. Do extra hard problems. Find the hardest ones in each chapter. Teaching yourself is extremely important
This course is a good indicator of whether you should pursue chemistry.
This course provides an interesting perspective on materials science (as it relates to general chemistry). It is important to stay up-to-date with the readings.
This is an excellent introductory chemistry course with a lively set of professors.
Try to pay attention during lecture, even when it's easy to lose focus. Read the textbook thoroughly and do the homework.

Unless you have to take it for your engineering requirement, I'd only take this class if you enjoy chemistry. Be prepared to study a lot outside of class, because the lectures oftentimes don't fully cover the material in the problem sets.
Very good alternative to CHM 201 if you're not a fan of chem
Work hard
always do the reading before lecture and attend every single one of the lectures.also be very prepared before lab and follow the instructions religiously.
pay attention to the demos. Read your text before lecture for maximum benefit.
read chapters before each week
read the textbook and teach yourself
prereqs: Concurrent registration in MAT 103 or equivalent placement is required..
descrip: CHM 207 is an introductory course in chemistry with examples drawn from materials science. The basic concepts of chemistry are introduced: stoichiometry, reaction types, equilibria, thermodynamics, quantum mechanics, and chemical bonding. These concepts are applied in discussions of the structure, reactions, and properties of technologically important materials: metals, semiconductors, ceramics, and polymers. This course is designed as a one term introduction to chemistry, however it may be coupled with CHM 202 to fulfill medical school requirements in general chemistry.

title: Fundamentals of Neuroscience
reviews: A bit boring, but cool class
Absolutely take this course! It's fantastic.
Always attend lecture and take strong, comprehensive notes.
Always go to lecture. Just always. No exception.
Attend all lectures because exams are based off of those, not the textbook, and he teaches some things in lecture that aren't in the textbook.
Attend all the lectures and take really good notes.
Be prepared to memorize material, but it is easy to comprehend if you put the work in. Best class I've taken at Princeton.
DON'T BUY THE TEXTBOOK.  WASTE OF $70!  NO REASON.
Definitely form study groups in order to make sure you have all the material presented in lecture.
Definitely recommend for anyone just interested in sciences in particular biology. Graziano is an amazing lecturer and no prior knowledge needed.
Definitely take it! Graziano is a great lecturer, learn very interesting things about the brain you didn't know before.
Definitely take it, but watch out for the small details. Record the lectures!

Do not be fooled by the story-telling lecture way of professor Graziano The story telling part is important. Take good notes!!! Although the multiple choice format of the exams sounds easy, there were not for me. The exams got harder each time. I wish I could have found friends to study with for the exams. Study with friends!!
Don't buy the textbook. Attend lectures and record them.
Don't get discouraged if you don't know something, literally everyone encounters that in this subject I think. Focus more on understanding and being able to work with a lot of things.
Don't skip lecture! The textbook is helpful for only a few weeks.
Easy course but very good intro o neuro and helps understanding some of our daily life.
Enjoy it, and you will learn more and better. Also, take very detailed notes, maybe exchange notes with friends, and don't study only on the night before an exam.
GO TO LECTURE

GO TO LECTURE. You don't even have to buy the textbook or read it at all - everything is based off of lectures, and Graziano knows enough that you will probably learn a lot anyway. Take good notes/record the lecture, and start studying about a week before each exam.
GO TO LECTURES. TAKE NOTES.  That is all.
Go to all of the lectures, since you will be tested on lecture material over material from the book.
Go to class or get other peoples' notes
Go to every SINGLE lecture otherwise there is no humane way that you will get anything about a B in this course
Go to every lecture and take meticulous notes. An exam question could come up on any sentence said in the lecture.

Go to every lecture and take thorough notes. Compare notes with your friends/classmate. Try recording the lectures if you don't seem to be getting everything/you can't write or type as quickly as the material is presented (I've seen people do this and did it once myself and it really helped!)

Go to every single lecture, do NOT miss out! I miss two lectures and screwed up the following exam! The textbook won't help you much beyond the first few weeks so don't underestimate good note taking and studying!

Go to lecture!! Doing the readings isn't 100% necessary, but lecture attendance is crucial. Even if you get another student's notes, missing just one class can make studying for the exam much more difficult.
Go to lecture, take notes and enjoy the drawings!
Go to lecture, take perfect notes, then memorize the notes. One of the best courses at Princeton in terms of how interesting it is and how manageable it is to do well.
Go to lecture.
Go to lectures and take good notes
Go to lectures, no matter what.
Go to lectures. Graziano is amazing. Get Taylor Webb as your preceptor.
Go to the lectures and take great notes!
Go to the lectures because Graziano is very knowledgable on the subject and talks about the cool experiments he has done with monkeys.
Go to the lectures! Write down everything the professor says. Study all of it.
Good course, pretty straight-forward and easy. Don't need to buy the textbook. Go to lecture.

Graziano is an amazing, funny, and engaging lecturer. Take this class. The material is fascinating and thought-provoking. TAKE REALLY GOOD NOTES AND GO TO LECTURE. The tests are entirely based off of what he says, anything he says, from anecdotes to pathways. Take it, take it, take it and enjoy.

Graziano is cool. Exams are easy if you go to lecture and write down every word. Material is fairly interesting, but 258 is definitely a foundation for higher-level NEU courses and feels a bit like AP Bio sometimes

Great class! The subject is very interesting, and Graziano is a good lecturer. It's also very little work. The textbook readings are neither mandatory or relevant for tests (you can do them if you're interested), and besides that, there were literally only 3 journal articles that we had to read throughout the entire semester. The tests aren't easy, but there are only 4 of them, and the rest of the semester you have almost no work, literally. Would be a good fifth class.
Great course, you'll learn a lot of interesting material
I love Graziano. He's a great professor and his lectures are very engaging and fascinating. You should definitely take this class if you are even remotely interested in neuroscience.
I love this course! Make sure you go to lecture, and pay attention! Some students record the lecture, and that would probably be very helpful.

I would advise students to be prepared for a difficult class if they are more humanities/social science oriented. Many students who take this class really love neuroscience, so those not as strong in the sciences should be forewarned.
I would tell them to try and write down every word out of the lecturer's mouth.

If you are interested in neuroscience, this is a very detailed class but it is heavily memory based and requires you to memorize many facts that are often times hard to put into a more general context.
If you are not required to take this course, but sure you are prepared to make it a priority, or to PDF. It isn't a great general interest class if you're interested in getting an A.
If you don't like memorization, or at least is capable of doing it, be cautious about taking this class. It's a lot of material and not easy to breeze through.

If you have a sound recorder, use that to record the material in the lecture because the professor doesn't use lecture slides and instead writes on the chalkboard. Even if you take good notes, there might be a random fact you forgot to write down that will appear on the exams.
If you think this will be a fun way to do your STN, you're wrong.
If you're interested in the subject and willing to put in the time to study a lot of detail prior to exams, I'd recommend the class.

If you're not sure you'll like it, you might be surprised! You need to be motivated to do well, though, and you need to be able to pay close attention and take careful notes during lecture. Otherwise it might start to drag on for you and you might get lost.
Interesting class.
It is a very, very difficult course to dive straight into, but also very, very worthwhile. Studying is recommended, it makes a huge difference.

It is a wonderful course whether you have previous experience in neuroscience or not.  It might be helpful to review high school level biology prior to the first unit, but other than that, just take good notes in the lectures and study them for the tests.
It might sound super easy because it is multiple choice but don't understudy. You will end up having to break your butt studying for the next tests to bring up your average.

It's a great class if you're interested in neuroscience. Prof. Graziano is a great lecturer. Just know that the field (and the class) mostly involve memorization of lots of facts -- I thought I was interested in neuroscience, but less so after I realized that.
It's a great course to take if you're interested in neuroscience and/or if you need to fulfill an STN.

It's not too difficult as long as you go to all the lectures and pay attention and memorize the stuff. Not really a great pdf class cause you really have to learn it all and pay attention in order to pass the tests, and most people do extremely well on them making the curve not helpful.  Don't skip class.
It's rather easy and if you need an STN, and have some interest in neuroscience, take the course.
Lots of information you learn and very easy.
Make sure to go to all the lectures: the course is not based on the textbook.
Make sure you exchange notes with multiple people before each test. Study ALL the details. Know your anatomy. The course had no real homework, apart from intense cramming before tests.

No slides, guided notes, etc. Hard to follow everything in the lecture and take down all of the notes. Lots of memorization. I spent a lot of time on wikipedia and in the textbook to organize my notes. Kinda disorganized, but exams were straightforward.
Not a bad PDF at all, and you learn a ton.

Overall this is a good course to fulfill an STN, although it is a bit harder than I had expected. Mostly there's a lot of really teeny (and less interesting) details to memorize, so how you do in the class will mostly depend on how much effort you put into very detail-oriented memorization. You should also know that this class is mostly focused on systems such as how the eyes and ears work with the brain, meaning that you learn a lot of neuroanatomy as opposed to cognitive neuroscience.
Record lectures, get every single detail for the exams.

Record the lectures and take notes again while listening to the recordings. By basically transcribing the lectures and then reviewing the notes/quizzing yourself, you can do well on all the exams. I never got the book and never opened it, so don't bother purchasing it. Go to precept... I didn't realize it factored into my grade! woops.
TAKE IT EVERYONE NEEDS TO KNOW AT LEAST A LITTLE ABOUT NEURO!!!! AND ITS FUN EASY INTERESTING YAYYY
TAKE IT!
TAKE IT!!!! It is the most interesting class that provides you with an essential insight into how your brain, your mind, works.
TAKE THIS CLASS

prereqs: Introductory Psychology, Biology, and Chemistry, at least at the high school level, are recommended background for enrollment. Students who have taken PSY 208 must have instructor's permission to take NEU 258 because they cover similar materials. NEU 258 is more detailed and leads into NEU 259 as a two-term sequence. NEU 258 is required for the Neuroscience Certificate..
descrip: This is a survey course on neuroscience, focusing mainly on sensory and motor processing in the primate brain. How does information from the outside world get into the brain, what neuronal pathways does it follow, how is it processed and used to construct an internal model of three-dimensional reality, and how does the brain choose and coordinate the correct behavioral response?

title: Topics in Analysis - Introduction to Incompressible Fluid Dynamics
reviews: I took it with Vlad Vicol and it was awesome. If you have an interest in PDE's or fluids or even functional analysis there is some very interesting material in this course and it is very well taught
prereqs: MAT320, 325, or permission by instructor..
descrip: Introduction to incompressible fluid dynamics. The course will give an introduction to the mathematical theory of the Euler equations, the fundamental partial differential equation arising in the study of incompressible fluids. We will discuss several topics in analysis that emerge in the study of these equations: Lebesgue and Sobolev spaces, distribution theory, elliptic PDEs, singular integrals, and Fourier analysis.

title: Contemporary East Asia
reviews: Carefully do the readings
Challenging SA, be prepared for heavy reading but great lectures

Closer to a course in sociology than politics or economics. As long as that's what you're looking for, it's an interesting course, and Professor Leheny is probably one of the most entertaining lecturers you'll have here.
Contemporary East Asia is a great course!  Besides being an engaging and entertaining lecturere, Professor Leheny has contributed greatly to the growth of my writing.  Strongly recommend!

If you are looking to see whether you have an interest in learning about East Asia, this is a good course. However, you may want to consider taking a course on one country, so you can get more in depth knowledge about the history. I felt that I needed to know more background information on the countries we studied to have been able to optimize my learning experience.
Keep up with the readings and be inquisitive

Professor Leheny is an amazing lecturer, and this class is worth it just to take a class from him. His two main goals are to improve your ability to critically analyze arguments and to improve your writing. His third goal is to teach you something about East Asia. This is good news for you if, like me, you are interested in the region, but it won't be very relevant to your studies in the long term. Readings are generally interesting and not too long, but be warned you do have to do them because they are the focus of the exams. I found this course gave me new ways of understanding representations of foreign countries in general (not just East Asia) and really broke down my tendency to make generalizations in areas that were unfamiliar to me. If you're an engineer looking for a humanities distribution requirement that will teach you useful tools for looking at arguments, I especially recommend it.
Professor Leheny is hilarious! Grading is a bit harsh, but workload is quite light.
Professor Leheny is the best. If he teaches this again, take it no matter what your major.
READ. Read. Do the readings. Take notes on the readings. Also, start the papers well in advance.

Take it and have fun! Professor Leheny is awesome and cares about his students. Prepare to laugh and learn a lot in class and TRY to get into his section. I was scared at first when I found out he was my preceptor but it turned out to be an extremely wonderful experience.

Take it if you want a challenging but fruitful course that will make you a better thinker, writer, and scholar of East Asia. A lot of it focuses on sociological and anthropological views which was something that was new and interesting to me. Also a must-take if you're remotely interested in East Asia. Make sure to get in on Leheny's precept however!
Take it if you're going to put the work in writing. It is a tough course and if you're not interested in politics in Asia, stray away.
Take it. Absolutely.

The exams require you to separate between the ideas from the lectures and the ideas from your readings (which can be very difficult because the lectures are based on the readings). Therefore read the materials before the class and make your own notes before going to lecture to avoid being influenced by his ideas. You can be penalized later if the instructor think what you write in your exam can be taken from the lectures without reading the materials
There is quite a bit of reading, but the professor is amazing. Choose your preceptor wisely.
descrip: This course is an introduction to the societies, cultures, and politics of contemporary East Asia. The rise of East Asia has inspired Western observers to reflect on the ways in which capitalism, democracy, and modern social relationships can unfold in different ways. It has also prompted debates about the development of political systems, about the most efficient and just ways to organize economic growth, and even about what constitutes Asia. Although the course will focus especially on China, Japan, South Korea, and Vietnam, we will draw special attention to issues that cut across national boundaries.

descrip: Economics is the study of how people and societies deal with scarcity. This course focuses on the advantages and disadvantages of market systems for allocating scarce resources.

title: Special Studies in Medieval Literature - Instituting Literature
descrip: What is it that sets "literature" apart from vernacular writing in general in medieval England? We examine the concept of "institution" in political theory, the philosophy of language, the creation of literary value, and the historiography of secularization and rupture. We discuss texts in which the shaping of institutions is a mode of literary self-constitution, and institutions that contribute to the shaping of texts, including mortuary guilds, mendicant and monastic orders, affinities and "bastard" feudalism, chantry chapels.

Take this class! You will leave a better student.

This is a really great course, and I highly recommend finding an opportunity to work with Imani Perry. In preparation for papers, I would think about what kind of media you are drawn to (literary, cultural, photographic, academic) as early as possible so that you might have an idea of what kind of lens you want to bring to your papers-- you will have a lot to choose from. Making a point to run your idea by Professor Perry is always a good move.
This is the best class I have taken at Princeton. I was challenged, encouraged, and surprised. This class managed to bridge the academic and personal perfectly.
Yes, but take it because you're interested in the subject not because you want to improve writing skills.
descrip: As the demographics of Blacks in America change, we are compelled to rethink the dominant stories of who African Americans are, and from whence they come. In this seminar, we will explore the deep cultural, genealogical, national origin, regional, and class-based diversity of people of African descent in the United States. Materials for the course will include scholarly writings as well as memoirs and fiction. In addition to reading assignments, students will be expected to complete an ethnographic or oral history project based upon research conducted within a Black community in the U.S., and a music or visual art based presentation of work.

title: Readings in Modern Korean l
reviews: Excellent course - absolutely recommend
I love it, beautiful people. It's a Fantastic course.

Your reading abilities in Korean will improve, and you'll get to read some great literature (and hear really entertaining stories from Professor Suh), but consider how much you like/tolerate writing, because there is a significant number of written assignments.
dsa
prereqs: KOR 402 or instructor's permission..
descrip: The 5th-year Korean course is designed to advance students' reading and writing skills to the superior level and to promote a deeper understanding of the Korean language, culture, society, and history. Readings cover various types of authentic materials (e.g., newspaper articles, editorials, think pieces, essays, and literary short stories). Discussion and presentation skills in formal settings (e.g., academic, professional) are also emphasized. Class discussions are conducted in Korean.

title: Survey of Selected Greek Literature - Survey of Greek Literature
descrip: A survey of major literary forms and works from the Archaic to the Greco-Roman period.

title: Planets in the Universe
reviews: A fun and non-stressful class, but you get out whatever you put into it.

Ask questions if you have any trouble with the p-sets. The professor and TAs are very very helpful. Don't be lazy about going out and doing your own observing/astrophotography because they will be a big part of your grade.
Be prepared to devote a lot of time figuring out the problem sets. And GO TO LECTURE! It is the only way that you can even begin to get the problem sets or the slides that he posts.
Be ready to do math.  Even though the description says you don't need to know that much, the math was the most difficult for me.
Definitely take it - it's a great course. Attend the lectures, be attentive and you'll do fine.

Definitely take this course, the subject is so interesting and Professor Bakos is incredible. It seems like a hassle to take part in all the observations and group journals etc. but it actually is pretty fun and definitely worth it.
Do all the readings because they are interesting and help to understand the concept better.
Don't take this course unless you really have a passion for astronomy or science.

Fantastic, Professor Bakos is an unreal Professor.  He loves Astronomy and knows so much about all of it.  Best of all is that he really cares about his students, he learns everyone's names and makes otherwise boring stuff exciting and interesting.
Go to all the Star Parties you can, go to office hours (especially with Tim Morton) for help on the homeworks. Do your observing early!
Go to lectures and star parties. Also, make sure you get your observing done before the weather gets too cold.
Good STN to PDF and if you book in reasonable amount of work you can get an A. A lot of people take for PDF so curve works to your advantage if you work hard
I would advise that they read the chapters that correlate to lecture and definitely go to office hours for any confusing concepts.
I would recommend previous experience in physics before taking this course.
If you want a distribution course, then take this!
If you're interested in actually learning something about astrophysics and being challenged for a PDF STN then take it but there are definitely easier classes to PDF.
Its a great SNL option
More math than I wanted, would have been better off in 201.
Not a great STN, even if you plan to PDF.

Only a minor level of physics is needed, but a general idea of how science works and how the universe works would help greatly with understanding the information in this course. Don't be scared by the sudden appearance of scary math and Greek letters! It's not as hard as it sometimes seems. Prof. Bakos is absolutely amazing, and always super excited about astronomy.
Requires some time, but it is worth it.
Super interesting material, with a very passionate professor (Gaspar Bakos). Great insight into the field of modern Astronomy.
TAKE IT
Take it

Take it for an STN or just out of interest!  Prof. Bakos is one of the most wonderful professors here, and he's got a great Hungarian accent.  And star parties are a blast.  He also gives out coffeebeans at the beginning of class.  So that's nice.
Take it if you are interested in astronomy, but not as straightforward for the social science mind as you might think.
Take it with Bakos - his passion makes the course really great. Go to all the star parties and enjoy the astronomy!
Take it.
Take this class.  Professor Bakos is amazing.  This is a must-take.
Take this course
Take this course if you like space and are comfortable with lower level physics.
Take this course! It'll make you look up at the night sky like you never have before.

Take this course, and Prof Bakos will be your new favourite human being. The readings in the textbook are helpful, but not necessary in order to understand the lectures (so you could conceivably do all the reading over winter break, if you so chose). Go to lecture - they're interesting and fast-paced enough that you'll miss a lot if you don't go! And choose your study group wisely - your observations and group journal activity count for much of your final grade.
Take this course. Problem sets are difficult and a few weekend evenings must be given for star gazing, but absolutely worth it.
Take this. One of the best courses I have taken in four years here and Bakos is simply amazing.

The course is fun if you have any interest in stars, planets, and why they behave the way they do, and is not too heavy on work. If you don't find it interesting, you will find the work pointless. Professor Bakos is funny and engaging and only occasionally goes on planned tangents. Otherwise he is a good lecturer and pretty easy to understand. If you have an intro to physics knowledge, the course should be quite easy, but if not, prepare to spend a good amount of time learning the physics to help you understand the math.

The course was particularly interesting when we got to use the telescopes and observe, but otherwise could get boring at times for someone who's not a science major - it got very technical at some points.

This is a fantastic course. I took it just to fulfill the STN requirement but absolutely fell in love with it. Professor Bakos truly loves the subject and is solely motivated by the desire to make you love it as much as he does. Lectures are long (because there is a lot of material and lots of foundation that needs to be laid before getting to exoplanets) but I learned a lot. Definitely one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton.
This is a good class if you are already really interested in the topic but if you know a bunch of stuff already I would stay away from it.

This was definitely the most fun I've had in a class at Princeton so far. Professor Bakos has so much genuine enthusiasm for this subject, and it shines through every lecture, which is never boring. The star parties and observations are great as well.

Try to take it with a friend if you can, it will make the observing portion of the class more fun and less of a hassle.  And go to lecture, the majority of exam material is covered in lecture and Prof Bakos is really great.
prereqs: This course is intended for non-science majors; however, familiarity with high school algebra and geometry will be assumed. An introductory high school physics course will also be useful.
descrip: This is an introductory course in astronomy focusing on planets in our Solar System, and around other stars (exoplanets). First we review the formation, evolution and properties of the Solar system. Following an introduction to stars, we then discuss the exciting new field of exoplanets; discovery methods, earth-like planets, and extraterrestrial life. Core values of the course are quantitative analysis and hands-on experience, including telescopic observations. This STN course is designed for the non-science major and has no prerequisites past high school algebra and geometry. See www.astro.princeton.edu/planets for important changes.

title: Physics of Gases
descrip: Physical and chemical topics of basic importance in modern fluid mechanics, plasma dynamics, and combustion science: statistical calculations of thermodynamic properties of gases; physical equilibria; quantum mechanical analysis of atomic and molecular structure including rotational and vibrational transitions; atomic-scale collision phenomena and excitation and ionization; emission, absorption, and propagation of radiation. Analyses of major greenhouse gases from point of view of molecular absorption and emission properties; discussion of effect of greenhouse gases concentration and disribution on climate equilibria.

title: Topics in Middle East History - Modern Syria
reviews: For those with limited knowledge on Syria and historiography, I would read primers on both before taking the course.
Heavy reading load; strong background in the historiography of the region would be useful before taking, but not essential.  Overall: good course.
I would strongly advise them to take it, read carefully the course material to be well prepared for the stimulating discussions in class.

I would urge anyone interested in the Middle East to take this course. However, I would advise that the readings and the written assignments are highly demanding (but certainly rewarding) compared to other courses at Princeton.
It's great way to learn about Syria but it is a lot of work.
It's manageable even if you're an undergrad.  Don't get intimidated by the reading load--I really think it's doable.

Students should expect a significant emphasis upon historiographical aspects of modern Syria, as opposed to the history itself.  It might be more accurate to title the course Historiography of Modern Syria.
Take this course! Students came from several disciplines to this course, and everyone came away from the course with a new understanding of modern Syria.
The reading load is intense, but it is well worth it!
prereqs: Juniors and seniors are permitted to enroll with the permission of the instructor only if they have prerequisite coursework in modern Middle East history..
descrip: This graduate seminar examines key historiographical, conceptual and methodological issues in modern Syrian history. Based on student interest, themes and materials covered may vary.

title: Seminar in Plasma Physics
reviews: Actively listen and try to ask questions. This is a very good setting to ask basic questions that you might not want to burden a speaker with at a higher level seminar.
Show up and enjoy the lectures!
This class is worth taking.
Try to attend each seminar, if possible.
Use this course to help gauge your interest in various 2nd-year and thesis projects.
descrip: Advances in experimental and theoretical studies or laboratory and naturally-occurring high-termperature plasmas, including stability and transport, nonlinear dynamics and turbulence, magnetic reconnection, selfheating of "burning" plasmas, and innovative concepts for advanced fusion systems. Advances in plasma applications, including laser-plasma interactions, nonneutral plasmas, high-intensity accelerators, plasma propulsion, plasma processing, and coherent electromagnetic wave generation.

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: Full-time research internship at a host institution, to perform scholarly research relevant to student's dissertation work. Research objectives will be determined by advisor in conjunction with outside host. A mid-semester progress review and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students for up to two semesters. Special rules apply to international students regarding CPT/OPT use. Students may register by application only.

title: The Sociology of Law
reviews: Definitely take this course if you're interested in how written law and the social world interact! Don't be intimidated by the socratic method part of the course.  Get to know Professor Scheppele outside of the seminars-- she is great!
Don't skip lecture, and take notes.
It was great!
Take it! Absolutely take it. Professor Scheppele is amazing, and this is a wonderful way to interact with her.
Take this course if you're considering law school at all

This is a great course for anyone interested in the interactions between law and society. Professor Scheppele is one of the most well-known and knowledgeable legal professors we have, and she's also extremely nice and approachable. Definitely take the chance to take a small class with her like this if you can.

This is one of those course that makes it impossible to see the world in the same way. While that might sound dramatic, I only mean to suggest that the legal lens through which this course will teach you to critically consider the workings of the social world will be tough to take off when you walk out of the final lecture! It will influence your conversations (and your own academic interests) in an astonishingly interdisciplinary fashion. As for the instructor, I know of no other professor who cares more about her students. Her lectures (both presentation and powerpoints) are extremely engaging and very well organized. It's the kind of course that you want to run over a few minutes every time.

While the majority of those who take this course are pre-law or sociology majors, I would still highly recommend it to anyone who is looking to develop a better understanding of the law. The course's discussion of comparative and international law could be especially useful to anyone who is studying foreign affairs and/or international relations.
descrip: Sociology has always been engaged in the study of law and, in this course, we will examine law with the tools of sociology. In Segment I, How Society Makes Law, we will explore the ways in which law provides a crucial basis for social organization at the micro-, midlevel, and macro- levels of society. We will also explore the relationship between legal norms and the moral commitments of societies and social elites. In Segment II: How Law Makes Society, the course takes up the legal construction of race, gender and class, and explores the legal basis for the creation of crime, money, citizenship and terrorism.

title: Advanced Computer Graphics
reviews: Assignments take 15-30 hours, with the photon mapper being the longest, and the laplacian meshes assignment the shortest.  Lectures are ok. Funkhouser is really nice.
Definitely a lot of work.  make sure you start assignments early cause they take 2x as long as you think they will.
Definitely take it if you have any interest in computer graphics.
Get started on the photon mapping assignment early.
Great lectures; make sure you ask questions if you are confused! Prof. Funkhouser budgets time to answer questions.
If you are interested in the field of computer graphics, then definitely take it. This course will prepare you knowledge on a broad level of topics in advanced graphics.
If you find yourself interested in graphics at all, take it.
It is a high level course with both the knowledge requirements and distributions. Be prepared to spend a lot of much in dealing with the problem sets but you will gain a lot from them.
It requires some background and interest in Graphics.
descrip: Advanced topics in computer graphics, with focus on learning recent methods in rendering, modeling, and animation. Appropriate for students who have taken COS426 (or equivalent) and who would like further exposure to computer graphics.

title: German Literature in the 18th Century - Weimar Classicism
descrip: Perhaps no moment of poetic and theoretical activity has figured so centrally in the formation of German literary history as Weimar Classicism. It was as much a meeting of the minds as a radical experimentation with forms and genres. Investigating the major contributions Goethe, Schiller and others, this course considers the appropriations of a number of traditions (Greek, Roman, Italian, German folk). Themes of the seminar include the classic and the beautiful as well as their subsequent canonization. Attention is paid to distinctions among modes of communication including treatise, epistle, ballad, elegy, and drama.

title: Macroeconomic Theory I
reviews: Do all the problem sets
Nothing in particular.
descrip: First term of a two-term sequence in macroeconomics. Topics include consumption, saving, and investment; real interest rates and asset prices; long-term economic growth; money and inflation; and econometric methods for macroeconomics.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Bitcoin and cryptocurrency technologies
reviews: Considering the only complaints I had were based on the incompleteness of certain course materials, I would highly recommend the completed undergraduate course to anybody interested in the growing field of cryptocurrency and its applications.
Definitely take it. You learn so much, not just about Bitcoin but about law, policy, economics, etc. Arvind is awesome, and Joe Bonneau was awesome too
Did not attend enough to rate.

If you have any interest in Bitcoin AT ALL, take this course. You will come out of it with almost a complete vertical understanding of Bitcoin at a technical level, but also learn a lot about the Bitcoin ecosystem as a whole.
If you have any interest in Bitcoin or cryptocurrencies, take the course!
Just show up and make sure to pay attention to lectures. Also make sure to start your project plenty early.

Take it! It's an amazing course. It may seem like a specific topic, but you'll learn a ton about so many areas of computer science (and become practically a leading expert on one area of increasing importance).

The course was well taught and provided a good introduction to BItcoin. We talked through a lot of different aspects of Bitcoin, including its impacts on a million different areas. It really helped me understand what Bitcoin was like under the hood.
The first few weeks are interesting when we explored the technical contents of Bitcoin. The remaining ones are boring.

This is an excellent course and Arvind is an incredibly charismatic teacher who brings the best out of his students with insightful questions and counterarguments. He is also willing to learn from his students and recognise the quality of their ideas. Bitcoin itself was a fascinating topic and I am still amazed that it just works, despite its incredible complexity. Even if you don't think Bitcoin will survive, the crypto and game theoretic principles you will learn in this course are well worth it. The programming assignments are fun and not too time-consuming, the papers on Bitcoin you will read are interesting, and the final project offers a great opportunity to get your hands dirty with Bitcoin.
Would 100% take this class.  One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton.  Has very real world applications.
take it only if you are super curious about bitcoin.
descrip: Underlying the widespread public interest in Bitcoin is an intricate balance of technology, market forces, and social norms. Bitcoin serves as an excellent case study for learning many core CS concepts, cryptography, distributed systems, game theory, programming languages, and system security. Topics: first-generation cryptocurrencies, how Bitcoin achieves decentralization, mechanics of Bitcoin, Bitcoin as a currency, mining, anonymity, community and politics, Altcoins, Bitcoin as a platform, the future of Bitcoin. The first half of the course will be 'flipped': students will watch online lectures and class time will be used for discussion.

title: Software Engineering for Scientific Computing
reviews: Assignments and projects are very time consuming, but well worth it if you can make the investment.
Be prepared to code a lot, and do the assignments thoroughly.
Be prepared to learn everything outside of class.
Class is very worthwhile taking.
Don't hesitate to take this course.

Good for learning OpenMP/MPI.  Probably too steep a learning curve if you have no programming experience, particularly in C or a related language, and probably too redundant if you have a very high programming competency.

Great course, please take this if you want to code more efficiently or learn C  /Python/parallel computing. In my opinion, no prior knowledge on these languages necessary as long as you have done some sort of coding before (e.g. matlab, fortran, etc.)

If your work involves any non-negligible amount of programming, take this class as soon as possible.  I wish I had taken it my 1st semester of graduate school, rather than in my 4th year.  But even then or later it is worth taking.

Just get a copy of the lecture notes and learn it yourself.
Take an undergrad computer science course instead if you want to get better at programming. For other topics, it is probably better to learn on your own or find a course that focuses on your specific subtopic of interest.
Start assignments early
Start homework assignments early so that you can ask the questions you have on how things work.
Strongly advice all graduate student to take the course, especially those whose research is on scientific computing. This course helps me to write better codes that are more readable and reusable.
Take it if you want to learn about software engineering
Take this course your very first semester. It takes up a lot of time and will interfere with research too much if you take it later.
The course provides a good overview on various subjects on computation. Great for the students who want to sharpen their computational skills. Very practical.
You should have some familiarity with programming prior to taking this course.

You will learn a lot if you take this course, but that is in spite of the lectures rather than because of them. This class is A LOT OF WORK. Do not take unless you really need to and have a good programming background.
descrip: The goal of this course is to teach basic tools and principles of writing good code, in the context of scientific computing. Specific topics include an overview of relevant compiled and interpreted languages, build tools and source managers, design patterns, design of interfaces, debugging and testing, profiling and improving performance, portability, and an introduction to parallel computing in both shared memory and distributed memory environments. The focus is on writing code that is easy to maintain and share with others. Students will develop these skills through a series of programming assignments and a group project.

title: Applications of Quantum Mechanics to Spectroscopy and Lasers
descrip: An intermediate-level course in applications of quantum mechanics to modern spectroscopy and lasers. The course begins with quite elementary introduction to quantum mechanics as a "tool" for atomic and molecular spectroscopy, followed by a higher level of study of atomic and molecular spectra, radiative, and collisional transitions using intensily QM 'tools". The final chapters are dedicated to plasma and flame spectroscopic and laser diagnostics.

title: Witnessing Disaster
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Colloidal Dispersions I
reviews: A good course for an introduction to the fundamental aspects of colloids.
Definitely take this course. The instructor is extremely good, and the class has very little busy-work.
High-level learning.
Take it!
descrip: Study of static and dynamic properties: hydrodynamics, Brownian motion, electrostatics, dispersion forces, electrokinetics, and electrostatic stabilization.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Gender in the World Economy
descrip: This course focuses on the opportunities, constraints and roles of women in an increasingly interdependent economy. Topics will include: dynamics & causes of fertility changes & household formation; maternal & infant health; gender & labor market institutions--types of contracts, informality, wage gaps & discrimination, unpaid work; intra-household allocation of resources & differential mortality rates; women's migration--selection & outcomes at destination, family reunification, remittances; differential access to education & health; credit market; & political & property rights.

title: Topics in Tonal Analysis - Advanced Tonal Analysis
prereqs: MUS 206 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will deal closely with a small number of works from the tonal and atonal repertoires and will serve as a critical introduction to several pertinent and influential analytical methodologies, including motivic, formal, semiotic, and voice-leading analysis. The focus will be in the musical and aesthetic values that each method either enhances or attenuates.

title: Europe in the 20th Century
reviews: As a senior history major, I thought this was a challenging class but still worth it because of how important the material is. It's pretty impersonal (Prof. Rabinbach still didn't know all of our names at the end of the semester), but if you're up for the challenge and are interested in what's happened in the world in the last century then definitely take it.
Do the readings
I think you should take it.  Pay attention in lecture and do the readings.

Most interesting part of this course was looking at European intellectuals. The course is heavy on the first 50 years of the 20th c, then zooms through until 1989. Rabinbach is not the most engaging lecturer, although lecture notes are important for doing well on the exams.
Take this course! It's great! This is not a "soft-ball" course though so for serious students only.
descrip: The course will explore problems of modernity in European society, culture, and politics from the First World War to the fall of communism in Russia and East Central Europe. Part I will consider: the impact of the Great War, the crisis of liberal ideas and institutions, the ascent of communism and fascism. Part II deals with: post World War II justice and reconstruction, the cultural, and political divisions of the Cold War, and the Central European revolutions of 1989.

title: The Rule of Law
descrip: Considers role of law in gov't: When is a state constrained by law & when it may legitimately change/ignore the law? Use a range of materials from fiction to court cases, legal theory to political history, etc. Proceed by negative example, considering cases from the US: Lincoln's conduct during Civil War, Roosevelt's economic emergency, the Cold War, Nixonian exceptionalism, "war on terror" after 9/11. Also consider comparative examples: Russian Revolution, the collapse of the Weimar constitution, the breaks from communism in the "revolutions" of 1989 & beyond. Also Nuremberg Trials & Kosovar War.

title: History of Criticism
descrip: Natural Philosophy from Antiquity to Modernity. Philosophy is, in many respects, always natural philosophy. This course examines ideas, theories, and philosophies about nature from the ancients to the moderns.

title: Probability Theory
reviews: It's a nice course for someone with interest in the topic who doesn't have a strong background in math, but there may be other probability theory courses which are better (I have heard ORF grad course is very good)

Probably the most thorough intro to probability theory you will get. The class logistics were a bit odd, but the material was fascinating, and the problems and the textbook are excellent. Sinai's lectures are also good, and the class is a good intro to probability theory, as well as many advanced topics and methods in analysis.
Read the book
To do the homework, it would probably help to have taken some discrete math/combinatorics and analysis courses. You might be able to do it without these, but you should consider taking the class PDF.
prepare for the final, it's an oral exam.
prereqs: MAT203 or 218 or equivalent..
descrip: Sequence of independent trials, applications to number theory and analysis, Monte Carlo method. Markov chains, ergodic theorem for Markov chains. Entropy and McMillan theorem. Random walks, recurrence and non-recurrence; connection with the linear difference equations. Strong laws of large numbers, random series and products. Weak convergence of probability measures, weak Helly theorems, Fourier transforms of distributions. Limit theorems of probability theory.

title: Advanced Topics in Combustion I - Turbulent Combustion
reviews: Although either turbulence or combustion sounds horrifying, this course is really a introductory course.  If you did not get stuck on plotting figures, the problem sets are quite easy and straightforward, so do not worry about workload.  The instructor is very dedicated and helpful.  As for lectures, big pictures are always clear, while modelling details are a bit difficult to follow.   We had a few undergrads taking the course, and it should not be a problem for them.
Interesting class focused on cutting edge techniques in turbulent combustion modeling. Would recommend to any student in combustion.
Prof. Mueller is an excellent lecturer.  However, you would be wise to have taken the prerequisites beforehand; otherwise, it will be very difficult

Prof. Mueller's style makes this course a "must-have" for anyone who is interested in doing combustion simulations. This unique structure of the course makes it a very essential class to take for combustion research.
Start homework assignments early
Take plenty of notes during lecture; read through the chapters of texts that are cited in each lecture, and spend time thinking through the nuances of the problems on the assignments.
The class gives a quality overview of the different interactions between turbulence and combustion, which I think is a necessary piece of understanding for any graduate combustion student to have.
prereqs: MAE 531 and MAE 553 are encouraged but not absolutely required..
descrip: Detailed treatment of the physics and subsequent modeling of turbulent combustion. Turbulent premixed, nonpremixed, and partially premixed combustion will all be discussed. Emphasis in the course will be placed on understanding relevant physical and chemical phenomena that lead to various modeling approaches (derived from both experiment and computation), the implicit and explicit assumptions in the various modeling approaches, and the relative strengths and weaknesses of the various modeling approaches.

title: Financial Risk Management
reviews: If  you are like me, coming from a different department and not well conversed with financial knowledge, but want to learn more about the subject, this is the best introductory course! You will for sure learn a lot from it.

If you have general interest in risk management, take this course. Professor Mulvey is a great instructor. Don't worry if you don't have a strong background in the field, if you are dedicated, the course will be really easy to grasp and enjoyable.

The assignments and examinations are very well taught and enjoyable to do. Max was a great TA to help anytime needed, but this was his last year.

If you interested in learning about finance, then definitely take this course. Professor Mulvey covers a variety of topics that are very interesting and I would strong recommend this course to anyone.
Is a good course with a lot of applications, take it.
It's a great course for risk management concepts and understand how to use optimization in asset management.
Not to take it with this Professor unless you want to learn about financial planning and ALM. I was very disappointed.
Recommend
Will recommend this course
Would not recommend. Very time-consuming at the end of the semester and not very useful.
start projects early.
descrip: This course covers the basic concepts of modeling, measuring and managing financial risks. Topics include portfolio optimization (mean variance approach and expected utility), interest rate risk, pricing and hedging in incomplete markets, indifference pricing, risk measures, systemic risk.

title: Introduction to the Professional Study of the Near East
descrip: A departmental colloquium normally taken by all entering graduate students. It is designed to introduce students to reference and research tools, major trends in the scholarship of the field, and the faculty of the department.

title: General Computer Science
reviews: 10/10 Would Recommend

A lot of people have trouble with COS assignments, but a lot of people find them very easy right from the start. I would highly recommend trying out a "learn to code" website (like CodeAcademy) for about 10 minutes to find out which type of person you are before committing to a whole semester of computer science.

Absolutely take this course! But beware, it's on you to take advantage of all the resources available! Go to your preceptor, use piazza, go to lab TA's- you have an army of people willing and able to help! One of the most organized courses at Princeton

Actually do the readings and use all the resources available to you! There are plenty of people willing to help you.  Be prepared to commit yourself to actually learning the subject matter and the programming assignments because they can be time intensive and confusing at times.  Overall, definitely take the class coding it a very good skill to have!

Always do the readings, always go to lecture and precept, and always ask questions. Also, play around with the programming assignments, because that is really when I felt like I was learning the most.
Always go and get help when you can.
Amazing. Best course this semester! Take it!
An absolute must. Very well taught and well run. Your time won't be wasted and you'll learn a ton.
Assignments can take a while, don't wait until Monday night.
Awesome course. TAKE IT!!! No matter what your major is. Get Doug Clark as a preceptor in the fall...go to office hours
Be patient!
Be sure to attend office hours and help sessions.  Lab TAs are also great.
Be sure to do the textbook reading and study with classmates to fully understand the material.
Be sure to watch for smaller style things in homework assignments.
Be sure you follow the assignment instructions to the letter, and work fast on the exams.
Be warned, this course is a lot of work. But you'll learn a lot if you invest in it, and if you're interested in COS take it.

COS 126 is a class that I think everyone should take because of its relevance to modern day society, regardless of what you're planning on majoring in. While there is definitely room for improvement for the course, it is overall a good introduction to programming in Java, and it provides an overview of the major theoretical concepts in computer science.

COS126 is a great class that everyone should take at some point in their four years here. It's a very solid (and very hands-on) introduction to the way computers and computer programming work. Even if you don't want to be a programmer or a scientist yourself, you will come away with a new appreciation for computers and the people who design their hardware and software. It's not terribly difficult  to get a decent grade so long as you work steadily on the assignments and participate actively in precept.

Classic course that most people take.
Useful skill to have and you learn a lot.
Consider taking the newbie precepts being offered starting next semester. I wish I had this option, as I fell behind almost immediately and had trouble catching up throughout the semester.
Def a good class to take, you learn a lot

Definitely consider taking it. Consider PDFing if you don't need it. I think it's one of those things whose difficulty is overblown because many of the students are first semester freshmen who probably would complain about any class you gave them. Aka not wanting to work is no reason not to do it, if you've taken a 200 level math or Econ, you have already done more work for another class.
Definitely give this course a try unless you know that you hate computer science.
Definitely go to the last few lectures about theory, take advantage of office hours/lab TAs, and give yourself a lot of time to complete the assignments!

This class and its assignments will take up a lot of your time if you are not experienced in it, because debugging code and even understanding a given assignment takes a lot of effort and time.
Definitely take it even if you're not going to major in computer science. You learn good, useful skills.
