Everyone should take some kind of COS class here, and this is great for beginners!

GET DAN LEYZBERG FOR YOUR PRECEPTOR. Other preceptors are great, but Dan literally has a 5 minute response time on average and never fails to give me thorough responses to my gazillion questions. IF YOU DON'T HAVE ANY COMPUTER SCIENCE EXPERIENCE:
I would recommend against taking this course. Though I learned a great deal, COS 126 was a huge time-suck for me, and didn't allow me to focus on my other courses. If you have no experience, this class isn't made for you. It moves at an extremely fast pace, and everything is cumulative, so if you don't understand one topic, you are hurting yourself for the remainder of the semester. 
In my experience, I have found that newbies either hate it or love it. If you are willing to take that 50-50 chance, then do so at your own risk. 

IF YOU HAVE SOME COMPUTER PROGRAMMING EXPERIENCE: 
Sure, go for it. It is very well taught, the assignments are decent, and though you will have to put some work into it (10hrs/week at the very least), you'll probably get by.

If you already have a basic understanding of java programming, consider skipping to COS 226. If you're a complete beginner, be prepared to put a lot of time into this. Also, if there's a bug you can't figure out just go to office hours or the lab TAs! There's some things that even they get confused about so don't be worried about it being a stupid question.

If you are interested in computer science and have strong background, I would say it's in your best interest to skip this course. Else, take this course. I personally had coding experience, but knew nothing of the theory in computer science, which I found to be quite intriguing. So, at least give computer science a shot and, more likely than not, you will stick with it for quite a while to come.
If you are new, be sure to attend lecture. If you  know your stuff already, lecture is pointless.

This is a wonderful course. I had absolutely no experience with computer science prior to taking it, and now I am considering majoring in it. This is probably the most organized class at Princeton. There is so much help and practice material available. descrip: An introduction to computer science in the context of scientific, engineering, and commercial applications. The goal of the course is to teach basic principles and practical issues, while at the same time preparing students to use computers effectively for applications in computer science, physics, biology, chemistry, engineering, and other disciplines. Topics include: hardware and software systems; programming in Java; algorithms and data structures; fundamental principles of computation; and scientific computing, including simulation, optimization, and data analysis.

title: Algorithms and Data Structures
reviews: .You should totally take this course if you've taken COS 126 and found it engaging. Stay on top of the material and make sure you'll be able to trace all algorithms with pen and paper.

A really great course.  Even though I was taking it as a computer-science outsider--not as a departmental or distribution requirement--I found the material to be really well-taught, the work interesting and pleasantly challenging, and the skills I learned applicable to my own Chemistry research.  I would recommend this to anyone who liked COS 126!

An excellent introduction to the more theoretical side of computer science which will get you thinking algorithmically, rather than simply about how to code something up. The workload is fairly chill (at least compare to 217), and the assignments are all interesting. Kevin Wayne is an excellent lecturer and explains concepts very intuitively.

COS 226 is an awesome continuation of 126. If you had fun in 126 and are looking for a challenge, this class is for you. The midterm and final are a bit tricky but the way the grading is, you shouldn't let it get you down. Kevin Wayne is a good instructor who really knows his stuff and tries to make the material very clear. Lectures can be boring and you can learn them on your own but I would still suggest going because of interview questions and it's generally helpful to hear it explained from an expert. Jeremie Lumbroso is a great preceptor. He's funny and a bit awkward (european though, so you never know if it's just a culture thing) but he really gets to know everyone in the class and teaches very well. As always, lab TAs and Piazza is super helpful so put in the effort and you'll really enjoy the class.

Coding assignments are the bread and butter of this course. They can be very challenging, but finishing one is extremely rewarding. It is essential that you find a COS partner that has a compatible schedule so that you can start early on assignments. Most people who got frustrated with assignments were trying to start them 24 hours before they're due. Lectures are very helpful, and precepts help too. Read if you don't understand a concept. If you breathe COS, you might not need to read. Don't underestimate the annoying & helpful Blackboard exercises. They often take more than an hour to get a typo-free full-credit score. Exams are very challenging. They reflect the computer science part of the course that you might not learn through the coding.
Definitely go to lectures and review every once in a while.
Definitely take it!
Do flipped lecture.

People say that every student at Princeton should take COS126, but I disagree; I think every student should take both 126 and 226. This class is just as fascinating as 126, and it really allows students from all backgrounds to understand the algorithms and data structures that are vital to store the nearly-infinite data in today's day and age. Topics such as recursion, divide-and-conquer, and logarithms can be applied to any career and possibly any aspect of life. Plus, the programming assignments are fun and interesting. I would not only recommend this course for COS students, but for ALL students.

Starting assignments early is necessary in order to perform well, as they do take longer than COS 126 assignments did.
Stay on top of your work and always manually work out the algorithms!!

Stay on top of your work and go to lectures. It's possible to do well on assignments and exercises without actually learning anything, but you should try to understand the concepts anyway because when the exam comes around, you're screwed.

Stick with one partner and complete the assignments early. Easy enough to get 100% with a little bit of forethought. Lectures are useful only for completing the exercises. Kevin Wayne's voice might be funny, but he is an excellent lecturer.
Study the past exams to do well on your current one.
Take flipped lecture if it offered!
Take it if any interest in COS.
Take it!

Take it! It's very well-organized. Nevertheless, here is a lot of material crammed into one course and I think some self-study is necessary to grasp all that is going on. Programming assignments are in general fun-to-do and having a partner (who is close to your level) makes things less stressful, though it won't help you learn all the algorithms & data structures taught in this course.
Take it! You'll learn a lot...but beware of the time consuming coding assignments. Definitely enjoyed this more than COS 126.
Take this course if you are willing to put in the time for programming assignments.

Take this course if you're at all interested in computer science. The assignments are usually interesting and not overly difficult (usually took 6ish hours), although there are some tricky parts so try to get started at least a few days early. Go to lecture!
There's little reason not to take this.
This class is worth taking if you want the cos certificate, or want a general overview of algorithms for interviewing purposes.
This course covers a lot and it might be a bit difficult to keep up at times
This course is challenging but very manageable. Take it if your at all interested in CS.

This course is great for thinking about how to tackle larger problems in computer science and essential for anyone who wants to actually use programming to solve problems in research or business. The assignments are fun, though they can be long, and the lectures are typical of the Princeton computer science department: step-by-step, basic, but interesting and well-made.
This course will make you a better thinker as a programmer.
This course will teach you EVERYTHING you need to know for software interviews. Take it seriously, and you can get a job anywhere you want! Also shows you what awesome things computers can really do.
To learn more, it is better to do the homework independently, though it is group work.
Very useful and interesting material to learn
Very well organized, but I wish they'd make lecture videos available to everyone instead of just the flipped lecture class.
Wayne is an excellent lecturer for an excellent course. Weekly assignments can take a while to write and debug, but are an interesting challenge.

When going to office hours, make sure they are still happening and whether they are in the location set at the beginning of the year. As an athlete, I could only make specific office hours and I was annoyed to find that they were either cancelled or had been moved.

Whether you are going into the tech industry, finance, or consulting, COS 226 is a must-take course. It covers the most important algorithms of today and does a great job connecting the course material to real-world applications. What you learn is directly applicable to any technical interview. The assignments are great and not too time consuming. The precepts were not too helpful but overall, it's a good course.
Yes, but be prepared to work hard.
You should probably keep up with lectures - makes midterms and finals a lot less stressful
can watch lectures online if eqaud is too far to go to
take it, its a great course that teaches you a lot about algorithms. also very necessary if you want to pursue tech careers because it analyzes the theory behind many things
take this class!!! for the assignments make sure to find a partner, because it will make it much easier to complete the assignments
think carefully about how serious about computer science you are before taking this.
prereqs: COS 126 (recommended) or placement by COS Placement Officer..
descrip: This course surveys the most important algorithms and data structures in use on computers today. Particular emphasis is given to algorithms for sorting, searching, and string processing. Fundamental algorithms in a number of other areas are covered as well, including geometric algorithms, graph algorithms, and some numerical algorithms. The course will concentrate on developing implementations, understanding their performance characteristics, and estimating their potential effectiveness in applications.

title: Mathematics for Political Science
descrip: Basic mathematical concepts essential for formal and quantitative analysis in political science research. Course prepares students for advanced courses offered in the Department, e.g., POL 573-576. Topics will include calculus, linear algebra, and probability theory. Some applications to political science will be introduced. The course is aimed for both students with little exposure to mathematics and those who have taken some but wish to gain a more solid foundation. No prerequisite.

title: Slavic Dissertation Colloquium
descrip: A practical course intended to facilitate the dissertation writing process. The seminar meets on average once every two weeks depending on the need and pace of the participants. Dissertation writers circulate work in progress for feedback and meet for discussion as a group. The seminar is required of all post-generals students in Russian literature who are in residence.

title: Problems in Greek and Roman Philosophy - Isocrates, Against the Sophists
descrip: Eminent educator and rhetorician, influential political thinker, and arch-enemy of Plato, Isocrates was a towering intellectual figure of 4th century Greece. After a brief introduction to the political situation and cultural developments after the Peloponnesian War, this seminar focuses on a close reading of two or three of Isocrates' major philosophical speeches, Oration 13 Against the Sophists, Oration 10, Encomium of Helen, and Oration 11, Busiris.

title: Fundamentals of Statistics
reviews: A much better intro to statistics than its Econs stats. The flipside is that it requires more effort... and coding.

Although the course wasn't organized as well as it could have been, I think that the statistics we learned is a very important topic to know. If you don't know MATLAB, pay attention to the examples he gives and ask someone he knows to help explain it to you. Work on PSETs with a group and don't be worried if they seem very difficult (the PSETs were harder than the exams).
An interesting introduction to probability and statistics. It is rather thorough and provides a good background knowledge. However, it does assume a fairly high level of mathematical understanding.
Course changes depending on who teaches it.
DO NOT TAKE.
DON'T TAKE IT. RECONSIDER YOUR LIFE CHOICES. DON'T BECOME AN ORF MAJOR. DON'T TAKE AN ORF CLASS. DON'T TAKE A CLASS TAUGHT BY VANDERBEI. JUST DON'T

Definitely go to office hours, don't stress too much about the problem sets starting off pretty hard.  Don't bother with the reading unless there's a topic you really do not understand.  Most of the course is explained pretty well in lecture and slides.

Do not go to lecture unless it is a review session. You are better off using the time you would use to go to lecture to instead learn concepts independently.

Do not take this course unless you have to.
Do not take this course.  Such a waste of time
Do your homework well, it counts for a lot.
Don't take it if Dr. Vanderbei is teaching it, unless you are already really well versed and mathematics. He makes the course entirely too difficult for everyone else.
Don't take this class unless you really know your stuff or if you have to.  I learned a lot, not just about statistics, but also about myself and what the phrase "bite the bullet" really means.
Don't take this course. If you have to, get a tutor.
Dont do it unless you have to. Especially not Vanderbei
Easy tests, but not worth it.

Everyone loved to complain in this course but in general it was fair. Lectures weren't particularly thrilling but print out the slides (which have all of the notes on them) and go. You'll be glad you did when you start your pset.
Find a good study group to do problem sets with and make a good cheat-sheet for the midterms and final
Go to all lectures and office hours!
Go to the precepts.
Have confidence, and give it your all. The course is not as easy as people might say, but is very rewarding.
I don't think this is representative of the ORFE department, so on't take it for that reason. If you like statistics, take it. If not, and hoping for an easy statistics course, look elsewhere.
I think Prof. Vanderbei just wants to show off his ability to do calculus. The textbook is also more difficult than necessary.
I think you can get a lot out of this course. The exams weren't as intimidating as the psets.

I would definitely take the course, but would focus on reading and understanding the textbook more than anything. Also, office hours don't help that much because everyone decides to show up. I would email Dr. Vanderbei or use Piazza to answer questions.
I would not take it unless it is a necessary requirement or the student has experience in coding and advanced calculus.
I wouldn't take it unless you have to.
If Vanderbei is teaching this class, DO NOT TAKE IT. Otherwise it's not so bad from what I hear. And for that matter, don't take any class with Vanderbei.
If this is how it will be taught, I'd rather suggest not taking it
If you have to take this course, fine. Try to get a professor other than Vanderbie
If you like a theoretical, math based approach to stats, take this class.
If you need it, you should take it, but it can be challenging if you hadn't taken stats before.
If you're interested in a general ORF introduction, take it. Be prepared to do your work -- you'll have to learn some things on your own, but it's a cool class.
In the likely event you have to take this class, wait until someone other than vanderbei is teaching it or you will have a terrible semester no matter how smart/capable you are
It's great with Professor Vanderbei!
Just do the problem sets, read the textbooks once in a while, and make sure that you go to the precepts.
Know what textbook and content is being taught and then decide whether to take it or not
Lectures are optional. Precepts are not. Find a great team to do p-sets with.
Make sure the professor has good reviews. I don't think the same professor will be teaching it next semester, so my opinion might have been totally different if I took it with a different person.
Not terribly difficult, but also not the most interesting
Only take if it is a requirement.
Overall good introduction class.

Please do not take it unless you absolutely have to. This is no longer the easy course it supposedly use to be. It's very poorly taught, the problem sets are a pain, and by the end of the semester, you'll realize that you've actually learned nothing.
Prepare for a lot of work and dull lectures if Vanderbei is teaching.
Probably don't take it if Vanderbei teaches it again.

Professor Vanderbei seemed to have handled this course completely differently from all other professors, and while the class with him was great, I have heard a lot of negative things about previous versions of this class. So it depends.
Read the textbook

Stats should be not necessarily fun, but I think that it should at least be interesting. It is a required course for some people, but honestly this course stank. Until this class can figure out what its goal is, I would strongly recommend against taking it.
Study and read.
Take advantage of office hours and precepts. Be prepared to spend a lot of time on homework and teach Matlab to yourself.
Take it if you must.
Take it if you want to learn, but don't expect a cakewalk
Take it not out of general interest but if you wish to pursue courses on this path.
Take it only if you need to. It's really helpful to have taken AP Stats before.
Take this course
Take time to do the problem sets.

The homework problems from the book were significantly harder than those on the actual midterm (they were more theoretical where as the midterm questions were more application based). Homework is graded generously (and worth 45% of your grade!)
This class is not easy, only take if you really want to or must.

This course covers some good material but could have been implemented better. Professor Vanderbei's lectures are not very helpful - in many instances he simply evaluated integrals on the blackboard while the derivation was right there on the lecture slide. The textbook was also too advanced for the course, and having to pick out what we needed to know was a hassle. Precepts could have been better too - they were just too big and not taught too well, since we mostly just did problems. However, the material covered in the course is still good to know, and as long as you do the problem sets (and know what you're doing) you should be fine on the exams - the material isn't hard. I would still recommend it over the less rigorous alternatives for statistics, but just be prepared. Also, if Vanderbei is teaching it, you would benefit by learning the basics of MATLAB for the problem sets before the semester starts.
This course is bad, but I'm not sure you have many other options. Hopefully, it will get better next semester with a new textbook, new professor, new TAs
This course is practically never good, but if you need to take it, you'll take it.

This is a reasonable class, but I'd expect you won't really enjoy it. It taught me some statistics without making me want to murder myself, but that's a far cry from saying it's a great class that defined my Princeton experience. But, if the professor changes again everything might get better.
This is not a difficult course. Do not fall behind  and you'll be fine.
Though the curve is generous and the professor is nice, be prepared to be faced with very high level and difficult readings and homeworks

Unfortunately if you want to take a stats class, it is rare that you will get a good prof. Have some background before coming in and make sure to go to office hours and push the instructors to hold review sessions/whatever would help you.
Unless you required to take this course, I don't see why anyone would want to take it. It's not interesting or entertaining in any way
Vanderbei is a boring lecturer, the textbook is very bad, and the course is very theoretical. I hope they change the professor and textbook for next year. Try to avoid taking it with Vanderbei.
Would not recommend it.
You can study this course on your own.
You will have a class more similar to AP Stats whereas this was more along the lines of ORF309.

You won't learn much from lectures and especially not precepts. Be prepared to self-study. Grading is still easy though because homework is most of the grade and exams are usually easier than homework.
n/a
p-sets and exams are definitely doable, but not the MATLAB part of the p-set. Make sure you know what you're doing with that beforehand and go to professor Vanderbei's office hours if you need help
start homeworks early, keep up with lectures, go to precept
vanderbei is a great guy. but he sucks at teaching.
prereqs: Three semesters of Calculus or its equivalent.
descrip: A first introduction to probability and statistics. This course will provide background to understand and produce rigorous statistical analysis including estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing and regression. Applicability and limitations of these methods will be illustrated in the light of modern data sets and manipulation of the statistical software R. Precepts are based on real data analysis.

title: Contradictions of Freedom in American Capitalism
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Major Author(s) - Samuel Beckett
reviews: Be charitable with the readings and you'll gain a lot from this course.

Take whatever class Fintan is offering. He's incredibly smart and generous. The Beckett class was particularly great but even if you aren't familiar with the topic he's teaching about next, it's still really worth it to take the class. He's so passionate about it that he'll make you love it too.
descrip: Samuel Beckett is arguably the most influential writer of the second half of the 20th century. He reinvented theatre with Waiting for Godot and wrote startlingly original fiction. Today few works in either form do not bear some trace of his imprint. Beckett, however, is often misunderstood as purveyor of bleak nihilism with a relentlessly pessimistic view of the human condition. In this course, we will explore a very different Beckett: a writer of compassion, invention and harsh beauty, responding to his Irish roots and to terrible public events with humor, playfulness and courage.

title: Viruses: Strategy and Tactics
descrip: Viruses are unique parasites of living cells and may be the most abundant, highest evolved life forms on the planet. The general strategies encoded by all known viral genomes are discussed using selected viruses as examples. The first half of the course covers the molecular biology (the tactics) inherent in these strategies. The second half introduces the biology of engagement of viruses with host defenses, what happens when viral infection leads to disease, vaccines and antiviral drugs, and the evolution of infectious agents and emergence of new viruses.

title: Great Books of the Jewish Tradition
reviews: Ask as many questions as possible about the readings before you get entirely lost and can't tell any of them apart anymore.

Great survey course.  Make sure you thoroughly go over the readings (doesn't take too long anyway) before class so you can participate in the discussion.  Pay attention in class, and the papers will be straightforward, and you'll be set.
Interesting course!

It is a great course to take if you want to learn more about books like the Talmud, the Mishnah, and the Zohar and haven't had extensive experience with them before. If you are an observant Jew you should also be aware that the class is taught from the perspective that the Torah was written several  hundred years after the events which it describes and was written by people rather than given to Moses on Mount Sinai.
Make sure you have an interest in Jewish traditions, because it is very rigorous for a course.
This class is more of a literary analysis class than a history or religion class, but it does teach alot more than ancient criticism and analysis of texts.

This is a really good class. It can be tough if you come from no background in Jewish history or thought, but is full of valuable knowledge and thought provoking 'Talmudic' discussions. It's a very invigorating class, though the assignments can be challenging and the readings a bit obscure.
descrip: This course is intended to introduce students to the classical Jewish tradition through a close reading of portions of some of its great books, including Bible, the rabbinic midrash, the Talmud, Rashi's commentary on the Torah, Mishneh Torah, the Zohar, and the Haggadah. We will pay particular attention to the role of interpretation in forming Jewish tradition.

title: Digital Photography
reviews: Great course overall
I would take this course if you have any interest in digital photography. It is a great way to learn more about photography as well as printing.
It's what you make of it.
Learned a lot. Had a lot of fun and was a great class overall! Just make sure you don't leave printing to the end.
Take it. It's fun, sometimes a lot of lab hours, but with Lawson there aren't many assignments

The course is good to get a foundation in digital photography, photoshop and digital printing. Artistically Ms. Lawson looks for work along her own interests and it can be challenging to defend work with a different purpose or focus.

take this class if you're interested in photography, but haven't had a very technical background in it. By the end of the class, you will be not only quite competent in Photoshop but also in composing images. It is very low stress, so it works great to satisfy a distribution requirement.
descrip: This studio course introduces students to aesthetic and theoretical implications of digital photography. Studio emphasis is on mastering digital equipment and techniques, managing print quality, and generally becoming familiar with all aspects of the digital workspace. Popular media, found photographs, and the "life" of digital images will also be investigated. Slide lectures, readings and class discussions of student work in critique format will augment visual skills with critical and conceptual understandings of contemporary photography.

title: Subcultures
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Criticism and Theory - Mimesis
prereqs: Students may not take a grade of incomplete (INC) in this course..
descrip: Mimesis, from its ancient to contemporary definitions, names a relation to the world that is also a formation of the self. This course emphasizes materialist and psychoanalytic understandings of mimesis, considering its imbrication in other spheres such as political economy, aesthetics, desire, mimicry, technological reproducibility, imperialism, racial politics, and play. Readings include Plato, Aristotle, Marx, Freud, Adorno, Benjamin, Auerbach, Chow, Spivak, and Taussig.

title: Ends and Means: Issues in Composition
descrip: The topic is composing for percussion which will involve the study of percussion literature, in particular, percussion quartet literature from the 20th and 21st century as well as the creation of new work by seminar participants. The So Percussion Quartet will visit the seminar several times throughout the term to perform and discuss relevant music and works in progress by seminar participants.

title: Life in the Universe
reviews: Don't take it.
I would work on problem sets ahead of time, and always attend the optional precept.
If you are interested, the lectures are amazing and the professors are all seasoned experts.
If you like science at all you will like this course. There are so many disciplines covered that everyone will known some and everyone will learn some. This was my favorite course at Princeton.

If you're interested in life on other planets and the origin of life and you have a solid background in 100 level physics, biology, and/or chemistry, this course will be interesting and not too hard for you.

There were times when I felt that I did not know enough to take advantage of the course. I'd recommend a pretty strong background in general sciences. That said, it is a class that you can make the most of with effort and interest.
prereqs: At least one course (but two are recommended) in Astrophysics, Biology, Chemistry, Physics or Geology is required. In the case of freshmen, an advanced placement score of 4 or 5 in Chemistry, Biology or Physics is required..
descrip: This course introduces students to a new field, Astrobiology, where scientists trained in biology, chemistry, astronomy and geology combine their skills to discover life's origins and to seek extraterrestrial life. Topics include: the origin of life on Earth; the prospects of life beneath the surfaces of Mars and Europa, a moon of Jupiter; and extra-solar planets nearby that offer targets for NASA space telescopes searching for life. 255A is the core course for the Planets and Life certificate.

title: Intermediate/Advanced Spanish
reviews: Come to class prepared.
Enjoy the class and participate as much as possible.
Fun if you need to take it. You need a good attitude, and be willing to learn and speak Spanish.

Good luck, and may the odds be ever in your favor. It seems like it's difficult to get both a quality teacher and a quality class for intro spanish. Switch around sections if you can to get different classes' vibes, and get recommendations from upperclassmen for the best professors.
If your take this course, try to get Paloma or some other good instructor. In classes like these, the professor is a key component.
In order to understand the information you really have to buy into and do all of the exercises. And don't be afraid to ask questions after class!
It is a fun class, but it can be a lot of work. However, it's much better than 101/102.
It's better than 101/102!

Just your average language class. This one really helped me improve my writing/reading skills and my vocab to an extent. If you take this class try to get Lorena! She's the best and she's super invested in how well everyone does in the class.
Lorena is amazing.
Make sure you do the book activities.
Miguel is awesome, the course is generally uninteresting but not terrible.
Stay on top of the homework.
Students should continue to practice Spanish outside of class to further their skills.
Take as a requirement. Try to get Jorge Quintana
Take it and get it over with. You'll get through it. It's not the best thing, but it's not the worst.
Take it if you want to continue building your skills, but it does require independent studying and a strong grasp of grammar and really strong written skills.
Take it with Francisco, and don't take it at 9am because only losers do that.
Take it with Miguel, if possible.
Take this class with Lorena!! She's very willing to help and genuinely cares about you doing well in her class.
Take this course if you need to fulfill a distribution requirement but know that to get a good grade you will have to put in a lot of effort.
Take this course with Loreana. She knows so much and is extremely helpful and fair.
Take this course! I know it's a requirement for most people, and in my case, it was a fun requirement.
This class does require time and effort to learn the material. Constantly practice your listening skills and language tables can be helpful.

Try to engage yourself in the material as much as you can. If you have already taken Spanish in high school, chances are most other people in the class have as well (after doing the 101-102 sequence) and will be really disengaged in the course.
Try to get the most out of it, as it's probably the last language class you'll take
Well if you've made it this far, you have to take it.
Yes. Great course and necessary for most even considering it.
You don't have any choice about taking Spanish 107, but if somehow you get to choose your instructor then you should choose Professor Vasquez. You won't regret it.
You probably have to take this course for distribution stuff, but it's fun!
prereqs: SPA 102 or 103 with a passing grade..
descrip: An intermediate/advanced language course that continues and reviews the introductory level Spanish, while further developing students? communication skills through communicative activities inside and outside of the classroom, as well as various types of materials, both audiovisual and written. Goal will be to improve the Spanish skills acquired in previous courses and students' abilities to develop and express more complex ideas in Spanish both orally and in writing. By the end of the course, students should have a command of the four basic language skills: listening comprehension, speaking, reading and writing.

title: History and the Body
reviews: Amazing course. One of my favorites at Princeton. Prof. Kunzel is awesome. TAKE IT!
Definitely take this class, you won't regret it!
Great seminar about how the body has been viewed over time. Professor Kunzel is very knowledgeable and passionate about the course material, and her enthusiasm shows during every class.

If you have any interest in the topic at all, you should take this course!! Fascinating, well-written readings, flexibility to pursue topics that interest you... This course will change the way you think of sex, gender, and race. Princeton is lucky to have Prof. Kunzel, she is a great professor and makes time for all of her students.

Prof. Kunzel is lovely, but the course felt little like a history course, and more like a discussion of contemporary issues related to sexuality. If that's what you're interested in, go for it, but don't expect a historically-based course!
Take any course taught by Professor Kunzel. She is such a great professor.

The material is very interesting. Cross your fingers the people in your class can really engage with it and want to. Push each other and the professor. Ask for more feedback about written work. Very very manageable class. Assignments aren't demanding.

This was a great and broad-ranging class that provides an excellent introduction to race and gender history, but also delves into fascinating topics that are covered less often, like biometrics, terrorism and discipline. Take it! Professor Kunzel is great and very supportive.
descrip: This course introduces students to new scholarship on the history of the body and the shifting political and cultural contests over understandings of the "natural" or "normal" body. Through readings in gender and sexuality studies, history, and disability studies, as well as autobiography, film, and other primary sources, we will explore changes in the ways in which human bodies have been conceived and represented, and will consider the work of historians and cultural theorists who move further to historicize the lived experience of the human body.

title: Precolonial Africa
reviews: I would take this class with the expectation that you will not really walk out with any answers. Just more questions.
Take it if you're really interested in the subject matter, but otherwise you could find a better course. Easy grading, and not too much work.
Take the course! You will enjoy it and learn more about African history.
The message of this course is one that isn't often repeated elsewhere. The course itself is interesting and well-taught, so I'd definitely recommend taking it.
^ see above comment
take it!
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: The course explores the rich history of the African continent before colonial occupation during the 19th century. It concentrates on people and civilizations indigenous to Africa, focusing on ancient civilizations as well as on the expanse of Islam and the Atlantic slave trade. Travelers' accounts, epics, and archaeological evidence reveal diversity of African culture.

title: Intensive Elementary Chinese
reviews: Be prepared to consistently work. Be friends with the kids in your class. Have fun with it! The instructors are wonderful.
Find a smaller section. There are more opportunities for participation. Participation is key for foreign language.
Heavy workload, but the teachers are exceptional. Take it but be prepared for a lot of work!
If you have even the slightest interest in Chinese, you should take this course.
It does take time, but not too much time. Class is often pretty interesting and enjoyable

Learn the material. Don't just try to get a good grade. Cramming for weekly quizzes was my biggest mistake. I did decently well on the quizzes but my improvement was significantly less than my peers. Also, go to Chinese tables as much as possible
Make sure you stay on top of all your assignments and study vocab throughout the week, not just the day before the test (Fridays).
Prepare for each class ahead of time so you don't feel lost in class!
Prepare for work!  Prepare for studying!  But you'll have great classmates and great teachers!
Prepare to work hard, and make sure to find opportunities beyond the classroom to practice speaking (Chinese table is great). Overall, it will be an extremely rewarding experience.
Prepare yourself for a lot of work, however, it is extremely rewarding.

Take it! I already fulfilled my language distribution, but I decided to take Chinese 103 because I had heard wonderful things about Chinese at Princeton. Great decision. It's not hard, but it is a lot of work.
The course moves at a very fast pace, so you have to keep up with the lessons and memorizing characters.
Work at it regularly
definitely take this course it is amazing
descrip: Designed for students who already have some familiarity with spoken Mandarin. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills, and how to analyze grammar. Students who speak Mandarin with non-standard accents will be trained in standard pronunciation.

title: Living with Animals
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Physics for Future Leaders
reviews:
A bit more involved than expected, but compared to other classes pretty chill if you were okay with physics in high school.
Class is difficult conceptually, not mathematically.
An easy and engaging STN/STL requirement. Put in two hours a week on the problem sets and you will do well.
Definitely take this class if you are somewhat interested in physics.
Do it! Omelon and Steinhardt are the bomb. Also go to the Spectacular!
Enjoy
Go to lecture.
I don't really know what to say
I would not recommend this course, as is. It was confusing and disorienting--almost as though the material was supposed to be simple but because it was so simplified, it was made more complicated.
If you have to do a science at Princeton this seems like a good class to take. It's not easy, but if you put in hard work and seek help from the resources available to you (Aaron) it is doable.
Make sure you go to lecture and be ready to learn.
Meh
Memorize every little detail of lecture, because you will be tested on it
TAKE THIS CLASS! you won't regret it
Take it for an easy STN.
Take it! An enjoyable course that was not particularly difficult, if you are willing to put in the effort
Take it. If you have any physics background it will be pretty easy
Take this class for STN
Take this class if you need an STN. It is straightforward and manageable.
Take this class.  You will not regret it.  Best class ever
Take this course if you're interested in physics but not too interested. Good way to get a basic understanding of a variety of concepts
Take this if you need the requirement. It was also just a fun class. We learned some cool physics stuff and lecture were engaging.

The homework takes more time than you want it to because there are some trivial questions, but lectures are fairly interesting and keep you awake with various demonstrations. Learned a basic overview of physical principles and that was what I aimed to get out of the class so I guess it was successful.

This course is light and interesting even for those with no particular prior interest in physics. You don't need advanced math skills and the lectures/demonstration are entertaining. One problem set a week is not bad.
You can get a good grade with just a solid effort. If you slack off the class quickly becomes more trouble than it's worth.
harder than you'd expect, even if you're PDF-ing it
prereqs: Math skills at the level of high school algebra are assumed. No prior classes in physics or astronomy are necessary..
descrip: What do future leaders of our society need to know about physics and technology? The course is designed for non-scientists who will someday become our influential citizens and decision-makers. Whatever the field of endeavor, they will be faced with important decisions in which physics and technology play an important role. The purpose of this course is to present the key principles and the basic physical reasoning needed to interpret scientific and technical information and to make the best decisions. Topics include energy and power, atomic and subatomic matter, wave-like phenomena and light, and Einstein's theory of relativity.

title: Ritual, Myth, and Worldview
descrip: How do rituals work, and for whom? What do myths reveal, and how do we know? How do worldviews conjure up pictures of the universe and ways of behaving in it? This course examines these questions and the relations between them by surveying major anthropological interpretations of the function, structure, meaning and role of agency in myth and ritual.

title: Seminar in Research Methods
reviews: Be ready to discuss, it is a three hour seminar.
It''s mandatory for NES majors.
It's an alright course. Some interesting material, but the readings can be boring. If you're an NES major you have to take it anyway...
Participate in class-that's where the most enjoyment comes from. Find a reading you like and think of a number of questions. Talk when you have something to say.
descrip: Introduces advanced undergraduates to the basic methods of research and analysis in history and the social sciences as well as to fundamental debates in the field of Near Eastern Studies. Topics addressed include causality, research design, case studies, selection bias, historicism, Orientalism, ethnography, textual analysis, and the ethics of research.

title: Shakespeare I
reviews: All of the lectures in this course were very stimulating, and his assignments really give you the freedom to explore the aspects of Shakespeare's plays that most interest you. If you're looking for a fantastic English course, this is the one.

Do writing seminar first

Take another English class first

Probably P/D/F it if you are not really confident that you can do close reading well
Don't take it unless you have to. Maybe try Shakespeare II.

I would advise students to stay on top of the readings and to be willing to ask questions if they are perplexed by the material or by a point made in lecture - it will make the later paper writing easier.

I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in reading Shakespeare with a microscope. I would not recommend this class to someone who just has a general interest in reading Shakespeare--it probably won't be what you expected.
I would take this course if you like shakespeare.
If another professor teaches this course, I would recommend it to another student, but if Professor Cormack is teaching it, I would advise against it.
Make sure you keep on top of the reading, and read the plays multiple times.  Go to office hours for papers!
Read the plays before the lectures, otherwise you'll be lost. Interesting class.
Take it because of David Lennington. Best preceptor. Prof. Cormack gives very interesting, but very complicated lectures, so only take this if you are really interested in Shakespeare.

Take this course with Bradin Cormack if you enjoy consistently having your mind blown, though keep in mind that the readings of texts he offers in lecture are non-standard (and quite philosophical at times)

This course is awesome. Be prepared to spend a lot of time on readings, which you must complete on schedule to understand what is happening, but also know that this course will blow your mind every lecture. Fantastic!
This course rules if you love Shakespeare but only if you really do love Shakespeare. If you're going to take it (and you should), read the plays. Twice.
Wait for another professor to teach the course maybe? Or just read Shakespeare on your own - the notes are usually pretty good in the margins.
Would suggest strongly against taking it, as it stands right now.
descrip: This class covers the first half of Shakespeare's career, with a focus on the great comedies and histories of the 1590s.

title: Differential Geometry
prereqs: MAT 355 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This is an introductory graduate course covering questions and methods in differential geometry. As time permits, more specialized topics will be covered as well, including minimal submanifolds, curvature and the topology of manifolds, the equations of geometric analysis and its main applications, and other topics of current interest.

title: Computational Social Science (Half-Term)
descrip: This half-semester seminar introduces students to compuational social science. Topics include experiments, digital traces data, crowdsourcing, and ethics. Techniques and approaches are illustrated with examples from the literature. No previous knowledge of computer programming is required, and graduate students from other disciplines are welcome.

title: Climate of the Earth: Present, Past and Future
reviews: Course summary presentation may take some time in your spare time, but it worth.
It is a helpful class for an overview in climate. Tests are difficult--seek advice on preparation.
It's worth taking. Students can learn a lot if he/she puts high engagement into it. Otherwise it would be a little hard to follow for students who have less or little background.
descrip: The goal of the course is to provide students with an introductory overview of the broad factors that determine our current climate, as well as past and future climates. We first build a foundation for understanding the principal features of today's climate. This includes examining the Earth's energy and water cycles, the processes determining the principal atmospheric and ocean circulation features, climate feedback processes, and dominant modes of variability. We then use this framework to interpret observational records of past climates, including ice age cycles, and to examine projections of future climate change.

title: Engineering Design for Sustainable Development
reviews: If you are interesting in going into sustainable development, this course will give you good experience with real-world projects/tasks.
Interesting. Impress the professors! They work at Environ!

Take it if your interested in sustainable practices - provides good insight and the small class setting is beneficial. Great design alternative for the MAE track for students not particularly interested in machine shop design.

The projects will be time-consuming, and most of the work is group work. This can be problematic if you are assigned to a team with members who have different standards of quality for their work than you do.

This course requires a huge time commitment and will keep you busy all throughout the semester. As an MAE student interested in sustainable design, I found the course less painful than some of our rather disorganized design courses. It's a good choice for a design course if you're interested in the material and have some time on your hands.
prereqs: CEE 303 or equivalent with instructor's permission. Open to Seniors and Graduate students only..
descrip: Students will design several features of a LEED-certified building project. Features that will be considered include ground source heat pumps; ventilation; photovoltaics (PV); insulation; glazing; green materials; and storm water management systems, including a green roof, and rainwater harvesting. Ventilation will be designed considering the potential for vapor emissions from building materials. Energy software will be used to determine the carbon footprint and energy costs of alternative designs.

title: U.S. Military and National and International Diplomacy
reviews: Could not recommend more strongly. You will learn more in this course than all previous courses combined. Admiral Mullen is a brilliant man who creates an environment that you will look forward to every Thursday afternoon.
Course was disorganized at times, and Mullen can be long-winded. But 100% worth it to take this class to learn from one of the best. Mullen is caring and I learned a lot from him.
Do not pass up this opportunity, and make the most of every minute. Admiral Mullen is an incredible professor and super down to earth. Soak it all in!

Great class and an incredible opportunity to hear from someone who has been involved in major foreign policy decisions. It's not easy though, as there is a lot of reading and a significant (but not crippling) amount of written work.
He was the top military officer in the U.S. Take this class.
I don't know if I'd take this again.
Once in a lifetime opportunity.

This course is a once in a lifetime opportunity. Admiral Mullen is a dynamic speaker and has amazing stories and insight on diplomacy and international affairs. Perhaps as important, Mullen genuinely cares about his students and strives to get to know them. If you can get in, take this class.
descrip: This seminar will review concepts of military strategy, national security policy, U.S. diplomatic relations with other global power centers, and efforts to transform international institutions to address emerging global security threats.

title: Classical Mechanics: Principles and Problem Solving (Half-Term)
reviews: I advise reading and working through problems throughout the course, and attempting to work on the problems for class, before class. Particularly because they move through topics very very swiftly.
I found it useful. You can review all the material on your own but the course probably makes the process easier, and you may also learn a few new tricks.
I would recommend that they attend to figure out if they needed help with Prelims problems, and then decide from there.
If you have good memories of the basic undergrad knowledge, you don't have to take this one.
Please take it! Do not hesitate!
Take it if you need to prepare for the exams!

This course is not for everyone, even if the physics department makes it sound like it is. In retrospect, I think I would have done better if the class was more a "everyone solve these problems at home and we will discuss in class" type session as opposed to a general review for a large portion of the section. Only take this course if you just need a general overview and know a lot of the nitpicky details already.
You don't actually need to take this class..
You will learn something every class, attend often and take notes!
descrip: A graduate-level review of classical mechanics emphasizing problem solving.

title: South Asian Islam, 998-1803
reviews: A relaxed, very interesting course on South Asian Islam

A very interesting course. If you are looking for a stimulating history of Islam throughout South Asia, or just story-time on Wednesdays from an excellent professor, take it. Barry is an educationalist and sue to this it is not a hard class, but it will greatly stimulate your interest in the subject.

An very good course and Prof Barry will keep you entertained for the 3 hour lectures, but he has a tendency to go wildly off-topic. We largely skipped the Delhi sultanate and the last 140 years of the course (lectures stopped at 1660).
As a History major, i would highly recommend that other History major's take a class by Michael Barry before they graduate.
Barry is a fantastic speaker. The format of the course is a bit scattered, but it's worthwhile if you're interested in South Asia and/or Islam.

I would advise students to take this class if they really enjoyed history, Islam or South Asia. A student taking this class should be prepared for 3 hour lectures and is comfortable in writing research papers.

I would definitely make the time to take this course. Even if you aren't previously familiar with the history of South Asia, Professor Barry will do an excellent job of teaching you what you need to know.
I would definitely recommend this class and recommend they attend all classes, as that is where all of the information comes from.

Pequods are veryyy expensive, so beware. If you are genuinely interested in the subject, take the class. However, if he offers Spanish Islam again, I would recommend taking that instead. I enjoyed it a lot more than South Asian Islam and felt like he lectured better for Spanish Islam. Also, as a South Asian, I found some of his views on the subject a bit problematic.
Prof. Barry is the man. Amazing lectures and great essay topics.

Professor Barry's lectures are wonderful for getting major themes, but you will need to invest some self-study to get the details. This course starts you off well but does not give a full, detailed picture of Indian or Indian Islamic history over this period.
Repetitive

Take a course with Barry in your time at Princeton. Go to lecture (the seminars are actually lectures, that's why they can be so large), they're incredibly interesting and you'll feel like a more educated human. Not time-intensive outside of the classroom.
The only reason not to take this course is if you can't sit still for 3 hours. Other than that, it is absolutely captivating and a manageable workload.
it's so easy to write two papers - DO NOT buy the pequods so expensive, and they are in the library.
descrip: This course traces Islamic history in South Asia from the first Muslim conquests in India through centuries of alternating Hindu-Muslim understanding and conflict, down to the final occupation of Delhi by the British. The course will provide deeper understanding of the cultural background, social and political roots, and religious outlook of the two modern South Asian Islamic states of Afghanistan and Pakistan. Particular attention will be paid to the attempt at cultural symbiosis under Emperor Akbar in the 16th century, followed by renewed sectarian tension and the collapse of Islamic rule while European sea-powers consolidated their grip.

title: Differential Manifolds
prereqs: MAT215, 217 or MAT203, 204 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: To cover the elements of calculus on manifolds. Introduce the concept of differentiable manifold, develop the notions of vector fields and differential forms, stokes theorem and the de Rham complex. The basic existence theorem in ODE is used to prove the Frobenius theorem on integrability of plane fields. The intent is to provide the preparation for the courses in differential geometry and topology.

title: Advanced Physical Chemistry: Quantum Mechanics
reviews: For the more math-inclined students, definitely take this class. It was a small class, which made learning the material much simpler than in a large lecture format. Professor Selloni also presents the material in a clear way and answers questions readily.
Take this course if you want to learn quantum mechanics with chemistry applications.  There is significant math, but it is very good.

Take this course over 305 if Selloni is teaching it. Ask her a lot of questions because she is friendly and helpful. Despite its math-focus, it won't really give you the most rigorous understanding, so it might be worth following up with PHY 208 or a grad course.
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 or CHM 215; MAT 201 or MAT 203 (multivariable calculus); MAT 202 or MAT 204 (linear algebra) is very helpful, but not required; PHY 101. First semester of a two-semester physical chemistry sequence intended primarily for chemistry majors. Students may take CHM 306 or 406 to complete the sequence..
descrip: First principles development of quantum theory, with applications to atoms, molecules, and their spectroscopy. This course will emphasize developing basic principles and focus on illustrative examples.

title: Major Filmmakers
reviews: I highly recommend any student to take this class, if not for the material, for the professor. Pr. Sitney will be teaching for the last time next Fall, and it would be a shame to have been at Princeton without having experienced this unique way of learning and interacting with a professor. Everytime Pr. Sitney teaches this class, he focuses on different filmmakers, making the class an ever-evolving course, in which Pr. Sitney himself learns about the films and filmmakers.
Take a course with P Adams Sitney if you can! It's a brilliant experience!
The quality of the discussions depends a lot on who your classmates are. Come to class prepared with issues you want to discuss.
prereqs: Please contact Professor P. Adams Sitney (padams@) for enrollment permission.
descrip: A seminar on the major films of Luchino Visconti, Robert Bresson, and Jean-Marie Straub (and Daniele Huillet) and their literary sources. All three filmmakers made important and eccentric adaptations of major literary texts.

title: Policy Workshop - Applying Behavioral Science to Family Planning Challenges
descrip: Behavioral Economics and Psychology are now widely seen as an insightful new tool to solve social and business problems alike. Several governments, including the UK and US, have been quick to embrace this new approach by setting up central 'nudge squads'. In this workshop, we will apply these powerful tools to a specific real-world social problem in Family Planning program uptake and usage in a developing country, most likely in Sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Modeling and Observing the Universe: Research Methods in Astrophysics
reviews: As an astro major you don't really have any choice about taking this class.  It's solid, and I suspect having taught it again as a larger lecture Professor Strauss will be more prepared in the future.
Definitely go to the problem review sessions, get to know and work with other students, and be grateful for having a final paper instead of a final exam!
Definitely take it if you are considering astrophysics major or if you are just curious about what astronomers do.
I would not take this course unless you were particularly interested in the content.

If you're an astro major, definitely take this course!  The material is very helpful and relevant to astro research and Strauss is a really interesting lecturer (even if he tends to get off topic a lot).  The problem sets, which make up the bulk of the grade for the class, are time consuming and sometimes quite difficult, but Strauss's office hours are immensely helpful in doing them.  Form a problem set group and start them early.
If you're in it, you probably have to take it anyway. It's difficult but not a class you have to close your eyes and wait for the end with.
It's better to take it after having a sound knowledge background in physics.

You will probably have to take this class. It is tough and requires a lot of work outside of lecture to actually learn and understand the material well enough to complete the problem sets. Don't underestimate any of the problems.
prereqs: PHY103/104 OR PHY 105/106, and MAT 103/104, or consent of instructor. Background in computer programming is helpful, but not required..
descrip: How do we observe and model the universe? We discuss the wide range of observational tools available to the modern astronomer: from space-based gamma ray telescopes, to globe-spanning radio interferometry, to optical telescopes and particle detectors. We review basic statistics and introduce students to techniques used in analysis and interpretation of modern data sets containing millions of galaxies, quasars and stars, as well as the numerical methods used by theoretical astrophysicists to model these data. The course is problem-set-based and aims to provide students with tools needed for independent research in astrophysics.

title: Objects of Andean Art
reviews: Be willing to put the time in to do the readings and attend ever lecture and precept. Each class is full of new material you'll need for the midterm, final, and papers. Don't be discouraged by that, however. The course is a lot of fun, has an expert in the field as its teacher, and is definitely worth taking.

Fascinating material but the breadth of the course is too much.  Memorize that map throughout the semester since Hamilton seems to care more about where art objects were located on exams than he cares about the object themselves.
Keep up with your readings and don't be afraid to have fun during precept!
Take it! Professor Hamilton knows a lot about this topic and will make it fun and engaging.
Take it, quite a unique experience.
YES
prereqs: This course has no prerequisites or restrictions. Students will be expected to actively participate in class discussions, demonstrations, and excursions..
descrip: This course provides an overview of Pre-Columbian Andean art, taught from objects in the University's art museum and nearby collections. Particular attention will be paid to textiles, organic materials, and their biological origins. Students will have weekly opportunities to examine objects firsthand. Assignments will develop broad art historical research skills of object study, writing about objects, and visual documentation of objects (photography, analytical illustration, etc.) Excursions and demonstrations of materials and techniques, generously supported by PLAS, will make the course ideal for hands-on and experiential learners.

title: Intermediate Turkish I
prereqs: TUR 102 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Extensive exposure to current news, authentic multimedia sources; in-depth review of grammar. Introduction to modern Turkish literature, with close reading of selected prose and poetry. Development of all language skills and cultural understanding is emphasized.

title: Dissertation Writers' Seminar
prereqs: This course is open only to post-generals students. Each student will give one fifty-minute presentation of work in progress..
descrip: A practical introduction to scholarly writing at the dissertation level and beyond, providing guidance on planning and completing the dissertation and on other aspects of becoming a professional scholar and teacher, such as mastering the craft of the journal article (conceiving, writing and submitting), writing effective syllabi for different kinds of courses, and turning the dissertation into a book (with visits by editors from leading presses). The seminar meets every two weeks and is required of all post-generals students in residence, who will have the opportunity to present and discuss their work in progress.

title: Decoding Dress
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Descartes, Kant, Hegel
reviews: Covering three giants of philosophy is too much for one course ? Brodsky is a genius and has a fascinating perspective and you should try to take a course with her. However, I'm not sure if this is it, as the three-hour lectures can get arduous and it's easy to disengage. That said, she is incredibly passionate, and is truly a genius in her field.

Definitely meet with Professor Brodsky. About your papers (or anything). She really takes the time to speak to students and cares about your learning.  
Also, do the reading!
Do it.

If you fall in love with Brodsky during the first class, take the course. Otherwise, don't fool yourself into thinking it will get better. This is a lecture course, not a seminar, and her teaching style is definitely not for everyone. That said, she is absolutely brilliant and you will learn a ton if you commit and manage to follow her through all of her tangents and wanderings.
Take the course, do all the readings.
Take this class if you are interested in the topic
You will need to be self-directed
prereqs: This course is unrestricted and open to all undergraduate and graduate students.
descrip: In this seminar we will read major works by the three philosophers whose formulations of thinking and experience continue to provide the basis for modern critical and theoretical thought. We will elucidate these works both individually and in their historical and conceptual relationship to each other considering their extension to the major disciplines whose bases they transformed (epistemology, aesthetic theory, moral philosophy, political and economic theory, and historiography, among others) and the basis of their own conception in specific discursive and, thus, literary forms.

title: An Introduction to the Islamic Scholarly Tradition
descrip: The course offers a hands-on introduction to such basic genres of medieval scholarship as biography, history, tradition, and Koranic exegesis, taught through the intensive reading of texts, mostly in Arabic. The syllabus varies according to the interests of the students and the instructor.

title: Political Economy Workshop
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Political Economy. Third and fourth year graduate students are expected to attend; first and second year graduate students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: The Diversity of Brains
reviews: An interest in biology, evolution, and animals would be useful for this neuroscience course.
Be sure to speak up in class, even if what you have to say sounds stupid to you. It probably won't be. Take this class! It's great!
Definitely a chill neuro seminar and is interesting. Asif is dope.
Great neuro seminar, highly recommended

I would definitely recommend this course. Prof. Ghazanfar is really nice, and all of the lecture topics are really interesting and fun to discuss. This course also teaches you a lot about how to analyze scientific papers. Really great course.
If you like neuroscience at all, you will like this course. Manageable workload, super engaging, and you will leave this class knowing a LOT of stuff you will not forget. Super cool. Take it.

It's a fun class, and Prof. Ghazanfar is an awesome chill dude. Not too much work (just a few Blackboard questions per week, and each student chooses one week to do a presentation during the semester. No midterm and only one short paper in lieu of a final exam). Great departmental or certificate requirement. Strongly recommend.
Meet with professor before your presentation.
One of the best neuroscience courses. Professor is funny and keeps students engaged. You learn to question papers and their content as well as lots of interesting information.
TAKE IT! Chill and informative like hell. But work on your speaking skills or it may cost you dearly. And work on thinking outside the box if you can.
TAKE THIS. All of the papers are super interesting, and classes are a lot of fun. Definitely a must for PSY or NEU students.

This is a great class! Interesting topics (mostly animal behavior) and low stress. Not a lot of work on a week-to-week basis (just reading 2 papers and writing a few paragraphs) and you have the freedom to have some fun with your presentation. It was not hard at all to fill the time, since the class was so eager to discuss the papers.
Very interesting way to look at a variety of animal brains.
prereqs: NEU/PSY 258, EEB 311, EEB 314, or NEU 101..
descrip: The premise of this seminar is that an understanding of the neural basis of behavior can be gained by examining species-typical behaviors. Each animal species has evolved neural solutions to specific problems posed to them by their environment. The course will focus primarily on forebrain mechanisms in mammals, highlighting the unique environmental problems that a species must solve and the ways in which the brains of these animals implement their solutions. Some example model systems include prey capture by bats, monogamy and aggression in voles, and eye gaze processing by primates.

title: Politics of Empire, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Persuasion and Propaganda
reviews: A very good class. It's well taught, covering a fascinating topic. Lectures rarely cover the allotted three hours. The group project is big, but you work on it in class every week and get good feedback, so it's very manageable. Not too much work outside of class.
Cooper is a fantastic lecturer and the material is interesting. Very relevant for behavioral economists and people interested in people's thought processes.
Definitely recommend
Do the group readings prior to the first meeting with your group.  You literally decided your research topic (a project that is essential to the rest of the course) on that first day.
Easy, interesting class.  Take with friends.
Go to lecture
Had potential to be more interesting/engaging. Cooper is very nice and very helpful 1-on-1, but not an amazing lecturer.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in psychology and persuasion.
It's really easy, but you don't learn anything and most of it seems like busy work.

Maybe. If the course's experiment component is improved, I would probably suggest it, but based on my experience I would not recommend it for Psych majors because it's pretty simple for a 300-level course.
For non-Psych majors, you might enjoy it simply for the readings, but the seminars were not wholly engaging.
Strongly recommend this course. Not a psych major, but I really enjoyed it.
The project requires some effort. Don't slack on that.
The research deadline will come more quickly than you think, so just be prepared to do effective, efficient work. Very doable, though, and you have great guidance throughout.

This class would have been a good course to replace PSY300. It forces you to go through the process of running an experiment, analyzing data, and writing a research paper much like a psychology senior thesis.
This course is great! If you have any interest in marketing or anything related to persuasion I would definitely recommend taking this course.

This is a really solid class for majors and non-majors. The exam/reading type work is very light, and the group project is really interesting to work on. Prof. Cooper is a really great professor and person, and he's not looking to kill you on a grade -- really just wants you to learn. Strongly recommend.
come to lecture
descrip: This course uses a social psychological perspective to understand the dynamics of persuasion and propaganda. The course will apply research on persuasion to an understanding of such areas as political election campaigns, product advertising and major propaganda machinery.

title: Advanced Korean I
prereqs: KOR 107, KOR 108 or placement test. This is a 3 day/week course..
descrip: Advanced Korean is designed to develop fluency in both oral and literary skills. Expansion of vocabulary, practice in reading comprehension as well as active skills of conversation and writing are stressed through short readings and class discussion. Readings include different styles of writings on various topics including Korean culture, society, and history. 100 characters of Hanjas are introduced.

title: Economic Development I
descrip: An examination of those areas in the economic analysis of development where there have been recent analytical or empirical advances. Emphasis is given to the formulation of theoretical models and econometric analysis and testing. Topics covered include models of household/farm behavior, savings behavior, equity and efficiency in pricing policy, project evaluation, measurement of poverty and inequality, and the analysis of commodity prices.

title: Jerusalem Contested: A City's History from Jewish, Christian, and Muslim Perspectives
reviews: I would highly recommend for anyone interested in the Middle East. Professor Gribetz is really good an introducing what can be confusing material and gives a comprehensive outlook of Jerusalem.
PDF this class if yo want to take it because it seems interesting.
Part of this course explores religious questions. I found it enriching, but just know it exists.
Take a course with Professor Gribetz!
Take it!
Take this class, it was great!
descrip: Jerusalem is considered a holy city to three faiths: Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. In this course, students will learn the history of Jerusalem from its founding in pre-biblical times until the present. Over the course of the semester, we will ask: What makes space sacred and how does a city become holy? What has been at stake - religiously, theologically, politically, nationally - in the many battles over Jerusalem? What is the relationship between Jerusalem as it was and Jerusalem as it was (and is) imagined?

title: Organic Chemistry I: Biological Emphasis
reviews: Aaa. Stay on top of your stuff silly, particularly during all parts.
Absolutely do not fall behind with problem sets, and attend lectures even if they seem opaque. The course accelerates in difficulty in the last few weeks.
Actually read the textbook, and do the problem sets.  Organic chemistry requires lots of practice, but it is rewarding

Although I didn't do that well in the class, I thought orgo was actually kind of fun. Just make sure to all of the past exams that they give you! Also, try to understand the problem sets and do your best on them rather than just getting it out of the way. Understanding them early on did wonders when it came time to actually prepare for the exams.
Always keep up with the lectures and do as many practice problems as possible.

An interesting class sadly ruined by the competitive nature of most students taking it. Are you the type of student that is not satisfied with anything less than an A? Well learn to deal with it. If not, then sit back and enjoy some organic chemistry. It's not particularly difficult but by the time of the final there are LOADS of concepts you need to know well. Few tips: don't blow off the first two midterms. Seriously, they're your best shot at getting a good grade and they're way easier than the third midterm and final. Also, start preparing for the midterms a least a full week before. (and 2-3 weeks before for the final) Labs are cool, I just wish there were more of them in the course.
Attend all lectures and precepts. Do reading beforehand so you go in with an idea of what's going on. Try to attend as many McGraw sessions as possible (if you can).
Attend lectures, and don't fall behind (especially in the beginning of the course).

Be prepared for a lot of studying for midterms. Practice tests are the key to doing well on the exams. Although there are no pressing assignments throughout the course, it is easy to get caught behind in the material. Keep up with readings and review lecture notes often.
Be prepared to work hard

Be prepared, unless you've had ample organic chemistry experience in the past, to put a good amount of time and effort into this class. I highly recommend completing all the previous years' midterm exams before each midterm since those proved to be the most helpful in learning and applying the material. Also, don't hesitate to ask questions whenever you feel confused, since the course is cumulative.
Be ready to put in a lot of time, but if you're willing to put in the time the class is definitely manageable. The McGraw review sessions are really helpful to go to.
Be sure to do the readings
Be sure to shop for TAs and complete the work in a timely fashion. It's important to learn to apply the material learned in class, as brute memorization will not help in any way.
Beware exams.
DO PRACTICE PROBLEMS!

Decent orgo class. Go to Jason's McGraw sessions if he does them, do at least a couple practice exams before each exam (under exam-like conditions too), try to do well on the first two exams because the third one's the hardest and you drop the lowest, pace starts out easier and ramps up after Thanksgiving. Also at 8:30 AM.
Definitely make sure to study every day a little bit rather than studying a lot the week before. It's very easy to fall behind.

Depending on desire to be premed and how motivated you are, you may do well in this class. The students who do well are usually ones who have already taken the subject matter before. They are at an advantage, and so will you be if you decide to begin studying early.
Difficult but doable if you work hard. Do all of practice tests!

Do EVERY single practice test. Then do them all again. There are themes and trends in organic chemistry and it's easier to learn by application and practice than by theory, at least for me. Don't memorize rules, understand the chemical basis behind them. I didn't love the textbook so I would recommend getting Klein's "Organic Chemistry as a Second Language" for some good conceptual overviews on material you may not have picked up on the first time around in lecture. 
Also, review your lecture notes. There are a lot of similar type questions from past exams, but I always find that if there's an unfamiliar type of problem on an exam it was covered in lecture. 
I personally think this course is too hard to take "for fun" or as a passing interest. Organic Chemistry demands a lot of your time, effort, and tears.
Do a little bit of orgo every day. It requires stamina, but you can learn it if you put enough time into it.
Do all the practice exams and use that to study, don't think you have it because you get the concept, you won't get anything right.
Do all the practice exams to prepare for the midterms/final.
Do all the practice tests before taking the tests!! Very important

Do all the readings and definitely do practice exams. It's very hard to do well if you don't do the practice exams as the actual test problems are much harder than anything during lecture and anything in the problem sets. By far, the most interesting class I took my first semester at Princeton.
Do all the work. Even if it says it is optional. It is not. Take a precept with Jeff Lipshultz if he is teaching again. He will save your life. Go chemistry.
Do as many of the practice exams as possible before the exams! Go to McGraw if you need help.
Do it if you have to or really love chemistry.
Do it only as a requirement.
Do not take this course if you do not have to. There are so many more interesting chemistry courses you can invest your time and work in.
Do past papers. Try and work in a group.

Do the homework. Do the practice exams. Print out all the answer keys to bring to the exam. Don't try to learn all the material the night before because some of it takes time just to sink in. Don't despair if one exam goes poorly because there's always a chance to make up for it later.
Do the practice tests (like everyone else will tell you!)
Do the problem sets
Do the problem sets, and start studying for the exams early!
Do the readings ahead of time. That way you'll be ready for the lectures.
