Do the readings, they help. Cheat sheets are key. And practice, practice, practice!!

Do. not. take. this. unless. you. have. to.
This is obviously not a 'for fun' class. If you're premed, you'll have to take this regardless and it doesn't matter what the reviews are. Good luck.
Doing all of the practice exams is very helpful for preparing for the midterms.

Don't be afraid to take it. It's not terrible. It's not for everyone, yes, but if you like chemistry/puzzle-solving you'll probably like the material. I did. Be prepared to learn most of the material outside class/lecture. Take it as a freshman if you can.
Don't be intimidated by all the negative comments you hear about the course. Most people do fine if they just study in advance before the exam.

Don't be scared of Orgo! The course really prepares you well, and there are a number of gimmicks meant to raise your grade (i.e. dropping lowest midterm, or doubling weight of final if grade is higher than average of best two midterms).
Don't fall behind - seek help early if there is a concept you are having trouble with, because the material all builds on itself. Do practice problems as often as possible.
Don't fall behind!
Don't take it during freshman year.
Don't take it unless you have to, or you know that you love organic chemistry.
Don't take it unless you have to. If you have to, get "Organic Chemistry as a Second Language" and read the whole book (not that long).

Drink coffee before lecture, especially if they are covering every window. Otherwise, you will miss most of the material and have to rely on the dense readings, which are supposed to be meant as supplement only. Also, use past exams for practice.
Due to its challenging nature, I wouldn't take this course unless it is a requirement. But it is an interesting course.
Easy if you work hard enough.

Even though problem sets aren't graded, treat them as if they are. They will help you keep up with the material. Also, study for the exams steadily, maybe doing one practice exam per day in the week leading up to the exam.

Expect to put a lot of time into this course. Go to the McGraw Review Sessions- they are extremely helpful. When you are confused on a concept try to get help right away because it all builds on itself.
Expect to work hard for this class.
GO TO MCGRAW sessions!
Go to bed early.
Go to office hours. They are so so helpful.
Go to precept. It is very helpful. Lecture isn't strictly necessary but go if you can, it's no fun having to copy down notes on your own from blackboard.

Go to the lectures if you can. They are very helpful and provide all the relevant information though you can print out a set of filled in/completed notes after the lecture is completed. There are a lot of helpful resources which makes learning the concepts way less difficult.  Do as many practice tests as you can and really try to understand the labs that you do because the lab related questions at the end of each test can be very confusing. I really liked organic chemistry better than general chemistry. It is more applicable to what I want to do. It was easier for me to since I am a more visually predisposed person.
Good luck waking up at 830! Difficulty of the class is overstated.
Great class to take (but don't take it if you don't have). It's a lot of work. And definitely keep up with your work.
HARD
HIGHLY RECOMMEND.
I mean, take it if you have to take it. Not too bad a class. Wouldn't take it for fun.

I think the course needs a better book. I think 8am lecture is a recipe for disaster because the course is pretty difficult. I wish there were more precepts and the lectures were more lesson based rather than history based. If you buy Orgo as a Second Language, and come awake and prepared to the lectures, I think it wouldn't be too bad. I wouldn't take it concurrently with another challenging course.
I would recommend it.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to take a higher level Chemistry course.
I would strongly recommend this course. The subject matter was very interesting and I felt like I learned a lot.
If this is material you are interested in and ready to put in a big effort to learn, you will find this course rewarding.

If you don't have to take it, I would avoid it. But don't let it scare you off, its well taught and if you get a good preceptor its not impossible.  You have to put in the time and do all the practice exams in order to be prepared.
If you don't need to take it, don't. If you do, don't fall behind.

If you have a strong background in organic chemistry (e.g. having gone to chemistry olympiads), ask around to find out the level of difficulty and content covered first to see whether you will learn anything new
If you have to take it, you have to take it. Push through.
If you need it for premed or for chemistry, take it as you need to. Don't take for a distribution requirement unless you really love chemistry.

If you put the hours in, you'll learn a lot in this course. The content is very interesting, you just have to make the effort to study every chapter outside of lecture and precept. Don't skip precepts, they help more than most realize. Unfortunately, most students in this course are premeds with horrible attitudes about learning. Don't let them drag you into their grade-obsessive tactics of only learning what might show up on the midterms or the MCAT. Take the midterms seriously. They are fair tests, but you might not be ready for the first one if you don't start studying early. This class is extremely rewarding if you take because you are interested in the subject. If you're only doing this to fulfill Medical School requirements and lack a genuine interest in science, you might hate this class.
If you're interested in chemistry, this is a great course. Otherwise, you're probably gonna take this course anyway. It's not as horrible as everyone says it is. Just put in the effort!
It is really fun- give it a chance.
It's a fine course, everything that it's expected to be.  Also, go to all of the mcgraw review sessions, they saved my grade.
It's a stereotypical college course. Study and good things happen.
It's hard, but approachable and the material was occasionally enjoyable. I don't recommend taking this if you don't have to or aren't really interested in it.

It's not easy. But it's a really good class. Chances are that you're taking this class because you have to, so it's hard to advise for or against, but I'd just say you'll make it through this class intact
It's ok.  Stay on top of your work.  You can tell beforehand how well you'll do based on how comfortable you feel with the material.  Totally doable
It's tough, but quite interesting and very fair.  Also, incredibly well taught, so you'll really learn the material.
Keep up with the material, once you get behind it's not impossible, but difficult to catch up.

Keep up with the material.  This may mean reading the textbook and going over your notes every day.  It is so easy to fall behind in this course.  Take advantage of all the resources given to you for extra help.
Keep up with the work

Lecture is not that important, keep up with the lectures by looking at notes and read the textbook. Precept is a must! The McGraw sessions with Jason Shields are also heaven sent. You will learn more in the McGraw sessions than in anything else.
Lectures are not worth going to, just learn online and take a lot of practice tests.
Make sure to do lots of practice exams.
Material not too hard, just do the practice problems
Meh
N/A
Never fall behind, look at lecture notes, and ask questions
Not as bad as people make it out to be. A well taught course which is both fun and challenging.
Only if you need to
Only take if interested or required.

Organic Chemistry is not the monster everyone makes it out to be. This class is challenging, but if one goes to their lectures and precepts and does a bit of studying before an exam, they'll be fine. And Semmelhack is one of the finest lecturers in the science courses.
Organic chemistry is not as bad as you may think it is. This course is great.

Orgo has a scary reputation, but I actually really enjoyed it. Don't expect lectures to be completely enlightening, and don't be afraid to ask your preceptors and lab TAs for additional clarification and help. They're very willing in my experience. Above all do every single one of the practice exams. If you do them all as well as the assigned reading (and if time the suggested practice problems) and understand what's going on in the problems you will do very well. Don't be intimidated and keep on top of the material, because it's highly cumulative. Budget enough time to study for exams (starting practice exams a week before and spreading your studying out over the week is good). When you take exams, don't try to memorize things, just focus on what can possibly happen, take them as a learning/problem-solving situation. Sounds weird, but you need an open/flexible mind because there are a lot of exceptions and if you think you know the only things that can happen you will always feel a "how on earth was I supposed to know that" sense. Keep a well-organized binder but try to get to a point where you only use it sparingly. Don't freak out, either, the grading policy is very fair (lowest midterm dropped OR if final is better than midterms all midterms dropped and final is 80% of grade). Just take the course seriously and you might turn out to like it a lot!

Orgo is learnable and not impossible. Do every single practice test, read all the textbook chapters, and expect to devote large amounts of time to this course. Don't leave things to the last minute. Go to Semmelhack's office hours if you can because he does the whole pset. GO TO LECTURE AND ALL PRECEPTS.
Orgo is orgo. It is very time consuming but the material is taught well.

Orgo is orgo. It probably won't be your favorite class (who likes waking up for 8:30?) but it really isn't that bad. The preceptors and Semmelhack do their best to keep it interesting, and Semmelhack's office hours are pretty helpful. The exams are killer, because you never really get a break, but at least you get to drop one.

Orgo is very hard, and takes a lot of work, particularly before exams.  It is very logic-based, which I loved and am good at, but some people aren't and thus find orgo extremely difficult.  However, I generally found it very interesting, and liked orgo overall.

PRACTICE! PRACTICE! PRACTICE! Do all the practice exams. Get study guide or a concise book that help with orgo and help you practice. Make sure you actually do the problem sets! It pays off! Go to Jason Shield review sessions!!! Use all the resources available. Orgo is not as scary and hard as people make it seems!

Practice is the best way to manage the course. The readings can sometimes be helpful, but if you take advantage of practice exams you should be fine. The people teaching the course know what they are talking about, so don't be afraid to go to office hours. Don't be discouraged if your performance or your learning habits don't catch up to the course at first. There's a lot of room for improvement if you dedicate yourself to it.
Prepare diligently throughout.
READ THE BOOK BEFORE LECTURE and KEEP UP WITH THE READINGS. It will save you hours of studying in the long run
Read the book before exams and especially review the chapter subtitles.
Read the book first and then use lecturers to review.
Read the book. If it's a choice between lecture or precept, go to precept. If it's a choice between lecture and the book, go read the book. Lecture is, for many people, not helpful.

Read the textbook and talk to the tutors at McGraw if you're having trouble. Make sure you understand the concepts and don't try to get away with memorizing everything. Take practice exams and either go to class or go to office hours (if you look over the completed notes online). There are 150 other students in that room so don't be shy to talk to someone in your precept or lab period or even someone sitting next to you. Orgo can be quite hard if you try to conquer it on your own. So get to know the people around you in lecture/precept/lab and get to know your TAs because they can and will help you!

Read the textbook, do at least two Orgo problems each day to keep your mind fresh on the material, get a good night's sleep before lecture, do all the practice tests, do the homework, go to precept, stay positive.
Read the textbook. Actively participate. Go to Jason Shield's McGraw Sessions. Try to appreciate the class because, many-a-time, the people who don't do well and don't have fun.
So much work. Only take it if you have to or if you are genuinely interested
Stay on top of the material
Stay on top of the material. Do the complete readings whenever possible, and complete the problems sets. Go to lecture.
Stay on top of your work! It is really fun!
Stay on top of your work! The exams never stop! Practice makes perfect. Use the lecture handouts and old practice tests.
Study hard.
Study long and hard for the tests, but its fun!
Study study study and don't get behind... The units are very much cumulative so you don't want to miss one topic and be lost for the rest of the semester.
Study. Go to office hours. Stay ahead.

TAKE ALL THE PRACTICE TESTS BEFORE EXAMS. Try and find a good preceptor? it will make your life a lot easier. Do the assigned practice problems, and try and do them throughout the semester instead of cramming the week/days before an exam. Come prepared to lab. Ask questions, and be precise if you can. Get help if you need it. This is definitely doable (I'm a freshman and did well), but you have to be willing to put in work and get the help you need. Also, forming consistent study groups for problem sets is advisable.
Take all the practice exams.
Take at least two or three of the past exams before each midterm, since most of the questions/concepts are recycled year to year.
Take it for premed/prereq. But if you have a background in orgo or chemistry, take it because it is like solving a puzzle and can be fun.
Take it if it's a requirement for your major.
Take it if you have to, it's not unenjoyable. But probably too much work for general interest.

Take it if you have to.
If you know you won't be awake at lecture or have time/willingness to do the readings, familiarize yourself with outside teaching sources (khanacademy, etc.). 
At the very least work through all the old exams. Practice makes a huge difference in this course -- you get what you put in.
Take it only if you are in love with chemistry or if you have to - this is a difficult course, it is rewarding, but its difficult
Take practice exams as preparation for exams
Take the course if you have to for premed or if chemistry really interests you - beware, it will dominate your life if you take it.
Take the practice tests!  All of them!
Take this class freshman year if you can, get a good preceptor and do all the practice tests.
Take this class if you like chemistry or are interested in organic chemistry. You will learn a lot, one of my favorites here at Princeton.
Take this if you want to challenge yourself.
Take this only if you have to.

The course involves a lot of work, especially in preparations for the exams. But the best way to learn the information, at least for me, was to keep on top of the textbook readings, as to better understand the material.
The course is pretty cumulative. One concept builds pretty fundamentally on the last.
The course is very interesting and you learn a ton of chemistry, but you are going to have to put in a lot of time and stay completely on top of the material to have any hope of getting an A.
The course material is not too difficult, but the high number of high achieving students make it hard to get a good grade. If you want a good grade, this class will be a huge time-sink.

The hardest part of the course is having to study for the three midterms during the semester and the final. It's an interesting class overall, and other than exams the workload is fairly light. But the exams will be difficult. If you want to do well, I would suggest taking more time to learn things throughout the semester and ask lots of questions.

There are so many resources available to help with this course but it costs one of your most precious resources: time. From review sessions to office hours, if you put in the effort and time to really understand the concepts you should be good. Just put in the time throughout the semester and not just when exams roll around.

This class is not nearly as bad as people paint it to be. 

Put in the work, go to lecture, and do ALL of the practice tests. And get to know Henry- he's great.

This course gives you a good introduction to organic chemistry. However, the lectures are pretty dry, and the curves for the exams can get unreasonable because many of the students in this class have taken organic chemistry classes in the past. Only take this class if you have to.
This course is all about work. You have to put a lot of work and time into it and if you're not ready for that then don't take it.

This course is hard, but if you invest in learning the material, it can be fun, and you will learn a lot. If you do the Psets and put work into them, you will learn from them even if you get a lot wrong. They are not graded, so don't worry; just get it right the next time.

This course is not as difficult as it is cracked up to be, but it does take a lot of time and you MUST put in the time to understand what's going on. The course is invaluable for people going into chemistry, biology, and medicine, and  it really challenges you to take all the details of a system into account before drawing conclusions about its properties or dynamics.
This course is not at all easy, but if you put in the work, it is immensely rewarding. Do all of the practice exams! They are made available for a reason.

This course isn't a lot of time day-to-day, but exams require a lot of preparation beforehand and the material is very cumulative meaning it's better to get help early on rather than to struggle through.

This is not an easy class. Don't get behind on the material, since everything builds on previous content. Get help if you need it. 
Attending lecture is not enough to be able to do well on problem sets and exams.
This will be your first priority. If you get lost early on, it is worth the extra time to catch up.
Try to do well from the beginning! Do lots of practice problems.
Use outside resources such as websites, books, and material from other schools available online to help grasp the material.
Work hard and keep up with the material.
You probably have to take this course, but don't worry about it. Work hard and you'll do well!

You probably will have no choice in taking this class....
As long as you do all the practice tests you can easily skip lectures and precepts.
You will have to invest a lot of time in the class to do well if you've never done organic chemistry before, but it's an interesting course.
You will need to commit a lot of time to studying on your own. Practice exams are very very helpful!
don't take it unless you are premed
hard but ok
i liked orgo. dont believe the hype
not as bad as other people say.
prepare EARLY EARLY EARLY, devote the majority of your time this semester to this class and practicing problems.. be one step ahead always or it's incredibly easy to fall behind
stay on top of everything
take if you must.
work hard
prereqs: CHM 201 and 202, or CHM 203 (or CHM 207) and 204, or CHM 215. Please contact Patrick Andrae (pandrae@princeton.edu) for all changes in lab and class sections after the completion of registration {OR} to add CHM 303 {OR} to be added to the waiting list for closed lab or class sections..
descrip: This course is designed as the first part of a three-semester sequence, CHM 303/304B and MOL 345 (biochemistry). CHM 303 will introduce the principles of organic chemistry, including the structures, properties, and reactivity of simpler organic compounds. The emphasis will be on the mechanisms of organic reactions, with examples taken from biology when appropriate to illustrate the principles. For a complete presentation of the subject, the course should be followed by CHM 304B in the spring.

title: Topics in Economics - Energy Economics
descrip: Examines the economics behind many issues related to energy use, including the investment and use of renewable and non-renewable resources, energy conservation, deregulation of energy markets, transportation, and energy independence. Current policy options will be discussed.

title: Philanthropy: Can we save the world through generosity?
descrip: Please see website

title: Special Topics in Entrepreneurship - Building and Financing Technical Ventures
reviews: Attend the lectures and get to know the professor since he's a really great guy!

DEFINITELY TAKE IT! Prof. Hejazi is incredibly sweet and is always ready to give you valuable feedback (He responds within 30 mins!). Also a great class if you want to know about venture capital in the biosciences area and how important legal regulations and getting the right clearances are into getting a business started (something few other classes go in depth about).
Definetely take it!
Hejazi was a visiting professor with industry experience, so the class felt a bit arbitrary at times.
If you're at all interesting in biotech or medical startups, this class is for you. Super interesting, and the best part is getting to develop your own ideas and learn how to bring it to fruition.
If you're interested in entrepreneurship, TAKE THIS!
If you're into venture capital and entrepreneurship, I would definitely look into this course. A really interesting topic that I don't think is covered very much in any other class.
Overall pretty good course, though relatively simplistic
Recommend if you're interested in entrepreneurship! Unfortunately Professor Hejazi is a visiting professor.
Take it!
Take it! It's not too much work, and the professor was amazing.
This course number is used for one-offs, so these reviews probably aren't helpful.

This is a special one-time seminar class, so I'm not sure this really applies, but generally an interesting class with a minimal/reasonable workload. Final presentation is fun to do and doesn't really seem like work.
Would definitely consider taking it, and it is easy to fit in as a 5th class
prereqs: There are no prerequisites for this course. Students from all disciplines are welcome..
descrip: With the initial perspective of what it takes to attract funding, the course will then provide the experience of an early-stage entrepreneur seeking initial investment, covering in detail topics such as: opportunity assessment, intellectual property review, proof of concept development, technology de-risking plan, regulatory issues, market validation and team building. The course will then provide guidelines to help students identify financing needs, develop a funding strategy and build a pitch deck for potential investors.

title: Superhero Trials
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - GIS for Public Policy
descrip: This course is designed as a practical introduction to the use of computer mapping (Geographic Information systems) for policy analysis and decision-making. Students learn ArcGIS through examples of map applications. Students are expected to complete exercises and a final project applying GIS to a policy issue.

title: Dance Performance Workshop: Advanced Repertory and Choreography
reviews: Take it! Even if you don't plan on getting a certificate
prereqs: DAN 319 or equivalent experience. Interview with faculty for placement in composition section from April 7-18, 2014. To arrange an interview, email Professor Lazier (rlazier@) or Professor Fehlandt (fehlandt@) and send a list of any previous composition experience at Princeton. NOTE: Placement for Technique/Repertory component of class will be held Wednesday, September 10th from 4:30-6:20 at Hagan Dance Studio at 185 Nassau..
descrip: Students are exposed to distinct choreographers by learning and performing repertory and creating choreography. The Technique and Repertory sections of the course develop technical expertise, expressive range, and stylistic clarity. Students will dance with attention to alignment, detail, spatial clarity, and an awareness of other dancers. In Choreography classes, students will work together in movement-based laboratories to develop choreographic decision-making skills. Readings and viewings inform studio practice and place dance in current artistic movements.

title: Introduction to Portuguese I
reviews: Portuguese is a dynamic course that engages you into a community. The professors are willing to meet with you outside of the classroom and the sense of community is very strong.
Take it! It's so much fun and all the professors in the Portuguese department are super nice!
This is a must take class. The Portuguese department is amazing. Just be prepared to invest so you are taking full advantage of the course.
prereqs: No credit is given for POR 101 unless POR 102 is taken..
descrip: Students will be taught the fundamental skills of oral comprehension, speaking, reading and writing, while gaining exposure to the Portuguese-speaking world through the media, literature, film and the music of Brazil, Portugal and Lusophone Africa.

title: Economics of the Labor Market
reviews: Ashenfelter is very much an "old school" professor whose lectures tend to be more narrative rather than your typical Powerpoint point by point. It takes some getting used to, but the guy is brilliant and learning from him is quite worthwhile! He might even invite the whole class over for lunch!

Take this if you're looking for an incredibly easy and relaxed econ course taught by a giant in the field.  You won't learn that much, but you'll be duly entertained by Ashenfelter and his countless stories.
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 302 and MAT 102 or MAT 103..
descrip: To provide a general overview of labor markets. Covering labor force participation, the allocation of time to market work, migration, labor demand, investment in human capital (education, on-the-job training, man-power training), discrimination, unions and unemployment. The course will also examine the impact of government programs (such as unemployment insurance, minimum wages, or a negative income tax) on the labor market.

title: Numerical Prediction of the Atmosphere and Ocean
descrip: A practical introduction to the numerical approaches that are used to simulate the evolution of the ocean and atmosphere. This course covers the forms of the equations of motion that are most appropriate for numerically studying various atmospheric and oceanic phenomena, and the numerical techniques that are used for their spatial and temporal discretization. The conservation properties of the continuous equations of motion and the numerical approaches for reproducing them are covered, as are the parameterization of unresolved phenomena, and specific considerations for accurate simulation of tracers.

title: Basic Principles of Quantum Mechanics
prereqs: Successful completion of a quantum mechanics course (at the level of CHM 405) and one semester of linear algebra.
descrip: Basic QM concepts at a rigorous level appropriate for graduate students in experimental and theoretical physical chemistry, applied physics and engineering. Topics include (i) mathematical formalism of Hilbert spaces and operators in time-independent quantum theory (ii) single-particle QM for bound and unbound states (iii) basic angular momentum theory (iv) exactly soluble systems: harmonic oscillator and hydrogen atom (v) indistinguishable particles (vi) variational theorem (vii) time-independent perturbation theory (viii) time-dependent theory and Fermi's golden rule, and (ix) applications to chemical problems.

title: Economics of the Internet: The Digital Revolution
reviews: Bhatt is big on participation, but as long as you speak up one or times per class, you're fine. Interesting material. Good way to keep up with current events/trends in tech/internet economics.
Great class. Interesting material and easy problem sets.
Great course, and fairly interesting once you get further into it. Although the paper at the end is long, it was fun to write.
I would take it. P sets are easy and lectures are fun an engaging.

It's pretty fun; take it if you want to talk about the tech industry and learn about graph theory. It's a lot more qualitative and almost like consulting training, than a typical econ class. Also Professor Bhatt is really chill and doesn't mind going on tangents or following wherever the flow of discussion goes so if you're not into that this class could be kind of frustrating.

Some of the concepts are a little left of center, and definitely different to traditional economics courses. However, the case studies are really stimulating, and overall I think I got a lot out of this course. It helps you to think in different ways.
Stay engaged and don't be afraid to speak up
Take if you are interested in the internet. Very relevant stuff. Very manageable workload.
Take it, not too hard and it's interesting to learn about the Internet from an economists perspective

Take it, or any course with Swati Bhatt! She's a great teacher who cares about her students and her content is very interesting. Daniel was also an awesome preceptor (though I didn't have precepts with him, he helped me a lot in clarifying doubts for a couple problem sets)
The course topic is extremely relevant and could be very interesting; however, if the format of lectures and grading (currently no exams) stays the same, I would not recommend it.

This is a bit of an odd class. 30% participation, no exams. Long paper at the end. Almost entirely Econ majors so I felt like I came from a different background with ORF. The case studies were pretty cool for personal interest, but a lot of the time it felt like the classes were too slow and the lectures were repetitive.
You should take this course, but keep in mind that you'll get a lot more out of it if you go out of your way to learn more about the subject matters glossed over in the class.
You'll get out as much as you put in.  It's not a terribly hard course so definitely put in some time to think.  Professor Bhatt values critical contribution.
You're probably going to take it because it has "internet" in the name, right? Yeah... don't.
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Using applied microeconomic theory and case studies, this course examines the impact of digital technology on markets. In a connected economy, information is freely, constantly and ubiquitously available to all participants. We ask how these features affect the way markets function. Topics include the economics of platform markets, social networks, technological innovation, intellectual property, internet security, privacy and other regulatory issues. Using case studies, we cover the impact of the internet on education, health, media and new industries, such as big-data; internet search, online advertising, mobile and cloud computing.

title: Microeconomics for Public Policy
reviews: Be prepared to work REALLY HARD.
Be prepared to work hard, but the curves are favorable and you can get through it. Professor Rosen is the best.
Definitely recommend. You learn a lot and Rosen is a great professor.

Definitely take it. Rosen is an amazing professor who meticulously prepares his lectures and cares profoundly about his students. The math is a bit hard at first but gets easy by the end. I would recommend to anyone. Also better than ECO300 for WWS students (if Rosen is teaching)
Definitely take this course
Definitely try to take it with Prof. Rosen.
Doron is a really good preceptor! Final was a lot harder than expected. It was too hard
Exams are really hard.
Get ready to work very hard. But high rewards. Take with Rosen. He is the best professor at Princeton.
Go to every lecture and do not fall behind, you won't regret it!
Go to lecture!
Harvey Rosen is the best professor I've had at Princeton. The course is amazing. Favorite class this semester.
I love Professor Rosen! Take it with him.

I would recommend this course ONLY IF ROSEN IS TEACHING IT. If there is another professor teaching it, WAIT UNTIL YOU CAN TAKE IT WITH ROSEN. Professor Rosen is by far the best aspect of this course. His lectures are amazing- both very interesting and engaging. His real-world experience in the field of public policy makes much of what he says extremely relevant. In addition, by the end of the class, he had memorized everyone's names (in a class of around 80 people). Be warned, however, that he will call you out in the middle of class to answer questions. Also be warned that the problem sets are very, very hard, and the textbook does not do much to enhance your understanding of the material (definitely not worth the $250 they want you to spend on it).
If you enjoyed 100 and like math, this class is good. If not, it's pretty tough

If you're choosing among the options for the WWS micro core requirement, take this class with Rosen. He's an incredibly engaging lecturer and creates a really positive learning environment. You should know that this course isn't as "public policy" focused as you might expect. It's really more micro with a calculus focus and hints of public policy (for the sake of examples). But once you accept it for what it is, it's a great class overall. If for no other reason, take this class for Rosen.
It is a difficult topic, but as a WWS major who needs to take this class -- take it with Rosen.
It's hard
Make sure you review your problem sets against the posted solutions as they come back, its a lot easier to understand the topic while its fresh in your mind.
Prepare to work hard, and get stumped on some questions on the midterm and final, but if you need to take an upper level econ class this is the way to go.

Professor Rosen is an amazing lecturer, even if you don't love Econ. He calls on students on class but it's never malicious--if you don't know the answer he moves on easily or tries to work it through for the rest of the class, and he also knows everyone's name (he recited them all one class!). I had him as a preceptor too, and he's incredible--really willing to engage and answer questions from the class material. No one in WWS 300 really wanted to take it, I think, but everyone made the effort to engage with the material, in my opinion, because Professor Rosen inspires it in his students.
Put a lot of effort into the problem sets
Rosen is fantastic!!!!
Rosen is great and this is a decent class, but I wouldn't take it unless you have to for the Woodrow Wilson School.
Take if rosen is teaching. worth the effort. his tests are very predictably difficult and you can do well
Take it
Take it with Rosen - he's a fantastic lecturer.
Take it!
Take this course with Harvey Rosen. He is a fantastic lecturer and will expand your understanding of the economics of public policy dramatically.

This class is really hard- be prepared to spend a lot of time on problem sets and exam studying. Work with other people because you can't really get help from the professor or preceptor on problem sets. Take for woody woo requirement- I wouldn't if you don't have to.
This course taught by Professor Rosen is great and I would recommend it as a departmental for WWS majors.
This has been one of my favorite classes at Princeton. Professor Rosen was amazing. I don't think he'll be teaching this class for a while, but if he does, be sure to take it!
This is an engaging course that encourages independent initiative and active participation
WWS majors take it if you have to take it; first couple weeks' psets are hard but it gets easier
Would definitely recommend this class for intermediate microeconomics. Definitely take this with Professor Rosen.
You have to take this, but this is a surprisingly good class, especially with Rosen as a lecturer. You will have to do work, but if you did well in ECO 100 this course should not be too hard.
You're gonna take it. And you're gonna like it. I would take it again. I almost want to change my major to economics. There is a lot of calculus, but he teaches almost everything.
good presentation but not necessarily the stellar class everyone makes it out to be
the first two weeks are undoubtedly tough, but push through and it gets much better.
prereqs: Prerequisite: ECO 100. This course is not open to students who have taken ECO 300 or ECO 310..
descrip: Microeconomics is the study of how people and societies confront scarcity. This course, taught at the intermediate level, focuses on markets as a mechanism for dealing with scarcity, and uses examples that cast light on public policy issues.

title: Mythmakers, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Policy Workshop - Urban Youth Violence Reduction
descrip: This workshop deals with reducing Urban Violence in the Philadelphia area. More detailed course description to follow in August.

title: Witnessing Disaster
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Senior Independent Work
prereqs: For each project the requirements are set in consultation with the faculty advisor, and depend somewhat on the nature of the project. An oral presentation during Reading Period (as per departmental schedule) and a written final report is required. A written report is required by the Department, even if ELE 497 is taken as a part of a two-term sequence with ELE 498. An unbound copy of the report must be turned in to the ELE Undergrad Office by Dean's Date. Details of requirements are available from the ELE Undergraduate office. Senior standing is required..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. A student may propose a topic and find a faculty member willing to supervise the work. Or the student may select a topic from lists of projects obtained from faculty and off-campus industrial researchers, subject to the consent of a project advisor. There is no formal reading list for the course; however, a literature search is a normal part of most projects.

title: Israeli Media: Barometer and Engine of Sociopolitical and Cultural Change
reviews: Anna is not a pushover. But the course is interesting. Just be prepared
The more you put in, the more you get out
descrip: This course uses various forms of Israeli media, including television shows, web sites, blogs, and newspapers, to explore the ethical and moral dimensions of contemporary debates on cultural pluralism in Israel and tensions in Israeli society. Topics include relations between Jews and Arabs, rifts between Orthodox and secular Jews, and the challenges of accommodating and integrating into a single society immigrants who come from diverse backgrounds and lack a common immigrant experience. The course is intended for advanced speakers of Hebrew.

title: Isn't It Romantic? The Broadway Musical from Rodgers and Hammerstein to Sondheim
descrip: Song. Dance. Man. Woman. These are the basic components of the Broadway musical theatre. How have musical theatre artists, composers, lyricists, librettists, directors, choreographers, and designers worked with these building blocks to create this quintessentially American form of art and entertainment? Why are musicals structured by love and romance? This course will explore conventional and resistant performances of gender and sexuality in the Broadway musical since the 1940s.

title: Ethnographic Playwriting
reviews: Aaron is a wonderful person to get to know. Take this class if you want to have a fun time rediscovering how to think about theater.

Great class. A little unstructured but the subject matter is really interesting. Aaron is also great at leading discussion, bringing in new examples of experimental theatre and is very supportive and engaged with his students.
Landsman is fantastic, and makes this course worth it
There is some extent to which I feel like one should have done at least some playwriting/theater study before jumping in to this as the deep end.
prereqs: For admission, please contact Professor Tim Vasen at: tvasen@princeton.edu.
descrip: This course delves into a collaborative, ethnographic approach to making theater. We will read, watch and discuss the work of subculture theorists, theater-makers and other artists and thinkers, all of whom use staged conversations as the basis for characters, scenes and entire works. We will hash out ethics and responsibilities for those of us who engage communities outside our own.What does it mean to take responsibility for someone else's words, write them down, and give them back? What is it like to put the words of a stranger in your mouth? Finally, we will make theatrical material using this approach for an end of semester showing.

title: Introductory Physics I
reviews: As far as physics goes, this is probably the easiest it will get. Definitely take 101 over 103.
Avoid it if you can.
Be prepared for lots of mundane assignments

Definitely try to be in Prof. Uson's precept. He is extremely charismatic and approachable and probably explains the information better than the other instructors. This course could definitely be a lot harder, but it is also not that easy. Weekly quizzes were a pain but forces students to stay on top of material, which ended up being helpful.
Do practice problems and make sure understand wiley. Prepare before class.

Do the learning guides. Understand concepts, read book chapters, do "read-study-practice" section of wileyplus before quizzes. Advocate to the wileyplus people to post the go tutorials much earlier. Understand concepts and then practice. Go to office hours when you are confused. Listen to your professor's advice. Also go to the math review part through McGraw. You may think you have a strong math background until you cannot remember how geometry works. Also go to McGraw night study sessions with the tutors available to help you!
Do the readings and seek to get some help from the preceptor if necessary.
Do well on the quizzes and Professor Uson is great!!!
Don't do it if you don't have to. Thank goodness I stuck with 101 and not 103. Get McGraw help or office hours or something.
Don't take if you don't have to. Take the weekly quizzes seriously.
Don't take if you don't have to. This is certainly not a course for fun or to fulfill the STL requirement.
Don't take this class unless you love physics or are required to do so.
Don't take this course unless you need to.
Don't take unless you have to

Don't unless you have to. If you're pre-med, just do it-- it's not hard after the first few weeks, especially in comparison to 103 or 105. Learn the material on your own by doing practice problems, reading the book, and checking out past quizzes. Don't expect lectures or precepts to be very helpful or clear. Don't expect this class to give you a love of physics, especially if you already dislike the subject.

For a requirement, especially a core science, it's a good course. Have Uson as a preceptor, he's fantastic, and sweet, and endlessly patient (and provides pizza for study sessions). Keep an open mind about it, and do your practice problems. You're going to do well if you do the practice problems.
Generally, students do not think introductory physics is structured well at Princeton, but this class is bearable because the teaching and TA faculty are experienced, helpful, and reachable.
Go over old notes once a week and you'll do fine.
Go to office hours, it is easier to learn from Uson individually than in a group setting.
I struggled in this class because I had never taken physics in high school. But in general it is a fair and well-taught class.
I would tell them not to take it unless they need it because it is not particularly interesting.
I wouldn't take this course simply for general interest. Only if you need it or it would benefit your major or career plans.
I wouldn't touch this course with a 39 and a half foot pole.
If you are a biology major and need to take physics but are more interested in biological applications, a new physics course (PHY 108) is being offered for this purpose.
If you are a natural at physics, this course will probably go quite smoothly for you, though there will be a few challenges. If you are not, be prepared to work extremely hard!
If you are pre med, take this course.
If you get McDonald, switch or drop.
If you have any questions, Prof Uson is super helpful!
If you took high school physics, most of this should be review, but there is still a lot of work involved, even though it's only 101.
It's phy 101, you probably have to take it, do lots of problems before the exams

Just stay up with all the course work! Always do your wiley plus and you'll be fine. Also, go talk to Juan! He's SO nice, helpful, and super willing to help you understand the material. He's one of my favorite professors at Princeton and probably one of the most committed to his students and their learning.
Lecture demonstrations are cool and precepts can help, but you learn physics by teaching yourself to understand it.
Most people in the class took it probably because they had to; PHY103 or 105 might be a better option if you just want to learn physics and have calculus background.
Overall a great course and professor uson is the best.
Really engage in precepts and make sure to do the assigned readings as they are essential for the tests and quizzes.

Stay on top of the material and actually attempt the problems before you ask for help; it'll help you in the long run. Make full use of the extra help sessions and office hours. 

Otherwise, everything else is straightforward! Definitely an AMAZING class: can be taken by people with a scientific incline or not-- did not really matter because regardless the material was presented in a friendly yet intellectually stimulating way.

Students should make sure to do the recommended questions from the book and the learning guides every week. I found them very helpful in reinforcing skills and preparing for the weekly quizzes. Also, office hours can be very useful if you dont understand something.
Study. A lot.
Take it if Uson is teaching! Get into his precept as well. He's excellent. Fun class.
Take it if you are pre-med.

Take it if you need it. It has a heavy workload if you only need to fulfill your STL requirement, but if you're a premed, TAKE IT. Take it over PHY 103--you only need a 101 level understanding of physics for the MCAT anyway. PHY 103 is not worth the pain, unless you plan on becoming a BSE student or a physics major. The concepts in 101 are basically like AP Physics B, except the pace is much faster. We pretty much finish 1-2 chapters per week, so stay on top of your work.
Take it only if its a requirement.
Take it, ignore anyone's criticisms- if you stay on track, you'll learn a lot.
Take it. Physics is fun! Well, maybe just bearable... But can be fun!
The title PHY 101 is misleading. This class is hard. Take 103 if you know calc. You can still study engineering as opposed to premed.
This class is a typical introductory physics class. I would recommend doing a lot of practice problems since this is the best way to get a good understanding of the material.

This course starts out relatively easy, as long as you took Physics before. However, after the midterm, the sections become increasingly more difficult, and it becomes much more necessary to attend class. The especially difficult topics are Fluids and Thermodynamics, in my opinion. This class requires some weekly discipline, since there are online homeworks due every Thursday and Sunday, and a quiz every Monday. These are important. Labs are a pain and should not be required for this class, and they don't even help your grade because preceptors are instructed to maintain a certain average. All in all, this class is necessary and manageable.

This is a pretty entertaining class. The lectures are fun to go to. The classes help you learn how to do things. Wiley computer program is a pain, but the professor Juan really cares a lot for his students.
Use the textbook.
You probably have to take it anyway, so trying to dissuade you won't make a difference.
don't take it unless you need to
dont take unless you have to
prepare in advance for lectures or it is hard to follow
prereqs: Completion of laboratory experiments is mandatory. A working knowledge of algebra (up to quadratic equations) and trigonometry (solving triangles, vector projection) is required..
descrip: The course is concerned with an introduction to the fundamental laws underlying physics and having general application to other areas of science. The treatment is complete and detailed; however, less mathematical preparation is assumed than for PHY 103-104. Mechanics and thermodynamics are treated quantitatively with a special emphasis on problem solving. In the spring semester PHY 102 covers electricity and magnetism, optics and relativity using the topics treated in PHY 101.

title: Beginner's Russian I
reviews: Complete all homework assignments as efficiently and as completely as possible so the material stays with you as you proceed.
Definitely review every day!

Do not take it. If you want to learn Russian, go to Russia after graduation, or go to Middlebury in the summer. I wish I did not have to waste another course next semester in this terrible department.
Get ahead early on
Great course! Mark is a fantastic, and very knowledgable professor.

I would recommend this course but warn you that as all 101 language courses it definitely requires a good deal of work and dedication.  You will be expected to memorize a lot of vocabulary and will dive into grammar relatively quickly.  After taking both Spanish and Arabic here at Princeton, I was impressed by the difficulty of the Russian 101 course in terms of the amount of vocabulary specifically.  With that being said, you will learn a lot during one semester and Russian does have cognates with English.  I think that taking this course can lead to amazing summer opportunities like studying in St. Petersburg and you definitely learn a lot of Russian which is amazing.
I would tell them to take the class because it is very enjoyable, interesting, and worthwhile.
If you enjoy learning languages, you will probably find this class too slow-paced. Get yourself a decent book of Russian grammar and then listen to songs/movies/online recordings.

If you have any interest in Russian affairs, history, or literature, you should take Russian. It is not super difficult, there is not much work at all, and the grading is super reasonable. That being said, it'll only be fun if you like hearing about Pushkin or Dostoevsky.

If you have any interest in the Russian language do it.  Don't worry if you feel overwhelmed and intimidating in the first two weeks, after that the alphabet clicks in and the process becomes much smoother
It's a good course in Russian and it's actually not that hard.
Keep up with the vocab!
Prepare to have to study heavily, but expect to speak the language fairly well by the end of the course, should you decide to take it.
Probably quite good if you know nothing about Russian

Russian is a great language, especially if you are willing to put the time and work into the class! Skipping classes (even for sickness) will put you behind quickly and you should always start memorizing new vocal before you think you have to,

Russian is a very tough language.  If you are simply taking an introductory language class to meet Princeton's language requirement, don't take Russian (for the same reasons that you wouldn't want to take Arabic or Mandarin).  However, if you are at all interested in Russian this was a great introductory class.
Stay on top of the homework, because it can pile up quickly! Practice your speed-cursive, because tests can be very long!
Take it!

This is an easy fifth course, despite meeting daily and having daily homework. For somebody who is serious about learning Russian as quickly as possible, it can't hurt to take a course, but most of the learning will have to come from friends or online, because the slow pace of the first semester can be frustrating.
descrip: The objective of RUS101 is to give a basic knowledge of Russian. All aspects of introductory grammar are thoroughly presented in this course, with emphasis on conversation throughout the term.

title: Religions of Late Antiquity Workshop
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop providing students in the Religions of Late Antiquity with the opportunity to present their current research for discussion. Note: REL 525 (fall) and REL 526 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Environmental Decision Making
reviews: Awesome class! If you are willing to get out of your comfort zone and take a class that will make you think creatively and critically about the environment, take this class. Professor van der Vink is passionate, knowledgable, and funny, and while the work can be challenging, he is a fair grader.
Definitely take this class. Professor van der Vink is an awesome teacher who truly cares about his class. You will learn valuable skills that you will use in the future.
He's not teaching it anymore, which sucks :(
I think it isn't being taught again but if it is, go ahead if you need a QR. You'll be happy you did.
I wish everyone could take this course.
I would strongly recommend this class to any student interested in learning about sustainable policy/decision making.
If professor van der Vink offers this class again, definitely take it. Take any of his classes, they will be hard and challenging but are well worth it. He teaches you a new way to think.

If they ever offer this course again, YOU MUST TAKE IT. This course justifies classroom education as opposed to online learning. There's nothing you could read or watch that would replicate the experience of GEO 197. It radically altered my opinions on climate policy and social entrepreneurship. What we learned went way beyond academic material. This course teaches you how to approach problems and effectively communicate ideas. Professor van der Vink is the best instructor I've ever had and likely the best I will ever have. He's dedicated, funny, inspiring, and full of amazing experiences. He wants all his students to succeed. Yes, the course is a lot of work, but I can't think of a more rewarding experience than this.
If this course is offered again, take it! Devote time and energy to the assignments. Don't worry about taking notes, just listen well. And become friends with Professor Van der Vink!
If you need to fulfill a QR, this is DEFINITELY the way to go. Even if you're not interested in the subject matter, you will grow to love this course.
If you're interested in business, politics, the environment, or sustainability in developing countries, take it. Aka, if you're interested in anything take it
It's a good QR to take if you aren't a math person.
Start on the problem sets early.
TAKE IT AND ENJOY!!!!
TAKE IT!

TAKE THIS CLASS. Gvdv is a very interesting, smart and funny professor who has an immense capacity to facilitate learning without a huge emphasis on "the right or wrong answer." The skills I acquired from this class will last me a life time.
Take it! It is vdV's last hurrah so the course may be different, but an excellent course to take.

Take it!!! van der Vink is a fantastic and inspiring speaker. Pretty straightforward class, not very stressful, but you learn some important lessons and contributes to as well as might change your way of thinking.
Take notes, ask questions, go to office hours! Office hours always help elucidate assignment requirements and its a great way to get to know the professor better
This course is the best out of all the courses that I've taken throughout my entire life. Although it's a tough course, it's all worth it. DEFINITELY TAKE IT. You'll never regret it.
This is a fun class and a great QR for people who don't like math. Cool field trip to the beach!

This was the best course that I've taken at Princeton. van der Vink is one of the funniest, most engaging, and kind Professors at Princeton. You wont learn formulas and topics that you will forget in a year or two, but how to communicate, approach a problem, and have fun while doing so.
Understand that van der Vink has very deliberate lessons he wants to teach-- you have to go with his flow.

Van der Vink doesn't lecture, he talks about himself. He gave us one assignment with deliberately misleading instructions just to trick us, and then gave us another assignment so that we would 'learn from our mistakes.' No, don't take it.
take it.... oh wait the stupid Geology department is canceling the course
descrip: Use of scientific data and arguments in formulating environmental policies, international development, poverty reduction, economic growth, conflict, and risk assessment. Class format consists of case studies for which students analyze the scientific arguments, evaluate the data upon which they are based, and determine the scientific credibility, political feasibility, and economic consequences of the various decisions.

title: Urban Modernism and Its Discontents
reviews: Absolutely take it if you're at all interested in urban studies or architecture. Professor Carvalho is an amazing instructor.
Definitely take it! an interesting way to approach urban studies.
Enjoy it!
Great professor, interesting topic. Take it if you're interested in LA or architecture, or both!

Professor Carvalho is awesome. He is super engaging, incredibly knowledgable, and a really nice guy. You will learn a lot about cities and Brazil and the discussions can be a lot of fun. Some material may be more accessible or enjoyable than others depending on your academic background and interests, but overall the course was very enjoyable and strongly recommended.
Take it, be ready to learn new things!
Take it. Bruno is an excellent teacher.
Take this class! Probably one if not the best classes I have taken at Princeton. And Bruno is a professor you must take a class with at some point in your Princeton career.
descrip: This interdisciplinary course explores some of the tensions between modernization projects and cultural production from the 19th century onward, examining representations of cities in literature (poetry and prose), maps, film, painting, theory and policy.We will focus on the cultures and histories of major cities in the Portuguese-speaking world, but will consider them in a global context.Topics include Rio de Janeiro's favelas and potential consequences of the 2016 Olympics; the architectural history of the modernist capital of Brasilia; Sao Paulo's explosion into a megalopolis; contemporary urban innovation and environmental challenges.

title: Italian Civilization Through the Centuries
reviews: Great class! Do all the readings!

I would recommend this course, but I will have to say that this class if not easy. It will challenge your ability to utilize context clues in helping you with reading comprehension. That being said, the exposure that you receive from all of these works will make you a much better student of italian. I you plan to study the Italian language seriously, then I would suggest taking this course.
Take good notes during lecture; these will be important for the weekly short essays!
Take this class!  It's a decent amount of work, and you definitely should do all of the readings, but it's a lot of fun and it definitely improves your Italian.
This should certainly be on your radar if you've taken the introductory Italian courses and are interested in pursuing the ITA certificate (or if you just like Italian, like me.)
prereqs: Italian 107 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is designed to give an overview of pivotal moments in Italian culture, such as the relationship between Church and Empire in the Middle Ages, Machiavelli's political theory during the Renaissance, and the rise and fall of Fascism in the 20th century. Through the examination of the most relevant intellectual, historic, and artistic movements and their main geographical venues, students will be able to acquire a comprehensive understanding of the development of Italian history and civilization.

title: Ethics in Context: Uses and Abuses of Deception and Disclosure
reviews: Big emphasis on discussion, sometimes a lot of reading, but overall quite a good course (Lederman is great, and lots of support for final paper)

Definitely take it if you're interested in anthropology or ethics. The course is really interesting and pretty relaxed. However, consider the fact that it's a seminar so you have to speak up and be engaged.
Great EM for people who aren't interested in "right and wrong"
Interesting class. The main workload comes at the end of semester so this would go well with a class with weekly assignments.
Interesting material, just go to class and read the readings and you will be fine. But it helps if you are confident to speak out in a class of about 25.
It's not too hard and usually interesting.
Keep up with the readings.

One of those classes where you really get as much as you put in. If you participate and do the readings, then you will enjoy this class. If you don't put in as much effort, it's not as engaging (expected).
Participate aggressively so you get a lot of feedback on your thoughts.
Take it! It's a great course!

The topic is great, the readings are great, but honestly the professor was my least favorite part of this class. You have to raise your hand in seminar and wait to be called on. Oftentimes, you don't get a chance to talk until the discussion has progressed to a different topic. Also, the discussion doesn't flow naturally like in other seminars since the professor stops after every single person in order to go on a 2-minute spiel about something. Going to class was awful. You don't get the intimate feel of a seminar. Hated this class so much. Like actually despised it. Also the grading was harsher than necessary since the things that the professor wants are non-intuitive and not detailed very well in the syllabus.
DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS
prereqs: This course approaches ethics as culturally-meaningful social practice. No prior anthropology courses are expected; however, students with prior training in anthropological field methods are welcome to incorporate fieldwork as a basis for the final paper..
descrip: Stage magic delights us with expert illusions; biomedicine and other fields use deception as a research tool (e.g., placeboes); and everyday politeness may obscure painful truths. With deception and disclosure as springboards, this course explores the contextual complexity of personal and professional ethical judgment, with special but not exclusive attention to knowledge circulation. Topics include: social fictions in daily life across cultures; the tangled histories of science and stage magic; ethically controversial cases from popular culture ("reality" TV, journalism), the arts (fictive memoirs), academia (sharing/plagiarizing), and more.

title: Topics in Social Stratification (Half-Term) - Race and Schooling
descrip: Education is becoming increasingly important for upward social mobility in the U.S. and abroad and has been linked to societal inequalities in health, income, and other life-chance measures. This seminar engages both quantitative and qualitative studies and focuses on 1) the historical trends and understanding of racial/ethnic differences in achievement, and 2) the current issues/debates within the sociology of education literature. In addition to considering the relative underachievement of blacks and latino/as, this course also examines the academic success of Asian Americans and Asians living within the U.S.

title: The Science and Art of Mapping the World
descrip: Please see freshman seminars website

title: Found Sound
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Quantum Field Theory
reviews: A really good course
A well-taught course on some of the most important theory in physics. Very difficult and a lot of time, but interesting and elegant
Be prepared to spend a lot time.

Great, but hard class! I've been wanting to learn about QFT for a long time, so I really enjoyed the course. Even though I don't think Verlinde is the best lecturer, I still think he managed to teach us a lot of the material effectively.

I would suggest that even students who have taken QFT before to at least try the class out for a week or two just to see if the approach is different from what they have seen before. At least in my case, I quickly discovered how little I knew about some of the 'basics' of qft!
Please, please go to office hours. It's free one-on-one time so take it!
Pretty time consuming. Not sure it's worth it if you don't need QFT for your research.

QFT is a necessity for any theoretical physicist!  It is not that hard and now I understand a lot more. Be aware that this course only offers an introduction to QFT; consider taking PHY 510 in the Spring.
Take it.
This is a good course, but be prepared to work inhumanly hard on psets and exams. Also, plan on taking QFT more than once in your physics career if you truly want to understand the subject.

To undergraduates considering this course: QFT with Verlinde was incredibly hard and incredibly time-consuming. It will be the focus of your semester, perhaps at the expense of your thesis. That being said, it is fascinating, and you learn a great deal. Think hard about whether this course is for you.
Try to read some of Tong's notes beforehand to get a grasp on what QFT will be like.
You MUST take this class with friends. Problem sets are much more bearable when you work with others.
descrip: Canonical and path integral quantization of quantum fields, Feynman diagrams, gauge symmetry, elementary processes in quantum electro dynamics, applications to condensed matter theory

title: Intermediate Spanish
reviews: As long as you're disciplined in doing the homework, you'll be fine. Lots of projects.
Be on top of your work
Do all the readings, because not only will your spanish skills improve, but you will learn a lot about the hispanic world as well.
Do it. It's interesting. You'll learn more than just traditional grammar, but gain a new perspective on the Spanish World.
Do the home works, always.

Do the work and come to class and you will do well. This professor is also very easy to get along with and very happy to help you in any way possible, including extensions on turning in homework and such.
Do the work and the grammar exercises and you will be fine.
Don't be afraid to ask questions.

Go to class. Do the readings and the homework ahead of time (do the week's homework on the weeend perhaps). Do the grammar and keep a grammar revision sheet - movies are awesome - shop around for classes not taught by grad students.
Great if you would like to learn Spanish.
I would advise another student to do every assignment with his best effort, as each assignment will be a great opportunity to improve his skills.
I would recommend it.  It was interesting and helped improve my language ability.  Show up to class, do your assignments and pay attention.
I would recommend taking this course if you are at an intermediate Spanish-speaking level and want to learn more about Spanish culture around the world.
I would strongly recommend taking this course if you want to improve yourself in the language and feel ready to take a more advanced language course.
I would take it again before I would choose to drop down to 103.
I would tell the student do not be afraid to sound stupid and try to keep up with your homework because if you do not do it, it will be apparent in class.

If you are an engineer and don't have to take a language, don't take this as a fourth or fifth course. If you do take this course, try to avoid taking it early in the morning because you will be tired when you come to class.

In addition to focusing on improving spanish speaking, reading, and writing skills, this class also provides a very in-depth look at spanish/latin american culture that relates to many societal problems prevalent today. Overall, the course is not only informative, but also enlightening and interesting.
It is essentially what is to be expected from a language course.
It's a great course and Prof Perez is amazing!
It's a great, interesting class, but you have to work hard!

Make sure to check Blackboard daily, as well as to keep up with the Manual de Gramatica. Be on top of everything. The class starts off smoothly and then before you know it, you have essays, quizzes, and presentations--at least one due each week.
Make sure to do the readings.
Pretty fun and interesting material to learn, love Gorka, cool dude.
Stay on top of the work.
TAKE IT WITH GORKA
Take it if you have experience in Spanish and want to finish up with the language or need it to major in Spanish. Other languages are probably better though.
Take it if you like Spanish.
Take it with Profesora Vallejo. She is very fair, and she rewards you for putting in effort even if you don't do so well.
Take it!
Take this class if you want to strengthen your spanish skills in a cultural context.
Take this class! It's fun and interesting.
This class was very fun and challenging. If you're interested in Spanish, be excited for 105! Alsina rocks.
This class will help improve your mastery over all aspects of Spanish language and culture at the intermediate level. Great class.
This course is challenging, but if you practice your Spanish skills, you will be able to do well. The material itself is very interesting.
This is an awesome course! You should definitely take it!

Try and get Anna Alsina Naudi if you can! Also, doing all the readings and thinking about the material as you go along will help you with the compositions, tests, and presentations, because they are all related to the same units.
Try to keep up on new vocabulary as you go.
speak in spanish in class
prereqs: A satisfactory score on the Department's Spanish language placement test..
descrip: SPA 105 is an intermediate language course that focuses on oral and written communication and the consolidation of listening and reading skills. Students in this class are exposed to a variety of audiovisual and reading materials (movies, commercials, newspapers, adapted short histories, and discussions on current topics relevant to the Hispanic community in the USA) that engage them in a sociocultural and pragmatic learning of the Spanish language. Students will be also working hands on technology via hybrid activities that bridge language learning with the Digital Humanities. SPA 105 prepares students to move on to Advanced 108.

title: Literary and Cultural Theory - Elements of the Ideal: Problems in Medieval and Modern Thought
descrip: This course examines natural philosophy from antiquity to the near-present. It pays special attention to the dialectic between idealism and materialism, and assesses their attendant phenomenologies. Other thinkers we will discuss that are not included on the sample reading list are Marx, Engels, and Nietzsche. All philosophy, in some sense, is natural philosophy. The problem is to know how this is, and how this isn't.

title: Contemporary Facade Design, Procurement and Execution
reviews: Insist on drawing more throughout the course.
Make sure you take tech classes. They help.
Set up a crit for the final project however you can several weeks before it is due.
Take if you are interested in the topic and willing to engage and participate.
The course is entirely case study based and involves work constructed in the 21st century. The lectures are stimulating and the topic, I felt, was incredibly relevant.

This is a good course to take if you have no previous experience in the architecture practice as it opens up the discussion to a lot of practical challenges that the architect would face in real work. The course is pretty challenging and requires strong commitment and good time management.
descrip: The course introduces students to the current state of facade design and engineering as an emerging integrated discipline and for students to develop an understanding of the global facade industry. Discussion focuses on the multi-faceted and changing role of the architect in enabling and leading the necessary collaborative process that is required to collectively achieve common goals in a discipline that is both essential to the artistic expression of building and which is highly technical in every regard.

title: Advanced Graphic Design
reviews: A unique opportunity to produce a book and practice graphic design at Princeton!! I loved my experience of it.
Definitely take it, especially if you've enjoyed other design courses here, and especially if Danielle is back!!
Do work steadily over the course of the semester, do not save up work and do it in nodes

If you're genuinely interested in graphic design, then this is one of the only and best opportunities on campus to get instruction and experience with a professional in the field. In my semester, the whole course revolved around one major project, in which each student picked a place in the Princeton area, researched it, and designed their own book to visually portray it. That said, you have a lot of freedom in choosing your subject matter and how you want to present it. And as a result, it's up to you to decide how much time you need or want to put into it. Danielle is super down-to-earth and accessible, and this will be one of your favorite classes at Princeton if you want to get hands-on practice and come out with a meaningful project to keep at the end of the semester.
prereqs: VIS 214/Graphic Design; VIS 215/Graphic Design: Typography; VIS 216/Graphic Design: Visual Form; or VIS 217/Graphic Design: Circulation.
descrip: This studio course builds on the skills and concepts of the 200-level Graphic Design classes. VIS 415 is structured around three studio assignments that connect graphic design to other bodies of knowledge, aesthetic experience, and scholarship. The class always takes a local concept or event as the impetus for investigations. This semester we will take New Jersey, as a place and an idea, as a starting point. Studio work is supplemented by critiques, readings and lectures. Students will refine their approaches to information design and visual problem solving, and to decoding and producing graphic design in print and electronic media.

title: Introduction to Formal Semantics
prereqs: Students should have basic familiarity with logical formulas (or an ability to acquire it quickly)..
descrip: We will study a formal approach to meaning that develops a technical framework for assigning meanings to expressions (primarily English ones) that makes use of functions and sets. This is a course for anyone interested in how formal methods can be applied to the study of language. The course covers material that is essential for any prospective student of linguistics or philosophy of language.

title: Fundamentals of Environmental Studies: Population, Land Use, Biodiversity, and Energy
reviews: A good course, especially if you need a PDF. Material was fairly easy to understand.

A huge amount of work for a PDF STL.

Precept was an enormous waste of time.
An okay course. Perfect for an STL/N as not much work is required. Caylor and Wilcove are quite funny and if you can get Catherine for lab it's worth it.
Definitely would have been better as an STN, but if you need a easy STL take it (even though the lab is kind of boring).
Easy STL
Go to lecture, do the readings, be engaged in precept, enjoy learning about how messed up our world is, yet keep an optimistic viewpoint.
Go to the lectures - very interesting!
Highly recommend regardless of why you're interested in this class. Best survey class I've taken. STEM people don't expect this to be math heavy.
I would only recommend that students be as diligent as they can be in their lecture note-taking. It's not safe to rely on the slides for all the information necessary.

If you want a basic intro to environmental science this is the perfect course for you (also for the science requirement as it also adresses policy questions). For science background students you may try some more advanced courses.
Make sure you are really into environmental studies.
Pretty easy course for PDFing. I crammed for the midterm and had no trouble getting a couple of points below the average. Some labs will take longer than others.

Read the readings; they are important for examinations. 

I would recommend this course, simply because I think it's the best lab course offered at Princeton for students without a genuine interest in science. However, I would recommend it more for an STN. I would've thoroughly enjoyed the course more if I didn't take it for STL.
Take it for the STL! Learn a little about modern-day issues and have fun with the course!

Take the class so that you can learn about the issues that we are actually facing in the real world, but don't expect a perfect course. The labs are frustrating but totally manageable, and the lectures/reading materials make the class worth it

Take the lab if you need an STL. If you have a good science background you will breeze through it. Just go to lectures and pay attention, I did so and only studied for the midterm for 20 minutes and got an A.

The course was far more "Fundamental" than I had expected. While I did learn some new information (or at least more specific information), anyone with any background in environmental studies or ecology will be slightly bored.
The lab definitely enhances my overall perception of the course, so I would recommend taking that
The lectures are far more relevant to the tests than the homework (which is ironically what they will tell you the midterm questions will resemble more closely).
This is a good, easy STL.

This issues are important for being a good citizen, regardless of your nationality. It is a good lab if you are not super sciency or mathy. Try not to apathetically take it just to knock out your STL though. Actually engage in the issues. They are relevant and well presented.
prepare for the lectures, and be genuinely interested in the topic.
prereqs: Course is appropriate for all students regardless of intended major. P/D/Fail option is available, but precludes qualifying for the Certificate of Proficiency in Environmental Studies..
descrip: An expanding human population and the desire of all people for a more prosperous life have placed tremendous demands on the environment. We will explore how human activities have affected land use, agriculture, fisheries, biodiversity, and the use of energy. Our focus is both global and local, highlighting not only fundamental changes in the biosphere, but also the ways in which individual decisions lead to major environmental changes. We explore the fundamental principles underlying contemporary environmental issues, and we use case studies to illustrate the scientific, political, economic, and social dimensions of environmental problems.

title: Seminar in Contemporary Art and Theory - The Aesthetics of Hunger
descrip: What kinds of aesthetics issue forth from need?
