Taking its name from Brazilian film director Glauber Rocha's 1965 manifesto, this course investigates how practitioners and critics have sought to understand political, social, economic, and material limitations as generative conditions for aesthetic form. Moving between Latin American debates of the 1960s and 70s and the contemporary moment, we examine how hunger, scarcity, and imperfection inform such concepts as violence, excess, subject formation, image circulation, geopolitics, neodevelopmentalism. Case studies include works of literature, art, cinema, philosophy, and historiography.

title: English Literature of the 18th Century
reviews: Have fun with the assignments and stay on top of reading!
Really great for a British Foundation credit. Prof. Johnson is enthusiastic, knowledgeable, and likes to assign creative projects that were actually fun to do.

don't take this class. disorganized to the extent that you cannot figure out the homework and everybody in the class has to text everybody else to figure out what the assignment even was to begin with. serious meh.
descrip: Surveying major works of drama, prose, and poetry, this course examines this period's dizzying transition into modernity. We will address topics such as race and colonial encounter, changes in class and gender relations, the contrary pulls of religion and materialism, and compelling developments in satire, prose fiction, journals, and essays.

title: Introduction to the Mechanics and Dynamics of Soft Living Matter
reviews: Do not take unless you are good at derivations/physics. Attend all lectures (participation is important, and class notes are necessary for problem sets).
Do the reading and do the problem sets ahead of time.
It's a pretty easy class. If you're interested in the subject matter, definitely take it.
Psets are hard but the course is worth it. Brangwynne is a great professor and the material is really interesting.
Read everything, and PARTICIPATE!!!
Read notes carefully and take good notes!
Take it! It's great if you have an interest in biology, and there isn't too much work.
This course is fairly difficult, especially the final paper. You should try to do the readings and start the paper early.
descrip: This course introduces the concepts of soft condensed matter and their use in understanding the mechanical properties, dynamic behavior, and self-assembly of living biological materials. We will take an engineering approach that emphasizes the application of fundamental physical concepts to a diverse set of problems taken from the literature, including mechanical properties of biopolymers and the cytoskeleton, directed and random molecular motion within cells, aggregation and collective movement of cells, and phase transitions and critical behavior in the self-assembly of lipid membranes and intracellular structures.

title: The Literature of Fact - Unconventional Foreign Correspondence
reviews: An wonderful class that I would highly highly recommend.
I enjoyed the course a lot. If you have an interest in writing and in learning more about journalism, do take this course!

I would recommend definitely taking a journalism class while you can. They are some of the greatest gems- you take an interesting class with a renowned professor who has been in the field and get wonderful access and feedback from the professors through the bi-weekly meetings. Professor Eliza Griswold was incredible; I cannot say enough wonderful things about her and the class. It really helped me think about my own interests and apply them to our assignments, but on the larger scale, helped me work on creating a path for my future.
TAKE IT. Professor Griswold is fantastic. I one hundred percent recommend this class. She is so approachable, interesting, helpful, and there is so much to gain by any student from this class.
Take a journalism course. If the professor is good, you'll get a lot more personal feedback on your work than you will in possibly any other type of course at Princeton.
Take it! Professor Griswold is fantastic! She really cares about her students and has such great stories to share.
Take this!

take it if you can, it will be One of Those Courses that bridges the gap between your student self and your identity as a person in the world. the final assignment didn't feel like a "paper," it felt real
prereqs: Enrollment by application - see course web address.
descrip: This course will examine the contemporary evolution of journalism as a hybrid between traditional non-fiction and other genres. Memoirs, oral histories, novels, poems and satire: all these forms can be now employed in the service of the highest forms of non-fiction storytelling. We will study hybridization from magazine features to book-length reportage with an emphasis on social justice. Students will be asked to respond critically to material, to conduct one substantive interview for an oral history, and to practice methods of genre bending with an eye toward developing one weekly assignment of their choosing into a final paper.

title: Pushkin
descrip: An analysis of Pushkin's major works in all genres (lyric poetry, narrative poetry, dramatic works, prose, novel in verse, etc.). Some attention will be given to Pushkin scholarship, both Russian (Tomashevsky, Tynyanov, Lotman) and American (Bethea, Sandler, Todd).

title: Computer Architecture and Organization
reviews:
- This course is necessary for most of ELE/COS students. Even if your main field of interest is not computer architecture, it provides the very useful information, which might help you. 
- Prof. Martonosi teaches perfect. I really liked the way she motivates all the students.
- Almost every session you have a problem set!
Ask questions and definitely speak up in class (the participation grade can really hurt you).
Attend office hours if you are stuck; Caroline can perform miracles.
Definitely not a bad place to start learning about the nitty gritty of Computing.  If you've taken ELE 206/COS 306 this class will be fairly easy.
Definitely take this course, even if you have no interest in architecture. It's basically puzzle-solving, and the puzzle is how to build a computer.
Generally recommended
Great and reasonable course! Professor Martonosi is excellent, and the material is very fair and interesting.
Great way to get a systems class. If you want to learn about how you get computation from current, take this class! You learn how processors work and it's only getting more relevant these days.
I will recommend it to others.
If you are interested in computer architecture, then take this class.

It's not as gruelling as some COS/ELE classes due to lack of programming assignments, but you still learn a fair amount! Maybe a bit too high-level if you've taken ELE 206 already, though. Watch out for the participation points.
Make sure you participate in classes! This is an important part of your grade. Show up to lecture and get on top of the reading and you should be fine.
Meh, take ELE 206 / COS 306 instead.
Only take if you enjoy this kind of stuff.
Probably one of the easier systems classes. Martonosi is really enthusiastic about what she's teaching, but depending on your background, it may feel really slow.
Semi-Interesting, lectures sometimes slow, workload is not bad but exams were difficult.
Take it if you are interested in learning what's under the hood of a computer.
Take it if you need a systems or are truly interested in computer architecture
Take the course if you want to learn about computer architecture. ELE206 prepares you very well for the first half of the year.

This course is a great way to learn about interesting topics like instruction sets, caches, virtual memory, pipelining and parallelism. This class complements OS very well, and I would recommend taking the two concurrently.

This is a well taught course, but if you've taken courses such as ELE206 and COS217 then quite a bit of this course will seem to pass by slowly. Participation is 25% of your grade, so keep that in mind as you go to each class. Otherwise, a pretty good course to take.
Very good class!

Very reasonable workload and exams for a COS class. Highly recommend for a departmental. Professor Martonosi is a great professor and makes the class interesting. Was slightly intimidated by the idea of computer hardware and architecture, but the material was really manageable and made sense. Exams etc are very fair.
Well taught and good material, but not the best layout.

Workload is around average for a COS class.  Homeworks are due every class and can take anywhere from 1 hour to 3/4 hours (with the reading).  I took this class with 3 other COS classes and had a really difficult semester but it was doable.
course is well taught/structured

if you have done 206 and 217, no need to take this class. you really won't learn anything new. even if you haven't taken those classes, just avoid. tbh the class doesn't teach ANYthing that is more than basic or can't be learn on your own. plus, exams and assignments are vague and poorly specified. the professor doesn't know the subject well.
prereqs: COS 217.
descrip: An introduction to computer architecture and organization. Instruction set design; basic processor implementation techniques; performance measurement; caches and virtual memory; pipelined processor design; design trade-offs among cost, performance, and complexity.

title: Independent Research Project
descrip: Independent research or investigation resulting in a substantial formal report in the student's area of interest under the supervision of a faculty member.

title: Faith and Power in the Indian Ocean Arena
reviews: Definitely take this course. It's a good introductory course but more importantly region specific. The professor is amazing but you must have some interest in the subject matter in order to engage with it.
Highly recommend - topics were fascinating and Professor Laffan is awesome and hilarious. You will learn so much and have a great time doing it. Prior knowledge helps but is not necessary.

I think this is a topic everyone should look at. The Indian Ocean was a meeting point for so many empires/civilizations/nations and not much is known about the political, geographic, or religious history of the area. This course gave a very thorough and wonderful review of everything. Also, Laffan's dad-jokes are hilarious :)
I would take it even if you did not know a lot about the Indian Ocean arena.  Professor Laffan is a great guy and he will give you a great start towards understanding the area
Just make sure you try to get the geography of the region down before you try to get the history down. but definitely take the course
Laffan is great.
Make sure to do the readings
Professor Laffan is one of the best professors in Princeton.

Stick through the first few weeks, where it seems like the readings are endless and a bit on the dry side of things. The reading load really does lighten up, and you'll learn so much about this region. It's a great distribution requirement to broaden your global knowledge.

TAKE THIS COURSE! You will love this course and will find it very interesting. Professor Laffan is an amazing lecturer and you will learn a lot. He makes the history of this region very interesting and engaging. You will never be bored and you will constantly learn something new as you travel around the indian ocean each lecture.
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: This course offers a chronological and topical overview of one of the world's most diverse and contested spaces. Sketching the deep linkages between East Africa, the Subcontinent and Southeast Asia, short focused readings and in-depth precepts will highlight such issues as the spread of Buddhism and Islam, the rise of colonialism, the importance of nationalist and third-worldist movements, the struggles for exclusive ethno-religious enclaves and the consequences for diasporic communities with ever-tightening links to the Americas, Europe and Australasia.

title: Francophone Literature and Culture Outside of France - The Francophone Caribbean
descrip: An examination of the literature and theory of the francophone Caribbean from the Haitian Revolution to the present. The course focuses on how literary creation, history and theoretical reflection united in this unique and compelling culture.

title: Topics in Social Anthropology - States in Crisis
descrip: This seminar explores states in various kinds of crisis: their "weakness" and "failure," their borders and margins, their porosity and dysfunction, their proxies and pawning, their disasters and debts, their violence, their corruption - as well as opposition and threats to state power: dissidence, social movements, paramilitary organizations, communal and corporate sovereignty. Readings tack between theories of what the state is and is not, and recent ethnographies that propose critiques, re-imaginations, and oblique visions of the state - opening new avenues to examine agency, justice, economy, and social ties.

title: Writing about Science
reviews: BEST CLASS EVER. If you have any interest in science and any interest in writing ABOUT science, you need to take this class. I loved every second of it, and even though it's a 3 hour seminar, it doesn't feel like it. Honest. There are just so many interesting facts and stories from the world of science journalism that Michael tells you about. One of my favorite classes at Princeton, ever.
Definitely take it if you're interested!
I highly recommend taking this course.
If Lemonick is teaching it, take it.
Mike is a great professor and has a lot of experience to drawn on for the class. Assignments are varied and engaging. Easy amounts of reading and writing.

Professor Lemonick is a professional journalist. You're not going to learn journalism better from any other source. The course isn't entirely structured, which has good and bad points. Good - there is a lot of flexibility in the seminar conversations, and you can tailor your learning through questions and such. Bad - you have to make sure you feel like you are learning the more "lecture-like" concepts yourself, because tangents can sometimes throw off the seminars. Lots of guest speakers are great though - you certainly won't be bored.
Take it if you like Mike's laid back, rambling style, or if you enjoying doing and talking about science writing.

Take it! It's worth taking just to get to know Mike, who is a fantastic person and professor, but it's also a great introduction to science journalism. The workload is manageable and actually fun. If you have any interest in communicating science to a general audience, this one's a no brainer. Just do it!
Take this class if you have real interest in a scientific field-- you'll write best when you're pulling from your own background and expertise.
Take this course, I promise you won't regret it!
The readings are fun and interesting, pick topics for papers that excite you, and use the feedback from Professor Lemonick.

This class epitomizes the "you get what you put into it" ideal. Mike gives excellent feedback on your papers, but this isn't as useful if you don't put that much effort into them in the first place. An easy class to coast through, but one that you miss out on a lot if you do so.
prereqs: Must have fulfilled writing requirement.
descrip: This workshop-style course is designed to teach students in both science and non-science majors how to write about science "broadly defined to include physical science, biomedical science, environmental science, engineering and technology" in a way that non-scientists can follow. The goal is to instill not only an understanding of scientific results, but also their context, along with the nature of the scientific process itself. In order to do so, we'll focus on several important aspects of the writing process.

title: The Ordinary
reviews: Be prepared to engage and discuss each seminar.

Enrique is a fantastic instructor, and the paper is almost entirely self-directed. If you come to class engaged, do the readings, and ask lots of questions, then you will get a lot back out of the seminar.
I think it is better to have some knowledge on modern architecture theories.
Take this course if you're interested in the relevance of research/documentation in contemporary architecture discourse.
This course is too abstract, too conceptual and too diffuse. I felt that this is the course in which I have learnt least.
This is a reading and discussion intensive course. Its objective is to expand upon your conception of 'the ordinary' as a means of discovery and to search for ways of doing that in your own work.
prereqs: Course is best suited to students in the School of Architecture. Interested students from other departments should consult the instructor..
descrip: This course examines the notion of the "ordinary," and the ways in which it has been exploited as a site of inquiry in the architectural debate, particularly from the mid-1950s to the present. Structured upon a series of projects dealing with the scrutiny of so-called existing conditions--from Alison and Peter Smithson to Aldo van Eyck, Reyner Banham to Robert Venturi and Denise Scott Brown, Rem Koolhaas to Atelier Bow-Wow--we will interrogate the ways in which architecture has dealt with emergent and seemingly irreducible urban phenomena, as well as has by the same token constructed a peculiar practice of architectural theory.

title: Sociology of Culture (Half-Term)
descrip: The course provides an introduction to the sociology of culture, exploring work that draws on different theoretical traditions, addresses different scales of analysis, and employs different research methods. Topics include culture and cognition, Weberian (ideas, status cultures), Durkheimian (ritual, social classification), and Marxian (hegemony, ideology) traditions, production of culture, and new modeling approaches to the study of cultural change.

title: Freud
descrip: Through close reading of primary texts, this course offers an introduction to the diversity of Freud's writings, and to the movements of his thinking until his death in 1939. Beginning with the Studies on Hysteria (co-authored with Josef Breuer in the mid-1890s), which presents the practice and theory from which twentieth-century psychoanalysis would develop, we will consider the conceptual questions and innovations that occupied Freud across the next forty years, with readings on key topics such as sexual difference, literature, culture, therapeutic practice, dreams and fantasy, and everyday life.

title: Introduction to Islamic Theology
reviews: Come to class and take good notes. Exams are very easy.
Definitely worth taking and relatively easy. Professor Modarressi is fantastic, get to know him!
Do the readings and talk to the professor if you are confused.
Take this course- I was definitely excited for every seminar.

This is a great class for anyone interested in learning about Islamic theology.  The topics are all relevant today. After taking this class, I feel comfortable being able to discuss Islamic theology with others.
descrip: This course is a general survey of the main principles of Islamic doctrine. It focuses on the Muslim theological discourse on the concepts of God and His attributes, man and nature, the world to come, revelation and prophethood, diversity of religions, and the possibility and actuality of miracles.

title: International Trade I
descrip: The determinants of foreign trade: (1) inter-country differences of factor endowments and technologies and (2) scale economics and imperfect competition are studied. Dynamic comparative advantage; innovation and growth; factor movements and multinational corporations; gains from trade; tariffs and quantitative restrictions on trade and their role in dealing with market failures and oligopolies; the political economy of trade policy; international negotiations on trade policy; and economic integration are studied as well.

title: Theories of Judicial Review
descrip: An introduction to the debate over the legitimacy and proper scope of judicial review and the empirical literature or judicial review and judicial politics, with a goal of connecting debates over what the Court should do with an understanding of what the Court can do and has done.

title: The Islamic World from its Emergence to the Beginnings of Westernization
reviews: Definitely take this as a very good and manageable survey course
Do the readings, take the papers seriously, ask questions, GO TO OFFICE HOURS because Professor Cook is very helpful and eager to provide knowledge!
Great course for getting to understand the development of Islam into the political, religious, and cultural force it is today. Course load is not too hard, and Professor Cook is extremely nice.

If you want an straightforward overview of Islamic history, this may not be the course for you. If, however, you want to take a course with one of the foremost scholars on the subject in the world, and understand how he approaches historical scholarship, this class may well prove indispensable to you.
Take it. Michael Cook is great
Take this course if you are at all interested in the Muslim world.  A very comprehensive and oftentimes nuanced look at a massively important part of the world.

This is a good high level tour of Islamic history but neither that detailed or excellent. When Professor cook is talking it is a wonderful seminar, unfortunately the far less knowledgeable students talk or lead the discussion for at least 30% of class time
descrip: Begins with the formation of the traditional Islamic world in the seventh century and ends with the first signs of its transformation under Western impact in the 18th century. The core of the course is the history of state formation in the Middle East, but other regions and themes make significant appearances. The course can stand on its own or serve as background to the study of the modern Islamic world.

title: Studies in Greco-Roman Religions - Community Formation in Early Christian Sources
descrip: Course focuses on basic primary sources, both Greek and Latin, that offer evidence for the early history of Christianity (100-400 CE). To allow for breadth of reading and to include participants from various departments, one may read primarily in English, with reference to the original texts as necessary.

title: Early Christian Biblical Interpretation
reviews: Do the readings every week and ask good questions in class!
I would recommend this course to students from all majors. It is a great course if you find the course material interesting. The assignments are manageable and the readings are cool.
If you've been reading your Bible but don't know what the Septuagint is, I highly recommend taking this course. You also get a break for Late Meal, which is always a plus.

It's a very enjoyable class if you're interested in early Christian biblical interpretation. It's not too much work, and the professor makes the work geared towards students' interests (you get to pick the topic to write an essay on, and you can usually tell him if you want to present on a specific article in class rather than another).
Take it! It's a chill and informative way to fulfill your HA requirement.

Take it! You will learn so much about the origins of the Bible. Professor Papoutsakis is very good about not stepping on anyone's religious beliefs while maintaining an academic approach. He's also just a fantastic person.
Take it, whether or not you know anything about the Bible. It's very interesting to learn the History of it. That said, you don't read the Bible at all in this class.

Take it. He's so chill, he just wants you to care about the material and learn, he's not about making it hard so you can prove yourself for a grade. Just take it out of interest for learning more about the Bible.

This course is amazing. If you are interested in learning more about the early history of Christianity then you should definitely take this course. It's not too much work and Professor Papoutsakis is the man.
prereqs: No prerequisites, or restrictions. Primary sources will be read in English translation..
descrip: In this seminar, we shall study the ways in which the Christian Bible, comprising the Old and the New Testament, was interpreted in the early Church. After a broad survey of the history of Biblical interpretation to the end of the sixth century, we shall focus on the exegesis of specific Biblical themes (The Creation Narrative; the Story of Cain and Abel; the Sacrifice of Isaac; themes from the Book of Daniel; the Adoration of the Magi; Christ's Entry into Jerusalem; Lazarus and the Rich Man). Primary sources will be read in English translation.

title: Invective, Slander, and Insult in Latin Literature
reviews: I would advise the student that the class gets progressively more difficult as the class progresses through authors, something that can only be expected but should be anticipated properly.
This is a great course pulling from many different Latin authors, and while it's challenging, it is definitely doable and your Latin will without a doubt improve over the course of this class.
prereqs: LAT 108 or equivalent.
descrip: This course aims to build skills in reading literary Latin in a variety of genres, both poetry and prose, while introducing students to an important social function shared by many kinds of texts: Winning status and prestige by slandering a rival. The kind of insult that wins over an audience tells us much about Roman values in various realms of public and personal behavior.

title: Global Environmental Issues
reviews: A good option to fulfill the WWS science policy requirements. However, take only if you have a pre-existing interest in environmental issues.
Fun course to take if you're interested in various environmental issues and the policies surrounding them
I enjoyed it! Professor Mauzerall is very nice and so is the preceptor! They are always very willing to help so don't be scared even if you don't have any exposure to the field.
If you require a structured, well-organized course taught by theme, this is not the class for you.

If you're in the market for an introductory course in energy/environment topics, there are much better courses to select from (MAE 228/328, for example). This course was awkwardly broad and unfocused. If you've already run the gauntlet of Princeton's energy/environment courses, there is nothing for you here but annoyance with tedious problem sets that won't teach you much. Grading is rather subjective and our "final exam" was very tedious and silly, so avoid if possible.

Interesting course if you want to learn about a variety of environmental issues. Lectures and discussions vary in quality, but I definitely gained a lot from taking this class.  The workload was somewhat more than average, although usually within reason.

Take it! It's a really interesting class where you look at the issues from both a science and a policy angle. It's great whether your background is technical or policy. Lots of readings, though, so be prepared to skim at best.
They need to find a way to give better structure to this course. Also, it could do with more science material.
Try hard to participate in class.
prereqs: AP Chemistry, CHM 201, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course examines a set of global environmental issues including population growth, ozone layer depletion, climate change, air pollution, the environmental consequences of energy supply and demand decisions and sustainable development. It provides an overview of the scientific basis for these problems and examines past, present and possible future policy responses. Individual projects, presentations, and problem sets are included.

title: Writing About Art (Rilke, Freud, Benjamin)
reviews: Professor Doherty is amazing! My favorite class at Princeton thus far. The writings of Rilke, Freud and Benjamin are transformative.
Take this course if you are at all interested in the writers involved or aesthetics in general. Prof. Doherty is a wonderful seminar leader.
Take this course! Professor Doherty runs the best seminars I've been involved in. The texts are difficult but rewarding. Make sure to read them closely.
descrip: Seminar addresses significance of works of art, and of practices of writing about visual art, in the work of three great writers of German in the early 20th-century: poet Rainer Maria Rilke; founder of psychoanalysis, Sigmund Freud; and philosopher and critic Walter Benjamin. Emphasis on close reading and critical analysis. Readings drawn from variety of fields and genres, including: lyric poetry, experimental prose, psychoanalytic theory, cultural analysis, aesthetic theory, criticism. Topics include: situation of work of art in modernity; art and the unconscious; the work of art and the historical transmission of culture in modern Europe.

title: Transmission and Compression of Information
reviews: An enjoyable introduction to the underlying theory of communication systems.
Good class, good professor -- subject material is interesting, the base material relates to a lot of fields inside randomized algorithms, probability, etc.
I think this is a must take course for every undergrad. student. Especially, the ones interested in communication theory should definitely take this.
I would recommend this course for anyone who is interested in applied math and/or probability. Definitely attend all the lectures and read the textbook!
Interesting material. Well-taught.

It was a great decision to take this course! Professor Abbe is a wonderful, very engaging lecturer, and he would make sure to explain any mathematical tools/notation that he is using without assuming a lot of prior knowledge. One of the best things about this course was learning about how mathematics can be systematically, ingeniously and rigorously applied to an extremely important field of engineering - and Abbe makes sure that you can appreciate the bigger picture. Take it as along as you are interested in applied mathematics!!
It's a good course, though can be a bit tough.
Keep up, because it is very math heavy and previous knowledge is important.

This course is really interesting. Information Theory is an incredibly interesting topic. Professor Abbe was a great lecturer and teacher. Make sure you are comfortable with probability before taking this course.
descrip: This is an introductory course to information theory, which covers topics in digital communication. The emphasis is on Shannon's source and channel coding theorems, and on algorithmic methods to compress and transmit information. The class material includes data compression, entropy, some error correcting codes, channel coding, mutual information, quantization, detection, modulation.

title: Of Love and Other Demons
reviews: Ask questions about the assignments. Do the readings because you'll be able to participate in class discussions. Pay attention in class and take notes!
Class participation is important and you have to go to class to do well, but other than that the class is great and the workload isn't too heavy.
Great class! Readings are not too long, great Spanish class with literature/film components!
I love Prof. Guerrero! A great man and a great lecturer.

I took this class because I took SPA 209 (the cinema class that you NEED to take if you're interested in Spanish) and wanted another class with films in it. The material itself was a mixed bag since you have a mix of readings and movies, some of which were interesting but others not as much. Guerrero makes the class shine, though. He's an energetic and engaging professor who not only keeps the class interesting but really covers a lot of topics I never would have imagined with respect to love. Plus my conversational Spanish skills have gotten better. The workload's not too bad although it's a little annoying to carve a few hours out to watch the movies each week, but overall I'd recommend the class.

It's a solid and interesting 200 level Spanish course. Not too time demanding and interesting. Know that some of the readings and many of the movies are sexual in nature and if you are not comfortable with this, you should not take the class.
Speak in class as much as possible -- don't be intimidated by native speakers.
Take this course! Professor Guerrero is an excellent professor and extremely passionate about what he teaches. His feedback is very useful and will really help you become a better writer.
This class is great and I would highly recommend it. You have to do the readings to engage in class discussions, but they're never overwhelming and it's actually really interesting.
Very interesting, worth a look
prereqs: SPA 207 or higher, or instructor's permission.
descrip: Love is the subject of the world's greatest stories. The passions aroused by Helen of Troy brought down a city and made Homer's masterpiece possible, while the foolishness of those in love inspired Shakespeare and Cervantes to create their most memorable characters. Many powerful Latin American and Spanish stories deal with the force and effects of love. In this course, we will study a group of films and literary fictions that focus on different kinds and forms of love. We will pay special attention to the forms of narrative love (quest, courting, adultery, heartbreaking), as well as the translation of love into language, body, and image.

title: Seminar in Medieval History - The Environmental History of Medieval Europe
descrip: Reading and research seminar on the environmental history of medieval Europe.

title: Program and Policy Evaluation
prereqs: WWS 507B/507C or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course introduces students to evaluation. It explores ways: to develop and implement research-based program improvement strategies and program accountability systems; to judge the effects of policies and programs; and to assess the benefits and costs of policy or program changes. Students study a wide range of evaluation tools; read and discuss both domestic and international evaluation examples and apply this knowledge by designing several different types of evaluations on programs of their choosing.

title: Mathematics for Economists
descrip: An exposition of those parts of mathematics necessary to equip the graduate student in economics with modern techniques of analysis and empirical investigation. Service course.

title: Ethical and Scientific Issues in Environmental Policy
reviews: 100% take this class if you can.  Singer and Wilcove are both great, the material is fascinating, and the seminar structure actually works well in this case.  Plus there's really only two assignments (you lead a one of the seminars and there's a Dean's Date paper) so beyond the readings it's not incredibly demanding.  Seriously I can't recommend this class enough, I'd take it again in a heartbeat.
Good course, not too much work
Great class. Take it to strengthen your understanding of science if you are not strong in the sciences. It is a good intersection of the two topics.
If professor singer offers this course again, take it. It is his area of expertise and you will not get many chances to take a class with an expert.

If you at all care about environmental issues but want to think more critically about them, this is the course. You get a lot out of it without it being too demanding of a workload. Also, the ecological crisis is so serious and scary.
Solid class; never too much work. You don't use all of the readings though they are pretty good.
Take it if you're interested in the environment and don't have trouble staying focused for 3 hours.
Take it, whether or not you are concerned about the environment! You will learn about important issues and discuss them with informed, caring people who have interesting and useful opinions.
Take this course!

The people in the class who seemed to like it most were scientists/engineers who hadn't gotten a chance to think about ethics before. That's the target audience. It might not be as interesting if you are a humanities/ethics person.
This class was pretty cool! If you have an interest in learning about the ethics guiding the environmentalism movement, then go ahead and take (apply for?) it!
Would recommend only to those who are independently driven to conduct their own inquiries into the issues at hand via the readings.
prereqs: Open to juniors and seniors only, by application. To apply, submit a one-page statement indicating why you want to take the class and what you believe you could contribute to it. Your statement should be a Word attachment to an email sent to either Professor Wilcove (dwilcove@princeton.edu) or Professor Singer (psinger@princeton.edu) by April 14, 5pm..
descrip: This course will discuss policy issues relating to the environment, using several case studies to provide a deeper understanding of the science and values involved.

title: Audio Journalism - Radio Storytelling in the Digital Age
reviews: Definitely take it! It takes some time to do the assignments, but it is definitely worth it!
Definitely take this course, especially if Bruce Auster comes back to teach it again. It can be a lot of work, but it's also always a lot of fun.
If it's ever going to be offered again, don't miss out on this chance!

Prof. Auster is one of the most caring professors I have ever had. I also learned a ton and have a much deeper appreciation for audio journalism. Anyone who likes podcasts or public radio must take this course!
Take this class if you love radio and are ready to commit the time and energy.
This class is a great one but it takes up a lot of time. Remember to stay on top of your work and work a little bit every day if you can.
This course is such a great change from other Princeton courses. Do yourself a favor and take it.
prereqs: Enrollment by application - see course web address.
descrip: This course will focus on audio storytelling techniques and the challenge of reporting on national policy-making in an age of social media. Case studies will illustrate the best practices for reporting on stories out of Washington, with an emphasis on national security coverage. Topics may include surveillance and privacy; terrorism and the Boston Marathon bombing; and internal White House debates over troop levels in Afghanistan. The course will address the craft of radio reporting, including different styles of writing; the use of sound; the difference between print and radio; the growing role of social media; and how to conduct interviews.

title: Strategy and Information
reviews:
First, do you have probability background?
Do you know what a density function or a probability distribution is with detail? Can you evaluate expected values and such? The answer to all these questions should be "Yes!" if you are considering taking this course, because I came in with no background on that and things did not go so well.
Also, the classes are "not required" but I would say that that should be ignored because if you did not come in knowing everything then I would say that going to these would be a great decision. If you are interested in this course you should really be aware of what it entails.

I loved the course. Wish I spent more time throughout the semester reviewing material instead of all the final, where it all came together. It's very rare that a course on the "technical' side of things teaches you to think in a more generally logical and structured way, but I think Game Theory definitely does! Take it.
I would just warn students that this is a challenging course, and requires a rather solid background in mathematics.
Make sure you have the time to care about it, if you are interested in game theory it is worthwhile

One of my favorite classes at Princeton, even though I am going to medical school. The course is rigorous yet accessible. Prof. Abreu knows how to teach, and the book, problem sets, and lectures are designed to efficiently teach the fundamentals of game theory with the most learning per time spent.
Read the textbook and work on the assignments early. The class is hard but there is a lot of support available!
Take it! Really fun class! Gotta love the psets (:
Very enjoyable classes/lectures. Material is all in "economic" contexts (compare with a Math department class) but still leans theoretical.
prereqs: MAT 175 or MAT 201 or equivalent.
descrip: Explores basic themes in modern game theory and information economics. Non-cooperative solution concepts for games will be developed and applied in a variety of contexts including auctions, bargaining, repeated games dynamic interaction in oligopolistic industries, and reputation formation.

title: Biopolitics in China and Beyond
descrip: Biopolitics has been one of the most heated topics of inquiry in the past two decades in social sciences and humanities. This course traces its origins and discusses its important anthropological implications. While engaging with its major Euro-American thinkers and interlocutors in global context, this course introduces the practices of biopolitics in China to examine its non-Western roots and historical conditions unique to the discussion of biopolitics --China's modernity under the influences of its long dynasties, its semi-colonial experience, and most importantly, its communist revolution, Maoist socialism, and post-Mao reform.

title: Feminist and Queer Method
descrip: This course explores the paradox of producing positive knowledge in the absence of or in opposition to disciplinary dictates about what counts as knowledge. We consider queer and feminist studies alongside other anti-disciplinary formations.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Geosciences (Half-Term)
reviews: I think the readings are super useful to contribute to discussion, especially if you are shy to speak up. Don't be afraid to speak up, even if your opinion may contradict that of a professor's.
It is a requirement
descrip: Course educates Geosciences and AOS students in the responsible conduct of research using case studies appropriate to these disciplines. This discussion-based course focuses on issues related to the use of scientific data, publication practices and responsible authorship, peer review, research misconduct, conflicts of interest, the role of mentors & mentees, issues encountered in collaborative research and the role of scientists in society. Successful completion is based on attendance, reading, and active participation in class discussions. Course satisfies University requirement for RCR training.

title: Abraham Lincoln and America, 1809-1865
descrip: No political figure in American history has attracted more scholarly or popular attention than Abraham Lincoln. This course explores the tumultuous middle decades of the American nineteenth century through the life and career of this one man, at once so exceptional and so representative. While tracing Lincoln's biography from the Illinois frontier to the White House, we will explore how his own life was shaped by, and in turn shaped, great national questions of expansion and empire, enterprise and society, slavery and emancipation, and Civil War and Reconstruction.

title: Artificial Desires
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Political Philosophy - Political Ontology
descrip: This seminar will cover some basic concepts deployed in political thought and practice, looking at the various ways in which they may be institutionally implemented. The concepts discussed will include those of the state, the constitution and the people as well as some more regular social concepts like that of agency, corporation, freedom and power.

title: Directed Research
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed research is normally taken during the first year of study. The total grading of the course will be 25% poster presentation and 75% submitted work.

title: Responsible Conduct in Research: A Course on Ethics in Engineering (Half-term)
prereqs: This course is required for graduate students in engineering who participate in federally funded research; the course is highly recommended and/or required for undergraduate students as well as post-doctoral researchers in engineering who participate in federally funded research. There are no prerequisites for attending the course..
descrip: This course educates the graduate student of engineering in the responsible conduct of research. The lectures provide theoretical background information as well as case studies about ethics in day-to-day research situations, in publishing and peer-review, in student-advisor relationships, in collaborative research, as well as in the big picture and considerations of long-term impact. The students are provided with resources to consult in ethical questions. In small-group discussions in research field-specific precepts, the theoretical concepts are made relevant to the individual students situations.

title: Economic Analysis of Development (Basic)
descrip: Introduction to the processes of economic growth and development. The course examines various theories of development; poverty and inequality measurement; and the role of markets for credit, labor and land, as well as education and health, in development. The role of public policy will be considered within each of these topics. The course may also cover topics such as foreign aid, commodity pricing, and tax policy. (Prerequisites: 511b; 512b can be taken concurrently.)

title: Introduction to Finite-element Methods
reviews: Every body should take this class. it gives strong knowledge on structural mechanics.
This course is very time consuming.
challenging material, heavy time commitment, a lot of fun!
descrip: Basic concepts of matrix structural analysis. Direct stiffness method. Axial force member. Beam bending member. Formation of element stiffness matrix. Assembling of global stiffness matrix. Introduction of boundary conditions. Solution of linear algebraic equations. Special analysis procedures. The finite-element method. Introduction. Basic formulation. Plane stress and plane strain problems. Plate bending problems. The use of structural analysis and finite-element computer codes is emphasized throughout the course.

title: Macroeconomics/International Finance Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Advanced Design Studio
reviews: At the end, you'll realize you learned a lot, but it can be a struggle to get through Mario's very ambiguous assignments :-)
I would suggest taking a different studio, if the option is available.
Make your last studio count!
You either have to take it or you can't take it.
prereqs: This course is open to Architecture concentrators ONLY..
descrip: The Advanced Design Studio examines architecture as cultural production, taking into account its capacity to structure both physical environments and social organizations. A specific problem or topic area will be set by each studio critic, and may include a broad range of building types, urban districts or regional landscapes, questions of sustainability, building materials or building performance. Studio work will include research and data gathering, analysis and program definition. Students are expected to master a full range of design media, including drawing, model-making and computer-aided design.

title: Effective Mathematical Communication
prereqs: For second-year graduate students..
descrip: This course is for second-year graduate students to help them develop their writing and speaking skills for communicating mathematics in a wide variety of settings, including teaching, grant applications, teaching statement, research statement, talks aimed at a general mathematical audience, and seminars, etc. In addition, responsible conduct in research (RCR) training is an integral part of this course.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - The Eurozone Crisis and Beyond
descrip: In the second half of 2011, the crisis in the eurozone threatened to run out of control. This course discusses four themes: 1) the critiques of the concept of the eurozone prior to January 1999; 2) why the eurozone appeared a major success at its 10th anniversary, which coincided with the beginning of the global economic crisis; 3) the interconnected nature of the crisis, weak sovereigns, weak banks, and weak growth prospects; and 4) the domestic and multilateral measures to deal with the crisis. The course also considers the future of the eurozone.

title: Medieval Architecture
reviews: Definitely take the course if you like medieval history and art. It's a comprehensive look at the past between the fall of Rome and the end of the Gothic era; so much was built then, and the history behind those buildings so rich, and the reflections on modern society and architecture so plentiful, that there's something in the course for everyone.

If you have any interest in medieval architecture, the medieval era at all, or want to learn how to approach studying architectural elements, take this course. Go to lectures and precepts and do the readings and you will do well in the course. Memorization skills are helpful for the exams. Incredible professor who makes the subject very engaging and is very approachable.
Pay attention during lectures and go to every lectures not only because the content is interesting, but Professor Doquang provides you with all of the information you need as long as you listen.
Really low-key, interesting course. Professor Doquang is really excited to teach the material, and presents it in such a way that going to class is a nice, relaxing experience.
Take if interested in the material, but it is quite dry
Take it! It isn't a lot of work, except for studying for the exams. MSD is very enthusiastic.
Take it!!! You definitely don't need to know anything about medieval architecture to take this course and you'll leave the course feeling like an expert. : )
take it
descrip: A survey of Western architecture and urban design from ca. 300 to ca. 1500 A.D, with a particular emphasis on Italy, Germany, and France. The aim will be to explore the major developments in religious and secular architecture in the West from Early Christian times to the Renaissance. Various aspects of architecture will be considered (patronage, functional requirements, planning, form, structure, construction techniques, symbolism, decoration) with the aim of attaining as complete an understanding as possible of architectural developments and urban design in their historical context.

title: Statistical Theory and Methods
reviews:
Do not take this course with Prof Hallin. Do not take any course TA'd by Lucy.

The subject material, however, is very interesting so if anyone else teaches it, definitely take it.
Good
It might seem to be an abstract and hard to follow course, but at the end of the semester you will be so happy of taking the course with Professor Hallin.
Must-to-take for anyone want to know graduate level statistics. The notes are the same every year so it would help a lot if students read the notes before the class.
Prepare for a lot of theories.
descrip: A graduate-level introduction to statistical theory and methods and some of the most important and commonly-used principles of statistical inference. Covers the statistical theory and methods for point estimation, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing.

title: Neuroscience: from molecules to systems to behavior
reviews: Analyze your data right after the lab. Saves so much time.
Focus on the small tasks at hand and don't get overwhelmed, ask for help and make sure that both you an your lab mate know how to carry out every procedure individually, other than that, TEAMWORK!
Great course if you want to learn neuroscience lab techniques. Very lucky to have a course like this as an undergraduate.
I would say to be prepared to spend all day twice a week in lab troubleshooting with Alan and the TAs. Still, expect to learn a lot.
descrip: This laboratory course complements NEU 501A and introduces students to the variety of techniques and concepts used in modern neuroscience, from the point of view of experimental and computational/quantitative approaches. Topics include synaptic transmission and plasticity, two-photon imaging, patch clamp recording in brain slices, optogenetic methods to control neural activity and student-designed special projects. In-lab lectures give students the background necessary to understand the scientific content of the labs but the emphasis is on the laboratory work. Second half of a double-credit core course required of all NEU Ph.D. students.

title: Research Ethics & Scientific Integrity (Half-Term)
descrip: This course is concerned with the professional obligations of social science researchers. Topics covered include teaching and mentoring relationships, human subjects protections, professional codes of ethics, data management, peer review, collaboration, scientific misconduct (fraud, fabrication and plagiarism), conflicts of interest, and scientific agenda-setting. The course is intended for graduate students in Sociology and the Office of Population Research.

title: Documentary Film and the City
reviews: Absolutely take it. This class was engaging, eye-opening, challenging, and fun at the same time.

Definitely take it. Carson is a fantastic speaker/guide/teacher/etc. Only class of its kind at Princeton. Apart from being an urban studies/sociology class, you learn skills including talking to and interviewing people, film editing, shooting, discussing and critiquing your own work, and more.
Don't be afraid of your final film.  Jump right in!  Be courageous speaking with your subjects and never hesitate to ask Purcell for help!!!!

I would absolutely recommend this class. I definitely went out of my comfort zone in taking it but, in the end, am so glad I tried this out. You will put a lot of time into this class and into producing a documentary but the payoff makes it all worth it. This is a great opportunity for students to engage with the greater community and to discover their own creativity. I learned so much about so many different things, have a much greater appreciation for and understanding of documentary film making, and am ultimately really proud of what I accomplished. And the professor, Purcell, is absolutely wonderful and so willing to share her knowledge and time!
take it if you like videos and cities.
prereqs: Interested students should apply by submitting a brief (2 paragraph) email to the instructor. Students should demonstrate not only their interest in the topic but also their ability to responsibly conduct fieldwork with documentary subjects and collaborate with fellow students. Some experience with photography, video, sound recording, or video editing is useful, but not required..
descrip: This seminar uses non-fiction film to explore issues facing the post-industrial American city. Students will study the evolution of documentary methodology and apply these techniques hands-on, collaborating on short films about the city of Trenton. They will establish relationships with subjects, gather observational footage, conduct interviews, and weave narrative in a visual medium. Students will gain a greater understanding of urban history and the challenges cities face today as well as a foundation in the practical and theoretical issues of documentary. For more information, see thetrentonproject.com.

title: Problems in Ancient History - Politics & Religion
descrip: This interdisciplinary seminar explores the intersection of politics and religion in the ancient world. The special case to be studied, exempli gratia, will be Augustus' Res Gestae, although individual projects may range across the Mediterranean throughout Antiquity, and may focus on any form of surviving evidence (historical, literary, monumental, numismatic, etc.).

title: Modern Regression and Time Series
reviews: A good level of mathematics and statistics is essential. Some understanding of the language R beforehand would certainly help though is not essential.
Even if you don't do well for the math part of the course (all the midterms), doing well for the final (programming) makes up for everything. So build up programming skills.
Have some coding background and work on integral calculus before taking this class!
Interesting class, a little bit slow though
It is a very useful and interesting class.
Make sure to be well prepared with math and R before taking this class. These will be a key in exams.
Might be hard and boring at the beginning because very conceptual in math, but at the end a real skill and a real understanding of the market trends

Not a great use of your time. Not all that many hours of work, and you do learn some cool stuff, but the assignments are frustrating, the exams were all poorly written and thus somewhat arbitrary, and the final was so poorly designed that it literally crashed my R due to problems with the data provided. Take something else, and read the book and do the exercises on your own.
Start early working on the course
Take this course if you want knowledge in applied statistics with financial data. Do not attend the precepts. Rather spend time on working by yourself or with other students.
This course is very good if you want to have some basic understanding of working with real data
prereqs: ORF 245 and MAT 202.
descrip: Heavy tailed distributions and copulas. Simple and multiple linear regressions. Nonlinear regression. Nonparametricegression and classification. Time series analysis: stationarity and classical linear models (AR, MA, ARMA, ..). Nonlinear and nonstationary time series models. State space systems, hidden Markov models and filtering.

title: Institutional Finance, Trading, and Markets
reviews: .Definitely take this class! The professor is nice and makes the material seem really easy and interesting. The trading simulations are fun and instructing.
Be very quantitatively oriented. Even though it's an ECO listed course, it fits more of the mindset of an ORFE student (it's also cross-listed with MFIN surprise surprise)
Enjoyable course, definitely manageable. The trading simulations are a unique part of the course that you can't find many other places at Princeton.
Not much, really. Depends a lot on who is teaching it.
Stephan is a really nice guy, clearly young though and not an experienced teacher. I'm sure he'll get better with more experience. The in-class trading simulations are INCREDIBLY fun.
This class is fun because of the trading simulations, but the rest is meh.

You have trading simulations in Rotman trader. They feel kind of contrived though. You go over some microstructure models. But we also covered stuff on banking, asset/derivatives pricing, portfolio management. It wasn't as focused on trading as I expected. Workload wasn't that heavy.
yes, take it! trading is fun!
prereqs: Introductory Asset Pricing Class (ECO 363/FIN 501) or Derivatives Pricing Class (ECO 465/ FIN 522)..
descrip: This course covers important theoretical concepts and recent developments in asset pricing under asymmetric information, financial intermediation, behavioral finance and market microstructure. Topics include market efficiency, liquidity crises, asset price bubbles, herding, risk management, market design and financial regulation. The course examines these concepts theoretically as well as via a simulation software, whereby classic decision-making settings are realistically revisited in a competitive classroom environment.

title: Classical Mechanics B
reviews: Consider taking this course if you are at all interested in the more theoretical aspects of classical mechanics. This course gives students a good balance of theoretical knowledge of physics and advanced machinery to work through more challenging problems.

Definitely take it! This is a very enjoyable class if you?re truly into physics, which you must be since you are considering taking it. The professor is very engaging and easy to follow, but you?ll be expected to work out some of the algebra outside of lecture. Although it might not be clearly stated in the course description, linear algebra is essential to understanding certain concepts in the class, and you should take it as a coreq at a minimum. Multivar Calc should be a prereq. Awesome class. Take this class if you want to see the world in a whole new light.

I don't think "Death mech" was as difficult this semester as it's often made out to be. The class is relatively straightforward once you've mastered a few basic concepts. Just be prepared to do algebra. Take it!

I was expecting this to be a terribly difficult and painful course, but by the end of the semester, I was pleasantly surprised. Of course, the material is quite challenging, but Giombi truly knows how to lecture and how to present the material, and probably made the course what it was. Just stay on top of the work, and this course will bend your mind.

If you are a physics major, I would recommend you take this course rather than 207. This course really lays down the foundations for most of the modern physics that is to learn in the future. Although a bit challenging at times, the content remains very interesting and necessary for anyone wanting to understand a more modern formulation of most physical concepts.
If you're a physics major, take 205 versus 207. It's better taught and you will have a better understanding of physics.
If you're a physics major/certificate, you have to take it. If not, STAY FAR FAR FAR AWAY.
It seems easier in retrospect. It takes a lot of work to get through.
It's not as deadly as what they named it.
Start the problem sets early and be prepared to put in a lot of time. Work with other people and ask TA's and the professor for help, because going to office hours helped me a lot.

Take it if you are interested, especially if Giombi is teaching. The "Death Mech" name for this class is definitely a misnomer. You do learn a lot of material but the course load is manageable and the exams were fair.

Take it, it's a very good class. The moniker "Death Mech" doesn't really apply (at least with Giombi). It's a fun class and you'll learn a lot. Just be prepared to work hard and possibly receive a bad grade.

Take the time to understand the readings and to push your knowledge further when Giombi mentions salient topics during lecture. These will solidify your understanding of the subject and make it generally really interesting.
Take this course rather than 207 if it with Giombi. Amazing lecturer, makes everything seem easy, you can learn a lot!

This course certainly earns the infamous title "death mech." The problem sets take AT LEAST 10-15 hours per week to do properly. However, if you are willing to put in the time and effort each week to learn the material and do the problem sets, you will absolutely love to course. I think it is the best course I have take at Princeton so far, and probably my favorite. Just don't underestimate it.

This course, in my opinion, is only slightly more difficult than PHY 105. If you enjoyed PHY 105 and did well and still care about physics, you should take this course. 

I would say the workload is a step up from PHY 105, but not to an extent that is unbearable. The workload is roughly comparable to most math classes. It also takes a bit of adjusting to as the first several problem sets are computationally somewhat intense, while the later problem sets become quite a bit easier. 

You should do problem sets individually, but It's a good idea to form a study group at least to go over answers and talk over problems.

This is one of the few perfect physics courses at Princeton.  Giombi is a huge improvement from Jones last year, and he is the best lecturer I've ever had.  He presents the material so clearly that even relativistic Lagrangian mechanics don't seem too hard.  He clearly cares about you as a student and likes to answer questions,  and you shouldn't be afraid to approach him just because he's stoic.  Giombi is a true wise man.  The problem sets took the lecture material and made us stretch it a little bit, but as always, if you have someone to check with then there's no reason why you shouldn't be getting 100% on them.  Tests were extremely fair and the average was usually a 70 before-curve, and the curve of this class makes it easy to get an A if you have a good understanding of the material (which you should, because Giombi lectures so well).  Also, you don't actually have to do the readings, so I guess that's a plus too.

This is such a cool class--it is a beautiful utilisation of highish-level math to do real problems in interesting ways. It is quite difficult, so be prepared to spend a lot of time on it, but in my opinion it was totally worth it. I am a physics major for a reason though....
Yes, it's Death Mech, but really the problem sets were not as long as people make it out to be (maybe 8-10 hours, not 15)! Definitely a must for pursuing a serious interest in physics.
You have to take it, and take it over 207. It's very hard, but I'd like to think it was worth it.
prereqs: (PHY 103 and 104) or (PHY 105 and 106); one 200-level math course; or instructor's permission..
descrip: Classical Mechanics with emphasis on the Lagrangian method. The underlying physics is Newtonian, but with more sophisticated mathematics introduced as needed to understand more complex phenomena. Topics include the formalism of Lagrangian mechanics, central force motion and scattering, rigid body motion and non-inertial forces, small and coupled oscillations and Hamiltonian chaos. The course is intensive but rewarding.

title: Linguistics and Language Acquisition
reviews: Cool class, very little work, lots of interesting material. Definitely worthwhile
Definitely take it if you have any interest in how children learn language . Adele is awesome.

If you have no background in Psychology research, try letting the professor know ahead of time. The course is oriented around research, so familiarizing yourself with research practices would be somewhat helpful

Take this if Prof. Goldberg is teaching it, her lectures are great and the workload isn't bad. Warning, though: the textbook is unbelievably dense, and you will have to read it to learn some of the material.
This is a cool class about how children learn language, with an emphasis on the role of experience. The textbook is really boring, but not that necessary to doing well.
This is a great class for someone who is new to linguistics.

This is a great class if you've wondered what linguistics is all about and also enjoy psychology. You don't need background in either subjects to do well or understand the material in the class; in the beginning the vocabulary may be confusing but just look up the explanations or ask Prof. Goldberg. You'll learn the main debates in the field of language acquisition, the theories of how children learn words, word order, syntax etc., some neuroscience, and bilingualism. The workload for this class is not bad. Make sure to go to lectures though, and take good notes. It's easy to forget how experiments were conducted, so make notes about the methods and results and how to read the graphs as Prof. Goldberg is explaining.
Try it out. Great class to PDF.

Very fun and interesting course.  Professor Goldberg is a very engaging lecturer and incredibly helpful and approachable.  Readings are difficult, but the lectures cover the material in the reading and are fantastic.  Highly recommended.
loved this class; didnt really open my textbook once, because everything was covered in lecture. pay attention in class, as midterm/final draw directly from things prof says.
descrip: We investigate the development of language from infancy to adulthood. The class examines naturalistic and experimental data concerning the acquisition of phonology, syntax, and semantics in light of current debates in linguistics and psycholinguistics.

title: Studies in Spanish Language and Style
reviews: Check the syllabus and make sure that the weeks with a lot of work don't conflict with your work with other classes.
Definitely take this course with prof. Bono if you are interested in Spanish!
Do all of the assignments well--everything counts. Participate because it's enjoyable and it makes you better at Spanish. Spanish dept classes are pretty laid back so enjoy.
Do perfectly on everything.
Do the readings, put thought into the compositions and don't try to wing any of the roleplays or presentations. Work picks up at the end of the course so be prepared.
Go in being really familiar with your complex grammar as it will help a lot.

Great introductory course, I wasn't sure which 200-level course to take but this one is truly a great way to start your study of Spanish at Princeton, make sure to get Profesora Bono as your instructor.
Highly recommend this course, keep up to date with readings, study the grammar
I would be prepared to actually do all the work, and don't try to slack off, especially with a language because that is the only way that you will be able to improve.

I would not take this unless you plan to devote a SIGNIFICANT amount of time doing the work, daily. And if you're coming from SPA 107 in the spring, I suggest you study abroad over the summer. Do not take the summer off. You will regret it.
I would recommend staying on top of nightly work and being an active participant in class.
I wouldn't take it. Study abroad if you want to get better at speaking.
If you are pretty good at Spanish, TAKE 307. You will be upset with yourself if you take this class and your language skills are strong. Just get a head start and take 307.
If you want a class more dependent on speaking and writing Spanish, rather than being tested on specific grammar, I urge you to take this course.
If you want to continue with the language, definitely take this! It is engaging and isn't a huge leap beyond AP Spanish, although at first it may feel like it.
Make sure that you do all of the readings thoroughly, because they will usually be integrated into assignments and essays later on.
Make sure that you spend ample time on the papers and be prepared for class. If people are not prepared for class, the discussions are a bit awkward and unilateral.
Make sure to do all the readings.
Not a very time-intensive course.

Really try to comprehend all of the readings and focus on how to improve your own writing abilities. Meet with the professor often if you have any doubts, or just to talk over what they're expecting. Don't expect to improve your speaking skills.
Take it for a manageable 200-level language class.
Take it if you need it for your major only.
Take it if you want to continue with Spanish, and try to get into Monserrat's class. She's awesome.
Take it!  It's great and not too overwhelming with the workload.
Take it! After completing this course I feel like I've mastered the Spanish language to an extent and continuing onwards would be out of interest, not out of necessity to improve my skills.
Take it. Workload isn't too too bad and it is interesting and fun.
Take the course but keep in mind that how good the course ends up being often depends on the levels of spanish in the class.
Take this course if you want to refresh or strengthen your Spanish before jumping into a higher level Spanish course.
Take this course with Monserrat. If she's not teaching, wait until she is.
Take this if you want to continue in Spanish here.

The course is a good introduction to higher-level Spanish practice and exposure.  It's very hard to get by without doing the work because it will be very obvious, and it's immensely obnoxious to be partnered with someone for a project who doesn't want to do anything.  But the workload is usually light (except for weeks when it suddenly gets heavy) and the classes go by quickly with interesting activities.  Do the readings (they're quick) and pay attention, and you won't have to study very much.
The professor is really nice, its difficult it you aren't naturally good at spanish, but it is also manageable course.
There is a strong cultural focus but the course is pretty interesting.
This class is really useful if you put the effort into the readings and homework. It's possible to skate by, but it's an interesting course that's worth devoting time to.
Your Spanish will improve significantly and the class doesn't require a whole lot of work. You might want to proceed with caution if you took SPA 107 though.
prereqs: SPA 107 or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score..
descrip: An advanced language course designed to increase students' fluency and accuracy in Spanish with an integrated approach to content: classes and assignments draw on various types of texts (literature, film, visual media) that focus on Madrid and Buenos Aires. Students hone their linguistic skills by engaging in discussions about the urban environment, and its cultural and artistic productions. The course aims to raise intercultural awareness and to explore the contexts in which cultural values and meanings are created. Reading and writing assignments cover different genres, and verbal interaction and personal production are actively encouraged.

title: Intermediate Persian I
reviews: Amineh is the greatest and kindest professor I've ever had, and Persian class is just fantastic. Take it if you have any sense.
Definitely consider taking this course! Professor Mahallati is an excellent teacher of the Persian language.

Just take this course. Don't be intimidated by the language just because it's written in Persian script and whatnot. It's really not that hard, and it's such a beautiful language. Also, you will never find a teacher as great as Amineh ever.
Strongly recommended. I loved this course, and Amineh is one of my favorite professors. She is totally awesome.
Take this course if you're interested in learning more about Iran or want to learn a Middle Eastern language that doesn't take as long to master as Arabic
prereqs: PER 102 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: PER 105 is designed to introduce students to intermediate level Persian. It stresses oral fluency, written expression, and reading comprehension. It will help the students to read texts of intermediate level difficulty communicate and converse in Persian in everyday situations write intermediate narrative style paragraphs coherently with reasonable accuracy.

title: Topics in Contemporary Architectural Theory - Creative Space
reviews: Be prepared for extensive reading and constant critical engagement.
Don't expect Sylvia to get to know your name. She doesn't care. She will get to know you if you participate in discussions.

Excellent course. It helps to identify a topic that you might be interested in writing on early in the semester, and aim to present on that topic. Also, stay on top of the readings, and they are all very worthwhile.
I highly recommend it and really think the course could inspire them to do even better work.
Professor gives critical and decisive critics yet it depends a lot on one's own to make the fullest of this course
Start the paper early enough to get her a draft.

The class is okay. Topic was cool, readings were good. Meeting every two weeks really kills any momentum for the class. Sometimes Sylvia decides to leave early or not to come at all. On days when the class is good, its really good. Other days its just mediocre.

The course readings are demanding and do not always reveal their significance easily. As such, allowing plenty of time for digestion of the same content, even time for rereading brings the material into clearer focus. An understanding that the historical progression or evolution presented informs out particular contemporary situation lends the same content a certain productive immediacy.

Try to identify an aspect of the topic that interests you and pursue it with intensity within and outside the course?general discussions complement close readings, Sylvia is adept at reconciling both.
descrip: Creative Space is a double agent. On the one hand, it constitutes a new corporate vernacular that uses stock architectural motifs for commercial gain and operates precisely counter to the typical concerns of advanced architectural thought. On the other hand, Creative Space realizes the concept of `art into life' and vindicates the strain in modernist thought that maintained architectural space could positively transform the subjects it contained. This seminar investigates the emergence of contemporary Creative Space by focusing on the history of spaces of production, theories of creativity and the relation of tools and their users

title: Policy Seminars
prereqs: Enrollment is limited to WWS concentrators and certificate students. The course is required for concentrators, for whom it is considered Junior Independent Work. Junior concentrators are automatically signed up for the policy task force as Junior Independent Work, not as WWS 401. WWS juniors who are certificate students must enroll. Seniors serving as commissioners and graduate students serving as consultants may enroll with permission of the instructor..
descrip: In policy task forces, students work in groups of 8 to 10, first formulating the general problem, then engaging in individual research on subtopics, and finally presenting their inferences for discussion and debate and producing a collective policy report.

title: Introduction to Ottoman Turkish
prereqs: Command of Modern Turkish or permission of the instructor..
descrip: The course will provide the students with the necessary skills to read and understand Ottoman Turkish written in the Arabic script. The texts will consist of materials printed in the late 19th and early 20th centuries: short stories, articles and newspaper clippings. Students will acquire the basic Arabic and Persian formulas in use, along with the vocabulary and terms of the era. Equal emphasis will be given to establish a sound grammatical foundation as well as intensive reading exercises to build fluency.

title: Traditional Chinese Architecture
reviews: Attend all classes; there is little writing on the ppt slides, and so the entirety (as well as the most interesting part of the course) of information is given from the Prof. during the seminar
Definitely take this course if you have any interest in the material and also to get to know a really amazing professor.
I hope you enjoy it as much as I did.

If you have any interest in the material, or even if you have no knowledge on this subject, I would highly recommend. Really changed the way I think about architecture, even Chinese intellectual theory, as a whole. Pay due respect in this course and do all the required readings assigned, even though at no point will you ever really be tested on it. It's for your own knowledge and benefit to be involved in discussion and to get as much as you can out of this class.
