Interesting subject matter, but the class was dull at times. Not much work if you don't want to do it but that also means you probably also won't get much out of the class.

Professor Silbergeld really loves what he does and it shows. He is knowledge and engaged with students both in and out of the classroom. Take it if you have an interest in architecture or need an good departmental.
Take it if you (1) like China and/or (2) want to look at architecture as a social and cultural phenomenon.

This is a great course. Not like anything you have seen. It covers material that is difficult to encounter in other circumstances and does so very efficiently. If you are looking for a course that will force you to think in a different way and different thing, this course is definitely for you.

This is an excellent course which will expand your knowledge of ancient Chinese architecture. It is not demanding in terms of work, only a midterm and final paper. This class focuses on true learning and motivation, taking the focus off of constant testing for the purpose of proving yourself. If you are motivated to learn and do the readings, you will take a lot away from this class.
the readings aren't all necessary.
descrip: Thematic introduction to traditional Chinese architecture, urban design and garden building, with attention to principles and symbolism of siting and design; building techniques; modularity of structures and interchangeability of palace, temple, tomb, and domestic design; regional variation.

title: Main Currents of Spanish Thought, 1848 to the Present - Cultural Wars & Subalternity
reviews: Artaud used to say that actors and artists should considered themselves "athletes of the spirit". If you want to take this course ?which will be helpful in many ways, and will cover the subject matter thoroughly in a rich and deep way? you should accept the premise that you will have to endure "athletic" critical training.

Be prepared to participate, and practice oral presentation skills. The reading load is intense, but very enjoyable. Be strategic. Make use of break time to grab a refreshment, as classes can go for a very long time. You will learn A LOT. Strongly recommend.
Definitely take this course! Or at least go to the first class and judge by yourself. Questions raised in this course are hard to find in other courses.
I would strongly recommend this course because of the stimulating class discussion and weekly work that a student would receive.

Really important to understand complexity of intellectual, political and cultural landscape of Modern Spain.
Really important to learn the engaged and intense academic practice of German Labrador. He is very young, but has an impressive intellectual maturity to engage students in discussions.
Engage yourself in a experience rare in the academic career, challenging personal values, the disciplinary power in organize a seminar and your intellectual energy in discuss sometimes more than four hours!
descrip: This course seeks to explore the cultural logics of the Spanish Modernity since 1789 to the present, studying the historical configuration of Iberian Modern cultures though aesthetics, as a violent process that involves memory, power and communities. Among the topics to be addressed are places of memory, national imagination, hegemony and resistance, subalternity, political subjection, biopolitics, popular cultures, political art, underground aesthetics, historical memory, mass cultures, avant-garde and poetics in a wide range of texts and materials, from zarzuelas, theater plays and poems to novels, documentary films and images.

title: Fundamentals of Environmental Studies: Population, Land Use, Biodiversity, and Energy
reviews: A good STN course to take overall.
A really excellent option for an STN to PDF. I did minimal reading and never went to lecture and found the exams quite easy. The only downside is the weekly precept response.
An interesting, straightforward course. Definitely take it if you have any interest whatsoever about the ways in which biology, policy, and normative social thinking collide.
As is the case for every Princeton class, try your best to stay on top of the readings!
Ask the professor what they are looking for in terms of exam answer formats.
Don't expect to have to put much into the class, but do go to lectures, and ask questions.
Excellent STN! Professors are enthusiastic and material is useful. Really, really try to get a good preceptor though.
Go for it, reading is very light and you can skip /skim most of it. And if you go to lecture you'll actually learn things. Given the time investment, you'll probably get a pretty high grade.
Good survey course, but doesn't go in depth with the science, which can be a blessing or a disappointment, depending on what you're looking for.
Grading is so formulaic and unpredictable that I wouldn't recommend taking it for a grade even though it is an easy course.
Great course to PDF!  It definitely removes the burden of having to complete all of the (way too many) readings and suffering through the draconian grading of the midterm and final exam.
I would strongly recommend this course to any student at the university!!
I'd recommend it for an STN, but don't be fooled and study at least a little for the midterm and final.

If you want an easy STN/STL, this is a good option. If you're taking it for a certificate or something, then it's an easy course that doesn't take too much time. Is it the single most illuminating class I've taken here? No, but I mean the class emphasizes breadth over depth, so I expected that. I think I'd recommend this class overall.
If you're looking for a good way to fulfill a science requirement, this is a great course that is easy but also very relevant to modern society.
If you?re looking for an STN, consider ENV201A: lots of topical, real-life issues, generally interesting lectures and a good choice to take for a grade/PDF
It's a pretty easy class if you're willing to put in at least some work. Worth it if you want a broad introduction to environmental studies.
It's easy and interesting
It's essentially a humanities class that gets you a STN, so if that's what you're looking for, then you're set.
Make sure it's clear what the preceptor's grading criteria are from the get-go. And pray.
Make sure you read the readings before lecture.
Make sure you're keeping up with the class!
PDF is your best option as the work you have to put in to get even a B /A- is probably not worth your time if this is a distribution requirement.
PDF this course unless you're very interested in the subject matter and willing to invest time in the class. Wasn't bad as a PDF because going to lecture isn't necessary as they post the slides.
Relatively interesting STN - good for pdfing
Take it as a distr req
Take it if you are interested in learning about the basics of environmental policy.
Take it if you are interested in the material.
Take it if you need it for the ENV certificate or the STL requirement, but otherwise it's a little basic/boring.
Take it if you're interested/need an STN!
Take it! Everyone should be informed about these issues because they pose important policy and ethical questions for us that will define our time on this planet.
Take it.

Take this ONLY if you MUST. The atmosphere of the class is terrible. Its appropriation of ethics and economics is strange and EXTREMELY OFF-PUTTING. The students in that class were extremely rude, dispassion, and occasionally racist against the preceptor. I regret to have wasted my Princeton tuition on this class.
Take this course as an easy PDF or if you are interested in environmental studies.
The more you participate in precept, the more fun it is
This was a relatively easy STN. I would recommend it to non-science majors looking for an STN, but it might not be engaging enough for someone who already has a background in environmental studies.
Worth the STN. Easy PDF
You have to actually do all the reading in order to get a good grade on homework. Can't fake it.
definitely take this course
i would not recommend taking this course
i would only recommend this course for the distribution requirement, lots of work and harshly graded

i wouldn't recommend it, but it wasn't horrible. if you are willing to do the work you will learn a lot and get a good grade. but you have to put in more effort than you are expecting if you're PDFing
prereqs: Course is appropriate for all students regardless of intended major. P/D/Fail option is available, but precludes qualifying for the Certificate of Proficiency in Environmental Studies..
descrip: An expanding human population and the desire of all people for a more prosperous life have placed tremendous demands on the environment. We will explore how human activities have affected land use, agriculture, fisheries, biodiversity, and the use of energy. Our focus is both global and local, highlighting not only fundamental changes in the biosphere, but also the ways in which individual decisions lead to major environmental changes. We explore the fundamental principles underlying contemporary environmental issues, and we use case studies to illustrate the scientific, political, economic, and social dimensions of environmental problems.

title: Reading & Writing About the Scientific Literature in English (Half Term): Science and Engineering
prereqs: Course open to international graduate students in their second semester of study or beyond in any field related to science and engineering. Non-Credit. Enrollment by application..
descrip: Introduction for non-native speakers of English to reading and writing about the scientific literature in science and engineering. Topics include how scientists work with the research literature as both readers and writers, how scientific articles are constructed and interpreted, how research findings are presented, and how scientific arguments are developed. Two 80-minute seminars. To apply, visit http://www.princeton.edu/writing/wse

title: Ethnography, Evidence and Experience
reviews: Carol Greenhouse is worth whatever content this course teaches. She'll change your life.

Do the readings - it will make lecture a lot easier and you will do a lot better on your papers - but if you don't do the readings then listen intently to what Greenhouse says in class and ask her to slow down when you don't understand. Also go to office hours with her because she is delightful to talk to and will give you lots of helpful ideas for your papers.
If you're not an anthro major but would like a course that stimulates high level abstract thinking, this could be a good one.
Never be afraid to speak up in class and/or reach out to Carol outside of sessions - she's unbelievably encouraging and helpful.

Originally I wasn't very excited for this ANT requirement, but it has been an exceptional class. Professor Greenhouse's love of anthropology is infectious, and her lectures are beautiful, deep, and informative (though sometimes difficult to follow for these reasons). Class discussions were typically pretty great.
Professor Greenhouse  is excellent! Don't hesitate to take it with her.
Take this class freshman year. It really helps set a foundation of knowledge with regards to Anthropological thought and sources that you can look back on for other classes.
Take this class!

This course is a great place to develop your writing! Professor Greenhouse is always eager to review papers and talk about ways to improve for the next assignment-- this is definitely something to take advantage of.
prereqs: No prerequisites. Assumes basic general knowledge of the scope and aims of sociocultural anthropology, cultural studies or other ethnographic inquiry, and/or intercultural or international experience. For students lacking such preparation, any 200-level course in anthropology (or a related field's introductory course) may be taken concurrently. (ANT301, The Ethnographer's Craft in Spr 2015, is intended to supplement ANT300 but either course may be taken separately. Together they are designed to help prepare students for independent ethnographic research.).
descrip: This course relates key concepts in anthropology (e.g., culture, society, power, meaning) to everyday experience, with the aim of fostering students' ability to think analytically across diverse cultural fields. We alternate between classic theoretical texts and "dossiers" of highly current readings about issues both familiar to students (from experiences at home or abroad) and relevant to ethnographic research and writing. For example: digital media, embodied knowledge, language, ritual and symbols, textual interpretation, and modern forms of power and inequality.

title: The Literature of Enlightenment - Defining the Human
descrip: At the eve of the French Revolution, debates about identity and difference, diversity and equality, announced the stakes of the democracy to come. This course asks how political, scientific and religious discourses marked individuals as 'others' in the eighteenth century. What strategies of resistance did individuals, in turn, employ to define themselves? It considers 18th-century answers to contemporary questions surrounding sex, race and class in travel narratives, utopias and political essays. The Enlightenment's legacy, and the relation between colonial past and contemporary post-colonial struggles will also be explored.

title: Into the Wild
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Intermediate Chinese I
reviews: Assuming you have taken your first year of Chinese at Princeton, this probably won't be any different from what you are already used to. Make sure you really understand the usage of the grammar/vocabulary (particularly in the second half of the semester it starts getting more nuanced), those are weighted heavily on the tests. Language tables are a good way to get exposure to speaking/listening in a more freeform setting where you can hear newer vocabulary and express things in the language that don't get touched on in class. Speaking and listening are really crucial parts of Chinese, so that's more motivation to go to the tables and push yourself. On the weekly compositions and for the oral part of your midterm/final, really make a conscious effort in incorporating the material you've learned. Say ??????????????????????? a lot for maximal language gains. And hopefully take it because you really like the language, because that is what will really keep you going when you are putting in the work (which there is a considerable amount of).
Chinese 105 was awesome! Having classes every single day was a challenge, but I've grown used to it and I appreciate that we have a chance to practice so much.

Definitely take this course. All the teachers are really nice and dedicated to teaching you the language. It's a lot of dedication(definitely took the most time out of any of my courses), but it is effective.
Don't be nervous about speaking with the instructors in Chinese; it is by far the best tool for advancing your language capabilities.
I had 3 years of background with hs Chinese before entering this course, and I felt like I was at exactly the right level upon entry.
I would recommend this course.

If you enjoy Chinese / are interested, definitely take this class. The workload is pretty light. Be warned though: class meets every day, and grades are strongly curved towards the B range. (You won't fail, but it's disproportionately hard to get an A)
It's a hard course, and you will work a lot, but it's very rewarding. Figure out how to memorize words and their characters early on, otherwise you're screwed.
It's so much work. If you are not thinking about going to China to really immerse yourself at some point I don't think I can really recommend the class.
Keep up on all your work! You will get out of this class what you put into it, and it will help you improve immensely if you let it!
One quiz at a time
Probably one of the best ways to learn Mandarin but not to have fun or little work. The methodology is very repetitive but seems to be efficient with a substantial amount of work.
Study every day, if you don't you will fall behind quickly.
Take Chinese. It'll be tough, but it's good for you.
Take it if you like Chinese

The Chinese program at Princeton is ridiculously good and teaches you the language at an incredible pace. It takes work, but it's definitely manageable. If you see a class with Peng Laoshi especially, you should take it. He's really good at teaching you information and is a ton of fun.

This course does not have too much written work, but does require you to review the material before class each day. The teachers are all very knowledgeable and invested in their teaching. Your pronunciation and knowledge of grammar and vocabulary will definitely improve through taking this course. While you do not do any writing during class, and instead spend the time learning grammar structures and practicing them verbally, do not expect to do too much conversational speaking.
Way too much material, super unrealistic. The teachers are nice and seem sympathetic but it seems unnecessary for them to jam more than manageable workload on us. Hindered my learning
it's definitely a lot more work than 101 and 102, but it is still fairly manageable. (Just don't expect to have every word memorized)
prereqs: CHI 101 and CHI 102 or equivalent..
descrip: While reinforcing the knowledge students have acquired thus far, this course will further develop the students' audio-lingual proficiency as well as bring their reading and writing ability to a higher level.

title: Communication Skills in Formal Arabic
reviews: Depends who's teaching the course, but it's generally a pretty easy way to keep Arabic in your schedule. Not that interesting though.
I would recommend against taking this class until they revamp the syllabus. Hannah is a competent teacher; it's just that the structure of the class is boring.

Make sure you are prepared for class discussion of the assigned readings. It is especially helpful to look up vocabulary beforehand. Participate a lot in class, it is the only way to improve your speaking skills.
Not too intense. Pretty fun.
prereqs: Successful completion of ARA 107 or Departmental permission..
descrip: The goal of this course is to familiarize students with the ways that Arabs express themselves when speaking in a formal setting, and to help students gain greater confidence in expressing themselves in Formal Spoken Arabic, a simplified form of Modern Standard Arabic. Attention will also be given to developing native-like pronunciation and grammatical accuracy, as well as to enriching one's socio-cultural understanding of North Africa and the Middle East through discussions of topics ranging from the personal (food, family) to the socio-economic (women's roles, Arab cultural identity, education and illiteracy in the Arab world).

title: Student Life: The University in Literature and Film
descrip: Please see freshman seminars website

title: Quantitative Analysis III
prereqs: Prerequisite: POL 572..
descrip: Second course in applied statistical methods for social scientists, building on the materials covered in POL 572 or its equivalent. Course covers a variety of statistical methods including models for longitudinal data and survival data. Material covered corresponds to the quantitative part of the General Exam in Formal and Quantitative Analysis at Level II.

title: Fixed Income: Models and Applications
reviews: Be prepared to spend a lot of time but worth it.

Both professors were definitely knowledgeable and taught well. Students just need to have a good math foundation in order to benefit from the class, if not it'd just be a very painful semester-long struggle. So don't take it unless you know stochastic calculus or are very good at math already

Don't focus your exam revisions on the stochastic calculus of the course. There are a of discrete time concepts as well. There is a lot of attrition in the course, I wouldn't take the course without a stochal background, unless you're in the 1 year M.Fin
Excellent introduction to Fixed Income
It is a hard class butt very useful
Lots of work but very interesting class.
Take the course, it is very useful.
The course is heavy, easily equal to two grad courses
Very challenging, a huge amount of personal work but at the end, you learn a lot and understand a lot better Fixed income products
prereqs: FIN 501, MAT 201-202 and recommend MAT 203-204..
descrip: Course covers no-arbitrage models of contracts based on interest rates including bonds, forward and future contracts, swaps, options, and other derivatives, and develops the theory of arbitrage-free pricing of financial assets in discrete and continuous time, as well as many special models that can be used to price and hedge fixed income securities.

title: Modern Physics II: Nuclear and Elementary Particle Physics
prereqs: PHY 304 and 305.
descrip: Introduction to the Standard Model of particle physics describing elementary particles and their interactions. Specific topics include symmetries and conservation laws; electromagnetic, weak, and strong interactions between quarks, leptons, and gauge bosons; and experimental methods in particle physics. Selected topics covering current research in high energy physics will also be discussed.

title: Regression and Applied Time Series
reviews: 0/10. You probably will only take this course if you are an ORF major. I have pity on you.

Be prepared for a lot of math. The textbook is often unreliable (beyond the basic explanation of concepts) since the math formulas and r code are often unreliable. There is a lot of help available to you, though, if you need it. Professor Zeng was really helpful and friendly.
Be prepared to learn a lot of the material on your own. Take the practice exams and be prepared to write quickly come exam time.
Do not take this class unless you are required to as an ORF major.
Do not take this course if you do not have to. By far the worst course I have ever taken. Yong Zeng barely spoke english and had no idea how to teach a course.
Do not take unless you have to. Just awful
Don't take it unless you are very interesting in statistical analysis in R and very good at messy computation math.
Don't take this class unless you need it for ORFE.
Don't take unless you need to

Horrible class. You won't have Yong Zeng next year since he's a visiting professor, but the level of work was unreasonable, the lectures weren't much use, and the only thing that helped us survive this class were the precepts.

I didn't understand anything from this class and I was confused 90% of the time throughout this semester. Pretty much every lecture I was just blindly copying down what the prof wrote on the blackboard without understanding anything. I still don't know what this class was about, but I'm glad it's over.

I don't recommend this course if you're not an ORFE major. If you are, this course made me seriously regret not switching out earlier. I still could have this semester, but I'm almost done with the requirements at this point. I'm still not really sure what we learned in this class and we only reached time series in the last four weeks or so, which we rushed through. Although the material itself is not as hard as ORF 309, this class is not taught as well, so it is about the same difficulty. The professor gave good outlines of the textbook and expected us to read the textbook on our own, which may be fine at other schools, but isn't something Princeton students are used to, hence the complaints. He is a visiting professor and to be fair, he did often ask us for suggestions, and he could be somewhat flexible, i.e. making homework assignments optional. I wish the ORFE department spent more time on its core classes.
I mean, if you're searching this class, I'm sure you have to take it...
I would not advise this course for anyone who is not an ORF and required to take it.

If anyone is still borderline COS/ORFE, this class should convince you to switch to COS.  I just...regression and time series are very interesting, but not when taught with such a terrible textbook and with purely limited financial applications.  The R code is out of date, the curriculum is half-review, half-completely-out-of-the-blue, and I'm really sad that Princeton ORFE has not revamped this class.  It's pretty much as bad as ORF307.
If you are not required to take this course, then do not take it!
If you are taking this it is because you are ORFE and have to really good at math or are a psycho
If you're an ORFE student, you have to take it. Otherwise, don't even bother.
It is worth switching out of ORFE to avoid taking this course. Avoid if you have a choice. Or switch your majors if you can.
It's a very dry course by nature of the material, don't expect lectures to keep you on the edge of the seat. That said, if you enjoy ORF, the content is truly interesting and highly applicable.
Not as bad as it sounds.
Steer well clear, unless you need to. Some useful concepts, but you can absolutely learn them on your own and in less time.
Take if you are interested in Applied Math, but be warned you will be on your own,
Take other core classes before this one even though there are only a few prerequisites

Take this course if and only if you have to because it's a requirement for your major. It's really easy if you read the book and have problem solving ability, but it's an annoying waste of time and completely useless.

Terrible, terrible class. The professor has a big heart but ORF 405 is and has always been cursed. Lectures were regurgitations of the book (which was confusing at times and had many typos) and homework assignments are basically looking up how to do things you never learned and/or plugging in crazy equations handed to you at precept. Only took it because I had to.
The course is very variable because it is taught by a different professor every year.
The material is interesting and useful. It was a pain to go through, though.
This class was horrible, and the textbook was worse. The professor changes every year because no one wants to teach the class. Lots of tedious computation.
This course is consistently one of the worst classes at Princeton. If you have to take it, you have to take it. Otherwise, don't even consider taking this class.
This is a pretty miserable course. I didn't really learn anything and the professor can't be easily understood or heard. He is a sweet guy, but his lectures were completely useless.

This will probably be your worst class as a Princeton student. The material is hard and lecture was unhelpful (and most people didn't go). Professor Zeng is super nice and friendly and approachable. However, lecture was not at all helpful - most students would agree. This course was much better than Hallin's the year before (which I dropped) in that we had a textbook to follow, hw assignments that weren't impossible and a reasonable midterm (I haven't taken the final yet). However, all of our learning came in precept and from reading the textbook and not lecture which wasn't at all helpful. Why does the department make 405 required if they don't make a Princeton professor teach it?

Unless you have some unique hankering for really dry regression knowledge, don't take this. If you're an ORF major like me, suck it up and try to stay on top of things as best as you can. Brush up on probability and go to office hours as often as possible.

You're probably going to see a lot of bad reviews for this class. Yes, lectures can be boring at times, but the professor is one of the friendliest teachers I have ever had at Princeton. He is very helpful and answers questions clearly.
do not recommend.  please look into the professor before taking the course
this is the worst ORF class i've ever taken. beware if any visiting professors are teaching this and if so, STEER CLEAR OF THIS CLASS.
prereqs: ORF 245 and MAT 202.
descrip: Regression: linear, nonlinear, nonparametric. Quantile regression. Time series: classical linear models, univariate and multivariate; elements of spectral analysis; stochastic volatility models (ARCH, GARCH, ....); dynamic factor models

title: When Music Is Made
reviews: ABSOLUTELY take this class! Don't be afraid if you have very little music experience. I came into this class having only taken some piano lessons like 10 years ago and I thoroughly enjoyed all the assignments. However, if you have no musical background whatsoever, know that this class will end up being a good amount of outside work.

An excellent, chill introduction to music theory. Take if you are a musician like me who has never learnt music theory and wants to be able to better understand the pieces you are playing as well as learn to improvise/play jazz.

As someone who plays clarinet and piano, the first half of this course was a big review (starting from: what is a quarter note?  What is a scale?), but the second half of the course was super interesting.  You learn some really cool tools for writing songs, and I learned how to listen to music in a completely different way.
Ask for help from your preceptor with the midterm/final project. They will give you feedback that will really help you think about your composition in a different way.
Ask questions and talk to your preceptors after class. They are so talented and amazing and there is much you can learn from them.

Assignments take 2-4 hours per week. No readings, no final. Seriously, don't buy the textbook (or buy it from me, it's still shrink wrapped). If you played an instrument in high school, MUS 104 will be the easiest A of your life.
Definitely take it, but it is no longer just "clapping for credit".
Dennehy is a funny lecturer! You learn how to write basic melodies by taking this course
Don't buy the book.  Make sure you have a musical background.

Don't buy the book. Don't worry too much about looking bad in front of your classmates, because people/the teacher are generally mellow (in my class, anyways). Have fun with your songs, and don't worry too much about what other people will think about it.

DEFINITELY try to get Prof Dennehy's precept as well.
Fun class, expect to sing in front of students, bit more work than expected, but compared to other classes, quite chill and enjoyable.
Good course to have fun and fill distribution requirement.

I loved it. Easily my favorite class this semester. It teaches you everything you need to know about music theory and composing so that at the end of the semester you can compose your own pieces (for the second half of the class, all the homework is composition) - maybe you won't be the next Bach, but you know, it's enough. Workload totally doable, although I would say that you get more out of the class if you put more work into the class.

I would definitely recommend this course for any and all students interested in music that do not feel then need to continue in the music department.

Really... this course is a complete Dead End, not like PHY 103/104 where you can still take the sophomore courses, a complete Dead End in the music department.
I would recommend any class Prof Dennehy is teaching.
I would strongly recommend this course. There's really no reason not to take it.
I would tell students to attend all lectures and precepts and listen closely and they will do well.
If you have any interest in learning how to write a standard song, this is the course for you!
If you like music its good.

If you want to relearn the music theory you used to know (or never learned any in the first place), take this course! It's extremely helpful and practical, what with the songwriting assignments, yet a very manageable workload even if you spend a lot of time writing your songs.
If you've had music theory before, should be totally fine. If you don't know how to read music, I wouldn't take it.
It's good to have musical experience prior, else a PDF works too.

It's not "clapping for credit" - as in, you'll have to work harder than just breezing by. Assignments and projects include composing and arranging songs. However, it's a really interesting class and still a nice way to fulfill an LA requirement, especially if you're not fond of English classes.
Not a bad time. Writing music definitely isn't the worst homework you could have. It's probably harder if you aren't familiar with music though (which I would say most people in the class were).
Precepts are where all of the learning happens. Get a good one and actually try on stuff.

Really, the only reason you should take this course is if you have an interest in music theory and composition, yet don't quite feel qualified to take the MUS 105 or 106, track which are both tougher and possibly more rewarding. The difficulty of this course primarily depends on your previous exposure to the subject - if you don't play any instruments and can't read music, it is advisable to not take the course until you have learned these things. Except for that, the level of the course should be appropriate for any and all amateur musicians interested in theory.
Take it for fun :)
Take it if you love music! Definitely a little knowledge on music theory helps, especially with the former half of the course.
Take it!
Take it! It's not the greatest for students with no background in reading music or theory but Is otherwise amazing.
Take this course if you have some musical background.
Take this is you want basic music theory in order to compose or arrange, but aren't as interested in the theory.
There is only one week on voice leading. The course exposes you to a lot of modern music, which was eye opening for me.

This course is a good LA if you have some music background. I had prior experience with piano and music theory (ABRSM grade 8/grade 5) and found the course to be fairly easy, though much of the later material about harmony was new to me. The textbook was barely used and is not worth getting since the professor's notes are adequate and posted online, but this may change in future semesters since this is Dennehy's first time teaching it. Weekly assignments and the three quizzes were straightforward, and lectures were informative but started to become less organized and focused towards the end of the semester (just listening to various songs). We were given a lot of freedom in composing our midterm and final projects (literally just compose a song around a certain length), which was nice. When I was shopping the course, I was initially not so thrilled about composing, but it turned out to be not so bad. Professor Dennehy is a nice guy and is pretty chill. His precepts were also the best for learning material - the other preceptors seemed to ask questions or analyze pieces all the time. In short, a good LA for "baby music theory" if you prefer to learn some stuff about music rather than memorize composer birthdays as in MUS 103. However, prior music experience (reading music, keys, intervals, chords) and some piano ability for composing is definitely recommended and advantageous.
This is a really good course if you want a basic introduction to music theory without having to put in a ton of time.
it's a lot of work

very steep learning curve if you haven't taken any theory classes or played music before. Suddenly goes 0-100 in the middle of the semester for no reason. However, by the end you will never look at music the same way!
descrip: An introduction to the fundamentals of music theory through exercises in melody, harmony, composition, ear-training, transcription, instrumentation and analysis. A variety of musics will be studied. The main emphasis in the course will be on the practical and creative application of these skills in small composition assignments.

title: Empire to Nation: 20th Century Japanese Fiction and Film
reviews: Don't take this class as an easy LA or to PDF. DO take this class if you're ready to put some work in and learn a lot about Japanese film and fiction!
I strongly recommend this class if you love watching amazing films and reading literature from a very rich and formative era in Japanese history. Great course!
Participate in class - especially if the class is small. Only through talking can you get feedback on your ideas.
descrip: This course will examine modern Japanese fiction and film that engaged with Japan's shift from "empire" to "nation" (roughly from 1930s to 1960s) with a specific focus on identity formation via race, ethnicity, and nationalism.

title: Asset Pricing
reviews: Take only if strongly interested. Otherwise an empirical methods or a theoretical class might be better.
descrip: Introduction to asset pricing covering theory in both continuous and discrete time to study dynamic portfolio choice; derivative pricing; the term structure of interest rates; and intertemporal asset-pricing and consumption-based models. Pre-requisites: All required courses in micro, macro and econometrics at the first-year PhD level.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Negotiation
descrip: This course examines the principles of negotiation and provide firsthand experience in simulated negotiations. Sample topics include distributive negotiation, integrative negotiation ("expanding the pie"), conflict management, and coalitions. Research on the variables that affect success in negotiations is discussed. Students engage in a series of bargaining exercises between individuals and teams, and results are analyzed by the class.

title: Theory of Groundwater Flow
descrip: Fundamental physics of fluid flow and contaminant transport in porous media; derivation of governing equations; analytical solution of simplified equations, with application to well hydraulics; and parameter estimation and analysis of field problems. The course examines the application of numerical models and gives an introduction to multiphase flow systems and advanced methods for equation development.

title: Beginner's Greek: Greek Grammar
reviews: A wonderful class to take if you're interested in ancient languages or Attic Greek in particular. If you don't have a special affinity for language learning but are taking this class for another reason (for example, you'd like to read the New Testament in the original Greek), keep in mind that you will likely require a lot of self-discipline to stay on track. You don't need to be a genius to understand the lessons and do the translations. All it takes to be good is practice. That's easier said than done. The most helpful piece of advice I can give to you is a recommendation to set apart a 20 minute chunk each day to review principal parts of verbs. If you're going to forget everything else, fine, but don't screw yourself by not keeping up with the verbs, especially since there aren't THAT many (certainly not as many as there would be in LAT 101). Verbs are your bread and butter, and with six principal parts for each verb, you need to butter that bread daily.
It helps if you have some familiarity with another inflected, dead language before diving in.
That it is a lot of work and studying, and is more difficult if one has little or no Latin.
prereqs: Greek 101-102 are a unit. Greek 102 must be taken to receive credit for 101. Greek 101 must be passed to qualify for 102..
descrip: Designed to enable the student to read classical Attic Greek with facility; at the end of the year a short Platonic dialogue or comparable text will be read. Equal emphasis on acquiring a vocabulary and an understanding of the structure of the language.

title: Topics in Medieval Italian Literature and Culture - Petrarch's Lyric Poetry
reviews: Immerse yourself and have fun!
Marchesi is insightful, kind, and brilliant to say the least. It was a lot of fun to poke fun at Petrarch with him, and draw connections between him and earlier writers.
Take anything by Prof. Marchesi he is an amazing professor and can make even the densest of texts seem accessible.
prereqs: Course taught in Italian. One 200-level ITA course or permission of instructor required..
descrip: Considered by many the greatest scholar of his age, a successful rival to Dante, the revered teacher of Boccaccio, Petrarch bequeathed to posterity the most beautiful sonnets ever written in the Florentine vernacular. In the course, we will study the "Canzoniere", his collection of lyric poetry, a book which shaped the language of love in the European Renaissance, and a sample from his "Trionfi". The texts will be analyzed in relation to their historical and cultural context and for the impact they will have on modern European Literature.

title: Contexts of Composition
descrip: Course focuses on contemporary techniques of tonal organization in concert music and jazz. Depending on student interest, topics in jazz theory (including jazz arranging) and others in instructor's recent book (including geometrical models of musical structure) may be considered. Goal is to collect theoretical ideas that can be put to immediate compositional use.

title: Problems in Byzantine History - Formation of Byzantium 600-850: Sources & Problems
reviews: Take this course if you want independence, both in readings and in presentations, and if you would like to improve your skills at presenting and discussing your thoughts on a varied range of subjects related to Byzantine History.
descrip: Between the later sixth century and the middle of the ninth century eastern Roman state, society and culture experienced a series of substantial transformations which resulted in what we call today 'Byzantium'. This course looks at some of the key sources for this process and analyses both the ways in which they have been interpreted and the questions those interpretations raise. Particular attention will be paid to the issues associated with relating written textual evidence to archaeological data and interpretation.

title: An Integrated Introduction to Engineering, Mathematics, Physics
reviews: ALWAYS do the readings before coming to class.
Be sure to get to know Vikram out of class. He is an incredible individual.
Compared to what my roommate said about PHY 103, it sounds like EMP is a much better choice, and I really enjoyed it.
Definitely take EMP physics. The rocket lab is really fun and you will learn a ton. The professors are great, friendly, and very patient and willing to help.
Do the readings and keep up with weekly assignments, and go to office hours.
Do the readings!
Don't worry about this course, worry about EMP math.
I recommend this course, if for no other reason than building a rocket in lab.
I would definitely recommend EGR191 over PHY103, especially for the rocket lab. The class is rather fast-paced, and it is important not to fall behind on learning the material.

I would definitely say to take this class of PHY 103 because the rocket lab is a lot of fun and Vikram is a great physics professor. I would definitely recommend going to Vikram's office hours because he explains things very clearly and is very open to help.

I would recommend reading the Tipler book for every section you do and read them thoroughly. It really helps with both the problem sets and the tests. I didn't read the book until a week before finals because I thought it was useless. I really regret that decision.

I would strongly advise them to not take this course unless they already have a solid background in mechanics from high school, specifically AP. It is absolutely necessary and most of the class has it so, from personal experience, you would feel way behind if you don't. The lab is really cool.
If you don't have a good physics background, you're probably going to have to work pretty hard

If you have placement into multivariable calculus but no placement out of physics: Instead of doing MAT 201   PHY 103, take EMP! Well, unless you want to take MAT 203 and/or PHY 105, but I strongly suggest EMP for its good level of challenge and the incredible rocket lab! Moreover, you get to bond with awesome people since there's only about 60 people or so in the program.
If you like hands-on physics, definitely take this course. The lab was an amazing experience.
If you want to do an interesting lab and have taken physics C before but want to learn a few more physics topics, take this course.

My biggest piece of advice for success in this class is always 1) ask questions, Vikram likes good questions and is concerned about you understanding the concepts, and 2) Do practice problems!! It is not enough to memorize the concepts and equations. You must put it into practice in order to do well on quizzes and exams.

Pros: Rocket lab is really fun (you don't really "design" the rocket; you more just analyze and manipulate the data it collects when you launch it). Lab instructor (Norman Jarosik) is really friendly and does all he can to make sure you succeed and understand the content. You also learn to solder, use MATLAB, and format your technical documents in a program called LaTeX which is really useful for higher-level classes. Demos are interesting and fun to watch. Vikram (the professor), holds a lot of office hours so you can always ask him questions. Because you would be taking this class with EGR 192 at the same time, the professors are more willing to change due dates of assignments around (and reschedule review/problem sessions) when they conflict with each other since everyone will have the same schedule conflict. You would definitely not have this conveniency in regular MAT 201 and PHY 103

Cons: While interesting, demos don't really contribute too much to really learning the details of the concepts you need to know to do the problem sets. Instruction during precept and lecture is not always very helpful to complete problem sets. Expect to rely on reading the textbook for the details of each general concept Vikram introduces in class (but, from experience, this seems to be true for most classes, not just physics). Other than a few lessons that overlap with EGR 192, there isn't much connection between the two classes (which is what I expected). 

In general, I would do EMP and take this PHY class over regular PHY 103 because you get to know the people in EMP a lot better and from what I hear, the instruction in PHY 103 isn't much better. The EMP lab is also undisputedly better by 1000% compared to PHY 103 labs.
Put effort into your weekly lab reports.
Take EMP if you are deciding between different intro physics - the lab is fun and it helps you meet people.
Take it only if you want to take a more difficult math and physics tract.
Take it.
The EMP sequence is definitely a better alternative to 103/201.  Rocket lab is great and the professors will actually know your names.
The physics section of this sequence is good, and the lab is particularly enjoyable.  If you decide to take it, you may have to emphasize learning the computations.

This course is a great class, but the math component is very difficult. I recommend being very thorough with the math problem sets and making sure you understand the material. There is a lot of it and it's a faster pace than MAT 201.

This course is very manageable if you've taken a higher level physics course in high school. But I know students who were only exposed to the material on a superficial level in high school, and they struggled in this class.
Use Webassign to lean what is important and lecture as extra examples.
concepts more important than equations
do the readings as long ass you do that you will enjoy this course through out !!
take it if you're not afraid of a challenge, and want an awesome lab experience
prereqs: All first-year engineering students who have placement into multivariable calculus on the basis of a score of 5 on the BC calculus exam (or equivalent) are eligible to enroll..
descrip: Taken concurrently with EGR/MAT/PHY 192, this course offers an integrated presentation of the material from PHY 103 (General Physics: Mechanics and Thermodynamics) and MAT 201 (Multivariable Calculus) with an emphasis on applications to engineering. Physics topics include: mechanics with applications to fluid mechanics; wave phenomena; and thermodynamics.

title: What Makes for a Meaningful Life? A Search
descrip: Please see website

title: Seminar in Italian Literature and Culture - Performance and Spectacle in Modern Italian Theater and Film
prereqs: 200-level Italian course or permission of instructor..
descrip: The purpose of this course will be to explore the dynamics of spectacle and performance (artistic, political, sexual, anthropological) in representative plays and films by major Italian authors of the 20th century. A close analysis of works by the Futurists, Eleonora Duse, Pirandello, Fo, De Filippo, Bertolucci, Fellini, and Visconti will enable us to address questions of a textual and critical nature related to contemporary issues. Special attention will be given to the representation of individual and societal tensions, the imaging of the female voice, and the relations between the political and artistic imagination.

title: Russian Language Pedagogy
prereqs: Open to Graduate Students Only.
descrip: A practical course required of graduate students who are teaching beginning Russian. The course covers all issues relevant to the teaching of the language: phonetics, grammar presentation, efficient use of class time, class and syllabus planning, writing quizzes and tests. In addition to weekly meetings with the instructors, students are expected to meet as a group to develop best practices for covering each week's material. An important part of the course is instructor supervision of teaching.

title: Intensive Beginner's and Intermediate Spanish
reviews: Be prepared to do a lot of busy work and outside studying.
Be prepared to use a different book or online sources to learn grammar.
Definitely be ready to work hard. There is a lot of work in this class, and it is very fast-paced, but overall a very rewarding experience.
Definitely practice writing, since most of the points students lose on the exams are from the essay portions of the exam.
Do all of the homework assignments before you go to class, they're really helpful and don't be afraid to speak up.
Do all your online homework and study the vocabulary for every class and you will do fine. It is rigorous but you will surprise yourself in learning spanish.
Do not wait until the last minute to do the acciones.
Do your direccion homework every night and dont wait to do them at the end! Also engage as much as you can in class!
Don't let the work build up!  A little each day will save you from some very stressful periods of playing catch-up.
Don't take the course with Rina Ramos
Engage in the class.
Get a bike.

I had a shaky background in Spanish when I came to Princeton, so when I placed into SPA 103, I was hesitant and thought that maybe I should start from SPA 101. However, I decided to take this class and do not regret it. It gives a nice review at the beginning of class and was never overwhelming.
I liked the course but it is mostly busy work and the grading makes it very difficult to get an A.
I would definitely focus on concepts from the book and Sol y Viento when studying for tests.
I would not expect too much from it.

I would recommend participating in class on a daily basis in order to improve speaking skills. I would also suggest working on assignments such as the compositions or website ahead of time, as they are graded strictly and really require effort to do well on.

I would say definitely take the course. It will greatly help your spanish in all aspects and is an interesting and captivating course. It is important to keep up with reviewing the new topics the night before, doing the homework, watching the videos, and studying. It is easy to get behind with all of the work.

I would tell another student considering taking this course that it is important to be comfortable with Spanish in order to be successful. Nobody taking the class is perfect, so speak up when you have something to say. It's also quite important to keep up with the textbook reading and the online assignments.
I would tell them that it's helpful for improving language skills.
I would tell them to keep up with the vocabulary and to make sure to participate a lot in class.
If you are looking to better your Spanish skills and this is the right placement for you, the class is definitely worthwhile.
If you get placed into it, take it. It moves quickly but you'll manage, and help is available if you need it.

If you have a Spanish background in almost all grammar tenses and some vocab, even if you haven't touched the material for a few years, I would take the class. It is a wonderful program and well structured class, no matter who your professor turns out to be.

If you were placed into this course level, I would absolutely try and take the class with Alsina if possible. She is always so kind and creates a very welcoming environment for students to learn a new language. She's also very good at explaining grammatical concepts in easy to understand ways.
It would be easier if they knew some of the grammar structures already but it is a very interesting class.
It's better than taking two semesters.
Keep up with readings and hw, so you do not get swamped! Also, practice speaking Spanish outside of class.

Make sure that you are doing the homework each night and keeping up with the lessons in the book. Study the tenses and vocabulary on your own time, so that you are comfortable speaking and answering questions in class. The more important aspects of this class are to be prepared and to practice.
Make sure you prepare for class the day before, so you do not walk in without a general base of the new concepts being covered.
Only take this class if you have a lot of time. It is extremely intensive and requires a lot of work outside of class hours.
Practice speaking outside of class.
Proof-read!
Rina Ramos-Lopez is awesome. If you can get her, take the class.

Speaking often in class is the best way to improve your spanish. Even if it is not perfect, it gives both you and your professor to correct your mistakes and this is essential to getting the most out of the class.
Stay ahead on assignments and readings.
Study a lot and ask Rina if you are ever confused about anything.
Study hard because not everything will come easy right away.  Do the readings assigned on blackboard before coming to class because the material will be covered and you will have to participate.
Study on your own time. You won't want to set aside thirty minutes a night that you don't have to, but your grade will be better if you do.
Take it whether it is a requirement or not.  Having elementary knowledge of Spanish is very useful.
Take it--it's an enjoyable and manageable class.
Take prof Rina Ramos Carvejo de Lopez!
Take this class! It's incredible.
Take this course to fully understand Spanish grammar!
Take this course with Ramos. Very good class and pretty easy to understand.
This class is certainly not for absolute beginners and takes a bit of time to get used to.
This class is very good, but it is very fast paced. If you don't already have a solid foundation in Spanish, consider taking 101 instead.
This course covers spanish from the beginning, but is by no means a "beginner" course.
To keep track of mistakes and try to avoid them. Also to start participating in language tables as they can help improve speech.
Try to speak Spanish outside of just class with a few friends. It will really help your fluidity and just Spanish knowledge in general.
Use quizlet! It is very resourceful in learning new words. Also, participate in language tables!

You probably have to take it for a language requirement, so do. It's not too difficult, and grading is fair. Meeting everyday gets really annoying, but it helps you improve. Get Anna as an instructor.

You're going to have to take the class in order to fulfill the SPA 103/ SPA 107 requirement, so just get through it. It is not very difficult, and it will teach you some stuff and refresh your Spanish.
great class for middle level spanish speakers.
take it
prereqs: A satisfactory score on the Department's Spanish language placement test..
descrip: SPA 103 is an intensive course that covers the most relevant structures and vocabulary from SPA 101 and SPA 102 in one term. Designed for students who have previously studied Spanish at elementary levels. Language is presented in a cultural context in order to develop the skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing.

title: Classical Mythology
reviews: Be sure to stay ahead of the readings. That is, do the readings before lecture.

Do all the readings! They are very enjoyable! Try to start the readings early because they are a lot, but if you are like me and have trouble remembering certain details, you should not start them too early because there are quizzes on the readings each week.
Do all the readings. But that being said, they're very manageable anyway.
Do the reading, but don't try too hard to memorize every detail, because you'll never finish the reading if you do. Just get the gist; Haynes will summarize in lecture.
Do the readings and go to lecture.  It's not hard
Do the readings each week and go to lecture.
Do the readings. They're not especially long, and definitely fun.
Don't slack off on readings.

Good course. Your basic humanities fare. Do most of the readings, go to precept and speak occasionally and you'll be fine. Easy LA for STEM people like myself, I PDF'd it and did basically no work the whole time (apart from the Dean's Date paper I banged out in a day).
If Melissa Haynes is teaching, take this class. She is an amazing lecturer and the material is fun and engaging. Probably one of the few classes at Princeton I would actually retake if I could.

If you have seen any of these works before, you will likely not get the chance to dive more deeply. However, it is a great way to touch on and get a comprehensive feel for classical mythology as a whole.
It was harder than expected. Write as many details as possible for the quizzes and be familiar with the actual prose of the reading as there is a lot of quote identification
Make sure to do the readings and think deeper than what is on the page. Be confident in your analysis skills and don't be afraid to ask for help.

Make sure to do the readings, and read them thoroughly. They are very interesting, and there are details within each text that can turn your view on the entire story. Also, participate in precepts, since that would be a great way to review and compile what you've learned.
Make sure to start brainstorming and researching for the paper a bit early. There are so many topics available to write about that it takes some time to narrow ideas down.

Melissa sometimes starts lecture a few minutes early, so make sure to get there on time. The lectures are where most of the artwork and important quotes are presented, so you don't want to miss them. The reading is interesting and not difficult, so I would recommend doing all of it.
Not a good class - do not take! The lectures are dull and the professor is patronising. A weird form of assessment as well. There are much better CLA classes out there than this.
Pay attention in lecture, she tells you everything you need to know!
Stay diligent with the readings.

TAKE IT!  I learned an incredible amount from this course.  I began knowing nothing about classical mythology and now feel so much more informed when I see an ancient Greek or Roman piece of art or encounter a reference to a Greek or Roman myth.  I highly recommend this course.  To everyone.
Take if you have minimal to no prior background in mythology.
Take it if you're interested in classical mythology but if there is another CLA course that looks more interesting - take that.
Take it take it take it!!
Take it! I loved it.
Take it! It's awesome! The readings are more of an enjoyable break than unpleasant homework if you don't mind reading a play or two a week.
Take the course! It's a lot of fun!
Take this class! It's fun, not too difficult, and interesting.
This is a fun course, but it's definitely not a throw-away. There is work in this class.
ok class for distribution
sure
the reading is enjoyable
descrip: An introduction to the classical myths in their cultural context and in their wider application to human concerns (such as creation, sex and gender, identity, transformation, and death). The course will offer a who's who of the ancient imaginative world, study the main ancient sources of well known stories, and introduce modern approaches to analyzing myths.

title: International Institutions and Law
reviews: A significant amount of work. One student joked that they would put "Keohane's class" as the reason for why their thesis was behind schedule on their thesis progress report. But it is certainly worth it. I doubt many would regret taking the class.
Be aware that there is a 40-50 page single spaced group paper and a 10  page final paper; that is not very clear from the syllabus. This class is a lot of work, but very good.
Its a lot of work but very rewarding. It helped me figure out my senior thesis in regards to topic, structure, timing. Plus, Professor Keohane is very eager to help.

Know that this course is A LOT of work. The group assignment I turned in was close to 50 pages and my individual paper was an additional 20. The readings are great and the professor is amazing. I strongly recommend this class to people who are willing to devote the time to it.

Take it! It is a lot of work but if you put in the time you will learn a lot from it. The opportunity to interact with Professor Keohane is precious. Prepare to work very hard for it. You will have to write a taskforce report with 2 other people and a final paper. The final paper is about 5000 words and the taskforce report is about 35-50 pages single-spaced. It may sound intimidating but the experience overall is really rewarding as you learn how to do serious political research.

Take this course if you are going to take it seriously. Professor Keohane is amazing if he sees that you put effort and care into your work, but the course can be a difficult burden on your life if you don't actually work on it.

This class is A LOT of work. Here's what you have to do:

- In a group with two other people, you have to write a paper that's 40 pages long, *single-spaced*. That's about 80 pages long double-spaced, which is about the length of a senior thesis.
- In addition to this paper, you have to write an individual paper that's 5,000 words long. The subject of this paper can be (and is intended to) be related to the subject of the group paper, but the two papers must be distinct.
- Weekly readings are about ~200 pages, and often more. Basically, you read a book every week.

Of course, if you get through the class, it's going to be a very rewarding experience, and you're going to learn a lot. Professor Keohane is fantastic.

But the workload is really huge. This class was many times harder than my WWS Research Seminar and JP. I had to push aside the rest of my classes in order to keep up with this one.
This class is more work than any other class you've taken at Princeton. Don't be fooled. Its great though, so take it. Don't chicken out.

This is one of the hardest classes I've ever taken, but it was so worth it. Professor Keohane will push you to go above and beyond, but you will be very proud of what you've accomplished. Definitely the hardest politics class I've taken here, but I really enjoyed it. Take it if you're interested in the subject, but be prepared to do copious amounts of reading and writing.

You'll learn a lot, but there is way more work assigned for this class than any other politics class. The "taskforce" which is not the final paper is a 3 person group paper which he expects to be between 50 and 100 pages (he gives a general estimate of at least 25 single spaced pages, and when we turned in the first draft that length he said it was underwhelming so we all stepped it up to between 35 and 55 pages single spaced). On top of that there is a 20 page final research paper, whole books each week, in class defenses of the taskforce, presentations of other student's work, and for each class you have to prepare questions and answers regarding the readings.
a lot of workload but worth it.
prereqs: POL 240 or its equivalent is required. Students must write a 3-paragraph application of not more than 500 words. One paragraph should discuss the student's educational background and should include other information relevant to the issue of international institutions and law. The second paragraph should indicate what the student hopes to learn from the course, the third paragraph should discuss any career aspirations relevant to the topic. Applications submitted to the Undergraduate Program Office no later than 4PM Thursday April 24 will receive preference..
descrip: This course will focus on the continual tension between international law and international politics. It will examine the impact of tension on issues of intervention and other issues of substantive importance, including environmental protection, trade, human rights, laws of war applicable to the "war on terror," and crimes of state. It will discuss recent developments affecting international institutions and recent changes in international law, such as the changing conception of "sovereignty." The principal course objective is to help students learn how to do original research and analysis on issues related to international politics and law.

title: Introduction to Early Sufism (ca. AD 800-AD 1200)
reviews: An enjoyable class, for sure - Barry is very knowledgeable and a blast to listen to. A warning - he tends to repeat himself from week to week. Readings are frustrating - you buy way more than you end up reading, and the amount of reading from week to week varies hugely. Still, I learned a good amount from the class, and think it did its job as a distributional well.

As a STEM major, I was wary of taking a philosophy/religion course. However, Professor Barry is incredibly welcoming, and it was never a problem. He seems to care about his students and emphasizes the content over the grades, which was refreshing.
Do suggested readings.
Go to all the lectures -- they're only once a week and very interesting.

Gold standard for a university-level humanities course and certainly among the top of the top at Princeton. Professor Barry is a profound thinker. This course not only changed how I value my education here but also was highly enlightening on problems in the Middle East today. Rarely does a class on a topic so old impart lessons on issues so recent.

One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton. Barry is a fountain of knowledge and an absolutely phenomenal lecture. This is some pretty deep stuff but he does a great job of distilling it into a collection of take-away truths. At the very least, he'll open your mind.
So take it.
Pay attention!
Professor Barry is a great professor, and you should take it if you are interested in near eastern studies.
Really happy I took this course. Michael Barry is absolutely brilliant, and so happy I've had the chance to learn so much from him!
Take it! Prof. Barry is amazing and you learn so much!
Take this course. It's really interesting and there's very little work involved. Plus, it gives you a lot to think about
descrip: Popularized through translations of world-famous poets like the 13th-century Rumi, the Sufi mystical strain pervaded Islamic culture for a thousand years and played a major historic role in furthering friendly relations between Muslims and other religious communities through endorsement of spiritual tolerance. This two-term course examines Sufism's origins, growth, social role, guiding ideas, impact on Islamic literature, and even on medieval European thought as filtered through Spain, and the profound but controversial influence of the Spanish-Muslim Ibn `Arabi (1165-1240) as far as India.

title: The Psychology of Decision Making and Judgment
reviews: A solid class to take if you are interested in psychology. A lot of it is just interesting and good to know for personal education.
Cool class, but pretty difficult.

Decent class.  It's fascinating to read studies and hear anecdotes about all the unexpected ways people operate in real life.  The topics can get a little tedious though.  It's important to keep up with the readings for the exams, which might ask some specific questions that you can't answer just from lecture
Definitely a worthwhile course to take
Definitely take it. This course will influence the way you think. Very relevant to everyday experience.
Definitely take. It's the best class I've taken at Princeton.
Do the reading
Do the readings way ahead of time and meet with the professor and preceptors to digest them
Do the readings! You will be asked for the details of experiments etc.
Do the readings. Know the methods.
Do the readings. They are important

EVERYONE should take this course. It's like Thinking Fast and Slow but more in depth and you learn concepts that you wouldn't get reading Thinking Fast and Slow. For economics majors, this class basically proves why the rational agent model (expected utility theory that you use in ECO310, ECO311) is incorrect and flawed. SUCH A GREAT CLASS. The lecture slides aren't great so show up to lecture and do the readings!
Even though my grade might not reflect it, I learned a lot in this course. It might not help your GPA but it is definitely worthwhile.
Get Darshana as preceptor--super helpful.

Grading arbitrary and opaque -- bad course structure and preceptors non-helpful. Course material is interesting, but preceptors / instructor ruin a good class but making it hard to do well. Grading not explained well, hard to take for WWS requirement.
I do not understand the grading methodology of the assignments/exams. Seems very arbitrary to me. Regardless, this course is one of the best I have taken and EVERY LECTURE  is so interesting!

I loved it! One of my favorite classes here! Just know that the grading of the class (the assignments) are mostly arbitrary, but overall I would take it anyway because the material was so interesting!

I understand why this course is so popular now. I learned so much that was relevant to my own life and loved sharing material from the course with friends outside of class. Lectures were fun. Readings were cool. Strongly recommend.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students.

If you are considering going into public policy, or just want to know more about human decision-making in the real world, I would highly recommend this course. The readings are manageable, and as long as you keep up with them and attend lecture you should be fine. However, make sure to read the chapters assigned in the textbook.
It has its moments of being really cool, but it is quite repetitive.

It's not very focused on policy or implementation. It comes up, but the WWS/Politics types tend to be surprised at how much dense psychology research there is. Also a note for everyone: going to lectures and taking notes definitely helps for the assignments and tests, even if you think you know a lot of the material. The way Shafir presents it is idiosyncratic. Also, keep up with the readings and know the overall key points from each.
Make sure to do all the textbook readings
More work than you think.
One of my favorite classes. Really interesting material - Prof Shafir is great!
Pay attention to studies and terms.  The final is essentially a long vocabulary test.

Pretty easy Econ departmental, didn't really have any Econ though, was predominantly a psych class. Very interesting, a lot of stuff you learn is pretty common sense but it wouldn't be something you would think of yourself.
Pretty interesting! Grading is kind of subjective, but I feel like I learned a lot of interesting concepts.

Psych majors only take this class if you are prepared for economic theory and probabilities. The class is really interesting but the professor expects students to know specific details of way too many readings for exam questions.
Really interesting course--just make sure you keep up with the readings in detail, as you will need to know them well.
Some work, not too hard and interesting.
Stay on top of the readings
Take it
Take it!
Take it. Interesting topic, and concepts supremely easy to grasp.
Take it. Professor Shafir is awesome and the class is great.

The material is fascinating and eye-opening. This is a course that may very well change the way you think about the world. Be warned that the exams require quite a bit of specific knowledge and can be quite stressful.

The material is very interesting, but the assignments are just done in a terrible way. It's not that they're hard, it's that they are vague, graded surprisingly harshly (as far as I can tell from the grading distributions, most people are at a B- overall, and there will not be a curve), and little feedback is provided. It's interesting, for a class where a lecture went over how important feedback is for learning, how little feedback we got. In other words, the material is great and I highly recommend reading those readings, the class is poorly executed.

For Professor Shafir: you can improve your course by increasing the amount of feedback students. Even though I feel like I've learned a lot, I don't really have a benchmark to see if I really understand the material, or if my understanding is improving. Assign a few more assignments, and instead of using them to evaluate students like it seems like you are, use these assignments to actually teach people. That's what really makes a great educator, in my opinion: someone who uses assignments and tests to teach, not just to evaluate. Maybe you want to be a great researcher and not a great educator, but if so, why teach the course in the first place?
The readings and topics were interesting; however, the manner in which the material was presented was not.
This class is fascinating. Take it!
This class is hard but the material is amazing!

This course is an interesting survey of psychological concepts in decision making. Professor Shafir is an engaging lecturer and the readings describe a useful collection of concepts relevant to policymakers. The content, however, could be more organized, and the composition of exams is difficult to anticipate. Furthermore, grading at times seems arbitrary. If this course is offered PDF in the semester you are reading this, I highly recommend it as a very interesting course. Otherwise, I recommend it with the qualification that you will have to be alert to what material is most likely to be covered on exams, and how graders want you to present it.
This course is so important to making your own decisions in the real world - just watch out for the fact that specific authors and readings WILL be tested on exams, no matter what the prof says
This course is very interesting, but challenging. Do the readings!

This course is well-taught (if you can understand Shafir in lecture), but I don't know what the hype is all about otherwise. There is a lot of material and it's all over the place. It provides a good superficial understanding of the concepts it intends to teach, but at the end of the day, I don't know how long the majority these concepts are going to stick with me. At times it was interesting.
This is the most applicable and interesting class I've taken at Princeton. It's a little bit more work but I strongly recommend it
Try to remember the details from every single reading in the course; you will be tested on it unfortunately.
VERY FINICKING GRADING material is really basic so they literally pick on everything but interesting subject
Worth taking, if only to learn how many different pivotal studies the professor has been part of.
okay, good departmental
take it for the wws requirement
take it!
prereqs: Introductory statistics for social science or equivalent.
descrip: An introduction to the logic and research findings underlying decision-making and judgment under uncertainty. The focus is on the contrast between the rational theory of judgment and choice, and the psychological principles that guide decision behavior, often producing biases and errors. Among other topics, we will consider political, medical, and financial decision-making, poverty, negotiation, and the law, along with the implications of the findings for the rational agent model typically assumed in economics, throughout the social sciences, and in policy making.

title: Family, Friends and Groups: The Ethics of Association
descrip: Please see website

title: Topics in Migration and Development (Half-Term) - Immigrant Integration
descrip: This is a reading course, not a research seminar. We devote a week to each of six thematic areas: 1) assimilation theory: old and new, 2) challenges to assimilation theory, 3) the second generation, 4) integration beyond the United States, 5) ethnicity, 6) cultural and political integration.

title: Beginning Studies in Acting: Scene Study
reviews: -take this course
Be open-minded and ready to do things out of the box
Definitely take it!
I would highly recommend this course if you are interested in theater and acting, but be prepared for self disclosure
Take it, especially if you're getting the theater certificate. Don't slack off, and work a lot outside of class.
Take this and take it with Tracy.
Take this course!! It has been one of my favorite courses at Princeton. Tracy is incredible, and you will grow as an actor and a person.

The classes can get very personal, particularly early on (though they definitely stay personal later), but it helps expand your comfort zone and can actually be very good for stress from other classes - not that that means you should neglect the work at all.
The more you put into it, the more you will get back.

This is a great class.  One word of caution.  If you are not an arts major, you are going to be expected to act on that level.  It can be done, but it will take more time and frustration than you will anticipate.  That being said, I would recommend taking this class.
This was a great class?very fun and very different from the typical academic Princeton class. Tracy is such a wonderful person and a great instructor. It was a 100% positive experience.
You definitely need to spend time outside of class working on scenes with your partner. Practicing in the actual classroom was especially helpful.
prereqs: Open Enrollment in April and May 2014. In September 2014 enrollment by permission of instructors during the first two weeks of classes..
descrip: An introduction to the craft of acting through scene study monologues and, finally, a longer scene drawn from a play, to develop a method of working on a script. Emphasis will be placed on honesty, spontaneity, and establishing a personal connection with the scene's substance.

title: Ancient and Medieval Japanese History
descrip: This course provides an introduction to the written sources of Japanese history from 750-1600. Instruction focuses on reading and translating a variety of documentary genres, and court chronicles, although visual sources (e.g. maps, scrolls, and screens) are introduced in class as well.

title: Intermediate Hebrew I
reviews: Definitely recommend it if interested in the Hebrew language or Israeli culture.
If you have an interest in hebrew I strongly recommend the course.
If you want to take Hebrew, this is really a mandatory class, but if you're taking it for fun or something, it's a lot of in-class time.
prereqs: HEB 102 or Placement Test..
