descrip: Reinforcement and expansion of reading, oral, aural, and writing skills through maximum student participation, exclusive use of Hebrew in the classroom, and coverage of remainder of basic grammar. Readings of graded selections from prose, poetry, and newspapers, and viewing and discussion of Israeli films and television programs open a window on Israel and its culture.

title: Diseases in Children: Causes, Costs, and Choices
reviews: Definitely take it.
Dr. Notterman is a great professor. Weekly visits from patients were fantastic. The material is really interesting and the work is engaging and manageable.
Dr. Notterman is a wonderful Professor. The class is incredible. If you are pre-med, this is the class for you!
If you're interested in childhood medicine, take this course! Professor Notterman is great! The course has fascinating material, and the work load is really manageable.
It's wonderful! Take it - it's wonderful to get exposure to real patients and the experiences they've had with disease and with doctors.
TAKE IT!!
Take it if you're at all interested in medicine or pediatrics!!!!!
Take it!! Best class I've taken here.
Take this course! It's an amazing survey of child development and childhood diseases.

This is a great class for anyone interested in healthcare and medicine! Dr. Notterman makes his lectures really accessible and has a wealth of knowledge to share. Also, it's an amazing opportunity to meet real-life patients and hear about their experiences firsthand. I really appreciated that the course combined the biological, social, and clinical aspects of disease, providing a holistic idea of pediatric diseases. You will learn a lot and really enjoy it. The course was a real pleasure.

This was my favorite course of my time here and an excellent class for anyone interested in clinical medicine.  While it discusses the molecular biology underlying a variety of conditions and diseases, it also gives considerable attention to the ethical and social implications.  Having patients and their families join us and discuss their experiences with the relevant conditions each week was always very insightful and memorable.  My class was quite engaged, and Dr. Notterman was great at taking the time to answer our numerous questions during lecture.  The work load was not too extensive, and the assignments were fairly thought-provoking.
Very interesting and great opportunity for more clinical/patient focus than a lot of the biologically focused classes here
prereqs: MOL214 or MOL215 or equivelent.
descrip: Within a broader context of historical, social, and ethical concerns, a survey of normal childhood development and selected disorders from the perspectives of the physician and the scientist. Emphasis on the complex relationship between genetic and acquired causes of disease, medical practice, social conditions, and cultural values. The course features visits from children with some of the conditions discussed, site visits, and readings from the original medical and scientific literature. Prerequisite: 214 or 215. Two 90-minute classes.

title: Mechanics and Waves
reviews: A wide array of topics were covered in the course. It provides an introduction to quantum mechanics.
Definitely go to the problem review sessions, get to know and work with other students, and study all problem sets and textbook examples in detail for the exams.  Take advantage of office hours.
Go to lectures and take thorough notes. Ask for help is something is unclear.

If you want to learn about analytical mechanics or if you want to take QM in the future this is a good course to take. Phy 205 is a lot more work, it will give a stronger understanding of analytical mechanics, though both prepare you well for QM.
If you're looking at taking PHY 207 you probably don't really have a choice.  Have fun with it.
It takes a lot of time to be in this course.
Take this course!

The concepts presented in this class are, of course, very interesting and useful. However, the instruction quality is extremely poor, especially with Professor Romalis. As a result, I have found myself in a dilemma- I cannot tell you to not to take this class because the material is definitely interesting and you do need to take this class regardless if you wish to become a physics major. But on the other hand I do not wish you to suffer through the awful implementation of this course. If you must take this course, then I would strongly advise prioritizing reading the readings before the lectures, and petitioning the department to replace the professor.
This  class is great for anyone even mildly interested in physics. Definitely form a study group ASAP to work on problem sets together; it makes it all the easier.
This is truly and excellent course - the mechanics material is beautiful
prereqs: PHY103 and PHY104 or PHY105 and PHY106; one 200-level math course; or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course covers wave phenomena, both classical and quantum, and it also includes an account of special relativity and introductory aspects of statistical physics. Topics include: special relativity, Lagrangians, small oscillations, coupled oscillations and waves, wave-packets and the Schrodinger equations, and elements of statistical mechanics. Mathematical methods will be developed as appropriate, in parallel to physical concepts.

title: Economic Perspectives on Inequality (Half-Term)
descrip: Economics is centrally concerned with models of human capital development, educational attainment, labor market dynamics, unemployment, labor turnover, job duration, wage setting institutions, the role of unions, human capital formation, the relationship between economic status and other aspects of well-being (including health). Economists are essential partners in the behavioral study of preferences and decision making, mobility and redistribution, and the institutions of industrial relations that govern the labor market.

title: Theory of Computation
reviews: Dvir is a dry lecturer, but the interestingness of the material makes up for this. The problem sets were fun and of moderate difficulty, and the final was very manageable. Definitely take this course if you find theoretical computer science fascinating.
Good choice for a theory course - it's interesting and well taught.

I was going to say "definitely don't take this" but I have to be a little more fair: Definitely don't take this if Zeev is teaching it and you're not a math major. Zeev clearly doesn't like his CS students and is the most unhelpful teacher ever. This is also a course clearly designed to screw over CS students because its an easy A for the math majors and is crosslisted.
As for the course itself, its a lot of Turing Machines, so if you like that, then knock your socks off. If you're not great at theory, definitely buy the Arora book in addition to Sipser because it is a lot more detailed and has lots of additional examples. Also if you're not a theory person and you have a choice, this is definitely one of the harder/less exciting theory options.

If you are interested in the topics, the course is great. On the other, it is probably one of those courses which can be self-taught. Unfortunately, the lecture were not very engaging but they were compensated by really good problem sets.
If you enjoy mathematics and/or theoretical computer science, this course is for you. Go to lectures and take thorough notes - that will help you a lot.
It's fine.
Just read the book at home.
Only take it if you're interested in the material.
Take it if the subject material looks interesting to you and you aren't intimidated by having to write proofs.
Take it if you are interested in theoretical CS.
Take it! It's a relaxed, fun course.
Take the course.
Take this course if you are interested in theoretical computer science.
Take this if you want an easy theory requirement.
The curve was pretty steep.
The material is really fundamental for anyone interested in theoretical computer science, and it will increase your understanding of the field in a deeply conceptual sense.
The material is really interesting, but Zeev Dvir is very bad at communicating generally, and teaching specifically. If someone else is teaching it, I recommend the course.
This is a fun course to take which isn't too hard (at least for math majors...). I'd definitely recommend at least some experience with proof-based mathematics and rigor before this class.

You are probably reading this because you are a COS major who is required to take a theory course beyond 340. This course is tough in its own right, but is greatly exacerbated by the fact that 50% of your classmates will be math majors who have already seen a large amount of the material before, and who will set a ruthless curve. Expect no mercy. Zeev Dvir is a fine lecturer. He isn't terribly interesting, but he at least knows his stuff. He also doesn't understand the plight that students face when they spend unreasonable amounts of time on assignments and exams. Finally, he seems to be fully determined to enforce a grade deflation policy which is no longer required. Proceed with caution, and take this as your theory course only if the material (computability and complexity theory) interests you significantly more than that of other theory courses. Or if you're a math major.
prereqs: COS 340/341 or equivalent mathematical maturity..
descrip: Studies the limits of computation by identifing tasks that are either inherently impossible to compute, or impossible to compute within the resources available. Introduces students to computability and decidability, Godel's incompleteness theorem, computational complexity, NP-completeness and other notions of intractability.This course also surveys the status of the P versus NP question. Additional topics may include: interactive proofs, hardness of computing approximate solutions, cryptography, and quantum computation. Two lectures, one precept. Prerequisite: COS 340/341 or instructor's permission.

title: Transportation Systems Analysis
reviews: Enjoy it!

If you like structure, stay away from this class.  If you like clarity, stay away from this class.  If you like knowing what you're supposed to do on assignments, stay away from this class.  If you like laughing, take this class.  If you suck at Excel and/or coding in R, don't take this class.  If you're a stickler for political correctness, dear God stay away from Professor Kornhauser.

Kornhauser rocks. As long as you act like a normal human being around him he will like you, and treat you fairly. He is very approachable outside of class, and his antics make for very engaging classes
Professor Kornhauser is both delightful and frustrating.
So this class is really whatever you put into it. It's not too much work, but the project at the end can be killer if you want it to be.
Take it! Have fun with Kornhauser.
What you think of this course will entirely depend on what you think of Kornhauser. I would recommend at least shopping this class though.
lots of work
prereqs: ORF 245 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Studied is the transportation sector of the economy from a technology and policy planning perspective. The focus is on the methodologies and analytical tools that underpin policy formulation, capital and operations planning, and real-time operational decision making within the transportation industry. Case studies of innovative concepts such as "value" pricing, real-time fleet management and control, GPS-based route guidance systems, automated transit systems and autonomous vehicles will provide a practical focus for the methodologies. Class project in lieu of final exam focused on major issue in Transportation Systems Analysis.

title: Information Security
reviews: A great introduction to security thinking. You're learn a lot from this course. Beware, though, that the grading is sometimes unfair and you should communicate with the TAs and possibly attend office hours whenever you're in doubt.
A very good course. Would definitely recommend.
All the great things you've heard about this course is true. Felten is amazing, and this will be one of the best upper level COS classes you'll ever take.
Any student majoring in computer science should definitely consider taking it, specially with Dr. Felten being the instructor. I also strongly recommend attending the lectures.

As a COS major, this was easily my favorite course in the department. Very interesting material, very applicable, and the workload is very reasonable. I could not recommend this course more strongly, especially with Felten (but I'm sure it's great with Arvind, too).
Be careful when working on your first few assignments, as they count for a lot.
Be prepared for some bit-twiddling and the server assignment, but this is a very well done course, if you're interested in the topic (which nowadays, most everyone is).

Definitely attend lecture (Prof. Felten is a great teacher, and surprisingly few people showed up). Consult Piazza early and often, since a lot of gray areas in the assignment spec are addressed there, and you can lose points if you disregard instructor comments there.
Definitely take this course (with Felten if possible)!! This was my favorite COS class to date
Do it - super topical, highly relevant, well taught, very fun way of thinking (how would you design a lottery system securely?)
Don't expect too much.
Don't leave the secure storage assignment to the last minute.
Don't miss out on the brilliant Ed Felten.
Don't wait to long to start on the homeworks.

Felten is a fantastic lecturer and the material is really interesting. The assignments were interesting in theory but pretty poorly executed - underspecified and graded inconsistently/incorrectly. Hopefully Frankle is going to revamp some of the worst of the assignments.
Felten is a fantastic professor, but the problem sets are hard (esp. the first four or so). If you have a group of friends who are also taking it, its a no brainer -- great cs departmental.

Felten is a really good lecturer. 

HUNT DOWN THE PRECEPTORS and talk to them. If Frankle is precepting again, he's the man. Go to his office hours.

Felten is a wonderful lecturer, material is interesting and relevant. Assignments are highly design oriented and meant to a synthesis of lecture materials. Some are better than others but overall TA system and feedback on assignments are lacking.
Fun class for interest, not much work.

Get started on assignments early and get help as often as possible. As a non-COS major with minimal programming experience, it was definitely a challenge, but the course material is super interesting and Ed Felten is an amazing lecturer and experienced/accomplished professional in the field. You should definitely take it if you're interested in cryptography and internet security in general. There is no better opportunity out there to learn about it than here with Ed Felten.
Go to office hours and go to lectures.
Good overview of information security.
Great class in the CS department. Not as much work as most other CS classes. This class is worth taking just for the final project.
Great class, interesting assignments. Not easy but not terribly difficult either. Overall a fantastic intro to security concepts for anyone who thinks they might be interested in them.
Great course - pay attention in the lectures and do the assignment. Office hours are beneficial but varies greatly with TA.

Hard to study for final because material is based on logic.  Overall class was very good.  Beginning assignments were time consuming (first 3) but became a lot less so until the last assignment.  I took this with 3 other COS classes and I didn't have any free time.  Many people enjoyed the last assignment, but I had so much other work due that it was hard to enjoy it.  Material in class is good though.  I wish the final exam was more directly related to the material learned.
I wouldn't take it unless you're really into infosec/crypto.. The assignments were very time consuming and it was hard to be motivated if you're not interested in the subject

If Professor Felten is teaching this course again, I would definitely recommend taking it. If another professor is teaching it, I can see the potential for it to become disorganized or trite, but chances are it will remain a great class even if there is a different professor.
If you are interested in the subject take, even if you are not also take it, it is really well taught and a reasonable amount of work.
Interesting COS departmental. Felton knows his stuff.

Interesting class. Take if you need a COS departmental. Not too much work, particularly in the second half of the semester. Make sure to go to lecture. If you don't keep up on the material, the final is going to be difficult.

Interesting course that covers many topics relevant to the real world (also lots of cool theoretical areas).  Good area to understand if you plan on being a software engineer, and interesting regardless.  Light workload overall.  Did well in the class, and spent about 70 hours over the course of the semester (assignments ranged from 3-13 hours to complete).
Interesting material, knowledgeable professor. Assignments got worse with time (not b/c of difficulty, but because of arbitrary grading and unsubstantiated vagueness).
Light-to-moderate workload, interesting material, great professor--take it for sure, whether you are concentrating or getting a certificate in COS.
Material isn't particularly difficult, pay more attention to programming assignments as that will largely determine your grade.
Please take it.
Pretty interesting. Fine course. Don't take if you already know a decent bit about computer security.

Prime departmental material right here. First of all, Ed Felten is a rockstar, and you should definitely seize the opportunity to take this class with him if possible. The material is not only very interesting but somehow very practical. The assignments, however, are where this course really shines. Sometimes you won't even code at all, and you will be asked to design a system using certain properties (or review the designs of others). The last assignment is the finest I've had at Princeton. Overall, this course is not terribly stressful but a great time.
Really interesting/cool! Definitely look into taking this class!
Start homeworks early!
Start the assignments early.  And while the class wasn't particularly interesting, I think it does provide information worth knowing.
Take it - it's an enjoyable, interesting, and relevant COS course.
Take it if you're interested in the topic.
Take it with Felten. He's amazing. Beyond amazing. Also interesting material
Take it with Professor Felten. You will not regret it.
Take it!
Take it, makes a lot of things clearer that you took for granted
Take it, sure.
Take it.
Take it. Great course, very manageable workload. More-so than almost any other CS course (perhaps Functional), it'll leave you with a completely new way of thinking.
Take it. It's awesome
Take notes. Contribute to note-taking.
Take this class if you want a nonmathematical review of good security practices.
Take this course if you are really interested in the material.

Take this course if you don't mind teaching yourself almost all of the low level crypto stuff--there will not be precepts to help you, and you will be left out in the cold with many of the actual coding. The lectures are very interesting and pretty great for the most part, just be aware that you are likely going to be confused with the first few assignments and there is little guidance to help you along the way.

Take this course only if you have the time to go to all the office hours and already have a very strong grasp of java and coding.  No help will be given if you don't remember the coding tricks in java.

Take this course!! Felten is really great and the stuff you learn is super relevant to everything today (security is everywhere). Also, the first few lectures are a bit dull but power through they get better (and there is no text book so you need to take notes).
Take this course. If you have any computer science background, take this course because you will undoubtedly learn something and enjoy every single lecture.
Take/acquire good notes. Pick good coding partners.
The assignments are very interesting. You end up learning a lot from them.
The course was fine, I just wasn't as interested in the material as I thought I would be.
This course is one of the most interesting courses ever. Its also kind of terrifying. Felten is great so definitely take it.
This is an interesting course on security and recommended for anyone looking to get a good introduction to the topic.

This is easily the best course I've ever taken at Princeton. But make sure you take it with Felten--Arvind is a good lecturer, but he tends to prefer speaking to an nonexistent audience from pre-made lecture slides--Felten will use the blackboard and take you through the process step by step so you don't get lost. He's amazingly good at demystifying topics, and watching him lecture was like watching MTT conduct the SF Symphony in Mahler. The assignments were really good too--they could take up a ton of your time, but required a lot of hard thinking and creating solutions to problems you don't see in other areas of CS.
take it
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226..
descrip: Security issues in computing, communications, and electronic commerce. Goals and vulnerabilities; legal and ethical issues; basic cryptology; private and authenticated communication; electronic commerce; software security; viruses and other malicious code; operating system protection; trusted systems design; network security; firewalls; policy, administration and procedures; auditing; physical security; disaster recovery; reliability; content protection; privacy.

title: Molecular Biology
reviews: Be prepared
Both professors are amazing and the classes separately would be great but the combined course is overly difficult.
Enjoy reading! Enjoy discussion!
Go slow, ask questions, and the final will be worth it.
I would recommend that they do some reading about phage and E.coli beforehand, such as Ptashne's book or another historical book. So they can be a little more prepared when class starts.
It's very important to take this course as a MolBio grad student.
Read the papers, and then read them again!
Treat each section as its own separate class.
n/a
descrip: Advanced-level discussions of selected topics in prokaryotic and eukaryotic molecular biology. Emphasis is placed on original research papers and extensive reading together with critical thinking is required. Topics include the genetic code, mutagenesis, chromosome and chromatin structures, mechanisms of DNA replication, recombination, repair, and transposition, gene structure and function and mechanisms of gene regulation. Examples from bacteriophage, bacteria, lower and higher eukaryotes will be used to illustrate these different areas of molecular biology.

title: Intermediate German
reviews: A fair continuation of the German classes. Expect less focus on grammar and more on the readings and film-watching.
Great course. Not too demanding.
I don't have any advice. Do what you want. I can only say that I am glad I took it.
I recommend taking this class.

I would recommend this course to students with a serious interest in learning German. The course is demanding enough to best suit someone who is committed to improving their German, not just passingly interested. I would specifically recommend taking the course with Angiras if possible. Its success followed largely from his obvious experience and ability to set a positive tone.
Study the vocabulary every night and go out of your way to acquire other vocabulary words on your own.
Take it! Great class that will push you out of your comfort zone in a fun way!
Take it. It was a pretty fun way to start the day, and your German will improve a fair amount.
prereqs: GER 102 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Develops deeper proficiency in all areas (cultural understanding, production skills, and receptive skills), using a combination of language-oriented work and cultural/historical content, including film and texts.

title: Play, Leisure, and Sociability
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Quantum Mechanics: Principles and Problem Solving (Half Term)
reviews: Attend often!
If you have good memories of undergrad knowledge, you don't have to take it.
Same comments as in the mechanics class evaluation
See mechanics review
Take if you need to prepare for prelims.
Trying to keep up as best you can, and review the topics and problems before class.
Useful.
descrip: A graduate-level review of quantum mechanics emphasizing problem-solving.

title: Topics in Domestic Policy Analysis - Managing People and Organizations
descrip: This course enhances participants' understanding of their own motivation & behavior, & that of others. Students understand what environments make them most productive & satisfied, how to create most productive work environments for employees, how to manage different types of professional & interpersonal situations. The course uses cases & readings to explore topics of individual motivation, leadership, power & influence, managing conflict, organizational culture, working in teams, communicating effectively, decision making, fostering creativity/innovation, managing change.

title: The Classical Roots of Western Literature
reviews: Be prepared for the magnitude of reading assigned, and go to office hours.
Don't drop it early on just because the reading load is daunting. You don't have to do even half of it, so don't!
I would advise other students taking this course to complete the readings as early as humanly possible. They add up very quickly.
If you enjoy the reading list and aren't afraid of  a lot of reading, this is a wonderful class. And professor Heller-Roazen is extraordinary!

Please take it if 
a) You love classical literature and don't mind having to read 300   pages a week 
b) you want to be mind-blown and inspired every single lecture
c) you don't mind working hard.
Take it! And do all the readings. Don't come in and try to fake it, because it's really obvious so these guys will pick up on it before you even open your mouth.
Take it! Maybe it'll shock you out of your postmodern complacency. Should be a required course for everyone.
Take it, read what you can, come prepared with something you want to talk about during precept.
Take this class. Put your concerns about GPA aside and simply enjoy the incredible readings and lectures. You won't find any better class in the humanities.

Take this course if you are interested in becoming a more well-read student with better critical thinking skills. The professors are excellent and the reading is heavy but very manageable. However, be warned that the essays involve very close reading.

This is a great course for people interested in reading and understanding foundational Western literature.  Don't take it if you're not self-motivated to read the works for the sake of understanding lectures-- if you rely on grades to force you to do work, you don't get as much of that here and you
descrip: An introduction to comparative literature through readings of major works of the classical Greek, Roman, Arabic and medieval European traditions.

title: Introductory Painting
reviews: Curiosity is probably most important in this class. If you have things you want to explore that will carry you through and you'll have a fantastic experience.
I would recommend other students to not wear any clothes that you wouldn't want paint stains on. Oil paint never washes out!
It is important to know that the course takes quite a lot of time outside the classes.

Take it if you are willing to trek to a studio 2-3 times a week, and  put a huge amount of time into your paintings.  If you're not a natural artist, this course will be a challenge and your grade will be average compared to the work you put into the course.  I really liked art but this course killed me so beware!
Take it.
Take this class!
Take this course if you love to paint!
This course improves your conception of painting. It teaches you to interact with a canvas. Eve is a wonderful teacher who opens your eyes to a hidden world that most are not willing to learn about.
This course really changes how you see the process of art, even as an experienced artist. Be prepared to put in lots of time.
descrip: An introduction to the materials and methods of painting. The areas to be covered are specifically color and its interaction, the use of form and scale, painting from a model, painting objects with a concern for their mass and its interaction with light.

title: Identity Politics
descrip: Graduate seminar on identity politics within the U.S. context; primary focus is on ethnic, racial and religious identities. Course tackles questions about when, why and to what extent ethnic, racial and religious identities take on significance in American politics. In doing so course examines theories of identity development and change; considers strategies for measuring identity; and assesses the standard empirical approach to studying identity in American politics. Course also explores how context, institutions and elections work to politicize identities under some conditions.

title: Writing an Effective Scientific Research Article (Half Term): Sci & Engineering
prereqs: Course open to graduate students who have completed sufficient research to begin writing a research article in any area of science or engineering..
descrip: Writing workshop for students in any area of quantitative research, including science and engineering, who are prepared to draft a research article for publication based on their original work. Topics include getting started, presenting data, communicating visually, understanding the elements of a research article, using evidence persuasively, revising effectively, soliciting useful comments from readers, and incorporating feedback. One 2-hour, 50-minute seminar.

title: Sex, Violence, Death, and Other Entertainments for Kids: Challenging Drama for Youth
reviews: Be prepared to be active in class - otherwise there is no point. Read the plays proactively.

Bob is fantastic and you should take a class with him. He really cares about his students and it shows. This class is especially cool because it's a field that is so often neglected, but is actually super interesting. Take it!
I would advise that they definitely take the course!

I've now taken three dramatic literature courses with Professor Sandberg, and each has been crucial to the way I view the theater and the world. He is there for you in so many ways. As far as the content goes, give it a chance! Don't come looking for Beckett and Shakespeare; you won't find it here. Instead, come ready to explore themes which we wrestle with in adulthood as they are presented to young audiences.
TAKE IT! (:
This course is great! Professor Sandberg is a great teacher and truly makes each student feel involved in the discussion. I would definitely take this course if you have any interest in theater.
descrip: This course will examine a wide variety of highly imaginative plays for children and teens, focusing on how they work as plays and the challenges they present to youth and family audiences. For much of the 20th century, theater for young audiences was simplistic, safe and shallow. Now, plays for young audiences are tackling subjects like sex and death head on, and playwrights are creating works with sophisticated styles and structures. These are exciting theatrical works of the highest artistic order.

title: Utopia: How Fiction Meets the World
descrip: Please see website

title: Advanced Quantum Field Theory
descrip: Relations between Quantum Field Theory and Statistical Mechanics, Renormalization Group, Non-Abelian Gauge Theories, Asymptotic Freedom, Quantum Chromodynamics, Chiral Lagrangians, General Constraints on RG Flows.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for graduate students and post-docs.

title: What Makes a Poem Endure?--24 Lyric Masterpieces
descrip: Please see website

title: Workshop in Biodrama and Documentary Theater
reviews: Have fun!
I really enjoyed the class, and encourage others to take it.
If Professor Tellas is giving this or any other class, take it. you will learn plenty about theater and about yourself.
Take it. It was great.
This was a crazy class and I sorta loved it although it was a little hectic at times. Do it!
dope
prereqs: A 200-level course above SPA 209 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Vivi Tellas is an Argentine theater director and curator with a focus on "unintended theater." Workshop will explore, through writing, analyzing, and performing, different forms of everyday theatricality outside professional theater. Students will study two performative "real" spaces. In "Family Theatre," students will explore through their own biographies, the theatrical themes of love, death, secrets, and frustration. In "Found Theater," students will explore the town of Princeton searching for everyday living stages, or what Tellas defines as "urban ready-mades." The workshop will conclude with documentary performances by the students.

title: Applied Algebra
reviews: A solid introduction to groups and rings, but don't expect to be wowed, or that there will be a lot of "applied" material
If you are in the science and at all interested in applied mathematics, I highly recommend this course, particularly if taught by Prof. Taylor!

It is important to say off the bat, this was a great course. Now, I'm sure if you're reading this you are debating between taking MAT 340 and MAT 345, as was I. I ended up taking MAT 340 for a number of reasons. First, Christine Taylor is a great professor. She does lecture extremely fast, this is true, but the trick is to not even try to take notes is class because you'll always be behind during lecture. Just jolt down things now and then, then after class Prof. Taylor posts LaTeX notes for each lecture, which become your lecture notes. Second was, I felt this was a course would really allow me to grow, and become very comfortable with proof based mathematics, which it did. Bottom line: a good course. Take it.
Pretty interesting with real applications. Not too much workload if you have some prior experience with proofs.
Solid course to learn about groups, rings, and fields if you don't want to commit to the more difficult Algebra I course
Take it if you want an interesting introduction to proof-based math. If you have taken 215 though, consider Algebra as it isn't a very mathematically rigorous class (hence applied).

This course gives you a great taste for math in an abstract setting. You should definitely have experience in proof based math, but don't be too intimidated by the fact that this is in the math department (math majors take MAT 345, a harder version).
if you're interested in algebra but don't want to take the math math class, this is the class for you!
prereqs: MAT202, MAT204, or MAT217.
descrip: An applied algebra course that integrates the basics of theory and modern applications for students in MAT, APC, PHY, CHE, COS, ELE. This course is intended for students who have taken a semester of linear algebra and who have an interest in a course that treats the structures, properties and application of groups, rings, and fields. Applications and algorithmic aspects of algebra will be emphasized throughout.

title: Junior Independent Work
descrip: Subjects chosen by the student with the approval of the faculty for independent study. A written report, examination, or other evidence of accomplishment will be required.

title: Corporate Restructuring
reviews: Definitely take this course if you have even a remote interest in finance. Sexton is a great professor, highly accessible, and interested in your success in the course.
I would take this course again and recommend it to anyone who is interested in having a career in finance.
Interesting, but maybe not worth the logistical stress of poorly-made assessments. Lectures are good.

Pretty good class if you're interested in going into finance or even consulting. Good background understanding of the M&A business and Sexton is fair and has a great understanding of the industry. Exams and assignments are pretty straightforward and come only from the lectures and readings, so make sure you do them!
Prof Sexton is fantastic
Professor Sexton is great. Take it if you are remotely interested in corporate finance.
Take it if you are interested in the industry. Experienced instructor and real-world applicability.

Take it if you have ever wondered what these mergers/acquisitions/spinoffs/splitoffs are all about and if you just plainly wonder what Wall Street people do for a living. The course is advanced however and you'll have to catch up to competitive classmates who probably already have a fair understanding of how M&A and finance in general works. 
Prof. Sexton has the most CRISP notes ever. He is straightforward and very encouraging. The WGOH presentations will ask you to examine a current merger/acquisition happening and it is satisfying to see that you can make the connect between what you have learnt and current events in the market.
good intro to restructuring, but not a well designed course

take this class if you have any interest in mergers, acquisitions, and the general finance of a business. sexton is a wonderful lecturer and reliably sticks to the material in his lecture slides, plus there are only 4 problem sets and you get to do them in groups!
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310.
descrip: This course applies topics from microeconomics (ECO 310) and corporate finance (ECO 363) to study corporate restructuring. Topics include mergers, acquisitions, joint ventures, divestiture and share repurchases. Each of these is discussed in the context of the relevant economic theory, institutional and regulatory environment, and with a focus on shareholder value.

title: American Cinema
reviews: A fun course -- especially if you're looking for an English course that isn't so "English"-y.
A very easy LA. Might be frustrating for English majors.

A very fun class -- take it with friends!  If you watch all the movies and put effort into the essays, it'll be a higher time commitment than other fun classes, but definitely worth it! Professor Fuss' lectures are very insightful, and made me think a lot more deeply about the movies we watched, and cinema in general.
ABSOLUTELY.
Absolutely take it. Makes you look at cinema and all films in a different way.
Absolutely take this course.
Actually go to lecture, take thorough notes, meet with your preceptor, and watch ALL the movies.
All you really have to do is watch the movies and go to lecture. Take good notes.

Always watch the movies before lecture - not worth going if you didn't watch. And even if you've watched one of the movies prior to the course, watch it again...you'll see things you missed the first time.
Analyze the film beyond just what you think, look into a new perspective and a new mindset
Attend lecture! It's fantastic!
Avoid Kira's precept.

Be careful with your preceptor.  Make sure it's a veteran on whom there are reviews.  

Frankly, it would be better just to watch these movies on your own with Wikipedia open.
Definitely take it
Definitely take it, big class so be prepared for pros and cons that come with it
Definitely take the course as it allows you to watch a great series of movies guilt free.
Definitely take the course if you are interested in popular movies/even American history. The course definitely causes you to look at movies (even non-syllabus ones) in a new light
Definitely take the course. It is very interesting and you get to watch some great movies that you should definitely watch at some point in your life.
Definitely take this class! Diana is the best, most friendliest teacher in the world. You won't regret it. And take it with friends its so much fun.
Definitely take this class. It's not too much work and it's worth it. Also go to lectures, it's not that long and it's worth it.
Definitely take this course if you have any interest in film, anything ranging from film analysis to casual moviegoing.
Definitely take this course, Professor Fuss is fantastic and the movies are all worth watching regardless of whether or not you have to.
Definitely take this course, if you work hard at papers you can get good grades and the movies are all great
Definitely take this course.  Watch all the movies and start to think of every movie different because of it.
Definitely take this course. It will change the way you view films as well as develop your ability to speak intelligently about films.
Don't be afraid to think out of the box, it's hard to be wrong
Don't take this course for an easy A grade or an easy LA requirement. Take it for personal interest (it is well worth it!)
Enjoy
Excellent.
Films are fantastic, grading is kind of arbitrary. Your experience depends on your TA, but its an easy class overall that's fun to be in.
Fun easy LA if you need it
Fun, though not particularly special or fascinating
Go for it.
Go to lectures if you actually care to learn about the movies! They teach you so much more than you learn by just watching the movies alone.
Go to office hours for the paper
Go to your preceptor with your paper drafts just so they know you're working hard on it.

Good selection of movies and not a big work load. But beware: Most of the students are not taking the class seriously, which makes it hard to get anything out discussion. The lectures are pretty engaging, but not terribly helpful for the papers and some claims are a bit ridiculous.
Great PDF option tough A.
Great and relatively easy LA course. Awesome movies and well taught critiques.
Great class! Go to lectures and watch the movies! Its fun and watching movies is a good way to productively procrastinate!
Great course with a relatively fun/light work load. Definitely take if you love watching movies like me!

Great course. It's incredibly easy and fairly enjoyable ? not just to slip by with a B, but to fully engage. Workload is two movies a week, two short papers (midterm and final), and exam, all fairly enjoyable and not very time consuming. And the movies are great. Take it.
I hated the papers and the grading. I am not an English person, don't know why I thought I could take this class as my "easy class".
I recommend this course to any student--regardless of their major. The classwork, written work, and films were all enjoyable and reflected the course's level of organization.
I strongly recommend taking this course: so interesting and fun!

I took this course because I wanted to learn how to get more out of movies beyond aesthetic enjoyment. I watched all the films, attended all the precepts, attended almost all the lectures. It's worth taking this class just to watch the movies. It could be so much better though. Professor Fuss is an ok lecturer. I felt like quite a few times, she was really grasping at straws -- maybe she's just a really postmodernist reader who is trying to create meaning, but I think if she was trying to interpret what the director intended, it sometimes seemed far-fetched. That being said, it made me think more critically about movies in general, so I liked that. My preceptor, Kira, is a very very very sweet person. That being said, she was not a good preceptor. The main issue was that every time she asked a question, no one really knew what she meant. I didn't end up getting anything out of the precept, which is a shame because I really liked the other ENG precept that I had.
I would recommend it.
I would recommend this course to someone looking for an introduction to film studies.

If you are comfortable with a class that lacks focus and isn't clear about what's expected from you, and you just want to watch movies and hear semi-interesting observations about them in lecture, then I would say go for the class. If you want to be serious about film analysis, the class doesn't analyze films closely enough, and if you want to talk about the films in a social context, the class is too stretched to adequately address that as well. 

Professor Fuss is well meaning and I've heard that her precept is pretty good, but she is not that engaging and the overarching focus of the lectures is not clear and does not match her original, stated intentions from the opening lecture. 

Be ready for precepts that include students who don't care and preceptors who don't know what they're doing.
If you're an English major, definitely take this for the theory & criticism requirement. This class is a lot of fun, there's no secondary readings. It's just watching movies.

If you're interested in film at all, take this class. Professor Fuss is an excellent lecturer and the workload is relatively light. Also, the movies are fun to watch and I really think I learned something about them.
It will make you dislike movies you once liked.
It's a good class to get an overview of major films.
It's really easy.

Its a great course, but definitely don't skip lectures as the notes she gives can be very helpful on the final. Don't skip precepts either, and incorporate your ideas and get comments on them from classmates and preceptors, which will be very helpful for writing your papers.

Lectures were really boring for someone with some film background. Professor makes "insights" that can really just be found on Wikipedia or film review sites. Don't take it if you are really into movies -- you've prob already have seen the Hollywood flicks on the syllabus, and you won't learn anything new.
Look for a preceptor you like, Because they control your grade in the class.
Make sure you go to lecture, take notes, and watch the movies.

Not a bad class, but watch out for the no-PDF option! This would be a great class to PDF, but unfortunately it's hard to get a high grade without since. There are only four grades in the class - two papers, precept participation, and the final exam, so if you don't do well on all those things, you're screwed.
Not an easy class if you want to do well.
Not as easy as people say it is...
Not worth taking if you just want an easy blow-off class. Preceptor was harsh and critical, and I do not feel like I learned much from the class.
One of the best classes I have ever taken in Princeton! Great break from problem set classes.

Pretty cool class. I wish that the syllabus was a little more widespread however, with less emphasis on Shia Labeouf and his career. I understand he is a great American actor, but it seems pretty restrictive to only watch movies with him in it
Really enjoyed watching the films for this class. Still, the lectures were pretty unimpressive and the precepts an absolute waste of time.

Relatively easy, but way less interesting than you think it'll be. Professor Fuss' lectures are not interesting and her analyses are often pretty dumb and irrelevant. My high school film class was 10x better. Still easy though and nice to watch movies for homework
Remember its npdf
Requires a degree of self-engagement but a fairly low commitment class.
Stay on top of all the films
Super interesting! Easy homework to just watch movies.

TAKE IT! I absolutely loved this class! It's great if you love watching movies and want to to see them from a more academic perspective. Aside from her crazy puns, Professor Fuss comes up with some pretty interesting ideas in lecture. The workload is fairly light - mostly just watching films which is fun and only a few really easy readings. There are two papers and a final but if you get a good preceptor than you should do just fine.
TAKE THIS COURSE - especially for a 5th class.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!!!!!!! One of my favorite that I've taken at Princeton so far. You will not regret it!!!
TAKE THIS. Professor Fuss is the best professor and gives the best lectures I have had here at Princeton.
Take it
Take it as a 5th class.  Pay attention in lectures and everything will come easy.
Take it if you want an easy class and are interested in watching the movies.
Take it if you want to catch up on your American movies.
Take it if you want very little work during the semester.
Take it seriously - some people don't realize the class is no PDF.

Take it simply for the reason that you don't know as much about the American film industry as you might think. But expect to get lower grades on the papers than you like if you don't watch every movie or learn how to write a  paper about film.
Take it!
Take it! But don't expect it to be a walk in the park if you're just looking to get rid of an LA. It's possible to get an A, but the class isn't a joke so take it seriously.
Take it! Great films and if you're at all a decent writer the assignments are pretty easy
Take it! It's an easy and interesting LA, and probably my favorite course of the semester.
Take it! It's awesome to 'have to' watch movies as homework. I wish there were more classes like this at Princeton.

Take it! It's fun, a lot of your friends will be in it, papers are fun, and learning about American cinema is such a useful skill that will influence the way I watch movies and think about culture for the rest of my life!
Take it, you won't regret it
Take it.
Take it. 100%.
Take it. not too much work.
Take the class to watch the movies.  It is fun even for just that reason.
Take the course. It is a good way to get rid of a LA requirement
Take this class!
Take this class!! It's awesome, and it's a great excuse to watch cool movies in the name of doing homework.
Take this course and watch all the movies.
Take this course if you want to think about films in new critical ways.
Take this course!
Take this course!  Lectures are decent and precepts are great.  All you have to do is watch Hollywood blockbusters!

Take this course! If you are concerned about the grade you might get on your paper, talk to your preceptor early in the writing process. Aside from that, this course is officially my favorite non-science class.
Take this course! Whether you're a film buff re-watching these movies for new insights, or you're watching them for the first time, American Cinema is a blast!
Take this course. It is very enjoyable and a great opportunity to watch films you've always wanted to see but haven't had the time to. Professor Fuss' lectures are insightful and thought-provoking.
Take this. Great class on cinema, inspiring and insightful lectures. Made me watch movies in new ways.
The movies are good to watch, the topics are straightforward, and the workload is light.

The movies are good, but her lectures are so, so bad. She thinks that every sentence is like the most important revelation in the world - her voice pitch goes up in a sort of "A-Ha!" type reaction. Took a lot of energy to convince myself to go to lecture everyday. That being said, it is pretty easy, and all your friends will take it, so take it.

This course is great and a light workload. Don't stress about readings. Try to watch the movies and attend lecture, but overall your grade depends on your papers and the final. Talk to your preceptor about your argument on your papers beforehand, they will often give you great evidence or warn you against weak arguments. Plus they are grading you so it helps to be on the same page.

This course is really fun and almost no work, but I'm an English major and I don't expect to get an A in this class. Everyone I talked to did poorly on the first paper, but if you need an LA with almost no work, this is the way to go. Everyone should watch these films at some point. Don't take it if you don't like hearing weird theories/opinions on films stated as facts. There is little room for your own interpretation/argument with the interpretations given, as far as this course is concerned.

This is a great course. Please don't take this course because you're looking for something that you think will be easy. Yes, it is an easy class to pass, but it certainly isn't easy to write good essays. Instead, take this course because you love film. Having a couple of favorite movies isn't enough (like the 6 people in my precept who only wanted to talk about Mean Girls). You really need to be open to accept film as a form of literature/art. Many people in the course can't do this, and they spend most of their time during lecture scoffing at Professor Fuss's excellent analysis because they think she's reading too far into these movies. Do everything you can to watch all of the movies before precept. They are all excellent and worth your time. Also, don't skip the reading. It's very short and helpful. If you love movies, this is the best class at Princeton for you.
This is great course, take it!

This is not an "easy" class in terms of workload or materials - you will have to write papers and take exams which require a serious analysis of film. However, the work is often very enjoyable and fun, because we study popular American movies. I'd recommend it if you're looking for an entertaining class to complement a hard schedule.
Try to get Professor Fuss as your preceptor.
Watch all of the movies, even if they don't seem interesting at first.
Watch all the movies and attend every single lecture. Seriously, you'll regret it if you don't and it's the best way to get the most out of the course.
Watch all the movies and go to the lectures. They are actually pretty interesting. The second half of the semester was really interesting.
Watch all the movies.

Watch as many of the movies as you can! Some people only watched half of them and I think it really takes away from the overarching themes of the course. 

Also, take the time OVER THE WEEKEND and watch both--don't try to do it during the week, unless your schedule is really free on certain days.  It's much harder to find two 2-3 hour chunks of time during the week than it is on a Friday, Saturday or Sunday.
Watch the films before precept.
Watch the films.
Watch the movies before lecture and pay close attention to them. What you get out of the class is very dependent on how engaged you and your classmates in precept choose to be.
Watch the movies before lecture!
Watch the movies on time
Watch the movies.
While this class is about movies, don't take it lightly. I know other people who did so and didn't do as well as they hoped.
Yes
You get to watch movies for homework. its awesome.
You have to like watching all kinds of movies.

You only need to go to the lectures you are going to write papers on, so really only need to go to two lectures all semester then bum notes off a friend who actually went. The theories proposed are laughable. She is grasping at thin straws. But that also means all you need to do to write good papers is come up with the most incredibly unbelievable idea possible and you will get a good grade for originality and deep thought.
You'll watch cool movies, but don't expect this to be just a walk in the park.
Your homework is watching movies and writing two papers. This class is fun and the subject matter is not very complex. Everyone can get involved.
fun class
great class to get rid of your LA, very easy
highly recommend
not a difficult course, but know that watching the movies might be more of a burden than a fun break because many of them are boring/hard to follow
not too much work and the movies were good, i would recommend it
take it
take it - papers are easy, movies are good.
take it if you like movies!
take it!

this class is tempting because it seems easy and you get to watch movies. The latter part is true--your reading is just watching good movies, and that's fun. But as long as Prof. Fuss is lecturing, you might want to think again about taking this course because she sucks. Sucks sucks sucks. All the lectures were about the same things (the holy trinity of raceclassgender) and she speaks like a 12 year old. Lectures were supremely boring and useless for any and all writing you'll do. My preceptor (kira) also sucked--mean and unhelpful, facilitating the most awkward precept possible, full of bizarre questions, awkward silences and irrelevant asides. I know some preceptors are better, but regardless, think twice about taking this class.
watch the movies
descrip: This film genre course addresses the cultural heritage of our national cinema. How has cinema shaped American culture, and how has American culture shaped cinema? We will focus on iconic figures in American film: robbers, tycoons, cowboys, gangsters, detectives, lovers, monsters, cyborgs, survivors. Each week will pair an early film with a later one to trace a given genre's evolution; for example, the week on westerns might pair John Ford's "The Searchers" (1956) with Ang Lee's "Brokeback Mountain" (2005). The course studies not art house films but commercial Hollywood films that serve as important barometers of their times.

title: Colloquium on the Biology of Populations
reviews: Attend the lectures even if you think you won't be interested - most of the invited speakers are top-notch and may change your mind about what you find interesting!
descrip: Discussion of the central problems of population biology and approaches that have proved fruitful. Topics ranging throughout ecology, evolution, biogeography, and population genetics are usually related to presentations by visiting speakers and students. (This is a core course.)

title: Master Drawings
descrip: An introduction to the study of drawings taught entirely from original works of art. Intensive use will be made of the Princeton University Art Museum, with trips to an auction house, dealer, and museums in Washington, D.C. and New York City. Of interest to all planning a career in the arts, collecting, or training their powers of visual analysis. For 2014 the focus will be Central European (German, Austrian, etc.) drawings from the late eighteenth to the early twentieth century.

title: Seminar in 17th-Century French Literature - Classical Quarrels
descrip: From the Querelle du Cid to the Querelle des Anciens et des Modernes, the French 17th century was marked by crucial controversies which led to, and beyond, what would later be called "classicism." This seminar focuses in particular on quarrels concerning the theater, whose public nature made it the cultural battlefield par excellence. Readings include both the works in dispute and related critical and polemical texts. Among the issues to be explored: the uses and "morality" of dramatic fictions; the relation between writers, critics, and the public; imitation, originality, and progress; language, authority, and gender.

title: Reading Spain in Federico Garcia Lorca's Life and Works
reviews: A lot of work but great!

Be prepared for more work than you will have done in almost any other humanities course - if you are willing to put the time in it will absolutely be worth it, but it is an incredibly challenging course.
Lot of work, very rewarding.

Take this class if you have any interest in Lorca, Spain or analyzing literary works - Prof Mendez is a genius and extremely passionate about the subject, and always willing to help students out with questions about (admittedly often difficult and complex) texts. Be warned that this class involved a lot of consistent work (assignments every week) but as a result it stretches and challenges you at a level that few other Princeton courses I've taken do. I feel that my Spanish ability in reading improved tremendously, and writing and speaking probably improved too. Don't be afraid to ask questions and speak up in class, even if you can't quite phrase them perfectly or if you don't understand the texts exactly. This is one of the classes where what you put in does correlate with what you get out of it. Prof Mendez is also very approachable, open to feedback and flexible, which I really appreciated and admired.

The course is a lot of work and Prof. Mendez might not always be your favorite, but I think you'll get to the end and be happy with all you've learned. Be mindful that the course isn't predominantly Lorca's writing and that there's a lot of other material, so if you want to just read Lorca this might not be your favorite.
!Toma la clase!
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish course or instructor's permission. Preferably, a second 200 or 300-level course..
descrip: This course focuses on one of the most renowned and influential Spanish poets of the 20th century - Federico Garcia Lorca. We will examine Lorca's vast corpus of poems and plays to see how they combine experimental aesthetics and popular traditions. We will also study the readings and re-readings of "Lorca" as both an author and a mythical figure, standing for freedom, the defeated Spanish Republic, the historical avant-garde poetry, and gender politics. Among other topics to be discussed are flamenco culture, popular music, surrealism, the Wall Street Crash of 1929, the Spanish Civil War, historical memory and the Francoist mass graves.

title: Postblack - Contemporary African American Art
descrip: As articulated by Thelma Golden, postblack refers to the work of African American artists who emerged in the 1990s with ambitious, irreverent, and sassy work. Though hard to define, postblack suggested the emergence of a generation of artists removed from the long tradition of black affirmation of the Harlem Renaissance, black empowerment of the Black Arts movement, and identity politics of the 1980s and early 90s. This seminar provides an opportunity for a deep engagement with the work of African American artists of the past decade. It will involve critical and theoretical readings on multiculturalism, race, identity, and contemporary art.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: If you are taking Advanced Poetry, ask around to determine which professor to take the class with. Regardless of which class section you end up in, push yourself, and you could end up writing things you are very proud of or at the very least learning a little bit more about yourself. Also, engage with your classmates' work before class otherwise you will be lost in class (and how do you expect people to engage with your work if you don't engage with theirs?)

Professor Phillips made my poetry better and made me the envy of all my friends in other poetry classes. Our workshop felt like a family, and I feel as though my poetry improved by leaps and bounds. His feedback is thorough and nuanced, and he is always generous with his time. Probably one of the warmest professors I've ever had and by far one of my favorite. Five out of five stars.

Take it really seriously, start reading and early, take advantage of all of the resources Professor Phillips provides, go to the archives, get wacky with your writing, read read read read and then write and don't apologize for what's on the page.
Take this class!
Take this class!!  It's so much fun, and you really learn both how to write and read poetry better.
This course is very much up to you-- how much effort and time you put into it is your choice, but I would only take it if you're highly interested and willing to put in effort.
yes yes yes
prereqs: By application only. Students must have completed two 200-level CWR courses prior to applying. Please visit the Lewis Center Creative Writing website for application information. Please note that this course cannot be audited. Application deadline is April 11, 2014. Accepted students will be able to enroll in SCORE May 19th-23rd..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of poetry for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the places of literature among the liberal arts.

title: Introduction to Classical Chinese I
prereqs: CHI 107 or CHI 108 or instructor's permission.
descrip: Introduction to the grammar of classical Chinese through study of selections from ancient texts. Readings include the Analects and the Mencius.

title: History of International Human Rights
reviews: A very interesting course in a fascinating field intersecting political theory and history. The readings are great, although long. Only take this class if you have time to do the readings, however--the class is solely-discussion based and you will get nothing out of it otherwise.
Take this course! The course has a really interesting take on human rights, and the readings are thought provoking.
This course has heavy reading but it is also very interesting. Participation is important!
meet weekly with professor and be very ready to have own opinions to discuss about the readings - have to get through a lot of material though
descrip: When and how did human rights become an important concern of the international community? This course will answer that question through a reading of contemporary works of history, political theory and classic texts from European political philosophy. Together they provide a common framework that will allow students to understand current debates over universal human rights, international law, and democratic sovereignty. Recent debates about global political projects undertaken in the name of human rights will figure prominently in the class.

title: Economic Inequality and the Role of Government
reviews: A great course on an interesting and hot topic.

Definitely take this course if you would like to learn more about redistribution policies used to alter the current state of income inequality- Prof. Kuziemko is a wonderful lecturer and economics scholar and will be a joy to learn from!
Good class, take it if you're interested in the material!
It's a great course. Interesting, engaging, lot of take away and real life application and will also help you understand how econometrics works.

Lecture was great (I sooooo have a crush on Ilyana Kuziemko <3) and the material was really interesting but problem sets are really small and don't accurately represent what's going to be on the midterm and final, which is frustrating. Also the midterm had really arbitrary questions such as random facts that may or may not have been said on lecture. Doing problem sets does NOT prepare you for testing, which is frustrating.
Prof. Kuziemko is a fun lecturer. Interesting, great for electives.

TAKE IT. It's easy enough math that anyone who has taken a basic stats class can follow along. This class improves your knowledge of the inequality debate, understanding of the basic econ frameworks that (economists theorize) underly so many different trends, and ability to think critically about all the issues you didn't even know pertained to inequality!
Take it!
Take this class if you are interested inequality. Professor Kuziemko took a vague concept thrown around in media and applied the economic principles and theory to explain the deeper economic context.
prereqs: ECO 300 or 310.
descrip: In the US and many other developed countries, economic inequality has risen to historic levels in recent decades. What are the causes of this trend -- "natural" market forces (e.g., globalization?) or changes in public policy (e.g., erosion of the minimum wage)? Are measures currently proposed to counteract inequality and poverty -- e.g, progressive taxation, transfer programs to low-income families, public insurance programs such as Medicare -- effective? An emphasis is placed on understanding what basic microeconomic theory as well as empirical evidence can (and cannot) tell us about these questions.

title: The Politics of Public Policy
descrip: An analysis of the forces that shape the behavior of public organizations and individuals in organizational settings. The emphasis is on the workings of U.S. governmental agencies. Special attention is given to writing skills as they apply to the roles of advisers and decision makers in public-sector organizations.

title: Elementary Twi I
reviews: If you have any interest in taking this class (i.e. if you are even reading this) sign up! It's a really fun course and Tikya (Teacher) Hannah is a great instructor.
Take this class if you speak Twi or if you want to learn a fun African language.
descrip: An introduction to Twi language and culture of the Akan-Twi-speaking people of West Africa. The course is taught in Twi and focuses on acquiring novice-level skills to perform basic communication functions in the culture of Akan-Twi speakers of West Africa. Students will be introduced to basic grammar, communicative skills and cultural activities that will be reinforced through role plays, conversations, dialogues and songs. By the end of the course, students will have acquired basic grammar competence to perform in everyday situations with an understanding and appreciation of the culture of the Akan people in Ghana, West Africa.

title: Urban Sociology: The City and Social Change in the Americas
reviews: Be aware of the heavy reading load.

Do all the readings, because the readings are very interesting. PFK is very intelligent, but her lectures were not engaging and the class was not a wholly positive experience. That being said, it was easy and I learned a lot from the readings, so it turned out ok.
Do the readings!!!
Don't take this class.
Easy class. Dont have to do the readings, just read other people's memos.
I would take it.
I would take this class because PFK is an engaging passionate lecturer but be prepared for disorganization

I would tell the student to take the course if he or she is interested in the history of urbanization in America. The course is very informative. I would encourage good reading skills, as the material can be extensive and advanced in prose. Overall, it is good exposure to the field of sociology, the topics discussed, the type of research conducted, and the critical thinking involved.
If you are looking for a distributional requirement you should take it.
If you're interested in the material, go for it! But I can't say it was the best class I've ever taken. It wasn't a lot of work though, which was helpful for a tough semester.

If you're interested in the origin and evolution of cities, take this course. People say that PFK is overly-opinionated and goes off on tangents in lectures. Isn't that the point of this educational experience? Supplementing learning from reading with the insights of professors who have committed their lives to the study of what they're teaching? PFK provides lecture handouts that summarize the main takeaways from the readings, which is obviously quite valuable. Then, she contextualizes the information she's purveying by describing its relevance and importance to the world as we know it. Take this class. If you find it boring, you're not paying attention.
It's a great course if you want to learn more about how cities work--the workload isn't too much, but if you keep up with the readings, you can be able to knock out the papers without much trouble.
It's not worth the time, the lectures and precepts feel like a waste of time.
Keep up with the readings.
Make sure to stay on top of the readings.
Not a heavy workload, good for a first sociology class. Interesting topic. I think you'll get more out of this class if you pay close attention to the readers and not slide by.
Not going to be anyone's favorite class but it's not much work and you'll learn some interesting concepts.
Only take this course if you have a demanding schedule and need a joke class.

PFK should not be teaching any class at Princeton. Lectures are worthless (about 25% of the class shows up and she rambles about nothing for most of the 50 minutes) and her opinions are frustrating no matter what your own beliefs are. It's easy to get a good grade while doing zero work, but even then this class was the biggest waste of time in my four years at Princeton.
Professor is very knowledgeable about the course.  Work is not too demanding.  Baxter was a great preceptor.
See above.
Take for a really eye opening semester.
Take it
Take it if interested.
Take it, you won't regret it.
Take it. It's enjoyable and PFK is very engaging. Whether you get her or another preceptor, you will definitely get a lot out of this class.
Take the class. Very interesting and the work is manageable
Take this course for fun.
Take this course!
This was my worst class of the semester. Usually terrible classes are redeemed with interesting readings, but that wasn't even the case this time. I'm sad I wasted a credit on this course.

Try your best to do the readings. Class notes are provided, but try to pay attention to the lecture. Make sure you attend as many lectures as you can because Patricia Fernandez notices when there are many people missing and takes attendance.
dont get caroline
really easy so take if you want but it's tough to learn anything of value
take as a PDF!
take it
take it if interested, manageable workload and interesting discussions
take it. Easy class
descrip: By taking a comparative approach, this course examines the role of social, economic, and political factors in the emergence and transformation of modern cities in the United States and selected areas of Latin America. We consider the city in its dual image: both as a center of progress and as a redoubt of social problems, especially poverty. Attention is given to spatial processes that have resulted in the aggregation and desegregation of populations differentiated by social class and race.

title: The Fall Show
reviews: Be prepared to put in a lot of hours, especially during tech week.
Do the Fall Show! If you love theatre or you love being on stage or you love working with great directors, take this course. It will be time consuming, yes, but it is a lot of fun.
Go in with an open mind and an eagerness to bring your ideas and talents to the table. You are no longer just a student but a co-creator.

I would just say be aware of the time commitment required and how the commitment will change as the semester continues and tech week gets closer.  
And if I were talking to my past self, I would say try to be less intimidated by the process and the people.  I think I would have gotten more out of it had I been more willing to participate during the first few weeks.
If you're interested, definitely read the script first!  It's usually a pretty weird show.
It takes a lot of time! But so do all theater shows on campus. Definitely definitely do the fall show at least once while you're here - especially if Tracy is directing.

Obviously, the show will vary from year to year, but the Fall Show experience is pretty standard. You'll get to work in-depth on a difficult piece, typically with a very qualified director. You don't do very much traditional classwork, but you'll end up spending much more time than you would for a normal class on rehearsal and tech. Ultimately, you get out of the Fall Show what you put into it. If you are ready to invest heavily into making art, then you will enjoy this process immensely. Recommended, especially if Tracy Bersley is directing.
Really put in the time outside of rehearsal for the show.
Take it, and be prepared for a heavy rehearsal load and a great time.
The fall show is different every year, but be prepared for 8-12 hours of rehearsal a week instead of 4, as our class time allots!
take this as a course -- don't try to take it in addition to 4 others....really commit to doing a great show
prereqs: Please contact Professor Tim Vasen (tvasen@princeton.edu) for enrollment permission/further information..
descrip: The Fall Show provides students with a rigorous and challenging experience of creating theater under near-professional circumstances. A professional director, design team, and stage manager, as well as two weeks of performances in the Berlind Theatre, are key components.The Fall Show involves an extensive rehearsal period and concentrated tech week,often requiring more time and focus than a typical student-produced production might. This course is repeatable once for credit. Students cast in the Fall Show, or those who take on major production roles (such as Asst. Stage Manager, Asst. Designer, or Asst. Director), will receive course credit.

title: Studies in German Film - Early German Cinema
descrip: This seminar in media history, theory and criticism will subject a rediscovered cache of rare silent films to a variety of critical interrogations, exploring the complex intermedial dynamics (relations to theater, variete, literature), establishment of key legitimation discourses (film criticism and theory, the Autorenfilm), development of new narrative forms ("birth" of the feature film the serial detective genre), work of ignored pioneers (the Brothers Skladanowsky, Oskar Messter), gender and clas dynamics is the transformation of the public sphere, and issues of technology, politics and the historicity of perception.

title: Introduction to Historiography
descrip: The literature of art, architecture, and archaeology in Europe until the late eighteenth century. Some sessions may be devoted to East Asia and to other areas. Later interpretations, consequences, and comparisons with other cultures will be considered.

title: Advanced Macroeconomics: Domestic Policy Issues
prereqs: WWS 512C, or equivalent..
descrip: This course is about the economics and some of the politics of central banking, especially monetary policy. Special emphasis is given to central banks as unique policymaking institutions and, especially, to the Federal Reserve System, although other central banks are mentioned frequently. Since the focus is on monetary policy, the course presupposes a working knowledge of the relevant macroeconomics, but particular aspects thereof are taught in the course. Attention is paid to the causes, consequences, and central bank behavior during and since the recent financial crisis.

title: Advanced Dynamics
reviews: A good overview of topics in dynamics that go beyond what's taught in MAE 206. This course covers similar material to the physics mechanics classes, but is more geared towards engineers. If you liked dynamics and want to learn some better methods for analyzing dynamical systems, this is a excellent course for that.
It is a very serious course and might be tough at the problem sets and exams but if you can pass through it you will learn more than you were expecting.
Try and solve the exercises suggested by Naomi during lectures and ask questions if something is not clear, specially notation.
descrip: Principles and methods for formulating and analyzing mathematical models of physical systems; Newtonian, Lagrangian, and Hamiltonian formulations of particle and rigid and elastic body dynamics; canonical transformations, Hamilton-Jacobi theory; and integrable and nonintegrable systems. Additional topics are explored at the discretion of the instructor.

title: Modern Microbiology and Disease
