reviews: Man up and take the lab section. The labs aren't too difficult and are actually interesting. It sounded a lot better than precept. We also finished early many times, and the lab reports were more like problem sets, so don't be intimidated by lab.
N/A
Take it! There were some kinks to work out because it was the first year of the course, but it's a very interesting subject matter

Take this class if you are interested in learning more about microbes and their relation to disease! Professor Schwalm is a very kind, caring professor! She will take the time to make sure you understand the material.
This course is interesting and useful material for pre-meds, but at times a bit disorganized and confusing. But in general a good course!
This is a good survey of microbiology and the labs were good. The workload is not that high and she tests concepts, not nitty-gritty details.

This is a really fascinating topic that I would encourage anyone, especially MOL students, to take. You really get to learn about specific pathogens, their methods of infection, and a lot of other topics that are very current in the field of molecular biology. The paper is also a good way of getting you to work with research and propose/develop your own ideas. Take it!!!!!
prereqs: MOL214, MOL 215 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course examines the field of modern molecular biology through microbial biology, including viruses, bacteria, and parasites. Particular emphasis will be placed on the impact of microbes on everyday life, both positive and negative. Topics will include pathogenesis (molecular mechanisms of virulence, antibiotics and antibiotic resistance), additional roles of microbes in human health (gut microbes, viral vectors), microbial biology (communication, microbial genetics, cell division), and microbe-habitat interactions (biofilms, bioremediation).

title: Linear System Theory
reviews: Definitely, depending on the students interests and his exposure to the subject.. I feel the course was stimulating even for students well versed in the subject..
Go for it.

If you do not have a solid math (especially linear algebra) backgroud, do not take this course. Linear algebra review was done only in one class, but the entire course required linear algebra. If you want to learn basic theory of machine learning take it. Otherwise, dont. I dont think that this couse is a must-take.
Nice course. You will learn a lot.
Pore over Ramadge's notes and ask the preceptor lots of questions.
Study the proofs.
This is a truly introductory course. Many topics were covered but almost none of them was discussed in a deep level.
descrip: This course covers the fundamentals of linear models for data generation and analysis. The topics covered are important for further study in signal processing, machine learning, communications and feedback control. The focus is on fundamental results but these are illustrated with applications of current interest.

title: Advanced Hindi-Urdu I
prereqs: Intermediate Hindi / Intermediate Urdu or equivalent proficiency.
descrip: Close reading of selected literary materials, generally short stories, with additional focus on historical and social context, literary styles and trends. Literary texts supplemented with viewing of film, documentary, and author interviews, as well as germane poetry and music. Reading and writing assignments are provided in both Hindi and Urdu. Students choose their preferred format. In-depth classroom discussion and analysis of all materials.

title: Advanced German
reviews: Be prepared to be very engaged, my class was only 5 people. Good review of grammar and vocab and not too overwhelming.
Definitely do the readings so that you can actually add something to the conversation.

Definitely take the course, even if you do not need to fulfill the language requirement. The two pieces of advice I would give would be to keep up with the nightly readings as not doing them will make class participation impossible and be disciplined in learning the weekly vocab. Though it might seem like an inconvenience in the moment, it is certainly better to learn the words on a weekly basis rather than biweekly cramming for the quizzes!
If you're thinking about it, take it! Keep track of the syllabus - all the homework is on there and you can plan ahead.
It is a challenging course but your German improves.
Take it with Professor Nagel!! She's fantastic and the material we cover is really interesting. One of the best course I've ever had!
Try to be engaged in class and read the readings carefully before class.
prereqs: GER 105 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Continues improvement of proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing using texts, online media, and other sources as a basis for class discussion. Grammar review is included. Conducted in German.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
prereqs: Completion of EGR 350.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Reproductive Health and Reproductive Rights
descrip: Examines selected topics in reproductive health, with primary emphasis on contemporary domestic issues in the United States--such as unintended pregnancy, and sexually transmitted infection--but within the context of the international agenda on reproductive rights established in the 1994 Cairo international Conference on Population and development.

title: Music from the Hispanophone Caribbean
reviews: It's a good class, but you'd be significantly better off if you know a little bit about some of the music we're studying here to begin with.
Make time to do all the readings and listenings, you'll get so much more out of the seminars and have a really great time at each one.
Never miss a class taught by Prof. Vazquez.
TAKE THIS CLASS. you won't regret it. especially if you're at all a fan of any music.
Take this course! And any other that Professor Vazquez is teaching, regardless of your familiarity with the material.
Taking this course is a great idea, even of you don't need it for a major or certificate.
descrip: This interdisciplinary seminar utilizes the musical cultures of Puerto Rico, the Dominican Republic, and Cuba to reflect upon the aesthetic, migratory, and social histories of the Hispanophone Caribbean. Students will listen to the sounded legacies of conquest, slavery, colonialism, and U.S. intervention and occupation. The effects of transnational migration on music's performance and reception will also be one of the key themes in the course. We will not only consider the creative traditions and receptive worlds embedded in musical recordings, but will also pay attention to music's traces in literature, film, and other ephemera.

title: Advanced Topics in Engineering Mathematics I - Numerical Methods for Engineering
descrip: Introduction to numerical methods for the solution of problems relevant to engineering. Topics include numerical interpolation, differentiation, and integration and solution methods for initial value ordinary differential equations (explicit/implicit, stiff/non-stiff), boundary value ordinary differential equations (direct/shooting), and partial differential equations (hyperbolic/parabolic/elliptic). Emphasis is on the analysis of these methods for their accuracy, stability, and convergence.

title: Chinese Cinema
reviews: Definitely take it! You watch a variety of Chinese films and most of them are great.
Don't hesitate, if you would like to be an educated and informed cinema connoisseur!
Don't take this class if you want to watch enjoyable movies or martial arts movies. We watch some heavy stuff.
I highly recommend this course to everyone with a slight interest in film, even if its not with chinese culture or aesthetics. Be prepared as this course would change the way you watch/enjoy films.
Take it if you are interested in Chinese history and culture, not just movies.
Take it!

To get the most out of the class, make sure you watch all the films with a critical eye instead of just sitting back and watching them as if you were in the movies. Be warned that after taking this class, your head will actually start to think that way and start raising questions even when you watch movies for fun at theaters...!

Watch the movies of course!! And definitely do the readings he has listed (at least skim them if you don't have much time). Talk to Professor Silbergeld about your essay ideas early! He will give you amazing guidance and references for your research.
descrip: Thematic studies in Chinese film (Republic, People's Republic, Taiwan, Hong Kong), 1930s to the present with emphasis on recent years, viewed in relation to traditional and modern Chinese visual arts and literature, colonialism and globalism, Communist politics, gender and family values, ethnicity and regionalism, melodrama and the avant-garde, the cinematic market, artistic censorship, and other social issues.

title: The Enlightenment and the Interpretation of Pain
prereqs: Students taking this course for credit in French are expected to do some of the readings in French. Their final papers must be written in French in accordance with FIT guidelines..
descrip: When the sum of our pains surpasses that of our pleasures, non-existence becomes preferable to existence. This argument became ubiquitous in Enlightenment philosophical debates. Many used it to discuss the rationality of suicide, God's creation, religious faith, as well as the metaphysical grounds of human existence and the idea of progress. Some criticized the quantitative premises of the argument and questioned the idea that pain could change the positive value of human existence into a negative one. We will examine those debates in philosophical and literary texts and discuss their later and contemporary echoes in ethics.

title: Modern Microbiology and Disease
reviews: Definitely take this class!  Professor Schwalm is one of the best professors I have ever had.  She is really good at explaining concepts, is willing to meet and help students outside of class, and is a fair grader.  She doesn't really try to trick you and is really just committed to helping you learn a lot and become more interested in biology.  She definitely did that for me.  Therefore isn't too much work so it is definitely manageable and the material is fascinating.
Go to lecture and office hours to make sure you're understanding the most important parts.
Great course. Really interesting and informational. Take if at all interested in disease and things like that.
I strongly recommend this course if you are interested in medicine. The subject material is very interesting and we go into detail about many interesting diseases.
If you have an interest in viruses or bacteria and their medical implications, take this course.

It's a really great course! You learn about the mechanisms of how the common pathogens (e.g. TB, malaria, ebola, HIV) are associated with the particular symptoms they cause and how antibiotics work. Very up to date with current events.
Just pay attention during lectures and you'll be fine.
One of the easier upper-level MOL classes, taking it as a MOL major can be tedious since it's just a broad overview of stuff we've already learned
Pretty easy and pretty interesting.
Take it - it's an awesome course! The material is really interesting and not a lot of work.
Take it if you are extremely interested in the subject matter. It requires a significant amount of studying for the midterm and final, and a lot of attention during lectures.
Take it if you're motivated to learn a lot, attend every lecture 3 times a week, and engage in discussion.

Take it! Make sure to go to lecture - taking notes on the slides is probably a good way to go about it - and review each week as you're doing the problem sets, and you won't need to spend too much time cramming for the exam! Professor Schwalm is great!

Unless they change this course, I wouldn't recommend it. The topic of material is just way too broad to go into any significant depth in any topic. It ends up just being memorization of basic principles of a variety of topics. This could be an interesting class if they tweaked it a little bit or if you are interested in a very broad shallow course.
interesting and manageable class
probably shouldnt take it.. especailly if you're MOL you wont find it very satisfying
prereqs: MOL 214, MOL 215 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course examines the field of modern molecular biology through microbial biology, including viruses, bacteria, and parasites. Particular emphasis will be placed on the impact of microbes on everyday life, both positive and negative. Topics will include pathogenesis (molecular mechanisms of virulence, antibiotics and antibiotic resistance), additional roles of microbes in human health (gut microbes, viral vectors), microbial biology (communication, microbial genetics, cell division), and microbe-habitat interactions (biofilms, bioremediation).

title: Seminar in Theoretical Astrophysics
reviews: Don't give talks that are super technical, try to get the underlying essential physical/astrophysical concepts across, and prepare well in advance (preferably showing the course instructor(s) your slides well before your talk). If you have to give a math-oriented talk with complicated (or even simple) equations in your presentation, then it is crucial that you introduce the variables and equations. Teach to the ~advanced undergraduate level, not to the 5th-year graduate student, postdoc, or professor level.
Ensure your talks are pedagogical-- we are all here to learn.
Give yourself a couple of weeks to put your talk together.

The course is an excellent choice if you want to explore various topics in high energy astrophysics. Anatoly met with all of us before the presentations to make sure that we properly understood the topic. The presentations themselves had a good format and we all received peer feedback. The presentations were sometimes a little bit too technical so it would be good to take a glimpse over the readings before each presentation.
Try to make mistakes and errors here before you start your career talks.
Useful if you are interested in high energy.
descrip: Designed to stimulate students in the pursuit of research. Participants in this seminar discuss critically papers given by seminar members. Ordinarily, several staff members also participate. Often topics are drawn from published data that present unsolved puzzles of interpretation.

title: Europe from Antiquity to 1700
reviews: A LOT of reading....
A must-take before you graduate.
A reasonable history class
AMAZING TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT the lectures will be the highlight of your week i promise
Attend lecture and do the readings.
Definitely take this course. Grafton is an amazing lecturer, and this course is just important in terms of basic knowledge about the foundations of Western culture.
Do not take Ghosh as your preceptor, but don't let this course pass by!

Get the professors precept! Take it to go from no appreciation of history to some appreciation of history. Don't take in hopes to make you think about history in a new light or to see the applications of history in the modern world
Go to lecture or at least get the handouts. Do readings.
Good as a fifth class.

Grafton is a very smart guy and a pretty good lecturer, but the course material is unexciting enough where I don't think it's worth it if you're looking to take it as a departmental (unless you're looking for an intro history class).

Grafton's lectures are fantastic! Really informative and very interesting to listen to. Be aware, though, that the course covers a very broad time period so it doesn't go into too much detail on any one part. That can be good or bad depending on what you're looking for. Also, precepts can be pretty hit or miss because some of the preceptors aren't that good and some of the students in the class aren't too engaged in the material.
Highly recommend!
I loved this course and could not recommend it more highly if I tried. Professor Grafton is amazing and I found the material incredibly interesting. Definitely take it!

I was surprised by how much I enjoyed and learned from this class.  I'm a physics major and history isn't really my thing, but I really enjoyed Grafton's lectures.  I actually went to class not out of duty and habit, but because I found Grafton's lectures genuinely interesting.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The reading can overwhelm you if you don't stay on top of it, but overall it's pretty manageable. And the lectures are amazing.
I would strongly recommend this course.
I would tell them to go to lecture and do the primary source reading because all the information for the course is there.
If Prof. Grafton is teaching the course, take it - his lectures are amazing.

If you only take one history class while at Princeton, TAKE THIS COURSE! Prof. Grafton is a genius and he genuinely cares about his students and the material. His lectures were the highlight of my class schedule this semester. You will learn so much! Cannot recommend enough.

If you're interested in history, take this course! Lectures are like story time and preceptors are really nice and engaged. May be a lot of reading and more stringent grading than desired by someone looking to get a requirement out of the way, but if you actually have any interest in European history, you will probably really enjoy this course. It's also good if you're a potential history major and you want to get a better idea of what areas European history you're more/less interested in.
Interesting class. Grafton is great. Precepts vary. Need a robust list/ summary of primary sources to do well on the tests.
Keep track of big themes as you go through the course -- will be helpful for the final!
Meet with your preceptor - it helps!
Professor Grafton is a great lecturer. I recommend taking the course for the opportunity to hear him lecture. The readings are generally pretty interesting too.
Professor Grafton is hands down one of the best lecturers I've had the pleasure of hearing speak in my last seven semesters here. It's all worth it for his lectures.
TAKE IT!!!
TAKE THIS COURSE. For that matter, take any course with Professor Grafton.
TAKE THIS COURSE. You will not regret it. Great survey of European History.
Take it if you want an interesting HA with reasonable amounts of work.
Take it! It's a great overview of European history up through the Reformation and it's a great gauge of what doing History here means. The readings are awesome as well!
Take it, because it has awesome lectures, but beware of all the reading and information to come.
Take it.
Take it. TAKE IT. You will not regret it.
Take the course but probably PDF it.
Take this course as Professor Grafton is very good indeed, but be prepared to manage a lot of material in a closed note final
Take this course! Grafton is so charismatic and he makes even the mos boring and daunting readings interesting, which the reason you should go to every lecture if you can.
Take this course!! Excellent lecturer and interesting course material. A lot of reading but very manageable.
Take this course. Just take it. It's one of the best lectures in Princeton--you'll be doing yourself a favor.

This class gives you a good sense of what Professor Grafton's lectures are like. The class also exposes you to more content than you can digest (condensation of ~2000 years of history into one semester), with lots of opportunities to learn how to read primary sources like a historian.  Even though the pace of the readings was very fast for me, I really appreciated having exposure to thinkers like Abelard, Aquinas, Pico, Machiavelli, and More. It's quite rare for people to study such a wide span of human history in a short amount of time. Focus on the readings you and your preceptor care about. Ask your preceptor and Grafton for advice on your final paper throughout the writing process. Although the class is huge, Grafton and his graduate minions make a great effort to help students on an individual basis.
This class is excellent, go to the lectures because it's Grafton's amazing storytelling that makes the class.

This course is an absolute must if you are interested at all in the humanities. Even if you are an engineer or a quantitative person, this class will open your eyes to the ways in which science developed from philosophy. This is a class for everyone. Take it. Professor Grafton's lectures are fantastic.

This course is phenomenal. One of the best I've taken at Princeton. Tony Grafton's reputation precedes him and you will see why--every lecture, he knocked it out of the park. You will learn a lot about European history, but you will also learn to think like a scholar.

This is a really great course, full of interesting stories and invigorating reading. Prof Grafton is a wonderful, funny lecturer. Jenna Phillips was my preceptor and she was the best I've ever had. Not a ton of work (plenty of reading, though) and just a class you don't dread going to cause it's kinda fun.
WONDERFUL
Worth it if you do the readings.
take it
take it if you have the chance!
take it if you want a fairly easy fairly interesting history in this time period.
descrip: This course shows how Greeks and Romans, Jews and Christians, nobles and merchants built the civilization of the west.

title: Quantum Mechanics with Applications
reviews: Make sure you have significant experience with Quantum Mechanics before taking the class.
Recommended for people who have taken at least 1-2 quantum mechanics courses before. For beginners very hard work will be required.
This will give you a good background in QM
better take an undergrad quantum course before
might be useful for newers in Quantum mechanics, or as a review.
prereqs: ELE342 or PHY 305 or equivalent or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course covers the principles of quantum mechanics, including applications of relevance to students in applied physics, materials science and engineering. Topics include the concept of Hilbert Spaces, Schrodinger and Heisenberg Representations, Bound State problems in one, two and three dimensions, consequences of symmetry, Angular momentum algebra, Approximation methods for stationary states, Many-body systems, Quantum statistics, Time dependent Perturbation Theory, Second Quantization and Electromagnetic Fields.

title: Disease Ecology, Economics, and Policy
reviews: 3 hour lectures are brutal. The stuff you need to know you learn in precept. Hopefully the way this class is set up will change
Do not take this class if you need to fulfill Woody Woo requirement; there are much better and easier classes offered.
Don't do this for WWS science requirement, just don't
Great course for those looking to fill science requirement for WWS or who are in GHP and interested in more of the quantitative issues of health and health policy.

I would recommend this course because you definitely learn a lot of material and it is challenging.  However, grading can be a bit rough and sometimes expectations aren't 100% clear.  The lectures can get really boring and confusing and that is why precept is so important.  In precept, a lot of what was confusing will be clarified very well.  When you learn code it will be important to really pay attention and learn it so that you don't get overwhelmed with your poster project.  This class might be a struggle at times but at least it fulfills GHP and WWS and presents some really cool, esoteric material.

I would take this course to fill the WWS science requirement, but know that it is quite a lot of (often unpleasant) work particularly with the poster project. It is interesting material, but since last year it seems the course has become much more difficult than it had been in the past. I would not take this course just for fun/interest, particularly without a really strong science background.
If you are interested in global health and in the relation of science and policy take this course!
If you need a science policy class, don't take this one. It is more math and science than it is economics and policy.
It was an okay class. It was pretty interesting at times, but the grading is very nit-picky, and the math was kind of confusing.

Its an interesting class. WWS concentrators will probably find it harder than some of the other science policy classes. It isn't as policy oriented as it might seem. Pretty standard EEB class. Problem sets and midterm were pretty fair. I thought the final was harder than expected.
Not too much work. Pretty interesting.
Pay attention in lecture! It's very important.

Precepts are super important - make sure you go and take good notes. Focus primarily on lecture material when reviewing for exams. Super interesting if you're into public health, but make sure you're willing to work hard and ask questions for the assignments.
Really interesting course, however, the final project was much more work intensive than expected and required R.
Really interesting. Learned a lot. Had fun with the project even though it was a lot of work.

Recognize going in that this class is a huge amount of work. The professors and preceptors are very busy and over-worked and won't care about you personally that much. You have to fight for attention and help. You will learn a huge amount and it will be very interesting, but your grades will probably suffer unless you are an EEB/ENV or GHP students. They will have a big advantage over you. Your work will be graded arbitrarily and you won't be given good reasons why. So take it for the love of learning, but accept that it will be frustrating and demoralizing at times.
Start working on the poster sooner rather than later.
Take a lot of notes during lecture
Take this class if you like diseases. Might have been too much science for some WWS students.  May be repetitive if you've taken many public health/epi courses, but the modeling material will be new.
The material is so interesting but it is often hard to pay attention for the entire lecture!
This class was even more difficult for a WWS major. Be prepared to put in a lot of time and effort for this class.
This is an extremely difficult class for anyone who has no background in it. If you're a WWS major looking for a Science Policy requirement, I recommend looking elsewhere.

This is an ok class. Go to office hours. Make sure you're in a good precept because the preceptor makes all the difference.  Don't feel overwhelmed by the amount of math they introduce, it gets easier as you go.
We covered a LOT of material in this class. It moves at a really fast pace, but you learn a lot.
idk record the lectures or something it's almost impossible to pay attention for three hours straight which is a shame because the material is actually interesting
n/a

the math during lectures will be explained during precepts, so you don't have to worry too much about that. try your best to pay attention during lectures though as that will be the bulk of the essay and short answer segments during the midterm and final.
the midterm is unexpectedly tricky and there is quite a gap in the performance of WWS versus non-WWS students
prereqs: Calculus is required..
descrip: The dynamics of the emergence and spread of disease arise from a complex interplay between disease ecology, economics, and human behavior. Lectures will provide an introduction to complementarities between economic and epidemiological approaches to understanding the emergence, spread, and control of infectious diseases. The course will cover topics such as drug-resistance in bacterial and parasitic infections, individual incentives to vaccinate, the role of information in the transmission of infectious diseases, and the evolution of social norms in healthcare practices.

title: Modern China
descrip: This seminar introduces students to major historiographical and methodological issues in twentieth-century Chinese history, with emphasis on the Republican period. Topics reflect theoretical debates and empirical questions, including: nationalism and citizenship, urban life, gender and sexuality, the Communist revolution, early PRC history.

title: Institutional Finance,Trading and Markets
reviews: Good course to take
Highly recommended! Both Professor and the preceptor are so nice and helpful!
I think it's an intro level course to a lot of asset pricing concepts and some behavior finance materials.
It is a good course for undergrads to get a overall idea of how things work
Not very demanding class but we see too many models in my opinion
Some understanding of statistics could be useful. Very interesting and different course.
Will recommend the course

any student with limited background in economics and finance should take this course as an introductory level course that provides an overview of some theoretical concepts. the trading simulation is also helpful.
prereqs: introductory asset pricing class (ECO 363/FIN 501) or derivatives pricing class (ECO 465 / FIN 522).
descrip: Institutional Finance examines how finance professionals create value through the practical application of the theory of finance. The course presents a unified framework for thinking about financial decisions focused on the perspective of managers of financial institutions. Students should emerge from the semester capable of valuing a broad range of financial instruments and investment opportunities. They will be able to identify, implement, and manage risks associated with a wide variety of investment strategies.

title: Designing Secure Systems
reviews: Go for it.
I like the project aspect of the course. Professor Mittal is an engaging lecturer, and the workload isn't all that bad.

I think since this is a introductory course, I might not recommend it to a very advanced student in Cyber Security but its definitely a great course for a someone new to the field or someone who has no background in the subject.. It also exposes you to ample of state of the art research opportunities..
Interesting material but pretty disorganized course overall
It is similar to Information Security

It is worth taking if you are interesing in privacy and security, especially focusing on the online social network or other software-based systems.
Prof. Mittal gave you a solid fundation and background, which helps you prepared for your future research.
Lots of overlap with Information Security, so if you've taken that you'll be set. Otherwise it's about the same difficulty level but with a project instead of frequent assignments.
good
prereqs: This course is for seniors and graduate students who wish to develop a background in security. Previous exposure to security is not required..
descrip: Our society is increasingly transitioning towards an information-centric paradigm, enabled by pervasive networked computing devices. This has brought concerns about security and privacy to a forefront; attackers can undermine security and privacy by exploiting vulnerabilities in our systems and protocols. This course focuses on fundamental mechanisms that enable security. These include cryptographic mechanisms, architectural techniques, and network-level primitives. We will also study how to leverage interdisciplinary techniques from formal methods and machine learning to secure our systems.

title: Electrical Engineering Master's Project
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out a master's-level project and presents their results. For M. Eng. student, 597, fall term; 598 spring term.

title: Workshop on Social Organization
descrip: A two-semester course for graduate students whose work is at the intersection of the fields of organization studies, economic sociology and social network analysis. In addition to covering foundational readings in these fields and addressing selected special topics (e.g. social organizational aspects of economic crisis), the workshop provides opportunities for students to develop research projects and presentation skills, and to read the work of and interact with scholars brought to campus by the Center for the Study of Social Organization.

title: Studies in Indian Religions - Up to 1300
descrip: This course is a survey of major text traditions in Indian religions, with an emphasis on the historical/cultural framework against which to read the development of Buddhist traditions. Major topics addressed are: "Orientalism" & "Hinduism"; Vedas & Upanisads; Early Buddhism; Dharmasastras & Mahabharata; Mahayana Buddhism; and Tantra & Vajrayana.

title: Structural Analysis for Architecture
reviews: Keep up with the material and attend precepts!
descrip: Elementary structural analysis for architecture students covering statics, strength of materials and approximate methods of analysis, including historical examples.

title: Intensive Fourth-Year Modern Chinese I
reviews: Definitely keep on top of the schedule and don't push your work off. It is a very work-intensive class so I recommend finding a routine that works for you and keeping that routine. Try to read your readings and review the vocab before class so that the actual class time can be spent more on discussing the readings than on trying to learn every vocab word. Don't just know the definition of the vocab, actually know how to use it in a sentence, because that is what you will be tested on.
Excellent course if you want to improve your spoken and written Chinese. You get out of this course what you put into it; if you want to learn a lot of higher-grade vocab you will.
Good luck have fun!
If you are comfortable with your conversational Mandarin, take a different 400-level class. If you want to learn grammar structures and be more comfortable with formal writing, take this class.
It is not an easy course. I would take it if you are genuinely interested in learning the language. It is hard but manageable.
Only take it if you KNOW you're going to put a lot of effort into this course.
prereqs: CHI 305, CHI 306 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Reading and discussion based on Chinese scholarly journals, popular essays, and newspaper articles. Students are exposed to a variety of modern Chinese literary genres, as well as some of the major substantive issues that modern Chinese intellectuals have faced.

title: Golden-Age Poetry
descrip: A close reading of selected lyric poetry of the Renaissance and Baroque periods. The course will have a workshop format: every week each student will prepare a brief analysis of a given poem in order to stimulate class discussion.

title: Japanese Monsters and Ghosts: A Social History
descrip: Please see freshman seminars website

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: ABSOLUTELY take this with A.M. Homes! She is incredible - brilliant, attentive, honest, and incredibly helpful. Favourite creative writing professor so far.
Absolutely take it. Joyce Carol Oates is leaving, unfortunately, but this is still a great class.
Definitely take if interested in certificate.
Do it but be prepared for honest (sometimes too honest) criticism and definitely make sure you drive your own writing because there's a lot of flexibility in how much effort you have to put in.
Don't take it just because its JCO - she is pretty cool and not a bad teacher, but there are better ones.
Great course! Professor Oates is an inspiring teacher, and very helpful in editing fiction.
JCO was very chill and her class very inflexible.  The only downside is sometimes she would dominate the conversation, making it feel a little boring.
Professor Oates is not going to hand you anything. You get from the course what you put into it.
Take it if you need motivation to write short stories biweekly.
Take it! And be willing to properly engage.
Take it! Professor Homes is brilliant.
Take this.
definitely take any creative writing course, and if you have the opportunity to take one with professor oates don't miss out.
take this course if you are serious about craft, and know that this professor will care about your work and engage with it, not just go through the motions
prereqs: By application only. Students must have completed two 200-level CWR courses prior to applying. Please visit the Lewis Center Creative Writing website for application information. Application deadline is April 11, 2014. Accepted students will be able to enroll in SCORE May 19th-23rd..
descrip: Advanced practice in the original composition of fiction for discussion in regularly scheduled workshop meetings. The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Utopias, Dystopias, and Manifestos
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Corporate Finance and Financial Accounting
descrip: Major topics in modern corporate finance. We will study investment policy (investment decision rules, project valuation, cost of capital) and financial policy (mostly capital structure decisions). Additional topics (private equity, bankruptcy and reorganization, merger and acquisitions) will be covered if time permits.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
reviews: Good course to take. Be sure to go to meetings, be at least a little engaged, you could make something really cool.
This is a great course and the workload is fair.
prereqs: Seniors only (except for juniors who have completed EGR 351)..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Proseminar in Anthropology
descrip: First term of a two-term survey of major anthropological writings, primarily for first-year graduate students. This seminar will focus on some major figures who have influenced anthropological theory and shaped our ideas of what anthropology is or should be. Historical formulations of some issues which are currently revisited and hotly debated such as rationalization and unreason, science and communication, subjectivity and dialogic encounters, and the status of knowledge and truth in the social sciences will be examined.

title: Advanced Econometrics: Nonlinear Models
reviews: To succeed in this course you need to be well-prepared from 517-518, and have an excellent general math background. You should not take it if you are just an applied micro student ? just ask technical questions in your applied courses. However, I?m also sure the class differs a lot depending on the instructor.
descrip: This is half of the second-year sequence in econometrics methodology (ECO 513 is the other). The course covers nonlinear statistical models for the analysis of cross-sectional and panel data. It is intended both for students specializing in econometric theory and for students interested in applying statistical methods to statistical data. Approximately half of the course is devoted to development of the large-sample theory for nonlinear estimation procedures, while the other half concentrates on application of the methods to various econometric models.

title: Optimization Under Uncertainty
reviews: At the core, the material is interesting, but the class itself could be organized a bit better.

Fantastic ORF class!! You get to learn a lot about asset allocation and the more practical applications of ORFE. Professor Mulvey is great! The assignments/projects are the perfect amount (no exams!), and you become very good at excel after the class! TAKE IT!

I recommend taking this class because it is the first ORF course I have taken that has put such a strong emphasis on real world applications. Start your homework early. Pay attention in class or at least reread your notes sometimes regardless of whether they are relevant to the assignments because there is a lot of very useful information taught in this course.
Professor Mulvey cares a lot about the subject, but be warned that he focuses on financial analysis rather than the optimization. Overall, a very good class though and a reasonable amount of work.
prereqs: ORF 307 or MAT 305, and ORF 309.
descrip: A survey of quantitative approaches for making optimal decisions under uncertainty, including decision trees, Monte Carlo simulation, and stochastic programs. Forecasting and planning systems are integrated with a focus on financial applications.

title: Becoming a 21st Century Scientist: Modern Scientific Communication
reviews: -Great course for forcing yourself to think, write and speak about your project. Great way to prepare for generals especially for those who struggle with public speaking.

I would recommend this course for other students if they feel that accountability will help in their preparation for generals. It was a great help to consistently get feedback as my project evolved from people outside the lab and always helpful to hear that my classmates were struggling with the same issues.
This course is fabulous, and it will prepare you for generals!
descrip: This course is designed to teach core competencies needed to succeed as an independent scientist. Students develop skills in (1) knowledge acquisition; (2) critically evaluating scientific findings; (3) formulating questions that push forward the boundaries of science; (4) developing testable hypotheses; (5) creating an innovative research plan employing discipline-specific techniques and the appropriate controls; (6) writing a well-organized, logical and succinct research proposal; and (7) become proficient in communicating knowledge, research findings and defending ideas through verbal presentations.

title: Democracy
reviews: Beware that the emphasis of this course is more on theoretical models and math than Democratic Theory, which is more about learning the ideas of historical philosophers and situating them in a modern context of democracy.
Don't take it!
Don't take it.

I've probably learned more than I have in almost any other course I've taken at Princeton. It's an amazing course but is probably not what you're expecting. This is NOT a case study course, so you won't learn specifics about other countries. It focuses on abstract considerations rather than actual happenings. I personally loved the theories, but some classmates were frustrated. There's also a game-theoretical/quantitative component when it comes to voting behavior, so be warned if that's not your thing.
Although lectures are sometimes a little dry, Boix is very clear, organized, and overall quite good. The course covers a lot of material, but there is much less reading than other 300-level POL courses, and the papers are short and easy. Definitely a low-stress class. Get Kevin for precept. He's phenomenal.
If you're not interested in game theory-type stuff, this is not the politics course for you.
Not a lot of work, but graded pretty tough.
Participate in precept
Recommend.
The readings are more helpful than the lectures.

The subject matter in this class is fascinating. It will give you a much more nuanced and critical understanding of democracy. The readings and papers for the class are not too onerous, but some of the theoretical models used in the class can be confusing. Some of the expectations for the written work were opaque. Overall, the tradeoff between effort in and knowledge out is entirely reasonable and a strong reason to take the course.
There is a fair amount of math. If you aren't ok with that, don't take it or PDF. Very rewarding though.
While technical at times, anyone interested in democratization and economic redistribution should take this course
take it if you're interested and somewhat good w/ stats
prereqs: Not open to auditors..
descrip: This course explores the following issues: the exercise of power in dictatorial regimes (and their institutional structure); the economic and social conditions that facilitate the transition to democracy and its consolidation; voting in democratic elections and decision-making in committees and assemblies or parliaments; the role of electoral institutions; the mechanisms through which politicians are accountable to the public; the nature and performance of presidentialism and parliamentarism; the role of inequality in democracy; the impact of globalization on the governance of contemporary democracies.

title: Intermediate Arabic II
prereqs: ARA 105 or permission of the department..
descrip: A continuation of ARA 105 Intermediate Arabic I. This course continues the development of students' speaking, listening, reading and writing skills.

title: Building Science and Technology: Building Systems
reviews: Absolutely take it if you can. Show up to lectures and enjoy!
Friday morning lectures are rough, but make the effort to go to class. It's very easy to do well if you attend the lectures.
Get excited. It's a good course and you'll learn a lot.
Take if required in your major

The labs are a big percentage of the course, so make sure to go to those. They are also quite fun and hands-on. The readings are not so heavy, so if you supplement them by going to lecture you can expect a good grade.
take it
prereqs: The material in class requires students to have some experience and understanding of architectural design, drawings and details. It is required that undergraduate students have completed ARC203, ARC204 before embarking on this class. Engineering majors earning an architecture certificate should contact the instructor for permission to enroll in the course..
descrip: This course introduces students to the art and science of building. Emphasis will be placed gaining an understanding of construction materials, methods and the process of translating design ideas into built form. Specific topics are introduced each week during the two one-hour lectures. These topics are then further explored, and students gain hands on experience, each week during the two-hour laboratory component of the course.

title: Jazz Theory through Improvisation and Composition II
reviews: Don't shrug off composition guidelines; be creative but make sure you adhere to the challenge presented.
Great course on jazz composition.
Spend a lot of time on the few compositions you write, and take advantage of the textbook.
prereqs: Music 105 or Instructor's Permission.
descrip: An examination of the theoretical principles found in modal jazz through analysis of representative works by such composers as Wayne Shorter, Joe Henderson, and Herbie Hancock. The course will place a strong emphasis on student projects in improvisation and composition.

title: Advanced Computer Networks
reviews: A great course, the mock committee for paper review is very nice.
Be prepared to read lots of papers, but don't be turned off. Practice makes perfect.
Good discussion class, but don't expect to learn anything specific from the lectures. Just expect to absorb what everyone is saying in the class.

I do strongly recommend students in computer science and other related majors to take this course, specially with Dr. Rexford being the professor. They will learn many interesting points about the networks surrounding them and how they have evolved.
I loved 461 and guess I was expecting more. This course seemed to be more of a networking overview and is great good for non-systems students.
I'd recommend this course only in case if networks is your major field or it's very close to it.
If Jen is teaching this course take it!
If you are interested in networks, I feel this course is a must.
It is an excellent course that is definitely worth taking.
Jennifer Rexford is a world expert in networks and a fabulous lecturer.  The course is very accessible to anyone with a basic background in networks.
Networking is a strange specialty which exists somewhere between theory and application. If you're interested in the topic at all, I highly recommend this course. Rexford alone makes it worthwhile.

Not a great course but not a terrible course either. The final project is fun but some of the papers are pretty boring. The class was too large for a discussion, but we tried to have one anyways, which meant that a lot of people talked about how the papers made them feel rather than drilling down into how the systems actually worked. I feel like I would have learned more if it had been a lecture-based course. If you have a class that you really want to take, take it before this.
Participate in class and think outside the box
Start projects early!
Start your project early.
The class is great. Prof. Rexford gave the best lectures i have ever attended. Definitely take this class.
The class is well-organized and I really recommend it if you are interested in network.
The class requires lots of initiative -- to really get through the papers, to work early and frequently on the research project, and to contribute in lecture.
The course is very helpful for students interested in networking and systems research.
They should take it.
This course is good.
You should take it.
descrip: Survey of computer networks covering end-to-end principle, multiplexing, virtualization, packet switching vs. circuit switching, router design, network protocols, congestion control, internet routing architecture, network measurement, network management, and overlay networks. Survey of research papers from classic literature through contemporary research.

title: Preserving the Past
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to Riemann Surfaces
prereqs: A basic background in function of a complex variable is required (such as MAT330 or MAT429); some preliminary experience with continuity and differential form would be helpful (such as MAT215 and MAT218)..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the theory of compact Riemann surfaces, including some basic properties of the topology of surfaces, differential forms and the basis existence theorems, the Riemann-Roch theorem and some of its consequences, and the general uniformization theorem if time permits.

title: Dissertation Seminar
descrip: Open to post-generals students actively working on their dissertations. The seminar aims at assisting students in their research and writing and at developing their teaching skills by improving their ability to present advanced material to less expert audiences. Students make presentations of work in progress, discuss each other's work, and share common pedagogical problems and solutions under the guidance of one or more faculty members. It meets for two hours each week throughout the academic year.

title: Illusions, Delusions, and Neuroscience
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Geometric Analysis and General Relativity - Advanced Topics in General Relativity
prereqs: Undergrads must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will cover a selection of advanced topics in General Relativity, which could include the construction of dynamical black hole spacetimes, the formation of weak null singularities for the vacuum, and the stability of the Schwarzschild black hole.

title: Advanced Japanese I
reviews: A fine continuation to your previous education.
Class is a lot of work and difficult, but has excellent professors and is a fun and engaging class.
Go to class. Read the material. Engage with classmates and professor.
Good course to improve your Japanese. I felt like I learned less than in second year, though. Didn't seem as intensive.
I think it is great to take this class.

I would definitely recommend Japanese to any students considering it. It takes a considerable amount of work, but if you have an interest in Japanese, it is definitely worth it to take this class because of the awesome teachers and the class structure. I would also highly recommend taking PII before 3rd year because it makes it much easier to retain the amount of content you'll go through in a short period of time.
If you like Japanese, might as well.

If you're interested in improving your Japanese to a more natural level, then take this course. Whereas first- and second-year Japanese gives you the grammar you need to communicate, third-year takes that and shows you how to construct more natural expressions with it.
Matsui sensei is much more laidback than the others, so if you want to get more out of office hours and such, you'll have to be more self-motivated.
Take it if you really like Japanese for the language or else it will be quite dry.
Take it! Japanese is amazing, Japan is amazing, the course is amazing.
Take it, as well as any third year language course. If you've taken second year Japanese, do it.
Take it, it's a lot of fun!
Take this course!
it's a lot of work
prereqs: JPN 107. Students should have completed Intermediate (second-year) Japanese or equivalent as a prerequisite to admission in JPN 301.
descrip: This course is designed to further students' reading ability. Students will have ample opportunity to hear and use increasingly more sophisticated vocabulary and grammatical construction through discussion and composition. Japanese video tapes will also be incorporated into the course. Reading materials include "Tobira" and selected readings from works in the original language.

title: Rationality and Human Reasoning
reviews: Interesting course which covers (a bit superficially) basic logic, hypothesis testing, epistemology, and computation. A bit easy for those majoring in technical fields (like math and cs).
It's pretty tough. Definitely not for everybody. Very rewarding if you like this sort of thing.

Like all of Prof. Osherson's courses, he whizzes through his slide deck and then doesn't provide the slides to you. Also doesn't hold regular office hours. This makes this class difficult to not P/D/F, because it's so hard to study for it.
Not a hard class, keep up with readings (weekly quizzes) and go to lectures (lecture slides not posted online).
Read quiz questions very carefully.
Take as good EC

Take it if you want an introduction to logic (not as rigorous as something in the math department, obviously, but still informative to someone without prior experience) and probability, as this class not only introduces theories of logic, language, and probability but also contextualizes them in terms of (descriptively) how people actually reason (at times examining where perspectives such as those of psychologists, evolutionary biologists, and economists lead to intense disagreements over the implications of experimental results). The time commitment is relatively small, so the rewards are even more pronounced.

This class is basically random topics from COS 126, ECO 100, ORF 245, and PHI 201 packaged together and called a PSY class. So, if you're good at the subject matter of those classes, take this. Otherwise, don't
This class is not really a psych class, its an introduction to mathematical logic
descrip: Reaching belief and making decisions are two activities performed especially well by humans. Contemporary investigation distinguishes normative from descriptive questions about belief and decision. The former concern how our cognition ought to function; the latter, how it actually functions. Fundamental theories of belief and decision will be presented in the course, and discussed from both the normative and descriptive perspectives. Utility, logic, probability, and abduction will all be examined, with additional topics drawn from computability theory and from collective choice.

title: Mathematics for Economics/Life Sciences
reviews: A very fair math class, especially compared to MAT103

Absolutely take this class if needed as a requirement or for a general understanding of multivariable. From my understanding of most math courses at Princeton, this class is unique in its ability to still encourage critical thinking without overwhelming students with extremely difficult problem sets or exams. This class complimented relevant, effective teaching with reasonable homework and exams.
All the very best.
Attend tutoring and office hours!
Be on top of the problem sets and go to office hours as much as possible.
Do not take unless you have to. Don't take math at Princeton.
Do your problem sets and stay on top of your work.
Don't take if you want to learn useful math or applied math.
Give yourself enough time to study the material and do p-sets. It doesn't seem like a lot, but if you miss a concept, the whole p-set will take even longer.
Go to class, get your problem sets done early, go to office hours, use McGraw.
Go to every lecture, otherwise you're going to have difficulty learning the material on your own.
Go to lectures, take good notes, redo old problems and examples when you study.  Also office hours.
Go to review sessions
Good class if you are planning on using this stuff and not doing physics/engineering.
Good course. Don't fear workload.
Good math class to take after 103!
I recommend the course, and advise students to grasp all the topics before the week of the quiz.

I recommend this course if you need it for ECO; the problem sets are difficult but in opposite to most courses offered in the math department, tests and quizzes are very fair and not meant to trick you.
I would advise that they take it but not rely too much on the textbook to learn the material.
I would tell the student that being engaged is very important, and that one should attempt to always understand the material well.
If they are interested in Multi-Variable Calculus or are interested in a Economics major, I would recommend them to take the course.

If you are a prospective Econ/Woody Woo/etc. major, definitely take this class instead of 201/202. A number students originally in 201 ended up having to drop down to 175 because 201 is just too hard. 175 teaches you what you need to know in a very clear and thorough way - I have never been more confident about my math abilities than I am after having taken 175. It goes without saying that you must regularly attend classes, but you also should attend the weekly review sessions with Vu Chan or other undergraduate course assistants. These are helpful to practice harder problems. Before quizzes/exams, also be sure to go to the professors' extra office hours. Lastly, take advantage of McGraw Study Hall to review homework problems - it is possible to consistently get 100% (or close to it) on problem sets by checking your answers with classmates. If you work hard and take advantage of the resources available, there is no reason you shouldn't do well and learn a lot. Don't hesitate about taking this class if you need it!

If you don't have a recent or strong math background but need a math course, this is the one for you. Prof. Johnson is hilarious and teaches the concepts really well (and in an organized fashion!) through examples. I believed in math at Princeton again after this course!
If you're looking for an easy math class, this is it.
It's boring and irrelevant, but at least is isn't hard.
Keep up with the work and you will do well.
Keep up with the worrk and its not bad
Make sure to go over the concepts and be sure to understand them quickly so that you won't forget them. Everything is interconnected.
Make sure to review your notes and read the chapters. If not, you will easily become lost.
Make sure you understand your work on the problem sets, will come in handy later
McGraw is normally very helpful
Need it for an econ major. Hanne was great
Not a bad class
Only if you have to, or if you have a random interest in math.
Pay close attention in lecture and take your time on the problem sets.
Pretty easy course, consistently attend lectures because helps with understanding. If you're looking for more rigorous math then definitely take mat201
Study for the test and you'll do fine. HW was harder than tests.
Take it and stay on top of homework
Take it for a QR. Incredible teacher, great support system with McGraw if you need help and the bar is not set unreasonably high as with some other math classes.
Take it if you have to. It's not that hard if you pay attention in class.

Take it with Professor Johnson! It does take a lot of time and effort at times to understand the concepts and able to apply them to complex math problems but it is intellectually stimulating and just the right level of difficulty for those who like math but do not want to go into harder courses like 202 and beyond.
Take it. A lot easier than 103, very intuitive concepts.
Take this class with Johnson if you have to take it for a departmental requirement. Otherwise its not worth taking.
Take this course
Take this course if you're not a math geek but you want to learn the basics you will need in higher economics classes.

The class was very good and moved at a nice pace for me. However, I was expecting much more application to specific problems related to Life Sciences and Economics. This course is great if you're looking for a class that teaches multivariable at a slightly more manageable pace than 201, but if you're hoping for practical application you'll probably be disappointed.
This course is fairly easy and Professor Johnson is great. She's an excellent teacher with a great sense of humor.
This is an especially good course to take if you are an AB COS major. It spares you the pain of taking a 200 level math course.
Work systematically and it will not be hard.
excellent if you are not strong at/don't like math. If you are interested in learning multi in more depth rather than just the beginning of the basic concepts, probably not the course for you.
go to lecture because thats the best way to learn the material. much better than the book
good for ppl who dont want to continue w/ math
not gonna be fun
would recommend
prereqs: MAT103 or equivalent..
descrip: Survey of topics from multivariable calculus as preparation for future course work in economics or life sciences. Topics include basic techniques of integration, average value, vectors, partial derivatives, gradient, optimization of multivariable functions, and constrained optimization with Lagrange multipliers.

title: Music in the Renaissance
reviews: Go ahead and take it - it's fun! Be aware that all Renaissance music pretty much sounds the same, though, with a few notable exceptions.
I strongly recommend this course.  It was a LOT of reading, but overall it was very interesting and the music we had to listen to (and eventually memorize by hearing) was beautiful.

I would advise them to keep an open mind about Renaissance music, as it is definitely more interesting than it presents, but it was ultimately disjunct and did not present much opportunity to really learn about and connect with the material.
Interesting material, be prepared for unclarity and chaos.
Take it if you want the professor.
You can try it out, but expect to do a lot of reading. Also, if you're interested in the music THEORY, don't take this course. It's mostly history, there's very little theory involved.
descrip: General historical survey of European Art Music in the period 1400-1600, covering such composers as Dufay, Ockeghem, Josquin, Byrd, Palestrina, Lasso, etc.

title: Physics of Earth, the Habitable Planet
reviews: I wouldn't recommend this course. The material is interesting but the lectures are poorly explained and the class is not organized very well, leaving you frustrated most of the time.
Take it!
Take this course if you are looking for a good qualitative exposure to climate science.
Talk to professor, ta, and preceptor for help.

The workload is very manageable throughout the semester. However, the latter part of the course gets quite work heavy. Make sure to start early on the Dean's date assignments and final projects. Working steadily over a long period of time is key to getting the final projects done. Attend lecture and take good notes.
This course has a lot of tedious assignments that are not conceptually hard, but take a lot of time. Do the readings in the book to clarify the topics.

Well....they assigned the final paper in September, and then completely changed it a week before the winter break. Also, two huge class projects are due on Dean's date. Also, there is no percentage breakdown of grades, so you have no idea which assignments count for anything.

Philander is actually really interesting and so is the class subject matter.....but not sure whether it's worth taking owing to the disorganization fo the class.
prereqs: MAT 201, PHY 104 or equivalent.
descrip: Earth's habitability depends on the continual recycling of various gases and even rocks, mainly between the atmosphere, oceans, "solid" earth and biosphere. The atmospheric and oceanic circulation's that effect this recycling involve phenomena such as the weather, hurricanes, Jet Streams, tsunamis, the Gulf's Stream, deserts, jungles, El Nino and La Nina. The class will discuss how global warming will affect these phenomena.

title: Bakhtin, the Russian Formalists, and Cultural Semiotics
reviews: I don't believe it's going to be offered anymore, but if it is, definitely take it if you are interested in literature at all, not just Slavic literature.
If Caryl Emerson is teaching, this might be the best course taught at Princeton. Be ready to use a lot of your brainpower on it, but also get more out of a class than you ever have before.
Sadly, Prof. Emerson is retiring after this year, but I think this will still be a good course because of the material.
Take it, but I think Caryl is leaving.
Take it, take it, take it! Even if the material doesn't immediately sound like it will interest you, Professor Emerson is amazing, and you will learn more than you could possibly expect.
There is a certain buy-in factor. You have to want to do the readings and want to learn the material. If you aren't going to do the readings, don't bother taking it.
prereqs: Knowledge of Russian not required..
descrip: The seminar surveys (in English) three influential schools of 20th-century Russian textual and cultural criticism: the Russian Formalists (1920s); Mikhail Bakhtin (1920s-70s), and the cultural semiotics of Yury Lotman and the Tartu School (1960s-80s). Readings will include both primary and secondary texts; major essays will be read in conjunction with literature that illustrates and tests the critical approach.

title: Inorganic Chemistry: Structure and Bonding
reviews: A very well-taught course with interesting material and a reasonable, directed workload.  Expect some exam-time stress (because the tests had a lot of material in a little time), but overall the course was really great and presented with a care that other higher-level chemistry courses typically aren't.
Be ready to go fast on the exams. Otherwise, this class is a pretty straightforward one. Interesting topics, well-taught, and not hugely stressful.
Be sure to understand the material well. The exams are extremely long, so the only hope in finishing them is if one works quickly. Also, do  not procrastinate on the homework. It is quite long.

CHM 407 is a well organized course. The subject matter is an in-depth extension of general chemistry topics and didn't blow my mind, but it was interesting to see a more rigorous theoretical basis for some of the phenomena we observe in chemistry.

Definitely take CHM 407 over 408, for departmental course in inorganic CHM. In inorganic, VanderKam is enthusiastic, knowledgable, and very dedicated to her students and will help you find success at whatever level you enter the course in. Go to class. Please, I urge you to take this course.

Don't get behind. Also learn to appreciate how fun this material actually is - it's easy to get lost in numbers and charts and things, don't do that because what is actually happening is actually really conceptually cool.
Find study buddies?
I definitely recommend it. Take it before 408

I know that you've been told that you can take CHM 407 and CHM 408 in any order, but I am of the opinion (having taken 408 first) that it would have been better to take 407 first.

This class is very fair. Do your work and study hard and good things will come to you. You also learn a lot about IR, UV-Vis, Raman, etc...

If you take this course, you will learn a lot about inorganic chemistry. Just be ready to work fast on the exams. Literally, practice each type of problem until you have no hesitations. I have never felt so short on time on any other exam.
It's not enough to know the material on the exams, you must practice so that you'll be able to do everything QUICKLY.
TAKE THIS CLASS!! This is by far the best chem class I have taken at Princeton.  Go to VanderKam's office hours if you ever have questions.  She is incredibly helpful and dedicated.
Take it! It's wonderful and super useful! It's like Quantum and Organic had the most perfect baby in the world.
You likely need this as a CHM departmental.
prereqs: CHM 301/302, or CHM 303/304, or equivalent is required..
descrip: Structural principles and bonding theories are discussed for various classes of main group inorganic and transition metal coordination compounds. Includes an introduction to the electronic structure of d-orbitals and ligand field theory.

title: Composition
descrip: Emphasis will be placed upon the individual student's original work and upon the study and discussion of pieces pertinent to that work.

title: Topics in Differential Geometry - Kahler-Einstein Metrics
prereqs: Undergraduates must request permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will start with the basics in Kahler geometry. Next, we will discuss the Aubin-Yau and Calabi-Yau theorems. A large part of this course will concern recent progresses on Kahler-Einstein metrics of positive scalar curvature and their relation to geometric stability.

title: Topics in Algebra - Representation Theory
prereqs: MAT345 or MAT346..
descrip: An introduction to representation theory of Lie groups and Lie algebras. The goal is to cover roughly the first half of Knapp's book.

title: Seminar in American Politics - The Tea Party and the History of Populist Movements in America
reviews: Definitely take it if interested. Prof. Achen is great and grades nicely.
Definitely take this course! It's very exciting to learn about the Tea Party during this time, and Prof. Achen is awesome!
I think the most valuable resource of the entire course is Professor Achen himself. I enjoyed hearing his thoughts more than anything else.

Take this class! It's a lot of reading but its enjoyable. Professor Achen really makes you think, but you will come out of it with a better understanding of the Republican Party and the political landscape in general.
Take this course.  Professor Achen is great.

The course material is interesting but the seminars can be kind of boring. If you're interested in learning about movements outside of the Tea Party, the populists and the abolitionists, this may not be the right course.
not a hard course, and interesting topics
descrip: The Tea Party is the most important recent American populist political movement. Why was it relatively successful? Who backed it in the voting booth? Who backed it financially? Why was it more successful in some states rather than in others? America has a long history of populist politics. How does the Tea Party resemble previous popular movements such as abolitionism, the Depression-era radicals, and the Civil Rights and antiwar movement of the Sixties? Why are populist surges more likely in some periods than others, and how are future populist movements likely to be different from those we have seen thus far?

title: Studies in Ancient Judaism - Apocalyptic Literature of the Byzantine Era
descrip: The events of the seventh century--the wars between Byzantium & Persia followed by the Muslim conquest--seemed to some Jews to signal that the messianic age was about to dawn. From a very different angle of vision Christians felt called upon to explain the significance of the Muslim conquest for their eschatological expectations. This course considers the literature produced by Jews and Christians in response to these events & the impact of Jewish & Christian texts & traditions on each other against the background of earlier Jewish & Christian apocalyptic literature & the messianic expectations of the centuries before the rise of Islam.

title: Intellectual History of China to the Fifth Century
reviews: Be prepared to engage in your own way with the texts -- I think there is a tendency in Princeton seminars for students to attach themselves to the professor's take on academia, and this is a nice refrain from that expectation.

Go to Professor Peterson's office hours, pick up your own interests because the papers are often quite open-ended in terms of what you can write about. It also wouldn't be bad to briefly orient yourself in the time period with a little timeline and cursory knowledge about the era.

It's a great class if you're interested in the material. Otherwise it'll be dry and full of long difficult reading. Make sure you really want to know about this topic - it's very interesting and the course is well laid out and Professor Peterson is very knowledgeable.
Professor Peterson is an excellent professor, and if you have an interest in China, political philosophy, metaphysics, and more, this is an excellent course.

This was my favorite class I've taken at Princeton. No doubt. If you're thinking of taking this class, do not hesitate, especially if you're interested in thought in general. Do not be intimidated by the volume of reading. It's very doable.
Wonderful class
prereqs: A prior course in EAS is desirable but not required..
descrip: Critical consideration of a selection of monumental contributions to early Chinese thought, and the uses to which they were put by later Chinese thinkers. Readings will be from English translations such as: [Analects],[ Lao-tzu], [Chuang-tzu], [Mencius],[ I-ching] and secondary works. All assignments are available on reserve.

title: Intermediate Japanese I
reviews: I wish I'd gone to office hours more often. The resources to excel are there for you, but it's just so much effort.

I would tell the student that if they work hard every day, an A is possible. They should really love the language, because sometimes it can get a little difficult. But the teachers are wonderful, and have wonderful personalities, and small classes often allow for some interesting questions and funny realizations.

I'm assuming you took JPN 101 here. If so, you can expect a very similar experience.
If you haven't taken JPN 101 here, I highly recommend the Japanese program at Princeton. It is immensely rewarding.

Japanese 105 is a wonderful class, especially if you took 101 and 102 at Princeton. The Senseis are wonderful, humorous, and understanding although they can be strict. The course load is difficult but improves your understanding of the language in leaps and bounds.
This is an amazing course and you will learn a lot of Japanese from very passionate teachers, however, only take this course if you are willing/are able to commit a lot of time.
Tough with heavy workload, yet very provocative to the skills and interests of Japanese study.

When you take a language course at Princeton, you are investing a great deal of your time and effort for the chance to learn a beautiful new language with some of the best instruction in the country. This course is absolutely more work than others, but you will learn so much in such a short time. The professors are helpful and kind, and class is a joy to come to if you're willing to laugh and have fun. Ultimately, only you can decide whether this language fascinates you enough for you to find its study rewarding.
You will have to put in a lot of time and effort to do well and learn the language. Practice writing the kanji a lot if you want to remember them for the exams. Also be prepared for the many quizzes.
descrip: This course aims to give a thorough mastery of modern colloquial Japanese (Tokyo speech) by consistent review and reinforcement of major grammatical points and more advanced vocabulary and grammar. Students will reinforce four major skills by speaking - listening drills, readings, and written exercises.

title: The Civilization of the Early Middle Ages
reviews: After taking this class I know I will ask Reimitz to be my thesis advisor. Its a great class with a great professor.
Definitely get used to doing a lot of reading! Go to lectures; they are great!
Definitely take this course whether or not you are particularly interested in history - Interesting and engaging with a great professor.
For a history major interested in this period, highly recommend.
Go to class and get something out of the lectures.
Highly recommend!
I loved this course! Take it!
Pay more attention to the readings than the lectures.
Read all the material even if there is a lot of it. It's really worth it.
Take it especially if you're interested in late Roman history and the middle ages. Professor Reimitz is an awesome guy.
Take this course! The professor is amazing and the reading is so interesting.
Take this course; weird area of history, that the Professors sheds light upon
definitely worth taking!
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: This course will survey the "Dark Ages" from the end of the Roman Empire to the end of the first millennium (ca. 400-1000 AD), often seen as a time of cultural and political decline, recently even labelled as the "end of civilization". The complex political and social landscape of the Roman Empire, however, had more to offer than just to end. This course will outline how early medieval people(s) in the successor states of the Roman Empire used its resources to form new communities and will suggest to understand the "Dark Ages" as a time of lively social and cultural experimentation, that created the social and political frameworks of Europe.

title: Preserving the Past
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to Genomics and Computational Molecular Biology
reviews: Great introductory survey of genomics methods with practical applications. Anastasia is also brilliant!

Interesting material. Class is essentially optional though. The class is not related to problem sets. Problem sets were really tough though and would take many more hours than expected. Relatively chill though since no midterm or final.
It's cool! People will all sorts of  diverse backgrounds take it so the grading isnt too stringent.
