Material is too broad to be interesting to students not directly involved in computational genomics. Arbitrary grading.
Start problem sets early.
Take it only if you have a COS background.
interesting, but a little disorganized
descrip: The course will provide a detailed overview of experimental and computational approaches used to study molecular systesm. We will focus on modern technologies used to generate and alanlyze "omics" data, such as genome sequences, gene expression, transcriptional and post-transcriptional modification, proteomics and mass spectrometry, molecular interaction networks and chemical genomics. We will also discuss and apply fundamental statistical concepts relevant to genomics (data evaluation,estimation of true and false positives, significance testing, multiple testing correction) and learn basic programming tools.

title: Junior Seminar
reviews: Definitely be an art history major very interesting!
If you are on the fence about being an art history major, this class will convince you that you made the right choice. TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT.
It's mandatory, but it's also great.
You will enjoy this required seminar.
descrip: An introduction to a range of art-historical approaches and to the writings of key figures in the history of the discipline. Attention is also given to research and writing skills specific to the history of art.

title: Fundamentals of Solid Earth Science
reviews: Attend all the lectures

GEO 203: the class of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. Would cautiously recommend. ON ONE HAND: the class was incredibly informative; I learned so much about everything geology and geosciences. The class was super comprehensive and taught valuable concepts about the world around us and the earth we live in. Higgins is a great lecturer, one of the best I've had at Princeton, and a cool guy in general. Dani and Joel, our two preceptors, are awesome as well. The field trip was fun, and GEO 203 treats you like a kid in general, with cookie breaks in the middle of class, middle class science experiments, and candy aplenty. ON THE OTHER HAND: they treat you like kids, which can be annoying. The psets take up a lot of time, the instruction hit-or-miss. Irving's lectures, which comprise half the course, are sleep-inducing.
I would not recommend this course as an "intro to geology" because you really have to be a science or engineering major to do decently
If you don't love geosciences already, this course probably won't change your mind.  That being said, you will learn a lot and get a good background for future work in the department.
Not too hard but not super interesting. Gets repetitive at times.
Take it if you already have a strong interest in geology.

The class isn't perfect, and it can be too technical at times.  Overall I enjoyed it.  However, do not take this if you haven't taken COS or at least calculus.  There's a significant amount of MATLab coding and assumed math knowledge.  The fact that there are no pre-reqs is a joke.  As a junior engineer I had no issues, but I imagine I would not have been able to take the class freshman fall.

The problem sets are tedious and often really hard to do without office hours, so definitely go to office hours. The only outside of class work you do for this class is problem sets (which are worth 50% of your grade, so put some work into them). You learn a lot and the information is really interesting
This class is challenging and uses math. Lots more math than I expected. However, it is interesting, and the professors and preceptors are very helpful.

This class made me glad that I'm not a geology major. It's honestly a bit dull and any learning that does occur feels so passive. Try to get Dani as your preceptor because she's pretty much the coolest thing about this course. And Joel awesome as well, but he's just not as involved as Dani.

This is NOT an easy intro course and the problem sets and exams take a large amount of time to prepare for.  Is great for anyone interested in any major related to geology.  Be aware that there are TWO required field trips and one takes up an entire weekend during the school year.  A final note, it is very important to attend lecture and class because all the assignments and tests relate back to things from class not necessarily in the readings or online material.
Try to break down weekly concepts as you go along in the course. Also try to connect relevant lecture material through the course
Try to stay on top of the material and definitely ask for help on the homework if you need it.
Unless this is the stuff you are really interested in, I would not take it. It is a ton of work for a 200 level course, and if it not what you are interested in, at times painful.
Wonderful class.  Interesting and fast-paced.
prereqs: Single variable calculus is a prerequisite, and the course also introduces basic multivariate calculus, simple matrix algebra, and elementary tensor calculus. The course serves as a prerequisite for several upper-level GEO and CEE courses..
descrip: A quantitative introduction to Solid Earth system science, focusing on the underlying physical and chemical processes and their geological and geophysical expression. Through the course we investigate the Earth starting from its basic constituents and continue though its accretion, differentiation and evolution and discuss how these processes create and sustain habitable conditions on Earth's surface. Topics include nucleosynthesis, planetary thermodynamics, plate tectonics, seismology, geomagnetism, petrology, sedimentology and the global carbon cycle. Two field trips included.

title: Engineering Design
reviews:
1. LISTEN TO GLENN. You'll always learn something.
2. Start manufacturing your projects ASAP.

At the price of late nights in the machine shop before the design projects are due, you get to learn how to use the tools and machines in the shop and actually build things hands-on. Learn as much as you can from Glenn. He's a wealth of practical knowledge.
Avoid it at all costs
Do the Creo tutorials, and don't leave all your manufacturing for the week it's due.  Write crisp reports.
I would say to focus on the design project and get the creo tutorials done early.
It's a departmental. You have to take it. It's one of the worst departmentals. Have fun.
Its an interesting class. Design and learning your way around the machine shop is fun, although lectures can be dry.
Labs and projects are really fun
Make sure you learn from the CAD tutorials; and start the final project and the crane project early.

Shop is great. Make sure to talk to Martinelli at the beginning of the year to force him to set definite outlines (like, we had a pop-up midterm, which wasn't great). When you do the weekly Creo tutorials, meet up with other people and do them at the same time, that way you can help each other out and be done much faster.
Take it, if only for the shop time.
Take this class if you must.
Takes time.

This course is useful. Learn everything you can about Creo modeling and machine shop practices, as those are the main takeaways from this class. You will learn design as an overarching concept, and also brief snippets of design details. Be prepared to work hard around midterm week and also over reading period. There is not much work aside from the design projects at these times.

This course will not be like any other you've taken so far. There is no "right answer." There is only what works or doesn't work, what you can make and what you cannot make. That all depends on how well you know the material from your past courses and if you can apply it here.
Work hard on the reports.
You have to take it as an MAE, sorry.
nothing in particular
take it for the hands on experience in the shop and the lessons on Creo (CAD) and CNC
prereqs: MAE 206, 221 and 222, and CEE205 or MAE 223.
descrip: This course introduces the technical foundations and basic processes of Mechanical Design, which are appropriate for the design of both mechanical systems, and components. The emphasis is on innovation, and designing for the complete product life-cycle. Topics in parametric design and design optimization are also presented. Basic techniques in Computer Aided Design (CAD) and Manufacturing (CAM) are first introduced in the classroom, and then reinforced and expanded in the laboratory.

title: Advanced Condensed Matter Physics II
descrip: Course introduces and present ongoing theoretical investigations of new research topics in condensed matter physics: topological insulators and Chern numbers, topological superconductors, the fractional quantum Hall effect and non-abelian statistics, as well as new high-temperature superconductors. The techniques needed to deal with such systems, such as Chern numbers, topological band theory, Berry phases, conformal field theory, Chern-Simons theory, t-J models, Gutzwiller wavefunctions, Hubbard models, are explained.

title: Topics in Nonlinear Analysis - Introduction to PDE's and General Relativity
prereqs: A good knowledge of Geometry and PDEs..
descrip: This course is a fast moving introductory course that will include a quick review of the basic linear PDE.

title: Policy Workshops - Managing Elections in Fragile States (Burma)
descrip: The objectives of this workshop on Elections in Fragile States are: 1 To introduce the fundamental electoral policy elements which comprise an electoral process, their relationships, and their potential impact on electoral outcomes. 2. To examine analytical frameworks and methodologies which provide insights and skills in electoral process design and administration. 3. To discuss international standards and norms so that widely accepted methods of evaluating the democratic quality and technical efficiency of an election can be applied.

title: Independent Study II
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies. Usually taken in the Spring semester.

title: Intermediate French
reviews: Contribute to class discussions, go to office hours and invest time in practicing every day, which is something that I sometimes was unable to do.
Definitely feel free to try a new language or jump back into one previously studied. Also take advantage of the resources offered (instructor, online, etc.)

Engage with this class and your French will come along just as you wish! Don't forget to study outside of class, especially when it comes to grammar and vocabulary, which isn't covered extensively during class.
I would recommend that students taking this course keep up with the work, practice on their own, and not be afraid to participate in class since that is the best way to improve.
I would say that they should work at it every day and they will get a lot out of the course.  You learn french fast.
I would tell that student to do all the grammar practice exercises and revise papers extensively and carefully. This class is really about having the basics down well.
I'd recommend this course. Great course for developing your oral and grammar skills.
If you are committed to improving your French, your efforts in this class will be well worth your time.
If you have a genuine interest in French, this class is the way to go! It immerses you in the language, and you're surround by people with just as much passion.
It is an interesting class and I would recommend taking it if they're interested in developing their french language skills.
It is worthwhile in developing better language skills, and it was fun! They should be warned that some assignments take longer than expected to do well.

It's not a formidable course if you stay up with the grammar and course material. The written exams are very difficult, so make sure you keep up with the material throughout the semester and do not wait until the last minute to cram everything.
Just do the work, practice French on your own outside of class, go to language tables, study your vocab and grammar.
Keep up with the home works and the vocabulary learned in class.
Make sure to do all of the readings, because that is what a lot of the class discussions are based on.

Make sure you are willing to develop your speaking skills outside of the class. The midterm and the final "interviews" are chill, but focus on fluency and directness. Had I done more speaking, listening to France24, and attend the French Tables wherever they happen, I would have been set.
Participate!
Study hard and speak a lot!
Study the vocab!
Study your vocabs!
Take it! It's not as difficult as language courses' reputation suggests, since we only have three days a week of instruction.
Take it! do the practice exercises
The course is enjoyable and helpful, take it. Attend lectures and set aside enough time for writing assignments.
The course provides a terrific opportunity to allow you to progress as far as you want, above and beyond what's outlined in the syllabus.  It can be as challenging as you make it.
This isn't high school anymore! French is as much of a real class as everything else!
You will get out as much as you put in.
be engaged!
make flashcards
practice writing outside of class and speak often when you can!
prereqs: Typically two to five years of high school French. Appropriate score on the Princeton French Language Placement Test, or special permission of the Placement Officer..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to develop your listening, speaking and writing skills, while allowing you to strengthen your knowledge of contemporary French society and culture. There is a thorough review of French grammar and a wide range of communicative activities chosen to improve proficiency and give practice of newly acquired linguistic material. The course aims at building your confidence in French, while giving you a foundation for the understanding and appreciation of French-speaking cultures and exposing you to their rich literary and artistic productions. A wide range of authentic material will be offered, including films.

title: Problems in Early Modern and Modern North African History
descrip: This graduate seminar introduces students to problems related to the history of North Africa from the 16th to the beginning of the 21th century. In particular, it explores the crucial issues of chronology: how periods in North African history have been defined and to what extent are they relevant? This seminar focuses on the issue of majority and minorities in North African studies by reviewing recent research on Berbers and Jews in the Maghrib. In a second part, this seminar also surveys recent topics in the relevant literature, such as environmental history, gender studies and religious history.

title: The Nature of Theatrical Reinvention
reviews: Don't be afraid to speak up - this course is all about creating a conversation about theater, and the more students contribute the more they benefit from this class!

Don't take it as your first theater class, take it if you've had some experience or at least wanted to direct, or if you're an actor that particularly engages with the overall vision of shows you're involved with.
TAKE IT.
Take it take it take it!

This seminar was amazing!   John Doyle is an incredible teacher and mentor.  He didn't assign a lot of homework and yet I learned more in his class than I have in many other classes.  The emphasis was on process rather than product, which was very freeing.
take it as a 5th course
prereqs: No restrictions or prerequisites..
descrip: This seminar explores how iconic pieces of theatre can be re-explored for modern audiences. The course will examine various aspects of how an artist can think out-of-the-box and the mechanisms the artist can use to do so. There will be discussions, theatre visits, possible access to theatre practitioners and assignments which will encourage the participant to explore their own imaginative approach to storytelling. The course is designed for performers, directors, designers but would also be of interest to dancers, writers and those interested in how theatre can be challenging and relevant.

title: Elementary Biblical Hebrew I
reviews: Definitely consider taking this class!  It's not easy -- so realize that from the beginning -- but if you're genuinely interested in learning the material, you really will learn a lot.  Professor Meshel is truly an amazing professor!
I would recommend the course, and especially professor Meshel, to anybody with an interest in Biblical Hebrew, linguistics theory, semitic languages and culture, and/or the bible.
It's tough and super fast paced, but I learned so much and it really is a very rewarding course.

Prof Meshel is a really great professor - he is genuinely interested and excited about the material. Although there is a lot of grammar and memorization which can get heavy at times, the results of being able to translate portions of the BIble are very rewarding. I thoroughly enjoyed this class!
prereqs: Class meets four times per week. The fourth meeting is a required precept, which will be scheduled at the beginning of the semester..
descrip: Students will achieve a basic ability to read the Hebrew Bible in the original language. During the semester, students will learn the script and the grammar, develop a working vocabulary, and read a selection of Biblical passages. The course is designed specifically and exclusively for beginners with little or no previous knowledge of the language. Students with prior experience in the language should contact the instructor about course alternatives.

title: Latin American Studies Seminar - Latin American Cinema
reviews: A good, relatively low-pressure course on cinema.  Take it if you want to know more about film history, but don't expect to spend much time on analysis of film techniques.

I would recommend this course to another graduate student hoping to establish a working knowledge of the history of Latin American film and gain an understanding of Latin America's cinematic canon. I would not  recommend this to a graduate student who already has a foundation in the subject or who hopes to pursue a more theoretical project on Latin American cinema.
It is interesting and worth it.
Take it - don't let limite (the first film) scare you off
prereqs: No prerequisites..
descrip: A survey of the art and industry of cinema in Latin America. Beginning with the silent cinema, the course will trace cinema's journey through the efforts to create nation film industries, the reaction to cinematic modernism, and finally to the contemporary impact of changes in technology as well as the expansion of the notion of the political to include questions of race, gender and sexual identity.

title: Combinatorial Mathematics
reviews: Ehrenborg and Readdy are wonderful. Unfortunately, they're only at Princeton for a year. But combo is fun! Take it you're a math major, or even if you're not!
Get started on psets and exams early, because you never know how long it will take for something to "click."

Math majors: take this course. This will teach you a different way of thinking as compared with other core classes. Other majors: this course is doable and will be interesting if you are willing to put in the time.
Not a bad (hard) math course. But course might be different because taught by visiting lecturers

Profs. Readdy and Ehrenborg are visiting professors, so I don't think they're teaching this again at Princeton, but if they do, take it. They were great. They motivated the material well and explained everything clearly. It really got me interested in the field of combinatorics, which I originally thought I wouldn't like. Because of this class, I plan to study further topics in combinatorics.

The reviews for this class are unlikely to be relevant to anyone because Profs. Readdy and Ehrenborg are visiting, and these types of courses tend to be eclectic and vary hugely depending on the professors. But just in case - this class was a lot of fun. The professors are among the friendliest and most helpful that you will ever meet, the material is interesting, and the workload is manageable. The only slight modification I might have benefited from is more clear guidance for course readings beyond the lecture notes. There were books on reserve but they were sometimes difficult for me to navigate as a beginner in the subject.
They were the best.
Unfortunately, I doubt these guys will be teaching this again anytime soon. But combinatorics is a fun course.
prereqs: MAT202 or equivalent..
descrip: Combinatorics is the study of enumeration and structure of discrete objects. These structures are widespread throughout mathematics, including geometry, topology and algebra, as well as computer science, physics and optimization. This course will give an introduction to modern techniques in the field, and how they relate to objects such as polytopes, permutations and hyperplane arrangements.

title: Gender and Sexuality in Modern America
reviews: A really interesting HA that doesn't require much memorization. Readings are pretty much optional

Absolutely take this course, especially if you haven't had any prior experience in gender, women's or sexual history.  You learn about a lot of American history topics through a new lens which was quite eye-opening for me.
Be prepared to read a lot and take really good notes in lecture.

Canaday is passionate about the subject enough to the point that it makes you want to care. She teared up multiple times during touchy subjects - you could hear a pin drop in the room - but she was very genuine. Papers aren't bad, take-home final wasn't bad either.

DO the readings!!!  While sometimes long, they are interesting and really contribute to the depth of knowledge that one can achieve through this course.  Lectures are also highly informative and are a must-attend.
Do all the readings, because they are very interesting!
Do as much of the reading as you can and don't be afraid to meet with the professor or your preceptor in advance of the final paper if you want help narrowing in on a topic!
Do the readings and go to lecture.
Exams are based more on lecture material than readings. Go to lecture! They're interesting and provide important context for the readings!

Find someone to share the Pequod with because it's frankly really expensive and it's hard to realistically get through the readings. (If this is allowed:) Try to do half the readings and have the other person do the other half, then meet up and discuss them later. Stay after classes and talk to your preceptor about LGBT things.
Go to lecture! It is the most interesting lecture course I have ever taken and the lectures help you function with a foundation of knowledge that is necessary to understand the course material.
Great history course for both history majors and non-majors!
I would recommend other students to take this class because I think course material is really really interesting.  The precept was one of my favorite things about this course.
I would tell them to take it only if they were very interested in the course material.

If you are at all interested in the study of gender and/or sexuality, take this class!  It's a great overview of the past 100 years but also provides tons of interesting detail.  Professor Canaday is excellent and very passionate.
If you're at all interested in gender, sexuality, or the history of America during the 20th century then you should take this class!
If you're interested in it specifically, take it. Great material, learned a lot. But be mindful of the fact that it is a history course, and not a philosophical approach to gender and sexuality.
It is a very interesting course and if you go into it with the desire to change your perspective, it will be even better.
It's a great way to understand the history of gender and sexuality in the U.S. in terms of periods of regulation, followed by resistance.
Keep up with the readings and really think about the material.
My favorite course at Princeton after 3.5 years. Well taught, well run and an excellent introduction to gender/sexuality challenges.
One of the most amazing courses I have taken at Princeton.
Read read read. The material can be dense at times, but it is a must.
Read stuff and go to lecture. The course is really well-organized so the final will be much easier if you actually know what's going on.
Stay on top of the reading and be prepared for the final take-home due at the end of classes.

Students should be sure to do the reading ahead of time, as it is interesting and helpful. Be sure to start the research for the final paper ahead of time so that you can ask your preceptor questions.
Take good notes, maybe on a laptop so you can get everything down. Take notes on all of the reading so it's easy to refresh at the end of the semester for the semester!
Take it!
Take it! Not a lot of work and very thought-provoking
Take it! you haven't learned a lot of this history in high school!
Take it.
Take this class! Canaday is one of the best professors I've had at Princeton. Everyone should take this class just for general life knowledge. Such interesting material- amazing class!
Take this class! The lectures are informative and interesting and you learn so. Readings are manageable
Take this class. You'll learn a lot and love the material.
Take this course-- it's so important to understand the long narratives of feminism, women's rights, and gay rights in America.
The material is great, but be prepared for a lot of reading!
There's a lot of reading, but Canaday is one of the best professors on campus and you should definitely take this class if you have even the slightest interest!

This class is so important for everyone to take, whether it immediately interests you or (maybe even especially) if the idea of it makes you uncomfortable. Don't be fooled - this is a history class, not a gender theory class, which I think makes it both more accessible and more enjoyable in the long run (and this is coming from someone who doesn't particularly like history). The lectures are really well organized and interesting, Professor Canaday is the coolest person (I had her as my preceptor and it was really great), and the material is a combination of everything you thought you knew being turned on its head and stuff you probably never heard of or thought about before. There's a substantial amount of reading and it was not an incredibly easy class, but it was all fascinating and I have absolutely no regrets about taking this class. Take it!

This is a fascinating course taught particularly well by Prof. Canaday.  Readings are interesting and not too overwhelming.  There is both a final test and a paper, so just be aware of that.  Great course!
This is an excellent and very important class. Professor Canaday is a wonderful lecturer, and it is well worth taking!

This is an interesting class, but it is also very challenging. Though fascinating, the readings are long, and the papers are neither easy nor graded easily. Take it only if you are prepared to work very hard and still possibly get an undesirable grade.

You should absolutely take this course.  Professor Canaday is a phenomenal lecturer, and everything you talk about in this class is relevant to today's issues of gender and sexuality.  The reading can be a lot, but it's pretty easy to get through and very interesting.  Definitely take this.
going to lecture is definitely more important than doing the readings.
make sure you are ready to read a lot and do not fall behind.  Make sure you make good daily contributions to precept.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: This course examines the history of gender and sexuality across the 20th century, with emphasis on both regulation and resistance. Topics include early homosexual subcultures; the commercialization of sex; reproduction and its limitation; sex, gender, and war; cold war sexual containment; the feminist movement; conservative backlash; AIDS politics; same-sex marriage; Hillary; and many others.

title: Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Wisdom of Crowds
descrip: Please see website

title: Reading Literature: Poetry
reviews: I strongly recommend this class.  This class is more than fair and you learn a lot about poetry and gain a new perspective.  Even if you are an expert, the discussions were never stale and the class time flies by.
Interested in poetry? Go for it.
There are probably more interesting courses to take. Try one of those.
This was my favorite class of the semester. Take it if you're looking for a solid, well-taught English class and to get a good working knowledge of important poets and styles of poetry.

While it may be theoretically possible to coast through the course, the material is more than worth engaging with.  However, it is easy to pick and choose from those which specifically interest you, so don't get discouraged by all the centuries-old, stale poetry.  It's a great opportunity and not an excessive time commitment.
take it!!
prereqs: Prospective concentrators are required to take ENG 200 and one course from the following: ENG 205, 206, 207, 208, 209..
descrip: We will read widely across the field of poetry in English, and discuss how we experience meter, rhythm, rhyme, voice, fixed and open forms, and metaphor. Throughout we will attend to poetry's manifold social and cultural functions: its role as a form of longing, praise, rebellion, ecstasy, erotic persuasion, mourning, or civic identity. We will zero in on a few poets--Bishop, Frost, Merwin--and "catch" poetry in live performances, utterances and advertisements.

title: Criticism Workshop
reviews: Enjoy each class and don't miss anything!
Fintan is an amazing professor and by reviewing theater I feel like I grew so much as a writer. A highlight of my Princeton career.
Fintan is wonderful and this class is wonderful. I learned a ton about writing, about theater, and about myself. What more could you ask?
If you have a chance to take a class with Fintan, do it. No matter what the subject is he will make it interesting and enjoyable. You will come away a smarter, more rounded person.
prereqs: This course is by open enrollment. Please register directly via SCORE..
descrip: This workshop is devoted to the development of the student's critical sensibility. Through extensive in-class analysis of their own reviews of and other kinds of writing about professional theater and dance productions, students will come to learn what makes a good critic of the performing arts.

title: Neoclassicism through Impressionism
reviews: Art history is difficult to get into. Take this if you think that you are genuinely interested, tough if you're not and are new to art history. Maybe 100/101 would be better for you.
Course was challenging to do well in and required a significant amount of work for a course taken for general interest.
Definitely take it if you are interested in European art!
Definitely take it, but be prepared for a lot of reading, and make sure to use your precepts.

Definitely take this course! This is a really great course for people of all levels of art historical knowledge in interest. If you want to take just one art history course at Princeton, this is a really great one to take. It covers a lot of the big names in art, lectures are amazing, and assignments are interesting and manageable.
Do the readings - they'll help you understand what's going on.
Do your readings and truly enjoy the class
Don't take it as the fifth.
Excellent class - one of my favorite at Princeton.
Go to all the lectures and participate in precept.
Go to every single lecture.

Go to lecture. Make sure to take good lecture notes, especially on slides in which 2 paintings are compared.  Don't fret about reading every critic's work in detail. For the midterm and final, you just need to be able to mention their name and the general sense of their argument.
Great class with a manageable work load and I strongly recomend it. Profesor Alsodorf is awesome too.
Have a true love for learning the subject, even if it's somewhat unfamiliar.
I LOVED this class. Prof. Alsdorf makes the class, so only take it if she's teaching it. Alot of memorization required for the final, so keep that in mind.
I have not met anyone who has had a bad word to say about this course. Take it! Make sure you do the readings prioritizing the e-reserves over the text book.
I recommend taking this course. It was a good PDF, but I would also recommend taking it for a grade. The class is very manageable, but at the same time it is very interesting (and well organized).
I would advise students to attend all lectures and do all of the readings.
I'd take Art 100 first to learn how to be an art historian before taking this class, but it is very fascinating stuff!

My first piece of advice would be to read as many of the readings as possible and take good notes on them. Also, I would suggest posing any ideas you have about an artist in precept. If it's wrong, you can correct your understanding. If it's right, you can have a whole new perspective on an artist that you can use in your papers.

PDF this class! The material is really fascinating and probably not something you've thought about or deeply analyzed before, but it's a really great way to get an introduction to this field with really well-organized lectures. I knew I was going to PDF it and it went really well because they're not easy graders and had I not PDFed I would have had to put in a lot more effort, but since I did it was minimal effort, maximum reward.
Prepare for the tests and try to get into alsdorf's precept
Prof. Alsdorf gives wonderful, interesting lectures! If you're worried about your skills in Art History, take this class as a PDF! Great art and great lectures and great conversations in Precept.
Stay on top of the readings.
TAKE!
Take it
Take it if you are interested in learning about a great period of art history
Take it if you want an interesting introduction into art history.
Take it if you want to learn about European art, but consider PDF'ing from the beginning. This class is graded strictly and you can't expect a good grade casually.
Take it take it take it! The lectures are wonderful, the readings are exciting, the art is beautiful.
Take it!

Take it.  If you enjoy thinking about art to any degree, this course will profoundly stimulate and inspire you.  Go to every lecture because each is extremely valuable, not just for the course, but for your own enjoyment.
Take this class if you are interested and the work will be enjoyable and stimulating.
Take this class, it's interesting and you get to judge artists.
Take this course, even if you're not planning on majoring in art history.
Talk more in precept.
The course was amazing. I got a thorough education in something entirely new, and even developed a passion for it. Definitely take this if you're curious about art history!
This class gets a lot of hype but just seemed like a normal art history class to me.

This is by far one of the top classes I have taken at Princeton. TAKE IT! Even if you don't have any background in art history - TAKE IT! Prof Alsdorf makes it totally worth it as a lecturer and it's a very manageable amount of work. AGAIN: TAKE THIS CLASS!
Very interesting course that taught me a lot about various leading Impressionist artists but was not easy. Prepare to do a lot of reading and writing.
Work on papers early; they are a lot of work!  Try to keep up on readings, and don't be afraid to participate in discussions; you get to bounce off your ideas and learn from classmates.

You have any interest in the time period definitely take this course. It's a lot of work considering it's 200 level class, so I wouldn't recommend taking it as an easy 5th class. That being said, if you're not necessarily interested in getting an A, or plan on PDFing it anyway, it could be a really interesting course to add to your schedule and simply attend lectures and skim over the readings.
go to all the lectures
take it if you are interested in 19th century art.
descrip: A broad study of European painting and sculpture from the French revolution to 1900 with special attention to art's relationship to social, economic and cultural changes. Lectures will explore a range of themes including art and revolution, the rise of landscape, shifting conceptions of realism, and the birth of "modernism" and the avant-garde. Emphasis on major figures including David, Canova, Goya, Ingres, Turner, Courbet, Manet, Monet, Degas, Rodin, Van Gogh and Cezanne.

title: Topics in Economic and Organizational Sociology (Half-Term) - Gender and Economic Activity
descrip: Introduction to a gendered analysis of economic processes and institutions. Course investigates when, why, and in what ways gender shapes production, consumption, distribution, and transfer of assets. After a general discussion of gender theories, it surveys how gender works in a variety of settings and activities, such as labor markets, intimate economies, and caring labor. We end with an overview of strategies aimed at reducing gendered economic inequalities. Overall, the course attempts to strengthen intellectual bridges between economic sociology and gender scholarship.

title: Ornament Past and Present
descrip: This course has three aims: close encounters with some of the world's major traditions of ornament, close examination of issues that arise in the study of ornament and its history, and the cultivation of skills for writing about ornament. One troublesome issue is simply the problem of defining "ornament" (or "decoration"): is this anything more than a catch-all category for arts traditionally excluded from "the fine arts"? Themes for discussion include plant, animal, and geometrical ornament; space constraints as a stimulus to invention; and the relations between ornament and architecture.

title: Money and Banking
reviews: But topics and slides were really, really good and I learned a lot about monetary and banking system.
Go to lecture and write down the things that aren't in the slides
It is an interesting and approachable elective for the finance certificate
N/A
Take it if you are super interested in money and banking. Otherwise, there are other courses that are more interesting.
The exams are not easy.

This class was extremely boring and poorly taught; most people stopped going to lectures after the first few weeks. With all due respect to Prof Haddad, I had difficulty understanding him due to his accent. I should have dropped this class at the beginning of the semester. Also, psets and exams were much harder than you would expect.
prereqs: ECO 300 or 310; ECO 301 or 311. Basic statistics: mean, variance, OLS (there will be a refresher at the beginning of the class).
descrip: This course explores the role that money, financial markets and institutions, and monetary policy play in shaping the economic environment. We investigate why these markets and institutions arise and may lubricate the resource allocation analytically (rather than descriptively), using tools of economic theory.

title: The McGraw Seminar in Writing - The Art of Writing for Intellectual Magazines
reviews: Definitely take it.
Do it. You won't regret it.
I don't know if this will ever be offered again, but it was amazing. Richard Just is the best, you will learn so much, and it's an unforgettable experience.
If you are interested in long form journalism in the US, this course is very helpful.
If you have any interest whatsoever in journalism, this course is 100% worth taking.
It's a bummer that Richard won't be back teaching this class, because he was by far the best.
TAKE THIS COURSE. If you ever are so lucky to take a course with Richard Just--do it! He is such an amazing teacher and excellent human being and kind person.
Will be more useful if you intend to be a journalist, but an interesting course nonetheless.
prereqs: Enrollment by application - see course web address.
descrip: This course will explore how to write magazine essays, with an emphasis on using interviews and other research to build bold arguments. In an age when journalists are too often expected to opine instantly, we will head in the opposite direction, examining the art of developing sustained arguments and ideas. We will read and debate magazine essays on numerous topics including politics, education, race, gender, law, and sports. The class will include meetings with many of the writers whose pieces we will read. Students will also spend the semester researching and writing a long-form magazine essay on a topic of interest to them.

title: Special Topics in Information Sciences and Systems - Multiuser Information Theory
prereqs: ELE 528.
descrip: Advance information theory of channel coding, network coding, lossless and lossy compression with several sources, destinations and/or side information. Problems of Slepian-Wolf, Wyner-Ziv and Gelfand-Pinsker as well as multiaccess, broadcast, interference and relay multiuser channels.

title: Thermal Physics
reviews: .It's an interesting course. Make sure to stay on top of the material and prepare for the quizzes/final.
Don't expect to like this class.
Don't take it with Aizenman
Don't take it, if at all avoidable.
Don't take unless you're a physics major.
Have to take it, have fun.
I would take it if youre a physics major.
I wouldn't recommend taking this course. If you're a physics major, you have to, but otherwise it's simply not worth your time.

If Aizenman is teaching this, this will be an awful class. The problem sets are a waste of time, the lectures are incredibly disorganized, and the exams are difficult because the course is so poorly run (not because the problems themselves are hard). I also had Aizenman for Complex Analysis, and he is not a good teacher. Apparently several seniors in the class took General Relativity their Junior Fall instead of Thermo. If Aizenman is teaching this, I recommend doing what they did -- take a different physics course your Junior Fall in the hopes that Aizenman will not be teaching Thermo your Senior Fall. This class was an incredible waste.
If you're in it, you probably have to take it anyway. Work with others, ask questions, and budget time.
It's probably a requirement for you, but definitely not a good course at all. Barely can say I learned the material.
Read the textbook if you don't follow what's going on in lecture and ask both the professor and TA's questions. In preparation for the exams, do as many practice problems and exams as you can!

Really look into the lecturer if you have a choice when to take it. The reviews are very accurate, and some people favor one style over the other. More than likely, you'll have to take this class if you're considering it. It's interesting and easier than quantum, but not as exciting.
Stat mech is a beautiful area of physics, and i t's a departmental anyway
Take this class. Aizenman is very passionate about this topic. If you are struggling, the TAs and Professor are more than helpful. The material is rigorous and very applicable.
The textbook is excellent. However, the lectures were baffling.

Try to avoid Aizenman if you can. Lectures are confusing (I suspect confusing for Aizenman as well) and usually unhelpful for doing the homeworks. Exams are too easy and so are graded somewhat arbitrarily.

Try to avoid taking the course with Aizenman since he's not a good lecturer. He's very good at explaining things one on one, so if you do have the course with him, go to his office hours. He's also very nice and very approachable.
Very confusing/frustrating

You probably don't have a choice of whether to take this course, but if you have any wiggle room in your schedule, at all costs avoid taking this course (or any other) with Prof. Aizenman. Ask the upperclassmen about him -- they'll have many horror stories. 

Otherwise, Stat Mech is a beautiful and interesting field of physics, and the techniques you should learn here will be useful in almost any area of physics!
You probably have to take this class; try doing the readings before class, and go to office hours.
prereqs: PHY 104 or 106; PHY 208.
descrip: A unified introduction to thermodynamics and statistical mechanics, both classical and quantum. Topics include heat engines, kinetic theory, black-body radiation, ideal Fermi and Bose gases and phase transitions.

title: Topics in Literary and Cultural Theory - "Psychoanalytic Turns"
prereqs: Graduate seminar, open to undergraduates with pre-approval of instructor only..
descrip: Seminar addresses turns to psychoanalysis in history and criticism of art and literature. In our reading of psychoanalytic theories (Freud, Ferenczi, Klein, Lacan) and critical writings that have followed them, paths and detours lead to questions of terminology, translation, perception, mediation, representation. Forays are made onto terrain of works of art and literature that might be understood as instances of psychoanalytic criticism and/or critiques of psychoanalysis. Need for critical reflection on meaningfulness of psychoanalytic theories for current scholarship in the humanities is a guiding concern of this course.

title: Junior Seminar: Introduction to Classics
reviews: Definitely keep in mind the big picture question of "What is Classics?" throughout the course.
Stay interested in the subject matter and good things will happen.
You're sort of stuck taking it.
descrip: This course will introduce concentrators to the study of classical antiquity. Students will become acquainted with different fields of study within the Department, including literature, ancient history, ancient culture, linguistics, and reception studies; gain experience in the methods of their chosen area(s) of study; and acquire an understanding of the history of the discipline and its place in the twenty-first century. Sessions will involve guest visits from members of the faculty. Particular attention will be paid to acquiring the skills necessary to pursue independent research and the selection of a topic for the spring Junior Paper.

title: Introduction to Nanotechnology
reviews: Take the course if you want to learn how to write and critique and proposal and to go out of your comfort zone and learn about a new research field.
descrip: This course will thus cover a broad range of subjects, with particular emphasis on characterization and control of materials at the nanoscale. The focus is on both the techniques necessary for scientific investigations at small dimensions, and the very latest research developments in this rapidly evolving area. Specific topics covered will include fundamentals of nanoscience, processing of nanomaterials, self-assembled nanostructures, bionanotechnology, graphene, nanoelectronics, size-scaling of properties, and nanodevice fabrication and testing. The course will also provide critical practice in scientific writing and presentation.

title: Advanced Thermodynamics
reviews: Read other textbooks to understand concepts. Exams can change drastically from year to year, try to get as much practice as possible.
descrip: Derivation of the laws of thermodynamics starting from postulates based on everyday experience. Application of thermodynamic principles to the solution of practical problems in modern chemical engineering. Microscopic and statistical basis of thermodynamics.

title: Generalized Linear Statistical Models
prereqs: The course assumes prior exposure to statistics at the level of WWS507c and familiarity with matrix algebra and calculus..
descrip: The analysis of survey data using generalized linear statistical models. The course begins with a review of linear models for continuous responses and then considers logistic regression models for binary data and log-linear models for count data, including rates and contingency tables and hazard models for duration data. Attention is given to the logical and mathematical foundations of the techniques, but the main emphasis is on the applications, including computer usage.

title: Trade Workshop
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Intermediate Korean I
reviews: Definitely take.
Engage with the teacher on a personal level--he's really fun and has interesting opinions and thoughts!
Go to the language table. Go to Professor Choi to practice speaking Korean!
If you are interested in the language, you will do well. The teacher is amazing. You'll learn the curriculum in a fun way.
It's fun -- you should take it!
Really enjoyed the course! Do take it if you're interested in Korean culture. Not a lot of effort is required to get a good grade compared to other classes.
prereqs: KOR 101 and KOR 102 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Intermediate Korean is designed for students who have learned the basics of the Korean language and want to improve their competence to a higher level. Complex sentences and grammar are covered while the basics are reviewed. Balancing four language skills -- listening, speaking, reading, and writing -- is emphasized.

title: Studies in the History of Islam - Legal Categories and Social Realities
descrip: This seminar explores the relationship (or dissonance) between legal and social categories in the context of late Medieval Muslim societies. Some of the topics covered in this context are gender, slavery, religious minorities, ethnicity and hybridity, communal violence and concepts of transgression. Readings include scholarly literature and Medieval Arabic texts. Students are expected to write a final research paper making some use of Arabic sources.

title: Introduction to the Professional Study of History
reviews: Check readings in advance.
Do the work. Read as much as possible. Get involved in the discussion. It's worth it.
Don't be afraid to speak out early in the semester.
Don't worry about it being mandantory, there will be interesting things in it anyway.
If you are in history, you have no choice in taking this course.
It is a departmental requirement, but for what it's worth, I'd recommend it.
It's a mandatory course anyway
It's required, and it's not nearly as bad as everyone seems to say.
Taken notes when reading the required readings

The course is a good way to get to know your cohort. Beyond that, being in class with people studying such vastly different topics can be an excellent chance to learn how different areas of history function, so engaging in the class is helpful for everyone.
Well, you HAVE to take it, no?
You get what you put into it.
n/a
descrip: A colloquium to introduce the beginning graduate student to the great traditions in historical writing, a variety of techniques and analytical tools recently developed by historians, and the nature of history as a profession.

title: Independent Work
prereqs: This course is restricted to MAE concentrators. Non-concentrators may seek the approval of the MAE department to enroll..
descrip: Student selects subject and advisor - defines problem to be studied and proposes work plan. A list of possible subjects of particular interest to faculty and staff members is provided. Written report and oral presentation at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339 Fall Term project; 340 Spring Term project.

title: Mathematical Models in the Study of Politics
reviews: Definitely take this class if interested in game theory, however be prepared to work hard.

Go to office hours! Matias is super approachable and helpful. Read the lectures beforehand can help you with understanding what is going on in class. The first few classes may seem easy for people who have taken ECO 310, but be aware it gets more difficult later.
Great course for a solid understanding of game theory in a very applied setting.

If you're here, you're in the political economy certificate or you're a POL major who needs the analytical requirement. Under no circumstances should you take this as an elective.  Matias genuinely cares a lot about his students. He's a wonderful guy, is extremely accessible, and will provide as much help as you need. Unfortunately, he's a bad lecturer and makes things a lot harder than they need to be through over-reliance on theory and proof rather than actually demonstrating how to solve problems. Luckily (I think it's because he doesn't use slides), he's a very good preceptor and is helpful in office hours, so you're not totally on your own. Problem sets consist of very long questions, are frustratingly difficult, and are exacerbated by the fact that the book is not easy to understand unless you read it a dozen times. At least there are only 4 sets in the semester. I normally hate group work, but do yourself a favor and find a partner you trust. The problems are solvable with two brains but can be brutally unforgiving with one. The exams are much easier than the problem sets thankfully. There's also a very generous curve, so don't freak out about grades. Total workload is reasonable, but it is not evenly distributed over the semester, so it can get quite bad. Overall, this class can be very annoying, but it does teach you a new way of thinking, which is quite valuable.
It was a difficult course for me, however it was interesting material.

On the one hand, Professor Iarcyzower genuinely wants his students to succeed. He is one of the few professors I have had at Princeton that genuinely cares that his students are learning the material and doing well. On the other hand, Professor Iaryczower's teaching style is incredibly disorganized. He often arbitrarily announced quizzes two days in advance and later ended up pushing them back when students complained. He did not plan to provide practice exams, and when he did so, he did not provide solutions to the practice final. While Prof. Iaryczower is a wonderful person, his class is incredibly frustrating (and unnecessarily so). Would not recommend.
Pretty standard beginner game theory course, take if interested in learning the basics.
Prof. Iaryczower is awesome, and very willing to help outside of the classroom. With that said, it's a very hard course, definitely the toughest material I've faced at Princeton.
Take if you are interested in the applications-oriented side of game theory. Be prepared for problem sets and projects assigned at irregular intervals.

This course is basically a game theory course. It is a bit tricky for students who are not mathy, etc. Matias is a great lecturer - he was always willing to meet outside of class and make sure that you have the tools to do well if you want to. If you are interested in game theory at all I would definitely recommend it!
This is not an easy course. Take it if your quantitatively-minded. Don't take it if you're not (or take it and PDF it).
Tough, wouldn't recommend unless for POL ECON certificate
prereqs: MAT 103.
descrip: An introduction to the use of formal game-theoretic models in the study of politics. Applications include: voting, bargaining, lobbying, legislative institutions, and strategic information transmission. Familiarity with mathematical reasoning is helpful.

title: Contradictions of Freedom in American Capitalism
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Intensive Elementary Arabic I
reviews: Be prepared to spend awhile on homework, though you'll pick up your pace with time. Review of words and speaking practice beyond the homework would be worthwhile.
Find another Arabic course. If not taking this one means switching up or down a level, so be it. I wish I had done that.

If you have already taken Arabic for 1-2 semesters and it has been a while, or you have had experience with Hebrew or Persian, this is probably the best class for you. You won't spend lots of time reviewing and you can just right into the language.
Intensive Arabic means lots of homework and it can be very challenging for people who have no prior experience with Arabic. But it is certainly worth it as one can really learn a lot!
Take this course if you want to learn more about the Arab world, but I strongly recommend you have some previous exposure to Arabic or else it will be extremely challenging
prereqs: No credit is given for ARA 103 unless it is followed by ARA 104. ARA 104 is normally followed by ARA 105. Students should consult with the department to determine specific placement and discuss summer study options..
descrip: Designed for students who already have some familiarity with any dialect of spoken Arabic and/or students who have had considerable previous experience in learning languages. The course will emphasize reading and writing skills, as well as how to analyze grammar.

title: Topics in 20th-Century Italian Literature - 20th Century Italian Fiction
reviews: Do the readings because they are interesting and because it will make the seminar not drag on.
Excellent course for any purpose, be it major requirement, certificate course, or course of general interest.

Not the best ITA departmental I've taken but interesting nonetheless and probably valuable in the long run for comps. One book a week with presentations. Some of the novels are long and/or difficult, but it's in your interest to do them because he chose especially hard quote identifications for the exam this time around.
One of my favourite classes in the Italian department.

The amount of reading was a little bit daunting which unfortunately encouraged some students to skip it. The books assigned were all great, but to encourage everyone to actually do the reading and participate more thoughtfully, I would recommend reducing the weekly quantity of reading.
This is Frassica at his best - he knows his stuff when it comes to the Italian 20th century. Expect a lot of reading in Italian.
prereqs: ITA 107, ITA 208 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: The course's goal is to analyze the Modern movement in Italian fiction from 1900 to the present, particularly as it reflects various responses to social, political and cultural problems of the period. The following topics will be examined: Fascism in literature; literature of neo-realism and its relation with films, and neo-capitalism; the protest movement of the 1960s and '70s, and the new outlook for the '80s, '90s, and beyond.

title: Topics in Domestic Policy Analysis - Implementing Urban Economic Development
descrip: In this course, we analyze examples of development strategies in the United States, Europe and Asia, at the urban and regional levels, with a focus on the practical role of city government leaders and strategists, and how to make their role more effective. This course is taught primarily through case studies. Most of the classes focus on economic development, but we also spend some time discussing related issues (such as sustainability and income inequality).

title: Mechanistic and Physical Organic Chemistry
reviews: Do as much outside reading as possible (textbook, research papers) in order to grasp the material.
It is a good course to learn and have fun.
Previous knowledge of physical organic topics would have been extremely helpful.
descrip: This course covers the fundamentals of physical organic chemistry to provide the students with a thorough understanding of chemical reactivity. Within the framework of organic reaction mechanisms, the class discusses a number of topics, including the essence of structure and bonding, the nature of reactive intermediates, and the use of kinetic measurements and isotopic labeling studies to decipher chemical mechanisms. Grades are based on problem sets, a mid-term, and a final exam.

title: Introduction to Ocean Physics for Climate
reviews: An extremely difficult course, largely because it is poorly organized. Gabe and Sonya both can't tell when they have lost the class, which happens frequently. The actual material covers large-scale ocean circulation, marine boundaries, the meridional overturning circulation, and some types of waves. Take it you have a strong interest in physics or climate. Problem sets are impossible without attending office hours, not because they are too difficult, just because the actual questions and the grading criteria are so impenetrable. This is one of the those classes where problem set answers will be changing until the night before the thing is due.

Attend all the lectures and do not be afraid to ask questions. Professor Vecchi and Legg both are eager to answer any questions about the material. Attend as many office hours as you can to get help on homework problems.

Be prepared to spend a lot of time on this course if it is taught by the same professors and AI.  It's worth it, I think, but it will take a lot of effort.  And you really have to put that effort in to be able to learn the material because it is really fast-paced.
Be sure you know what you're getting into. This material is pretty interesting, but the class is extremely theoretical and derivation-heavy without much practical knowledge of what it all means.
Brush up on basic physics and calculus, will save a lot of time later on.  Only take course if interested in oceanography/physical dynamics of the ocean system.

This course was very challenging, and not only because of the content. Specifically, the lack of clarity and organization in Prof. Vecchi's lectures introduced a huge amount of unnecessary confusion into the learning process. Ditto for the problem sets?unclear and poorly written instructions made attending every office hour and precept a near-necessity. However, I found Prof. Legg's lectures to be well-organized, at an appropriate level, and very clear (though dense and fast-paced). I would recommend this course only if Prof. Legg is teaching. If Prof. Vecchi is teaching, I advise caution; only take if you are prepared to be frustrated and ready to invest an inordinate amount of time into clearing up confusion.

This is not a trivial class at all. There should be more math requirements for it, so be ready to review your calculus book, or make sure you take full advantage of professor and/or TA time. Also, don't let the work pile up. Lectures build on each other, and there is a very nice sequence to the class. If you don't understand lecture X, make sure to work that out before you try to understand the following ones. It is an extremely coherent course, so you truly need to be proactive and make sure you understand things. Finally, even if the math is overwhelming, focus on the concepts behind it. Once the pain and stress were over, I realized how interesting the field actually is and how much we can learn from the class.
you need to be good at maths
prereqs: MAT 202.
descrip: The study of the oceans as a major influence on the atmosphere and the world environment. The contrasts between the properties of the upper and deep oceans; the effects of stratification; the effect of rotation; the wind-driven gyres; the thermohaline circulation.

title: Critical Trespasses: Theorizing Political and Intellectual Borders
descrip: This seminar structures an encounter with theoretical writings about nation, subjectivity, power and culture, which are assembled for their relevance to "East Asia." The collection is not meant to be comprehensive, but is intended to facilitate discussion of work that has shaped and revised active intellectual traditions. It starts with reflection on "area studies" as an academic discipline and move to considerations of national identity and nationalism. It proceeds to a study of power through psychoanalysis and "neo-Marxism." Finally, it turns to practices - writing, media, technology - that embody and inflect these conceptual formations.

title: Studies in Tibetan Religions - Buddhist Lineages
descrip: This course introduces Tibetan Buddhist traditions based on sources in translation, emphasizing the historical development of the major lineages and their distinctive practice traditions. Course topics will include Tibetan tantric systems and rituals; Tibetan innovations in and approaches to Buddhist philosophy; Tibet's distinctive approach to religion and politics; Tibetan views of space and locality; Tibetan scholasticism; and the challenges posed by modernity and Chinese rule.

title: Middle High German Literature - An Introduction
descrip: Introduction to Middle High German language and literature 1100-1300. Selections from Arthurian romance (Parzival, Tristan), epic (Nibelungenlied), lyric poetry (Minnesang), and mysticism (Meister Eckhart, Mechthild von Magdeburg). Additional readings on history and culture also examined.

title: Biophysical Chemistry I
descrip: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to basic principles of macromolecular structure, stability, and interactions. Major topics include protein structure; protein thermodynamics and folding; nucleic acid structure and stability; principles of intermolecular recognition; and principles and practice of ligand binding analysis. Special emphasis is placed on understanding, in macromolecular systems, the relationships between structure and stability; the molecular origins of cooperative effects; and the relationships between covalent and non-covalent properties.

title: Integrative Dynamics of Animal Behavior
reviews: A personal interest in animal behavior would help, but I think this would be a pretty interesting class to most anyone (definitely a good EEB departmental). Some basic background in bio or behavioral ecology would be helpful to non-bio people because some concepts are on the difficult side. The workload is moderate. Overall, a class that's definitely worth taking.
Definitely take it.
Do it! It's a great overview of some classic, some emerging topics in behavioral ecology, which is a fascinating field.
Great class!
Interesting course that's slightly heavier in workload. Cookie breaks are awesome! Good for EEB majors.

It's not the best EEB course out there but it's certainly not bad.  I found it a bit tedious because I already knew at at least a basic level much of what was covered, so maybe it would be a more interesting course for someone with less of a background in EEB.
TAKE IT! Even if you've already taken 311, this is a great course with great professor/preceptor!
TAKE THIS CLASS IF BLAIR IS TEACHING IT!!! She is an amazing teacher - even better than most professors on campus. But I think she's leaving this semester, which is too bad.
Take it!
Take it! Blair is great. Preceptor Matt is literally perfect.
Take it! Really interesting if you want to learn about animal behavior.
Take this class.  Blair is awesome and you learn so much about animals.
Take this course if you're looking for a good, interesting EEB course that won't make you want to gouge your eyeballs.
This class is interesting and is a good EEB departmental. Overall there is a large amount of work with weekly papers, a term paper, and take-home test.
This class is very interesting, but it is more of an investment than I was willing to make. Lots of assignments and very time consuming.
This course is A LOT of work. Not all of the assignments are hard, but there are a lot of them. There is a final paper and a final exam, which is ridiculous.

This course is amazing! Prof. Costelloe is incredibly dedicated, organized, and engaging. I was surprised by how much I liked this course since I've never studied behavior before. Definitely take this class!
This is an interesting course and there were a lot of fun examples.  Compared to the other species interactions course this one is focused on the larger concepts while Gould's focuses on examples.
Very interesting material, but be prepared to do alot of weekly extra work outside of the class.

Very reasonable workload, fair exams and assessments, and interesting lectures. How well you do is proportional to how hard you work, which is refreshing. But you will not have to work extremely hard- just give spend a little time on the assignments. Definitely take it if you have any interest!
descrip: This course will explore the fundamental principles that underline the evolution and mechanism of animal behavior. Animal behavior naturally crosses scales and disciplinary boundaries. This course will integrate our understanding of behavior with information from neuroscience, evolution, physiology, genetics, and the biology of complex systems.

title: Cinematic Translation, Generic Adaptation: Melodrama, Horror, Action
reviews: Having some background in film would help but is definitely not necessary. I didn't have any background and was still able to hold my own. It is a 300-level class so there will be upperclassmen taking it which means (generally-speaking) more elevated thought and a higher chance that others will have experience in film (but not everyone is this way). We had very little written work, only a weekly response to a film we watched that week, no midterm, and a 10-12 page paper due on Dean's Date. No final exam. Readings are provided each week but you can get away with not reading all of them every single week. You are also responsible for watching one film on your own during the week and that is necessary to do every week because it is always half of the weekly discussion.
Laid-back and fun professor. Good introductory course to film studies that won't molly-coddle you.

My advice would be to read as much of the readings as possible. Sometimes it is easy to skip the readings because they are not talked about largely in the seminar; however, they help not only with analyzing the films each week, but they also help spark ideas for the final paper.
Very interesting topics discussed, not that much work, fairly easy grading, take it for different opinions on film
descrip: This course centers on a set on cinematic genres-melodrama, horror, and action-that have proven to be particularly suitable to global adaptation and appropriation. Their mobility may stem from the physical responses (tears, fright, violence) they represent or elicit. We will examine films from Hollywood, European, and East Asian cinemas to interrogate the question of cultural translatability, while at the same time reconsidering the social and cultural effects of genre itself. One of the central questions of our investigations will be: How do cinematic forms and their translation inform the discourses of nation and cultural difference?

title: Property, Wealth, and Equality
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: The Religions of China
reviews: Do not take this course unless you expect to sit in on mandatory lectures that are sub par on their best days.
Do the readings--they're the best part of the course
Don't take it unless you don't mind a boring class to PDF
Don't take it.
Don't.
Great introductory class.
I'd recommend it if you are interested in the material, but otherwise skip it.

I'd take the course if mandatory lectures don't bother you (and there are ways to make up lectures if you miss them) - the content is interesting, the workload isn't terrible, and I definitely I felt I learned a lot. Also, Professor Teiser is one of the nicest professors I've ever encountered at Princeton and is willing to help you through the course if you have any trouble keeping up.
If you are interested in Chinese history or Chinese religious traditions, this class provides a great introduction.
Lectures are mandatory and poor in information density. Sitting through each one was a massive waste of time when the same material could have been read through in a quarter of the time.
Make sure you participate as much in precept and start assignments early.
TAKE IT
Take it if you're interested in the topic. Not a lot of work, but the papers were graded rather harshly.

This is a pretty good course.  Be aware though, if you are thinking of taking a course to really get an in depth, philosophical look at Chinese Religions. look elsewhere.  However, if you are looking for a general, more superficial overview of Chinese Religions and China in general, this might be a good course for you.  Be aware also, that this course has lots of little assignments (such as weekly blackboard posts, short quizzes, event reports, papers), which, though very manageable, take up a considerable amount of time.  Bottom line: I've taken better courses, but I've also certainly taken worse.

This was a very interesting course if you are interested in China and/or religion. It is very well taught and the discussions in my precept were very thought provoking. I highly recommend taking this course.
Try to do most of the reading!  The knowledge is worth it, and you probably won't get back to them if you don't have a class to motivate you.
Without prior knowledge of Chinese history, I'd imagine some units in the class seem unmotivated.
kinda boring, kind of interesting
prereqs: Open to students who have not taken prior courses in Religion or Chinese studies..
descrip: A thematic introduction to the history of Chinese religion. Topics include cosmology, ancestors, gods, mythology, ethics, shamanism, divination, gender, and mortuary ritual. Readings drawn from a wide range of sources, including sacred scriptures, philosophical texts, popular literature, and modern ethnography.

title: Advanced Arabic I
reviews: Do all the homework. Don't get lazy. Expect no help in memorizing vocab-be good at it on your own.

Do the homework on the days assigned -- your language learning will work much better if you do a bit each day, slow and steady, rather than cram before an exam. And try to speak only in Arabic in class, it will be rewarding!
Go to office hours - Professor Bell is very helpful.
I don't really think you should take this class. It won't improve your Arabic much, but it will take up like a lot of your time. Do something else.

I would advice students to take this class to help them improve their grammar and vocabulary skills. However, I would tell students that there can be a good amount of homework in this class and they need to also stay on top of learning the vocabulary.
If you want to improve in Arabic, then take it. You will learn a lot of grammar, cram in a lot of vocab, but you probably won't do a lot of speaking.

If you're fine continuing to study fairly fine grammar points and acquire semi-useful Al Kitaab vocab, this works for you. Be warned that after studying abroad, it will almost certainly feel like a step back in terms of difficulty, and what you're learning.
It's a lot more work than 107.
Take a section that has fewer students
This class has so much work!
What you get out of the course is really whatever you put in.
descrip: Development of speaking, listening, reading and writing at the upper-intermediate to advanced levels of proficiency. Course is taught primarily in Arabic.

title: The Literary Fantastic
reviews: A great class - really great readings and discussions, very reasonable work
Do the readings.

If this course is offered again by Professor Trezise, take it! I am a science person through-and-through, but I have a soft spot for unusual fiction. If you enjoy reading for pleasure and appreciate things like magic realism, Poe, and seminar-style discussions, this course is for you! Professor Trezise is brilliant. This is the best course I've taken yet!
Make sure you do close reading so that you come to class prepared for deep discussion of the texts.
prereqs: At least one 200-level literature course is strongly recommended..
descrip: A study of the fantastic in nineteenth- and twentieth-century fiction and in a selection of theoretical texts. Issues to be discussed include the relation of the fantastic to neighboring genres such as magical realism, the cognitive challenges it poses, thematic preoccupations such as the double and altered sensory states, the importance of reception, and interdisciplinary approaches drawing on philosophy, psychoanalysis, and literary theory.

title: Solid-State Physics I
reviews: A fun course to take, especially to have a good physics picture.
Don't stress too much on the grading for the problem sets

Don't take it if you're familiar with solid state. Rather attend to the classes you think you don't have a solid foundation on.
If you never studied solid state before, it's a very good introduction.
I would just note that it is a difficult, graduate-level course.  Grading is fair and, if the topic is interesting to the student, I would strongly recommend it.
If you have no background, this course will be helpful.
It takes a lot of time and work, but is a good one to be taken.
Make sure you take Quantum Mechanics first!
Read the course notes with each lecture.

The material of this course is advanced, but do not get scared. The course goes at a slow pace, as it should and you really have time to understand everything. Professor Shayegan is an excellent lecturer and he really cares that you understand the material. This is the best taught physics course I have taken at Princeton and I am a physics major. The problem sets are not too hard.
This course will teach you important concepts in solid state physics, but be prepared to read a lot on your own.
This is a good course, but not an easy course.  You should always pay enough time on it and I'm sure you would get a clear picture in solid state physics.
better take some elementary courses before
prereqs: ELE 342 or PHY 208 and PHY 305 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: An introduction to the properties of solids. Theory of free electrons--classical and quantum. Crystal structure and methods of determination. Electron energy levels in a crystal: weak potential and tight-binding limits. Classification of solids--metals, semiconductors and insulators. Types of bonding and cohesion in crystals. Lattice dynamics, phonon spectra and thermal properties of harmonic crystals.

title: Creative Writing (Literary Translation)
reviews: Definitely take it! Professor Novey is great and you'll learn a lot about how to become a better translator.

I definitely would recommend this course to anyone interested in translation or creative writing of any sort.  It definitely taught me a lot about the practical challenges of translation and improved my own original writings in the process.

This was an excellent class.  It was a lot of fun puzzling through translations, and Professor Novey was not only constructive and insightful, but cheerful, enthusiastic, and truly excited by what she does, which was great.
You learn a lot about translating and how to polish style and tone as a writer as well. However, it was a lot more work than originally expected. You get what you put into it, though.
prereqs: This class is open to any student with fluency in a language in addition to English, by application only. Students apply with either 3-4 pages of original literary translation, or a paragraph explaining why they would like to take the course.
