See the Creative Writing Program webpage for application information. Please note that this course cannot be audited. Application deadline is April 11, 2014..
descrip: Practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by professionals and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. Students MUST be fluent in their chosen language.

title: Normative Ethics
reviews: Great small alternative to PHI202; professor cares a lot and that makes the difference
I would tell them to take it and make sure to do the readings, as Professor Frick will ask people questions on them in lecture.
It's a great course, even if don't have any philosophy background. Take if interested in ethics or moral theory.
Take as both someone who wants an introduction to ethics or also a more theoretical introduction if you've done more applied ethics.
The course is not too demanding and is full of thought provoking philosophical scenarios. If that interests you, then I would definitely recommend the course.

The course was a lot of work when I took it with 2 papers, a term paper, and a final exam. However, Professor Frick really cares about his students and is a great lecturer. If you are interested in philosophy and have time to put in the work, I say go for it.
descrip: A detailed examination of different theories concerning how we should live our lives. Special emphasis will be placed on the conflict between consequentialist theories (for example Utilitarianism) and nonconsequentialist theories.

title: Independent Work with Design
prereqs: This course is restricted to MAE concentrators. Non-concentrators may seek the approval of the MAE department to enroll..
descrip: Course similar to MAE 339-340. Principal difference is that the project must incorporate aspects and principals of design for a system, product, vehicle, device, apparatus, or other design element. Written report and oral presentation at end of semester to faculty, staff, fellow students and guests. Independent work with design is intended for juniors or seniors doing only a one term project. 339D Fall Term project; 340D Spring Term project.

title: International Politics
descrip: This course introduces competing theories of international relations and evaluates their explanation of foreign policy decisions and general patterns in international relations over the last century. Broadly covering security policy and international political economy, topics include the causes of war, the role of international organizations to promote cooperation, and the interaction between domestic actors and governments in negotiations on trade and the environment.

title: Development of the Multi-Skilled Performer
reviews: I found it to be much more rewarding when I had an instrument to play (that was not the piano). If you can't play an instrument, don't completely avoid the course if you still are interested, but also know that it definitely enhances your experience to do so. And please please please don't get caught up in how well you play your instrument and chicken out because you haven't picked up your flute in 7 years or something! Trust me, that doesn't matter!

I would recommend taking this class if only for the professor.  John is renowned and wonderful.  If you do not play an instrument, this class will definitely not be as fun or practically enriching for you.
If you are willing to apply yourself for at least 4 hours a week to learning from a genius and creating something beautiful then take this course!
If you like theater and/or music, you will like this course.  It is unlike anything else you've ever taken.
Take it! But don't take it if you're shy.
Take it! John Doyle is very kind and actor-musicianship is really fascinating. Ask lots of questions!

Take this class! John Doyle is wonderful. Even if you don't play an instrument or haven't played your instrument since elementary school, you can still get a lot out of it and he will adapt things for you.
This class really opened my mind to what theater can be and what performers can do.  John Doyle is a wonderful teacher. Take it!
prereqs: For admission, please contact Tim Vasen, director of the Program in Theater (tvasen@princeton.edu). This course CANNOT be audited..
descrip: A practical class. This is a workshop based class for those interested in multi-skilled performance and in how performance skills can illuminate new forms of theatre making. Ideally participants should have musical skills and be able to bring an instrument to work with. A lack of instrument would not preclude somebody from participating. It is helpful, but not necessary if students can read music. The course is also open to those interested in directing or other aspects of storytelling. It is also available to music students who are interested in all aspects of performance.

title: Quantitative Analysis (Basic)
descrip: Statistical analysis with applications to public policy. The course begins with an introduction to probability theory followed by discussion of statistical methods for estimating the quantitative effects of changes in policy variables. Regression methods appropriate for the analysis of observational data and data from randomized controlled experiments are stressed. The basic level (507B) assumes a fluency in high school algebra and some familiarity with calculus, while the advanced level (507C) assumes a fluency in calculus.

title: Radical Innovation in Global Markets
reviews: Definitely take the course. Worth it to expose yourself to all of the ideas and technology. You will be reminded how talented your peer group is and can actually make friends in the course. High amounts of learning and low amounts of stress.
Enjoy it and you will do well!
Ensure that you form a good group from the beginning. Work collaboratively on the cases and incorporate all view points. That is where the real learning in this course happens!

Highly recommended, but purely for the experience of reading and discussing the cases with your group.  Lectures are usually a rehashing of the cases.  However, as a computer science major, the course gave me a broad overview of a ton of technologies I hadn't known in-depth before, and public policy that was completely new to me.
If you're a follower of technology in the news or if you're interested in how disruptive companies like Uber run up against regulators, this course will be very interesting to you.

If you're interested in business, tech, or public policy, this class is worth taking. If you're interested in the Keller Center classes this is a fairly good one. Weekly case study practice provides practical experience students want from a business class but there are larger thematic takeaways to balance it out.

It's fun. The class seems like a lot of work but if you have a good team then it's really not bad at all. Shinn is pretty cool and laid back. It was interesting to read about some events and technologies I had never heard of. Shinn also brought in his friends from his former life, which all had interesting stories - Silicon Valley types.
Lots of fun if you're interested in putting in the work and are interested in entrepreneurship.

Prof. Shinn is a good professor and the work isn't too time-consuming, but be prepared for the uncertainty and lack of direction (in terms of grading, class discussion, group assignments, etc.) that comes with this course.
Take it!  A great professor, interesting material, not too much work, get to meet classmates through group work.  10/10.
Take this class!

This class covers a lot of interesting topics, but it isn't for everyone. Shop it, read the cases, and engage in discussion during shopping period.

PS Shinn is a very good professor to get to know.

This course was really worthwhile for me. It focuses on case studies on a variety of different technologies and a lot of time is spent working in groups to prepare to discuss the cases in class. It was great for learning how to think critically about business decisions and how businesses and the public sector interact.

This is a good course for senior year, or a good 5th class jr. or sr. year... I definitely recommend it as an interesting and unique course among Princeton offerings to get a sense of business, thinking like an executive/entrepreneur, building d-trees, etc however I think that I went in with too high of hopes for the class and was disappointed a bit.. so just be realistic that this is an interesting class but by no means incredible

This is a good, fun class if you're ok doing the same thing (case studies) twice a week, every week. Not too much work. Your team (assigned first half of the semester, self-chosen after fall break) really determines how much you enjoy the class because you spend all your time with them.
This is a refreshing course to add to your schedule. It's a lot more practical and interesting than many other classes.
wonderful class! one of my favorites. prof. shinn is great!
prereqs: A background in engineering, computer science, or the life sciences is helpful but certainly not required..
descrip: Radical innovation solves big problems and alters the way we live, colliding with government polices as the effects ripple across national frontiers. Where do these innovations come from, how do they work, and what policy problems do they cause? This class examines the impact of technical innovation on a global scale. Students learn how innovations in areas such as satellite imaging, global positioning, internet search engines, and pandemic vaccines have a profound impact on foreign policy. Students learn to think about innovation from the standpoint of business managers, government regulators, social entrepreneurs, in very practical terms.

title: Biophysics
descrip: The course presents a broader view of biological physics. While the course starts with an overview of the fundamentals of biological physics, using Frauenfelder's text book as a guide, the course will move on to higher levels of biological systems, using evolution and ecology as our primary organizing principles. The course will have a section on the Physics of Cancer at the end.

title: African American History from Reconstruction to the Present
reviews: Great course.
Highly recommend.
I highly recommend the class to anyone who's interested in learning something new.
I recommend this course, it's great.
I would strongly recommend other students  take this class.  Make sure to do all the readings because these will really help you in the papers.
If you want to understand America, you must take this course.
Take it - great material.

Take it! It is a side to American History that you rarely hear (and when you do hear it, it isn't as detailed or compelling as it is in this course). The material is so relevant and crucial to understanding the state of race and inequality in America today.
Take this course! Amazing lectures and exciting readings, and the final paper is actually a really enjoyable project. You will want to do the work.
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the major themes, critical questions,and pivotal moments in African American history since emancipation. It traces the social, political, cultural, intellectual, and legal contours of he black experience in the United States from Reconstruction to the rise of Jim Crow, through the World Wars, Depression, and the Great Migrations, to the long civil rights era and the contemporary period of racial politics. Using a wide variety of texts, images, and creative works, the course situates African American history within broader national and international contexts.

title: Intensive Portuguese
reviews: Be on top of your work, because it is a highly demanding course, particularly because of its intensive grammar content, and get prof. Andrea de Castro Melloni if you can!
Do as many of the exercises in the book as possible, since they do help, and speak up. Have fun too! Go to the Portuguese language table now and then.
If you know Spanish really well, this course will not be hard, but if you know it less well, then it will be more work. In any case, you will learn all Portuguese grammar if you stick with it!
The first days of the course are tough -- but stick in there and you'll go from zero to fluent in Portuguese within 12 weeks. Do your work, do the readings regularly. It is worth the effort!
descrip: An intensive course designed for students who have fulfilled the language requirement in Spanish or another Romance language. Knowledge of one of these languages provides the basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. This one-semester 'crash' course teaches fundamental communication skills--comprehension, speaking, reading and writing--and some exposure to cultural aspects of the Portuguese-speaking world, but does not offer an in-depth study of grammar.

title: Networks: Friends, Money and Bytes
reviews:
Because of the flipped lecture format, the number of people going to lecture decreased as the semester went on (like to 30-40% of the class showing up) - though Professor Chiang didn't seem to mind. The textbook was good enough that you didn't even have to watch the online lectures. HW was pretty easy in general, with few exceptions. The content was pretty interesting but also pretty scattered and simplified to be teachable. The midterm (haven't taken the final yet) was fair in difficulty, just a bit harder than HW. The project is what you want it to be - and the Professor seems pretty reasonable in expectations.

So not very time consuming and not that hard. But also not a very active class and what you get out of it is what you put in (textbook/lectures and project)
Challenging but rewarding and extremely interesting.
Don't underestimate how much time the final project takes.
Take it if you are into any kind of network, its very interesting, not insane amounts of work, and very well structured
Take it if you want to learn something new and interesting and relatively close to how the practical world functions.

Take this class if you don't mind spending an extra 3 hours a week actually watching the lectures and then more time understanding, by reading the book, to be able to participate in class.  The material is interesting, but way too much time is asked of the student to be fully committed to this class.
Take this course! Prof. Chiang and the TAs do an amazing job, and you will learn a ton!
The course is interesting but the flipped classroom completely ruined the experience. Sad but I can't even come close to recommending this course even though I enjoyed the subject material

This course uses a flipped classroom lecture style, but you can just read the textbook and you will be fine.  It teaches you all the essential stuff about the internet, by framing it all in applications (like Google's PageRank algorithm). There's also a project you do at the end, which you have an opportunity to create some type of marketable app or explore some new technology, which is pretty dang cool.
Very time consuming
good class for people interested in how networks all around us are working.
good course, would recommend
prereqs: Knowledge of calculus and linear algebra..
descrip: This course is oriented around 20 practical questions in the social, economic, and technological networks in our daily lives. How does Google sell ad spaces and rank webpages? How does Netflix recommend movies and Amazon rank products? How do I influence people on Facebook and Twitter? Why doesn't the Internet collapse under congestion, and does it have an Achilles heel? Why does each gigabyte of mobile data cost $10, but Skype is free? How come WiFi is slower at hotspots than at home, and what is inside the cloud of iCloud? In formulating and addressing these questions, we introduce the fundamental concepts behind the networking industry.

title: Civil Society and Public Policy
reviews: A course taught by Professor Katz is always a must-take. Great readings and a great perspective from a very accomplished, intelligent, and experienced person.
Could be a really good course if you had more time and were more interested in the subject.
Definitely take this seminar!

Do each week's readings thoroughly -- Professor Katz doesn't expect you to finish every book and generally cuts out superfluous readings, so make sure that you really pay attention to the readings he does assign because they will form the basis for most class discussion.
Good course to take!
Great course. Take if interesting in the subject matter and in engaging with classics.

Great low work course if you want to pdf and defer all your effort to a final paper. Professor Katz is very nice, and is really passionate about the subject. However, students have very different backgrounds in the subject and in social/political theory in general so it is tough to discuss the material in a very sophisticated way.

If anything, take this course for Professor Katz (and go to his office hours!!). This course is a way for you to gain a better understanding of civil society (which is crucial in understanding development and policy implementation).
Katz is an interesting person, and this material could have been worthwhile, but for some reason they didn't work together.
Take it. Easy grade. Prof Katz is worth listening to.
Take this class regardless of your major or your background!
Take this course! Katz is so knowledgeable about the subject, and you have interesting discussions and guest speakers which you'll learn a lot from.

Yes take it! Prof. Katz is great, the workload is not too demanding, the material is very interesting and if you are a WWS major it will give you another way of thinking about policy and possible intervention points to change behaviour.
descrip: Civil society is the arena of voluntary organizations (churches, social welfare organizations, sporting clubs) and communal activity. Scholars now tell us that such voluntary and cooperative activities create "social capital" -- a stock of mutual trust that forms the glue that holds society together. The course will be devoted to the study of the history of these concepts, and to the analysis of their application to the United States and other societies. This will be an interdisciplinary effort, embracing history, philosophy, anthropology, sociology, and other disciplines.

title: What Environmental Arts & Humanities Are Good For
descrip: Is the climate blazing? Our cities have food deserts? Your groundwater supplies are contaminated with toxins? Historians, literary scholars, and artists to the rescue! This course explores how to deploy the humanities and arts to grapple with our most urgent environmental challenges--and is affiliated with a fall 2014 What Arts & Humanities Are Good For PEI series of panel events. The course asks how, exactly, we can put the indispensable methods and insights of the arts and humanities to work to create more sustainable places and to enact more equitable and effective environmental policies.

title: Youth and Youth Movements in the Modern Middle East
reviews: Fantastic course, really interesting and relevant material, and great reading list - I highly recommend it! I think a lot of people were scared off from this course because there was a lot of reading and Prof Pursley can come off as intimidating at first. But, I had virtually zero NES background and Prof Pursley made the material very accessible. Do be ready to commit yourself to spending time on the readings, but it is definitely worth it.
Keep up with the readings
Make sure you do all the readings!
Professor Sara Pursley is amazing. Take this course, you will learn much more than you expect.
Read the readings, reflect. The class is really interesting if you let it be.
Take it!
descrip: The 2011 Arab Spring, often framed as a "youth revolution," has fueled new interest in Middle East youth movements. Through the study of youth, we'll explore the texture of everyday life in the region during some of the core political upheavals of the past century, such as decolonization, the Arab-Israeli conflict, the 1979 Iranian Revolution, the Lebanese Civil War and the 2011 uprisings. This focus opens onto pressing questions of the modern era related to the family, gender and sexuality; religious and secular approaches to self-formation; notions of progress, change and revolution; and experiences of war, dislocation and migration.

title: Seminar. 19th-Century European Art
reviews: It's a great seminar for learning about the Impressionists and art historical approaches to these artists. More importantly, it's a great course for learning how to look at art and to appreciate its significance.

Prof. Alsdorf is an incredibly organized, knowledgeable, articulate and engaging professor, presenting even extremely challenging readings in a clear and interesting light. I would strongly recommend taking a seminar with her! The focus of this class on new approaches to Impressionism/Post-Impressionism also made what may seem like an "over-done" area of art history fresh and approachable.
Prof. Alsdorf is very encouraging and moderated class discussion well. If you're really interested in the topic, definitely take it although be aware that there is some pretty dense theory.

Take it if you have a background on Impressionism already, are prepared to do a lot of reading, and think critically about scholarly articles. Do not be intimidated by the 50/50 ratio of undergrads to grad students in the course. Be prepared to participate and to attend class trips.
descrip: Impressionism and Post-Impressionism: New Approaches. This course will consider a range of recent scholarship -- both from the academy and museums -- that has shifted understandings of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist painting. By reading these texts against canonical ones, students will gain a deep and critical perspective on the state of the field. Special attention will be paid to methodology and changing approaches to the blockbuster exhibition. Artists discussed will include Cezanne, Degas, Monet, the Nabis, Pissarro, and Seurat. Field trips to museums in NYC, Philadelphia, and Washington.

title: Interdisciplinary Studies in the Humanities - Revisiting Nature's Nation - An Ecocritical History of American Art
reviews: I would certainly encourage it, if the material was of interest.
If this course is ever taught again, absolutely take it! The professors are kind, intelligent, thoughtful people who genuinely care about what they teach and how you think. It was a gift of a course!

This course is not for the faint of heart - there are a lot of readings, covering complex ideas in both environmental studies and art history, and non-trivial weekly assignments. However, the class covered a lot of interesting material and it was exciting to be at the forefront of art history by studying eco-criticism, an area that is just beginning to take off.
You need to take this course if you have dual interests in art and environmentalism.
prereqs: The course is open to all sophomores, juniors, and seniors; no previous experience required.
descrip: This course critically explores the interface of American art and environmental history while laying the basis for a groundbreaking traveling exhibition on the subject being organized by the Princeton University Art Museum. Using emerging interpretive strategies of "ecocriticism," we will approach American art as creative material that has imagined and embodied environmental issues concerning land use, species extinction, pollution, climate change, sustainability, and justice in a variety of historical contexts since the 18th century - when the foundations of "ecology" as an idea first began to materialize.

title: Historic Gardens and Designed Landscapes
descrip: Please see website

title: Advanced Physics (Mechanics)
reviews: Attend lectures and read the textbook.
Be prepared for the workload, especially if you're taking MAT 203 as well.
Be prepared to work hard then, you will be rewarded. Great for prospective majors.
Do not enroll in any physics class at Princeton University. The people in the classes are snobby, evil, and self-important, and I do not neeeeeeeed this in my life. Nor do you.
Do the problem sets ahead of time and go to office hours.
Hard class but very interesting material

I did not enjoy this course. I feel that it is taught at an unreasonably high level, and even as a person considering majoring in physics, I had a lot of difficulty following the material. I would still recommend taking it over 103 if you took AP physics C in high school, as you might get something out of it at least, whereas you're unlikely to learn anything new in 103. But be ready to spend a lot of time and frustration on this course. I am very torn as to whether or not the course was worth it.

I would advise students to really think about whether or not they want to dedicate all this time to this class unless they either need it or really want to spend a good amount of time on the problem sets.
I would not take this course without physics background.  I entered as a newcomer and was challenged a lot by it, and should have placed myself into 103.

If you enjoy physics, most certainly take this class over PHY 103. If you enjoy challenges, also take this class. If, however, you do not work well learning by yourself through struggling, maybe it's not the best choice.

If you have 5s in your AP Physics and are NOT a Physics major take this course only if you want to have Physics/Math major friends. Not a significant amount of new material learned, though tests are difficult.
If you like physics, challenging problems, and think 103 will be boring I would definitely take this course. It will be easier if you had calculus based physics before, but it not necessary.

If you take this course do the textbook readings and take good notes as soon as possible. Start the problem set as soon as possible and go to office hours and ask questions. Lectures and class are often unhelpful.
If you take this, you are probably required to. Remember the tricks and definitely go to the problem sessions.

If you want to be a Physics major, dont think twice. If you've done AP Physics with calc. then take this. If you dont fit into one of the above categories, do 103. Or you could always take 105 for a week and then assess.
It's a hard course, but worth it!
It's a tough class. Don't take it unless you're confident in your physics abilities and really love the subject.

It's not clear that there's a significant benefit, if any, to taking Physics 105 106 instead of Physics 103-104 in terms of retaining and appreciating the material. The textbooks are much better for 105-106 but the problem sets and final exams are exhausting beyond measure.

Only take this course if you are willing to invest a huge amount of time studying on your own and doing problem sets. The content is very interesting but the teaching was not very good. If you do not put a lot of time in it might be detrimental to any confidence you have in physics.
PHY 105 can be challenging but you'll also learn a lot, though it's more independent learning than 103.
Read the book before going into the lectures.
Read the textbook, go to problem set sessions, and ask questions, because it's a difficult class.
Some kids fell behind due to inexperience with the problems so it's important for them to use the resources of office hours.

Start the problem sets early and do a lot of practice. Make sure that you really understand the problem sets, even after they are graded. Most importantly, stay positive throughout the course, which has many emotional ups and downs.
Take it if you enjoy physics, or think you might enjoy it!
Take this course if you like physics. Otherwise, it's definitely not for you - a lot of my friends ended up dropping.
Takes a good deal of time, be ready to invest that time in the course.
The course is a definite must - you need to spend a lot of time on the reading materials and the homework but they will be hours well spent.
There is a sizable gap between 103 and 105. Would recommend starting in 105 if you are debating.

This class changed the way I see physics. In most physics classes I had taken in high school professors would simply teach us a lot of physical phenomena and the equations related to these phenomena at most giving some intuition on why these equations were true. In this class, however, via rigorous mathematical description of the model, and rigorous deductive work with calculus, the professor was able to make it very clear how all these phenomena and equations follow from Newton's laws.
This course is over complicated and poorly taught. Professors believe they can teach an entire subject matter by doing one problem on the board per lecture, and in the end very little is learned.
This course is very hard.  It really is very, very difficult.  But the material is very interesting.

This is the physics department's introductory course to the major, and it lives up to its name. A lot of time commitment (that I wasn't nearly as ready to give) has to be put into this class to really understand the concepts. Problem sets are absolutely pivotal in passing the class; do the problem set by yourself before going to the review session, and use the review session to check your answers and maybe learn a different method to doing problems. Read the worked examples in the textbook. This class will definitely determine whether physics is the right path for you or not.
You can certainly do this course without knowing too much calculus, but it helps A LOT to be able to at least do simple differential equations, like separable ones.  Definitely do the readings.
look over the AP score sheet thoroughly so you don't make my same mistake
recommend only to students who have very strong background in Physics and calculus.
prereqs: Good mathematical aptitude required - students should be taking MAT 104 or higher concurrently. Students do NOT preregister for PHY 105. Instead, sign up for PHY 103 and select C03 or C04. There is a weekly problem session on Wednesday evenings, 7:30-10pm. Do not schedule your lab section for PHY 105 or any other courses during this time slot..
descrip: PHY 105 is a first-year course in mechanics, taught at a more sophisticated level than PHY 103. We get excellent physics majors from both 103 and 105. The approach of PHY 105 is that of an upper-division physics course, with more emphasis on derivation and the underlying formal structure of physics than one gets in 103, and with challenging problem sets due each week.

title: Aerosol Observations and Modeling
descrip: This course focuses on ground-based and satellite observations of aerosol particles and their impacts on climate through modeling studies. Course material includes satellite and ground-based measurements of aerosol particles, mathematical formulation of transport, and numerical models of aerosol distribution. It studies how aerosols impact climate change through direct and indirect effects including cloud-aerosol interactions.

title: The Female Literary Tradition
reviews: Good class! Prof. Nord is an excellent professor and very open to helping students.
Take the class and do all the readings.
Take this course! Professor Nord leads really interesting discussions, and each text on the reading list is a winner. Just be prepared to read one novel per week!
This is a great course with an excellent reading list. Professor Nord guides discussions well and is very available and helpful outside of class.
descrip: The course will survey a range of novels by women writers from the early 19th century to the present. How is the "tradition" transformed by post-WW II globalism, the geography and politics of empire, by differences in nationality, class, religion, and sexuality?

title: The United States, 1920-1974
reviews: A very easy HA.
Amazing amazing class. Definitely take it. The material is all stuff you should know for life in general and Kruse is great.

As many of the other reviews will say Kevin Kruse is a fantastic lecturer and tells amazing stories.  However the precepts are very dependent on the preceptor so try to switch if the precept does not seem engaging.
Attend all the lectures and take good notes. If you don't attend the lectures it will be difficult to do well on the exams.
Attend every lecture and do the readings. They're worth it.

Chill class. Predictable (in terms of format and essay questions) midterm, final, and a nice 5 pg paper. Good amount of readings. Not as mind blowing as others say, but Prof. Kruse is a great lecturer.
Completing all readings and attending lectures prepares one adequately for coursework.
Definitely take - one of my favorite classes ever at Princeton.
Definitely take it, especially with professor Kruse.
Definitely take it. Lectures are captivating and information dense.
Do all the readings. You'll thank yourself when you're preparing for the essays.
Do every reading and be engaged in precept discussions.  Attend every lecture because they are so interesting!
Do the readings and go to lecture. You won't regret taking this class. Kruse is an incredible lecturer.
Do the readings and speak up during precept. Its the best way to understand the course topics and get something out of the class experience.
Do the readings just because they're interesting and soak up every minute of Kruse's lectures.
Don't stress out about getting all the reading done. Go to lectures and precept!
Even if you aren't particularly interested in U.S. History from 1920-1974, taking this class will be informative and you'll probably enjoy it as much as I did.
GREAT! Would totally recommend. It's such an interesting time period and Kruse is amazing.
Go to class and do the readings, they're not a ton of time and super helpful and make your super interested.
Go to every lecture even if you can't finish all of the reading.
Go to every lecture, take notes, and listen.
Go to every lecture. They are very great.
Go to lecture!
Go to lecture.
Go to lecture. You need to go to lecture. Don't really need to read all of the books, although I did. It's a very doable history class to be honest.
Good course. Kruse is a great lecturer! Reading list was interesting - enjoyed the focus on primary source documents.
Great PDF-ing course, great course to do well in as well. Interesting, informative, and the lectures are great.
Great class, definitely take with Kruse. Lew-Williams is a very good preceptor.
Great course if you want a survey of crucial points in American history from 1920-1974.
Great lecturer, take it.
I have no advice. Take it if you want. I'm very glad I took it, and I would take it again if that made sense.
I highly recommend this class! You will learn so much and it is very interesting.
I think if you are interested in history this would be a good class.

I would advise another student considering taking this course that if she had already studied American history it was still worth taking, provided that she was interested in taking a deeper look rather than studying totally fresh material.
If you have the slightest interest in history, take this course! It is very well organized and Professor Kruse is a great lecturer.

If you're already a serious American History buff, you might not find anything new or interesting here. Also, if you're very conservative, be warned that Prof. Kruse's narrative invariably leans to the left. Otherwise, the course is a good HIS course for anyone with a general interest in the US or US History.
Interesting overview of US history - not too hard
It doesn't matter what you're studying--take this class!
It's a good survey course, but don't expect to improve your reading or writing skills.
It's a great course! Take it.

Just take it.  Don't have any second thoughts.  It's an amazingly taught course and if you are at all interested in American history, you will enjoy it and get so much out of it.  Don't skip lecture.  Not because you need every word of it to do well, but because every word of it is so interesting and powerful.  Professor Kruse does a great job of making history come to life and pulling you back in time.  He is by far the best lecturer I've had at Princeton and I cannot recommend the course highly enough.
Just take this class if you have any interest in US history at all, or if you want to feel like you're getting the most out of Princeton.
Keep up with readings. Focus in lecture. Don't take out your phone; Kruse is a boss and WILL call you out.

Kevin Kruse is a god amongst men! I actually looked forward to going to lecture, which is not something you can say for every class.
However, I have some issues with other aspects of the course: the readings are basically just repeats of lecture, and the redundancy gets old pretty fast. I also wish that the course had taken a more "big picture" approach to history: I felt like there were no big takeaways at the end of the semester, and that was dissatisfying. But honestly, it was worth it for Kevin Kruse, and for that reason I definitely recommend the course.
Kruse is a great professor. If you come to lectures and do the readings, it's not difficult to come off with some sort of A.
Manageable workload, extremely interesting lectures; the course covers subject matter that everyone should have a firm grasp of before leaving college.
Most fun course I had taken!
N/A

Prof. Kruse is one of the BEST professors here. Take this class and go to lecture because it's never boring and will help if you haven't done the reading. The reading isn't bad, really, I have read much worse in other history courses. This course teaches American history in a much more nuanced way than your typical AP US class. Do it and love it.

Prof. Kruse's distrust for technology in the classroom makes for an interesting atmosphere. Be prepared to write quickly. 
The class is worth it though. Lecture is like story-time, and if you pay attention and come to class, the rest isn't too difficult.
Read
Recommend as a PDF
Spend time doing the readings and do a good summary of key terms as you go along--very helpful for midterm and finals.
Strongly Recommend
TAKE IT
TAKE IT!
TAKE THIS COURSE! Professor Kruse is an incredible lecturer and the readings are genuinely interesting.
TAKE THIS COURSE.
Take it

Take it if you are at all interested in 20th Century US History. Even if you aren't, take it because it puts so many other things in context from other courses. Everyone should know the material from this course at some point in their lives, so take it now and have it with an amazing professor.
Take it if you need a history class, take it if you don't. Every American should know this stuff.
Take it!
Take it!  If taking it PDF, still very worthwhile because learn a ton with minimal work.
Take it! Kruse is wonderful and there aren't a lot of assignments.
Take it! Very interesting.

Take it, because you will not regret it. The reading load is relatively light compared to other HA classes, the lectures are awesome, and most people have a cursory knowledge of US history, so it's not like you have a semester's worth of new material being thrown at you.
Take it, but not if you're serious about history.
Take it, do the readings
Take it, go to lecture, every American should have this history known.
Take it, it's extremely interesting.
Take it. Stay up on the reading and think about the deeper historical implications and enjoy
Take the course, stay on top of the materia
Take this class - you'll learn things you didn't know you didn't know and gain a new perspective on American history.  Go to lectures and you'll be fine
Take this class definitely.
Take this class for the lectures alone.
Take this class!

Take this class. If you do not take this class you are doing it wrong. Professor Kruse is amazing. You will learn so much about America that you did not know before. It is beautiful. God bless the USA.
Take this class./
Take this course!
Take this course! Go to lecture, Kruse is amazing. And do the readings.
Take this course! Kruse is awesome and readings are interesting and not too overwhelming.
Take this course! Professor Kruse is awesome and the subject matter is super interesting. Loved it!
Take this course.
Take this course. Go to every lecture, especially the last one. Kruse is so inspiring.
Take this course. Hard to actually get an A unless you do the readings, but the tests are really not hard and Professor Kruse is superb.
Take this course. Whether you're an American or foreign. It's well worth it

The BEST course I've taken at Princeton by far! Had it not been taught by Kruse, I don't think it would have been worth it. He is hilarious, sarcastic and very relatable to his students-- I can assure you that you will never be bored in lecture. I admit I cried a few times during his lectures (they were that captivating!). He is genuinely passionate about his field, well-respected by students and faculty alike and is always responsive to students' questions. Already looking forward to taking more of his classes!

The reading is reasonable, but still a handful if you're not used to it. Try to get the main ideas from the readings, even if you can't read all of it.
Lectures are very fast, but high quality.

This course is amazing.  Regardless of your major you should take this course.  Great overview of this period of history.  The lectures are absolutely incredible and the workload is completely manageable.
This is a must take!

This is the best class I have ever taken in my entire life. That is not an overstatement - Kevin Kruse is incredibly dynamic, the material is fascinating, and the workload is extremely manageable (120-150pgs/week). The lectures are captivating, and often moving - Prof. Kruse literally made the entire class cry TWICE during the semester. I was blown away by this course.
Yes
You should take it!
absolutely
take the course with Kruse
very helpful
prereqs: PDF option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: The history of modern America, with particular focus on domestic political and social changes. Topics include the Roaring 20s; the Great Depression and the New Deal; the homefront of World War II and the Cold War; the civil rights movement and the Great Society; the Vietnam War; the sexual revolution; the Silent Majority, the Nixon administration, and Watergate.

title: Corporate Restructuring, Mergers and Acquisitions
descrip: This course applies topics from microeconomics (ECO 305) and corporate finance (ECO 318) to study corporate restructuring. Topics include mergers, acquisitions, joint ventures, divestiture and share repurchases. Each of these is discussed in the context of the relevant economic theory, institutional and regulatory environment, and with a focus on shareholder value. Meets concurrently with ECO464.

title: Probability Theory
reviews: Absolutely take this class! it is fun! it is beneficial!
Definitely take it, it is faced paced and you learn a lot.
Great course.

Interesting course - especially for advanced students in math. It starts off at a decent pace covering sigma algebras, Lebesgue Integration, and measure spaces, so if you haven't seen any of this before, the beginning may be a bit troublesome.
Lots of measure theory review. Covers the main material (esp. martingales) well but approach is very "by-the-book."
N/A
Nah. I'm neutral. It's not a very special class.
None
Probably the best intro probability theory option . It's possible to take with or without prior knowledge of measure theory.

Professor Cheridito is an excellent lecturer, and the problem sets are well-written. The recommended readings are very helpful in filling the holes in one's understanding, though they can be a bit opaque at times. The workload is not overwhelming, but you will likely need to dedicate at least 10-15 hours per week on each problem set, on average.
Take if you're interested in probability theory.

Take it! There is a very extensive review of measure theory in the beginning so there is no need to have a background on it. The lectures are clear if a little slow and problem sets don't take too much time.

The first half of the course is pretty much just getting you used to measure theory.  The second half of the course mostly focuses on martingale theory.  I'm not sure how this stacks up to Math 385.  But if this is what you're looking for in a Probability Theory course then take it.  The workload is about the same as an upper level math course.  Not sure about ORF since this is my only ORF class.
The problem sets could take considerable amount of time every week.

This course is a decent alternative to MAT 385 in the math department.  Seems like everything is going to come down to one final exam though, so unless you love being under a ton of pressure.  Otherwise treatment of the material was pretty standard.
descrip: Graduate introduction to probability theory beginning with a review of measure and integration. Topics include random variables, expectation, characteristic functions, law of large numbers, central limit theorem, conditioning, martingales, Markov chains, and Poisson processes

title: Major Author(s) - Faulkner, Ellison, Morrison
descrip: This course reads major works of three of the most acclaimed novelists of the twentieth century. The seminar will explore Faulkner's sweeping accounts of the tragic ambitions of a mythic South, the absurd trajectory of Ellison's singular protagonist, and the haunting lyricism of Morrison's re-writings of histories small and large We will pay careful attention to the ways in which each attends to the problematics of race, gender, class and language in their particular narratives of American identity, to the formal innovation and craft of their prose, and to the seemingly ongoing "conversation" between the three authors.

title: Policy Workshop - State Policies on Hydrofracking
descrip: Hydraulic fracturing of shale is rapidly increasing the availability of natural gas in the United States and transforming the global energy landscape. This benefits the US economy and energy security. It may also reduce the emissions of greenhouse gases (GHG) and hence be beneficial for climate. However, natural gas is largely methane and methane is a potent GHG. This workshop attempts to provide cogent reasoned guidance on desirable state-level regulation of fracking to allow it to provide needed natural gas at reasonable prices while protecting local environment and global climate.

title: Electromagnetic Field Theory and Optics
reviews: Good course - Wysocki is extremely nice, and material is interesting.
Most of the beginning material is similar to physics E&M. It picks up and introduces new topics after the midterm.

Pretty good course for everything optics and wave related. Prof. Wysocki explains everything well as long as you pay attention. The front is a little slow in reviewing Physics 104 material, but it gets interesting at the end when you get into optics and things that you can apply to your everyday experience.
Take it!
prereqs: PHY 103 and PHY 104..
descrip: This course should provide the students with a broad and solid background in electromagnetics, including both statics and dynamics, as described by Maxwell's equations. Emphasis will be on basic engineering principles, and applications will be discussed throughout. Examples include cavities, waveguides, antennas, and fiber optic communications.

title: Topics in Algebraic Number Theory - Automorphic Forms
descrip: This course is aimed at early stage graduate students. I introduce basic facts about automorphic forms and Shimura varieties illustrated by the cases of GL(2) and U(2,1).

title: Legal and Business Spanish
reviews: Take it!! Professor Naudi is the best and she will really help your level of Spanish grow no matter where you are.

This is a great Spanish class that deals a little bit with grammar but mainly focuses on your development in speaking the language and applying it in real-world fields where you may come across the vocabulary. If you have any interest in using Spanish on a professional level in the future I highly recommend this class.

Try to speak in class when you can and answer questions without being called on.  Don't worry if you mess up a little when speaking- she cares more about the fact that you are actually trying to speak spanish.
prereqs: SPA 107 along with instructor's permission; or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or a satisfactory AP/SAT score (AP5/SP SAT ST 760)..
descrip: An advanced level Spanish course on legal and business language. The course aims to familiarize students with the vocabulary, grammatical structures and register specific to legal and commercial Spanish in context. Students will also be introduced to the basics of different legal systems and business cultures through the study of critical texts, situational cases and videos as well as class discussions, role-plays, presentations and independent research.

title: Directing Workshop
reviews: If you have the slightest directing aspiration, this is the class for you. Even for actors, this class will illuminate the other side of things and offer insight on the actor's role within the larger theater making process.
Take it!

This is not an easy course. You will be challenged and prompted to push your limits as a director. Sometimes this means going through moments of discomfort or uncertainty, as you must question your own creative process. However, you can always rely on the safety network provided by Tim and your classmates, who listen and respond with intent and attention. Experiment and have fun in this class, because you can, and that is what is expected of you. Personally, my entire pleasure in the course found meaning and value in the final project. I was deeply moved by this course, and would take it again if I could.
prereqs: Prerequisites: THR 201 or other acting course and by permission. Please contact Professor Tim Vasen (tvasen@princeton.edu) for enrollment permission..
descrip: Special directing assignments will be made for each student, whose work will be analyzed by the instructor and other members of the workshop. Students will be aided in their preparations by the instructor; they will also study the spectrum of responsibilities and forms of research involved in directing plays of different styles.

title: Studies in the Religions of the Americas - Sexuality and Religion in America
descrip: This course explores the relationship between sexuality and American religion. Sexuality has long been a contested and contentious issue within American religious contexts, and the need for greater understanding and clarity has only increased over the last half century. We will be particularly focused on the way in which religiously informed notions of sex and sexuality have touched every area of American life, including popular culture, politics, and the law.

title: Microeconomics Analysis (Accelerated)
descrip: Course covers many key concepts from microeconomic theory, including consumer and producer theory, competitive markets, market power, information and contracts. Emphasis of the course is on developing a formal, model-based treatment of these subjects and applying them to various relevant policy issues. The course is intended for those students who are already familiar with microeconomic concepts (at the level of 511c) and have an appropriate level of mathematical proficiency, including knowledge of multivariate calculus (including constrained optimization), basic probability, and some familiarity with linear algebra.

title: Muslims and the Qur'an
reviews: A great introduction to Islam. Zaman's lectures are interesting and the reading is good. A solid EM.

Be aware that it is a broad outline, there's not much detailed analysis of anything. Also, the writing assignments each week were challenging because Zaman wants you to think further than just what the readings are saying, which can be difficult.
Definitely take this as an easy EM!! Interesting and well taught :)
Definitely take this course and do all the readings, it is worth it.  If you do the readings each week and actually spend times doing the precept responses you will do fine gradewise.

Do as much of the reading as possible. I know it's a lot, but it is incredibly worth it, especially if you have little prior knowledge of Islam, like I did. You will learn so much. Also, go to the lectures. Professor Zaman highlights all important things that are likely to show up on exams in lecture, and he also adds material that isn't found in the readings.

Do the readings, pay attention in class. This course gives you a very good understanding of Islam, from its foundations to modern times. It is worth taking, although it can be a little boring at times.
Get a good preceptor
Great discussion of relevant topics, and not too difficult.
Highly recommend if you need a distribution requirement and want to understand Islam and modern events (ex: ISIS)

If you plan on PDFing, know that Zaman truly seeks to facilitate student discussion in precepts: he WILL call you out if you don't contribute! That being said, don't let that stop you from not taking this class: the material is great, the papers are short, and the grading is relaxed.

If you're new to Islam or to the Qur'an, this course is a nice introduction to the subject. If you're at all familiar with the material - and especially if you're NES or the equivalent - the course will be incredibly basic, so look elsewhere for departmentals as a junior or a senior.
Interesting subject and interesting course
Prior background in Islam is not needed: it is even better if you come in with an open mind instead of ideas which may prejudice you.
Provides a great background on Islam and the text of the Qur'an.
Spend time on the weekly papers. They will help you to become a better writer and thinker They will also help you a lot when you do the midterm and final essays.
Take it but it's a good amount of work
Take it if you want to fulfill the AB requirement and are interested in Middle Eastern culture!
Take it! Pretty easy, and Edgar is a GREAT preceptor. Readings are interesting.
Take it. It is fantastic. Readings might be too much, but it is worth it. Requires consistent work.

Take the lectures seriously because you will not glean all the information you need from the readings alone. Precepts are great for getting your questions out and to have any confusions clarified. Take the reading responses REALLY seriously, they are a huge part of your grade besides the take home exams. Be sure to summarize all the readings in like 2-3 sentences, then pick out one big idea you want to address and then analyze. Always end with some questions or a point that can be expanded upon.
Take this course because it provides you with a very solid and comprehensive background in Islam without being too much work.
Take this course if you're interested in Islam in any capacity, including and especially because of politics, and try to get into Prof. Zaman's precept if you can. He's great!
Take this course.

This course provides an excellent introduction to the origin and development of Islam into the present day. I recommend it to anyone considering the religion major, but also those who just have a general interest in Islam or are frustrated with its portrayal in the American media. I think if everyone on Princeton's campus took a course like this one, it would be a huge step forward in clarifying misconceptions about the religion. It's also great because it makes you think differently about what constitutes religion, and how religious concepts develop out of different historical circumstances. I really enjoyed the class and think it has made me a better student and citizen!
This is a great overview of Islam from Muhammad's time to the present. If you do the reading and attend lectures the assignments are straightforward.
This is a thorough, well-organized, super informative course about Islam taught by a really kind man/wonderful lecturer. Worth taking if it interests you at all!

This is a wonderful class to take, so far my favorite one at Princeton. I took it for my EM and loved it - and I'm not someone who is usually interested in religion. Definitely get into Professor Zaman's precept - he really cares about the students and gives great feedback on classes! I switched into his precept a few weeks into the class, and this was the best decision that I made this semester. I began by thinking that I would PDF this class but decided not to after all. There is a weekly reading response, 2 quizzes, and a take-home midterm and a take-home final.
This is one of those classes where you will remember what you learned even after the semester is over because the topic is so important.
descrip: A broad-ranging introduction to pre-modern, modern, and contemporary Islam in light of how Muslims have approached their foundational religious text, the Qur'an. Topics include: Muhammad and the emergence of Islam; theology, law and ethics; war and peace; mysticism; women and gender; and modern debates on Islamic reform. We shall examine the varied contexts in which Muslims have interpreted their sacred text, their agreements and disagreements on what it means and, more broadly, their often competing understandings of Islam and of what it is to be a Muslim.

title: Romanticism and Realism
descrip: In our seminar we will read seminal romantic and realist works, exploring the intersections and interactions between them that have proven formative to their internal development and that of their main genres, poetry and prose. Key critical, theoretical, and philosophical considerations of the textual and conceptual issues they raise will also be discussed, with a view to understanding the textual dimensions of the literary history that precedes them and that they continue to produce. Works by Milton, Wordsworth, Keats, Shelley, Hawthorne, Whitman, Melville, Faulkner, among others.

title: Beginner's Latin
reviews: Brace yourself.
If you want to take this class, do a little Latin over the summer. Start preparing as soon as this class occurs to you. It's REALLY REALLY FAST and the textbook presents things in a bizarre oder.
Make your own notes from the reading.
Professor Barnes is great.
das
try doing readings outside of class
prereqs: No credit is given for LAT 101 unless it is followed by LAT 102..
descrip: An introduction to the basic grammar, syntax, and vocabulary of Latin designed to enable students to read and understand simple Latin prose and verse.

title: Special Topics in MMS - A Social and Multi-dimensional Exploration of Structures
descrip: The class has pedagogical objectives related to the spatial relations of dimensions and time (sustainability and society). It develops the students' skills in drawing, model making, writing, oral communication, and advanced engineering analysis. The course is focused on a study of one theme that changes every year. Within each theme engineering calculations of designs are made through advanced analyses. The social context is studied, a site visit is made during break week, models of a few significant works are created and placed on display as part of a small exhibition. Two three-hour studios per week with lectures included.

title: Advanced Macroeconomic Theory I
reviews: Take if interested.
You should take this.
descrip: Topics vary from year to year, reflecting current developments and the instructor's interests. Topics covered in past years have included methods of numerical analysis and econometric testing of equilibrium business cycle models, the role of monetary and fiscal policy in inflation determination, the nature of optimal monetary policy, dynamic games and time consistency in macroeconomic policy formation, central banking, and the theories of price stickiness.

title: Selected Topics in Russian Literature and Culture - Survey of Russian Poetry
reviews: Definitely take it, a great introduction to the expansive World of Russian poetry.
Get ready for an awesome semester!

I would advise them to take the course and make sure to keep up with the readings in order to get the most out of in-class discussions. Marking and noting things like stress and meter ahead of time are also helpful.
If you have any interest in poetry take this course!  Mark is terrific, and he will have you engaged in the material from the word go.

Take this course, even if you don't think you're interested in poetry! Russian poetry is so important in their culture and literary tradition and this course will allow you to understand why. Also Mark is so knowledgeable on and passionate about the poems, it's amazing.
This is a fabulous overview of Russian poetry, if you're interested. I'd highly recommend taking it.
This is a great class that gives you a good overview of Russian poetry but also dives into the nitty-gritty of poetic technique.
prereqs: RUS 207 or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will serve as an introduction to major Russian poets from Pushkin to the present. No prior knowledge of Russian literature is assumed. The focus of the course will be on close readings of individual poems, but the intention is, by generalization, to reach an understanding of the development of Russian literature as a whole. All readings will be in Russian, but discussion will be in English. There will be an additional (optional) hour for those wishing to discuss the poems in Russian.

title: Politics of Empire, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: The American Jeremiad and Social Criticism in the United States
reviews: Amazing class, but the material is difficult to comprehend at times and challenging overall, but the whole class went on a journey together to understand why each of the readings was important which was really cool. Plus Professor Glaude really is one of my favorites from all the courses that I have taken so far.
Definitely take this class! I hope you have as an amazing a group of students as I did. If not - take advantage of spending this time with Professor Glaude and listen to his lectures.

Definitely take this course if you are interested studying criticism as an art and a political force. Professor Glaude does a great job of engaging the class and explaining new/exciting topics. Amazing class!
Make sure to do the readings and fully invest yourself in the class, that's the only way you'll get through.
One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton.
Prof. Glaude is the best! He truly cares about his students and the readings are amazing. Take anything he teaches.
TAKE IT. You'll never think the same way again.
Take it!
Take it.
Take this course!
descrip: This course examines the religious and philosophical roots of prophecy as a form of social criticism in American intellectual and religious history. Particular attention is given to what is called the American Jeremiad, a mode of public exhortation that joins social criticism to spiritual renewal. Michael Walzer, Sacvan Bercovitch, and Edward Said serve as key points of departure in assessing prophetic criticisms, insights and limitations. Attention is also given to the role of black prophetic critics such as James Baldwin, Martin Luther King, Jr., and Cornel West.

title: First Year Philosophy Graduate Student Seminar - The Philosophy of Saul Kripke
prereqs: For first-year Philosophy graduate students only..
descrip: A seminar for first-year graduate students in philosophy. Issues discussed will vary from year to year.

title: Algebra I
reviews: A great introduction to algebra. Take it for sure if you're interested in the subject. If you're a math major, you don't really have a choice. Make sure to start the problem sets early and go to office hours.

Artin includes a quote by Hermann Weyl in one of the later chapters of the book for this course which characterizes mathematics as the battle between the "angel of topology" and the "devil of abstract algebra." I took this class concurrently with the department's topology course, and not only can I fully attest to this characterization, but I can also tell you that I have never been so absolutely terrified to look at a problem set, or a book for that matter, than those for this class. The fear this class instilled in me of algebra every Wednesday night as groups of students gathered in the common room as part of their weekly sacrificial ritual to the devil of abstract algebra can really only aptly be described in religious terms as, indeed, a soul-sacrifice, or a baptism-by-fire of sorts. That being said, there is something incredibly edifying, perhaps even sublime, about peering into the void soul of the devil for an entire semester. One learns, of course, a very good amount of group theory, but one also comes out of this experience with a whole new perspective on life: after all, no pain, no gain. I know personally that I am all the better for taking this course.

All of which is really a long-winded way of saying that, regardless of how one perceives the difficulty of this class, there is something to be gained by everyone here. Perhaps the problem sets will not be as long in the future, but even if you don't "like" or aren't "naturally talented at" group theory, you should still take this course beyond the fact that it is a math departmental requirement.
Be prepared to spend a lot of time on psets.
Do not procrastinate on problem sets. They are challenging and meant to be long.
Don't take it unless you're prepared to devote your life to it and also feel like crying a lot.
Don't wait til the night before to start the psets, and read the text!
If you are a math / computer science major, take this course.
If you're a math major, it's more or less required. If you aren't, there's no real point. I did find it rather enjoyable, though.
Interesting class. The first half of the semester was easy compared to the second half. Be wary of the difficulty spikes.

It is really hard. I would say that if you are concentrating in mathematics then you definitely should take this because I suppose that it is important but find out from the instructor when the problem sets are due and try to work your schedule to include the least number classes on that day since the problem sets are intense and more than simply 'demanding'.
I feel that this course went over some really interesting things but that it is made really hard on purpose, though I guess that's life (and better off for you in the long run).
Make sure to have a good teacher.
Prof Sivek is not a great lecture, since his lectures mostly just mirror the readings. Nevertheless, I enjoyed the class, and I think I got quite a lot out of it.
Take especially if Steven in teaching.
Take it -- the things you learn are very fundamental and used in almost every field of math.
Take it if you're a math major but otherwise it's probably not worth it.
Take it!

This is a reasonable class with fun peers and interesting topics. Some students from outside the math department may find it a bit too time-consuming, but some also find it a nice break from their own departments.
You'll learn a lot, but be prepared for a huge time commitment
descrip: This course will cover the basics of symmetry and group theory, with applications. Topics include the fundamental theorem of finitely generated abelian groups, Sylow theorems, group actions, and the representation theory of finite groups.

title: Species Counterpoint
reviews: Good luck! Try to copy Palestrina a lot and write a lot of 7-6 suspensions.

Most who take it have to, so if you have to take this course, aim for Prof. Trueman's precept as you will be in safe hands there.  The course needs a listening supplement, and that is, for now, on you.
TAKE THIS CLASS. Not too difficult but great music.
Take it with Dan. If someone else is teaching, be wary that it takes dedication and skill to make Counterpoint seem as engaging and fun as Dan makes it seem.
Take it.

This is a tough course. I did well in MUS 105/106 and found this very challenging, if that helps give you perspective. That said, Prof. Trueman is great, and you really learn a lot about the style of music and about composition in general. Highly recommended if you're willing to put in the effort (~6-8 hours of assignments per week).
prereqs: MUS 106 or permission of instructor.
descrip: To lay the foundations for a thorough understanding of the principles of linear structure and voice-leading through the study of species counterpoint. Twice weekly exercises will lead to a complete 4-5 voice Mass Movement as a final project.

title: Socrates
reviews: Go ahead and try it out.

If you enjoyed Greek before, then you should take this class without a doubt! You'll definitely love it. It's a good mix of grammar and translation, so you get to read a fair amount of an original Greek text and your knowledge of the language will improve a lot.
If you love Greek, take this course! It's a great opportunity to immerse yourself in the ancients and to form bonds with a tight community of students.
Review your grammar beforehand and keep on top of the translation and grammar review!
Take it if you're a Classics major.
Take this course if you want a reading knowledge of Ancient Greek and are interested in the dialogue. You should be fairly self-motivated for this course to be enjoyable.

This course is the most work that I have ever done for a Princeton class, and it will likely be my lowest grade. If you can take it with Professor Wildberg, I recommend it; he's wonderful. But for the love of god, take the vocabulary list he gives at the beginning and learn it by heart, otherwise you will spend the entire semester looking up dictionary entries.
This was a good class, especially after 103, for helping to go back over concepts for a second time and really learn them, as well as apply grammar knowledge to a real text.
prereqs: CLG 102 or CLG 104 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: This course offers a close reading of a fascinating Platonic dialogue in tandem with an intensive review of Greek grammar.

title: 20th-Century Japan
reviews: A very interesting subject taught by a phenomenal professor. Go for it!

An excellent course for anyone remotely interested in learning something totally new or in Japanese history in particular. It's a lot of material, but really interesting, and not terribly difficult. Professor Garon has a phenomenal course put together, no doubt in part due to his decades of teaching it. Highly recommended.
Excellent history course - lectures were interesting and engaging. 20th century Japan is also just an inherently interesting place.
Garon is a great lecturer, and the material is interesting. A fair amount of work, and I wouldn't say grading is particularly easy, but it's definitely a worthwhile and interesting class.
I really enjoyed this class. I learned a lot, and the workload is not excessive.
I'm not a HIS person at all -- absolutely loved this class. Didn't do too many readings and did just fine, although P/D/Fed in end (regretted this decision). Prof Garon is awesome
If you are interested in the World Wars, take this course! It provides a fascinating understanding of the Japanese perspective.
Take it only if very ready to work hard.
Take it!
Take it, even if you do not know anything about Japanese history. This is a great course, especially for anyone interested in the 20th century, WWII, recent economic trends.
Take it, even if you know nothing about Japan or East Asia. Prof. Garon alone makes the course worthwhile.
Take this course if you are at all interested in Japan or History. Professor Garon is great!
Take this course if you are willing to work for it!
Take this course!
This class is a great way to learn about Japan from a non-Euro-centric perspective.

This is a pretty good class. The lectures are well organized and straightforward. This is a class where the more you invest in the course, the more you have an enriching and successful experience. There are a lot of readings, which are helpful but not all are crucial.

Too much reading is assigned, but that reading isn't always the most important. If you're smart, you can prioritize the important readings and still get a lot out of a great class with amazing lectures.
Would recommend this class for anyone interested in learning about Japanese history or culture. Would help to have another class on general Asian history prior to this class.
it is an interesting history class.
descrip: The course provides a general introduction to Japanese history from 1890 to the present, with emphasis on Japan's rise as the modern world's first non-Western power, imperialism, industrialization, social change, gender relations, democracy, World War II, the U. S. Occupation, state management of society, the postwar "economic miracle," and the preoccupation with national identity in a Western-dominated world. In the final weeks, we will think about post-1945 developments in terms of continuities with (and divergences from) the prewar and wartime history of Japan.

title: Topics in Legal Thought and Legal Practice
reviews: If they were interested in American law, and wouldn't mind a heavier reading load, I would definitely recommend this course. Great professor, great readings, and an all-around great course.
Take it and be prepared to feel a little overwhelmed by the workload. You will not be underwhelmed by the reading materials or Professor Hartog!
Take it and be prepared to read a lot.  Only take it, though, if you have an interest in law or law school.
This course would probably be most interesting to someone with a strong academic interest in the law.

Write your journal immediately after reading. I found that once I started doing this, I was able to find one or two threads in the readings that brought them all together for me. I went to class better prepared, and had more to contribute to the discussion. The course can be very abstract, so it helps to come to class with some concrete ideas to share
descrip: Seminar surveys historically significant schools of American legal thought, along the way questioning the notion of distinctive schools, as well as the distinctive legality and the distinctive Americanness of the thought. It offers an intellectual history of main themes in modern American legalism, with an emphasis on core controversies. Students will also find that the readings introduce a variety of methodologies and approaches used by historians and others who study issues of legality and law.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Topics in Algorithms
descrip: Study of current research in algorithms, focusing on optimization problems. Topics are drawn from applications of mathematical programming techniques, advances in spectral methods and approaches to go beyond worst case analysis. Other topics may be included depending on the interests of the participants.

title: Who Wrote the Bible
reviews: Don't think you need prior experience in religion or Hebrew to take this course- it's very accessible. Readings are interesting, and class discussion mostly focuses on interpretations of these readings. You'll enjoy the class if you actually put time into it.
Great class, manageable workload, fascinating lectures. Hard not to recommend
I would advise other students to take this class if they are ready to do a lot of reading and know they want to study religion.
I would advise them to take the class if they have an interest in Biblical scholarship. I would tell them that the final paper is a good way to improve writing skills.
If you are looking for a good HA this is definitely one to go for. Professor Meshel is great, especially if you aren't shy. The material is interesting and the workload is light.
If you are looking for an HA, or just to learn more about the Hebrew bible you should take this class.
Keep up. I imagine it'd be quite difficult with no previous knowledge of the Hebrew Bible.
Make sure to take organized notes during class! The lectures can be a bit all over the place, and you will be expected to know the material for the Midterm.
Not a good PDF class.
Really cool way of looking at the Bible and reading the text critically to see how it was put together, changed, etc. Meshel is also passionate about his subject and funny.
Take it
Take it if you are interested in the topic.  Not a bad PDF course.
Take it.
Take it. Accessible for students of all disciplines and helps dispel a lot of misconceptions about the Old Testament.
Take this class if you're interested in learning how to analyze multiple biblical texts and form a hypothesis on how they came about.
Take this class. It's amazing and fun and Professor Meshel is fantastic.
This course has fundamentally changed how I approach the field of religion and I would highly recommend it to any student interested in the study of the Bible and/or religion.
This is a good intro class, though a bit unorganized. I felt disengaged at times but the professor tried to learn everyone's name by the end and get everyone to participate.

This was an extremely fascinating course.  I had learned a lot of biblical stories in religious school, so it was fun to learn the historical explanation for why the stories are the way they are.   (Example: did you know that the story of Samson was originally a sun god myth?)  Professor Meshel is a fantastic lecturer, although lectures are a little bit disorganize, so you sometimes walk away from class wondering what it was exactly that you were supposed to learn.
descrip: The course will introduce students to the Hebrew Bible ("Old Testament") in its ancient Near Eastern setting. Key concepts often associated with the Hebrew Bible, such as God, damnation, sin, and history, will be scrutinized through a careful reading of a selection of Biblical texts including the Creation and Garden of Eden narratives in Genesis, the laws of Leviticus, the prophecies of Ezekiel and the poetry of Song of Songs. Particular attention will be paid to the transformations that the texts underwent through a continuous process of transmission and interpretation.

title: Psychological Studies of Inequality (Half-Term)
descrip: Two major areas of psychology make important contributions to the study of social policy and inequality. The first is social psychology, which focuses on inter-group relations, interpersonal perception, stereotyping, racism, aggression, justice and fairness. These are the micro-level building blocks of structural inequalities and processes that are shaped by the larger context of race, ethnic and gender relations. The second domain involves the fields of social-cognition, judgment and decision making, areas of research that study human information processing in a way that is not about individual differences, and often not social.

title: Chemical Oceanography
reviews: I really benefited from printing out the slides ahead of time and then taking notes on the slides.  For me it's more helpful to have everything together.

Speak up during class - professor Sarmiento has extra slides for pretty much every lecture, and he is more than happy to address your questions with a new figure or more data. It's amazing how well-prepared he is.
Keep a copy of your problem sets - sometimes it takes a while for us to get pests back, so it helps to save copies of old ones, which I commonly referred back to.
Do the readings - though the lectures are super clear, there is a lot of extra information in the book.
