This course is best best is you have a solid background in chemistry/oceanography and passion about the material is necessary to get the most out of the course.
Try to read as much as possible.
descrip: The chemical composition of the oceans and the nature of the physical and chemical processes governing this composition in the past and present. The cycles of major and minor oceanic constituents, including interactions with the biosphere and at the ocean-atmosphere and ocean-sediment interfaces.

title: Behavioral Economics Workshop
descrip: Seminar led by different guest professors each week to discuss their current research in the field of Behavioral Economics.

title: Structure and Properties of Materials
reviews: 1. Go to lecture. They're truly instructive.

Definitely a great class to take, especially because Prof. Arnold is a very engaging lecturer and the material is interesting. I'd recommend waiting until Junior year to take the class if you're MAE, because you'll want to learn the fundamentals in Solids and Thermo before diving into this class.
Even if you are not interested in materials, this class will still be rewarding, and absolutely worth taking. Craig Arnold is an excellent and interesting lecturer.
Even if you do not have to take this course to graduate, I would. If you like science, you'll like this class! Especially if Professor Arnold teaches it.
Everyone should take a materials class. Work quickly on exams and read the textbook!
For MAEs, as it's required, it's probably not going to be your favorite course, but there's not much you can do.
I loved the course, Prof Arnold is very engaging and the material is understandable.
I would say read the book, it is an amazing tool for this class.
Only take it if you have to or you love materials
Only take this course if Craig is teaching it. He's the man.
Practice homework problems for the exams.
TAKE IT WITH PROFESSOR ARNOLD!!!
Take this class, Professor Arnold is great!

This is by far the better course to fulfill the MAE materials requirement, but can also be taken based upon general interest in materials. Prof. Arnold delivers tremendous lectures and is always available for help.
Yes, it is engaging and useful
prereqs: It is expected all students will have completed the BSE freshman requirements of chemistry, physics, and math or their equivalent. MAE 221 recommended but may be taken concurrently. Audit option available only for non-departmental students..
descrip: Relates to the structures, properties, processing and performance of different materials including metals, alloys, polymers, composites, and ceramics. This course also discusses how to select materials for engineering applications. This course satisfies the MAE departmental requirement in materials as well as the MSE certificate core requirement.

title: Photography's History from Analog to Digital
reviews: If you want to learn about photography, DEFINITELY take this course
If you're willing to put in the work, this course will give you so much information on the history of photography.  McCauley can be tough at times, but she is a wonderful professor.
prereqs: Coursework in 19th and 20th-century history, literature, philosophy, or painting would be good preparation for this course. Studio photographers are also welcome..
descrip: A survey of photography from its multiple inventions in the early nineteenth century to its digital omnipresence in the present day. Themes will include photography's power to define the "real"; its emulation and eventual transformation of the traditional fine arts; and its role in the construction of personal and collective memories. Precepts meet in the Princeton Art Museum and Firestone Library to study original images.

title: Issues in Contemporary Art
reviews: Being that it's a program requirement, my recommendation doesn't really mean much but if for some reason you're in the program and this doesn't fit your schedule, consider changing the class that conflicts with this to be in this one.
Do the readings, even if you just quickly skim. It makes the class engaging and enjoyable
Great class! I wasn't too enthused about taking this requirement at the beginning of the semester, but by the end it was probably one of my favorite classes.
Have fun!
It's for the certificate program. Definitely take it.
Keep an open mind, and don't be afraid to be wrong.
Make your class discussion as off-the-wall and interesting as you can! Do not slack off on your independent work...it will pile up and become unmanageable very quickly!

While this course is a requirement for certificate students and is only open to certificate students, it is a very good and enjoyable course to take.  It introduces a variety of artistic topics and manages a half-discussion/half-workshop based class that is very engaging.  And you get to go on a field trip to an art museum.  So there's that.
You have to take it if you;re in it, so take it like you mean it.
descrip: A required seminar for Art and Archaeology Program 2 majors and Program in Visual Arts certificate students emphasizing contemporary art practices and ideas. The course addresses current issues in painting, drawing, sculpture, film, video, photography, and performance installation. It includes a visiting artist lecture series, critiques of students' work, and excursions to galleries, museums and/or artists' studios.

title: Topics in German Film History and Theory - Film Theory
reviews: Be willing to do a lot of your own work and not rely on Professor Levin for a LOT of things. He is willing to help, but you have to take most of the initiative and have a curiosity with the subject matter.
Prof. Levin is one of the best professors on campus. Take a course with him if you can.
Professor Levin is incredible. He has a wealth of information to share with his students and you will not look at film in the same way.
Take any course with Levin.
prereqs: Attendance at weekly Monday night screenings is mandatory..
descrip: What is film? Is it a language? Can one speak of cinematic literacy? Does film transform perception? Is there filmic thinking? This seminar on the theory and poetics of cinema will examine the varieties of ways -- semiotic, psychoanalytic, narratological - that filmmakers, philosophers and critics have analyzed film form, the cinematic experience, the construction of cinematic subjectivity, questions of aesthetic politics and notions of medium specificity.

title: Microeconomic Theory I
reviews: A lot of work and problem sets that aren't actually possible to answer. For example, in the first half of the course, there are some textbook problems that you can't really solve no matter how much time you spend on them. If you want to take this course, just make sure you have the basics, don't waste too much time on the impossible problem sets, and practice speed--that's what the exams come down to.
First year econ students have to, for everyone else I wouldn't really recommend it.
It is a very rigorous course in topics including choice theory, demand theory and game theory, necessary for anyone who is interested in economic theory research.
Make sure to do all the problem sets.
Nothing in particular.

This class is very difficult.  The curve is also not very good, median is somewhere around B-/B I've heard.  The exams are pretty brutal and everyone does well.  The first half of the course with Gul is fun, if you're an undergrad it's basically 310 with some MAT 215.  The second half is Abreu, basically 418 but even harder.  If you're an undergrad take 418 instead, Abreu is much more generous.
To do well on this course, you have to know the material BEFORE you take it.
n/a
descrip: First term of a two-term sequence in microeconomic theory. Topics include consumer and producer theory, choice under uncertainty and an introduction to game theory.

title: Constitutional Law and International Law
descrip: Please see website

title: Laboratory Techniques in Materials Science and Engineering
reviews: I feel like this course is easier if you come from a chemistry background than from a mechanical engineering background as I did, but the tradeoff is that it was a lot more broadening for me! Definitely worth taking, this certificate program is very cool.
LOT OF WORK. A LOT. Make sure to plan your semester accordingly.
Prepare yourself for a lot of BS writing when the problem sets and lab reports come around. Some of them take forever and have seemingly little to do with materials science. The labs are pretty cool.

Take this class if you are into materials techniques and characterization. Be mindful that the class is not homogenous, and assignments for the three parts differ significantly in both scale and level.
Take this to help fulfill the materials certificate, and if you have interest in materials.

The labs in this course were very fun, and I learned a lot about materials science techniques. Although lectures with Arnold and Vyawahare were informative, 3 hours of lecture time in addition to 3 hours of lab time was completely unnecessary. Lab reports and assignments in this class were very tedious and painful. Although they were infrequent (at first), they took a lot of time to complete and were poorly written. I did not gain anything from completing them - they felt like busy work. Furthermore, no work was given back until January! TLDR: labs were very fun but the course was organized poorly and the work is far from fun.
This is a required course.  You will learn a lot of practical material from the labs, but be prepared for mostly review in the lectures.

Though it's true that there is no final, the amount of work involved with the few problem sets does amount to a similar amount of work as other quantitative classes. That means don't procrastinate / work with friends who don't procrastinate if you can. In regards to the course material, it covers a wide breadth of material, from steel properties to electrical devices to food properties; there is likely to be at least one topic you are very interested in.
prereqs: MSE 301 or MAE 324 or CEE 364. Enrollment in this course is restricted with preference given to Certificate candidates. This course is required for students wishing to obtain a Materials Certificate..
descrip: A hands-on introduction to the use of laboratory techniques for processing and characterization in materials science. Structure-property relations will be explored through experiments in mechanical, optical, biological, and electronic properties of materials. The underlying theories and lab techniques will be explained in two weekly lectures covering such topics as electronic and mechanical properties, electron microscopy, electron diffraction and materials processing. The goal of this course if for the student to develop a solid understanding of materials properties and the common techniques used in research, as well as to gain valuable

title: Immigrant America
descrip: This course seeks to expose students to the recent social science literature on contemporary immigration to the United States, its origins, adaptation patterns, and long-term effects on American society. The course will consist of lectures by the instructor combined with class discussion of assigned texts.

title: Chinese Intellectual History
descrip: Methods, sources, and problems of research in history of Chinese thought.

title: Contemporary Art and the Amateur
descrip: Please see website

title: Cellular Biochemistry
reviews: Be prepared

I would advise them to go over their chemistry knowledge before taking the course. I wish someone had said that to me. It was really difficult at times to pick up concepts quickly because I hadn't taken chemistry course since freshman year of college.
It will teach you very important tools that could benefit your research, so I think it would be useful to take.
Read the papers carefully, but not necessarily thoroughly. You don't have to know too many details, but you've got fully understand the underlying principles, mechanisms, and applications.
Take a deep breath, and know that it all comes together at some point.
Take it if you want some more in depth readings in to cell biology and biochemistry topics.
The course is difficult but rewarding in the end. Readings and full comprehension of the readings is important for each class.
n/a
descrip: This course focuses on the molecules and molecular assemblies that underlie cellular structure and function. Topics include protein structure and folding; ligand binding and enzyme catalysis; membranes, ion channels, and translocation; intracellular trafficking; signal transduction and cell-cell communication; and cytoskeleton assembly, regulation, and function. A major goal of the course is to increase proficiency in parsing and critically discussing papers from the primary literature.

title: Roots in 20th-Century France and Germany
reviews: Take a course with Christy Wampole!
Take it!
prereqs: Reading knowledge in French and German is helpful but not necessary. French concentrators and certificate students are required to do the work in French..
descrip: This course traces the problematic theme of rootedness, a metaphor for the genealogical origins of people and their attachment to geographical spaces, in the literature, philosophy, and politics of 20th-century France and Germany. Topics: nationalism and regionalism; word roots (Heidegger's etymologizing metaphysics); Jung and Bachelard on roots and the subconscious; Sartre's abject root and the phenomenologists' efforts to "reground" philosophy; Derrida's negotiation of radicality; the root-to-rhizome shift proposed by Deleuze and Guattari; recent attempts to create a non-anthropocentric philosophy; transplantation and colonization.

title: Empire and Catastrophe
reviews: Definitely take this course.
Prof. Shawcross is great, and the course material was interesting. Not too hard and you can learn a lot if you put effort in!
Take it
Take it if you love history classes, do not want to overwork yourself, and strive to earn a good grade.

You should probably know about medieval history before you take this/have a strong interest in byzantium. Professor Shawcross is great but I don't think a good professor is quite enough to elevate somewhat boring subject matter.
descrip: Catastrophe reveals the fragility of human society. This course examines a series of phenomena--plague, famine, war, revolution, economic depression etc.--in order to reach an understanding of humanity's imaginings of but also resilience to collective crises. We shall look in particular at how political forces such as empire have historically both generated and resisted global disasters. Material dealing with the especially fraught centuries at the transition between the Middle Ages and the Early Modern Period will be set alongside examples drawn from antiquity as well as our own contemporary era.

title: Topics in Early Modern European History - The Origins of the Modern State
reviews: If you are a Europeanist in training, you will benefit greatly from this course.
This course is very worth taking for anyone interested, even tangentially, in early modern Europe!
You will learn a lot about the early modern state and its context.
descrip: This seminar covers major themes in the comparative study of early modern European states. It is intended for history graduate students who prepare for exams and independent research, but also for students in related disciplines. The seminar uses both classical and contemporary historiography to explore fundamental topics in early modern political history such as the nature of court society and absolutism, religion and confessionalization, the military revolution, and rituals and bureaucratic practices.

title: Seminar in Academic Writing
descrip: A seminar designed to examine and cultivate scholarly writing. We will consider examples from the historical and analytical writing about music and related disciplines, including more traditional and more experimental models. Students will critique one another's papers and dissertation chapters, focusing on form, content, methodologies, and analytical strategies, and will have the opportunity to present work in progress. Recommended for post-generals students in both composition and musicology.

title: Drug Discovery in the Genomics Era
reviews: A good 5th class, but guest lecturers (the bulk of the class) can be hit or miss
A laid back science class. You learn a lot while only being required to put in minimal effort.
A very reasonable course--take it only if you have interest in the subject.
Be sure to start the exams early as they can be quite long.
Easy and interesting class
Go to lectures because they're interesting, but not necessary. Midterm easy, work in groups. Overall chill class for senior year.
Good class. Not a lot of work. Wouldn't say I learned very much though.
Great course if you're interested in Pharma/disease. Very chill but worth taking.
Great course to take for a departmental. Easy and interesting
Great easy senior fall class for science majors or pre-meds. Super interesting material, lots of guest lectures, and light workload.
I would recommend this course for those interested in the process of developing drugs. It's really laid back.
Interesting but didn't learn as much as I had hoped

It's almost no work, and it's an interesting view of a very specific field. Honestly, it should be in the SOC department - it's much more about the dynamics of the workplace of a drug company than it is about actual chemistry.
Lots of great guest lectures.

Make sure you understand the concepts in lecture but don't stress about the details. All your tests are open-note, open-Internet. A low-key but interesting course. Good for pre-meds who need an upper-level CHM class.
Relatively simple way to fulfill a requirement, or if you want to develop drugs, but otherwise you won't get much out of it.  Particularly if you don't have a strong CHM background.
So many guest speakers from professional chemists in the pharmaceutical industry. Can't get better than that.
TAKE IT. If you have any interest in pharma, this is THE class.

TAKE THIS. It is one of your only opportunities to hear about the drug discovery process from one of the leaders in the field, not to mention frequent guest lecturers that really help to put the course content into context!

Take it! It's a super chill class and good if you're interested in medicinal chemistry or mildly interested in pharma. The lectures are given by Reider and a lot of people in the pharma industry. You don't necessarily need to go to lectures but there are some good guest lectures here and there. Most of the tips and concept review you need to do the exams will be covered in precept, so those are helpful to go to. The workload is just take home midterm, an oral presentation that isn't even really graded, and a take home final. All open internet, open notes, open anything.
Take it, it's a pretty chill class
Take this class for sure! Go to every single precept, they're super useful.

Take this course if you want a very laid-back overview of the pharmaceutical industry and exposure to numerous case studies presented by guest lecturers.  The course is fairly unorganized and precepts are optional (but fairly helpful), but keep coming to class and you'll be surprised to realize how you you're now recognizing a lot of the main ideas and even specific jargon in the drug development process.  The workload is minimal besides the take-home midterm and final, which are open-resource.  This class is especially great if you're a senior busy traveling for interviews.
Take this course. It's amazing.
This class is rather boring but easy. Don't expect to learn too much, and it's certainly not necessary to attend every lecture.
This course is great if you need a chill class, but still want to learn about cool stuff

This is a good and interesting upper level chemistry class, good for anyone interested in medicine, chemistry, drug development or the pharmaceutical industry. Very relaxed for most of the course, except you are definitely expected to put work into the exams and the landscape project.
This is a good class that combines themes from orgo and GHP, providing a realistic view of the current pharmaceutical landscape.
This is a reasonably interesting course with very little work. It is also an upper level CHM. If that is what you are looking for, take it.
This was a great upper level chem course.
Very interesting and not a lot of work.
Very interesting. Put work into the midterm and final

You should definitely consider taking this course! The workload is not extremely heavy, but the returns of taking this class are very high. You'll learn about engaging topics that are rarely explored in other courses! Definitely take!
You should take it. A great class to really learn a lot.
prereqs: Two semesters of organic chemistry (CHM 301 & 302 OR CHM 303 & 304/304B) or the equivalent..
descrip: A detailed review of recent successes and failures in the discovery of new drugs. Therapeutic areas to be discussed include: HIV, oncology, asthma, Alzheimer's Disease, antibiotics, diabetes, and neglected diseases (malaria, TB, human African Trypaonosomiasis). Case studies presented by leading pharmaceutical scientists will complement discussions of the functional steps required to select a target, indentify a new chemical entity, and get it to patients. The course will emphasize the integration of the molecular sciences and the role of chemistry in inventing and producing important new medicines.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Impact Evaluation Tools
prereqs: WWS 508c.
descrip: This course presents tools for designing, implementing, and analyzing impact evaluations from a practitioner's perspective. It explores real-world problems and practical limitations frequently encountered in conducting evaluations and methodological tools to address them. Topics include program operation rules and their implications for design choice, process and standards for assessing evidence, challenges to randomization, sample size determination, complex sample design, and construction of analytic and non response weights. Students practice addressing these issues through a series of case studies and analytic exercises.

title: Topics in German Literature - Literature and Journalism: On the History of a Creative Relationship
descrip: According to the obvious line of investigation there are clear cut demarcation lines: Journalism is a business while literature is art or journalism is writing short, factual articles about events while literature is all about creating fictitious events. Contrary to these simple truths stands the history of literature: journalism and literature share the same roots and this common ground could explain why so many literary authors have been engaged in journalistic enterprises. The seminar will start with Wieland's Teutscher Merkur and end with Rainald Goetz and his Vanity Fair Blog: Abfall fur alle.

title: Families
reviews: Definitely take this class.
Do not take it. Goldani is an awful lecturer.
Don't take this class.
Take it. One of the most relevant classes you'll take at Princeton.
You have to be interested in the content, because the professor can be hard to follow.
descrip: Selected topics in the sociology of family life including family diversity, gender and household division of labor, demography and history of family life, and the role of the state and social policy.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture I: History, Philosophy, and Religion
prereqs: This course is primarily directed to exceptional freshmen, but sophomores are also welcome to apply. For details, please see the description for HUM 216..
descrip: In combination with HUM 216, this course explores the landmark achievements of European civilization from antiquity to the middle ages. Students must enroll in both 216 and 217, which constitute a double-course. The lecture component for HUM 217 is listed as TBA because all meetings are listed under HUM 216. There are no separate meeting times for HUM 217.

title: Fall Film Seminar
reviews: Do it!

I'm just going to say it flat out here - I loved this course.  This course would've worked in general - a course based off of watching and editing material will always be interesting and engaging - but Alan Oxman's presence in the classroom as a lecturer, an intellectual, and a mentor elevated it to something very special.  In addition to being an excellent seminar leader who raises excellent questions, he also acts as a wonderful mentor for your work - always trying to find ways to improve it while never really putting it down.  He makes you want to hand in good stuff - for a P/D/F class - just because you want him to see you interested and trying to do a good job.  He is a traveling professor and it's not confirmed if he is coming back to teach next year, but if he is, trust me - you want to take this course.
If they are interested in editing, I would strongly recommend it.
If you are a film student, you MUST take this course. Hopefully it will be with Alan again.
If you want to learn this skill set, Prof. Oxman is an invaluable resource, so don't slack off. You might regret it!
prereqs: Open to VIS Certificate/Film Concentrators only AND/OR MUST have taken: VIS 362 or VIS 462. * FOR ENROLLMENT, PLEASE CONTACT PROFESSOR JOE SCANLAN AT: JSCANLAN@PRINCETON.EDU*.
descrip: This class will explore the art of storytelling through the aesthetics of film editing. By focusing on the editing process, students will not only learn how to edit their work but also how to better plan the writing, casting, sound design, and shooting of a film to better serve the editing process. Through screenings of award-winning films, informal class discussions with their directors, and exclusive access to raw scenes and footage, students will learn how to conceptualize the entire film production process as well as be introduced to accomplished professionals in the field.

title: The Sociology of Intellectuals and Ideas
reviews: An excellent introduction to a interesting sub-discipline within sociology. A lot of reading, but questioning the social influences on knowledge production is very interesting.
Probably don't take it, unless you're really interested in this academic discipline.
Read texts strategically--not every word. No close reading is possible with so much reading--learn to pick out important information
descrip: Intellectuals--a group defined in various ways, but consisting at its core of those individuals occupationally specialized in the production of knowledge and ideas--play key parts in modern society. This seminar examines sociological research on intellectuals, with a particular focus on academic intellectuals in the human sciences.

title: Quantitative Methods
reviews: Ask questions early about R in preparation for the PSETs
Best time spent to value of material ratio.
Chill Stats class

DO NOT buy the textbook. It is a complete waste of money and you will survive 110% without it. Lectures are not really worth the time, but it does force you to learn the information. Study directly off the powerpoints, word for word. Ask your preceptor EXACTLY what they want for the homework, or else you'll get points taken off left and right.
Definitely take this class - you get out what you put in. the exam material is fair.
Don't buy the textbook, Professor Conway's lectures tell you everything you need.
Don't take this if you actually want to understand statistics. All you need for this course is to memorize the slides. It's too easy and surface-level... which works for most psychology students...
Don't take unless you have to. Would recommend another stats class
Don't work too hard.
Follow along with the readings and pay attention in lectures.
For a stats class, I recommend it.
I do recommend this course as a good statistics course and way to learn the language R, which is a very important program for statistical analysis.
I would recommend this course to anyone.

I would say take this if you need a QR, because this is a doable class (not easy, but doable) and stats is useful.  Be sure to use McGraw if you need help because the stats tutors are incredibly wonderfully helpful!!
If you are looking for a basic statistics course and do not want to do much actual calculation by hand, this is a great choice.
If you need an easy class, go for it.
It's not bad just pay attention.
It's one of the easier stats classes, and completely doable. Just don't expect a lot of hand-holding.
Just read old notes once every two weeks and you'll be good to go.
Laid-back course; not a lot of outside assignments; exams were mostly memorization-based

Only take it if you have to be a psych major. If you are just looking for an easy QR take soc stats. The professor has tenure so he doesn't care about the class at all. The exams are horribly written and don't represent the material you learn in class or lab. The assignments are just blindly following lab instructions for R, you won't actually learn how to think for yourself and learn how to code in R. Skip lecture and watch Conways coursera classes on youtube instead. He's not a bad guy, he tries to make funny jokes, but he doesn't put any effort into the class.
Only take it to fulfill a distribution, otherwise don't bother.
Probably wouldn't have taken this course if it were not required but it's relatively harmless.
Read over the slideshows to study. Overall a very straightforward class, if you just read the slideshows and make an effort to understand them you'll do well

Reading the textbook isn't necessary, but if you feel like it would help you then you can read. Go to lecture, it really helps you learn the concepts when Andy explains them. Study for exams with the practice exams and the homework assignments, making flashcards from the lectures also helps a lot for tests and weekly quizzes.
Seriously take this class. It's one of the best I've ever taken at Princeton.
Straightforward statistics. Pretty decent fifth class.
Take for prereqs and an introdcution to stats.
Take it if you want to know something about statistics!
Take it. It'll be a requirement and you'll have to, but It's actually a pretty decent class.
Take the course if you need a stats class for a certificate like say, Global Health.

Take this with Professor Andy and Tasha.  They are great and make this class really engaging.  The material is difficult.  The tests are hard.  But if you stay engaged you should have no problem.  The only regret I have is not reaching out to the professor enough.

This class teaches you how to use R, but I don't think it does a very good job teaching the concepts behind any of the stats we were doing. The primary focus was making sure we could all run a proper R script. If you're hoping to learn something about statistics, you'll  probably have to do it on your own. Conway isn't really that good of a teacher.
This course is not hard but still review for exams.  They can be a little tricky.
This course is very straightforward, relaxed, and easy. Take this if you need a QR.

This course was kind of so easy that it was hard. I'm not entirely sure why, but it was just not easy to fully digest what was taught in lecture and to think about it further than the literal definitions presented in class.

This is a good class to take for a QR requirement if you need one.  The concepts aren't particularly tricky, you just need to do some memorization and basic coding in R for the labs.  The exams are fair and the grading system is good.

This is a good stats class to take if you don't have a strong math background. The book supplemented the lectures well, and there is a weekly quiz and homework assignment each week in lab. There were two exams and then a final exam.
Try as hard as you can to stay engaged in the lectures and labs because the textbook is hard to follow.
Try for another statistics course.
Try to pay attention, and ask about R is you have questions.
Very easy course
Very manageable statistics course, especially if you took statistics in high school. Andy is a lively and engaging professor.
easy QR
idk
it's easy but don't slack off too much
really easy. no need to do the reading. take it if you need a QR.
descrip: The purpose of the course is to introduce students to the basic techniques of statistical analysis used in psychological research. Students will learn the logic underlying the statistical techniques and learn how to perform statistical analyses and interpret the results.

title: Topics in Country and Regional Economics - Economics of the European Union and Economies in Europe
reviews: Don't be scared away from taking this class if you're not woodywoo, politics, or econ. It is very approachable if you are willing to take the time to read up on the material and ask the professor/preceptor questions during office hours.

I would recommend this course to students very interested in Europe's economics and policy who like small classes and a blend of assignments (problem sets, essays, and a presentation). It involves a relatively large amount of work but I feel like I've learned quite a lot and have an educated view about interesting issues.
The professor's slides can be boring as she tends to go off them very closely. Ask to mine her extensive knowledge on Europe.

This course is very informative and delves into interesting economic issues through policy evaluation, models and some mathematics. It takes a lot of work and the lectures are quite fast-paced, but Professor Weyerbrock is a great instructor who will definitely push you to develop a nuanced understanding of the EU.
prereqs: ECO 100, ECO 101.
descrip: This course studies the economies of current and prospective European Union (EU) members and economic integration in Europe after 1945. It explores the political motivation for, and the economic implications of, the European Union's moves towards ever deeper integration and enlargement. Topics include policy-making in the EU, adoption of common trade, agricultural, regional and competition policy as well as European Monetary Union and its implications for fiscal and labor market policies. The course focuses on current economic challenges and uses economic analysis to study policy issues.

title: French Theater Workshop
reviews: Be very engaged in class.
Before enrolling, do realize that this course is primarily a theater course, albeit one taught in French. That being said, it's a ton of fun. I was glad I did it to broaden my horizons so to speak.
Do it! Florent is so fun! You will want to take more theater classes! You learn a ton about French theater.
Don't miss the chance to take a class with Florent!
Florent Masse is a legend. Workload is fun, you'll practice your french, you'll meet cool people. There's no reason not to take this course-no reason.
I would say to absolutely take it; it is an amazing class. I would also say to enjoy it and have fun and learn something every class, because it goes by too quickly.

If you want to study the subjunctive, this is not the class for you. You will not take a single test. If you don't take the initiative to speak, you won't get much practice formulating your own sentences, either. If you struggle with memorization, you will not be happy.

If you love theatre and French culture, or maybe always wanted to try acting and have a background in the language, take this class. The weekly workload is not strenuous, but you will grow immensely over the course of the semester.
Its a fun class that isn't a ton of work! Know that you won't be speaking in class as much as other classes but the studios are fun and doing a final performance is rewarding.
Lots of fun. Not very hard courseload. Take it!

Such a fun class! Professor Masse is probably the most enthusiastic, passionate professor possible, and my pronunciation improved enormously! However, if you wish to improve grammar/writing, it is not the class for you. The primary focus is on theater.

TAKE the course! You will learn many acting techniques from a true professional, you will learn to pronunciation your French better even if you think you already pronounce well, and you will have fun! To make the most of this course, make sure you do the readings, go to the Seuls en Scene Festival, and participate in class!

Take it!
It can be a little daunting at times but Masse runs a really fun class with a light and supportive atmosphere.  The final performance was really scary for me though as I am not a theater person in general!

This course will improve significantly your pronunciation. Whether you already like theater or not, this course will certainly pique an interest if not fire it up. However, beware those who don't enjoy reading theater; a whole semester of it may get wearisome at times.
Try your best to fall in love with your scene, it is very difficult to really improve throughout the course if you don't
take this if you love french!
prereqs: FRE 108, or equivalent. FRE 207 recommended as a co-requisite. Course is conducted entirely in French. Interested students must contact the instructor: fmasse@Princeton.EDU to apply and schedule an interview. Course is open to Freshmen..
descrip: L'Avant-Scene will offer students the opportunity to put their language skills in motion by discovering French theater in general and by acting in French, in particular. The course will introduce students to acting techniques while allowing them to discover the richness of the French dramatic canon. Particular emphasis will be placed on improving students' oral skills through pronunciation and diction exercises. At the end of the semester, the course will culminate in the performance of the students' work.

title: Negotiation, Persuasion and Social Influence: Theory and Practice
descrip: Examines the principles of negotiation in organizational settings and provides firsthand experience in simulated negotiations. Theoretical and empirical research on the variables that affect success in negotiations is discussed. Students engage in a series of bargaining exercises between individuals and teams, and results are analyzed in detail by the class.

title: Linear Algebra with Applications
reviews: A very reasonable math class.
Absolutely avoid this course if you possibly can. The material is confusing and the exams are designed to make you feel like you know nothing.
Ask for the professor to explain all the proofs and logical implications between major concepts. Don't be complacent!
Be prepared for a struggle, but you'll be ok.

Be sure to attend precepts. When it comes to math, most people hear that it isn't necessary to go to precepts because all you're expected to do is hand in your problem sets the day that they're due and to take all required quizzes and examinations. However, precepts are very helpful in terms of getting extra practice and reiterating necessary formulas. It also forces you to do math every other day for a good hour, which you otherwise may not be doing if you skip class.

Be sure to take thorough notes and to read the textbook before each problem sets. It is also helpful to start the problem sets early so you have enough time to complete them in a relaxed manner and take advantage of office hours.
Class is structured similarly to 201, but I found the material to be more interesting.

Congrats, you've made it through Princeton introductory calculus. Your reward is a semester on a topic that sounds like you took it in the seventh grade. Don't be fooled, it's much more difficult than that. It's easier than 201, but that doesn't mean that you can slack off. Zsolt is good, and so is Andy Manion.
Definitely take it, I personally thought it was pretty interesting.
Do not fall behind, and try to think of all the exceptions that might occur for a theorem that is presented.
Do the assignments even if you don't need to (you're allowed to drop your two lowest assignments)! And previewing the chapters before class really really helps.
Don't fall behind.
Don't take this course unless you have to
Easier than some math classes here and very useful
Focus on understanding the material as opposed to churning out answers
Get Andy Manion as your teacher. If you have genuine interest in math, rather than just fulfilling a requirement, consider a course directed more towards math students than engineers econ major etc.
Good class - go to office hours, make use of the practice quizzes and exams posted online.

I don't have many positive or negative things to say about the class. It's challenging if you're not too comfortable with math and logical thinking. The best advice I can offer is to go to office hours and ask questions that can better improve the way you think about linear algebra, especially about concepts rather than just asking about problems.

I took this out of general interest after having taken MAT 104 and skipped MAT 201. (You don't need 201.) In general, I think the material is harder to master than in 104, but still manageable, maybe taking about 10-15 hours a week to digest and apply in psets. The majority of the work comes in the first half of the semester, when you have to wrap your head around abstract concepts that the rest of the course then just builds upon. Although I needed extensive help from online videos, a tutor, McGraw study hall, friends in the class and my professor to get through the course, I'm glad I took it because I think it helps you think in new ways. Take it with Zsolt.
I would encourage students to keep up with the work. It is a fast paced class and accelerates after the midterm
I would only recommend this course if an individual must or has an extreme interest in math.
I would recommend it. Good for understanding a wide variety of concepts.
I would recommend taking the course. It is well taught and fair.
I would recommend this class to anyone who wants to do college level math that doesn't involve calculus. The class is very organized and the material is interesting and not too hard to follow.
I would take this, even if 201 was hard for you. It sure was for me, but I found myself doing well in 202. If you put in the work, it is a great class.
If considering simply out of general interest and not a requirement, then perhaps not the best idea.
If you are comfortable with the textbook and aren't learning too much from lecture, consider skipping lecture and spending twice the amount of time on the text book.
If you can get Zsolt as your teacher, do. Very straightforward and funny. The material is also quite interesting and the exams were very fair. Very manageable workload.
If you're considering taking it, it's probably because you have to. Do the problems sets and works lots of quiz problems. Honestly, I found the material interesting, but the tests killed me.
If you're considering this class, it's probably a pre-req for you and you have to take it. I wouldn't take it otherwise, even if you felt like you enjoyed math in high school.
If you're going into a quantitative field, you should take some level of linear algebra.
If you're taking this course its probably because you have to. Approach like any other math course
It's much better than 201 - if you can avoid taking 201 and go straight to this, do it.
Its MAT 202. Take it if you need it. Dont if you dont
Like any other math course, do a lot of problems! If you don't understand a p-set problem, consult with your classmates or professor because that material isn't going to go away.

Like cough medicine, unpleasant but not unbearable. Matrices are quite clever and useful abstractions. Zsolt is a fine teacher, psets are tedious but necessary, textbook is a friend if going to class is unappealing.
Linear is a good thing to know. Take it.
Make sure to focus, linear can be tricky
Make sure to use your office hours! Understand the basics in the first few chapters, and it will pay off when you learn more complicated concepts.
Make sure you stay on top of your work, because each concept builds upon an earlier concept.
Only take if required.
Only take it if necessary
Pay lots of attention during lecture and make sure you are constantly on top of your material.
Prepare well in advance! Do you homework yourself and keep up with the class. Practice as many exams as you can and go to office hours to clarify doubts.
Read the textbook and go to office hours/McGraw.
Read the textbook before class and DON'T FALL BEHIND.
Read the textbook.
Switch classes until you find a good teacher, go to office hours
Take it if you have to!
Take it if you have to. It's easy enough to do okay in this class but difficult to do really well
Take it if you like cos or math or if you need to.
Take only if you have to, and pick your instructor carefully.
Take the course and enjoy it.
Take this class to learn about matrix algebra.

Take this class with Andy (except you probably can't since he's leaving after next semester)!  Go to office hours and ask all your questions (you won't look dumb!), Andy (and I'm sure other preceptors) are really dedicated to making sure you learn in this course.  There is a lot of material, so make sure you actually do the readings, watch the Banner videos online, go to lecture, and try to understand concepts, whether before or after you've completed the p-sets (EARLY ideally).  An awesome course - felt proud to have learned a lot and enjoyed it!
Take this class! Linear algebra is so much more fun than literally any other math class.
Take this course if you need an understanding of the tools of linear algebra.

Take this course if you need to / if you're interested in it. It probably won't be the most fun course you've ever taken at Princeton, but it is completely manageable and teaches you useful / interesting stuff.
The course is difficult, but Patakfalvi is a great teacher and the class is very do-able.
The course is very cumulative, make sure you don't fall behind. It should be a manageable course.

The course is very manageable so long as you keep up with the problem sets and readings. If you want a more abstract and conceptual understanding of linear algebra, I would recommend taking MAT204 or MAT217 instead. However, if you are just looking to learn the operations of basic linear algebra, this class does the job fine.
The first half of the semester is harder than the second half.
There is basically no curve on the test so do not assume that if you can get what is normally a good grade on the practice tests that you are ok for the final or midterm.
There's not much to say. If you have to take it, take it. If you don't, don't.

This class was a lot better than I expected it to be! You're probably taking this because you have to, but the material is pretty interesting and probably different from most of the stuff you've done until now.

This course is a prerequisite for BSE, and recommended for most science majors, so you probably don't have much of a choice in taking it. I recommend preparing for the class before it begins by learning Gauss-Jordan elimination to reduce a matrix to RREF form. Just sit down with a textbook or something, and reduce matrices until it becomes easy, and you make absolutely no mistakes in running the algorithm. I recommend this because the three operations of Gauss-Jordan elimination forms the basis for almost all computations in linear algebra, and the class has a lot of theory in it, so it's advisable to get learning the computational steps and perfecting it, so that you get it out of the way and are all the more ready to learn the theory behind linear algebra before you take the course.
This is a very challenging course - start all the homework well ahead of time, and chip away at them slowly.
This was a well-taught course that gave students a solid base in linear algebra.
Way easier than 201 if you keep up with it. go ask preceptor about concepts you dont get right away because concepts build on each other

Well-structured class. It follows the textbook quite nicely which makes it easy to read ahead or review concepts you didn?t understand in lectures. Find a lecturer you like, but make sure to go to review sessions by others to see if you can get a different perspective/approach. Try to understand the concepts, above all, because knowing how to do the problems without understanding what they mean won?t be very beneficial and won?t do much good on exam questions.

You have to take this course. Do not go to any of the classes, because they are useless. The instructors have no idea how to convey an intuitive understanding of the material, which is further hindered by a significant language barrier. Watch the MIT OpenCourseware videos (18.06 taught by Gilbert Strang) instead.
eh
make sure you keep up to pace with the material, as it builds up. Take lots of practice tests before the exams, they're the key to success
only take if you have to and watch adrian banner online
prereqs: MAT104 equivalent..
descrip: Companion course to MAT201. Matrices, linear transformations, linear independence and dimension, bases and coordinates, determinants, orthogonal projection, least squares, eigenvectors and their applications to quadratic forms and dynamical systems.

title: Third-Year Modern Chinese I
reviews: A definite step up second year chinese
A lot more work than previous years.
A lot of work.
Be prepared to put work into it every week. It's a lot of work, but you learn so much! And the teachers are all really great.
Be prepared to work hard! It's not too difficult, but there is a lot of work to do in order to be successful.
Beauty!
CHI 303 is a pretty heavy workload- do not let the workload stop you from taking the class, however. You will learn a lot of useful formal vocabulary.
Chinese is a bunch of work, but it's worth it.  There are a few things that seem unnecessary, but overall the class is great.
Enroll in a class section with the fewest people.
Expect to spend a lot of time.
If you love Mandarin, it's incredible.
If you're interested in the language, 100% take this course.

It's a lot of work (more work than CHI 105/107--I'd say it's about 10-30% more work) but also rewarding. The increase in workload is necessary to continue increasing the language skill. The classes are very entertaining, and the debates are especially fun--we all dreaded the first debate before it happened, but then we found it wasn't as stressful as we imagined. There's continuity from previous courses in the Chinese department, and it's well-organized.
Make sure you stay on top of the work, don't let it pile up until last minute.
Recommend if you want to learn more grammar and vocab, but be prepared to do a lot of rote memorization. It's also not a light workload.
Take it!
sfd
prereqs: CHI 107 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Designed to further develop the student's overall language skills through reading and discussion of contemporary affairs published in Chinese newspapers.

title: Labor Economics/Industrial Relations Seminar
reviews: Take it if it's your field.
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: American Mysticism
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: History of New Orleans: Invention & Reinvention in an American City
reviews: Any student should try to take at least one course with Prof. Guild while they are at Princeton
I would encourage students to read each other's blog posts more. They were surprisingly helpful and enlightening, which is usually not the case.
I'd say take it if you're interested, but be prepared to read A LOT!

Prof. Guild clearly knows a lot about New Orleans and it shows through in this course. The workload is a bit strange and very back-heavy (loaded on Dean's Date). The seminars were alright, but ultimately I learned a lot. I think the course will be better taught/better run in its second year - there were a lot of kinks this year that can be ironed out. If there are seminars that get glowing reviews, I might choose them over this one, but if you are traveling to New Orleans, planning on spending time there, etc. this class provides invaluable augmentation to one's experience of the city, giving a deeper layer of meaning to experiences there. Overall, the course was okay. In the end, I'm glad I took it, but it frustrated me throughout the semester - mostly because of the work distribution (and therefore grading distribution), the slow pace of the seminar time itself, and the lack of a directly cohesive narrative that we were exploring. From what I've heard, Guild is great in lectures - perhaps consider that instead? You can't necessarily go wrong with this class, but do consider other options. (Unless this becomes a travel class - then do it hands-down).
Take any class with Professor Guild.
Take it.
Take this course!
Yes, I think it will keep getting better with each year, and NOLA is a great lens through which to examine America.
descrip: Explores the 300-year history of what has been described as an "impossible but inevitable city." Settled on perpetually eroding swampland at the foot of one of the world's great waterways, this port city served as an outpost of three empires and a gateway linking the N. American heartland with the Gulf Coast, Caribbean, and Atlantic World. A unique crossroads of capitalism and cultures, New Orleans is, as one writer puts it, "an alternative American history all in itself." From European and African settlement through Hurricane Katrina, we'll consider how race, culture, and the environment have defined the history of the city and its people.

title: Religion in the United States
descrip: The United States is both one of the most 'modern' and most religious countries in the world. What explains this apparent paradox? What differentiates the myriad of religious groups in the US? Why are stances on sex and gender so fundamental to this differentiation? This course will examine these questions in relation to current theories in the sociology of religion as students gain in-depth knowledge about one denomination through original empirical research.

title: Intensive Third-Year Modern Chinese I
reviews: A lot of work.
As with any class, keeping up with the work throughout the course, ie. taking time to understand lesson, vocab, and grammar structures, will make the class a lot more worth it.
Be ready to put in the time, but very rewarding with great teachers
CHI 305 is really fun, especially if you have an interest in contemporary social issues in China. Your written and spoken Chinese will improve immensely.
Focus on learning how to use grammar structures instead of memorizing vocab or memorizing how to write characters.
It's a good course. Prepare for your weekly quizzes.

It's fantastic! You definitely should take it. Zhen laoshi is the best! It's not as much work as people make it out to be--at least, not as much work as most engineering classes I've taken. But it's definitely one of the most enjoyable classes I've taken at Princeton. The discussions are interesting and the material is very relevant to contemporary society.

Keep up with the readings. Go to class - if you miss your section, go to another section. Study vocab every day, or at least several days before the weekly quiz. Think outside the box for presentations and discussions.
Lot of work but great experience.
Stay on top of your work!
Study for the weekly quizzes!

Take this course if you want to improve, if you want to be forced to improve. You have to be prepared to work hard. I practiced writing characters and grammar patterns every day and spent hours working on my own study guides every week. This is a great course if you are prepared to work very, very hard just to get in the B /A- range (without curve).
Work hard, and it pays off.
prereqs: CHI 103, 108, or instructors' permission..
descrip: Designed for students who are interested in current political and social issues in Chinese affairs. Reading materials will be selected from newspapers of the People's Republic of China.

title: Pro Seminar: Computation, Energy, Technology in Architecture
descrip: The pro seminar is offered to incoming PhD students in the PhD track in Computation, Energy, building Technology in the School of Architecture (open to other interested graduate students as well) and is organized as a research seminar to introduce the participants to scientific research methods in the context of design in Architecture and science in engineering. It is structured as a series of introductory presentations of exemplary methods based on case studies and a number of guest presentations from collaborating disciplines.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Surveys, Polls and Public Policy
descrip: Course aims to improve students' abilities to understand and critically evaluate public opinion polls and surveys, particularly as they are used to influence public policy. Course begins with an overview of contrasting perspectives on the role of public opinion in politics, then examines the evolution of public opinion polling in the US and other countries. Class visits a major polling operation to get a firsthand look at procedures used for designing representative samples and conducting surveys by telephone, mail and Internet.

title: Architecture and the American College Campus
descrip: Please see website

title: Play, Leisure, and Sociability
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: General Chemistry I
reviews:
1.) Be prepared to teach yourself most of the material
2.) Lectures are not helpful so if you miss one or two, it's not a travesty.
3.) McGraw individual tutoring is a useful tool if you are having difficulty understanding some of the concepts. Do not go to the McGraw group studying because the tutors there do not help you.
ATTEND THE PRECEPTS
As long as you work hard and always understand the week's lectures before moving on, this course shouldn't be too hard. Reviewing some chemistry before taking this course would definitely help!
Attend lecture and take notes because certain concepts and derivations from lecture will be on the exams.
Be willing to work a lot outside of class to make up for the disconnect between how material is taught and how we, as students, actually understand.

CHM 201 is the intro chem course. It is recommended that BSE pursuers take CHM 207 for more relevant material. If you've taken any chemistry in high school, this course does teach a few things you may have never learned about, such as the basics of thermdodynamics, gases theory, and quite some detail about quantum mechanics and bonding theory. If you've taken AP Chem and understand what you've learned, you should take the Honors CHM course. Really, there is no reason to take CHM 201 unless it is a requirement.
Come prepared to give this course a lot of time outside of class and make sure you attend every lecture.
Definitely pay attention in lectures and be carful on lab procedures and calculations, you need to be precise on the lab practical exam.
Definitely take this class. You will end up loving chemistry!
Do it. It's pretty cool and some of the demos are exciting (the ones with the petri dishes, not so much).

Do not only the problem sets, but several problems from each chapter. The only way to approach the problems on the exams is to practice a lot beforehand, and if you only review material without applying it to problems, you will be stumped on the exams. Seek help from preceptors--they have office hours as well, and are very helpful.
Do not take this course. Unless you have to. In which case, try not to have to.

Do not take this for fun or without chemistry experience if you can help it.  Not having that experience will put you at a severe disadvantage to the pre-meds and engineers for whom this is a requirement.  If you have a strong chemistry foundation then it should be a breeze.
Do the problem sets. Use them as an opportunity to learn the material. DO THE READINGS.
Do the reading ahead of time and make your own notes. Pay attention to how formulas were derived.

Do your homework and make sure you understand how to work out each problem on your own, even when the homework is returned. It is usually the difficult homework questions that end up on the midterm/final exam. Attend lecture! There are things (like formula derivations) that will be discussed in class that won't be in your textbook. Read the chapter summaries of your book (no need to read the entire chapter) and do not leave homework until the night before! Also, do your best on your lab reports because they will help you tremendously when it comes to taking the written practical exam.
Do your homework and study. If you can, do all the readings because they really do help, unless you're a chemistry genius or something.
Don't expect much out of lectures, be prepared to learn almost everything from your textbook so read it! It is very doable if you do this though, be confident and tests will go fine.
Don't force yourself to take this class just because of a requirement.

Don't leave problem sets to the last minute. Go to the resource center in Frick whenever you need help understanding a chapter, problem set, or past exam. Take brief notes on each chapter and study your notes regularly. Always read the lab manual so that you're prepared for each experiment.
Don't suck at chem
Don't take course for fun, take it only if needed as a requirement. A fair amount of work needed to be put into it.
Don't take it if you're not a science person
Don't take it just out of general interest.
Don't take with Chan and L'Esperance if you can avoid it.
GO TO PRECEPT. READ THE BOOK. These two things alone will prove to be the most useful ways to do well in this course.
Go to lecture its worth it
Go to office hours, badger your TA with questions, and make sure you really understand the material.
Good class for a requirement.
Hit up McGraw and do practice problems!

I only took one year of real chemistry in high school, as opposed to many students who took 2. I would still recommend this class to them. If you have only taken 1 year, and you enjoyed the class, take this course. If you do not enjoy sciences and are looking for a STL, you can pass on this course. This course requires dedication and a love for chemistry.
I recommend this course. But some of the preceptors are pretty bad.

I strongly recommend attending classes even though many people are inclined to skip them. Also, really prepare for your lab so you can work efficiently even if it may be your first time in a lab. Maintain a close relationship with your textbook and utilize the online component when preparing for exams. Pay attention in lecture because specific items will appear on exams.

I suggest forming a study group with people. If I had not done so I would have had a lot more trouble understanding the material. Also, make sure you understand the concepts behind the problems presented because Professor Garnett loves asking about the conceptual side of chemistry.

I thought I didn't like chem because I had a bad teacher in high school. But this class is pretty interesting. Chan is very smart and also enthusiastic. If you ask him a question after class he is eager to explain it and you can see how invested he is in it.
Honestly, most people take this for a requirement, so there isn't much of a choice. But it is definitely bearable and manageable. Come in with a positive attitude and it'll be good.

I would advise that a student stay on top of the work, and to read the assigned readers prior to lecture. Professor Chan gets very specific in lecture, so it is nice to have a general understanding of the material before you attend it. Overall, the teaching assistants  are extremely helpful and very easy to approach, so do not hesitate to ask them a question if you do not understand something.
I would advise them to read the textbook carefully and to make sure they get a good preceptor.
I would keep up with the readings so that you can follow and understand the lectures better. Do not wait to do the problem sets. Attend review sessions before exams.
I would probably advise going in for office hours for someone who wanted to get more out of lecture than I did.
I would recommend doing the readings before every lecture to help with your understanding.

I would recommend that you do all of the readings before going to lecture and that if the book confuses you, know that there are always other general chemistry books on course reserve at Lewis Library that sometimes explain certain topics better than others. Utilize the resources if you need them. Practice enough, and the class will go fine.
I would suggest doing the problem sets early and making chapter notes prior to the lectures
I would tell that student to follow the lecture material by reading the book chapters that correspond with the material.
I would tell them that they must always abide by the lab rules and always come prepared to lab.
I would tell them to definitely read the book, go to office hours, and UTILIZE THEIR PRECEPTORS.

I would tell them to pay attention in lecture and to really focus on the concepts of each topic. Conceptual understanding is important in passing the class. It is also important to truly understand the material as it is being taught. This will make studying for exams and doing problem sets a lot easier.
I'd take this class if you need a refresher in GenChem topics, and if Chan is still teaching, just remember that he is a theoretical-type researcher and his lectures can tend that way also.
If it's just a distribution requirement, it is as you would expect; challenging in some instances, but manageable.
If you can test out with IB or AP credit, you don't need the course--it'll be so much work for no reason. Otherwise, I think it's a worthwhile class to take (aka a bearable pre-med requisite).
If you did well in chemistry in high school this class won't be very hard.  Garnet's lectures can be great though and the demo's are often interesting.

If you don't have to take this course, I wouldn't recommend taking it. It's okay at first, but the amount of work builds up towards the end as the material gets less interesting and more complicated. At least this year, the syllabus was abandoned and people had no clue what was going on for part of the year. A good amount of busywork.
If you want to take the class you must be willing to put in the work.
It is a requirement, just deal with it if you don't like chemistry.
It is an okay class, not too bad.

It is exactly what you think it is, a general chemistry class. Make sure you try and get a good preceptor though. There are definitely some that are better and more helpful than others! And take advantage of McGraw hours!
It isn't too bad. Try to place out if you can, but If not, you will still learn more than you did in high school.
It's a great introduction to chemistry. It really is.
It's a time-consuming course but isn't particularly difficult. The lectures were well-done and directly applicable to the exams.
Just make sure to do your reading and be proactive about the course and you'll do well. Lab is well.
Keep doing practice problems. The more you do, the more variety you encounter, and the more prepared you are.
Keep up with readings.

Make sure to read the book carefully and before you go to lecture. Take note of the key formulas, and understand what they represent and how they are derived. Also, a student who has never take chemistry would, in my opinion, struggle a fair amount in this class. You must know the basic concepts because they will not slow down to explain them to you.
Make sure to take good notes and pay attention during lecture and do not be afraid to ask for help.
Make sure you attend lecture.
Make sure you have the time commitment ready, especially when it comes to studying for exams.
Make sure you read each text book chapter after lecture.
Make sure you read the book before class to make the classes make more sense.
Most people who take this course are required to do so, but I think the class was made to be as informative yet enjoyable as possible. I recommend it.
Only take this course if it's a requirement for your major or if you have a deep passion for chemistry.
Pay attention in class.
Pay attention in lecture and do the problem sets and you'll be just fine. Go see Professor Chan in office hours because he seems really cool!
Pay attention in lecture.
Professor Chan is a luminary and incredibly interesting to listen to-- his understanding of chemistry (especially from the theoretical perspective) was not what I'd expected and was very interesting.
Psets are fairly easy, lecturers cover the basics pretty well but are not very interesting, and the exams were pretty hard.
Read ahead of lectures otherwise it will be extremely hard to follow.
Read before class and do not  expect to learn everything you need in class. Do independent studying. Find students good in chemistry to help you!
Read sections before lectures and take your own notes first.
Read the textbook and use it to help with confusing lecture notes.
Read the textbook because it will be hard to get everything you need from lecture.
Read the textbook chapter soon before or soon after lecture and start your pset early.
Read your textbook!
Review early
Skim the text and take brief notes before lecture and precept! Go to office hours!
Spend a lot of time studying and really sifting through the material.
Start the problem sets early, and attend all the lectures.
Stay ahead on the readings.
Students should definitely read all of the chapters and do a lot of practice problems in addition to all of the problem sets.
Study and then study some more. Always attend lecture.
Study in advance of the midterms, and do many practice problems.
Study what the professor says to study for the midterm!
Take it if you have to, but if RPL isn't lecturing, you may as well not go to lectures. Just read the book or YouTube it.
Take it only if you have to .
Take it. Get Michelle Hofman as your preceptor!!!!! She is the best.

Take the course if you have to, but if you don't have to take it, choose a different course over this. I would not recommend taking this just for fun because it is pretty dry by its nature. If you are taking it, try to get a preceptor that is clear and answers questions.
Take this class if you need the pre-req. Work hard, it is just chemistry.
Take this course if you enjoy chemistry and want to learn the fundamentals
Take this course only if you absolutely have to, and be prepared to do your own heavy lifting. Go to lectures if you want to, but they are not much use.

The most helpful thing for me was one on one tutoring in Mcgraw. Also the professors were really available to me in giving me extra help and going over things I was confused about so definitely email them for a meeting.
The textbook is your bible. Understand the concepts and you'll be fine. I often found the textbook more useful than lecture.

This class is a lot of work.  I took it because I'm premed but I'm more of a bio person than chem/physics/math.  However, it's definitely manageable.  Just plan your schedule accordingly if you're worried about workload, especially if you're a freshman.
This class was great. The professors are amazing, the lectures were great and I learned a lot.
This course requires a lot of outside studying and work, but if chemistry is an area of science you enjoy, then it is definitely recommended.
This is a good class even if you're not taking it as a distribution requirement! I recommend.
Work hard.
You absolutely have to study and take full advantage of the resources at hand in order to do well in the class.
You have to take it for the engineering program, and these professors and TAs are not bad.
always read the textbook!
n/a
only take if you have to, a lot of work
unless required do not take this course.
descrip: CHM 201 (Fall) and CHM 202 (Spring) comprise an overview of Chemistry. This sequence serves as the entry level course for concentrators in Chemistry, and for other sciences requiring General Chemistry as a prerequisite. This sequence is also well suited for premedical students. The goal of General Chemistry is to enhance our understanding of our surroundings through a study of matter at the molecular scale. Topics in CHM 201 include chemical reactions, equilibrium, energy and entropy, quantum theory, atomic structure, and chemical bonding.

title: Modern Childhood
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: 20th Century Poetry: Politics, War, Love and Religion
descrip: Please see website

title: Stochastic Analysis Seminar
descrip: Recent developments in the theory and applications of the analysis of random processes and random fields. Applications include financial engineering, transport by stochastic flows, and statistical imaging.

title: Territory and Group Conflict in International Relations
descrip: This course explores the role that territory plays in a variety of contexts in international relations. Although territory has been shown to be empirically central to the majority of violent disputes, explanations for why this is the case lag behind the evidence. Students analyze and compare the role territory plays in international conflict, the settlement of disputes, international trade, the effectiveness of treaties, civil wars, the settlement of civil wars, third-party intervention in civil wars, and rebel groups' choice of terrorism or insurgency in civil conflict.

title: Immune Systems: From Molecules to Populations
reviews: 8:30 am classes were tough but Professor Graham is an excellent lecturer and there's always a break at the halfway point--strongly recommend
Andrea Graham is awesome. Take this class if you have any interest in the subject and it will put you over the edge.
Definitely go to lecture! They're great :)
Definitely take it if you are interested!  Professor Graham is awesome and the course is really interesting and fun.
Go to every lecture. They are very interesting and really, really useful for the exam.
Go to lecture. They're well taught.
Great class. Granola bars so don't worry about the early time. Good connections with EEB and MOL.
I loved Prof Graham's lectures, but if you can't concentrate at 8.30 am, you still won't be able to :(

I recommend this unique course for its cross-scale approach and balance of specific content with bigger themes.  Accordingly, I feel like I will be able to take more away from this class than many other biology courses that just focus on details.  Professor Graham is fantastic--smart, articulate, and accessible--and the 8:30am lectures are among the most engaging and easy-to-follow that I've had at Princeton.  As a non-EEB major, I felt like I learned a satisfying amount about evolutionary biology.  The workload was fair, with two small creative papers, a term paper, and a midterm and final (both un-timed take-home, open-note).

I would highly recommend this course especially if you're not really interested in learned all the specific molecular mechanisms and structures of each molecule. You will instead learn how immunology is integrated on an evolutionary standpoint, which is a very different and new perspective worth exploring.
I would take this course if you are a MOL major or an  EEB major with a strong molecular biology understanding.

I'd definitely recommend taking it. Try to make it to lecture if at all possible. They're worth the 8:30 time slot. Beware that the assignments can be slightly confusing and the grading can be very nit-picky.
If you are a MOL major it would probably be one of the easier courses to take. Other than that I wouldn't recommend it unless they move it from the 8:30 time slot or make it possible to pdf.

If you can get up really early (if it will still be offered early), have a true interest in immunology, like interesting writing assignments, and can tolerate superfluous and/or difficult readings, then take it. If none of the above apply, then please reconsider taking it. It should be noted that I have found all of the EEB classes I've taken to be extremely annoying/distressing so if you don't have negative feelings towards classes in the department, then take my advice and comments with a grain of salt.
If you can wake up for it, this is a fantastic course. Changed the way that I look at disease, evolution, and health.

If you prefer to learn about the immune system on a more holistic level, take this course! The class is more writing based compared to pure memorization and testing (so often required of MOL courses), which can help to balance your schedule if you are taking several purely MOL courses.

One of my favorite courses at Princeton. Did a great job integrating molecular mechanisms with an evolutionary perspective. Workload is manageable and grading is fair. Yes, lectures are at 8:30 am, but Prof. Graham gives granola bars and is one of the best professors I've had.

Really great class! Definitely take it if you're at all interested in immune systems. Although its primary listing is EEB, it does focus a lot on the molecular levels of things (no need for prior knowledge). Professor Graham is a great lecturer with a fantastic sense of humor. And yes, she does provide granola bars for every single lecture. Definitely worth getting up at 8:30 for it. Favorite class this semester!
Really interesting but it is at 8:30am.
Super interesting course and Andrea is awesome! Worth the 8:30 time.
TAKE IT! This has to be my favorite course I have taken at Princeton. EEB 327 teaches you immunology in the most effective and interesting way! The assignments are really fun!
Take it! Andrea is awesome, the lectures are super interesting, and you will get granola bars EVERY LECTURE!
Take it! very interesting and worth the 8:30 start time
Take the assignments seriously. Meet with your preceptors for the term paper - they'll have good guidance and it constitutes a good amount of your grade.
Take the course.
The lectures and readings are very interesting, but the assignments can be difficult to try to integrate all the different scales. Worth it, though; Professor Graham is excellent!
This course is truly excellent for anyone looking for either a basic knowledge of immunology or an introduction to the field.

This is a really engaging course. Take this especially if you're MOL because it helps broaden your EEB knowledge and still pulls in the MOL side. Andrea made 8:30 AM lecture worth it! I never even felt sleepy in this class regardless of the number of hours I had slept. She's that clear and engaging! Do take!

This is a very good course for anyone interested in evolutionary biology, immunology, or drawing connections between different fields of biology. Go to lectures - they're early, but they're worth it. This class isn't a ton of work, but get started on your term paper early so you can get feedback about whether you're taking it in the right direction.
This is what EEB is about, and one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. Take it if you won't fall asleep at 8:30.
