Very early in the morning, lectures had repeated information or did not seem to make sense until the end. Very MOL focused and required looking up alot of molecules... shouldn't be cross listed as an EEB course
prereqs: EEB 211 and MOL 214..
descrip: How do immune systems work, and why do they work as they do? Why is there so much immunological polymorphism in animal populations? To address these questions, students will examine immunology across multiple biological scales. At the molecular and cellular scales, students will learn mechanisms by which animals recognize and kill parasites. At the population scale, students will investigate causes of the tremendous immunological heterogeneity exhibited by animals. Both the clinical relevance and the evolutionary basis of polymorphisms will be emphasized.

title: Introduction to Entrepreneurship
reviews: A great survey course for any student with an interest in entrepreneurship, business, or changing the world. Fun to take with friends.

Definitely take it! It exposes you to many of the initial topics surrounding entrepreneurship and is a great way to get a taste of entrepreneurship if you've been wanting to know what it's about or have wanted to explore it further.
Definitely take this class. Try to take it when all four professors (especially Professors Danner and Zschau) are teaching it.
Definitely take this course- Not to be missed. Great, engaging professors and interesting material. If you are thinking of business school  down the road, take this as a great intro!
Definitely worth taking.

Do NOT take this course unless they make major improvements to it next year. It seemed organized at first but it quickly became evident that the Profs. were making it up as they went along (e.g. they changed the format of the midterm the week before). Strongly recommend against it.

Do all the reading. 
Attend lectures.
Be on time.
Read around the courses and keep up to date with entrepreneurial opportunities around you and relate them to the course.
Be prepared to make this course a full-time concern and pleasure.

Go to every lecture! They're incredible lecturers and often bring in guest speakers. Readings are really interesting, too -- it doesn't feel like significant work to read. Take notes on the reading, though, because professors ask questions in class.
Harsh grading at the end.
I recommend it.
If you are interested in entrepreneurship take it.
If you're prepared to keep up with everything, go for it.
It will probably be better once they iron out the kinks
It's an okay class, but if you're going to take it be prepared to participate a lot if you want a good grade
Lectures are interesting, but assignments, midterm and final project are all graded very poorly and unfairly.
Make sure to do Lidow's readings as the lectures are all about the book.
Make sure you do the readings and prepare answers to the questions, because you could get cold-called at anytime.

Overall, I really enjoyed the course and would recommend it to anyone considering taking it. That being said, because the final project is a group project, you should take the class with a group of friends who have similar goals to you. I ended up in a group with four people I did not know. Three of the people were PDF- ing the class; consequently, they did not care about our final as much as the non- pdf-ers.
Participate in class.
Raise your hand.
Stay on top of the readings!
Super interesting. Anyone interested in business should take this course. Easy to do well and not a lot of work.
Take it
Take it if you are interested.
Take it if you would like an immersion, but chances are you can do a lot of research on this on your own.
Take it!
Take it.
Take it. Do readings. Go to class.
Take it. Without a doubt one of the three best courses I've taken at Princeton.
Take this class! It's so much fun and so amazing. You'll have such a great time. The professors are amazing.
Take this course if you are interested in entrepreneurship and want a good overview of the different types (financial, social etc.)

This is an interesting course and gives a nice overview of the entrepreneurship field, but still has some flaws that need to be worked out. The different professors' lectures are very disjointed, and you have to complete your final project entirely over winter break.

Three pieces of advice: 1. If Professors Kuenne, Danner, Zschau, and/or Lidow are involved, definitely take the class. 2. Seriously consider P/D/Fing it since the grading for a course like this is highly subjective. 3. No matter what other students and/or the professors tell you, ***ask for money during your final pitch presentation***.
To take the course but to make sure to have enough time to fully dedicate to it
Very interesting class but needs improvement. Interested to see how it will develop in the future.

Very interesting course to take if you are thinking about starting your own business or working at a private equity firm. A great way to get introduced to some awesome professors that know how to run businesses.
Wait a few years until this course is well established.
Whether you are interested in entrepreneurship or not, you should take this course.
prepare more than you think you'll need, because you want to have things to say in class.
take it offers insight onto the entrepreneurship field

this is a cool course--you learn a lot, but there's not really a deep level of learning. I feel like everything I learned in class could have been learned from just reading a handbook for entrepreneurhsip!
write in your journal every week actually
prereqs: There are no prerequisites for this course. Students from all disciplines are welcome..
descrip: The mission of this class is to give students a sense of the impact of entrepreneurship on the social and economic fabric of all cultures, while also defining the challenges all entrepreneurs must overcome in order to be successful. This class will adopt a point of view of the Princeton entrepreneur that pays particular attention to the opportunities and challenges faced by entrepreneurs who attend Princeton. The class will contain modules on the following topics, among others: Value Creation, Finding and Creating Markets, Business Models, Financials and Financing, and Leadership.

title: Did Kubrick Invent the iPad? -- Introduction to the Close Reading of Films
descrip: Please see website

title: Graphic Design: Typography
reviews: A unique class that is VERY little outside work and interesting subject to explore. Takes most of one day of your week, but worth it

If you want to have a chill time and explore your creative arts side, then take this course. The only thing is that it's 5 hours long on your Monday, but honestly, it's a welcome break from other departmental courses you may be taking.

Take it take it take it. It's a great time, and you learn so much more about a subject, both as "a practical seminar or, [as] a theoretical workshop" than I expected was possible. SO happy with the learning experience in this class.

Take this class with an open mind and an excitement for learning the practical side of the history of printed material. The hands-on aspects of this course make it a fantastic complement to other Princeton courses, and there is little to no work outside of the five hours of class per week. If you enjoy hands-on studio time and graphic design, those five hours don't feel like class at all. David is wonderful, and I highly recommend it.
There is no background experience necessary in terms of visual arts. It's a pretty fun and relaxed atmosphere, a very good introduction to the VIS department!
descrip: This studio course introduces students to graphic design with a particular emphasis on typography. Students learn typographic history through lectures that highlight major shifts in print technologies and through their engagement in studio design projects. Class readings provide the raw material for hot metal typesetting in the letterpress print shop, photo-typesetting in the mechanical paste-up studio, and state of the art typesetting and design software in the digital computer lab. Overall, the workshop synthesizes hands-on graphic design skills with aesthetic awareness and a critical vocabulary.

title: Intermediate Swahili I
prereqs: SWA 101 and 102 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This second year Swahili course focuses on enhancing the communicative skills acquired in the first year. Instruction is done through reading, writing, speaking and listening activities on cultural content that review and consolidate already acquired language skills. The course infuses cultural and socio-political aspects of life in East Africa with more complex grammatical concepts such as the subjunctive, grammar infixes, and relative clauses. Students are also introduced to intermediate-level reading and writing in Kiswahili.

title: Functional Programming
reviews: A decent amount of work, but it's fun to explore a different style of programing than you're used to.  As usual for COS, start assignments early and ask questions on Piazza if you're confused.
Best CS class I've ever taken.
Concepts aren't easy to understand, but provide different perspective on Computer Science. Interesting class but assignments are a substantial time commitment.
Definitely recommend taking this course. Very interesting and a different way to think about coding.
Definitely take it! Its really a mindset changing class. Be prepared to spend a lot of time on it though. Fear the exams.
Definitely take it. It's a little challenging at times but that's what I loved about it. I felt like I learned a lot and became an overall better programmer beacuase of it.
Definitely take it. It's a no-brainer.

Definitely take this course! It is a bit difficult and takes persistence, but not in a burdensome way. You will learn how to better construct and reason about your programs! Also, Dave Walker is generally fantastic.

Do not be intimidated by how superficially different OCaml is from imperative programming languages -- you will quickly learn to think recursively (which will be rewarding). Also, the proofs should not be too taxing.
Do the readings. If something is unclear about the assignments, turn to Christopher Moretti, he is very helpful and extremely approachable.
Fun and moderately challenging. You'll have a significantly better grasp of recursion after taking this class.

Functional programming is really cool.  I'd recommend this course for that reason alone.  Assignments can sometimes get tricky, so start them early.  The second half focuses more on the theory of programming languages than on the OCaml language; I found this theory stuff to be kind of dull, but I guess it's useful to know anyway.

Functional programming isn't extremely useful (you can get by with java/c etc) but most of my job interviewers have taken interest in the fact that I am taking functional. It is very fun to learn how to program again and really opens your eyes to all the different ways of constructing a programming language and the different paradigms out there. Very useful for understanding more about java/c even if you never use oCaml again
Good course but be prepared to do some serios work and deal with some very interesting but difficult material. Don't take too many hard classes at the same time.
Great class that introduces a new way of thinking and programming!
Great class. Work with a partner -- last assignment is a lot of work. Go to lecture, slides cover lots of stuff!
Highly recommend

I highly recommend this course -- you get a lot of the fun challenges like you did in 126 while learning a new language, but you also tackle some really relevant, interesting computer science concepts.  It's ridiculously fun!!

If you are going to have any other class that has a high workload, avoid this class. This class has a significantly higher workload than you would expect. However, it does a good job of teaching functional programming - and I feel like what I learned was valuable. Take it if it interests you AND you will not have an extremely busy semester.

If you like solving puzzles and are interested in a somewhat obscure area of CS, this course is interesting and somewhat fun. It's a fair amount of work, but definitely not the hardest or most time consuming CS course I've taken.
If you take this course, study A LOT for the midterm and final.  Most people do really well on all of the assignments so it really comes down to the exams which determine your grade.
If you're a CS major, your education is incomplete if you don't understand functional programming.
Interesting perspective on programming. Definitely worth taking for both COS and non-COS majors! Not too hard.
It makes you learn how to program recursively. A good course for CS Majors
It was okay. I wouldn't take it again, because I didn't find it interesting and it was definitely harder than it needed to be.
It'll be strange in the beginning, but as you get used to it, its a lot of fun.

It's an interesting subject and teaches you a really fascinating way of looking at programming.  The class itself is pretty time-consuming and the material is drier in the second half, but it's one of the better COS departmentals.  Take it.

Know that you are going to be very confused and frustrated at times because recursive programming is difficult to master. You will likely enjoy many of the assignments, while others will want to make you pull your hair out. Study hard for the exams because Walker will throw curveballs at you that he has not attempted to solve himself! Overall, assignments were enjoyable and interesting for the most part, but exams were miserable. Lectures were mediocre.
Learning how to code functionally is like learning how to swim for the first time.  There's a really steep learning curve, but once everything starts clicking, it's actually pretty fun!
Not as well organized as 217/226, but functional programming is something that all serious CS people should know

Not easy, but super interesting for COS majors. You already have C and Java under your belt, but OCaml is something totally different. Once you have those three, you'll understand pretty much any possible language
Only take it if you have to, or you are interested in functional.
Really good introduction to functional programming.
Study for the midterms, or suffer from this sadness I feel.
TAKE IT. will be very enjoyable, plus relevant in the coming years (if not already).
Take it if you have a lot of time to spend on it. The material isn't horrible, but it's definitely not an easy class and the assignments are pretty time consuming.
Take it if you want to learn a new paradigm about programming.
Take it if you're a COS major. It will change the way you program in even OOP languages.

Take it! Good class, you learn a lot and it improves your programming skills a ton. Just beware of the exams, they are super tough, and since most people get similar grades on the assignments, that is where the overall grades are differentiated.
Take it! This course teaches you how to write and reason about programs in a very cool way.
Take it. Absolutely take it. Whoever you are, you want to take this class. (As long as you already know some algorithms and data structures.)
Take it. Ocaml is not a widely used language. But functional programming is really interesting and helpful. You will feel being more clever after taking this course.
Take the course. It's very interesting and well taught, and the information you learn is very helpful for the future
Take this class!! Functional is a really cool way of programming and Walker is great.

The assignments are actually A LOT of work, so be prepared for that. Also, there is no final, so make sure you study hard for the midterms. Overall, though, a really enjoyable course with a great professor that covers a lot of important concepts. Would recommend it to anyone seriously considering CS as a profession.

The assignments get much harder as the semester goes on, especially the Dean's Date one (don't be deceived by the easier ones early one!). This course has some interesting material, and I'm definitely a lot better at recursion now, but it's not a "must take" class. Take it if your interested, but there are better classes
The assignments will take a lot of time, especially the later ones, so start early.
This class does not cover that many concepts, but covers each of them in great depth. Make sure to understand every topic on a deep level. Do lots of proof practice.

This course is deceptively hard. The material is very good and will change you extremely positively as a programmer, but it is very challenging and very easy to fall behind. Don't use your laptop in class, you probably aren't smart enough to figure out the material on your own.
This sounds very general, but if you get stuck (especially early on), go to office hours. Sometimes it just takes a bit more explanation to "get" an assignment.

This was a terrific course. I would highly recommend it. It exposed me to new ways of thinking about and writing programs. Even though I may not often find myself using OCaml or Haskell, I can still apply many of the ideas to write better programs in imperative languages.

The course is very well organized, and includes amazing supporting material (lecture slides, readings, Piazza, etc.). The assignments were always fun, interesting, and challenging, though a couple were crunched for time.
Tough. But really interesting!
Very interesting class that all COS majors should take -- you'll learn a really cool language, along with some more fundamental COS concepts that the language/programming paradigm helps reinforce.
Very interesting class.

You will learn functional programming, which is important and useful. You will also learn OCaml. If you are stupid like me you might have a hard time. You really have to think. The lectures are boring, but going to them will remind you of what you should know for each week. Also since the slides are very sparse text-wise, it can help to go to lecture, since if you don't go you might not be able to understand the slides just by reading them.
challenging but worthwhile
take it!!!
prereqs: COS 226 or with permission of the instructor..
descrip: An introduction to the principles of typed functional programming. Programming recursive functions over structured data types and informal reasoning by induction about the correctness of those functions. Functional algorithms and data structures. Principles of modular programming, type abstraction, representation invariants and representation independence. Parallel functional programming, algorithms and applications.

title: A Nation of Immigrants
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Intermediate/Advanced French
reviews: All you learn is grammar, no vocab unless you put in tons of extra hours so you'll never really learn the language unless you go further.
Anne-Laure is wonderful!
Come excited to learn and participate and it'll be a great experience.
Do the readings on grammar the night before  you learn the concepts in class. Also, start the compositions early.
Don't work too hard
French is definitely one of the better languages to take as a distribution requirement. The faculty are very nice and willing to help whenever.
Good class to learn intermediate French. Professor Hart is great, so if you can, try to get her.
I would highly recommend this course. Prof Hart is awesome.
Keep up with the homework and this class shouldn't be a problem.
Put in effort outside of the course to develop language skills. Classes are great, but they cannot do the whole job.
Stay caught up with your work and don't be afraid to ask questions.

Stay on top of your work and take good notes on what is discussed in class pertaining to the readings. It will become very helpful when it comes to the tests and you have discussion questions on the material. Very good class. Conversation based, and compositions help to keep up your writing skills.

TAKE THE COURSE 
cause you probably have to anyway
All the teachers are amazing
Take it
Take it.
Take this course (because you probably have to) but make sure you get a great teacher like Madame Kalim!
Take this course with Madame Hart!

The advice I would give students at this level is to stop focusing on vocab and conjugations, and instead, begin practicing different constructions that show up very often until they become automatic. That and watch lots of videos of french people on youtube paying particular attention to the constructions they use to express their thoughts and how it differs from the way one might say it in english.
The course was not all the challenging if you did the readings and came to class.
The professor was one of the best I have had here at Princeton. I just wish I spent more time on the course. If you follow the syllabus and do the readings expect your French to improve dramatically.

This course really helped increase my comfort level with French and expand my ability to use it. It essentially reviews, in more depth, the material learned in 101 and 102, but also incorporates a larger aspect of French culture into the class, and I found it more enjoyable.
Try not to take this class at 9am. It's relatively easy and not very time consuming in comparison to other language classes. If you did fine in 101 and 102 you will do fine in this class.
great class
take if you need
prereqs: FRE 102 or FRE 103..
descrip: The main objective of this course is to develop your listening, speaking and writing skills, while giving you a foundation for understanding and appreciation of French-speaking cultures. There is a thorough review of French grammar and a selection of communicative activities chosen to improve proficiency and give practice of newly acquired linguistic material. A wide range of authentic material will be offered, including readings from the media, short stories and contemporary texts, films and songs.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: Any architecture student with an interest in film, technology, and the new medium of the virtual world should definitely take this course. Keep an open mind and be ready for an adventure!

Figure out exactly what you need to get before you go on the class trip. Make a detailed story board for your animation or film or drawing or whatever so you know precisely what you need. If you're scanning, take footage in the exact place you scanned from.

TAKE THIS STUDIO! Liam is awesome, the trip is awesome, and making a film is challenging in the very best way. You'll get to learn some new tools, think about architecture in a new way, and have a phenomenal time.
take it, it's a unique opportunity in the architecture school. I'd take it again if I could
descrip: Vertical Design Studio

title: An Integrated Introduction to Engineering, Mathematics, Physics
reviews: Although the teaching isn't the best, you will really get to know the other students, many of whom are geniuses and can help with confusion.
Always take it seriously and always go to class.
Attend office hours.  Take this class just so that you can take rocket lab.
Choose the right professor
Class is a supplement to the readings; the readings are not a supplement to class.
EMP > Individual classes.
EMP is a good program, take it if you like physics, and engineering, and want a mild challenge (compared to MAT 201 & PHY 103), and want to make close friends.
Go to office hours. Read the book's methods.
Go to problem sessions! Working with other classmates is the only way to figure out how to do the problems. Also go to office hours.
Have some experience in multi variable

I had Antonio Ache as a professor for Fall of 2014-2015. I think if you are thinking about whether to take this class, you are probably trying to decide between taking EMP or not. While I think the physics portion of EMP is much better than the math, it is worth taking the math class so that you can have the great experience from physics too. While the instruction was not great (i.e. I had to look most stuff up in the book which was pretty clear if you took the time to read it), the professors host problem sessions every week before the problem set which is really great to not only get your problem set done (because frankly, the students are sometimes better at explaining the content than the professors) but also make friends! And from what I have heard from people in regular MAT 201, the instruction is no better and the tests are harder...of course this may not necessarily be the case next year. Another benefit in taking this course is the added flexibility of the professors because it is taken jointly with physics. One time, we had a big take-home quiz in math due the next day as well as a physics pset due the same day so Vikram Duvvuri, our physics professor, pushed the deadline for our physics problem set back a day so we could all focus on the math quiz. Of course, if you were not in EMP and just took MAT 201 and PHYS 103, you would not have this type of flexibility. Also, by the end of EMP, you really know nearly all 60 people in the program and because you all suffer over the same problem sets together, they become your closest friends.
I highly reccomend this class. The teachers are great, very nice and helpful, and the work was a good level of difficulty.

I really loved the close-knit aspect of EMP and the way in which the students really got close as a result of spending so much time together preparing for class. However, I would suggest not taking EMP unless you have an absolutely spectacular background in physics and math (maybe even prior experience of multivariable). Form a study group.

I would advise a study to take this course with John because he is very willing to answer in class questions. Be prepared to do a sufficient amount of outside studying. I would also strongly advise going to all the problem sessions for the problem sets.
I would definitely recommend this course, I feel like I really did learn a lot about Multi.
I would recommend this class, especially for MAE majors because this class is integrated with EGR191, which does rocket science.
If you ever have the opportunity to take a course with John Stogin, do it--he is truly invested in seeing his students understand the material.
If you haven't been exposed to muli varaible calc before, there's going to be a steep learning curve, since lots of the material is new.

If you really want to take EMP physics and you are very strong at calculus, then take this class. I, however do not recommend it. It goes at a very fast pace and requires a very large time commitment. I cannot say that the professors are very helpful.
It's a little harder than MAT 201 (more topics like ordinary differential equations), but the level of intellectual challenge is totally fair and stimulating!
Keep up with learning the material and don't be shy to go to officer hours.

Look for sources of help online, specifically Khan Academy. They explain the concepts in a clearer way. Also, if you are struggling with the class, schedule one-on-one meeting with the instructor or TA so that they are not rushed to answer your questions and you can ask all of the detailed questions you want. Also, start the problem sets early. You will always spend more time on them than you think, so it is best to come to the problem sets prepared and ready to ask questions. Also, COLLABORATE! You will not survive without it.

Prepare for a lot of out-of-class study, including reading the textbook, watching online tutorials/reading online walkthroughs, because the material is conceptually difficult to grasp, and the instructors can only do so much to help your understanding.
Take Mat 201 instead unless you want to be particularly challenged and work at a faster pace.
Take it if you want MAT 201 in a smaller class setting. The curriculums are roughly the same but just switched around in terms of order.
Take it if you want a tight-knit collaborative environment but also a very challenging one
Take it. Extremely hard, but John Stogin is an amazing teacher.

This is a great class to get you interested back into math. Definitely attend all the lectures because they're worth listening to, and they clarify the information much more than the textbook does. Attend nightly problem set lessons. Note that this course is significantly more difficult than MAT 201, especially the problem sets.
Yes.
its a challenging course but worth it
read the textbook before lecture, it really helps.
take this course if you are really interested in engineering or are not sure about what you want to study .it will certainly help you put matters and different majors into perspective.
prereqs: All first-year engineering students who have placement into multivariable calculus on the basis of a score of 5 on the BC calculus exam (or equivalent) are eligible to enroll..
descrip: Taken concurrently with EGR/MAT/PHY 191, this course offers an integrated presentation of the material from PHY 103 (General Physics: Mechanics and Thermodynamics) and MAT 201 (Multivariable Calculus) with an emphasis on applications to engineering. Math topics include: vector calculus; partial derivatives and matrices; line integrals; simple differential equations; surface and volume integrals; and Green's, Stokes', and divergence theorems.

title: Geodynamics
reviews: If you enjoy thinking about geodynamics, the course is very stimulating and worthwhile. If not, then it likely would be rather frustrating.
You should take this course if you are interested in learning Geodynamics.
prereqs: MAT 201 or 202.
descrip: An advanced introduction to setting up and solving boundary value problems relevant to the solid earth sciences. Topics include heat flow, fluid flow, elasticity and plate flexure, and rock rheology, with applications to mantle convection, magma transport, lithospheric deformation, structural geology, and fault mechanics.

title: Contemporary Logic Design
reviews: A well-paced class. Not the most difficult, but may lead to it being less engaging. Pretty manageable, except the final assignment picks up quickly.

As a COS major, I thought the topics in this course were interesting and approachable; if you have any interest in logic design, it's a good course to take.  Don't expect to learn much about Verilog, though -- you're pretty much on your own to learn it for the labs.
Definitely take this course if you're interested! It's a solid departmental.
Definitely worth taking and teaches a lot, but beware of the lab.

Don't let the simplicity of the first half of the course fool you - the second half of the course is a lot of work. Good for CS students, though, as much of the information is already known and the rest helps explain what's going on under the hood.

Don't take this course unless you have to. Professor Malik cares a lot about his students, but the exams are way more difficult that you expect, the TAs don't provide much guidance, and the labs during the second half of the semester are incredibly time consuming.

ELE 206 is a great course in which you'll learn how all digital logic works. This is calculators, computers, etc. After taking this course, you will know enough to build processors in minecraft like they do on the Youtube videos, or how to implement a TOY machine (from COS 126) in hardware. The workload is as much as for any other course with a lab, and is nothing particularly difficult in that respect. The final project, which is to design and implement a general-purpose processor, however, is quite substantial, so you may be spending the end of the semester in the ELE lab for many days working on it.

Non ELE/COS majors will also find it useful to take the course as a matter of subject interest. I recommend COS 126 be taken first since you will be at a disadvantage without it, though it is not necessary since Malik goes over everything you need to know, right from the beginning. Having an aptitude for quantitative reasoning will benefit you immensely in the course, since quite a lot of it is required.

Great lectures, interesting material, but beware... labs start out deceptively simple, and the 2nd half of the semester has only 2, but they will suck the time out of your schedule. Last 2 labs took 10-20 hours each, and me and my partner worked much faster than most groups. It is really cool building your own  computer, but it needs better structure...
Have a foundation in programming and be prepared to adapt to a different coding language.

Honestly, the laboratories will make you regret even considering signing up for it. If they keep the laboratories the way it is, absolutely don't unless you have to. Otherwise, if changes are made to the laboratories, it might become a very enjoyable class to take as the material is fascinating.
I highly recommend this course. It is incredible how we went from learning about transistors to designing a small processor. One of my favorite courses this semester.
I would highly recommend this course to any COS majors that want to see what happens under the hood. (ELE has to take it anyway, so...)
I would say work early and often on the labs and just stick with one partner for the semester on both labs and psets.
I would take this course if you are interested, but be prepared to learn and seek help on your own.

I'll write this mostly for COS people considering taking this.

This class definitely exposes you to some material that you won't see in any of your other classes (save if you do 375) and is legitimately useful. This is by no means a "must take" and you'll be fine as a systems programmer just by doing OS or whatever.
If this course sounds at all interesting to you take it, you will probably have a lot of fun.
If you're ELE good luck. If you're COS think about other options and take 217 before or with it because the content matches very well.
If you're interested in learning what goes on "under the hood" of most electronics, take this course
It can be challenging..
Its a difficult course, but worth the effort. You will learn alot,but be prepared to put in alot of hours. But Professor Malik is great and really cares about his students.
Labs take longer than you think!
Learn Verilog quickly, and get help soon! It's a bit confusing and you'll pay for it if you don't do so very soon.
Malik is the man. Very clear lecturer.
Plan on spending a ton of time in lab, and take it only if you are COS or ELE.
Plan time to do labs.

Sharad is really nice and cares about his students a lot, which is refreshing.  Lectures can be a bit dry, and the labs a bit frustrating, but the material is interesting, and you learn a lot.  Start the two final labs early.
Take if you're interested, but watch out.
Take it if you're interested in ELE/COS! Overall not a very difficult course, just don't overthink questions; Professor Malik is NOT out to get you!
Take this class if you are computer scornice minded. It's very abstract and hard but the challenge to think creatively was fun.
The class is great, the labs are terrible (in 2014). Hopefully the labs will be revamped to match how fantastic Professor Malik and the class are.

The course starts off pretty straightforward and the level of difficulty suddenly escalates towards the end -- be prepared! Even though, in the end, I didn't enjoy the course material that much (I'm a COS major), I still think that what we learned was interesting and valuable knowledge.

The material is interesting and very logical and Prof. Malik goes fairly slow and makes a special effort to make the class understand the material. The labs are hard but rewarding. However, the guidance available for them is not very good (you can do the labs whenever you want and TAs are available for help at only specific times which are quite limited in number)

The material was well-presented in lectures and the weekly problem sets only took an hour or two each, but the labs ranged from annoying to extremely frustrating. If you can put up with the labs, a good companion to COS 217.

The structure of this class is very interesting: there are no precepts or required lab time (even though they appear on the schedule). Don't let that fool you though- the class is hard and time consuming. The problem sets are challenging but the exams are just impossible. I thought the material was very interesting (especially in the beginnign with the basics) but gets very difficult. Professor Malik gets to know the students who come to class (though you don't actually have to attend because he posts all the lecture recordings online) and he really knows his stuff. However for the young ELE majors among you, be ready to be really challenged.
There's a lot of good material in this class, but a lot of the work is very tedious, so be prepared to spend time doing drawings of circuits, etc.  Tests are quite hard.
Unless you have a strong interest in basic computer architecture and are willing to sacrifice countless hours in a lab programming, I would not recommend this course.
Very interesting content, frustrating labs, and little instruction in design.
Very interesting, a lot of work, but except for the final lab nothing really takes an insane amount of time, you just have to stay motivated throughout the semester.

Whether or not you enjoyed PHY 104, ***TAKE IT***. I'm a senior Mechanical Engineer who now knows that I selected the wrong concentration. If you are deciding between MAE and ELE, this course will show you the right move. If only I had taken it as a sophomore...
very good COS departmental if you're interested in how computers work
descrip: Introduction to the basic concepts in logic design that form the basis of computation and communication circuits. Logic gates and memeory elements. Timing methodologies. Finite state systems. Programmable logic. Basic computer organization.

title: Women and Gender in Islamic Societies
descrip: This seminar focuses on issues of gender and sexuality in Islamic societies, past and present. Readings are drawn from the fields of history, religious studies, anthropology and sociology. Readings also include a wide range of texts in translation, including novels and poetry. Films are an integral part of the course. Topics include: women's lives; women's writings; female piety; marriage and divorce; sexuality and the body; and women and Islamic fundamentalism.

title: Race, Ethnicity, and Nationalism in Latin America
reviews: Do your readings

If you have an interest in the topic and don't mind it being taught a little dryly then go for it otherwise I might recommend a different sociology or Latin American studies class. Professor Telles does show knowledge about the topic but isn't the best at passing that excitement on to his students.
The reading for this course is very beneficial. That's where most of the concepts for exams come from. The content is also very interesting and informative.
Unless you want to waste your time on an easy, unstimulating class do not take this course.
descrip: Examines a wide range of issues regarding race, ethnicity and nationalism globally, but with an emphasis on Latin America. We will explore the basic sociological, political and cultural concepts of nation, race and ethnicity, emphasizing how they are used and their relation with one another in various contexts. For example, race and ethnicity have taken on special meanings in Latin America where they are central to ideas about the nation. Much of the course will focus on how that came about and how race is manifested in different national contexts. We will emphasize comparisons to the U.S. as well as across countries within Latin America.

title: Measuring Climate Change: Methods in Data Analysis and Scientific Writing
reviews: Be prepared to sacrifice time.
I fully recommend this class, but be prepared for a huge amount of work.
If you want to commit all of your time to this course you may be able to learn something. Don't take it if you're writing a JP at the same time.

Make sure you are up for the challenge.  It is really tough mentally, physically, and emotionally.  It is rewarding, and you will be a better student at the end, but it is absolutely painful during the semester.

Take this course only if you are ready for the rigorous workload. You must be interested in doing scientific research. It is almost essential to have a decent quantitative background and programming experience. Seek help often and get to know the professors.

This class is almost like having a guided JP.  It is a lot of time so make sure you have a balanced schedule if you decide to take it (especially as a junior or senior). Don't complain about the work and don't feel bad for yourself for having a lot of work to do, just do the work and appreciate the opportunity to be doing cool research projects.

This course is a lot of work - it is fascinating and fulfilling if you are able and willing to put the work in, and painful and disheartening if you cannot.  DO NOT take this course if you are a junior or senior.  If you are a junior, it is literally like having two JPs, and one of them (your actual JP or GEO 201) will suffer.  If you're a sophomore and willing to put the time in, definitely take it - you'll learn a ton.
You should not take this class as a junior, unless you are really motivated and willing to spend almost every day working on both this class and a JP
prereqs: Enrollment in the course is by application only (e-mail one short paragraph to explain why you want to take the course to maloof@princeton.edu). Two mandatory field trips (students cannot pass the course if they do not attend the trips). 1 - A weekend in the Catskills in late September or early October, dates TBA. 2 - 8 days in the American Southwest over Fall Break..
descrip: Students will use drone-derived models of landscapes, georeferenced field observations of the natural world, and data mining of the primary literature in combination with quantitative modeling to answer questions like: How have ancient climate changes been preserved in modern landscapes and the rock record? How is climate changing now, and how do we measure it? Students will build on what they learned as freshmen in the Writing Seminars about articulating a compelling hypothesis and making an argument based on data and analysis.

title: Topics in the History of Sex and Gender - History of Sexuality
reviews: I strongly recommend this course for any student. Take the opportunity to get to know a great professor, writer and scholar, and to integrate scholarship on sexuality into your work.
I would not hesitate to recommend this class or the classes of Professor Kunzel in general. I think her presence on the faculty has immeasurably changed the department for the better.
I would probably let them know that Professor Kunzel actually reads and comments on their reading responses, so they need to actually spend time on them.
It's about 19th-20th century America, for the most part! I went in thinking it would be more general!

Just work with Reg.
Change your field and work with her.

Simply that the themes of the course are far broader than they might initially seem to be--these 20th c. American works ended up being valuable to my own decidedly non-20th c. American research. It also served as an excellent environment for practicing speaking in front of my peers--something I've had trouble with in other courses here.
Take it! Prof. Kunzel is brilliant and kind, and the material is fascinating.

This class is equal parts deep engagement with assigned texts, with the academic backgrounds and perspectives of others, and with the complexities, joys, and puzzles of historiographical approaches to sex. Very highly recommended.
descrip: A survey of important work in the history of sexuality, seeking to understand sexuality not only as a topic of historical inquiry but as a category of analysis. Seminar focuses on U.S. history (from colonial period to the present), but some of the readings address contexts outside of the United States, as well as interdisciplinary and/or theoretical approaches to questions of gender/sexuality.

title: Women in American Higher Education
prereqs: Not open to students who have taken FRS 149, "Coeducation.".
descrip: The history of women in American higher education from the early 19th to the late 20th century, focusing on the founding and evolution of leading women's colleges; the early experience of coeducation; the formation of coordinate colleges for women; and the wave of coeducation that swept over colleges and universities beginning in 1969. We'll study the adoption of coeducation at previously single-sex institutions (e.g. Princeton, Yale, Dartmouth, Amherst, Vassar, Oxford, Cambridge) and investigate the experience of women's colleges that remained single-sex. We'll assess the results of coeducation and the continuing case for women's colleges.

title: Quantitative Analysis in Psychological Research
descrip: An introduction to quantitative methods in psychological research appropriate for first and second year graduate students. The topics covered include experimental design, null hypothesis significance testing, power, effect size, and confidence intervals. Specific procedures covered include ANOVA, ANCOVA, multiple regression, moderation, and mediation.

title: Seminar on Education-Theory and Practice
prereqs: Prerequisites: See Teacher Preparation Program requirements. Course requires admission into the Teacher Preparation Program. Enrollment limited to students doing their practice teaching (TPP 402) except by special permission from the program director..
descrip: Seminar taken concurrently with Practice Teaching (TPP402). Students investigate the processes of curriculum development and implementation, develop learning goals and rubrics for assessment, study national and local issues in education and their impact on schools, examine current philosophies and effective practices, reflect on their work and evaluate their performance as practice teachers.

title: Introductory Video and Film Production
descrip: A film/video course introducing the techniques of shooting and editing digital video. Works of film/video art will be analyzed in class to explore the development of, and innovations in, cinematic language. Production will be oriented toward film/video as a visual art, including narrative, documentary, and experimental genres. Several short video projects will be produced during the semester.

title: Ethics in Financial Markets
descrip: Please see website

title: Intensive Beginner's and Intermediate French
reviews: As a BSE, this was a great course to balance out computation-intensive courses. It's nice to come in every day for an hour or so and learn a new language. Unlike some courses, you actually feel like you are learning something and learning something useful.
Be prepared to listen intently and participate, because you go through the material quickly.
DO THE READING! It's good practice.
Do the assigned homework every night.
Do the homework every night because it makes studying for the test less overwhelming.
Go to French tables, and participate lots in class, don't worry if you talk "too much" because you will only improve with practice

Go to class, pay attention in class, and study a little bit at home a few nights a week. Also, do all the assignments even if they're not graded--they don't take much time and they're very beneficial. You will learn a lot and it'll be awesome.
Go to every single class, pay attention, and participate.
Have fun and really engage in discussions.
I hated French in high school but I love it here.  If you've had some French before, definitely try this course out before placing down or switching languages.
I would recommend it, and I think that doing the homework really helps to cement understanding of the concepts.
I would tell them to take it if they had to, probably don't take it if they didn't have to.
If you have to take 103, by all means try and take it with Prof. Verhey.
It is strongly recommended that you practice outside of class. Visit the language table. Chat with friends from the course, or even ones at higher levels.
It is very challenging if you have not taken French in the past, but absolutely worth it if you can dedicate the time. If possible, I'd suggest taking no more than 4 courses.
It's a fun class.
Keep up on the course pack and readings so you don't have to cram and memorize a bunch of grammar before the tests.
My advice would be to follow along with the textbook as you go though the syllabus. It will be very helpful to know the vocab in the textbook and to do the grammar exercises.
Pay attention in class! The professor gives a lot of helpful tips and tricks during class that you would do well to copy down and practice.
Practice outside of class.
Take advantage of the supplemental materials and guidance, there are a lot of resources available to help you improve.
Take it if you want to.
Take it with Vincent Chanethom if possible. It's a really good course; you'll learn a lot.
Take the class, especially if you can get Melissa.
The pace is fast - especially after the first few weeks. Good course to take if your French is basic/rusty.
language tables!
put effort into every class
prereqs: Prerequisites include approximately two years of high school French and an appropriate score on the Princeton French Language Placement Test..
descrip: FRE 103 is an intensive beginning and intermediate language course designed for students who have already studied French (typically no more than 2-3 years). Covering in one semester the material presented in FRE 101 and FRE 102, this course prepares students to take FRE 107 the following semester. Classroom activities include comprehension and grammar exercises, conversation, skits, and working with a variety of audio-visual materials.

title: Talking Politics
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Studies in 19th-Century Literature and Culture - Heinrich Heine und Sigmund Freud
descrip: The coincidence that Heinrich Heine died in the same year when Sigmund Freud was born (1856) functions as the point of departure to study the elective affinities and interrelation between a poetic and a scientific approach to phenomena such as the dream, the language of the unconscious, passions, wit, memory and the afterlife of religion and myth in modernity. Starting with Freud's explicit references to Heine in his book on Witz, the seminar will study the hidden traces of their affinities: 1. Heine and Freud read Shakespeare, 2. Fictious and scientific dreams, 3. Comparing their Moses-books, 4. Gods and ghosts, 5. Passions and paintings.

title: Photography and Literature
descrip: Please see website

title: Advanced Arabic Skills Workshop
prereqs: ARA 302 or permission of the NES Department..
descrip: Advanced readings in classical Arabic literature. Major emphasis on syntax and the accurate understanding of authentic material. Also some readings for overall understanding, with discussion in Arabic.

title: Optical Electronics
reviews: A quite relaxed course for learning.
Good, low workload class to take senior year, if Prof. Fleischer is teaching it.
I suggest this course and this professor
I would recommend to anyone who wants to refresh their memory about electromagnetism while covering a nice spectrum of topics. Workload is easy, lectures interesting, attention if needed.
You would have a broader ken after taking this course, and learn more than the textbook.
better bring the interest to the classroom
descrip: Fundmentals of light-matter interactions, waveguides and resonators, nonlinear optics and lasers.

title: Research Program in Development Studies
reviews: Take it if it's your field.
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Advanced Workshop in Musical Composition - Topics in Twenty-First Century Tonality
reviews: A decent amount of work; but if you're willing, it's great.
Ask for help. Donnacha is an awesome composer, person, and adviser.
Donnacha is cool, so utilize him as a resource outside of class when you can. In class, discussion is dominated by students.
It gets you to compose music. If that's what you want, it's a good course to take.
Only take it if you seriously can write music; and if you can seriously write music, take it!
Take it if you want to make music!
You have to take the class and yourself seriously to stay motivated and helpful.  The students are in it together.
prereqs: Some previous compositional experience. Pick up application in Woolworth Room 310..
descrip: Music 310 is a composition course for independent, self-directed composers, working in any style. The major requirement is to compose your own music related to the topic, and to present it at our class concert at the end of the semester. You are responsible for finding your own performers and leading rehearsals. Purely electronic works or renditions are also acceptable. In addition, I will ask you to listen to various pieces over the course of the semester, and to comment on them. We may have a few assignments to get you started.

title: Environmental Economics
reviews: Good course if you're interested in this. Not mathematically difficult, and requires little background in economics.

Great class. You'll be exposed to many interesting ideas and theories about why do things not always happen the way they should be. There isn't too much math in this class and the economic ideas touched upon are also not too difficult, so it is very much manageable to non-econ majors too, even if you haven't taken any econ before ( = don't worry the ECO 300 prerequisite).
Take this class, whether you are an economics major or not. For economics majors, it is an excellent departmental with interesting material and a workload that is not too heavy.
prereqs: MAT 103 or equivalent and ECO 300 OR equivalent..
descrip: Course introduces use of economics in understanding both the sources of and the remedies to environmental and resource allocation problems. It emphasizes the reoccurrence of economic phenomena like public goods, externalities, market failure and imperfect information. Students learn about the design and evaluation of environmental policy instruments, the political economy of environmental policy, and the valuation of environmental and natural resource services. The concepts are illustrated in a variety of applications from domestic pollution of air, water and land to international issues such as global warming and sustainable development.

title: Introduction to Gender and Sexuality Studies
reviews: Definitely take this class, no matter who you are.
Do all the readings, go to all the classes!

Don't let the "201" fool you. This course is a dive-in to theory that isn't always the easiest grasp. However, there is much to be gained by dedicating time to review the readings seriously and prepare for class discussion.
Don't.
Professor Salamon is the best. That's really all there is to it.

Take it take it take it. I wish that all students were obligated to take a GSS course as part of their distribution requirements, and I wish that this one could be mandated like that. A must-have for any Princeton student wishing to understand their own place and the place of others in the conflicting spheres of gender, sexuality, race, and ability.
Take it! It's not an easy course, but its an exciting and engaging one.
Take it!!

Take this course if you are pursuing the GSS certificate, it's very good and will prepare you with the language you need to understand contemporary issues, but the grading is hard and may not be worth it for someone who only wants an introductory class on GSS.

This is an amazing class with a great reading list. Professor Salamon is eloquent, funny, engaging, and extremely knowledgeable. I thought this would be a dry, heavily theory-based intro class but it was absolutely wonderful! Learned so much, had some of my most meaningful class discussions, and heard from two amazing guest speakers. This was one of my favorite GSS classes at Princeton.

This was my most challenging class and my favorite. It changed and clarified and enriched my thoughts about gender and sexuality (and race, class, etc.) in such meaningful ways. It's definitely heavy on theory, but if you're up for a challenge I highly recommend this course. It's so important for everyone to have the tools to think about the power dynamics that govern our lives!

Very strong and thought provoking introduction to gender and sexuality studies. Professor Salamon is AMAZING and the readings are great. Not a ton of assignments, so it doesn't have to be a lot of work. Definitely take it if you have any interest at all in the subject matter.
descrip: What does it mean to be a woman or a man? Or neither? How do gender and sexuality, those seemingly most personal and private of attributes, emerge from networks of power and social relations? This course introduces major concepts in the interdisciplinary field of gender and sexuality studies. We will analyze the ways in which gender, as an object of study and as a lived experience, intersects with class, race, and ability, and will examine the relation between gender, sexuality and power in literary, philosophical, political and medical discourses.

title: Studies in Persian Literature 900 - 1200 A.D.
prereqs: PER 302 or permission of instructor.
descrip: This two-term exploration of Classical Persian literature in the original acquaints students with the principal authors of chronicles, epics, imaginative tales, and stories of spiritual initiation throughout the Persian-speaking world (Iran and Central Asia and also medieval India and Anatolia) from the 10th to 19th centuries. Part I, ca. AD 900 - ca. AD 1200, addresses the formation and gradual Islamization of the ancient epic tradition, the writing of "mirrors for kings" for the Ghaznavid and Seljuk sultans, and the impact of Neoplatonic mysticism.

title: Modern Chinese Thought
reviews: Definitely take it if you're interested in China at all. Chou Laoshi is a great professor and you'll learn a ton.

If you're interested at all in modern China and are thinking about taking this course, definitely enroll and give it a shot! It's a really great way to take a small class at Princeton with an amazing, knowledgeable professor. The reading load is heavy but reasonable, and a lot of is just history. The presentations throughout the semester are very manageable, and the research paper is a lot of fun to write. Definitely take advantage of Professor Chou's office hours. He's very easy to talk to, and he'll give you great advice and guidance on your paper and on China topics, more generally.

My main recommendation would be to consider your suitability to this course.  I think I would have found it very hard if I was not also taking a course on Chinese history, which  gave me a lot of background that was very helpful for the readings and seminars for this course.   I would also say that having a bit of Chinese language is useful, but that it is possible to take the course without it.  It is just a bit more complex.
Take this class. You will learn so much and you will get to do so with a brilliant but also sincere and empathetic professor.
This class is really entertaining and intellectually stimulating. There is not a ton of work involved, but it's worth doing it because the material is so interesting. Speaking Chinese is a bonus.
descrip: A systematic study of problems and concepts connected with the development of modern Chinese thought. Such issues as antitraditionalism, the rise of communism, the emancipation of women, the promotion of Western ideologies and the process of modernization will be treated.

title: Selected Topics in Russian Literature and Culture - Chekhov
descrip: An analysis of Chekhov's major short stories and plays against a backdrop of his personal concerns, and political, societal, literary, artistic, and cultural developments. Some focus on Chekhov's impact on western European and American literature and culture. Some attention to film adaptations of his works. Some focus on the relevance of Chekhov's works to contemporary issues of the 21st century.

title: Computing and Optimization for the Physical and Social Sciences
reviews: AAA was the best lecturer I've had as an ORF major so far. He is careful to make sure everyone understands what is happening and adjusts/slows down when necessary instead of just trying to "finish the book." He was approachable if you needed help and continuously adjusted the lectures, psets, tests so that everyone in the class was comfortable. The class wasn't hard per say (in that you never felt overwhelmed like in ORF 309 or 405 etc). But it wasn't easy and you had to think about each pset - which were also reasonable.

Absolutely take this course. Professor Ahmadi is a fantastic lecturer and truly cares about his students. I was initially concerned that this course would have too much of an overlap with ORF 307 (Optimization), but I can assure you that this is not the case. In general, ORF 307 focuses on linear programming (simplex method, duality theory, etc.), while ORF 363 focuses on convex optimizaiton and computation (unconstrained optimization,  convex optimization problems, descent methods, complexity theory, etc.) with a week or two on linear programming.

After its revamping this semester, this course has become a super-useful class that I highly recommend!  I learned a lot, and a lot of what I learned kept popping up in my other courses.  If you're interested in problem-solving, strategy, and optimization, you should definitely take this!
Amirali is great! Take his class
Definitely take. AAA is awesome
Great course. Great Professor. He is really nice and is very helpful. Take it.

Great course. It is obvious how much Prof. Ahmadi cares about this class and he has done an excellent job. I think the material is important and applicable in other courses and other areas of operations research.
Great professor, always available outside of class

If Professor Amir is teaching this course, TAKE IT!!!!! He is the best professor I've had in the ORFE department. Very fair, very interesting, very dedicated to students. He would stay extra for office hours and was extremely understanding about workload. He was new this year so I'm not sure what his grading policies are yet, but as far as teaching goes he was THE BEST
If the professor is Amirali - take it. You won't regret it. Really great professor to have, and good subject matter to understand.

If you're interested in optimization, I think you have to take this course.  It is much more than ORF 307, and even explains linear programming better than 307 in my opinion.  Additonally, Amirali really cares about his students, and values and appreciates our input.  I felt as if we were all in the course together, not that we were disconnected from him because he's a professor.
If you're interested, take it. Know MATLAB beforehand though.
Start problem sets early. Go to office hours!
Take it - Professor Ahmadi is a great lecturer, the material is really interesting, and it isn't too  much work.
Take it if you have the opportunity. Professor Ahmadi is one of the best I've ever had.
Take it!
Take it! More difficult than expected, but a great class nonetheless. Amirali is a great professor and a super helpful, funny guy.

Take it. I've heard bad things about previous incarnations of this class, but Professor Ahmadi is one of the top two professors I've had at Princeton, the workload isn't too intense, and the material is really interesting and relevant.

Take this class. It is manageable as non-ORFE/COS but you will get some of the skills that are good for those majors such as writing proofs etc. Amirali is an absolute beast and a super approachable professor (go to his office hours because he's helpful and also a chiller).
Take this course if your interested ion optimization.  It is more orf than cos, so be careful and realize there is a lot more math than programming

This class is really interesting - definitely take it! It's quite doable and the professor (if it's Prof. Ahmadi) is really involved. He'll want you to really understand what's going on. If taking this class, just put in your full effort on all problem sets and go to office hours to get help when you need it! You'll learn quite a lot of things and really appreciate the power of optimization in general (and how to use MATLAB of course!)

This course has been significantly revamped and Amirali (Professor Ahmadi) is an awesome guy. The course spends about half the time on convex optimization and then covers a variety of topics such as linear programming, semidefinite programming, and computational complexity (theoretical concepts like reductions and NP-completeness). There's a good balance between writing theoretical proofs and doing computational exercises in MATLAB. The course is NOT the same as ORF 307 at all - I believe 307 spends all its time on linear programming. For this reason, I think 363 is a better course for learning about optimization in general. MAT 203-204 definitely helps, 309 is pretty much irrelevant, and a working knowledge of MATLAB is essential. Lectures and problem sets really help you learn the material and are worth your while, and the midterm is reasonable. The textbook is unnecessary; the professor's notes are more than adequate. In short, take this course if you want to learn about optimization.

This is a good course, Professor Ahmadi listens to your questions, plus he answers Piazza posts very quickly and thoroughly. I think the name of the course should be "Convex Optimization." I enjoyed it a lot more than ORF 307. When you do the assignments, keep in mind that you can use for loops in CVX.
amirali is one of the most caring profs i have had in my 3.5 years at princeton, the topic is pretty important and the course provides a good overview of the field
prereqs: Multivariable Calculus: MAT 203 preferred; MAT 201 is acceptable. Linear Algebra: MAT 204 preferred; MAT 202 is acceptable. Familiarity with MATLAB. Familiarity with basics of probability and random variables (e.g., at the level of ORF 309) is recommended but not required..
descrip: An introduction to several fundamental and practically-relevant areas of numerical computing with an emphasis on the role of modern optimization. Topics include computational linear algebra, descent methods, basics of linear and semidefinite programming, optimization for statistical regression and classification, trajectory optimization for dynamical systems, and techniques for dealing with uncertainty and intractability in optimization problems. Extensive hands-on experience with high-level optimization software. Applications drawn from operations research, statistics, finance, economics, control theory, and engineering.

title: Mapping the Universe
reviews: Definite take if fulfilling a requirement or just have general interest in the subject.
Definitely take this course if Gott ever offers it again...he's hilarious

Do the readings - they're probably actually more useful than attending lecture. Still, lectures are useful and Prof. Gott is hilarious.

Also, do your final mapping project on a space-time diagram of a story involving time travel. It's much easier and more fun than trying to invent a brand new map projection.
Do the readings thoroughly and enjoy the course!
Don't take it unless you're willing to put in the work.

Gott is retiring, and he made this course amazing, so I'm not sure what you can expect in the future. This class is quite easy if you go to lecture and stay awake, but the midterm and final have a lot of material only covered in lecture and lectures aren't available online, so the class is probably pretty hard if you don't show up to lecture and stay awake.
Gott's retiring, so this may not be relevant, but it was an easy STN. Also very interesting and entertaining, but pretty disorganized too.
Great course with great professor!
Great, easy STN, with a fun professor and minimal work
I honestly can't give "true" feedback, since there will be a new professor next year. However, the material itself is pretty interesting. So if you're at all interested, you may as well check it out.
I took this course as PDF but towards the final became very fascinated by the material. Prof. Gott is a great professor. Overall a low-stress, fun, and eye-opening course.
I would highly recommend this course. It is not too much work and if you just do the readings, then you will find the class to be incredibly engaging. Professor Gott is the best!
I would say take it with Gott, but he's retiring...
If you are a science major and want an easy A, take this course. But if you are a science major and don't want to be bored out of your mind, don't take this course.
It's a pretty good STN--Professor Gott's lectures correspond almost EXACTLY with the readings, which is definitely nice.
It's not going to be the same without Professor Gott!!! But take it if you want a fun astronomy class.
Listen in lecture. Tests are based more on memorization than analysis, I think. :( The midterm is very easy; don't over-study for it, like I did.
Make sure to get help on the problem sets.
New professor so I don't know
No one likes maps.
Only take this course if you are really interested in the topic.
Pay attention
Perfect PDF. Hardly any work at all
Prof. Gott was amazing. This is a super interesting course. Its very unfortunate that he is retiring.
Professor Gott is not teaching anymore, so I don't know what the course will be like next year.
READ THE BOOK! It helps a lot.
Read the books.
Take any class with Professor John Richard Gott III. He is amazing!
Take it
Take it if you want a very doable STN.
Take it if you're looking for an easy STN; an A is within reach for all students willing to work hard in the course.
Take it! It is an awesome class.
Take it! You will learn a lot while having fun.
Take it.  Great perspective on our universe.

Take it. Gott is a very well-spoken and funny guy. He is by far one of the best professors I've had. One doesn't necessarily have to go to lectures, but the readings are a must. At times, it was a bit hard to know what to study for the exams, but I feel just studying his lecture slides that he puts up is enough.
Take this course for a STN. Stay engaged but it should not require more than 2 hrs of work per week, on a busy week.

The first half of the semester is much easier the second, and you won't know what to expect for problem sets or the midterm and final. The professor will be different so I'm not sure how much fun it will be, but overall it's a good course for non-science concentrators.
This is a special course. You will be missing out if you don't take it, regardless of whether you think you're interested in astronomy or not.
To sum up: easy if you have any science background, interesting, though slowly presented material, passionate professor, easy problem sets and exams. Would recommend.

WORST class I have taken at Princeton, by far. It's safe to say that I learned almost nothing. Gott's lectures are terrible. He's disorganized, incomprehensible, and all-over-the-place. I often left the room having no idea what I was supposed to have gained from sitting there for 80 minutes. The first third of the course is agonizingly slow, and the second half lacks the slightest semblance of organization or purpose. Problem sets insult us with busy work like "make and color a map of this marble". I wound up PDFing because I had no clue what I was actually supposed to be getting out of this class. This course is a total waste of your time. There's almost no work though, and learning about time travel for 2 weeks is interesting, but you could probably spare yourself the agony of Gott's lectures and just read the book.
Was definitely worth taking with Gott
Would strongly advise them to take it were it not for the fact that sadly, this year was Prof. Gott's last year teaching the course.
You are going to have to do most of the readings to do well on the exams.
definitely
descrip: We will begin by discussing the cartographers' problem of mapping the curved surface of the Earth onto a flat plane, and compare different map projections and their properties. We consider projections for mapping the Moon, Mars, Jupiter, and the sky. Other topics include mapping the solar system and galaxy, the Sloan Digital Sky Survey 3D map of the visible universe, the WMAP map of the cosmic microwave background, Einstein's mapping of space and time, and mapping the inside of the black hole. Finally, we explore the Gott-Juric Map of the Universe, showing everything from satellites in low Earth orbit to distant galaxies and quasars.

title: Numerical Methods
reviews: This was one of my favorite classes at Princeton. It has a great blend of math, computer science, and applications. I highly recommend it to anyone who has an interest in theoretical computer science. If you're a math major, you might be frustrated with the focus of the class. As someone in physics, with an interest in math and cos, this was a great class for me.
prereqs: MAT201 and 202, or MAT203 and 204, or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to numerical methods with emphasis on algorithms, applications and numerical analysis. Topics covered include solution of nonlinear equations; numerical differentiation, integration, and interpolation; direct and iterative methods for solving linear systems; numerical solutions of differential equations; two-point boundary value problems; and approximation theory. Lectures are supplemented with numerical examples using MATLAB.

title: Calculus I
reviews: -take calculus in high school
ASK QUESTIONS
Ask for Ana Menezes!
Attend lectures and you should be fine!
Be sure to try to do well on the problem sets! They don't count for much in themselves, but they really help you understand the material.
Choose a professor with more experience.
Definitely take the class.
Do all the homework assignments and practice using old quizzes and exams.
Do all the problem sets, go to lectures, go to office hours, do all the previous exams quizzes etc. Just practice all the time.
Do lots of practice exams to study for the midterm/final.
Do not be afraid to go to office hours - your professor is there for you!
Do problem sets thoroughly and use review materials.
Do the homework in a group and go to McGraw it really speeds things up and I think you learn better.
Do the practice exams.
Do the problem sets and go to office hours! Do practice problems to study.
Do you work and study.
Do your problem sets. Practice a lot for the exams!

Doing the psets will get you average grades, a little more if maths is your thing. If it is not, practice on extra exercises. Solving a math problem quickly (which is what you are asked on the tests) comes with practice and experience.

Don't (unless you gotta or really like math)

If you decide to do it anyway, I would advise looking for multiple sources to help explain stuff. Calculus for Dummies is a good book, and if you go on Youtube, PatrickJMT is really helpful and can explain most of the topics covered. It's imperative that you understand what you're doing, because the class will be a nightmare otherwise.
Don't be afraid to ask questions, go to Mcgraw, office hours etc. It's not a class that if you fall behind you can catch up on your own.

Don't come into this course without prior knowledge of calculus. You are expected to know the basic concepts already. Go to office hours, tutoring, and study sessions as much as you can, and look at past exams and quizzes to get a feel for what yours will be like.
Don't take it without a reason. Take it if it is a prerequisite, but not if you have no intention of using it. It is challenging if you don't have the motivation.
Don't take the class if you don't need it for a requirement, and you're 100% sure.
Don't worry if you bombed the exam. So did everyone else.
Dont miss any lectures
Fairly easy course with only one assignment a week typically.
Go to class and pay attention
Go to class. Put work into your homework.
Go to office hours if you do not understand something

Go to office hours often and learn how to prove statements (rather than simply solve problems) as early on as possible.  This course took up the majority of my study time and I still did poorly, even after doing well in high school calculus, so be prepared to either work very hard or get a terrible grade.
Good intro calculus course
Hard class.
I recommend this course. As long as you keep on top of your work it's ok.
I think it really depends on what teacher you get.
I took BC Calc and did fairly well in it, yet for the majority of the time I felt completely lost in this class.
I would advise going to  every lecture.
I would advise other students taking this course to take advantage of office hours and keep up with the course material.

I would advise other students to go each section in the book thoroughly before doing the corresponding problems -- it is worth the while in exams and quizzes. If they get stuck on a problem, office hours are a great option, and McGraw can be a life saver as well.
I would advise them to go to office hours.
I would not recommend taking this course unless you have to.

I would not take this course. There are many students who have taken calculus in high school who are taking this course making it very difficult for those taking calculus for the first time or for those who do not have a strong of a background in calculus to ask questions and be able to take advantage of the course. Although tutoring helped, I would not recommend the class. The lectures are also not as helpful as just reading the book.
I would recommend it. Take it, but make sure you do all the homework.
If it is a pre-req, take it and work hard and finish it!

If possible, get Jon Fickenscher. He does a great job explaining concepts and keeping everyone engaged. Also just an incredibly nice guy in general. I wouldn't recommend the course unless you need it, in which case it's not too bad.
If they do the problem sets and keep up with their work and notes from lecture they will do fine on assessments.
If you get Fickenscher, be thankful. He's the best. You'll have such a great understanding of calculus after this class.
If you have to take math 103 definitely try to take it with Mr. Fickenscher. His explanations are good, he has an American accent, and he is helpful during office hours.
If you stay on your work, by going to all the classes, and going to McGraw for your p-sets, and putting in appropriate time studying, you will do well in this course.
If you want a review on the first half of Calculus(before integrals) then take the course. Otherwise I do not think it is that necessary.
If you want to do well in the course practice a lot of the material on your own.
It's a good class to take. Stay on top of the homework.
It's helpful to already know calculus.
Just don't fall behind and you should be fine, definitely take practice questions and exams before you take any test.
