Just go there to learn. Forget about grades for this.
Make sure to do the problem sets. If you don't do the problem sets then you won't be able to do well on the exams or quizzes
Make sure to start problem sets the week before, the sooner the better. That way you will not be stressed right before it's due and you will have time to go to office hours and study for the quiz.
Make sure to try hard even if you have seen all of the material before.
Make sure you actually want to learn Calculus. You cannot just show up and think you'll pass, you need to do the work and pay attention.
Make sure you do the homework.
Make sure you go to all classes and take notes
Make sure you have taken AB in hs, or you will have a hard time.
Make sure you review certain things before you get here, as it is baptism by fire

Make sure you spend adequate time studying for this course throughout the semester. Do not put off studying for the final until reading week. It is very helpful to get head starts on all assignments, quizzes, and studying.
Make sure you understand ALL the theorems and memorize everything, because the course is very theory based, unlike high-school where you just use all the rules.
Only take it if you need it for a specific major.
Only take the class if you can get Jon as a teacher.  I had Maria (for a brief period of time) and then Mihaela, and both were significantly worse.
Practice!

Professor Fickenscher is a fantastic teacher, and you should try and get him. Professor Fickenscher is a fantastic teacher and teaches the concepts very well. He is very open to taking questions and never seems to look down on people. He really wants the students to learn and love calculus.

Professor Jonathan Fickenscher is a really good professor, and a student would be able to learn a lot from his lectures. 
Additionally, professor Fickenscher would be able to explain well each question that a student has. Therefore, I strongly recommend taking courses that are thought by Jonathan Fickenscher!
Read the book. Go to lecture. Don't procrastinate.  If you have never taken calculus, do not take this class.
Start on your assignments early.
Stay on top of assignments and do practice exams.
Study regularly and take all classes.
Study!
Take it if you have the motivation or if you need to
Take it if you have to or if you like math. Even though it's Calc I, they make it as hard as they can, so watch out. Also, start your problem sets early. Night before can cause problems.
Take it if you need a QR requirement or are interested in math.
Take it if you need a math class. Not very hard but not boring, so a good class.
Take it if you need to learn calc
Take lots of notes during lecture (and don't skip lectures) because they are very useful in preparation for the exams.
Take notes during class. It may not seem important for math, but many of the quiz and exam questions are covered in class discussions.
Take the course, but make sure you have a solid foundation in Math.

Take this course if you are a math-y person. Most people in the class already know everything that is going on. if you are taking this for the distribution requirement and you are not a math person you will soon realise that taking this course is like riding a bicycle, except the bicycle is on fire, and everything is on fire because you are in hell.
Take this course if you need to build upon your fundamental calculus skills
Take this course.
Take with Professor Fefferman.
Take your problem sets to office hours.
The assessments (tests & quizzes) go beyond the simple book scope. They take it to the next level and beyond. Do not expect homework questions on your assessments or else you will be blindsided.
The class is very pace friendly.
This course was great. I enjoyed it.
This is a challenging course but not by any stretch of the imagination impossibly hard.

This is pretty much Calc AB. We started off with limits and finished with integration and Reimann sums. 
If you took Calc BC in high school, and are pre-med looking to fulfill the calc requirement (not all med schools accept AP credit), take this class. Easy, breezy, beautiful. 
The p-set doesn't take too long to do, the textbook is crap (but the prof teach all you need to know), and office hours are frequent and very helpful.
Try to do as much as possible by yourself in the problem sets and collaborate when you reached a point at which you don't know how to proceed. Furthermore, use the office hours!
Yes I would advise students to take this course.
You have to be willing to put in a great deal of effort and sometimes the class materials do not help with examinations. This is an at your own risk kind of class.
You will learn a lot of math in this course.
do the practice quizzes/exams

i would recommend this course for a good introduction to calculus, or if you have already taken a first year of calculus in high school, it is a good review and refresher course, as well as being one that you can easily do well in.
if you have to take calc, this course was relatively painless
its hard and fast paced, but grades are curved  and fair.
make sure you go to class and take good notes.
take is if you like calc
take it if interested in math
teacher makes a difference
work hard
work the problem sets early so that if you have any questions you will have time to get them answered
prereqs: MAT 100 or equivalent. Solid knowledge of precalculus (standard functions, algebra, trigonometry) is assumed..
descrip: First semester of calculus. Topics include limits, continuity, the derivative, basic differentiation formulas and applications (curve-sketching, optimization, related rates), definite and indefinite integrals, the fundamental theorem of calculus.

title: Artificial Desires
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

profs.name: Esther Roseli da Costa Azevedo Meyer

title: Art in Translation: From East to West and Back - History of Architecture
descrip: This seminar focuses on the translatability of cultural artifacts that resulted from Western trade and Western colonialism in Asia during the modern age. Main topics include the constitution of portable objects as art; the role of Museums in nation-building and the self-imagination of empires; the "discovery" of ancient monuments in colonized territories and the restoration practices that made them accessible - at a price - to colonizers; the repression implied by the very notion of translation and the cultural forces of resistance to which it gave rise in colonized areas.

title: Seminar in Japanese Art and Archaeology - Painting Painting, Japan
descrip: Historically Japanese painters worked in modes based on previous paintings: idioms associated with subject matter, national source, and formal qualities. Yamatoe, or "Japanese painting," first identified paintings depicting indigenous landscapes and came to be associated with an array of formal characteristics and native subjects. Karae, or "Tang painting," indicated styles and subjects associated with China. A mode often endured for centuries, even as new ones appeared (such as Yoga, or "Western painting"). This longevity and concurrence had many consequences, including the creation of hybrids that remade meaning.

title: History of American Popular Entertainments
descrip: This course investigates the history of popular entertainments in the United States from the colonial era to the present. Moving briskly among some of the myriad sites, sounds and spectacles that have captivated diverse American audiences, this course tracks how entertainment genres, venues, personalities and phenomena have shaped U.S. culture in enduring and significant ways. This course examines how U.S. entertainment--as simultaneously industrial operation and cultural production--has mapped routes of social encounter, mobility and resistance, while also serving as a platform for individual expression and imaginative escape.

title: History of East Asia to 1800
reviews: Definitely take this course if you have any interest at all in China, Japan, or history in general. Very well taught and interesting. However, not all the readings are necessary; lots of the secondary sources you can skim.
Definitely take this course! It is worth it.
Great course, great teachers, and you'll learn a ton.
Take it if interesting in East Asian History
This course provides a good overview of pre-1800 history in East Asia.  Both professors are enthusiastic and approachable.

This is a very well-done course about politically powerful men and major intellectual movements in Japan and China. While this is helpful, the course does not really discuss economic or popular histories.
none
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: A general introduction to the history of the political cultures in China and Japan, with some heed to comparisons with developments in Korea and the Mediterranean worlds.

title: Design of Very Large-Scale Integrated (VLSI) Systems
reviews: Come in prepared. It's a lot of work, and if you don't have any circuit background perhaps take something else first.

Definitely a difficult course, but very interesting. Verma moves you from the device level up to basic computer architecture, and does a great job of conveying the challenges of VLSI along the way. Psets are very hard, especially the first couple. Work in groups if you can.
Good course, but know going into it that there is a lot of work on the problem sets and final project.
I will recommend it to others.
If you have interest in digital circuit design, this class is highly recommended.
If you're interested in computing or circuits, it's a must-take. Lots of work but well worth it.
It's a lot of work and the course is very heavily front loaded, but Professor Verma is a super enthusiastic lecturer who is fun to listen to and great at explaining things.
Make sure you have the time to put in for HW and project. Always go to lectures.
Should be taken if you want to develop an intuition about current day challenges in high-performance chip design.
Start problem sets early!
This course is a must for circuit designers as well as computer architects. The professor teaches very well and the combination of coursework really helps to understand practical issues.

This course is greatly helpful. Maybe you will experience a relatively large work load on the first homework, but that is already the most tough time of taking this course. You will definitely find how useful and interesting this course is during the whole semester.
What's an order of magnitude between friends?
descrip: Analysis and design of digital integrated circuits using deep sub-micron CMOS technologies as well as emerging and post-CMOS technologies (Si finFETs, III-V, carbon). Emphasis on design, including synthesis, simulation, layout and post-layout verification.Analysis of energy, power, performance, area of logic-gates, interconnect and signaling structures.

title: Research Methods in Psychology
reviews:
Be careful, they're planning long labs! Haha

It was good, we learned a lot about research methods. We even learned things that many grad students and other researchers do not understand.
Bear through it.
Do not take this class unless you are super super super interested in research methods.
Do the readings and go to lecture.
Don't if at all possible. Switching majors would be preferable to this course in most cases.
Don't take this class. Oh wait, its a required course for the psych department.
Don't take this unless you have to.
Good luck- go to all classes and precepts.
I would strongly recommend any student NOT to take this class. Unfortunately, it is a required departmental and we HAVE to take it...
I'll pray for you, it will be rough.
If I was not literally being forced to take this class I would not be here.

If you are a psychology major, I have bad news for you...it's mandatory. My only advice would be to never show up to any of the lectures because it does nothing but make you contemplate suicide and waste your time. Todorov might actually be on drugs, because you have to be high in order to actually think that this crap is interesting. Just pray someone else is in the class is really smart and ride their coattails to a solid C
It changes every year. Good luck.
It is a course that you just have to make it through.  It is not fun, but just make sure you do the readings.
Not a bad course but you don't really learn that much. What you do learn is important and useful though. It's sort of like taking half a course.
Read the book.
Read the textbook chapters before lectures.
Review lecture notes because most of the exam questions are based on lecture notes. There are some based on the textbook readings and the precept readings.
Talk to Todorov about how to approach this class--focus on the broad and big ideas. It's a methods class. Approach it as that and only that.
This course is boring and frustrating, but not impossible to get through.
Unfortunately you have to take this class if you're a Psychology major, but you should try and fight to change it because at this point it is a complete waste of time.
You have to take it, and they're still working on it so I'm hopeful for you, but grading was really difficult and the class was boring/confusing
You'll have to take it as a psych student. Don't expect too much.
don't take it unless you have to
only take if required
prereqs: This course is offered to PSY concentrators only, and is offered every fall term. Students who are unable to take the course in the fall of their junior year (e.g., study abroad students) must take the course in their senior year or fulfill the requirement by another course at Princeton or at another university (subject to approval by the Departmental Representative). Early concentrators will be permitted to take the course as long as they have satisfied the prerequisite for the course (PSY 251 or the equivalent)..
descrip: This course will expose students to approaches and methods used in psychology research in an effort to provide foundational knowledge and prepare undergraduates for independent research. The first half of the course will address issues pertinent to all psychology research (experimental design, literature review, ethics, statistics and data interpretation). The second half of the course will focus on specific approaches and methods used by different subfields of Psychology, and will be team-taught by experts in the given area with the assistance of graduate students, and postdocs in running the precepts.

title: General Plasma Physics I
reviews: Awesome topic and sweet professors.  The problem sets and exams can be frustrating though.
Don't work the homework to death, use it as a tool to learn and derive most of your understanding from the solutions/exam preparation.
Take if you're interested in plasma physics.
Take it if you plan to study plasma physics or are in any way interested.
Very well-taught course. However, if you are seeking background for work in research, you may be better off auditing. Talk to people who have taken the course beforehand.
descrip: An introductory course to plasma physics, with sample applications in fusion, space and astrophysics, semiconductor etching, microwave generation, plasma propulsion, high power laser propagation in plasma; characterization of the plasma state, Debye shielding, plasma and cyclotron frequencies, collision rates and mean-free paths, atomic processes, adiabatic invariance, orbit theory, magnetic confinement of single-charged particles, two-fluid description, magnetohydrodynamic waves and instabilities, heat flow, diffusion, kinetic description, and Landau damping. The course may be taken by undergraduates with permission of the instructor.

title: Problems in Greek History - Classical and Hellenistic Inscriptions
descrip: Greek inscriptions provide especially valuable information on the political life, institutions and social structures of Greek society. The aim of the course is to give an introduction to the use of epigraphic documents in historical research. The sessions are devoted to the analysis of particular aspects of Greek society (e. g. relationships between city and country, king and city, Greeks and non-Greeks) on the basis of inscriptions from the Classical and Hellenistic periods.

title: Intermediate Portuguese
reviews: If you're interested in taking Portuguese with an amazing professor take any intro Portuguese class with Luis.

Luis is awesome and take the class with him. It's a lot of grammar focused work and the bookwork can sometimes be busywork. But I loved the reading Diva, just make sure you keep up with it. It's a good class and your portuguese will improve
Make to study and understand the grammar and verb tenses on your own time, not covered in class very much and you will be expected to know these things for assessments
Relax and have fun. If there's anything Luis has taught me, that's the best way to learn a language.
Take it! Significantly more rigorous than POR108 though.
Take this course. If you're good enough with languages to handle it, it will be invaluable to you, and you'll come away being able to read, write, and speak Portuguese.
prereqs: POR 108 or instructor's permission.
descrip: Students will further develop their language skills, especially those of comprehension and oral proficiency, through grammar review, readings, film and other activities. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to give in only one year of study a command of the Portuguese language sufficient for travel in Brazil, Portugal and beyond.

title: Junior Seminars
reviews: Be warned that Professor Gross does not give huge amounts of feedback and is not the most proactive of Professor's. He won't hound you about deadlines, so you have to make sure you create them yourself if you want his advice.
Devote a lot of time to this class every week
Do all of the readings, participate in discussion, and go to office hours.

Do as much work as you can early.  It does really add up, and its much easier to do it while you have Professor Jacobs to help you in person and access to primary sources and the libraries in Princeton.  Also start the weekly readings early, too, because it can be hard to read a full book the night before the class.

Do research for the JP early, but most importantly stay organized in your research. It won't be that helpful if you get research done early but then cannot find sources, make sense of that research later on.
Do the reading and be interested. Not for those who just want to fly under the radar.
Do the readings and understand that they are really there to help you.  Go talk to Professor Lozano and ask for help when you need it.
Dweck is brilliant, but not patient with those who have no background in European history. If the seminar's topic is one of your interests, take it, if not, it may prove trying.
Even if you're not interested in Latin American history, take this seminar because you'll learn how to actually pursue independent work.
I can't recommend enough taking Professor Cannadine's junior seminar!
I highly recommend Professor Lozano's course! She is a dedicated teacher and works to help you become a better historian and writer!

I like Prof. Jacobs, but I personally was looking for a more hands-on advisor to teach me how to do research and about the writing process. It is hard to be in her class (graded 50% class participation, 50% primary source journal) when other HIS majors are taking 'legitimate' HIS 400 classes and actually learning how to do research, becoming better prepared for the semesters that we're on our own. It might seem easier to have less work at the time, but it comes back to haunt you later.
If possible, take the required seminar with Professor Lozano.
If you are interested in the area/period, then recommend.
If you are looking for a low key course with lesser guidance in  JP writing, you should take this one.

If you have a conscience, you will work harder in this class than you ever have before. Professor Karl is so genuinely interested in your success that you can't help but give your best every class; you know he's doing even more for you. This is a class that reminds you why you're a history major. I would recommend it to anyone, regardless of interest or experience because of Professor Karl. You can't help but love his class.

If you're willing to work hard throughout the entire semester and have at least a vague interest in Latin America, definitely take it with Professor Karl. He's supportive, gives great feedback, puts a lot of personal interest into your project, and will definitely push you to write the best paper possible. If you don't plan on putting a lot of effort in,  try a different seminar.
Please take this JP seminar with Professor Dweck! Or any other class with him for that matter.

Professor Dweck gives honest and challenging feedback that will improve your writing more than the commentary other professors provide. He directs discussion expertly and makes every topic engaging, regardless of whether or not it was of major interest to you beforehand.

Professor Gross is an awesome guy: quite intelligent, super interesting to talk to, and incredibly nice. That said, if you are the kind of person who needs a professor to set guidelines or provide more than a superficial level of supervision as you write your JP, I would not recommend taking this HIS 400 Seminar. I don't feel as if I effectively learned how to write a JP in this course, and Professor Gross' style is a little to laissez faire for me.
Professor Gross is an extremely interesting academic who has a lot of personal insight on this topic. Do not expected active advising or instruction when it comes to assignments.
Professor Jacobs is patient and goes out of her way to work with you on the JP. Great advisor.
Professor Karl is a bit demanding, and you should probably have some interest in 20th century latin american history but you will write a better JP than any other junior seminar.
Professor Karp is amazing!
Professor Lozano is great.

Start thinking about your JP early, and make sure you understand how sources work. That means that more importantly than looking at every page of reading assigned is understanding WHAT the scholar is doing and why, and to place the sources in an array together: it not only helps in understanding how to research but it arranges the material itself in a much more comprehensible and significant way in understanding the history of the time.
Stay on top of your deadlines and start your research very early
Take anything with Professor Karl.
Take it - Prof. Karp is great!

Take it if you're interested in the time period and one of the various conflicts we are discussing in class. Try to manage your time well and start deciding a topic and researching as early as possible. Doing your best for individual assignments (source essay, prospectus etc) along the way will help immensely in visualizing and shaping your final paper. This class' strength (the breadth in topic allowing you to find something that you're really interested in) can also be challenging because there is a huge amount of material that you could choose to write about and it's hard to decide, but don't be afraid to ask Prof Karp for advice and try to decide things early. Language proficiency in the area you are interested in also helps a lot. The primary source is king!
Take it!
Take notes. Be pro-active. This is your JP we are talking about.
Take the Junior Sem with Prof. Karl! He's the best! You'll get the best feedback, guidance, and support throughout the entire JP process.
Take this course!!
Take this!
Terrific course, terrific professor--could not recommend more highly!
The topic, lecture, and readings were all fascinating. However, if you decide to take this from Dr. Dweck, be prepared to have your ideas, opinions, and research questioned with every step you take.

Try really hard to get Professor Karl as your seminar professor. He is amazing as far as providing guidance for the JP and also just seems to know everything about Latin America, so he is a great resource for any topic you might choose.
Try to make the most of it- the readings are interesting, and the discussions of structure can be quite helpful.  Also, office hours for your specific questions.
take it. LOTS of work but RLY awesome
prereqs: Compulsory course for departmental majors in the fall of their junior year..
descrip: The Junior Seminar serves to introduce departmental majors to the tools, methods, and interpretations employed in historical research and writing. This course is compulsory for departmental majors and is taken in the fall of the junior year. Students may choose from a range of topics. Seminar topics will tend to be cross-national and comparative.

title: Christian Ethics and Modern Society
reviews: A good class to p/d/f without too much effort! Readings are manageable, lectures are inspiring but not necessary for papers and exams. Get Beth Stroud for your precept - she is super helpful and organized!
Complete the readings on time and you should be fine. Pay attention to the questions Professor Gregory poses in lecture.

Courses like this are why Princeton requires and ethics or morality class. Take it. Doesn't matter if you're a Christian, atheist, prospective REL major, or a mathematician just trying to fulfill that EM requirement, every student can benefit from this course. It might not change your life dramatically, but this course offers a new perspective on history, politics, social issues, and everyday decision-making.
Do all of the required readings! And highlight interesting/important points as you go. It will make your life much easier once the midterm and final approach.
Do as much reading as you can and go to precepts because a lot of the material will be further explained and made understandable.
Do the readings and stay organized because the course revolves around them.
Do the readings; it makes lectures much more enjoyable and a lot less boring.
Do your readings
Good but not a great course. Hard to keep coming to lectures as the year goes on. Precept was very good though
Great course with interesting readings and lectures. A perfect choice for a P/D/F distribution as well.

I came in with high expectations and was disappointed. I don't feel like I really learned all that much, and I definitely get the sense I'm just jumping through a hoop to get a distribution requirement. That said, it is incredibly easy.
I definitely recommend taking this course.
I love it. It's a Fantastic course. Praise the Lord. May God bless you!

I recommend taking it. If you are a Christian, it is good to understand the bigger picture of your faith. You can see how different people interpret God's word, and figure out for yourself where you stand on many issues. If you are not a Christian, this class is a good exposure to understand Christianity as not only a religion, but how it has shaped America and many of the debates today.

I took for an easy EM, and it pretty much met the criteria (especially considering I was already very familiar with Christian ethics). I hear Tibetan Buddhism is also an easy EM, so consider that as well as this course.
I would advise the another student to stay ahead of the reading, even if you are just skimming it.

I would recommend PDFing if possible. Most weeks there is just too much reading to finish. Engage as much as you can in class, because if you do, it's really rewarding. This is class that you can definitely apply to your everyday life. However, you can also get by passively, it's just not as rewarding.

I would take it again. It's interesting and some of the readings are really engaging. Great for a distribution requirement or if you just want to listen to different perspectives on how a Christian should act in the modern world.

I'd definitely recommend this. There's a decent amount of reading to digest, but they're usually extremely interesting. I appreciated how a huge diversity of views were represented in the precepts and in the readings.
If looking for easy class, take it.

If you are exceptionally good at having objective, academic discussion, the course is a great opportunity for practice with many different viewpoints and philosophical schools.  If, like me, you are truly passionate and firm in your beliefs on any of the topics -- war, race, gender, the death penalty, the environment, etc. -- then the course will require an exhausting amount of forced neutrality.  There is an almost endless wealth of ideas to be gained from the course, but to access them requires an incredible amount of time and patience for potentially disagreeable stances.  It is easy to glide through the course without putting in much work, but there are better EMs to do that with.

If you aren't Christian, you will feel like you have been dropped into a fantasy land where several unfounded assumptions reign as supreme law. You will learn how these assumptions clash with one another, but you will never hear a good reason to buy into the assumptions in the first place. Enter at your own risk.

If you have to take ethics, this isn't a bad one to take. Easy exams. I had heard that precept can get very heated, but it truly varies on the mix of people in your class. Skim the readings to get the main gist and use precept to clarify the arguments in the readings.
If you want an easier 5th class and have an otherwise hard courseload, this is a pretty good class to take. Don't do all of the readings necessarily though...
If you're good at keeping up with reading take it. But it's A LOT of reading and the tests are pretty hard.

If you're interested in learning about how Christianity interacts with society today, take this course. Whether you're Christian or not - it's one of the rare courses that will stay with you. I learned a lot about myself and the world. Would strongly recommend it.
Interesting course. Would recommend to students with at least some knowledge of Christianity.
It's a good course to take if you're remotely interested in Christianity.
Its a pretty easy class if you have a good preceptor. If not, I am sorry.
Its a pretty good course for an EM requirement.
Keep up with the readings and try to develop an opinion.
More than just about Christianity. You'll learn about yourself and your community and our country.
N/A
Not bad.
Read the articles.
Stay on top of the readings. Exams and papers not too difficult given some effort. Good pdf.
TAKE IT.
Take it even if you do not have to
Take it.
Take it.  You don't need to be Christian.  The readings are fascinating so don't skip them.

Take it. I had no religious background, and didn't feel like I was at a significant disadvantage. This class is not only interesting, but will impact how you think about issues in the world. It's a very important class.
Take it. It's super interesting. The papers are not too long and will make you think.

Take it. This is the best class I've taken at Princeton. Honestly, I think it's what a college education should be about - thinking hard about difficult questions, with clear implications for how you live your own life, and how you engage with the world. Professor Gregory is wonderful and cares deeply about his subject, making the lectures very engaging.
Take the course and do as much of the readings as you can, they really make you think.

Take this course even if you are not Christian. In fact, take this course regardless of whatever religion you are. This is not a course that is designed to shove Christianity down your throat. This is a course that will help you understand reason why people believe the things they do. How do people justify their most cherished convictions? This course will help bring you closer to your fellow neighbor in terms of understanding as well as empathy.
Take this course! It covers thought-provoking material, Professor Gregory is excellent, and it makes you re-think and ground your beliefs about ethical dilemmas.
Take this if you are at all interested in Christian Ethics!
Take this if you want to learn an overview of the many different sides of each topic. Won't be too deep on framework or anything, though.

This course is fantastic. As a Christian, I feel like it has really broadened my understanding of my faith. The course isn't difficult at all, and the readings are somewhat lengthy towards the end of the semester but overall teach you so much about Christian ethics, and are very interesting. And gregory is fantastic. I feel like he's so much better in precept though, so you should try to get him as preceptor if you can.
This is an awesome class!!  There's quite a bit of reading, but the overall workload is reasonable, and it's a lot of fun.
This is the best course I have taken at Princeton so far. Take it. Gregory is a boss.
Try to find a study group to split the readings. Work on the papers in advance; they're short but easy to leave to the last minute.

i didnt want to take it. even though i had heard such good things about it. but then i ended up taking it and am super glad for it. so you should take it too. even if you have reservations...in the long run you wont regret it
take the class! it's worht it.
yes recommend - awesome course
descrip: An introduction to Christian ideals of conduct, character, & community, & to modern disputes over their interpretation & application. Are Christian virtues & principles fundamentally at odds with the ethos of liberal democracy oriented toward rights, equality, & freedom? What do Christian beliefs & moral concepts imply about issues related to feminism, racism, & pluralism? What is the relationship between religious convictions, morality, & law? Special emphasis on selected political & economic problems, sexuality & marriage, bioethics, capital punishment, the environment, war, terrorism & torture, & the role of religion in public life.

title: Race and Ethnicity
reviews: A chill and easy course. PFK is fun and interesting and the exams are brief and low-stakes.
Always take a PFK course.
Ask questions when you are confused!
Ask the professor or your preceptor for clarification of concepts if you do not fully understand them.
Be prepared to put the time into this course that it deserves if you want to get something meaningful out of it.
Definitely take it.
Definitely take this class, and do your best to actively engage yourself
Do all the readings and ask a lot of questions
Do the readings! Don't wait until midterms or finals to do them all.
Do the readings! Go to office hours!
Favorite class so far
For a distribution requirement, I would definitely recommend it.

Go into the course with an open mind. I understand that many students here live a privileged, sheltered life, and thus think these topics are not relevant. I understand many people want to take this course to get rid of their SA requirement. Please listen to what PFK says - she is a brilliant professor, she can captivate an audience, and her contribution to this topic at an institution that not only routinely accepts privileged, ignorant white individuals who then leave this school and go work in fields that directly affect marginalized groups is EXTREMELY NECCESSARY.

Go to lectures because PFK is an amazing lecturer and will make you think. The course is pretty easy even as a sociology course because you literally do the bare minimum amount of work; you turn in two 6-8 page papers, one as a midterm and one as a final. Readings are interesting but often there's a lot of them and you usually just need the general ideas and not the actual details. The main thing to take away is that race is always and everywhere relevant.

Honestly this class should be freshmen only. It's a very cursory overview of a range of topics related to race. I found lecture super disorganized and felt like most students in precept could care less.

I strongly recommend this course to other students. I also would say that be prepared to make comments in precept that might place you out of your comfort zone, but the conversations they ignite will be well worth it.

I would advise another students to stay on top of the readings because there are a lot. I would also suggest going to office hours, because Professor Kelly is a great individual and cares a lot about her students.

I would advise students to listen attentively in lecture, because Professor Fernandez-Kelly does a wonderful job summarizing and analyzing the course readings, preparing students well for the course exams.
I would advise the student to read carefully, as the readings are very well written and complex. The course does a good job at presenting good writing and research to us.

I would recommend doing all the readings before lecture and coming to precept with questions for clarification or discussion. It is these questions/answers that are most useful when writing the final paper.

I would recommend taking a course with PFK to anyone. She is very politically opinionated and not afraid to share her opinions with the class. This should not scare those with different political opinions from her from taking her class. You can learn a lot, challenge your ideas, and she will definitely take time outside of class to get to know anyone one-on-one regardless. Dope class. Would recommend this class to anyone.
I would recommend this course. It isn't as easy as everyone makes it out to be, but you will definitely learn something by the end of it.

I would take this course if you are comfortable with PFK's teaching style.  She relies on big picture concepts that will not always align with the syllabus.  I appreciate this method, but some may find it confusing if you are inflexible.

If she takes an interest in you, milk it. Don't be afraid to go up to her after lecture and ask questions or give your thoughts! Do the reading. Do not browse the internet in lecture. She will see you and call you out. PFK is amazing and knows her stuff.
It's an interesting class; I would recommend it.
Lectures are really repetitive and the readings are long and dry, but it's still not that hard to do well on exams
Make sure to organize your papers well. This is key!
PFK IS A SUPERSTAR TAKE IT XO

PFK is a really entertaining and engaging lecturer (and go to lecture, because she notices who is and isn't there and may call you out by name). Know going in that PFK advocates a VERY liberal agenda rather than an unbiased view of the material, but she's upfront about it. Do the readings, participate in precept, not for the grade but because yoll find the discussions very intellectually stimulating.
PFK is awesome she really likes to engage with the students and the professor student relationship is great. It helps you stay engaged in the course and makes you not want to mess up or skip class.
PFK is great. I managed to get into her precept, which was even better. Take the course.
PFK kinda just lectures on whatever she wants to, but the class is interesting and easy none the less.
Pretty easy class. Just go to lecture. You learn a lot if you're interested.
Read the readings carefully, and also look out for examples of the racism and societal norms you learn in class.

Really cool class to have taken in the current political climate. This class has hardly any work. They tell you what readings are needed to answer the essay exam questions, so you technically don't even need to read all semester except for midterm/final....

Stay on top of the readings as best you can. Most of them aren't too long, but it's just hard to read so much while you're also stressing about writing an essay. Also, come to lecture! PFK is inspired!!
TAKE THIS CLASS.
Take if interested/don't know much on the subject
Take it if you're interested in sociology.
Take it!
Take this class b/c you need 2 SA's anyways!
Take this class if you are interested in race and ethnicity. It gave a ton of historical context that enhances your understanding of a seemingly straightforward topic.

Take this course
It is a million times worth it.
Take this course if you are interested in sociology!
Take this course, and do the readings.
Take this course. Stay engaged, think about the theories and stay relevant in discussions. Get PFK to be your preceptor.
Take this. Now. Do it.
The course is a strong overview of prevalent authors and associated concepts in race and ethnicity.
The lectures form the foundation of the course. Attendance is necessary.

The readings in this class give you a really nuanced understanding of race formation in primarily America but also Latin America, Europe, Asia, and Africa. Try to get the main ideas from each reading so that you know exactly how to use each one come time for the take home midterm & final.
This class wasn't what I expected. It didn't focus on contemporary issues as much as I wanted and I didn't think many of the readings were very interesting.
Very interesting
Very interesting course that gets you thinking.
don't. PFK teaches the course as if a post-racial society is ideal.
if PFK notices who you are, please show up to all of the classes. she will notice who's missing.
take it if u want an easy class with no work.
take this class
take this course
this course is so good!
yes
descrip: Our goal in this course is (a) to understand various definitions of race and ethnicity from a theoretical perspective and in a plurality of contexts and (b) to account for the rise of ethnicity and race as political and cultural forces in the age of globalization. Why are ethnic and racial delimitations expanding in areas of the world where such distinctions were formerly muted? Is race and racial discrimination all the same regardless of geographical region? What are the main theories and methodologies now available for the study of race and ethnicity from a comparative point of view? These are among the questions our course aims to answer.

title: M.Arch. Thesis Seminar
reviews: Absolutely recommend. Essential. Though it should only be taken in your semester before thesis. Many of the new students didn't have a thesis/well formed opinions. The "mix" of pre-thesis and students fresh out of the gate was very frustrating.
Although apparently specific for a thesis project, what Sylvia Lavin teaches is a pleasurous research protocol. Tremendously useful for tasks that vary from writing an article to producing a PHD.
Listen to every word Sylvia says.
This course helps you to establish and evolve the ideas you have for your masters thesis project. I would strongly encourage everyone to enroll.
prereqs: Open to students in the final year of the M.Arch. program.
descrip: This course will support students in the development of a broad range of thesis topics optimized to the faculty of the SoA. A series of exercises will guide students to identify the primary questions that currently structure the discipline and those extra-disciplinary concerns which architecture must engaged today. Throughout the work, analyses of these issues will be linked to contemporary architectural production. All work will be conducted by small teams and will harness the dynamic feedback between specifically architectural problematics and the general logic of contemporary culture in preparation for future thesis work.

title: Africa, Africans, and the Atlantic Slave Trade
reviews: Do the work and take it seriously. You'll reap what you sow.

It's a great course on a distressing subject matter. Without understanding the long term impact of the Atlantic slave trade it is hard to understanding the inequalities that persist today. I recommend this course.
To think through what you'd like to "get out of" the course because it covers so much information that you couldn't possibly absorb everything.
descrip: The seminar highlights the major approaches to and debates about Africa's rich and complicated history with a focus on the impact of the Atlantic slave trade. Topics include the nature of African societies before the era of the Atlantic slave trade; the shifting of Africa's political and economic center of gravity from the interior to the coastal regions; and the demographic, social, and political impact of the slave trade on the Atlantic world including the underdevelopment of Africa and slave resistance in the Americas.

title: Readings in Latin Literature - The World of Pliny's Letters
reviews: Do all the reading and you'll be fine. Since most of the themes found in the letters are not  obvious, it'll be helpful to take notes in class.

I can't recommend this course strongly enough. If you think letters written by an old Roman senator might be dull, think again! Professor Haynes picks out the most entertaining letters to translate, and puts every letter in precise historical and cultural context. You will not regret taking this course, and will leave it with fond memories of Pliny and a great appreciation of Rome after the Augustan period.
Take it! Professor Haynes is awesome. Pliny can be boring sometimes but the majority of it is really interesting.
This is a good class, but you will have to participate a lot in class and the letters can be a bit dry sometimes; this isn't always super exciting but it is always interesting.
prereqs: LAT 108 or permission of instructor..
descrip: A reading course in Pliny's letters. We will learn to read Latin prose fluently and explore the political, social, and cultural world of an early second century AD Roman senator.

title: Microprocessors for Measurement and Control
reviews: ***TAKE IT***. This was hands down my favorite course in MAE (and possibly at Princeton). Essentially, this course is "Electrical Engineering for Mechanical Engineers" (and it has very little to do with what you learned in PHY 104). In fact, you literally get to build a computer during the first half of the semester. Professor Littman is an amazing instructor and Jon could not possibly be more insightful in the lab. Just make sure that if you take it, you follow their two main pieces of advice: 1. ALWAYS use the oscilloscope to debug, and 2. Start "crunch time" for your final project EARLY.
Attend lecture.
Definitely take it! It's a lot of work, but it's really worth it.
For any engineer who meets the prerequisites, I would highly recommend this course. Big time commitment, but you'll learn a lot and have a great time.

Great class - really lets you get hands-on with some real live engineering.  Scope of the material is extremely broad, which makes it challenging when you want to understand everything and can't.  Big time commitment, but it's semi-fun work.
If you like building things this is a great class.
If you love circuits take this course. Good instruction.
It is a VERY rewarding class but you need to be ready to put in a lot of time into the project if you have little/no experience in electronics.

Some if it is cool and rewarding. But a lot of other times you will feel like a sweatshop worker in some factory tinkering away all hours of the day and night.

And eveything will break for reason's you don't know and your life during finals when the project is due will be miserable.

Otherwise, as MAE classes go, its not horrendous. But could use a big makeover.
Take it, it's awesome, but be prepared for some brutal work during reading week/finals to get it working. Your group will make or break this project

Take this course if you like electronics but understand that it is a huge time drain during finals, especially if you end up having to debug your circuit a lot. Try to understand what is expected of you as soon as possible and work on things early.

This is an amazing course. The material covered in class is both interesting and pertinent to the final design project. The project itself is challenging but exciting. One of my favorite courses at Princeton. I would definitely recommend it to anyone with the time to spare.

Trains is a lot of fun, but know what you are getting yourself into. The project will probably take a few hundred man hours to complete because the hardware is very difficult to debug. You will learn a lot of useful lab skills, however, so if you think you're up to the task, by all means, take it.
Well, it's probably required if you're looking at it.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 224, or introductory knowledge of analog and digital electronics.
descrip: Introduction to microcomputers for measurement and control. This is a hardware course in the area of electro mechanical systems. Students design and build microcomputer controllers and apply them to the automation of various aspects of a model railroad.

title: Religion and Media
reviews: Always do the readings
Be prepared to be involved and do the work, but it is very interesting.
Engage in the conversation, which is one of the more rewarding aspects of this course.
If you are interested in Religion, Media, Advertisement, Persuasion, Social Movements, or anthropology take this course.

If you want the experience of being in a small seminar without the three hour long period, then this class is awesome. Professor Rouse will introduce texts and commentary that will challenge how you think about the role of religion, which has become an increasingly relevant topic in contemporary news. The readings are manageable, and I highly encourage you to go to Prof. Rouse's office hours if you want to get more out of the course.
Keep track of overarching themes across readings to stay oriented.
Participate in class and do the readings.
Take it. Read! and do a creative media project!
descrip: This course explores how religious media in the United States shapes cultural and social identities. From televangelism to religious radio programming, the mass marketing of faith is contributing to how people understand themselves as gendered, raced, and classed subjects. But are these programs helping to sustain a fragile consensus within and between religious communities, or are they threatening religious pluralism? This course examines what is at stake politically in this religious war of symbols generated within mediascapes.

title: Contagion
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Art of Adventure, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced French
reviews: Definitely take the textbook readings and Quia exercises (online grammar practice) seriously, as these won't be taught explicitly in class. Grammar is more important than vocabulary. Give yourself enough time on the first composition, because they seem short but until you know what pace you write at in French, it's better to have some extra time.

Great class; recommend taking it if you (like me) are a junior with good French knowledge from high school who hasn't taken a French class since. (FRE 107, which I accidentally went to, was filled with people who could not speak French.) Prof. Chenoweth is great. It also meets only three times a week. Second semester is spent on reading "The Stranger," so make sure you are interested in that.

However, I think this class gives an unrealistic amount of work. As a junior, two oral reports, a final interview, a test, two worksheets (including doing a reading and watching an entire movie) and a composition due in the last month is far too much.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I would tell future French 108 students to take advantage of the small class size. Moreover, keep track of all of the material (grammar learned, reading content, etc.) because you'll need it for future assignments in the course.

It's up to you how much you get out of this course because it's not particularly challenging, so if you really want to change and improve your french a lot of that will have to come from you independently because it won't come from your work in the classroom.
Not very 'advanced' but it's fun if you have a good class

Take it!  If you're considering between FRE 107 and FRE 108, take FRE 108.  It's less class time, you talk about fun stuff and read fun things and read interesting books in class instead of tedious grammar.  But do make sure you study for the grammar part of the exam and pay attention in class when grammar does get covered though.
The readings are interesting, and the instructors are very accessible.

This course is excellent. I would recommend reading the grammar carefully each week and spending a lot of time practicing your presentation at the end of the semester and make sure you have a good time and speak a lot in class.
This was a fun and very helpful course
highly recommend
prereqs: Placement through the University's Placement Test, completion of FRE 105, or permission of the Language Coordinator..
descrip: FRE 108 is an intermediate advanced course, with a brand new syllabus. It will take you on a journey through various periods of French history and culture and offer an opportunity to reflect on important questions at the center of controversial debates. Through a wide variety of authentic material, you will develop your ability to communicate in French and gain understanding of French and francophone cultures and societies. FRE 108 also helps prepare for applying to our study abroad programs.

title: Autobiography and Identity
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Citizenship: Law, Culture and Society
descrip: Please see website

title: Studies in Forms of Narrative - Henry James and Gustave Flaubert
descrip: The seminar starts from Henry James's complex and ambivalent attitudes toward Flaubert's novels, his baffled attempts to understand Flaubert's project, and moves on to consider principally how the two novelists developed radically incompatible theories of the uses of fiction in their late work.

title: Czeslaw Milosz, Joseph Brodsky: Poetry and History
prereqs: No prerequisites.
descrip: Course considers the work of Polish-born poet Czeslaw Milosz and Russian-born poet Joseph Brodsky by combining history of literature and intellectual history, and treating their life stories as emblematic of historical, cultural and political phenomena of the second part of the 20th century. Course uses close textual analysis of major works by both poets (and some of their contemporaries) to address such topics as: literary history, World War II, Polish-Russian relations, dominance of English-language poetry, growth of high culture in the United States, and the decline of exile.

title: Advanced Vector Calculus
reviews: Be prepared to work very hard, and think over the material a lot.
Be ready to work hard
Be warned: it's not easy.
Better if you know Multivariable Calculus going in.
Challenging but you get out of it feeling you've  stepped out of your comfort zone and actually achieved something.
Do ALL THE PRACTICE EXAMS. The problem sets don't prepare you at all! Also, review the chapter before going to lecture. You'll understand the direction of lecture better that way.
Don't be frustrated with the text. It takes a couple of readings to fully understand it.
Go to office hours, and read the textbook because it's a VERY difficult course.
Go to the lectures.
Hard but interesting course

I suppose if you wanted to take multivariable, and wanted the theory. I don't think that it's all that helpful for people who don't want the theoretical math basis for the calculus, but of course that's what 201 is for.
I would not take this course if you are not comfortable with proofs.

I would suggest that one should take this course only if they want to be in a harder more intense math environment than MAT 201. The course is difficult so one should be ready to study and dedicate a good amount of time on the problem sets.
If you haven't taken multivariable calculus before, 201 may be a better choice, since many of the other students probably will have.
If you're good at math, this course is for you. However, if you're more interested in applications than theory I would not recommend this course.
It is going to be difficult. But in the end it is worth it.
It was really hard in the beginning and I felt like everyone else understood things while I didn't, but definitely stick with it. The class is very rewarding and it gets much better.

It's a lot harder than MAT 201 (and a bigger time commitment), even if you've taken calc III before. The pset/exam problems were interesting, but challenging. Expect to spend about 8 hours on the psets (more on the later ones), even if you work with a group. I would only take it over 201 if you're a physics major.
It's tough, but I think worthwhile.

Just don't take it. You will regret it if you do take it. Just buy a book (a better one that the joke they use) and teach yourself this course. At least you know how to read and speak english, which is an incredible advantage over some of the TAs in this class.
Keep focus up until the very end, even if it seems harder with so many assignments coming out.

MAT 203 is quite a bit more work than MAT 201, so if you are in BSE and you want to satisfy your multivariable calculus requirement, take 203 if proofs are your thing. Otherwise, you'll do better in 201
Make sure you know your analytical math
Make sure you take a lot of practice test.
Not for the faint hearted. If you don't have a real interest in the maths do 201, and if you're English and haven't done limits before you should look at single variable limits beforehand.
Read the book along with lecture and do every past exam that you can find.
Recommend if have ample time.

Seriously know if you think you're ready for this course. It's really no joke, and you'll probably spend a ton of time on the psets (unless you're amazing at math) so you really need to be prepared. How much I'd recommend it would really depend on the person.
Study a lot for the midterm and final. Review lecture notes and the textbook regularly.
Take MAT201 unless you are thinking that you might major in mathematics.
Take it if you want to learn multi and really understand it but don't expect this to be your favorite course of the semester. If you're just taking this for a requirement (econ etc) just take 201.
Take it if you're interested in multivariable calculus or you have to for the BSE requirement. Expect for the problem sets to take about the same amount of time every week (~6 hours for me).
Take it only if you have to.

Take this course if you are really interested in theory and find mat 201 too easy (too applied). Exams questions, literally have no numbers in them. It is very conceptual and abstract. Do 201 if you are not a theoretical person (like me) as this course can be quite a struggle.
Take this if you want to meet awesome people who want to be challenged.

The course is definitely challenging, even though I'd taken multivariable calculus in high school. The material is all very high quality and presented well, but understanding it all is a major time commitment. In the end, it's extremely rewarding to finally understand the concepts and proofs.  I would recommend trying the course, but dropping down to MAT 201 if it becomes too rigorous.
This course is a definite must.

This course is definitely challenging, even if you have some multivariable calculus background.  If you have time in your schedule to do all of the readings and spend time on the problem sets, I would suggest taking it as I learned a lot.  The tests were pretty challenging because the problems require you to apply your knowledge to new topics, but I think the grading was pretty fair.

This course is hard, but that doesn't matter. Even if you transfer to normal Linear Algebra next semester you will be glad you had the courage to do this. Ask yourself, what would the high school student who Princeton admitted say about taking this course?

This is a good course to challenge yourself. I got much more out of it because of sitting in the front at lectures and going to office hours frequently. Collaboration on problem sets and group studying are key!

This was a very interesting course, but also very challenging and time-consuming. Do not take it if you are not willing to be challenged or want to be always at the top of the class. Your grade will come out okay at the end if you work hard and do decently (read average) on the exams. Make sure to do many practice exams! And start the problem sets early! They easily take 10 hours a week. Find people to work with or at least to ask questions when you're stuck.
Teng Zhang was a instructor who was interested in teaching, and I really liked him. I would recommend him, but I did not have experience with the other lecturers.

This was needlessly difficult course. I don't feel like I learned much more than I did when I took multi in high school, but it was certainly five times as painful here. I implore you not to to take this if you are not considering a math-intensive engineering or physics major. Even if you are, I would recommend you conserve your stamina and just take 201.
Work hard every week.
prereqs: MAT 104 or MAT 215, or equivalent..
descrip: Vector spaces, limits, derivatives of vector-valued functions, Taylor's formula, Lagrange multipliers, double and triple integrals, change of coordinates, surface and line integrals, generalizations of the fundamental theorem of calculus to higher dimensions. More abstract than 201 but more concrete than 218. Recommended for prospective physics majors and others with a strong interest in applied mathematics.

title: PhD Gateway in Security Studies
descrip: The field of Security Studies is distinguished by its focus on a clearly delineated set of intellectual and practical problems. This course will serve as the required gateway for all students entering the Woodrow Wilson School.

title: Plato
reviews: Do the readings. Don't fall behind.
I would recommend taking this course with Professor Barnes, especially if you are interested in the linguistic aspects of Classics
Take anything in which you study Plato
Take it if you feel confident in your Greek.  It's a fair bit of work but fun and certainly manageable.
This class is excellent.  The Symposium is a joy to read, though extremely difficult.  Barnes may not be teaching it next time round, but if he is, definitely take it.
prereqs: Greek 108 or above..
descrip: The course will read Plato's Symposium in its entirety. It provides an introduction both to Plato's philosophy and to Plato's art of writing. Accordingly, the emphasis will be put on language, dialogical form and philosophical content.

title: Integrative Advanced Japanese I
reviews: By this point you should already know how awesome the Japanese program here is. There's not too much of a transition from 3rd year; if anything it gets a tiny bit easier (still as time consuming though). If you can fit it in, take it!
If the student already has learned good grammar basics, it would be a nice course to take.
If you really love Japanese and Japanese culture and have a strong desire and purpose in learning the language, definitely take this course!  Be prepared to budget a lot of time for it.

It's a lot more challenging than 3rd year and you will probably struggle at first, but if you put in the effort you will learn a ton from Shibata sensei. Everything she does is for your benefit! She is the best <3
Shibata-sensei is a very good teacher.
keep taking japanese
prereqs: JPN302 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: Four skills approach to advanced Japanese with a focus on reading, listening and speaking. Reading materials include novels, essays, etc. Video materials are also used to enhance listening skills. The goal of this course is "advanced" level according to the ACTFL/ETS guidelines.

title: Statistical Physics: Principles and Problem Solving (Half-Term)
reviews: Again, try the lectures out and ask questions, but I actually wish I'd let go of going to the lectures a bit earlier and just studied in earnest on my own instead.
I think it is useful for prelim preparation, that's all.
Read a textbook instead. I recommend Callen.
Same comments as in the mechanics class evaluation
See EM review
Take it to study for prelims and be reminded of concepts.
descrip: A graduate-level review of statistical physics emphasizing problem-solving.

title: Religion and Culture Workshop
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop devoted to the critical discussion of research in progress in the ethnographic, historical, and normative study of religion and culture. Designed for dissertation writers receiving fellowships from the Center for the Study of Religion and post-doctoral fellows. Note: REL 521 (fall) and REL 522 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Intermediate Twi I
prereqs: TWI 101 and TWI 102 or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is a continuation of TWI 102. It builds on the basic Twi structures acquired in TWI 101 and TWI 102 through oral and listening activities. Students will continue to build on their vocabulary through readings of short stories. It continues to focus on communicative skills and cultural awareness. By the end of the course, learners are expected to reach proficiency level ranging between Intermediate Low and Intermediate Mid.

title: Liberation Photography /The Engaged Photographer
reviews: DO IT.

I don't think that you will have the chance to take this course because Professor Street is leaving, but it is interesting with a minimal work load. I would recommend it, especially if you have never thought of photography being a means of activism and combat reporting. However, don't think that you'll be taught how to photograph -- this is more of a learn-as-you-go class with respect to your final photo essay.
If you are interested in photography or more specifically the history of photo essays, you 100% should take this course, especially since Prof. Street is a visiting professor.
Listen intently to Professor Street - he is a very interesting man with a fascinating take on the purpose of photography
This course won't be coming back, but spend your time elsewhere.
prereqs: Enrollment priority will be given to members of the American Studies Program, anyone who has been arrested for civil disobedience, anyone who has served time in jail, and anyone who has been in the military. Contact Judith Ferszt in the AMS office, jferszt@princeton.edu, or (609) 258-6771, for information..
descrip: This is a hybrid course that focuses on a powerful and important facet of modern visual culture--those photographers who embrace the human condition and use the camera as a tool to explore the world; fight poverty, injustice, and exploitation; shape public policy; and advance human rights. This course is not about technologies, cameras, darkroom techniques, or Photoshop. Writing is essential. The course is project-oriented. While studying exemplars of still picture communication, students will create and present a modest photo essay and supply meaning through the right words, intelligent sequencing, and creative captioning.

title: Advanced Topics in Genetic Analysis
prereqs: MOL342 is an absolute requirement..
descrip: The application of current tools of human genetics and genomic analysis including SNPs, copy number variants, HapMaps, high throughput DNA sequencing and DNA microarrays to perform genome-wide association studies of complex traits with an emphasis on neurological diseases including autism and schizophrenia. Recent evolution within the human species and genetic divergence of human populations in response to selective forces. Extensive use will be made of online genome databases as interactive tools for genome analysis.

title: Junior Seminar in French Studies
reviews: Do all the readings! So that you'll feel more engaged and want to talk which helps your French.
prereqs: Conceived for Junior Concentrators in French, it is also open to students from other departments..
descrip: The course will initiate students to scholarship relative to these fields and teach a variety of theories and methodolgies reflective of the diversity of French studies. It will teach literary approaches based on rhetoric, poetics, semiotics, philosophy, psychoanalysis, and so forth. Furthermore, it will introduce a theoretical agenda that reflects the evolution of French Studies over the last decades: gender studies, post colonialism, media studies, literature and science, literature and law, digital humanities, animal studies, performance theory etc.

title: Topics of Popular Music - Analysis of Protest Music
descrip: This course explores interdisciplinary frameworks for analyzing popular music in social movements, using literary theory, urban studies, political science, social science, music theory, and ethnomusicology. Topics include urban space, cyberspace, festivals, the music industry, musicians' roles, and allegorical and intertextual approaches. The antinuclear movement in post -3.11 Japan will serve as a constant example throughout the course, along with antiwar movements of the 1960s, Latin America under dictatorships, Arab Spring, and movements post-2011.

title: Seminar in International Relations - Conflict and Cooperation in International Politics- Security and Trade
reviews: Definitely take the course!

Gowa is exacting and borderline dogmatic, but her intelligence and syllabus are compelling. She is a must-take for any student interested in IR, especially those used to thinking in terms of the Keohane / Moravcsik perspective.
Professor Gowa is tough! But a very worthwhile course for all those interested in International Politics. I feel I now understand political economy.

Take the course. Great professor and great class. You'll come away with a whole new perspective on the macro scale workings of the international systems. Don't take it if you don't have a good history background and be prepared for some challenging math and economics if you're coming from a strictly humanities background.
This seminar provides a solid foundation of international relations topics and theories, including some game theory.  Be prepared to read a lot and talk about the readings every week.
descrip: This course is an introduction to conflict and cooperation in international politics. It emphasizes the impact of the anarchic international system on patterns of conflict and cooperation across nations, issues, and time. It spends roughly equal amounts of time on war and trade. It also considers the role of domestic factors in international politics, but it privileges the role of the system in explaining outcomes. Students will be introduced to elementary game theory, the use of quantitative data, and trade theory.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Data Driven Statistical Genomics
reviews: I would strongly suggest graduate students to take this seminar if you're interested in this field. The instructor is excellent and the materials and projects help a lot.
Take a full course in machine learning (particularly focusing on Bayesian methods) BEFORE taking this course
Take this course if you want to work on a stats/machine learning group project and receive guidance/feedback.
descrip: Case-based, hands on introduction to statistical genetics through the lens of Bayesian statistics. Topics include statistical approaches to data exploration, association testing, model selection, dimension reduction, undirected networks, and time-series analyses. Although the papers we will read will mainly come from the statistical genetics literature, much of the material will be transferable to other domains. Prerequisites: linear algebra, introductory probability and statistics

title: Economic Sociology (Half-Term)
descrip: An introduction to economic sociology seen not as a subordination of sociology to economics but as the sociological explanation of economic phenomena. It focuses on alternative accounts of phenomena that most specialists have explained using economic concepts and theory. In particular, it seeks sociological explanations of production, consumption, and distribution, and transfer of assets. After a general orientation to economic sociology as a whole, the course explores economic activities in an unconventionally wide range of settings including households, informal sectors, gift economies, and consumption.

title: Introduction to Mathematical Physics
descrip: An introduction to mathematically rigorous methods in physics. Topics to be covered include classical and quantum statistical mechanic, quantum many-body problem, group theory, Schroedinger operators, and quantum information theory.

title: Elemental Building Function
reviews: Be advised that this is a seminar class, and not too much information will be introduced in class by the professor.

Forrest is extremely nice. I would say, coming to the course with some sort of specific interests, things you want to learn about, in order to get that out of it would make it more useful than just showing up / doing the work.
Forrest was super helpful, knowledgeable, and generous with his time.
I'm not sure what we did all semester to be honest. Forrest casually covers a lot of ground. Its a super vague class, where you learn some concepts and some bits of information in a lot of areas.
It is not a course about technology; it is more about thinking.
It's a discussion based course with weekly assignments. The material is stimulating and the discussions engaging.
descrip: This course will build a discourse encompassing the many aspects of building function to try to rediscover the best role of the architect. We will attempt to discover what level of functional system knowledge is appropriate for the architect today. A palette of potentially complex topics will be provided to explore building function, but to avoid the seminar becoming overly technical, it will be grounded in the basic elements of function that one might imagine: Aristotle's Air, Fire, Earth, and Water. Air: space and comfort; Fire: energy and operation; Earth: materials and construction; Water: flow and systems

title: Projects in Jazz Performance
reviews: TAKE IT IF YOU CAN HANG WITH THE JAZZ CATS, OTHERWISE PISS OFF
Take it if you've had a decent background in jazz before. If not, there'll be a steep learning curve.

The course is appropriate for jazz musicians from the intermediate to advanced level. Unfortunately, given the limited practice time available to many Princeton students, it is difficult to incorporate some of the topics into ones everyday playing. Overall, this course was great! It was a great experience to work so closely with Ralph Bowen in a combo setting.
prereqs: Enrollment by application and audition..
descrip: A performance course that focuses on the development of style, concept, and repertoire in the jazz idiom. Students are coached by faculty in extended projects in performance.

title: France Today: Culture, Politics, and Society
reviews: Definitely take this class. It may look like a lot of reading, but it's actually quite manageable/light. The content is interesting and informative, and Prof. Sagnier is great.

If you can speak french, just take this class. Please just take this because this class will be one of the best, if not the best, classes you'll ever take at Princeton. You don't even need much interest in the subject, Professor Sagnier will make you interested in it. She's that good. No matter how high your expectations are, she'll exceed them.
Prepare to be amazed! But, always do your homework otherwise you're in trouble.
She is a very great professor and if you can take this class definitely do it!
Take it if you love French and want to advance your skills even more!
Take it! Professor Sagnier is an excellent teacher and the subjects covered in the course is very interesting.
Take it. It is incredible and well worth your time.
Take this course if you are at all interested in french culture.
This course was really enjoyable. Students can choose to research a wide array of topics for their final project. There is a large emphasis on oral participation and fluidity.
Very relevant if you choose to study abroad.
You will maximize what you get out of the course if you do the readings carefully and take the time to look up words you don't know.
prereqs: FRE 207 or equivalent..
descrip: This course is designed to develop students' linguistic skills and broaden their knowledge of contemporary French society. Discussions and essays will cover a wide range of topics drawn from economic, political, social and cultural aspects of France and the francophone world. Current affairs will be discussed in class on a regular basis. The course will provide intensive language practice and students will improve their communication skills by completing a research project, to be presented orally and in writing, on a topic of their choice. Excellent preparation for Princeton-in-France internships or Sciences-Po semester.

title: Topics in Analysis - Interpolation and approximation
prereqs: Undergraduates require permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course includes the following: optimal and almost-opitimal extensions of data to functions in several function spaces, existence theorems and effective computation, classical and recent results, and unsolved problems.

title: Money, Work, and Social Life
descrip: This course offers an introduction to the sociological study of the economy. We will examine how production, consumption, distribution and exchange are intricately shaped by social relations, institutions and cultural meanings. Topics covered include markets, work, finance, commodification and the role of morality in economic life. Particular attention will also be paid to recent historical transformations in the U.S. economy.

title: The Literature of Environmental Disaster
reviews: Take it - lack of French knowledge is fine.
Take it.
Take this course!
Take this course! It's a moderate workload and very interesting. Also, a great opportunity to brush up on French!
Take this course, it's interesting, fun and not extremely difficult!
This course was interesting, and the discussions and readings were always good.  The topic, though very important, can get depressing.
descrip: In the Anthropocene, humanity has become, for the first time, a geological agent transforming the conditions of life on earth, but this power itself gives rise to unprecedented challenges, from air pollution and floods to nuclear fallout and plagues, from agribusiness to petro-imperialism. Literature sheds a unique light on this global crisis, highlighting in each case the lived human experience, the distinct visions of nature, and the complex social conflicts involved. Readings include novels, plays, and journalism about oil extraction, megadams and nuclear fallout from France, Russia, India, Nigeria, Japan and the US.

title: Metaphysics - Essence and Grounding
prereqs: Advanced undergraduates may attend with instructor's permission..
descrip: A study of selected issues surrounding the notions of essence and grounding, such as the logic and nature of essence, its role in metaphysical explanation, and its connection to modality; the nature of grounding, the philosophical work it can do, and its relationship to other forms of explanation; skepticism about essence and grounding.

title: Reason and Religion
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Persian Reading I
reviews: Everyone who wants to take a great language for fun or to try something new should take Persian. If you are already taking Persian, there is no reason to stop and Amineh's classes are the best.
Like all the Persian classes offered by Prof Mahallati this class is a fun informative learning experience in a wonderfully warm and encouraging environment
prereqs: Two years of Persian or permission of instructor.
