descrip: This course is designed to improve the student's proficiency in the reading and comprehension of Persian texts. The emphasis is on reading and understanding and translating modern and classical prose. In the Advanced Persian course students are also expected to write essays in Persian during the course of the semester. Advanced Persian Reading class will be conducted in Persian.

title: Greek Politics in Practice and Theory
reviews: Do take - it's fun!

Excellent course if you are interested in law or political theory. Plato and Aristotle are the basis for all of the human political thought that has followed. Professor Luraghi knows a lot about the subject, and he gives you a lot of freedom to choose what you want to write about on your papers. You write your own prompt so you can explore whichever aspect of the course you find most interesting!

I thought the course was great and relatively easy. The readings were interesting but the precepts and lecturers were rather boring. That being said if you want a relatively easy HA I would recommend it.
Read the books
Since this class is new, it still has some kinks.  I would recommend considering other Classics courses.
Take it, make sure you actually enjoy the material.
take it
take it!
descrip: This course will approach select classics of Greek political thought (Plato's Statesman and Republic, Aristotle's Politics) through a scrutiny of Greek social and political institutions. Students will be introduced to basic principles such as the distinction between free and unfree, the social and political status of male and female, and the distribution of political power and access to political participation in the Greek polis, in order to be in a position to observe how the ideas of Greek political thinkers map onto this reality.

title: Comparative Constitutional Law: A systematic introduction (Half-term)
descrip: This course provides an introduction into the systematic problems of comparative constitutional law. Constitutions are hybrid institutions that connect political processes and legal procedures in a complex and often highly ambiguous manner. The way constitutions work is diverse even within what one might call the Atlantic Tradition. The course attempts to give an explicitly legal perspective on constitutions that is open to non-lawyers.

title: Reading Medieval Culture
reviews: Fairly easy course on literature that everybody should read.
For an introductory course, this is a good choice.
This is a good course to take for those seeking to fulfill the LA distribution requirement or who are interested in medieval literature and culture.
prereqs: None..
descrip: Medieval culture, literature and literary theory, as well as Modern critical debates currently being staged, highlight the diversity of cultural production in the European Middle Ages. This course explores such topics as Medieval textuality and reading, text and image, subjectivity and spirituality, premodern sex and gender, and myths and realities of Medieval nation-building.

title: Switching and Sequential Systems
descrip: This course is designed to give seniors and first-year graduate students an introduction of sequential systems and finite-state machines. Topics include characterization of linear and nonlinear machines; synthesis and minimization of finite-state machines; machine identification; finite-memory machines; information lossless machines; finite-state recognizers; and machine learning, identification, and testing.

title: Documentary Filmmaking
reviews: Don't expect to know the answers, or to ever get them. Just expect to question and learn.
I enjoyed this course overall, though I think it is good to come in with some background knowledge of filmmaking.
This course is amazing.  Emily is a great instructor, and the course will teach you so much if you're willing to put in a lot of work.
Try to not waste time in the class.
descrip: This course will give students an introduction to documentary film and video production, with a special emphasis on the practical challenges of producing films in the real world. Students will learn fundamental filmmaking techniques from a professor with thirteen years experience running her own film production company, as well as a handful of guest professionals in the fields of cinematography, casting, and editing. Production and critique of student work will be augmented by film screenings, readings, and discussion of the effects that practical realities can have on the creative process.

title: Leadership Development for Business
reviews: Best course at Princeton. Take it. Professor is genuinely interested in his class and wants you to learn.
Definitely take it.  Do the readings.

Definitely take it. You learn a lot about business leaders as well as about yourself. Denny is extremely interesting and has a lot of stories to share. The guest speakers also provide interesting insights.
Definitely take this course. You get to hear from a CEO of Verizon 3 hours a week for 12 weeks. That's awesome.
Great class! Definitely recommend for seniors as a relaxed course to learn about the business world.

If you want to learn about leadership from someone who has lived it, then take this course. It's a light workload and you will learn concepts that can apply to your everyday life. The lectures are incredibly engaging, and Denny really knows what he's talking about.
Interesting course with limited work required. Mainly take it to hear from Professor Strigl.
It was a great course - If you are interested in the subject material, I would recommend taking this course. The readings were not too long and exams/midterms were very fair.
One of my favorite and most rewarding courses at Princeton. A little "fluffy" compared to other classes, but if very business-school esque, and the professor is amazing.
TAKE IT!
TAKE THIS - Denny is the man, super chill and you will learn a lot. It is not difficult, but you will take out what you put in.
TAKE THIS COURSE
Take it!

Take take take. This will change the way you see yourself and the leader you want to be. This will make you incredibly self-aware and will help you learn from previous successes and failures. 

Denny himself is a fantastic lecturer and you will WANT to give him your full attention. He's got an incredibly variety and depth of experience that he draws upon for lectures to back up lessons he teaches us. Note: lectures is misleading -- they are actually more like conversations. Very participant heavy in the greatest way. 

If you do the readings, you'll LOVE this class. If you don't do the readings, you won't learn as much and won't be as engaged but you'll still REALLY LIKE this class - also anything assigned for reading is retaught and discussed in class.
Take this class for sure. There are few classes at Princeton that teach you about real world business, and this is the most engaging one by far
Take this course. It's relaxed, but you get to learn through some incredible people and stories. Compared to academic literature, these readings are a nice change of pace.
This class was very interesting and very easy. It would be a great PDF because everyone does well on the tests.

This is a fantastic course! Definitely one of my favorites. Denny Strigl's book is fantastic. Even if you aren't able to get into the class, it's worth buying/borrowing his book (it's a quick read and incredibly useful). Try to come to class with a prepared comment or question in order to participate.
You have to take it.
You should take this course if you are interested in leadership or business at all.
take it ! loved it
prereqs: There are no prerequisites for this course. Students from all disciplines are welcome..
descrip: The Leadership Development for Business course deals with the strategic, organizational and leadership challenges that global corporations face. The course provides students with a unique perspective on leadership vision, and how leaders recognize and capitalize on opportunities. We will focus on how leaders achieve results and make things happen working with and through others. This course presents innovative, practical and field tested methods used by successful business leaders to achieve sustained results. Classes will consist of a mix of classroom lecture, case study discussions and guest speakers.

title: Public Policy in the American Racial State
reviews:
AAS 380 is incredible - almost everyone in the class says this is the best, most interesting class they have taken at Princeton. 

Prof. Murakawa is amazing and knows so much and has a remarkable way of engaging students. The class is controversial but SO relevant to what's happening in the US. You learn so much and learn how to truly think critically about issues. The readings are long (a book a week sometimes) but some of the best material I've ever read . I would leave this seminar every week with my mind blown. Can't recommend this enough. TAKE IT!!!!!!!
Do all the readings -- all material builds on top of each other.

In all honestly, I viewed each and every one of these seminars as illuminating, edifying, immensely-informative tell-all exposes. Every week was like a new, crushing blow--but in the best way possible. Never have I found any other class more enlightening. It simultaneously provoked a newfound cynicism, complete doubt of the possibility of real, lasting policy change, and confidence in the utter inefficacy of our government, structured as it is, but it also proved so incredibly gratifying to finally learn about things that, especially this past semester, could not have been more relevant or pressing. Professor Murakawa is utterly brilliant, and her passion for the subject is both palpable and inspiring. Though she often hesitated to lapse into lecture format and often stopped herself mid-sentence because she felt she was talking too much, what I think she failed to realize was that these impassioned monologues were probably the part of the course we--or at least I--enjoyed the most. To say that this course was stimulating would be a gross understatement, and the only flaw I can really think of is that, though Professor Murakawa encouraged criticism and opposition, people rarely held differing opinions because she was just too brilliant to disagree with, and I found myself sort of blindly believing every word that came out of her mouth...though all of this can hardly be called a flaw, really...
It requires a lot of work but it is very meaningful work. You come out of the semester feeling a lot more knowledgeable about the intersection of policy and race in America.
Make sure you have adequate time to devote to this course.  It does require good amounts of preparation, but it is very much worth it.

Realize that this will be a very significant amount of reading and that to get the most out of this course you must do them. 
Realize that if you do, this will be one of the courses that will truly define your Princeton experience.

This is the best class I have taken at Princeton. Definitely take it, but take it in a semester when you can make it a priority. Do the readings, talk in class, and pick a research topic you care a lot about.
descrip: In the context of de facto equality but persistent racial inequality, how do we identify race's role in public policy? This course addresses this question by drawing on a range of interdisciplinary texts. We begin by exploring different theoretical perspectives of race, seeking to define "the racial state" in historical and comparative terms. We then consider how race interacts with a variety of American political institutions, including the welfare state, immigration regulation, and the criminal justice state. We give particular attention to the complexities of racial construction and race's intersection with other forms of hierarchy.

title: Fundamental Concepts in Ecology, Evolution, and Behavior II
reviews: Do all the readings and think critically about them well before the class.

Do as many of the readings as possible but don't be shy to participate in discussions even if you weren't able to read all of the background - the point of the seminars is to have a stimulating discussion about a subfield of ecology, so help the instructors in guiding the seminar by asking questions about what really interests you about the topic!
Just get some background reading done and be prepared to learn about some interesting topics.
Start reading the papers early.
descrip: An advanced foundation in ecology, focusing on the 50 fundamental papers, is given. Topics include dynamics and structure of populations, communities and ecosystems, and conservation biology. (This is a core course.)

title: Intermediate Latin: Catullus and His Age
reviews: An excellent continuation of the four semester Latin sequence (101 - 102 / 103 - 105 - 108). Four days a week (which is better than a lot of 100 level language classes, which meet every day) with homework pretty much every night, but the amount you have to translate is generally very manageable.

Great course for a Latin-lover looking to brush up on grammar while reading interesting texts. Would recommend. Or for someone who took Latin in high school and is fulfilling the language requirement. Why take a live language when you can take a dead one?
Honestly don't take Latin unless you absolutely have to.
If you can, enroll in Dawn's section.
If you want to take latin, I'd encourage continuing to 105/108

If you've already taken 101 and 102 at Princeton, this is even better! You finally get to start reading real Latin, and even though it's really time consuming and admittedly really hard, it's so rewarding. The class is fun, the reading selections are good, and you finally get to use your Latin to read REAL stuff!!
It is a fairly standard course, but most certainly take advantage of office hours.
Keep up with the assigned readings.
Keep up with the work!
Make sure you stay on pace with the homework. You don't want to get behind, because when you haven't done the reading, you get less out of the following day's discussion and translation.

Most likely you have to take it, but it is a great course nonetheless. You really see your Latin ability  improved from what it was after LAT 102/103. Do the readings before class, don't fall behind, and you'll do fine. Also, when you do the homework, do it smart. Don't get bogged down on a single line, if so, you'll take forever. Do what you can, give it your all, but don't be afraid to come in to class with questions. And lastly, don't use online translations, you're only robbing yourself of the practice.
Take it--not too hard, and required for more study of Latin.
The instructor can make it more interesting but it is hard to get past the standard fare of daily translations.
This is an appropriate course if you want to take Latin and already have some knowledge of the language.
You're probably taking this class because you have to, or if you really like Latin. That's what this course is.
prereqs: LAT 102 or departmental permission based on Latin Placement..
descrip: This course aims at increasing facility in reading Latin prose and poetry and introduces students to the literacy culture of Republican Rome. We shall read selections from two important authors of the late Roman Republic, Caesar and Catullus.

title: Entrepreneurial Leadership
reviews: Be ready to do work with groups
Definitely take!
Do not take.
Great great course!

Highly recommended -- one of the few (if only) classes that will give you PRACTICAL experience in leadership. The quality of lectures and readings varies, but the experience of working with 3 different teams to complete very different types of tasks is invaluable.  It teaches you how to run effective meetings (which is something I've never explicitly learned before, but I will need to do in my job next year), what your leadership style is, and how it compares to others' leadership styles.  Being led by other team members will also teach you what works and what doesn't.
If you want to start a company, it's probably very helpful and presents a lot of good networking opportunities
If you're interested in running any sort of organization, I recommend this course. You'll learn some very useful skills. Be warned that it is time consuming.

If you're interested in taking your leadership abilities to the next level, this course is a must. If you want to start a business, this course will greatly increase your chances of success. It's a bit of work, though. You gotta want it.

It's a good class.  You learn a lot and it can be applied to a lot of life.  But go into it knowing you won't get much from lecture and Lidow will present stuff in a super-biased, I am the best entrepreneur way.
Relaxing course and definitely should take if interested in entrepreneurship.

TAKE THIS if you are willing to sit through a long lecture to potentially learn something interesting. It's very easy, just requires some focus. I learned a lot about group dynamics, group management, preparing for meetings, and leadership.
Take a different entrepreneurship course not taught by Lidow
Take it, do the readings because the quizzes will get you otherwise.
Take it. Inventory your traits and motivations. Hone your skills.
Take the course! But be prepared to work, and learn how he thinks about things.

The class will be annoying (have to meet with a group of 4ish busy Princeton students twice a week, so just the scheduling is a nightmare) and graded pretty arbitrarily, but you will definitely walk away a better leader.

This course is a lot of work. However, if you're tired of Princeton classes and want to think outside of the box, this is the course for you. You learn how to lead groups, make meetings efficient, and how to apply it all to entrepreneurship through bi-weekly practice and experience.
This course is excellent for anyone who wants to learn what it takes to be an entrepreneurial leader and acquire some experience at actually being one in the process.

You can learn a lot in this class if you really listen and observe! I got to experience working in different teams and learned so much. I think I may have been in one of the best all-star teams that I've ever been in my whole life so far. Some of your peers in this class are honestly some of the most talented, hard-working, positive, great bunch ever. Guest speakers weren't as frequent as I thought but still great! I really underestimated how great working in teams would be in terms of enhancing this course.
prereqs: Interest/passion in discovering how an idea can become a real company.This course is not open to students who took EGR 495 Special Topics in Entrepreneurship: Entrepreneurial Leadership..
descrip: The mission of the class is to enable students to successfully create and lead enterprises by teaching the basic skills required to be a successful entrepreneurial leader. This class compliments EGR 491 "High Tech Entrepreneurship" which focuses on 'giving birth to a company', by focusing instead on enterprise 'early child rearing'. The basic skills taught fall into three major categories: how to create and manage powerful relationships, how to know and manage yourself, in addition to understanding how organizations work as they evolve from the idea stage to become value producing, self-sustaining enterprises.

title: Introduction to Language and Linguistics
reviews: A great EC-- interesting topic and not hard at all

A great course to take because there are so many interesting things about language and linguistics that you probably didn't know before. Just make sure you do all the readings and attend class regularly and you've got yourself a good grade!
A nice subject but fairly blah class, info will be on slides/in book, light coursework
An interesting introductory class that is easy and manageable, especially with a full course load.
Ask questions in precept if you are confused about a topic and read the textbook if you need help.
Buy the books and pay attention to the problem sets. Attending precept is important, too.
Course work is very light. Very easy 5th class.

Definitely take it if you're interested in the topics! I found it really interesting and the problem sets were actually fun - like solving puzzles. Prof. Fellbaum is a good lecturer, and there's not a lot of work. I was planning to PDF it, but I ended up taking it for a grade because it's helping my average.
Do your work early in case you have questions that can be answered in precept!
Does not take a lot of work to go through the class, but exams can be difficult.
Don't be afraid to ask your preceptor for LIN studying tips.
Easiest course I've taken at Princeton, less than 3 hours of work a week, including going to precept

Even though the material can be somewhat dry, linguistics is conceptually fascinating in and of itself, and as creatures with a near-complete mastery of language, but very little understand of it, it is definitely worth knowing the basics of how language actually works.
Get Ozge Ozturk as a preceptor.  Go to lecture because Professor Fellbaum is a great teacher.

Go to precept! They were incredibly valuable in preparing me for doing all of the work for the course.

I've heard that in years past when this course had a different instructor the lectures were not very engaging. I can see how that might happen, but if Professor Fellbaum is teaching, then the lectures will be very good.
Good course if you're interested in linguistics. If you don't like languages, it's not the most exciting lecture class.
Good intro, though pretty slow moving. Highly recommend taking it with Fellbaum and getting into her precept. She's super fun and very nice.
Have fun with it.
I got by fine without buying the textbook.
I love Professor Fellbaum! She is wonderfully funny and so nice. The class was generally pretty easy. Good for EC. The problem sets are easy and the midterm and final not too bad.
I would definitely recommend this class.  It isn't that hard, especially if you go to lecture and listen.  I also found it *very* interesting.
I would definitely recommend this course. It's not too much work, but I thought it was very interesting.
I would suggest taking this course if you have a prior interest in languages. If not, then this course will be difficult to sit through.
If any student is somewhat interested in linguistics, I strongly recommend this course.
If you actually want to learn something, stay away
If you are interested in linguistics, take the course.  If you need an EC, take the course if Fellbaum is teaching again, because the workload is quite light.

If you are interested in pursuing a linguistics certificate or simply gaining more knowledge about language acquisition and construction, this is the course for you! I would highly recommend taking this course with Professor Fellbaum as her expertise in linguistics makes the course intellectually stimulating from beginning to end.
If you are looking for an easy class, you've found it. Otherwise, unless you have an undying interest in the subject, the class may kill any budding curiosity you do have.
If you have never heard about linguistics but is curious about what it is, take this class. It is fun.
If you're interested in linguistics, try a higher-level course.
Interesting material and overall a pretty painless course. Lectures and precepts can be a bit dry, but I do feel I know more about the subject. Studying the problem sets was useful for the exams.

It's a good class to take for the distributional. There were a lot of topics that were covered but we didn't go into depth in any of them. We only had four problem sets over the semester and the they did not take that much time.
It's a good introduction to linguistics.
It's a really interesting class that doesn't take a lot of time. Professor Fellbaum is a really good lecturer.
It's all true. Don't fail the midterm though.
It's laid-back and interesting, just have fun with it
It's not a difficult course, nor does it have a demanding workload. But the material can get pretty unexciting at times, so you should go into it with some personal interest to motivate yourself.
LIN 201 is an excellent and interesting course, and it may not be about what you expect. It is great about showing you many things you have not ever thought about regarding the way we communicate.

Linguistics is an interesting field because it makes you think about the way you talk and use language.  This class was interesting because it made you do that, but it was a little bit boring at times.  Lectures weren't all that exciting, and the material was fairly dry and not particularly challenging.  Take if you're interested in the material.

Linguistics is an interesting subject that covers a lot of material that I had never learned before. At times, lecture could be a bit boring, but I think that's the case for any large lecture course. It wasn't too difficult and not too much work, but very interesting. I would definitely recommend.
Make sure to go to precept even if you skip lecture.
Make sure you take the time to shop around and find a preceptor who will help you through - it makes a big difference.
Material is somewhat interesting, and the course isn't too much work at all.
Not that interesting, but easy distributional requirement.
Not very difficult, you get as much from it as you want to put in. Some parts are even fun.
One of my easier classes of the semester but still rewarding.
Only take this course if you are the kind of personal who immediately grasps concepts without needing to reinforce them through repeated practice.
Only take this if you have a very strong interest in Linguistics.
Pay attention in precept because it is really where you learn how to do problems on the midterm/problem sets.
Pretty easy class with interesting subject material
Pretty easy pdf, especially if you like puzzles! I actually enjoyed working on some of the problem sets

Read the material.
Use the opportunity to speak to the professor; she is amazing and very enthusiastic about teaching. She is an excellent all-round educator.
Read the textbook. It is very helpful in explaining concepts that you may not have gotten in the lectures, and also for solving the problem sets.
Relatively easy, non-stressful class.
Start the problem sets early so you have time to think over them because they can be tricky.
Study well for the midterm.
TAKE IT WITH FELLBAUM!

TAKE IT! I decided to take it on a whim with no idea of what linguistics actually was. It ended up being one of my favorite classes this semester. The subject matter is extremely engaging, and talks about the strange subtleties of language you may have never considered. Make sure to have good contact with your preceptor and go to office hours, since Professor Fellbaum is extremely open, and such an engaging professor to talk to.
Take it as an easy distribution requirement.
Take it if Prof. Fellbaum is teaching!  Some of the material is a bit boring, but the word puzzles are fascinating.  This is a great fifth class, since it does not have too much work.
Take it if you are willing to put the work in it.
Take it if you want an easy EC.

Take it if you want an easy course as an EC distribution requirement. It's easy to do well in, interesting, and the course work slows down at the end of the semester when it increases for most other courses.
Take it if you want to get a decent EC out or you like linguistics/want the certificate.
Take it if you're interested in linguistics. It's not very hard and figuring things out about languages you've never seen before on the problem sets/exams is fun.
Take it to knock out the distribution requirements. Easy course, easy to schedule around and hardly requires any work.
Take it!
Take it! With Fellbaum, specifically. It's painless and really interesting.
Take it. It is quite interesting and lots of fun.
Take it. It's an interesting class whether you want to pursue linguistics or not. But don't underestimate the material. Also, go to office hours. Fellbaum is always willing to help.
Take this class when Professor Fellbaum is teaching it! Actually take the time to enjoy the problem sets and do attend lectures.

Take this course as an easy fifth class! I wish I actually attended lecture because the material can be pretty interesting and it makes you think about the language you hear every day. Make sure you go to precept (and go to Prof. Fellbaum's precept if you can) as you'll go through examples that'll directly help on homework. The final is take home, open book. I put in very little time in this class and am still doing well.
Take this course if you want something easy and need to fulfill the EC requirement. Good for sophomores with five classes.
Take this course. Especially if you're an engineer looking for an EC.
Take this if you need an EC.
Take this with Fellbaum!
The course is interesting and will help you learn concepts about Language that you inherently understand. It is an introductory class though, so the material is fairly shallow and broad.
The first few weeks on phonology are very different from the rest of the course - don't be discouraged by the details of IPA
The lectures were interesting and engaging.
There are better linguistics courses to take than this one. Unless you need it, it's not worth it.

Think long and hard about what linguistics is, and don't assume you'll be interested just because you like learning other languages or writing.  Linguistics discusses very simple things that come naturally to us in confusing, technical ways, so be ready for that.  Beside that, just make sure you understand the problem sets before the midterm.
This class is a lot lighter in workload.  Works great as a fifth class.
This class is much harder than anyone expected. It is not fun and it is not useful.
This course introduces some interesting concepts. It's an easy course if you take the assignments seriously.
This course is probably the most ordinary course I've ever taken at Princeton!
This course is very easy to take pass-fail. Professor Fellbaum is great.
This is a fun and easy class.  You should take it if you have any interest in linguistics at all.

This is a good class for a distribution requirement, there are only 4 problem sets and the final is a take-home.  Material isn't too challenging but does involve a lot of memorization and specific details.

This is a truly fascinating subject area and the class itself is not difficult -- many people take it because it's an easy EC. If you take it with Fellbaum (and God knows you should), your final will probably be a take-home, and that will be wonderful. Only four problem sets, which means that you will have virtually the entire second half of the semester to dedicate to your other classes, making this an excellent choice for a fifth class.
Try to get Professor Fellbaum as your preceptor.
Very low commitment easy PDF
Would highly recommend it. Especially if you don't know much about linguistics. You find out a lot of interesting things about language.
even if you don't think you'll have any interest in the class or think it might be boring, take it to try something new.
only take it if you're super interested in linguistics and need it as a prerequisite
take this. you won't regret this.
descrip: An introduction to the scientific analysis of the structure and uses of language. Core areas covered include phonetics and phonology, morphology, the lexicon, syntax, semantics and pragmatics, with data from a wide range of languages. Topics include the biological basis of language, language and cognition, the neurology of language and language disorders, and first and second language acquisition.

title: Senior Seminar in Translation and Intercultural Communication
reviews: A very small sized class, not too much workload, a lot of freedom to do what you want in the final assignment!

It's required for the certificate, but I would say try to take it with Bellos if you can. Professor Wood was a lovely man but we had very little guidance/structure to the class and assignments and I didn't really feel as though I took away anything from the course that I hadn't already from other TRA program classes.
prereqs: Prerequisite TRA 200..
descrip: A required course for students taking the certificate in Translation and Intercultural Communication but open to all who are interested in translation or any of its aspects, that is in movements between languages of any sort. Readings will focus on recent contributions to the emerging disciplines of translation studies across a wide spectrum of thematic fields (science, law, anthropology, literature, etc.). The seminar will incorporate the individual experiences of the students in their contact with different disciplines and idioms and, where relevant, in developing their senior theses. One three-hour seminar.

title: Commutative Algebra
reviews: This course is a must if you are interested in further study in algebra, particularly algebraic geometry, algebraic topology, and homological algebra.
descrip: This course will cover the standard material in a first course on commutative algebra. Topics include: ideals in and modules over commutative rings, localization, primary decomposition, integral dependence, Noetherian rings and chain conditions, discrete valuation rings and Dedekind domains, completion; and dimension theory.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences IV
reviews: ISC is a good class, and professors care about it. You should take it.
Second year ISC is constantly getting more organized and improving. This is a fabulous way to be exposed to many aspects of biology. Do it if you've done the first year.
Take it! It's a fascinating look at genetics, and you won't regret it!

The course is fast-paced and interesting. The lecturers are great people who really care about their fields of study! Problem sets aren't as difficult as first year ISC, but can still take some time. Don't take this if you're not interested in genetics, and don't take it just to complete the ISC sequence.

This ISC semester is full of bio so know what you're getting into. You're gonna do a little bit of stats in pop gen, a little bit of computational biology in genomics (no coding though) and some classic biology with Wieschaus. Lectures are great and the homework is (in general) much more manageable than freshman ISC. I say if you've come this far, just do it!

This course is challenging and covers material that puts the field of genetics and related areas in perspective. It is essential for anyone considering any field in all of biology, and presents the information in a stimulating way that fosters student exploration and thought as well.

You really don't need to have taken the first year to take this class. If you did take the first year, have no fear because this class is MUCH easier and MUCH less work. 
If you're interested in bio and genetics, you should take it.
prereqs: Students should have completed ISC/CHM/COS/MOL/PHY 231-234, or equivalent preparation (MOL214, COS126, CHM201-202 or 203-204, PHY103-104 or 105-106), or received permission from Instructor. Note: ISC235 will be a continuation of ISC236, and will be offered in the upcoming spring term 2014-2015..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to genetics, developmental biology, genomics, evolution and population genetics. This is the first course in the year-long multidisciplinary integrated science sequence. Multiple faculty will be involved over the year, including P. Andolfatto (EEB), M. Murthy (MOL), J. Rabinowitz (CHM), M. Singh (COS), E. Wieschaus (MOL). 2 hrs and 40 min of lecture, one precept (1 hr 50 min), one evening problem session.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
prereqs: EGR 250.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of freshmen through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Game Theory & Strategy (Sess 1)
descrip: This course will present some basics about game theory (and perhaps debunk a few myths fostered by the movie "A Beautiful Mind"). While the course will be designed around the structure of game theoretic models, building from the simple ones to the more sophisticated, at each stage the emphasis will be on applications. These include models of oligopoly, bargaining, military conflict, legislative voting, and the design of the rules under which to negotiate, vote, or hold an auction.

title: Digital Communications and Systems
descrip: Digital communications and modem design, modulation, demodulation, and coding for communication and storage channels including disk drives and lightwave. Functions and their integration in a modern high-performance modem.

title: Latin American Studies Seminar - Politics and Drama in Latin America
reviews: I wish Alma was teaching this again, if she is absolutely take it. In general, I think it is great for anyone to take.
Interesting professor; unclear assignments.
prereqs: Some background in Latin American studies, such as previous study, study/travel, and/or reading knowledge of Spanish. An interest in performance and/or theater is encouraged..
descrip: Based on works of reportage by the instructor, this course will be an opportunity to discuss major themes and issues in contemporary Latin America. There will be sessions on Colombia, Cuba, El Salvador, Mexico and Venezuela, countries in which politics has been staged as a public spectacle, and/or in which the performance and ritual of violence has engrossed the young. There will also be sessions on Ernesto Guevara, on military and populist regimes and on Brazilian carnival as a reenactment of history. Good reading knowledge of Spanish helpful but not required.

title: Engineering in the Modern World
reviews: A great class that is not much work and still interesting. A good combo of history and science/engineering
A relatively easy and very interesting course.
Attend lectures! They're awesome!
Definitely take it! Especially if you are an engineer!
Definitely take it. 100%
Definitely take this course if you are seeking a relatively easy and very engaging HA.
Do the readings and take notes. If you do the problem sets and make a good study guide with dates, you will do well on the tests.
Go to lectures, the lecture slides have a lot of pictures without the explanations the professor gives in class.
Great - especially if you're PDFing.
Great HA for engineers. Math is plug and chug and the paper is interesting if you have a good topic
If you are interested in anything related to the history of engineering, then take this course!
It is a good course for HA requirement.
Its no secret that on a week-to-week basis the homework load difficult - just make sure you take this class seriously come the midterm, final, and final paper.
Keep up with the readings and go to lecture.
Read the books and enjoy the lectures.
Really enjoyed the class material. Was a lot for finals period to have a paper, presentation, and exam. The lectures are awesome and the readings are short and interesting.
Studying still required.
Take it and go to all of the lectures!
Take it as a distribution requirement. It is also pretty interesting.
Take this class if you want an easy HA and want to be engaged.  Be warned, the midterm and final are not to be underestimated.
Take this course only if you are interested in analyzing the history of modern day engineering.
This course provides a really good overview of engineering developments since ~1700.  So if that interests you at all, or if you need a good HA, this course would be good for you.
This is a great class to learn about inventors--fun, interesting, and relaxed.
This is a great survey course of engineering in the 19th and 20th century. As an engineer, I found it very nice to know all of the science and engineering discoveries that built modern engineering.

This is a well-taught and well-organized class. It's more work than you might expect to PDF it though. When PDFing for an HA, keep in mind that you have a final paper (which is 12  pages), a final presentation, and a final exam.
Trying to do some memorization over the course of the semester as opposed to cramming at the end.
You'll probably be dedicating quite a bit of time to this class, given the amount of readings and work that you have to do each week. Only take it if you enjoy the material.
easy ha
great
descrip: Lectures and readings focus on bridges, railroads, power plants, steamboats, telegraph, highways, automobiles, aircraft, computers, and the microchip. Historical analysis provides a basis for studying societal impact by focusing on scientific, political, ethical, and aesthetic aspects in the evolution of engineering over the past two and a half centuries. The precepts and the papers will focus historically on engineering ideas including the social and political issues raised by these innovations and how they were shaped by society as well as how they helped shape culture.

title: Beginner's Spanish I
reviews: Although class is everyday, the daily homework is not that much.  Jorge is a great teacher if you have the opportunity to have him.
Always come to class and be vocal with the professor.
Be prepared for a lot of work.
Be prepared for a quick moving class. I took Spanish all through middle school, so expected to have a slight advantage in the class. In actuality, I had to work very hard to keep up.
Be weary of the fact that although it is a 101 course, there will be many students who took Spanish in high school for one or more years, and come in with a lot more background knowledge.
Check the course calendar frequently to be sure of assignments and tests.
Definitely take it, after one semester you will already be able to hold a basic conversation and read and write basic essays without great difficulty.
Do not disregard studying early on in the semester. You will regret it.
Do not procrastinate!
Do not wait until the night before to study vocabulary for tests and quizzes. Attend office hours if you have any questions or concerns.
Do the assignments and constantly try to immerse yourself in the language the best you can.
Do the homework

Don't be afraid to make mistakes in class; you learn so much more if you speak and make mistakes than if you stay silent and just listen to others
It helps to study in groups
Don't take it at 9am. And make sure you keep up with the assignments.
Don't take this course unless you've taken Spanish before. Also I just hope you speak another language because foreign languages at Princeton are messed up.
Enjoy class, try to enjoy the work, and you will learn a lot.
Find out what class Zetterstrand is teaching. People give her criticism because she's the head of the department or something but she really teaches well.
Find ways to practice Spanish outside of class, perhaps at the language tables.

From talking to my peers, at least around half (if not most) of the other students had already taken Spanish. One guy I know had four years of Spanish behind him. If you've never taken Spanish, you will definitely need to work harder to do well.
Go to class, pay attention
Go to class. Pay attention in class because the topics actually build on each other.
Good start to a language.

I learned more Spanish in my first month at Princeton than I learned during years of high school language classes. If this doesn't attest to the sheer quality of Princeton's language department, I don't know what does. Yes, it is rigorous. But the feeling of leaving the classroom knowing that you are taking leaps and bounds toward fluency each and every day is irreplaceable.
I recommend it. It's an intriguing beginner's course that isn't too fast paced to struggle yet provides enough challenge to keep it interesting.
I think it is important to stay on top of the material in the textbook so that you can be prepared for class and get the most out of it.
I think students should take this class because it is a good beginner class in Spanish.

I think your experience of SPA 101 is heavily influenced by your teacher -- I had a grad student (Miguel) so it was pretty lackluster. Mainly, I was frustrated that everyone spoke in English 90% of the time, so I never got comfortable speaking in or listening to Spanish.

I would recommend this class if you've already taken Spanish in high school but aren't very strong in it. I would probably recommend taking another language if you're looking to begin an entirely new language (for English speakers), as there are many similarities between Spanish and English. In saying that, this class is both a challenge but manageable.
I would recommend this class to those needing to fill a language requirement.

I would recommend this course to a student who is looking to learn a new language. The Spanish department is fantastic and you will be really surprised about how much you learn in just one semester of beginner's Spanish.
If you have always wanted to take Spanish, Take it! You would not regret this decision I promise. It will be challenging but worth it in the end.
If you want to learn Spanish, this is a great way to begin!
If you're sure you want to take Spanish 101, make sure you get in the class with Prof. Zetterstrand. I hear she is supposed to be the best.
It's a basic intro language class, if you do the daily homework and supplement it with practicing vocabulary daily, you will surely ace the class.
It's a great language course, but get a bike if you plan to take it. It's all the way over by the E-quad.
It's fine.
Just put in the effort and it will be an enjoyable class.
Just take the course. It was great. Study little by little every day and although it's a lot of work in the end, it won't feel that way.
Make flashcards for the vocabulary and try to get ahead.
Make flashcards of the vocabulary words, and drill them constantly. My mistake was not doing that until the very end.
Make sure to stay on top of your work and don't be afraid to ask for help
None
Not a very stressful course. Manageable even without any prior knowledge of Spanish and a willingness to learn and participate.
Professor Zetterstrand is absolutely amazing. I highly recommend taking this class.
Research professors to find out who the most well-liked professors are, and try to put yourself in that section.

SPA 101 is very enjoyable if you have the right instructor. Unfortunately, I don't think Jorge Gaupp will be teaching this course again, but there are plenty of other good professors. Even if you are an absolute beginner to Spanish like I was, this course is more than manageable. With enough time and effort, you will do well.

Spanish 101 is a great course to take and even if you have taken Spanish before, there is still a challenge for you when you take this course. Professor Baranski is an amazing professor and wants to see all of her students excel in their ability to speak Spanish.

Spanish 101 isn't as easy as you think it sounds. It's intensive and can take up some time to learn properly. You have to be willing to attend class every day and be on top of the homework and readings. If you are, then it's pretty fun actually.
Spend time outside the class to review everything. You learn so much more if you do.
Study EVERY DAY and make note cards.
Study a lot - especially grammar.
Study vocab constantly.
TAKE IT. Professor Olander is the best!
Take Olander she is very nice and helps you a lot
Take Professor Zetterstrand's class!
Take Spanish 101 if you're a beginner!
Take good notes
Take it if you want begin learning Spanish. I learned so much in only 1 semester.
Take it if you want to learn the language.
Take it! Learn Spanish! It's so important. Know you have to take SPA 102, though!
Take it!! Prof. Olander was excellent and so helpful. The class was fun but not a joke, and most of the work was pretty enjoyable.
Take it.

Take the course 
It is 100%
Take the course even if you have a small interest in the language. It is interesting if you give it a chance.
Take this class if you know you need something to boost your GPA. The work is manageable and I found the class to be a generally low-stress environment. It's very possible to get an A in this class.
Take this class or die trying.
Take this course with Professor Baranski. She is a fun teacher and is always willing to work with you. She really cares about her students.
The books are expensive so try to ask a previous student if you could buy it off of them rather than buying the books brand new.

There will be a lot of things that you need to do outside of class to understand everything in class fully. This isn't a high school language class and you can't treat it like that, you need to be willing to learn and practice all on your own.
This course is challenging but manageable. I highly recommend Professor Cervantes as an instructor.
To take it and go to class
Try to speak what you learn daily.
Use what you learn as much as you can.
Very enjoyable, be ready to learn a lot!
fulfills the requirement
work for fluency instead of just doing the assignments - it makes it easier
prereqs: Students with previous knowledge in Spanish MUST take the Department's Spanish language placement test available online from July 15 - August 15 before taking this course. This also applies to Graduate students interested in taking the course. International Baccalaureate students must also take the placement test. Students with an AP5/SP SAT ST 760 score are not required to take this test..
descrip: SPA 101 presents the basic structures and vocabulary of the Spanish language. The four skills (listening, speaking, reading and writing) are practiced and developed by means of classroom activities and materials in which language appears in a cultural context. Classes are conducted in Spanish. No credit is given for SPA 101 unless followed by SPA 102.

title: Lyrical Traditions in Portuguese
reviews: Don't shy away from poetry just because it seems too esoteric / difficult to understand.  By the end of this course you will find an appreciation for poetry. I know I am going to miss my weekly excuse to sit down and enjoy beautiful writing!
Give yourself plenty of time to write the weekly papers.

This is a great Portuguese class! Poetry is fun and we explore a lot of different topics in the course: history, social issues, as well as literary analysis. Nicola is a great professor and the class is very student-directed. Definitely give the course a try-- you'll learn something new and improve your Portuguese!
prereqs: POR 208 or instructor's permission..
descrip: A voyage through the lyrical traditions of Portugal, Brazil, and Portuguese-speaking Africa, this course seeks to trace the evolution of the poetic form and illuminate dynamic and enduring intertextualities. Through close-readings of major works of poetry we will explore the ongoing dialogue between poets and artists of the spoken word across time and space, providing the foundation for a deeper understanding of the diverse Portuguese-language literary and cultural landscape.

title: Politics and Society in the Arabic Novel and Film
reviews: If you're interested in the Middle East or literature then you should take this course!
Take it for the amazing books and the interesting (though somewhat unstructured) discussions. Prof Levy is quite knowledgeable and the class is rewarding.

The readings are phenomenal.  If you are interested in learning more about the Middle East and reading some very interesting (mostly contemporary) novels, take it.  Professor Levy really knows the material.
This is an amazing class.  Professor Levy is wonderful and the literature you read really provides a glimpse into the past and present realities of Middle Eastern life.
descrip: This course examines how Arabic fiction and film has addressed major social and political issues such as the aftermath of colonialism, labor migration, war, social repression, women's rights, and dictatorship. The course covers novels from Egypt, the Sudan, Lebanon, Palestine, Morocco, and Iraq. Topics covered include the Lebanese Civil War, the Palestinian struggle, Islamic fundamentalism, Iraq under the Baathist regime, and the Arab Spring. The course will also look more broadly at experiences of the postcolonial world as reflected in modern Arabic writing. All readings are in English translation.

title: Christopher Durang: My Life in Art
reviews: If you only know Durang by his work, be prepared for someone you did not expect at all.
The Cadden experience is entertaining, but don't go in expecting a traditional, close-reading-focused English seminar semester.
This is a one-time-only course, so no one else will ever be able to take it!
Well, this course will never happen again because Christopher Durang was only here this year.
prereqs: None. For admission, please contact Professor Michael Cadden at: mcadden@princeton.edu.
descrip: This course will focus on the lifetime achievement of one of the nation's greatest playwrights, Christopher Durang, who will be participating in the class as the inaugural Roger S. Berlind '52 Playwright-in-Residence. We'll focus on Durang's writing and rehearsal process, the writers who have meant most to him, the joys and pains of theatrical collaboration, and the perils of writing comedy with a satiric edge.

title: Modern Japanese Prose
descrip: A study of selected major authors and literary trends in modern Japan, with an emphasis on the Meiji and Taisho periods.

title: Structural Materials
reviews: Great course to learn about materials.
Take it! It's a great course!
it's easy to catch up even if you don't have any background. And professor Wole is helpful too.
descrip: Stress/strain behavior of materials; dislocation theory and strengthening mechanisms; yield strength; materials selection. Fundamentals of plasticity, Tresca and Von Mieses yield criteria. Case study on forging: upper and lower bounds. Basic elements of fracture. Fracture mechanics. Mechanisms of fracture. The fracture toughness. Case studies and design. Fatigue mechanisms and life prediction methodologies.

title: Operating Systems
reviews: Be prepared to put a lot of time into the assignments. like, a lot of time. The material isn't the most interesting on paper, but if you have the time to spend on the assignments, this course can be very rewarding - you'll become a better systems programmer, and you'll leave with a working understanding of many OS functions.
Be prepared to spend a lot of time.  Worth it in the end
Certainly a lot of work, but you'll get a lot out of it.
Clear your schedule, but ultimately worth it.
I will recommend it to my class mates.
If you are at all interested in systems, take it. Totally worth the work
If you're at all interested in how systems actually work, you have to take this.

It's a hard class, but it's probably my favorite class that I've taken thus far. The assignments, though challenging, were very rewarding and fun (granted, they were often very unclear, so understanding them was a challenge in itself). JP's a good lecturer, one of the TAs is the best (most helpful) TA I've had here (the other, well, is probably the opposite), but as long as you keep up with the material and in lecture I think it will be a rewarding and fun class.
It's a lot of time, but the knowledge you get out of it is pretty useful and practical. It's not as bad as people used to make it out to be.

It's very interesting and important topic and changed how I look at systems and software. The assignments are tough and time-consuming, but it seems that the department is aware of this and has made / is making effort to address this.

Lots of work, but very rewarding.  And you don't need to be a CS major (I wasn't even an engineer).  As long as you took 217, liked it, and did well, you're probably set for this class.  Definitely take it if you have any interest in systems programming.
Manageable, despite the reputation. Assignments are very other week and the TAs are very helpful. The class is a little disorganized however.
OS is not a hard class.....so long as they fix the assignment instructions to the level of cos 217
Start early.
Super important material, have to take it, but hopefully the course staff would be more involved in future semesters.
Take it if you are interested in OS, obviously. The knowledge you pick up here will come handy in job interviews, especially stuffs about concurrency.
Take it if you're interested in the subject.
Take it in a light schedule semester
Take it only for a systems requirement. But consider other classes for that too.
The assignments take a lot of time. Definitely worth taking if you're a COS major.
The class is difficult but the material is extraordinarily important.
The course comes with a very heavy workload, so be prepared to schedule easier classes around it.
The material covers important concepts that a computer science/engineering student needs to know.

This class is not near as much work as it's rumored to be, I think in part because they just revamped the assignments. That being said, the assignments are tough and take a significant amount of time. But nowhere near as much as graphics. JP is a very good lecturer. From what I've heard and observed, he's much better than Kai Li, who normally teaches this course. So even though he's incredibly unorganized, I think you're probably better off with JP. Overall a good class and you learn a lot of useful concepts that you don't really learn elsewhere, such as synchronization.

This class, as you probably know, is a huge time suck.  Be prepared to learn a lot on your own.  TAs are not too helpful for assignments.  Choose your partner wisely.  JP is a good lecturer but is of no help for the assignments.  You will learn a lot about OS but will put in a ton of time.
This course has a well deserved reputation for being a lot of work. Be prepared to spend a lot of time debugging your implementations.

This is a great course!!  The material is really interesting, and the programming assignments are a lot of fun!  Having said that though, it is as much work as they say, so be prepared to spend a lot of time with your project partner.
This is an enormous time sucker. Be prepared to spend MANY MANY MANY hours in the fishbowl of Friend working on assignments.
Tough course, but I think you'll be glad to take it
Unless they improve the assignments and train preceptors better, run far, far away from this course. This class is endless frustration and little reward.
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226. Audit option only available with instructor's permission..
descrip: An introduction to operating systems. Emphasis is on the fundamentals of how to design and implement an operating system. Topics include operating system structure, processes, threads, synchronizations, concurrent programming, interprocess communications, virtual memory, I/O device management, and file systems.

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
reviews: Do the readings.

I would say that:
open your mind and you will find yourself deeply enjoyed in the course.
The course is useful for students who started doing research and attending conferences/writing papers.
Worth taking.
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing with the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students & post-docs.

title: Advanced Economic Theory I
descrip: Topics vary from year to year reflecting, among other things, current developments and the instructor's interests. Topics covered in past years have included expected and nonexpected utility theory, intertemporal general equilibrium theory, evolutionary game theory, dynamic games, contract theory, theory of organizations, and bounded rationality.

title: Music Theory through Performance and Composition
reviews: Be sure to practice.
Be sure to remember and take note of all the rules of different styles.
Be willing to work and to struggle. You aren't going to be Bach, unless you're really that good.

Class with Professor Tymoczko has been great; he's an engaging lecturer which will make for an for enjoyable class. Unfortunately I believe this is his left year teaching the class so I cannot vouch for how the course will be taught in the future. If the course will stay similarly styled, it's a great introductory music class for beginners and experienced students looking to increase their historical understand of how music evolved.
Definitely take if you are interested in learning more about music.

Dmitri was awesome, but I think he won't be teaching it next year, so that will make a big difference. 2/3 of the class are very experienced in music (some have taken theory before or even have perfect pitch), while the other 1/3 is less so. If you're in the 1/3, I bet it's a lot more work.
Do not take this class if you have never taken music theory before especially if you are only a vocalist!

Do not take this course if you do not have any music theory experience prior to Princeton. Especially do not take this course if you cannot even read music and do not play an instrument or sing, because time is not given to those trivial things.
Do the ear training!!!

Don't expect this to be an "easy A" course. It took as much time as my COS course. I thought it was a great course, mainly because I'm genuinely into music (always composing stuff on my own, started at 4yo, multiple instruments).
Don't procrastinate with the assignments and you will actually have fun doing them.
Fantastic course, take it if you have some music theory background. It's not like any other theory course you'll take anywhere else.
Go to all classes and pay special attention to all of the handouts!
Helpful to have a basic background in music theory if you're considering this course.
I have no advice. Take it if you want. I'm glad that I took it.
I would recommend it if necessary for a requirement- it was a lot of work for me.
I would recommend that the student be very dedicated to their pursuit of music and that he or she should be willing to work very hard.

I would say that it is important to work hard on the homework assignments and try to understand your mistakes when you get the assignments back. That way, you will better understand the course material and will be better prepared for exams.
If you play an instrument and like music, you really need to take this course.

If you want to get the certificate in musical performance or major in music, you have to take this course, so it doesn't matter what kind of reviews you read about this course.  If, however, you want to take this course out of general interest, I would simply advise you not to underestimate it.  It is very time consuming, and requires practice outside of the 5 hours of week of class time.  Dmitri makes the material more interesting that most people could, though, so if he's teaching, you should take this course.

Its a ton of fun, but make sure you know some music before. Reading bass and treble clef, knowing each of the key signatures and the definition of major and minor scales and chords is pretty important to know before you start.
Knowing how to play piano (even at a basic level), or at least knowing how to visualize a piano keyboard, will be very helpful.

Only take it if you have a strong basic understanding of music theory and can play an instrument pretty well. You must be willing to spend a lot of time composing original pieces in certain styles and analyzing classical pieces. If you are only somewhat interested in music, don't take it.
RECOMMEND! Everyone should take music theory at some point in their lives.
Read the hand outs before doing the home works. Make sure to understand each concept clearly before moving on because they build on each other.
Take advantage of your preceptor's office hours, make sure you allot enough time to finish each assignment thoughtfully and don't fall behind on ear training.
Take it if you are interested in theory. I heard Dmitri is not teaching next year so this may not apply. But his lectures are amazing.
Take it if you know how to read music! (But PDF it if you don't already have a background in music theory, because the AP Music Theory/music certificate kids trash the curve.)
Take it if you need it as a requirement? And make sure to do well on the homework assignments!
Take it if you're interested! The PDF option is always there.
Take it with Dmitri!
Take it, and don't work hard on the assignments. Work smart. Make sure you know what you're doing before you start working, and then go ahead.
Take it.

Take this class!  It is not easy especially if you don't have a strong background (if you're looking to learn some basic music theory for your LA that's MUS 104) but you'll learn SO much in 12 weeks.  The lectures and assignments are very engaging.
This class is NOT an easy class. It takes a lot of outside study and work, and has to be taken seriously.
This course is difficult, but if you enjoy music and already know some music theory you should probably like it. I strongly recommend this course.
This is an incredible class.  Definitely take it, especially if Professor Tymoczko ever teaches it again.
This is not a course you take for fun or for a good grade. Take it only for major or certificate.
Tymozcko is an excellent teacher and he makes the topic very interesting.
Uh... Take it.
Unless you have some music theory background, this course will be difficult
Unless you know theory already, and unless you know theory very well, don't take this course unless you absolutely must.
prereqs: The ability to read music in treble and bass clef. Basic familiarity with some instrument. Some prior exposure to music theory is helpful. Students who are nervous about their prior experience should consider 104..
descrip: MUS 105 is the first half of a comprehensive introduction to music theory, covering the basic principles of a wide range of Western musical styles, including medieval music, Renaissance music, classical music, jazz and rock. The emphasis throughout is on learning by creating, performing, and listening to music. Though this is an academic course, we try not to lose sight of the fact that music is something that brings us joy.

title: Applied Social Statistics
descrip: An introduction to basic concepts in probability and statistics with applications to social research. We cover descriptive statistics, sampling distributions, statistical inference for means and proportions (including point estimation, confidence intervals and tests of hypotheses), the comparison of two or more groups, and an introduction to analysis of variance and linear regression. Throughout the course we use the open-source statistical package R to illustrate and apply the techniques. The course is intended to prepare students to take Advanced Social Statistics the following term.

title: Studies in Religion and Morality - Monarchies, Empires, and Republics
descrip: This seminar considers competing accounts of religion and its relation to domination, liberty, and political sovereignty, beginning with Dante and ending with Hume, but not including Hobbes and Locke.

title: The Modeling Complex
descrip: The modeling complex refers to a category of architectural thinking and working that stretches from the Renaissance to the present. It includes those practices and processes that privilege a dynamic temporal and spatial relationship between architectural things or objects and their effects in the world over time. Things, objects, effects will be studied through readings in theory from architecture, art, philosophy, mathematics and the sciences, and through the examination of case studies.

title: Experimental Chemistry
reviews: Battle through it, collaborate with peers. Your fellow majors are what will get you through this tough class. You will learn a lot.

Don't take it if you don't have to--not because it's badly-run or anything, it's just tons of work and you will probably pull many late-nighters before you finish.  You will bond with other Chemistry majors, though.  Be aware that it is very front-loaded, with four lab reports due in the first half of the semester and an independent project in the second.
If at all possible, avoid this course.

If you don't know something for a lab report, look it up online and find a reference. Also, contact lab TAs early and ask a lot of questions, particularly about their individual expectations for your work.

If you want an easy time, take MSE 302 instead. Otherwise, it's a solid course which gives you a good exposure to various kinds of experimental chemistry and the statistical knowledge required to practice. Good sense of community comes out of the lab struggles too.
If you're a chemistry major, you'll probably end up taking this class.
It's a lot of work! Ideally, only take 4 courses when taking this (and JIW counts as a course!).
It's not as bad as everyone makes it out to be and actually turns out to be enjoyable after awhile.

Make sure that you want to be a chem major before taking this class.  If I had known how terrible this class was, I probably would not have picked chemistry.  I do not know anyone who was able to complete the lab reports without staying up very late (as in 5 am).  I used to be a well-rounded person, but I had to give up everything outside of class for this time-demanding course.
Make your schedule around this class. It took more time than my other 4 put together
Obviously you're only taking it if it's a departmental. Will destroy the first half of your semester. Good luck.
Plan ahead to write lab reports. They are very time-consuming.
Start lab reports early. They aren't as bad as people tend to make them out to be, but they are by no means enjoyable and take more time than a lab report should. Attend lectures.
Take it if you need to for the chem dept. It's a great way to make friends with the other chem majors.
This is the hardest course that you will ever take, for the first six weeks.  It is easily the work of two classes.  The last six weeks has a lighter workload.
You need to take it. If you don't wanna do a ton of work then don't take it.
You'll get through it.
You're probably taking this because it's required--good luck!
prereqs: CHM 202, 204 or 215 or equivalent. Concomitant enrollment in either CHM 305 or 407 is strongly advised..
descrip: The purpose of this laboratory course is to teach the principles and practice of modern experimental chemistry, including: data collection, analysis, and interpretation; experimental design; validity of data and meaning of statistical correlation; and theoretical and operational aspects of modern instrumentation. Applications of computers in data analysis and molecular modeling will also be covered.

title: Current Issues in Neuroscience and Behavior
reviews: I would encourage other students to take this course to really get a feel for the breadth of neuroscience research out there today.
It's a good seminar to get an overview of ongoing neuroscience research at all levels.
The speakers they chose are excellent.
n/a
descrip: Advanced seminar that reflects current research on brain and behavior.

title: Special Topics in the History of Science, Technology, and Medicine - Alchemy
reviews: I would greatly encourage any students up for a challenge, even advanced undergraduates, to take this class. It's very difficult, but worth the work in the end. I am a better historian after taking this class. And you get to take a field trip to Philadelphia (and Firestone) to look at cool manuscripts!
Ramping is excellent. Take a course if you have the chance.
This is a very good course, and you will learn a lot about alchemy, and the historiography of alchemy.
descrip: This History of Science graduate seminar will explore the topic of Alchemy.

title: Topology
reviews: Enjoyable class. Good introduction.
I would definitely recommend taking this course.
If it is with Szabo definitely take it
If you need topology for a math departmental, this course is the one.

If you're a math major or considering being one, take this course.  Topology is a beautiful and essential subject, and the course is extremely well done.  I'd recommend taking it sophomore fall since it's so fundamental, and it's one of the easier 300 level math courses.  Szabo is a great professor, and the book is really good.  Workload isn't bad for an upper level math course.
Must take it if you're interested. Szabo is a fantastic lecturer and even though the problem sets don't take a long time, you still learn a lot! However, the final is hard..

One of the best math courses available. The book by Munkres is an essential read as it basically explains everything from scratch and eases you into the world of topology. Professor Szabo also does a great job in making the various concepts clear and understandable. Assignments are generally easy and manageable and the class isn't very difficult until maybe the last couple of weeks where you mix up algebra and topology - I have to say I got a bit lost around that time. The final is based on the algebraic topology stuff from the last few weeks so it is pretty challenging. But overall, it's a fun and enlightening ride.

Stay on top of the readings and you should be fine. You will most likely not need to read Munkres for the entirety of the first half of the class, but it will become necessary for the second half.

Knowing some algebra, particularly group theory, will be very helpful for the algebraic topology part of the class. 

Professor Szabo is very good, but asking him questions will help you get the most out of lecture as he oftentimes will gloss over proofs.

Szabo is a great professor and the problem sets are very manageable in comparison to those of other math classes. If for no other reason, take it so you can finally understand the doughnut/coffee cup joke.
Take it -- fun and not hard.
Take it! It's well worth your time, Szabo's a great professor, and topology's a fascinating subject.
The book is really useful.
The final is much harder than everything else. I liked the first half more than the second half of the course

This course is very easy up until the final exam.  The final is a futt bucking.  Algebra I should really be a prereq.  Don't get in the habit of not going to lecture until then because Szabo is a great instructor and knows not just the material but how to teach it too.

This was a very enjoyable (and useful) departmental, so I would recommend this course to any other math major. Definitely attend every lecture--Professor Szabo is great and the lectures really help build your understanding.

You should definitely take this class, because it's awesome. Szabo' is great, the homeworks are not unreasonable, and the class is cool. I do have to say that it picks up after we enter algebraic topology, but fear not.
prereqs: MAT202 or 204 or 218 or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to point-set topology, the fundamental group, covering spaces, methods of calculation and applications.

title: Romanticism and the Age of Revolution
reviews: Annotate your readings! Really helps you remember what came to mind as you read the texts.
I'm an English major but didn't expect to fall in love with Romantic poetry. I ended up choosing a Wordsworth stanza as my senior quote
Take this course! Or, if you are unable to, take any course with Professor Wolfson's name on it - I certainly plan to.
descrip: Romanticism was a revolution in literary styles and subjects, and its writers lived in an age of revolutions...American, French, and roiling debates about the rights of men, of women, and the atrocity of the slave trade, and amid, within, and across this, the vital power of imagination. Our study will concern literary aesthetics and practices in this revolutionary age.

title: The Environmental Engineering of Buildings, Part I
reviews: Enjoy
Stay on top of the assignments, as they take a little bit longer than you anticipate.
Timing and scheduling was an issue at the beginning of the course - though it worked out through out the course of the semester.
none
prereqs: All undergraduate students must have permission of the instructor to enroll..
descrip: The first part of a sequence taught over two terms that provides a broad introduction to Building Systems, Environmental Control and Energy Conservation. Sustainable design themes and environmentally responsible practices are stressed throughout and form a backdrop to all the instructional material provided. The fall course focuses on fundamental concepts and provides an introduction to Mechanical, Electrical, Plumbing, Lighting, Acoustical and Life Safety systems. ARC 515, taught in the spring, considers the design process and the integration of these systems into buildings.

title: The Comparative Political Economy of Development
descrip: Analysis of political change and the operation of political institutions in the development process, with emphasis on the interaction of political and economic factors. Various definitions and theories of political development are examined and tested against different economic, ethnic, geographic, and social contexts.

title: Cities and Suburbs in American History
reviews: Go to all the lectures and take careful, as they are both interesting and necessary to succeeding in the class. Be selective and consistent about how much reading you will do each week, and mark interesting segments of each book for use in precept or exams.

I really recommend this course, especially if you have an interest in thinking about history and the built environment. Professor Isenberg is a very dedicated teacher. The lectures are more fluid so it may take a while to get used to the organization of the course, but this fluidity also helps to powerfully capture historical dynamics across time. As a history major, this was also a great pre-20th century American history course.
I would definitely take this class if you want your mind expanded about the city and the agency that we each have within our cultural landscape.
Maybe you would like this course if you are open to it, but don't expect too much.

This is one of the worst classes I have taken at Princeton. The lectures are disorganized, filled with incoherent tangents, and poorly supported arguments. Don't take this class. Find another history class if you want to try out history.
prereqs: PDF option is not available to History concentrators..
descrip: From the colonial era to the present, this course weaves together a comprehensive history of American cities and suburbs, cutting across social life, politics, economics, culture, and the built environment.
