Topics include urban planning and design, public and private spaces, social experience, urban investment and disinvestment, the metropolitan economy, politics and policy, arts and culture, city leadership, and the participation of ordinary people in shaping urban and suburban life.

title: Mechanics of Solids
reviews: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. CEE 205 is the whole package...in exactly what you do NOT want in a Princeton course. The course is a string of disappointments, like receiving a video-game shaped Christmas present that turns out to be a textbook. Lectures were haphazard, unclear, and sleep-inducing; precept is equally unhelpful. There is a serious disconnect between Adriaenssens and the students - after being let down for lecture and precept, I looked to office hours as the last line of defense and even those were disappointing. Avoid at all costs - CEE majors have to take it but for the rest of you, run while you can. Considering the bounty of courses Princeton offers it's a huge shame that students every year will be forced to sit through this one. The MAE version of solids is much better taught from what I hear. Mark my words, RUN WHILE YOU CAN.
Do the readings in the textbook. Make sure to stay on top of the different assignments

Everyone taking this course was required to, so if that's you then you'll be fine. It wasn't too time consuming and although I got lost halfway through the semester, the exams were predictable so it works out.
Give yourself time to complete the problem set and read the textbook examples for clarification of concepts/applications.

I would not recommend taking this course unless it is a requirement. However, it is still a reasonable course, and the material is not too challenging. Engage in the design experiences and try to apply what you have learned from lectures in your designs.

I would say to enjoy the design experiences and make them your own!! It is more important to develop a concept or idea of a structure than to get caught up in researching a thousand little details. Have fun with it!
If its something you have to take then that is probably why youre looking at it.  The mechanics of how things work is actually pretty interesting, there is just a lot you have to keep straight.
Interesting and well-taught course. Very manageable as long as you pay attention and do the work.

It's a well-taught and organized course. Even if you aren't CEE but have some interest in design, architecture, or how everyday mechanics works, it's an interesting class with many applications. There's certainly engineering/physics involved, but there are design aspects that don't rely on physics. The class isn't as difficult physics-wise as PHY 103, but it does expect that you already know basic physics.
Keep up with the readings, watch course videos before lecture, go to office hours for problem set help throughout the semester.
Look over examples from the book in each section, otherwise you'll have a hard time with the problem sets.
Make sure you know how to do shear diagrams THEY WILL NEVER GO AWAY (and that the one think I can promise about this class).
Not a bad class, but not super interesting.
Only take if necessary. Do not take if you are not a CEE major
Only take if required to.
See if you can ask for biweekly design experiences because they were pretty unrelated to material in class and took up a lot of time to do.
Take this if you are a civil engineering major.
Take this only if required and/or you're eager to learn about solid mechanics.
This class is a CEE requirement, so there's no way out of it. This class could have the potential of being actually pretty cool, but it just never impressed me in any way.

This class is very manageable if you work ahead on problem sets and try to stay up on the textbook readings every week.  Also precepts are the time when you will actually go through problems.  Office hours were incredibly helpful and you could often receive one-on-one help.
You might like it more than I did. It seems like most people did. Take it if you need to.
prereqs: PHY 103 and MAT 104.
descrip: This course teaches fundamental principles of solid mechanics. Equilibrium equations, reactims, internal forces, stress, strain, Mohr's circle, and Hooke's law. Analysis of the stress and deformation in simple structural members for safe and stable engineering design. Axial force in bars, torsion in shafts, bending and shearing in beams, stability of elastic columns, strain transformation, stress transformation, circle of Mohr, combined loadings, design project.

title: Introduction to Ballet
reviews: Everyone at Princeton should take this course. Tina is hilarious and dancing 4 hours a week is actually really fun. The worst that could come out of it is a P.

For someone who has never danced before, this was still a pretty enjoyable class.  Tina Fehlandt is awesome (fascinating professional experience and super kind).  The workload isn't bad (just a couple short papers outside of class, not much else), but I still felt like I got something out of it.  Dancing is very different from most of the other classes Princeton offers and it's really nice to have this class for the variety.  I would recommend this over DAN 209, which felt a lot more esoteric and less instructive (more introspective).
TAKE IT!!!!! This is a very popular class.
TAKE THIS CLASS it's the best

TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Tina is absolutely the best, and taking this course is one of the best decisions I've made. The classes were chill, yet we learned so many ballet steps and so much about the ballet world. Don't be shy to ask any and every questions you might have ever had about ballet, watching ballets, dance life, etc. The book readings are kind of hard to get through, but it's mostly for your interest and to have some background.
Take it and be engaged - it's extremely rewarding.
Take it. Do yourself a favor. You've earned it.
Take it. Tina is the best.
Take the course! Tina is understanding and patient and makes everyone feel at ease in the studio whether you've danced ballet or not.
Take this if Tina is teaching it. She is enthusiastic and makes ballet the most fun part of your day!
This class is loads of fun and not a lot of work but be ready to jump around and try out real ballet in class.
Very enjoyable. She makes it very fun and chill, especially for people who don't know ballet
descrip: From grand plie to grand jete, Introduction to Ballet is for students with a curiosity for the study of classical ballet. No prior dance experience necessary and beginners are welcome. In this studio course students will learn the fundamentals of ballet, gaining an understanding of its physicality, artistry, and principles of alignment. Students will examine the historical origins of ballet and its absorption of cultural influences. Live music will be featured in this class and key in exploring the inextricable link between music and dance.

title: 19th-Century Fiction
reviews: Attend lectures, even if you may not have done the readings
Best class I've taken in four years
Definitely take a course from Jeff at least once in your Princeton career! There is a lot of reading, but do the readings and the lectures will be even more amazing.

Definitely take it because of Jeff. He makes it the experience it is. The novels themselves are classics and everyone should read them. Expect to love lecture and don't expect to love precept... 

Also, read the books if you can before the semester starts! Then you wont be overwhelmed.

Definitely worth taking. Grading is generous and lectures are hysterical. Appeals to ENG and STEM people alike through Jeff's ability to conduct energies and lessons of this literature to modern life. Some things he says are bizarre and incoherent, but that comes with the territory of English Departments, right?
Do all the readings (especially the longer books) during the summer. Don't wait till the school year - you won't have time.
Do as much of the reading ahead of time as you can. Start thinking about your papers early, you have a lot of freedom with them.
Do as much of the readings as you can and attend lecture - the class is all about Jeff.
Do some of the reading early over the summer if you can. It might seem like a daunting task to read 6 long novels but I would highly recommend this class to anyone interested!
Do the reading ahead of time if you can; you'll get a lot more out of precept if you do the readings.
Do the reading ahead of time. You won't have time during the actual semester.
Get started on the reading early!!!!!! And never skip lecture. Don't be shy and get to know Jeff, you won't regret it.
Get started on the reading in the summer if you can! Don't stress if you get a little behind as he is very accomodating.

Going to lecture is sometimes like going to a comedy show, but also like sitting around a campfire with Jeff, but also like watching a P90X workout, but also like glimpsing into the galaxy of the world's best literature. TAKE IT
Great class if you need to get an LA requirement out of the way. You do not have to read all the books to do well! Take it, Jeff is amazing!
Great course, but to really get the most out of it, you ought to read all the lengthy books. Definitely read over summer. Alternatively, read one book each half of the semester, and pdf it
I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS COURSE. DROP A CLASS IF YOU HAVE TO TO FIT THIS IN YOUR SCHEDULE.
I HIGHLY recommend taking this course, especially if you don't live in Rockefeller (Professor Nunokawa is the master of Rocky College and he knows everyone there).
I recommend reading a number of the longer novels before starting the course, because you won't be able to keep up with the reading, especially if you're taking a heavy course load or 5 classes.

I would recommend this class for the lectures; if you can, try to get Nunokawa as your preceptor because I've heard many good things about him. The readings can be challenging to complete, so read them ahead of time and it'll make the lectures that much better.
If possible, read the books over the summer or before the semester starts.Then, you will have a very low workload during the semester.

It's a good one. Actually, it's a fantastic one: whether you're an English major, or an engineer looking for an LA to PDF, you really can't go wrong. Jeff Nunokawa is totally brilliant and totally insane, so go to lecture or you're missing out on a great show. It's a lot of reading, but if you read one or two novels over the summer then it helps a lot.

It's a steep workload so get started early. Professor Nunokawa is funny but he's also all over the place in his lectures. I thought the class was worth taking but I'm not sure I would recommend it to non English majors.
Lectures are great. Take the course if you are interested in fiction or writing and can get through a lot of reading quickly.
Make sure to read the books thoroughly

Must take. Jeff's class is a serious Princeton bucket list class. Can't miss it. Exciting take on everything that there is to life. Jeff's course description is not kidding. Everything. So take it. Make sure to read the books ahead if you are though since it's a lot of reading to do during the semester. But great books. Can change your life.
One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton. Took it out of general interest in English and to learn more about a subject I disliked in high school. Jeff is PHENOMENAL. TAKE IT.

PROFESSOR NUNOKAWA IS AWESOME.  Incredibly thoughtful fellow, and he's very welcoming to socially conservative students like myself.  A very Catholic man, in a sense.  Take the course, and try to read two novels back-to-back.  Then you're all set to write the papers.  Great class.  And you'll want to read the rest of the novels down the road.
Professor Nunokawa is an extremely engaging lecturer, the books are wonderful, and the overall atmosphere of lecture/precept is friendly and encouraging. Definitely a worthwhile course.
Read a book or two at least over the summer.
Read the books over the summer if you are planning on taking this course because it is a lot of pages per week.
Read the books over the summer.
Read the books over the summer. Get to know Jeff. Talk over paper topics with your preceptor or Jeff.

Read the novels over the summer. I felt that I had a very good handle on the material because during the semester, I read the novels for the second time. This really added to the experience because I was able to engage with the text in a much deeper way, that added a lot of insight to my writing and precept points as well.
Recommend

Set up a steady reading schedule at the beginning of the semester and try to stick to that. Your reading schedule doesn't need to include reading every word of every book, because that may not be possible, but you will get a lot more out of the course if you at least have a good idea of the general plot, writing style, major characters, and major themes in the novels.
Start reading in advance! Pace yourself with the reading.
TAKE IT. Keep up with reading. Think deeply about these amazing texts.

TAKE TAKE TAKE TAKE. Jeff Nunokawa is the BOMB - the man is a legend. Deserves his own distribution requirement - JN. To go through Princeton without experiencing JN is a major tragedy and a poor allocation of your Princeton course selection. Hands down best lecturer you will ever find - the man yells, tells stories about his mom, and talks so animatedly he pants to catch his breath. Everything a student could wish for in a professor: brilliant, engaging, approachable, friendly, entertaining. All the world's a stage to Jeff - he can command a lecture like no other. He will string you along with his eloquence, his vivacity, his stories about his mom (frequent occurrence). Jeff truly loves the subject matter as well; you can tell he lives and breathes it, and his love for 19th century fiction is second only to perhaps his love for his students. Please please please do yourself a favor and TAKE THIS COURSE or any course with Jeff.
Take it for Jeff.
Take it for the lecture.
Take it to get an LA out of the way, but nothing more.
Take it!
Take it! Awesome course with really interesting reading and really low stress. The lectures are really entertaining and I had a great precept.
Take it! Jeff is truly one of a kind. Just try to do all the readings over the summer.
Take it. Nunokawa is incredible. Do the reading over the summer.
Take the class, if only for Professor Nunokawa's lectures. They can actually make a Monday enjoyable.
Take the course, read the books, come to lecture - it will be worth your while!
Take the course. Try to do some of the readings in the summer, but it is not absolutely necessary to read all of the books. The papers are fun and lecture is legendary

Take this course if you're looking for an LA or fascinating English class, it's very entertaining and instructive. Just be aware that lectures are so much better if you have done the reading, and it is a lot of reading, so try and do them before term time.
Take this, you probably won't need to PDF but keep it as an option. Taking a class with Jeff is a good idea before you graduate.
Take this. If only for Jeff.
The novels alone are worth it (Middlemarch is the best English language novel you will ever read), but Jeff Nunokawa takes it over the top.

This course is great if you want to read amazing literature and go to energetic and entertaining lectures. The workload is also pretty easy, especially if you don't read everything. You definitely don't have to read much to get by, but the more you read the more you get out of the course. Precept quality is iffy. Overall I think this course may be a bit overhyped - I don't think it's a must take class. What I learned wasn't quite as revelatory as people make it sound. That said, it was enjoyable overall, and worth it if you're interested in the topic and have the time.

This is one of the most fantastic classes you will take at Princeton, if the teacher is Jeff Nunokawa. I read when I was deciding whether or not to take this class that there should be a JN (Jeff Nunokawa) distribution requirement at Princeton, and after this class I wholeheartedly agree! I felt like my heart grew 3 sizes after this class, and I know so much more about both 19th century literature, and life. I cannot recommend this class enough. 

Read in the summer, though! There are so many books and they are each so thick! You will thank yourself if you do, if you do you will not have to do much work for this class besides the two papers. The papers themselves are really open-ended, which can be hard to come up with a topics, but Nunokawa (and I'm assuming the other preceptors as well) gives very good feedback, and for me the writing experience was therefore made a positive one.

What can be said about Jeff Nunokawa? What can I say that hasn't already been said? Probably nothing, so allow me to add my voice to the chorus encouraging you to take this class. He is a hilarious, insightful person, and it is very fun to try to watch him talk quickly enough to keep up with his super-speed brain. He will make you appreciate books you once viewed as stodgy.
good class i liked it.
take it. 110%.
descrip: This course will acquaint students with the distinctive features of the nineteenth century novel, from Austen to Hardy. Lectures will seek to illuminate relations between social and aesthetic dimensions of the texts we read. We will consider how these fictional imaginings of things like love, sex, money, class, and race help shape the ways we live now.

title: Microeconomic Theory
reviews: A good review and deeper look at Microeconomic concepts. Fairly light workload (no readings, only 7 problem sets, one midterm and a final). Prof Chassang and the TAs are very willing to help on an individual level, so use them as a resource. Use lecture slides and problem sets as your primary review for exams.
Attend all lectures, definitely ask for help if you need it, otherwise you might struggle in the future
Attend office hours often and understand how to do problem sets from scratch.
Be careful on problem sets
Chassang is nice and has good intentions but his lectures are absolutely horrible and everyone is confused 90% of the time and he is completely oblivious
Chassang sucks and Nikhil is the worst preceptor at Princeton.
DON'T TAKE IT UNLESS YOU HAVE TO.  THANK GOD I'M PDFing THIS.
Enjoy
Go to office hours
Go to precept. While perhaps not necessary to understand the material, will make doing problem sets a lot easier
Go to precepts and redo problem sets and practice exams before the midterm or final.
Good class
If you are deciding between 300 and 310, note that 300 is great.
If you are looking for a good introduction to microeconomics, this is a great course. However, if you want something very quantitatively rigorous, I would recommend ECO 310.
Incredibly boring
It's very boring and Sylvain can be difficult to understand sometimes. Do not take this unless you have to.
Look at practice problems for final
Make sure you get help on problem sets if you need it.
See if someone besides Chassang is teaching it
Solid intermediate micro class. Not awesome, not too hard, but overall good.
Take it if you have to. Otherwise avoid it.
Take this course - very easy to follow and Chassang/Preceptors are great. Also, if deciding between ECO300 and WWS300, at least this semester seems ECO300 was a better experience for students.
Take very good notes and complete problem sets early
Use office hours.
Utilize office hours, redo practice exams and psets in prep for exams. Don't be afraid to ask questions.
Wouldn't suggest it unless it's a requirement. Chassang cares a lot but doesn't often explain things well. Problem sets are surprisingly confusing.
prereqs: Prerequisites: ECO 100 and MAT 103..
descrip: This is an intermediate microeconomics course. The general themes are: (1) choices made by individual consumers and firms, (2) equilibrium of the interaction of these choices in markets and (3) the role of government policy in improving economic outcomes. Some new concepts and techniques are developed, especially for studying behavior under uncertainty, and strategic interactions (game theory). The theory of each topic is accompanied by evidence, illustrations, and applications.

title: Intermediate Russian I
reviews: Do more tasks on SAM than the instructors assign.
Don't be afraid to make mistakes and actively engage in conversations in Russian with other students and Mark and your preceptor.
Keep up with the grammar!
Mark provides great tables/charts that organize difficult grammatical aspects. These should be maintained and referred to often.
Review your vocabulary every night.
This course can be fun, but challenging. May be a shock for people coming from first-year Russian at Princeton.
This course is fun and engaging. Take it if you want to improve your Russian skills and learn more about the culture.
prereqs: RUS 102 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Major emphasis on the development of vocabulary and oral expression with continuing work on difficult grammar topics.

title: Synthetic Organic Chemistry
reviews: Be prepared to memorize a lot of named organic reactions.
Don't take it as an undergrad. Just. Don't. The no-collaboration policy is awful. If you want to PDF it for the material, then go for it, but don't take it for a grade.

I took this class in the fall of my senior year. It taught me that I want to be a chemist at a liberal arts university, not a liberal arts student studying chemistry, or a pre-med.

It would have been nice to know that I am capable of handling (and enjoy) the rigor of graduate level chemistry coursework sooner. As such, I encourage you (if you think graduate school might be on your radar) to take a graduate class as early as possible.

Graduate classes take some getting used to. They are a lot of work, but now that I know how to handle them, I am not afraid to take multiple graduate courses.

Professor Knowles and Professor Doyle are both brilliant, approachable and helpful. Go to their office hours!
If you're looking to really learn organic chemistry this is a good class. Keep in mind it is quite hard.
Try to apply concepts taught in the beginning of the course during the whole semester to understand reactivity.
You will never regret to take this course!
descrip: A mechanism-based course on organic synthesis for advanced undergraduates and beginning graduate students who wish to learn chemical synthesis of organic compounds. Course deals with various classical and modern synthetic methodologies. Particular emphasis is placed on understanding scope, limitations, and selectivity based on the mechanism, with the goal to understand fundamental principles underlying each synthetic method. The knowledge and perspective acquired in this course is expected to provide sufficient foundation to understand and use the research literature in organic synthesis.

title: Numbers, Equations, and Proofs
reviews: Definitely take the course if you are unsure of proofs.
I would suggest always attending office hours even if you think you don't have a question

Number Theory is a very fascinating subject, but be aware that it is almost all theory and very rarely uses numbers. Be prepared to teach yourself many topics throughout the course. Also the only source materials we used were the instructor's lecture notes- no textbook. Foster a good relationship with the instructor, because he is a great help, and often the only one who is really able to answer your questions. I would caution students to only take this course if they are truly interested in the subject material and think they can handle the workload.
Take it if you are interested in theoretical math
Take it if you like number theory
Take it if you want a great intro into proofs.

Take this course if you have experience with proofs and number theory. The word, "introductory" is very misleading. It may be "introductory" at Princeton, but perhaps a disclaimer should be added in the course description.
This is a good introduction to proofs - the material is interesting and was understandable to me even though I do not plan on becoming a math major.

This is probably the most straightforwards and easiest proof-based Math class you'll ever get the chance to take at Princeton. Highly depends on the lecturer, but with Jerry Wang it was pretty good. The psets were easy my year though, so expect harder your year (that's good--you learn more).
descrip: An introduction to classical number theory, to prepare for higher-level courses in the department. Topics include Pythagorean triples and sums of squares, unique factorization, Chinese remainder theorem, arithmetic of Gaussian integers, finite fields and cryptography, arithmetic functions and quadratic reciprocity. There will be a topic, chosen by the instructor, from more advanced or more applied number theory: possibilities include p-adic numbers, cryptography, and Fermat's Last Theorem. This course is suitable both for students preparing to enter the Mathematics Department and for non-majors interested in exposure to higher mathematics.

title: Junior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor. Refer to course web page for additional details.

title: Ecohydrology of Savannas: Coupling Spatio/Temporal Modeling of Rainfall, Soil Moisture, and Vegetat
descrip: The dynamics of soil moisture in savanna ecosystems is studied as a result of being driven by stochastic space-time rainfall forcing acting on a heterogeneous vegetation made up by grasses and trees. The spatially explicit probability structure of soil moisture is linked to climate,soil, and vegetation.

title: Comparative Literature Graduate Pedagogy Seminar
descrip: Teaching practicum required of departmental PhD students and open only to those concurrently teaching in their first course at Princeton. A wide range of topics is discussed, based primarily upon the needs and experience of participants. These typically include: facilitating discussions, delivering lectures, grading papers, designing course syllabi, teaching with translations, using technology in the classroom, developing a statement of teaching philosophy, and preparing a teaching portfolio. Course leads to partial fulfillment of the McGraw Teaching Transcript.

title: Introduction to Formal Analysis
reviews: Keep up with the assignments and be sure to attend the seminars. When in doubt make it strange.
Sucks to be an MArch II, as you can't take this. Super fun class.
Treat every drawing carefully and critically.
descrip: Introduction to the primary projective systems that form the foundations of architectural representation and serve as essential tools of formal analysis and design. Coursework will be derived from a structured examination of key primary sources by Gaspard Monge, Brook Taylor and Girard Desargues.

title: Prejudice: Its Causes, Consequences, and Cures
reviews: As long as you go into the class with an open mind, you'll enjoy it!

DO NOT UNDERESTIMATE THE MIDTERM. It is quite specific and tricky. If you are willing to put up with some monotony, then it is an okay course. If you're looking for a goof PDF course, this is definitely it.
Definitely take it if ever offered again.
Don't bother reading the textbook, it will actually just confuse you on the exams
Don't miss lecture - best part of the course.
Even if you aren't interested in psychology as a discipline, everyone who wants to prevent prejudice should take this class!
Everybody take this course!!! Great professor, interesting readings, overall a great course.
Good class. Kind of depressing but you learn a lot!
Highly recommend
I have nothing but good things to say about this course. If you do not take it you are seriously doing yourself a disservice. It will undoubtedly change how you see the world.
Make sure to do the readings and participate and ask a lot of questions.
Read read read and early!
Sooooo good. You'll learn things about yourself, and Sinclair is so entertaining during lecture you won't get bored. The exams and assignments are fair. Learn the experiments.
Super interesting! Professor Sinclair is awesome!
TAKE THIS CLASS.
Take it
Take it! The atmosphere of the class is enjoyable, the material can sometimes be overwhelming so join a study group!
Very doable, straightforward, and interesting course.
You really learn a lot about the topic, and it's very applicable to everyday life.
do all the readings.
exams are a bit tricky, odd wording sometimes.
prereqs: None (PSY 252 would be helpful)..
descrip: Prejudice is one of the most contentious topics in modern American society. There is debate regarding its causes, pervasiveness, and impact. This goal of this course is to familiarize students with the psychological research relevant to these questions. We will review theoretical perspectives on prejudice to develop an understanding of its cognitive, affective, and motivational underpinnings. We will also discuss how these psychological biases relate to evaluations of, and behavior toward, members of targeted groups. In addition, research-based strategies for reducing prejudice will be discussed.

title: Fluid Dynamics
reviews: Chances are this is required for you. If you can stay awake through 830 lectures you'll learn a lot from Nosenchuck, and if it's possible to take this course with Jesse Ault from Howard Stone's lab as a TA, do it!
Don't take this unless you have to
Find someone to work with on assignments.
Go to precepts, and start the problem sets early.
Great course if you liked MAE 222.

I LOVED this course - it provides the fundamental building blocks you need to understand the coolest aerospace systems: namely rockets and supersonic aircraft. It doesn't hurt that the subject itself is counterintuitive and beautiful. Nosenchuck's lectures are worth the early time.
I know the lectures are at 8:30 in the morning, but find the strength to go to as many of them as you can.
I would say try your best to wake up. Its tough to manage work without spilling into the 2-3 am time slot. But it will help out a lot.
If you are interested in aerodynamics, definitely take this course. It is informative and interesting.

If you're even considering this course, you probably have to take it. Make sure that you get all of the lecture notes, because nothing will be posted on Blackboard. Overall, it's not a bad course, it's just not an especially good course, either.
It was pretty good.
It's gonna suck getting up in the morning to go to lectures, but if you've got to do it, better to do it for Dan Nosenchuck than for someone else.
It's one of the better MAE courses.
Lectures largely cover the materials in the textbook so it is easy to catch up. Work is manageable. Professor and TAs are great and very helpful.
Loved this course. Lectures are worth it. Try to follow along with the readings.
Not a bad class, problems sets aren't bad and the exams are reasonable. Interesting concepts with supersonic planes and shock waves.
Pace yourself on the exams, as they can be quite long.
Prepare for early classes and tough midterms/finals. If they are still open book and open notes, be sure you know the contents of your notebook and the book by heart.
Start the assignments early and do the readings; it will really help with understanding more of the lectures and with the assignments.
Take it if you are interested in fluids. Be prepared for a lot of work.
Teaches you lots about Fluid Dynamics, pretty exciting.
The book is pretty decent.  The lectures - not really sure, I didn't go that much.  Psets aren't that hard.  Slightly better than your average departmental.
You get to learn pretty cool things in this course, such as supersonic wind tunnels and other neat things that happen at supersonic speed.
be ready to get up early
definitely a great course for those interested in aerospace
interested? take it. No busy work, interesting material, problem sets are well balanced and don't make you suffer for no reason.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222 or Permission Of Instructor. MAT 202 is strongly recommended as background for enrollment..
descrip: The course is focused on compressible and incompressible inviscid fluid flow. Compressible subsonic and supersonic flows are studied in the first half of the course. The remaining portion of the semester addresses low-speed, incompressible fluid flows and aerodynamics of two and three-dimensional wings and bodies. Concepts of thrust, lift and drag are introduced and applied.

title: High-Energy Physics
descrip: An overview of modern elementary particle physics and the Standard Model. Specific topics include: weak decays, W and Z physics, deep inelastic scattering, CP violation, neutrino oscillations, Higgs searches, with an emphasis on areas of current interest. Course also covers concepts in experimental tools and techniques.

title: Topics in Algebraic Geometry - Arithmetic Algebraic Geometry
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Algebraic Geometry. Specific topic details provided when course is offered.

title: Fusion Plasmas & Plasma Diagnostics
reviews: Read Hutchinson and Wesson starting from early in the course.
This class is worth taking.
descrip: Introduction to experimental plasma physics, with emphasis on high-temperature plasmas for fusion. Requirements for fusion plasmas: confinement, beta, power and particle exhaust. Discussion of tokamak fusion and alternative magnetic and inertial confinement systems. Status of experimental understanding: what we know and how we know it. Key plasma diagnostic techniques: magnetic measurements, Langmuir probes, microwave techniques, spectroscopic techniques, electron cyclotron emission, Thomson scattering.

title: Readings in Modern Japanese I
reviews: I recommend the course for anybody with a strong language background; to get the most out of it, self-motivation is probably vital.
Improves reading and perhaps writing, not so much speaking or listening.
highly recommended for keeping up your Japanese and improving it through discussion, reading, writing, and watching a tv show.
prereqs: JPN 306 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: This course is targeted to students whose Japanese proficiency is at an advanced or superior level. In this class students will (1) discuss various issues in international relations focusing on Asian nations, using dramas, short novels and editorials, and (2) learn Japanese business manners and speak and write business Japanese. Through these activities, students will develop critical thinking skills as well as Japanese language skills.

title: Modern Poetry
reviews: Definitely take it! Professor Martin facilitates a really warm classroom vibe and it's a great environment to learn about poetry, especially if you don't know a lot about poetry already. She's really cool and one of the best facilitators of discussion I've ever had at Princeton, and you'll grow a lot as a reader and a member of class discussion as the class goes on.
I would advise students to stay engaged in the class discussions, because students get a lot more out of the course's outstanding material by adding to the stimulating dialogues in seminar.
I would recommend this to all students, but I will say that some knowledge of poetry will be helpful.
So fantastic - if you're interested in or enjoy reading poetry at any level you should take it, it's a wonderful overview of modern poets and it's really fun
Take it even if you don't see yourself as an English student.
Take it if you like really going into a lot of detail in a lot of different poems.
Take it if you want to read poetry! Whether you already love it or want to learn something new, you'll get a ton from this class if you put the work in (and it's not a lot).
Take it!

Take this course if you are drawn to the material! You will learn a lot about the historical context of the modern period, which is extremely interesting. I would not take this course just for a distribution requirement as it is pretty focused and requires an advanced level of close reading.
go ahead
descrip: This course explores the continuities and divisions in British and American poetry through and alongside the ride of modernism. Our main activity will be close reading (often difficult) poems, but we will also look at manifestoes, media, and how modernism marketed itself at the beginning of the twentieth century as a break from nineteenth-century traditions. The question and problem of history and tradition itself will be central to our course. We'll ask why British and American poets at the beginning of the twentieth century felt such a strong urge to define themselves in opposition to their predecessors, and to one another.

title: Atmospheric Radiative Transfer
reviews: Take this course! Consult the textbooks (Goody & Yung and Seinfield & Pandis) and the instructors.
descrip: Structure and composition of terrestrial atmospheres. Fundamental aspects of electromagnetic radiation. Absorption and emission by atmospheric gases. Optical extinction of particles. Roles of atmospheric species in Earth's radiative energy balance. Perturbation of climate due to natural and antropogenic causes. Satellite observations of climate system.

title: Parallel Computation
reviews: If you are going to take this course, keep in mind that this course is more about parallel computer architecture, not about parallel programming itself.
Very good and fun course. Should consider taking it if you have time.
prereqs: Prerequisites are ELE 375 or equivalent with good programmer experience. ELE 475 or equivalent is highly recommended. A certain level of programmer maturity is needed, and first and second year grad students are encouraged to take this class..
descrip: The class reads seminal papers on different parallel programming models and computer architectures. In addition, we explore different parallel programming models via programming assignments. Finally the course culminates in a project where students create a research-grade experiment and write a full length conference-style paper. One of the goals of this class is to get students introduced to writing a complete conference style computer architecture/CS paper.

title: Mathematical Modeling in Biology and Medicine
reviews: Absolutely a great class, Prof Tarnita is amazing!
Be comfortable with the math. The course is much more interesting and beneficial to the student if they understand basic math concepts as derivatives, exponential functions, and geometric series.

Difficult course so don't take it if you already have a hard schedule. If you want to learn how to model biological, medical, or any other problems, then this is a great class to take. You'll learn a lot of broad and useful techniques to use as well as some computer programming models to implement.
If you are an EEB major who has little math or computer experience/skill, be careful taking this course.  It's great, but it will require a lot of work.

If you are considering a career in research within MOL and EEB, I would highly recommend this course. As an EEB major, this course reinforced what I was learning in other classes while providing a whole new way of conceiving of ecological phenomena that I learned about in 309 and 321. EEB background is very helpful, but not entirely necessary. If you can think in terms of populations and population dynamics you should be fine. Rudimentary knowledge of linear algebra and calculus is a definite plus, though Prof Tarnita is willing to work with you if you are in a rut.

If you have any interest in mathematical biology, or using mathematics to get at other questions in biology, go for it! It is a reasonable workload and accessible to anyone with a modest calculus background (AP Calc AB would do).

Start thinking about your final project early - it is very manageable but it is a good idea to have something in mind that you would like to work on.
It helps to know matlab / some coding because you'll need it for simulations. Lectures are helpful especially since there isn't a textbook.
It's interesting and not a lot of work but the final report is more work than everything else.

Prof Tarnita is one of the most accomplished and down-to-earth lecturers you will likely ever have - she's reason alone to take the class. It teaches you a new way of thinking, isn't unduly onerous and if you're reasonably comfortable with algebra you'll have a good time!
Professor Tarnita is extremely nice and helpful.  She makes difficult subject matter interesting and manageable.

Professor Tarnita is one of the best professors I've had so far at Princeton. She is extremely encouraging and helpful. She doesn't just want you to learn something, she wants you to understand it and be able to replicate it. This is very important in a class about building mathematical models. She is very friendly and extremely approachable even though she is super smart. The lectures were pretty interesting, though the problem sets were time-consuming. Andrew's precept and office hours are definitely necessary - and he is also really amazing. Professor Tarnita is also very open to suggestions on how to improve the class.
That being said, this was one of the most difficult courses for me because I had only taken MAT 103. The course recommends a year of calculus. There is also some linear algebra involved. If you don't have a solid mathematical background, know what you're getting into and be prepared to work. Office hours really helps. But really, if you're interested in the topic (esp. species interactions and population dynamics), take it. It's a unique class.
Really interesting and engaging class for anyone interested in learning more about thinking about biological applications.
Take it if you enjoy either having a mathematical understanding of biology, or having a biological application of various mathematical concepts.
Take it if you have any interest in the subject. It's taught in a very accessible way, including all the math you need, and provides a really interesting perspective on biological problems.
Take it take it take it! Corina Tarnita is the best person, and you will learn so much from this class.
Take the course! You will obtain a strong foundation in mathematical modelling.
prereqs: One year of calculus required. However, at the beginning of each new topic, a short tutorial will be given to explain any new concepts and insure that all students have the necessary tools. Ability to use computing software (e.g. Mathematica) encouraged..
descrip: How can mathematical modeling help to illuminate biological processes? This course examines major topics in biology through the lens of mathematics, focusing on the role of models in scientific discovery. Students will learn how to build and analyze models using a variety of mathematical tools. Particular emphasis will be placed on evolutionary game theory. Specific topics will include: the evolution of cooperation and of social behavior from bacteria to humans; the evolution of multicellularity; the somatic evolution of cancer; virus dynamics (within host and within populations); and multispecies interactions and the evolution of mutualisms.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS)
prereqs: Completion of EGR 450.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: The Political Economy of Health Systems
descrip: This course explores the professed and unspoken goals nations pursue with their health systems and the alternative economic and administrative structures different nations use to pursue those goals. The emphasis in the course will be on the industrialized world, although some time can be allocated later in the course to approaches used in the developing countries, if students in the course desire it.

title: Principles of Macromolecular Structure: Protein Folding, Structure and Design
reviews:
-Read the papers thoroughly and have a good idea of the main goals and findings
-For each figure, know the question being asked, techniques used to evaluate it, data obtained, and conclusions drawn from it.
Do the readings. Ask questions about the readings. Review the readings.

Great course.  Professor Hecht runs the course in a group discussion manner.  Keep up with and think about the readings.  You feel as if you could do research in the field just based on this course alone.
I highly recommend taking this course if you're interested at all in proteins of any sort.
If you are interested in proteins, this is the course for you.
If you're interested in proteins and protein folding, take it! You'll learn a lot with a very low amount of stress.
LOVE this class! It's not stressful but you do learn a lot through reading papers and discussing them in detail in class.
Please do take this course! No prior knowledge of the proteins necessary.
Read the papers carefully.
Take it. Michael is awesome, Proteins are awesome, grad classes are great.
Take this course! It's a bit hard and intimidating at first (and throughout the course, especially with so many good chem majors), but definitely worth it!
This is a very straightforward and informative course on protein chemistry. Definitely take it if you're interested in proteins at all.
great class
descrip: This course is taught from the scientific literature. We begin the semester with several classic papers on protein folding. As the semester progresses, we read about protein structure, stability, and folding pathways. The latter part of the semester focuses on recent papers describing new research aimed toward the construction of novel proteins from "scratch." These papers cover topics ranging from evolution in vitro to computational and rational design. The course ends by discussing the possibility of creating artificial proteomes in the laboratory, and further steps toward synthetic biology.

title: The World of the Middle Ages
reviews: If you have any interest in the medieval time period, take this course! The readings can be time-consuming, but the classes are relaxed and interesting. Professor Poor is great and loves her subject area!
If you're interested in Medieval Studies, this course is essential.

If you're interested in the Medieval Studies certificate, it's worthwhile to get this prerequisite out of the way early. It isn't the most challenging course, but Professor Poor is a great lecturer and provides a solid foundation for any other Medieval Studies courses you might take.
Take it. It's a nice, laid-back survey course that talks about interesting subjects.
Take this course. It was very chill and laid back and I also left the course with a considerable amount of new knowledge.

This course is an excellent survey of the middle ages, covering a wide range of different topics from history and literature to art and music. Prof. Poor makes the class interesting and engaging - studying medieval history definitely doesn't have to be boring! If you're at all curious about the middle ages I would highly recommend this class as an introduction. I also took this class after having taken more specialized classes on the middle ages and still learned new things and enjoyed the class as a good broad background that I hadn't gotten before.
descrip: An introduction to medieval culture in Western Europe from the end of the classical world to ca. 1400. The course focuses on themes such as the medieval concepts of self, humanity, and God; nation-building, conquest and crusade; relations among Christians, Jews, and Moslems; literacy, heresy, and the rise of vernacular literature; gender, chivalry, and the medieval court. Material approached through various cultural forms and media; some lectures by invited guest lecturers. Seminar discussion format with some lecturing.

title: Public Finance I
descrip: This course provides a microeconomic examination of the role of government in the economy. Topics will include the theory and measurement of excess burden, optimal tax theory, the analysis of tax incidence, and an examination of the effects of taxation on behavior.

title: Jewish Thought and Modernity
descrip: This course examines Jewish contributions and reactions to the configuration of social, cultural, intellectual, economic, and political factors known as modernity. It explores how these factors challenged traditional Jewish life and how Judaism was variously reinterpreted to adapt and respond to them. It consists of a historical and thematic survey of modern Jewish thought, spanning from the rise of Enlightenment rationalism to the more recent existentialist and postmodern turns. In the process, it probes the nature and continuing relevance of the concept of modernity as well as interrogates the category of "Jewish" thought.

title: Topics in Automorphic Forms - Moduli Spaces of Vector Bundles
prereqs: Undergraduates must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: The goal of this course is to explain the proof V. Lafforgue's recent results on the global Langlands correspondence for reductive groups over functions fields. I also review some background material such as the affine Grassmannian, the geometric Satake correspondence and moduli spaces of G-bundles, G-bundles with modifications and G-shtukas. I assume that the audience is familiar with the material in Hartshorne's "Algebraic geometry" and Milne's "Etale cohomology".

title: Ordinary Differential Equations
prereqs: MAT 217 and 218, or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to the study of ordinary differential equations; explicit solutions, general properties of solutions, and applications. Topics include explicit solutions of some non-linear equations in two variables by separation of variables and integrating factors, explicit solution of simultaneous linear equations with constant coefficients, explicit solution of some linear equations with variable forcing term by Laplace transform methods, geometric methods (description of the phase portrait), and the fundamental existence and uniqueness theorem.

title: Topics in 19th- and Early 20th-Century Music - Modernism in Music and Dance
descrip: A study of the music composed for (or set to) dance and pantomime by Claude Debussy, Charles Ives, Sergey Prokofiev, Erik Satie, Igor Stravinsky, and Francis Poulenc. Course includes stylistic and syntactical analysis of the music on its own terms as well as discussion of the challenges that it poses to choreographers.

title: Advanced Drawing: The Figure
reviews: Honestly, the advanced course is not all that different than the intro drawing course, I think the bar is just set higher. Take this class if you are interested in having more time to make art, to put it simply. It's still rooted in traditional drawing techniques, but we were encouraged much more to color outside of the lines (literally, figuratively)--certainly still by now means experimental, but you are allowed a certain degree of freedom while simultaneously being guided through formal techniques.

Take it if you feel confident in your ability to draw from life accurately, and think you're flexible taking advice from the professor. I found that the only person who struggled to enjoy the class had a problem letting go of the style he already had, and was not flexible with some drastic changes the professor offered.
Take it if you're really serious about learning to draw the figure in the academic tradition. Don't take it if you don't have prior drawing experience or think it'll be an easy A or fun.
Take it.  Kurt is a great professor.  Do understand that the class is going to be primarily long poses.

Take this course if you are seriously interested in improving your figure drawing skills and observation skills. A lot of it will be self-guided and there will not be too much student-student interaction, but you will improve.
the class is pretty self-selective, so just ask yourself if drawing people for five hours on Mondays sounds like something you'd like doing.
prereqs: Introductory Drawing, or Introductory Painting, or Introductory Sculpture, or Introductory Photo, or Introductory Video..
descrip: Through careful observation, this class will focus exclusively on human figure and purse the development of a strong sense of bone structure, muscle contours and light. From this perceptual foundation, students will be encouraged to develop independent points of view. Assignments will loosely revolve around themes of narrative, abstraction, expression, and conceptual strategies. Primary source material will be live models in class, but photography, video and collage may also be utilized. Study of figurative issues in contemporary art will complement the course projects.

title: Humanistic Perspectives on Literature - Unpacking Derrida's Library: Secrets of the Archives
prereqs: Class conducted in English. Readings in English translation or French original..
descrip: Marking the 10th anniversary of Derrida's death, this course provides an opportunity to "unpack" Derrida's library, to remember several of his lessons - about philosophy, literature, history, politics, religion, economics, ideology, law, rights, nationalism, racism, colonialism, the media, university institutions, capitalism, rogue states, the war on terror, justice, responsibility, language, friendship, love, life, death, and mourning - all of which are more urgent and necessary than ever before.

title: Empirical Processes and Asymptotic Statistics
prereqs: Advance Probability (ORF 551) and statistical inference (ORF 524) or approved by the instructor.
descrip: Empirical Process theory mainly extends the law of large numbers (LLN), central limit theorem (CLT) and exponential inequalities to uniform LLN's and CLT's and concentration inequalities. This uniformaty is useful to statisticians and computer scientists in that they often model data as a sample from some unknown distribution and desire to estimate certain aspects of the population. Uniform LLN or CLT and concentration inequalities will imply that certain sample averages will be uniformly close to their expectations regardless of the unknown distributions. This class intends to review modern empirical process theory and its related asymptot

title: Elementary Turkish I
reviews: Take it! I was hesitant at first since I was starting the sequence as a sophomore and since the 4 course sequence initially seemed like a lot. But Professor Hatemi is a superb professor--the class setting is likely to be intimate and made up of some really curious students. And you'll very soon have a foot through the door and feel comfortable in the language, all due to Prof. Hatemi's fine instruction. Strongly Recommended.
prereqs: No credit is given for TUR 101 unless it is followed by TUR 102..
descrip: A performance-oriented, multi-media introductory course in modern spoken and written Turkish. Based on authentic input, grammatical properties of the language are introduced. Cultural aspects are stressed throughout. Language skills are developed through communicative activities in class and individualized work with interactive digitized learning aids.

title: Industrial Organization and Public Policy
reviews: I would recommend
Read the papers, and try to follow the mechanics in them - otherwise, this class will not be useful to you.
Start working on the problem sets as early as possible.
descrip: Methods for empirical and theoretical analysis of markets composed of productive enterprises and their customers are studied. Analyses are applied to modern market structures and practices, and public policy towards them. Topics include the roles of technology and information, the structure of firms, modes of interfirm competition, determination of price, quality, and R & D investment, and criteria for government intervention.

title: Projects in Instrumental Performance - Chamber Music
prereqs: Enrollment by application and audition. Auditions will be held on Tuesday, November 22, 2005, 6:00 - 9:00 p.m. Room 106 Woolworth Center (Sign up sheet is on the Bulletin Board near Room 101 Woolworth.) Contract Gregory D. Smith (609) 258-6078 or gsmith@princeton.edu for further details..
descrip: Instrumental chamber music class of the standard repertory of the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries. Preparation for performance of ensembles. Each ensemble's repertoire will be determined in consultation with the instructors during the first week of classes.

title: Optics and Lasers
descrip: An introduction to principles of lasers. Topics include propagation theory, interaction of light and matter, Fourier optics, and a description of operational characteristics of lasers, light scattering, and nonlinear optics.

title: Italy on Film: Political and Cultural Landscape
reviews: Participate in class!
Take this course! It's not very difficult and you'll learn a lot!
This is a great course to take if you are at all interested in the culture or history of Italy presented in a way other than the traditional lecture-type course. Highly recommend!
definitely speak as much as you can. even though gaetana is a great professor, ultimately it's up to you
prereqs: ITA 107 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: This course will explore the direction Italian culture has taken from WWI to the present, bringing into focus notions of identity and nationhood. Its purpose is to consider both historical developments and the impact of change in the formation of the Italian democratic state. We shall examine the ways film artists have identified visual images with specific socio-political factors such as the fascist ideology, the Intellectual Left, the economic boom and emigration, 1968 and the student's revolution, terrorism, diversity and gender in the new millennium. Extensive practice of writing in a variety of genres.

title: Synthetic Skin
reviews: Beware of dolls, texts, and discussions that may exceed the stated class time... but if the topic interests you, it will be well worth it!

Do not hesitate to ask Professor Guerrero for any extra time you might need outside the classroom in case you cannot follow the rhythm of the course. Philosophical readings can be very difficult sometimes, but Professor Guerrero is well aware of this and will be always able to work with you on advancing your understanding of the material.
I would certainly recommend this course and professor to other students.
descrip: Dolls are human creations whose "disgrace" is their birth itself. They are not born according to the principles of sexual reproduction and biological identity: motherless, they form outside of the uterus. Dolls are different from other artificial matters in their close relationship to childhood. But the even more definitive distinction is that they have been assigned to a sex: they are female bodies. This seminar proposes to explore the specificity of these synthetic lives, considering dolls in their relationships with toys, monsters, mannequins, automatons, puppets, virgins, and mommies, through the work of diverse contemporary artists.

title: Econometric Theory I
reviews: Do the "optional" problems on the problem sets.
Good course
Nothing in particular.
Read hyashi 80000 times.
descrip: A first-year course in the first-year econometrics sequence: it is divided into two parts. The first gives students the necessary background in probability theory and statistics. Topics include definitions and axioms of probability, moments, some univariate distributions, the multivariate normal distribution, sampling distributions, introduction to asymptotic theory, estimation and testing. The second part introduces the linear regression model and develops associated tools. Properties of the ordinary least squares estimator will be studied in detail and a number of tests developed.

title: Materials World
descrip: Please see website

title: Policy Workshop - Policy, Operational & Political Implementation Challenges of the ACA
descrip: The workshop focuses on the policy, operational and political challenges that continue to impact implementation of the coverage expansions, delivery system reforms and other innovations resulting from the ACA and its substantial impact on our health care system. The workshop client is a state (or states) taking a unique approach to particular elements of ACA implementation. The project is determined based on client need and student interest, with the overarching goal of creating a report that can deliver timely recommendations on a pressing implementation issue.

title: Studies in Islamic Religion and Thought
descrip: This course focuses on reading texts that are illustrative of various issues in Muslim religious thought. The texts are selected according to students' needs.

title: Senior Independent Work (B.S.E. candidates only)
prereqs: Open to qualified juniors as well as seniors, provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in computer science. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the student. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor.

title: Journeys in Portuguese: Studies in Language and Culture
reviews: 208 was my favorite class this semester. Nicola is amazing amazing and the material is fascinating. Just make sure to do your part and keep up on the readings and movies to get the most out of the class.

Give yourself enough time to do the readings/watch the movies! Because of the small class size, everyone participates in the discussion. When too many people don't do the readings for that class, the discussion can stagnate. If you are interested in/enjoy Portuguese culture and believe you are at a good enough Portuguese level, then this is a great class to take.
TAKE IT IF YOU LIKE PORTUGUESE
Take it! Not too much work, but just enough that you will really improve. Nicola is great!
Take it. Nicola is great!
Take the course! Be prepared for class every day.

Take this class! It will improve your Portuguese and your knowledge of the Portuguese-speaking world. I recommend doing the grammar assignments even though they aren't checked in class, because they'll help you learn to speak and write properly.

Take this course if you want to build on your Portuguese, particularly as a reader and writer. It's engaging and while you read and watch a lot of stories/movies, the work is a lot more engaging than language classes can be. I thought the expectations were pretty reasonable overall and Nicola was a very engaging teacher to have. She was good about gently correcting spoken Portuguese and having interesting discussions in class, and helped make the Lusophone world outside of Brazil and Portugal seem interesting and worth exploring. Take it!
The advice I would give them would be to be really proactive with regards to your writing and to meet with Luis once you get your essays back.
This course is a lot of work but it is worth it!
This is a great introduction to what further study in portuguese beyond basic speaking ability can be like and I found my Portuguese got a whole lot better in speaking, reading, and writing.
This was a very enjoyable class, and I would highly recommend it. Your command of the Portuguese language and knowledge of the Portuguese-speaking world will both improve dramatically.
prereqs: POR 109 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Designed as a journey through the Lusophone world this course seeks to present the Portuguese language in context by exploring historical, social, political and cultural aspects of Brasil, Portugal, and Lusophone Africa through the media, literature, film, music and other realia. Students will increase their fluency and accuracy in both written and spoken Portuguese, broadening their vocabulary and mastery of syntax through textual analysis, discussions, oral presentations and grammar review. An advanced language course and overview of the Lusophone world, POR 208 seeks to prepare students for further study of literature and culture.

title: German Intellectual History - Madness
reviews: Do the readings and talk as much as possible during discussions, and it will be fun and a refreshing brain exercise to think about them actively in class.

Don't hesitate to take this course!  The readings are incredibly thought-provoking, and taken from a wide range of styles and mediums.  Professor Pourciau is great, and she strikes a great balance between lecturing about material and allowing organic discussion to flourish.  Overall, this was my favorite course I have taken at Princeton thus far in any department.
Prof. Pourciau is excellent. Be prepared to do difficult readings.
Take this course if you speak German and want to practice really engaging in deep ideas in another language!
This was a really interesting course, and I would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for an upper level German class!
descrip: The notion of the poet as a kind of mad prophet, speaking ecstatically in the tongues of demons or gods, has ancient roots. To be "inspired," after all, means literally to become the receptacle for an external breath or spirit (spirare = "to breathe," spiritus = "a breath"), while the German "verruckt" suggests a displacement of the prosaic, everyday self. In this course, we will investigate what happens to the interplay of poetic creativity and madness when it enters the context of the modern German tradition. We will take our objects from literature, film, philosophy, psychoanalysis, music, and the visual arts.

title: Kongo Art
reviews: Do the readings for each class
I would absolutely recommend it.
Very niche class, but if it falls in your area of interest and you're willing to do the work it's a good one.
descrip: Easily recognized as among the most important examples of canonical African art, Kongo sculpture, textiles, and ritual design are famous for their conceptual density, stylistic variety and rigorous abstraction. The course examines the role of art in the life of the Kongo Kingdom and related peoples, from the arrival of Spanish explorers and missionaries in the 15th century, through the era of Belgian colonization from the late 19th to mid-20th centuries, to the period since political independence in 1960. The seminar coincides with and will explore the Kongo Across the Waters exhibition at the Princeton University Museum.

title: Responsible Conduct in Research: A Course on Ethics in Engineering (Half-term)
prereqs: This course is required for graduate students in engineering who participate in federally funded research; the course is highly recommended and/or required for undergraduate students as well as post-doctoral researchers in engineering who participate in federally funded research. There are no prerequisites for attending the course..
descrip: This course educates the graduate student of engineering in the responsible conduct of research. The lectures provide theoretical background information as well as case studies about ethics in day-to-day research situations, in publishing and peer-review, in student-advisor relationships, in collaborative research, as well as in the big picture and considerations of long-term impact. The students are provided with resources to consult in ethical questions. In small-group discussions in research field-specific precepts, the theoretical concepts are made relevant to the individual students situations.

title: Found Sound
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Water, Savannas, and Society: Global Change and Sustainability in Africa's Hallmark Ecosystem
prereqs: Assignments will entail some analytical work involving geographic information systems and statistics..
descrip: Savannas have played an important role in shaping human societies, including our evolution as a species. That role will grow, as savannas must be increasingly harnessed to meet growing demands for food, fuel, and fiber. Starting with a primer on savanna ecology, this course will examine the ecological and societal issues surrounding our use of African savannas. A key focus will be to explore tradeoffs between agricultural development, ecosystem services (e.g. carbon storage), biodiversity, and existing livelihoods, how those tradeoffs can be optimized to achieve sustainability, and how climate change will complicate such efforts.

title: Energy Solutions for the Next Century
reviews: DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE. Seriously, please just listen to the reviews. It is extremely boring and unengaging.
Dont take this class

I would recommend this class to anyone interested in alternative energy.

I personally learned a lot.
If you want a class that you don't have to attend lecture ever, this is for you. If you like to attend lecture, get ready to feel bad for yourself as a Princeton student.

Never take this class or any class with Jay Benziger. He will make even your favorite passion wither and die underneath his slow droning boring dry voice. Avoid him at all costs, and most definitely at other people's costs as well.
Only take it if you absolutely have to.
Only take this class if you are really interested in the material, otherwise you will find the lectures to be boring.

Solid overview of the most important energy technologies today including natural gas, coal, oil, nuclear, solar, and wind. This is not a work-intensive course even for non-science people. It's interesting for anyone who wants to go into the energy sector. Lectures can be a bit technical, but the assignments are not.

The material of this class is interesting and useful, but I would ONLY recommend taking this class PDF. It is incredibly disorganized- the professors didn't have a clear grading rubric, problem sets were mostly about spending large amounts of time searching for random statistics on google, and grading was very inconsistent. They also included chemistry and physics topics that are not familiar to non-science majors, despite there being no prerequisites for the class. This was the worst-organized class I have taken at Princeton.
prereqs: This course is offered for both engineering and non-engineering students. (Calculus or Thermodynamics are NOT requirements)..
descrip: This course will deal with issues of regional and global energy demands, sources, carriers, storage, current and future technologies and costs for energy conversion, and their impact on climate and the environment. Students will learn to perform objective cost-efficiency and environmental impact analyses from source to end-user on both fossil fuels (oil, coal, and natural gas), and alternative energy sources (bio-fuels, solar energy, wind, batteries, and nuclear). We will also pay particular attention to energy sources, technologies, emissions, and regulations for transportation. The course will also include tours to energy research labs.

title: Chaucer
reviews: Do not underestimate the amount of time the writing assignments will take. Because they are so enjoyable, they tend to take a long time.
Take it!! Professor Smith is amazing, really knows his stuff and is always very kind and encouraging. I personally found the workload to be very reasonable.
Unambiguously recommend; cannot possibly recommend in stronger terms.
descrip: We will be reading The Canterbury Tales, one of literature's undisputed masterworks. It's anything but stuffy, however: Chaucer makes poetry out of noisy sex, classical fables, Arthurian legends, the horror of the Black Death, and philosophy. You will learn how to read Middle English (in a day or two), in order to appreciate his poetics of the mashup--and how his poetry shapes modern novels, poetry, and art.

title: Fluid Mechanics
reviews: If you can take this course while Prof. Smits is teaching it, you should definitely do so.
Smits is excellent, workload is reasonable.
Take the course
descrip: An introduction to fluid mechanics. The course explores the development of basic conservation laws in integral and differential form; one-dimensional compressible flows, shocks and expansion waves; effects of energy addition and friction; unsteady and two-dimensional flows and method of characteristics. Reviews classical incompressible flow concepts, including vorticity, circulation, and potential flows. Introduces viscous and diffusive phenomena.

title: Exit, Voice, and Loyalty: Intellectuals in Latin America and the Caribbean
reviews: Be prepared to participate! Don't be discouraged, the quantity of reading is very manageable.
Enjoy!
I would recommend this course to other students.
I would strongly recommend students to take this course because of the great readings, discussions, and writing training you receive from the professors.
It is definitely worth of taking. Every class is an event that challenges your capacity of reframing seemingly old questions.

Really important to understand complexity of intellectual landscape in Latin America.
Really important as a language practice for Spanish and Portuguese Graduate Student.
Really important to learn the engaged and ethical practice of Arcadio Diaz-Qui?ones and Pedro Meira.
Take the course!
descrip: Taking Albert O. Hirschman's reflections on exit, voice and loyalty as our point of departure, the seminar addresses the ambivalent spaces Latin American and Caribbean intellectuals have occupied. Between commitment and compromise, reform and revolution, the lettered city and the people, media and literature, artists and writers have raised questions about politics, war, race, gender, violence, and the power or powerlessness of their own practices.

title: Screenwriting I: Screenwriting as a Visual Medium
reviews: Just be interested.

Just take this class and go nuts with it. If you have any ideas about "perfect", you should get rid of them. By the end of the class, I kinda fell in love with some the other writers' style, and that's what this class is really about , exposing your self to various styles and finding your own, or at least pieces of it. So, be "real", pay attention, and listen to other people, but really as cliche as it might sound this is a class you should try to have fun in.
Scriptwriting is tricky, but you're more creative than you think! Give it a try.
Take it!
Take it! Do the work and stay engaged and you will have a great time in a great class.
Take it! Pretty relaxed and fun.
Take it.
Take this if you are interested in film or anything arts related. This is such an awesome class that has really low commitments and fun assignments. Also it's pdf only.
Take this! And be engaged.
You get out of it what you put into it.
prereqs: Interested students complete a creative writing application (please visit the program website) by attaching a statement about why they would like to take the course, and optionally, a 3-4 page creative writing sample in any genre. Please note this course cannot be audited. Application deadline is April 11, 2014. Accepted students will be able to enroll in SCORE May 19th-23rd..
descrip: The course will introduce students to basic screenwriting principals and techniques, using cross-cultural and cross-temporal examples. Course will examine the visual power of storytelling in film and other relative media, concentrating on the strategic use of visual elements to create a unified viewing experience and the use of visual moments/behavior in creating memorable characters. Students will complete the course with a strong working sense of the core elements used in visual storytelling as applied in film, tv, or new media. Final portfolio will include one silent short film and two narrative shorts.

title: Continuum Mechanics
reviews: If you want to get introduced to general concepts for continuum mechanics, this is a good course.
fun class!
see if the methodology has improved before taking the class
descrip: Course covers 1) Introduction: the continuous medium; essential mathematics-scalars, vectors, tensors, indicial notations, transformations. 2) Basics: stress, strain and deformation; components, principal axes, tensors; 2D and 3D cases. 3) General principles: conservation of mass, continuity equation, momentum principal, motion and equilibrium, energy balance, constitutive equations: needs and axioms; ideal materials, elasticity, isotropy, plasticity, viscoelasticity and thermoelasticity. and 4) Applications: theory of elasticity, fluid mechanics.

title: Modern Control
reviews: It was pretty good, but I don't think it was as good as I hear Professor Leonard's version is.
Take the prerequisites first if you don't have a background in controls!

This course goes into more detail about different things learnt in 433. Basically you find out why and how things work, not just that they do. Since I normally approach things in a more practical/experimental way, I found this course challenging but also extremely helpful and I learnt a lot. If you're like me and what to extend your perspectives then this course can help.
Understand the main idea behind concepts presented in class. The math will follow.
prereqs: MAE 206, MAE 305, and MAE 433.
descrip: This course provides an introduction to modern state-space methods for robust control system design and analysis. Applications include controlling the performance of a variety of dynamical systems. Topics include stability, controllability and observability, state feedback control, observers and output feedback control, linear matrix inequalities, and optimal and robust control design methods.

title: Theoretical Geophysics
descrip: Geophysical applications of the principles of continuum mechanics; conservation laws and constitutive relations and tensor analysis; acoustic, elastic, and gravity wave propagation are studied.

title: Research in Architecture
reviews: I highly recommend the class
I think this is a class for those who want to specialize more on the topic.

Professor Vidler has a command of architectural and historical history that is near awe-inspiring, as well as decades of experience navigating academia and research. The benefits of the course, then, do not lie only in the content of the course's title and readings, but in the advice given regarding their approach, regarding scholarship in general.
descrip: This advanced pro-seminar explores architectural research techniques through collaborative investigation of a specific issue facing the field. Rather than study research methods in the abstract, students are asked to actively carry out detailed research in teams and reflect upon its limits and potentials. The research project of each semester is carried through to realization in the form of a book, a conference, or an exhibition organized by the students in subsequent semesters.

title: Domestic Politics
descrip: An introduction to the political analysis of policy making in the American setting.
