The course includes theoretical and empirical analyses of political institutions, including executives, legislatures, and bureaucracies. It also examines the political environment in which these institutions operate, with special attention given to the role of public opinion, interest groups, and elections.

title: Romanticism - Ecocriticism and French Nature-Writing
descrip: The purpose of this seminar is twofold: to provide a practical guide to the burgeoning field of ecocriticism through an overview of its critical canon; and to shed new light on the French Romantic tradition by reading it through an environmental lens. We will look at landscape painting and poetry, nature writing, animal depictions, and orientalist works from Rousseau to Michelet, and, in the process, analyze nature's shifting status as mere background, hostile other, sublime landscape, vital milieu, intimate place, and full-fledged agent. Topics include biocentrism, ecofeminism, vitalism, postcolonialism, animals, and eco-cosmopolitanism.

title: Policy Workshop - Peace-Building and Development in Conflict-Affected States
descrip: US Forces and its allies now play a significant role in development activities in places such as Afghanistan, Iraq. Not only is the military operating kinetically in these areas, but it is also seeking to win the "hearts and minds" of the local population by addressing needs/grievances. But what role has military-led assistance played in bringing stability and growth to conflict-affected nations? How do military-led efforts compare to those of civilian-run agencies? Does the military play by the same rules as these agencies? These are some of the questions this workshop seeks to address.

title: Notes on Color
reviews: Art students would really benefit from this kind of course, but non-art students (such as myself) can also appreciate the material if they have a general interest in the subject.
It's a lot of fun and not too much work.  The professor is also really understanding and easy to work with
Take it (if ever offered again). Get to know Jim, he's super laid back which was actually a little off-putting at first but it's just his personality.

Take this class if the subject matter interests you! It's a great class, I had a blast and learned a lot of things that have really stuck with me. If art isn't really your thing, then you probably won't get much out of it.
descrip: This seminar will explore the idea of color through a wide range of scientific, philosophical and aesthetic theories. While the eyes of normally sighted human beings render color in roughly the same manner, our reactions and ability to "see" color vary. Far from being a fixed entity, color is a deeply personal and psychological component of human perception and art. In addition to readings, presentations, and discussions, students will be required to keep two kinds of color diaries-one using portable watercolors and another using language-to chronicle their color perceptions, as well as write a paper on an artwork they encounter on campus.

title: Financial Investments
reviews: . Definitely take this class if you are interested in Economics.
Avoid Hong at all costs. Yacine is wonderful. Otherwise, this course is a very good introduction to the financial world. Take it even if you don't want that Goldman Sachs internship.
Be in Alex's precept!
Decent class, get Alex Rodnyansky as your preceptor if you can, I preferred Hong's teaching to Ait-Sahalia's
Do many practice problems.
Don't take it for fun. But if you have to take it for a requirement/certificate, its not the worst that could happen to you.
Don't take the course unless you need it for finance certificate
Don't take this class unless you want to spend many days trying to figure out what will be on the final exam and teaching yourself things that were not presented in lectures in the second half.
Don't worry too much about the details and focus on the big ideas covered in the class.
Exams are extremely challenging, particularly because there is little material to prepare for them. Make sure you know the concepts inside and out.
Exams are quite challenging. Be careful!
Find a good study/pset partner
Get Matt as your preceptor.
Get Matthew as your preceptor.
I don't think this is a necessary course to take if you want to look into finance. Go read some news articles or something.
I probably would not take this class. You could learn more about finance by just reading the textbook and watching lectures from MIT on youtube.

I went into this course considering the finance certificate and left the course knowing that I would never pursue it further. Professor Ait-Sahalia is pretty good and has good lecture slides, but Professor Hong frankly barely teaches you anything useful. Don't worry about going to lecture. If you're going to take it anyway, definitely get Matt Baron as your preceptor, and go to office hours and do every bit of exam prep you can - you're going to need it.

I wouldn't recommend this course. Although the lectures are straightforward, the material itself isn't very engaging. You can learn the material on your own. The problem sets were much easier than both the midterm and final and I felt like I did not learn the material on the exams.
INVEST IN THE BOOK
If you are strongly interested in pursuing certificate, you have to take it. So really think about it.
If you need to take it, it's not to bad and possibly enjoyable if you like finance. If you don't need to take it, I'm more neutral
Inessa's review session at the end of the semester was easily the most useful review session I have ever attended. If she is TAing again, I STRONGLY suggest going.
Introduction to finance. Not exactly the most engaging course
It is reasonably interesting if you like finance, the problem sets aren't too difficult/time consuming. The material is not exactly applicable, but it's not super theoretical either.

It stinks that this is THE finance class because it's brutal. Don't put lectures in Friend it's way too small. Don't put lectures in the afternoon, nobody can pay attention. Both professors need to be more dynamic, they make an interesting subject brutally boring.
It's a good and interesting course. Good gateway into finance.
It's a required class for the finance certificate, so you have to take it. Also, if you're interested in working in finance, this class is the closest thing Princeton has to get you prepared.
It's a very introductory class, even though its 300-level. Take it if you have a general interest in finance or if you need to as a requirement.
It's dry and kind of confusing but could be worth it based on your interests.
It's intro to finance.  Obvioously all you aspiring bankers will take this.
It's okay, only take if you are very interested, otherwise it's not very worth it.
Just remember that this is a very equations/computational course overall.
Lectures are incredibly boring but material is easy.
Material you learn is interesting, but lectures are not.
Meh.
Not a particularly difficult course, but avoid if Harrison Hong is teaching it for any part of the semester. Yacine Ait-Sahalia is much better.

Only if you desperately want the finance certificate should you take this course. Many of my friends, including possibly myself, will be dropping the certificate after this course. If you want to learn about finance your time is better spent in other classes.
Precepts vary a lot by preceptors. Some tell you how to do the psets, some do sample exam problems, others teach a lesson....

Prof. Hong ROCKETED up the difficulty of the exam this year (Fall 2013-2014). Past exams weren't great benchmarks for the difficulty of this year's. Don't let other kids tell you this course is super laid back and easy anymore
Read the book to understand some of the tougher concepts.
Stay away.
Super fascinating, especially if you have no prior finance experience.
Take if needed for the certificate, please don't if not.
Take it as an introduction to finance.
Take it if you have an interest in finance and investments.
Take it if you have to.
Take it if you want to learn about finance in general and why companies do things. Interesting stuff!
Take it if you're interested in finance and don't mind a lot of math.
Take it if you're looking for a good intro to investments and analytics. Don't take it if you are expecting an engaging lecture or precept.
Take it, it's good information to have in general for personal investing purposes. Make sure you study for exams, they can be difficult.
Take only if strongly interested in finance.
Take the class. Very simple.
Take the course if you want gain a broad knowledge of finance.
Take this course only if you have to.
Take this if you're really interested in finance, but otherwise it can be pretty boring.
Tests are much more challenging than problem sets. Interesting material. Useful for jobs.

The course gives a good background on financial investments and is very useful to take if you want to go into Sales and Trading. Some of the stuff is a little abstract, but it was very useful when preparing for a finance interview.
The exams are really hard so make sure you put in a lot of time to understand all the material.
The problem sets are hella easy. Final and midterm are much harder. If you have Matt Baron as your preceptor go to precept.
There isn't really an option for most of you. Just find a good preceptor and stick to them. They will be your savior
This class is very important, I would definitely recommend taking it. Can be tough sometimes but worth it.

This is a useful course to take if you are interested in finance or think you are interested in finance, because it will help you figure out how great your interest really is. That being said, ECO 362 is probably not the most exciting finance course out there, especially for the more mathematically inclined. It is really more of a survey course, without great mathematical rigor and with a lot of excel crunching. Pity that the second half was not very well-organized or well-taught. 1st half was quite good imo; it also felt more rigorous and coherent.
Very important course and topic for those interested in finance.
Very practical course for financial understanding. It could certainly be improved, but I would definitely recommend it.
Yeah, it's awesome
Yep, take it! Not hard, interesting material. You definitely have a leg up if you're an ORFE major.
You have to so just take it. Get Matt as your preceptor because he gives you all the answers to the psets (apparently). Alex is the best for actually learning.
You probably have to take it.But you can also judge if you want to pursue a career in finance in this.
You'll probably take it for the Finance Certificate.  Some topics will be pretty interesting, but not a whole lot of them.

don't take it unless you absolutely have to. 

find a good study group early on. 

go to Alex's lecture because he emails us precept notes.
dsa
if you're interested in finanace, take it. and READ THE BOOK that's all you need to truly understand/enjoy finance.
only take if you want certificate
only take this if you want the finance certificate or want a very, very basic understanding of finance, otherwise not a great class
pretty much required for the certificate so take it if you need.
read the wall street journal and you'll learn more
take it
take this course
well structured and comprehensive
prereqs: MAT 200, ECO 202 and ECO 310. Course not required for concentrators..
descrip: This course surveys the field of investments with special emphasis on the valuation of financial assets. Issues studied include how portfolios of assets should be formed, how to measure and control risk, how to evaluate investment performance and how to test alternative investment strategies and asset pricing models.

title: Ethics
descrip: Problems in ethics

title: Current Topics in Theory and Analysis - Chromaticism
descrip: The presentation and examination of an important work of current interest in theory and analysis and original research of faculty members and graduate students are explored.

title: Research Seminar
reviews: Pace yourself on your research work through the term and make your slides and abstract in December so you aren't rushed at the deadlines.
descrip: This is a continuation of CEE 509. Each student carries out research, writes a report and presents the research results. Doctoral candidates must complete this course one semester prior to taking the general examination. The total grading of the course is based 10% on oral presentation and written "poster" communication skills and 90% based on advisors evaluation of the semester's work.

title: Religion in Colonial America and the New Nation
reviews: Definitely take this course. It's a great foundation in all aspects of American religion -   not just the puritans.
Take it, Professor Perry is great. Try to work on your research paper in advance.
Take it. Professor Perry is awesome
You'll enjoy Prof. Perry's teaching style. Take this class if you're interested in the topic.
descrip: This class covers the history of religion in America from European contact through the 1840s or so. Emphasis will be on primary readings, organized chronologically around a few recurrent themes: contact and exchange; authority and dissent; the relationship between theological reasoning and everyday life. We'll pay particular attention to changing conceptions of religion's role in social organization and competing religious views of human nature over time.

title: Violent Politics
reviews: Absolutely. If anything, at least audit the lectures from Professor Shapiro - he is a very engaging lecturer and the material is very relevant to BBC's every day top-news feed.

Actually do the reading. It is so helpful and you will learn so much. Try to get the professor as a preceptor. Also if you are not interested in a 6 hour timed exam you probably shouldn't take this course.

Be prepared to do a lot of reading when you take this course or be ready to follow the instructor's advice to split the weekly readings  amongst a group and share notes. Also be aware that Professor Shapiro has a very straightforward and blunt style, which can be refreshing and/or off-putting depending on your preferences.
Be sure to attend all the lectures and understand the gist of all the readings. If you follow along with the readings then the course will be much more interesting.
Create a reading group so you don't have to do it all yourself
Do all of the readings
Do not take this class. It is not as interesting as it sounds and the exams are ridiculous.

Don't take it! The lectures were dense, the readings are impossible to get through every week, and the grading is extremely tough. Shapiro was not approachable or that kind in class to those who participated. don't do it.

Fantastic class, really interesting and relevant to anyone who keeps up with current events. Prepare for a lot of reading, they expect you to use a lot of the hypotheses presented in the texts in your analysis.
Find a reading group since the readings are long. But take it since Professor Shapiro is obviously an expert in the topic.
Form a study group or you will die.
I wouldn't really recommend it.
If you have an interest in the theoretical side of conflict and conflict resolution, this is the class for you.

If you're interested in national security issues or violence, definitely take the course. I found myself saying "hey, that could be relevant for my thesis" quite a few times. Take with friends though, because there's too much reading to do on your own.

It's a very interesting subject matter and you learn a lot in the class. So, if you're interested, definitely take it. Prof. Shapiro expects a lot, including participation during lecture, so be prepared for that. Also, you should form reading groups to split the readings because there is a lot.
It's more work than you think. Easy to PDF but maybe not a cakewalk if you want an A
Only take this class if you are interested in theory behind violent conflict.

POL 386 is a good class, and I think it's getting better--the readings are fairly extensive but manageable, and the material is quite interesting. If you're POL/WWS, I recommend it certainly, but also for general interest people.
REading groups are useful, but make sure that you review the notes and ask questions if you have them on a weekly basis
Solid course. Interesting material. Not difficult. But as a senior, I feel like there is a lot of repetition from previous courses.
Take it
Take it.
Take this class, but don't get Shapiro for precept.

Take this course if you have an interest in the material. It probably helps if you know about the topic before enrolling, but that's not necessary. Understand the readings and go to office hours/your preceptor if you have any questions! They are there to help and really want you to understand the material well!

The class is more theoretically based than I thought, exploring theories behind why violence occurs rather than actual violent events going on. Professor Shapiro's lectures were either hard to follow or covered information we had already discussed at length; with that said, he is clearly very passionate in what he's talking about. The midterm/final format of a timed-take home exam is not ideal either.
The class was interesting, but realize that there is a fair bit of statistical analysis as well as theoretical.

This class is a lot of work.  It's probably interesting if you have prior knowledge of war history, but otherwise a lot of it might go over your head.  There is also a ton of reading, way more than is possible to do in a week.

This class shouldnt be called Violent Politics - rather it should be called "Theories of Political Violence w/ a random application over historical conflicts". Professor Shapiro is clearly very intelligent and knows a great deal of information and history, but I found that his lectures were a bit confusing and he spoke way too quickly covering a a vast array of material in short periods. if you do take this class, definitely try to get Christoph for your preceptor. He is really smart and very helpful with providing help and clarification on the many readings that can easily become dense/confusing.

This course is VERY heavy in theory, which can be very tedious and difficult if you don't like that type of thing. If you want to learn about politics of violence in a little bit more of a historical type of way as opposed to just theory, I would recommend Human Rights with Gary Bass.
This is a good class. The take-home midterm and final are both 6 hours long. Lots of reading and Professor Shapiro is good lecturer, but a bit self-important.

Unless you are passionate about the subject, don't take. Even though the material is interesting, the volume of readings is enormous and you will not be able to finish them all. The tests are also unjustifiably long (6 hours!), and you will have to put in a ton of effort to do well.
Yes, unless you don't like history, stats, or psychology.
Yes. Topic is interesting but class isn't easy.
You learn a lot in this class. Make sure to stay on top of the readings!
do not recommend this course unless somebody else is teaching it.
don't take it unless the material is interesting to you
take this class!
prereqs: Freshman and sophomores may enroll with permission of the instructor..
descrip: Governments have tremendous power over our lives and thus the competition over who controls them is always intense and often violent. This course will study various ways in which violence is used to political ends. The larger goal of the course is to understand the sources of violence in political competition and the conditions under which political disputes can be peacefully resolved. Specific forms of violence to be covered include assassination, civil war, ethnic conflict, insurgency, revolution, riots, terrorism, and war.

title: American Literary History
reviews: English majors: Take this class for your American Foundation! It's fantastic.

I think this is a great course for people who are not necesarily interested in literature but like American politics, history or religion since we read a lot of religious and political texts and look at them in historical context. The seminar discussions were always really interesting. However, it is a small class with a lot of english majors and the papers were difficult, so that would be something to consider.
Take good notes in class! It will help for the final.

Take it!!!! I guarantee that this will be one of the best decisions you'll make. Even if you aren't an English major, or don't know much about American literature/history, this class is super interesting, approachable, yet also challenging. Professor Kotin and Professor Rivett are very helpful, passionate, and knowledgeable - the seminar is interesting and engaging, and rare in that it strikes the balance between being student discussion-based and professor instruction-based. The readings are also relevant and extremely interesting - some are well-known American classics, while others are more "obscure" but still worthwhile. Although a 200 level course, be prepared to think, read, and write a lot. It's a lot of work, but you always get great feedback and it's helpful for learning. Either way, this class was by far one of the best classes I took while at Princeton, and would take it again in a heartbeat.

Take this course! Try to do all the readings, because they're extremely rewarding. If you're thinking about being an English major, this course is a great example of what the department offers and expects.
prereqs: Open to all students. This course is
descrip: This course surveys American literature from the colonial period to the Civil War. We will read accounts of early contact, narratives of captivity and slavery, sermons, revolutionary tracts, autobiographies, novels, and poems. We will also examine modern representations of early America in fiction, poetry, and film. In lectures and precepts, we will discuss the influence of individual texts in relation to established accounts of American history to discover how American literature responded to and shaped debates about religion, race, gender, and liberty, and how these debates continue to impact contemporary life in the United States.

title: Introduction to Relativity
reviews: Be sure that you have reviewed the basics of Lorentz transformations and Special Relativity.
Go to the classes! The lectures are really good.
If you are interested in GR, you should take it any way and read a lot.

This is an incredibly fascinating course that does an amazing job of presenting the subject in a comprehensible yet intriguing manner. Prof. Pretorious develops the requisite mathematical background as it is necessary. Overall, it is a very instructive course and I would highly recommend it to anyone curious about this aspect of modern physics.
descrip: This course gives an introduction to Einstein's theory of general relativity. No prior knowledge of general relativity will be assumed, and an overview of the differential geometry needed to understand the field equations and spacetime geometries will be given. Beyond this, topics covered will include black holes, gravitational waves, and cosmological spacetimes.

title: Computer Vision
reviews: !! Take it! The topics covered are really interesting, the assignments won't kill you, and the final project can be fun.

Computer vision is an amazing topic, but unless you have a VERY strong background in linear algebra and willingness to put a lot of time outside class you won't get much out of it. If you are planning on taking this course talk to other people that have taken it before and make sure it is for you.

Do not take this class under any circumstances. It is terrible. The instruction quality is even worse than ORF stats. Sometimes the lectures were too high level to be useful. Other times they were overly detailed and we were presented with slides full of equations that made no sense. Nothing Professor Xiao tried to explain ever made sense. The assignments were horrible. Some were way to easy and just involved stringing together MATLAB functions we were told to use. Others were hard, but not in a helpful way. There is nothing to be gained from trying to decipher uncommented MATLAB code about something we don't understand because the lecture made no sense. Seriously, don't take this unless they completely redesign the class and have someone else teach it. By far the worst class I've taken at Princeton. Take graphics instead (COS 426). Funkhouser and Finklestein are great teachers.
Don't expect to learn anything too in depth, but surveys many very relevant and current topics in computer vision.
Don't take it unless you really, REALLY love computer vision.

Great course for a high-level overview of the field. Xiao is really smart, and tries to impart that information on you, but purposefully skims over the details and stuff you don't have to worry about. If you want to learn a overview of the field, this is the course for you; if you want to get into this field with research and stuff, it might be better just to study on your own or something.

I think this course will improve as Xiao teaches it more, and I recommend it to future students.  The topic is incredibly interesting, but also difficult (everything that seems simple is vision ends up being really hard.  This is what makes it interesting).  The assignments are neat, but did not do a great job of making sure I really understood the concepts.  Often only have to write a few lines of code, which meant I was not confident writing vision code until I worked on the final project.    Assignments varied in difficulty from 3-14 hours (for the SFM assignment).  My group spent ~60 hours per person in a final week sprint - I whole heartedly recommend starting before winter break and working on a piece at a time.  Everything takes longer than you expect in vision!

I would not take this course with Professor Xiao unless you are super-motivated to study the material by yourself. He presents a lot of high-level overview at an incredibly fast pace in lectures, and it is your job to do all the readings and figure out the details for yourself. Additionally, the programming assignments are very basic and do not teach you much - they are essentially exercises in reading Matlab documentation.
If you don't mind being slightly confused in lecture and are passionate about the material then take this class.
If you're not great at linear algebra you will probably be a little lost, but if you are then it's a very interesting topic.
It's pretty good.  A different feel than other COS classes, but some cool things.

Professor Xiao gives great lectures and the material is fascinating with many practical applications. However, supplementary structure outside lectures is very poor. Each TA is in charge of a different assignment and the quality of TA support and commitment varies widely.

Significantly easier than it used to be, but your grades are basically entirely determined by the quiz, which is disproportionately hard given the rest of the class. It also gets decently harder by the end compared to the beginning, but be aware that how much you end up learning by the end of the semester varies a ton and depends entirely on how much you're willing to put into it.
Take it -- it's not that hard, but very interesting. The lectures can be a bit dry at the end but mostly they're pretty good. You definitely learn a lot.

Take it if you're interested in the subject (computer vision is really cool), but you get out of it as much as you put into it. That is to say, unless you've had previous exposure to the topic, you probably have to pay a lot of attention in class, take notes, and do some independent review/studying on your own to come to some understanding of the material.
The course is interesting if you want an overview of computer vision.

This class was awful this semester, and if you're really interested in computer vision, then you should wait as many years as possible before taking it in order to give the instructors some time to fix this and turn it in to a functioning class.
This course does not require much background, which is especially suitable for people who are willing to work on computer vision. Prof. Xiao is very nice. You gonna enjoy this course.

This course provides a good overview of what is well-understood in the field of computer vision and what still needs improvement. The homework assignments provided useful hands-on experience to build intuition about how the algorithms talked about in class performed in practice.

This is really a survey class. A ton of complicated material is thrown at you, but you're just expected to know the basics of the major algorithms/concepts. Also, the problem sets are either trivially easy or insanely time-consuming (mostly because of poorly phrased structure/teaching, not actual difficulty). I wouldn't recommend it, but if you really want to know about Computer Vision... have fun, I guess.
Try taking this course after it improves in the future (hopefully it will).
Very interesting course, take it! Learned a lot of awesome stuff.
Vision > AI. take this course.

What a dismal course.  Lots of potential, but all the material was hastily discussed in a incoherent, loosely tied manner.  Be prepared to learn a lot on your own.  The assignments vary from extremely easy to very difficult.  Don't take it.

Xiao is funny at times but overall hard to understand. To do the psets you HAVE to go to office hours -- otherwise they won't make sense. I would be cautious about taking this one -- class is not very well organized/designed

You'll learn some things about computer vision. This was Prof. Xiao's first time teaching the class, so I expect it to improve in future years. If it doesn't change: the problem sets don't actually require you to understand the material, so it'll be your own responsibility to go beyond the problem sets and make sure you understand. Also, I found that the lectures went fast.
take if you interested in computer vision, you get a walk through of the entire field, and projects have extra credit if you want to learn more
prereqs: COS 217 and COS 226. The course will require programming (in C, C++, and/or Matlab), as well as some background in data structures, linear algebra and probability. Experience with computer graphics is useful, but not necessary..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the concepts of 2D and 3D computer vision. It surveys a wide range of topics from level-level vision to high-level recognition. We will discuss concepts such as filtering and edge detection; cameras and shape reconstruction; segmentation and clustering; optical flow and tracking; object recognition; motion recognition; statistical modeling of visual data, etc. Throughout the course, there will also be examination of aspects of human vision and perception that guide and inspire computer vision techniques.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences I
reviews: Already evaluated

Be prepared for this course to be most of your life! But be prepared to learn more than ANYONE else about science, and make an incredible amount of friends with those who survive though it! It's a wonderful course, and if you are willing to put in the insane amount of work, and genuinely interested in science, you will really love this course! DO NOT take this course, however, if you are not prepared to spend most of your time on it!
Done
Extremely difficult, but life-changing.  Worth every minute.  Remember Stokes Drag.
N/A
NA
See ISC 231 evaluation.
See evaluation for ISC 231.
See reviews of ISC 231.
Study.
The workload for this course is immense. Take this course if you are very passionate about science and research, and have a solid background in all the sciences already.

This is a very time-consuming class that you should not take if you are not willing to spend 2-6 hours every day on ISC (outside of class time), are not interested in all the sciences covered, and don't have a good background in math and science.  One of the most salient aspects of this course is the labs: you really learn a lot about doing labs and writing labs.
You can reasonably expect to spend 40 hours a week working on problem sets and lab reports.
prereqs: Familiarity with the calculus at the level of MAT 103/4 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics, chemistry, molecular biology, and computer science. This year long, four course sequence is a multidisciplinary course taught across multiple departments with the following faculty: T. Gregor, J. Shaevitz (PHY); P. Debenedetti, S. Shvartsman (CBE); J. Rabinowitz, H. Yang (CHM); P. Andolfatto (EEB); E. Wieschaus (MOL); O. Troyanskaya (COS); C. Broedersz, A. Leifer, B. Machta (LSI Fellows); J. Gadd (LSI). Five hours of lecture, one three-hour lab, one three-hour precept, one required evening problem session.

title: A Social and Multi-Dimensional Exploration of Structures
reviews: Definitely don't pass up this opportunity - you get to travel abroad to study and learn about structures that have never been studied or taught before! You will know more than your professors about the works that you study!
Definitely take this (or whatever the equivalent is). It will only get better as the professors get more organized.
Great course -- highly recommend!
If you love structural engineering and/or want to grow in teamwork skills, you must take this class!

TAKE IT! Give feedback to the profs about timing/due dates. Push to have assignments spread out across the semester, because we ended up having everything delayed until the very end, and January was kind of hectic. Choose a good group - peers with whom you'll work hard and get along well for an entire semester. This class was incredibly rewarding and an amazing experience, first in engineering and second in friendships/relationships with profs/CEE love!!!
Take it!
Take this course! This is a great way to experience many different sides of bridge and structural analysis.
This course is a must if you have the opportunity. The travel experience and the opportunity to see engineering projects first hand are unmatched. You will learn a lot by taking this course.
prereqs: PreReqs CEE 205 and CEE 312.
descrip: The class has pedagogical objectives related to the spatial relations of dimensions and time (sustainability and society). It develops the students' skills in drawing, model making, writing, oral communication, and advanced engineering analysis. The course is focused on a study of one theme that changes every year. Within each theme engineering calculations of designs will be made through advanced analyses. The social context will be studied, a site visit will be made during break week, models of a few significant works will be created and placed on display as part of a small exhibition. Two three-hour studios per week with lectures included.

title: Introduction to German Literature after 1700
reviews: I would take it. Great readings that are worth it and reading levels grow.

If you're interested in German literature at all, take this class! Professor Lande is an excellent teacher and the material is very interesting. This class will improve your German and it will also expose you to some of history's greatest works. That said, the work load is substantial. I found it very worthwhile though.
It's a bit of a rigorous class at times, but you'll be a better student for it. Not a bad gig, and Professor Lande is a gem.
Take it if you want a survey course and are prepared to still believe that you're good at a subject regardless of the professor's reaction to you.

Take it! Your German (especially written) will undoubtedly improve a lot and you'll learn interesting authors of German literature. Beware the papers are 4-6 pages long, so do start a little in advance. Also take your time to do the readings, it'll take longer than you expect, if nothing else because they're in German
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: An introduction to major authors, periods, and genres of German literature from the eighteenth century to the present. The course provides a background for the further study of German literature while developing interpretive techniques and providing intensive writing practice. Conducted in German.

title: Responsible Conduct in Research: A Course on Ethics in Engineering (Half-term)
prereqs: This course is required for graduate students in engineering who participate in federally funded research; the course is highly recommended and/or required for undergraduate students as well as post-doctoral researchers in engineering who participate in federally funded research. There are no prerequisites for attending the course..
descrip: This course educates the graduate student of engineering in the responsible conduct of research. The lectures provide theoretical background information as well as case studies about ethics in day-to-day research situations, in publishing and peer-review, in student-advisor relationships, in collaborative research, as well as in the big picture and considerations of long-term impact. The students are provided with resources to consult in ethical questions. In small-group discussions in research field-specific precepts, the theoretical concepts are made relevant to the individual students situations.

title: Design and Interpretation of Social Psychological Research
prereqs: Psychology graduate students only, or Instructor's Permission..
descrip: An advanced seminar that considers current research in social psychology. Contemporary research conducted by the seminar participants is discussed.

title: Elementary Persian I
reviews: Don't let the Persian alphabet scare you away! It was actually very easy to get the hang of it.  Study regularly on your own and seek out opportunities to speak Persian as often as you can, and you'll begin to see a lot of improvement.
I recommend all my friends who are considering taking a language to take Persian. It will be one of the best and most rewarding classes you may take here.
I would recommend taking the course

If you are interested in learning Persian, take this course. You will actually learn Persian. There is homework every night. But you really do gain a lot from this course and Amineh is just a wonderful person and professor.
Like any introductory language course, this one requires you to dedicate a lot of time to it, but the professor is great and the language is fun.
Take it!  The professor is wonderful and the language is beautiful
Without a doubt, I would recommend taking this course. Regardless of interest in Iran or Middle East, it is the kindness and warmth from the professor that has made this class my favourite this term.
prereqs: No credit is given for PER 101 unless it is followed by PER 102..
descrip: The focus of this elementary course is on sounds, letters and basic grammar of Persian language. The students will be exposed to the Persian culture through selected prose, daily news and class discussions.

title: Special Topics in Visual Arts - Extraordinary Processes
reviews: I would recommend Professor Scanlan's design studio for any student looking to investigate personal, individual, self-motivated artistic production. That recommendation is regardless of major/discipline; any student, if passionate about art, would benefit from the constructive critique, artistic precedent, and personal experience of Professor Scanlan.
Super. Take Joe's classes. They are fun and he has interesting things to say.
This class requires a lot of work so be sure to work continuously on your project(s) every week!.Talk to Joe and your other classmates whenever possible -- that's how the ideas begin!
This course is an excellent opportunity to make work and get regular feedback on it. You'll get as much out of it as you put into it.
prereqs: Must have taken any 200-level VIS course PLUS any 200-level CWR, DAN, or THR course OR 300-level VIS course.
descrip: This course will investigate how extreme amounts of invested time and manual labor are still capable of achieving a kind of magic, that is, capable of transforming the ordinary into the extraordinary. For the last century, artists around the world have become more and more interested in the aesthetic value of everyday life, in part as a political gesture designed to bring art down a peg or two, in part a celebration of the surprising levels of beauty and meaning that can be mined from mundane things. Readings regarding the extraordinary as a philosophy, an aesthetic, and a political statement will support in-class studio work and screenings.

title: Imagining Childhood
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Algebra
prereqs: Undergrads must request permission of instructor..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Algebra. More specific topic details provided when the course is offered.

title: Electronic Circuit Design, Analysis and Implementation
reviews: A fantastic class that runs through all the basics of analog circuitry. Prof. Prucnal is unfortunately retiring this year, but if future years are any like this, I'd highly recommend you take it! Coursework is well-paced, with a minor step up in work for the semester project that replaces the final.
Be prepared to invest a large amount of time and effort in the course.
Definitely take this class with Professor Prucnal as professor and Josue as a labta
Do all assignments as soon as you can, especially the long-term ones.
Do the problem sets.
Don't hesitate to ask the TA's or the professor for help! Especially on the projects, they can really help to debug problems.

ELE 203 is a departmental for all ELE majors, and it is a lot of fun. There are plenty of projects to keep up with, and the most important thing is to manage your time wisely. With regards to the difficulty of the material, it is paramount to do practice problems and sometimes even the pset more than once. If you find yourself not understanding something, it is extremely important to go learn it! Do not let yourself fall behind - do practice problems from the book (answers are provided), do the Pset problems 2 or 3 times using different techniques (I.E. do a problem using node analysis, then do it using mesh current analysis, then do it using circuit reduction), etc. Perhaps the biggest reason for poor performance is doing only the bare minimum - understanding the material cannot be attained from only doing the lectures, classes, psets, and projects. You must be proactive and work at it until reducing circuits is as natural as adding a pair of two-digit numbers. 

The following courses are helpful, but not necessary to have under your belt: single-variable calculus, linear algebra, E&M physics (Including sinusoidal steady-state analysis using phasors, the e^iomega thing). Things from these subjects pop up once in a while, and having taken these classes beforehand saves you from having to learn them on the fly.

If you are not an ELE major, the only caution I have for you is the workload. This class does require a lot of work, just like ELE 206 does. It is nevertheless a very fun and rewarding experience, and most ELE majors can take 5 courses with this included, and do just fine in them. The above helpful classes I mentioned above still apply - it is not recommended to walk into this course with poor knowledge of basic math and physics.

ELE 203 is officially changing. The class I took is different than the class future students will take. Prucnal is a caring professor who is excited by teaching and tries to be fair and not overly complicated. Debbie Varnell is a great preceptor. She has a lot of TA experience and is perpetually willing to donate her time to help you in the lab. The class has alot of huger projects in addition to the normal class/lab/precept requirement. It is very frustrating to put in so much time and to not have things working perfectly (as frequently happens) but it is extremely awesome to put in all the work and by the end have a working project which you built with your own hands. Be prepared to put in the time but be prepared to really understand how to wire a breadboard and all the basic (and very necessary) components of circuitry.
Fantastic class for ELE majors, and non majors should consider it as well. Very sad to hear Prucnal is leaving it, I think he made the class. Very in-depth labs, expect a lot of time in lab.
Fun course where you get to solder and play with circuits. The lab portion can take a good amount of time.
Great course to take. Lots of work required outside lectures, especially if you are not an electrical engineering major.

I took this as a math major thinking that it would be an interesting STL, but it turned out to be a lot of labwork for a pretty small and unsatisfying amount of material. Would not recommend to non-ELE people.
If you enjoy the material the course will be great. It is very time consuming.

If you take this course, expect to spend most of the second half of the semester in the Electrical Engineering Lab. Prof. Prucnal, is not teaching this course next year, so it may be very different in the future. Get started on your ECG early!
If you want to know about what is the backbone of all technology take this course.
If you're interested in how technology works and have enough room in your schedule for a very time-intensive class, I would strongly recommend this course.
It is a huge time commitment, but at the end of it all, you will be perfectly comfortable with fairly complex circuit design. It is certainly worth ever late night.
It's a lot of work and lab time, but it feels so rewarding. Keep up with the work and you'll be fine and come out of it feeling like you've learned so much.
It's a standard introduction to circuits. Builds upon the basics taught in PHY 104/106. The labs can be time-consuming though.
Its a very good course if you are at all interested in ELE, but be smart about time management, because this class will take a good portion of your schedule.

Its a very interesting course with a lot of aspects to it. If you are an ELE major, you will get exposure to a lot of basic and needed skills, and if you are not ELE then it is still a lot of interesting things to learn, but a fair bit of work (manageable though).
Make sure you're okay with long days debugging circuits if you want to take this class.
PRUCNAL is AMAZING. Don't know who will be teaching next year, but just the curriculum is great. Highly recommend.
Prepare for long lab times and do this class if you enjoy hands-on work!
Take it even if you are not ELE!
Take it if you're interested in it because it is a lot of work.
Take it! It's a great STL if you're not ELE and you learn so much in lab, plus the tests are very fair.
Take this course even if you're not AB! Prucnal is great, but leaving the course. I'd imagine it would still be a good class. A good amount of work, but worth it in the end.
Take this course only if you are ELE. There is a tremendous time commitment and you don't want to put yourself through that for no reason.
This is an interesting and engaging course - Professor Prucnal is amazing. Be prepared for a huge amount of work.
Tons of work, but very good.
Work hard.
Yes!
You'll enjoy this class if you're ELE.
descrip: Introduction to electronic theory and practice. DC and AC circuit analysis theorems and passive and active components, from resistors/capacitors/inductors to operational amplifiers. Feedback, sinusoidal steady state analysis, frequency response, resonance, diodes, transistors. Labs and demos support and extend class material, culminating in a functioning radio. Creative circuit design using light and sound outputs is encouraged. A final project on bio-sensing, including design and testing of an electrocardiogram circuit to sense real heartbeats. SPICE circuit simulation is introduced and leveraged in the labs and project.

title: Nietzsche
reviews: Anyone with an interest in philosophy should take this course.

Class is a bit overrated - certainly not life changing as some have indicated in previous reviews. But Nietzsche's ideas are certainly interesting and worth your time and Nehamas is the best guy out there to learn them from

Come to lecture with at least some questions ready. Always think of loopholes and questions about the readings, because Prof. N will give you many opportunities to ask questions and deepen your understanding of Nietzsche.

Definitely take it, even if you are not a Philosophy major. It will make you rethink a lot of your views and your view of philosophy as a discipline as well. Nehamas is a really intelligent and interesting professor, and you should take a class with him at least once.
Definitely take it. It will help you develop your thought.
Do it. You can't exercise your Will to Power if you don't know what it is
Do yourself a favor and take it.
Go to lecture because you will learn so much in each session

I can't recommend this class highly enough. Professor Nehamas is an incredible lecturer. He's clear, articulate, and entertaining. He breaks complex ideas into understandable terms.
Nietzsche is also an incredible thinker. His works are fun to read and his ideas are very powerful. If you have any interest in philosophy, take this class.
I enjoyed it, but it started becoming repetitive halfway through, and being in Prof. Nehamas' precept made it even more repetitive. He's a great lecturer but only a so-so preceptor.
If you have an interest in Nietzsche (or philosophy in general), it will be enough to get you through the class. Otherwise, it's not worth it.
If you want to take it, take Nehama's precept. The grad student I had as preceptor destroyed me

If you're even considering this at all, you should take it. This course changed my life. Looking back, one of the reasons I love Princeton is that I got to take it. If I had the chance to do Princeton again repeatedly, I would take this course every time. It has made life so much better.
It is not like other philosophy - this stuff in Walter Kaufmann's words "sings and sizzles."
Prof. Nehamas is a world expert, and the course is very well organized. Highly recommended for anyone concerned with how to live life.
Read Nietzsche on your own with the suggested texts and you'll get as much as I did out of the class.
Rigorous class since Nietzsche is difficult to understand, but very rewarding. Not recommended as a first time philosophy class unless you REALLY want to learn about Nietzsche.
Take it if you are interested in understanding life.
Take it.

Take this class! If you're one of my friends, you've probably already heard me recommending it! Don't worry about the prerequisite philosophy class, Professor Nehamas is totally obliging if you have a legitimate interest in the class.
Take this course.
This is a good course if you are interested in Nietzsche.
take it if you are interested in philosophy and dont mind a lot of reading

tl;dr Take it.

This is one of the Princeton-superstar courses you should take. Professor Nehamas is amazing, and you will enjoy his lectures a lot. The papers and the readings are not too bad.
prereqs: At least one Philosophy course-not elementary logic. Freshmen admitted only after interview. Please contact Prof. Nehamas for an appointment..
descrip: An examination of Nietzsche's central views, including the role of tragedy, the place of science, the eternal recurrence, the will to power, and the primacy of the individual. We will also examine Nietzsche's ambiguous attitude toward philosophy and his influence on literature and criticism.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - The Economy and Economic Policy in 2014
descrip: This course analyzes key aspects of recent economic performance and economic policy. Topics include: job growth and unemployment; state of the housing market recovery; income growth and inequality; fiscal drag; and monetary policy. The course emphasizes the connection between the pace of the economic recovery and the nature of the 2008-09 economic crisis, as well as the impact of key economic policies on recovery. The course also discusses the construction and interpretation of key economic indicators, such as the unemployment rate, home prices and the national income accounts.

title: Imagined Cities
reviews: Do it!
Do the readings, and be mentally prepared for 3 hours of class! Don't be afraid to speak up.
Take it. You'll love it.
Take this class! It has been one of my favorites of my Princeton career. The films are great, they readings are interesting and are relevant/important works.
Take this if you?re keen on cities. Lots of great films to make the class enjoyable too.
descrip: An undergraduate seminar about the urban experiences and representations of the modern city as society. Beginning with the premise that the "soft city" of ideas, myths, symbols, images, and psychic expressions is as important as the "hard city" of bricks and mortar, this course explores the experiences and imaginations of modern cities in different historical contexts. Among the cities we will examine are Manchester, London, Paris, Berlin, St. Petersburg, Algiers, Bombay, and Hong Kong. The course will use a variety of materials, but will focus particularly on cinema to examine different imaginative expressions of the urban experience.

title: Modern Genetics and Public Policy
reviews:
An incredible seminar. Touches upon all facets of genetics--the ethics, the policy, the social implications, and more.  Professors Wailoo and Tilghman are amazing co-teaching together.
On top of all this, reasonable workload as well!

Be prepared to hear a lot of WWS majors just say the same things over and over again in class. I loved the professors, but the students in the class made the experience miserable, especially since there were too many of them for a seminar
Definitely take it if you are interested in genetics and public policy!
Do it. Two of the best professors at Princeton. You wont regret it. Its two papers, no tests, and you learn a ton.

I cannot recommend taking this course strongly enough. It is designed to be interesting to students across majors and interest areas, especially biology, policy, history, politics, sociology, and anthropology. Lectures and discussions were well-organized, and the input of Professors Wailoo and Tilghman makes the course a unique learning opportunity.

If you have any interest in the rapidly-growing field of genetics as it relates to policy (implications on race / justice system, policies bordering on eugenics, etc.) ? TAKE IT. Prof. Wailoo and Prof. Tilghman are awesome, discussions in seminar are never forced or awkward but flow naturally and the seminars are organized incredibly well so they are never tedious. Easy to be engaged and a great opportunity to take a course on something that is immediately relevant with two excellent professors.
Interesting course. Take since you won't get a chance to learn from Shirley Tilghman again!
It's a great seminar!
Participate in class and ask questions either in class or in office hours.

Take it!!! This is a great course for anyone interested in medicine, science and health policy. It may be a little bit harder for science students, but definitely do-able and you learn a lot about policy in general just from being in the class. Both professors (Wailoo and Tilghman) are amazing and teach you so much about the field.
Take this class, but beware if the size gets about 20 students. May not be able to engage as much as you'd like if you're looking for a highly interactive seminar. Still learn a lot though.
Take this class- the material is fascinating and the professors are wonderful. I learned a lot!
Take this course!  It was enjoyable and interesting and covers very current issues.

This is a great class on a fascinating and novel subject area. The workload is quite manageable and the lectures themselves are interesting. Make sure to be ready as soon as SCORE opens, it usually fills instantaneously.
Very interesting course. Tilghman and Wailoo were both accessible and great professors.
Very interesting, much more policy-oriented. Meet with professors/preceptors about the essays.
descrip: Examines modern genetics' implications for public policy focusing on health, law, consumer products, and criminal justice. Topics include: genetic testing and therapy; consumer regulations including FDA rules on at-home genetic testing; the law and genetic discrimination in insurance; and uses of forensic DNA in the courtroom. Explores social, political, and philosophical problems in these areas: changing conceptions of the self; relation of new genetics to the old, racially-charged, eugenics; impact of new theories of gene action and epigenetics on ideas about the "hardwiring" of health and behavior, and on "genetic blame" and future policy.

title: Intermediate Photography
reviews: I'd take it! Except it to be a lot of work- which can be stressful... which can be frustrating given that this is most likely an elective. So if you have a light schedule and are really interested, do it. It'll get much easier after the first few weeks of using the camera (which can be intimidating at first).
TAKE IT. If you are at all interested in photography this is a great exercise .
prereqs: MUST have taken VIS 211 or 212 as a prerequisite for this class (Introductory Photo).
descrip: This studio course seeks to broaden students' skills through a wide range of photographic media. There will be an emphasis on the relationship between analog and digital photography and how visual artists negotiate the technological changes of today. A broad range of new tools will be introduced to the class including medium and large format cameras, scanners, Photoshop, color and BW pigment printing, studio lighting and the use of high-end digital backs. The class will consist of independent and collaborative assignments augmented by field trips, readings and discussion of contemporary issues.

title: Introduction to Water Pollution Technology
reviews: Do problem sets.
Don't take it unless you have to - there are better courses in CEE and GEO.
Exams are a little rough but the class is very interesting and Prof. Jaffe knows his stuff!
Go to lecture!!! There is no other way to do well on the tests!!
I didn't like the course.  Take it if it's required, but it isn't particularly well taught.
I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in environmental engineering and water pollution.
Make sure you udnerstand the concepts before any tests/hw/final project
paying attention in class and attempting hw can be frustrating at times but does actually end up helping for exams. jaffe is super nice and willing to help and answer questions!
prereqs: Student should have some background in chemistry and an interest in water pollution problems..
descrip: An introduction to the science of water quality management and pollution control in natural systems; fundamentals of biological and chemical transformations in natural waters; indentification of sources of pollution; water and wastewater treatment methods; fundamentals of water quality modeling.

title: Analytical Techniques in Differential Equations
reviews: Be sure you are willing to dedicate a lot of time to the assignments.
If you don't have extensive physics or ODE experience don't take this along with too many other courses.
Keep up with the outside reading. It helps to use multiple reading sources.
Read up on Bender and Orszag! Also, make sure to buy Heading. It's almost essential reading.
This class is worth taking.
descrip: Asymptotic methods, Dominant balance, ODEs: initial and Boundary value problems, Wronskian, Green's functions, Complex Variables: Cauchy's theorem, Taylor and Laurent expansions, Approximate Solution of Differential Equations, singularity type, Series expansions. Asymptotic Expansions. Stationary Phase, Saddle Points, Stokes phenomena. WKB Theory: Stokes constants, Airy function, Derivation of Heading's rules, bound states, barrier transmission. Asymptotic evaluation of integrals, Laplace's method, Stirling approximation, Integral representations, Gamma function, Riemann zeta function. Boundary Layer problems, Multiple Scale Analysis

title: Topics in Music from 1400 to 1600 - Renaissance Music
descrip: The sacred music of Josquin Des Prez (c.1455-1521): masses, motets, musical styles, reception, performance practice, analysis, aesthetics.

title: Ethnography of Schools and Schooling
reviews: Always do the reading!
Do the readings -- you'll regret it if you don't.
If you have any interest in the subject, take this class! Prof. Klugman is great and the seminar is extremely well-structured.

If you're interesting in education, you should definitely think about taking this class! It's a lot of reading and perhaps more big writing assignments than other classes, but Professor Klugman is an engaging lecturer and a great person and always willing to talk to you one-and-one, and most of the ethnographies you read are really interesting.

Professor Klugman is one of the best professors I have had a Princeton. This class is fascinating if you have any interest in our education system or would like to go into the teaching profession. I highly recommend it!
Take it! So so amazing of a course, would definitely strongly recommend
Take it, but keep in mind all the work that it requires.
Take this class! It is definitely worth it!
Take this course! Prof. Klugman is wonderful and his teaching style is very effective. You will learn a lot about qualitative research connected to the hot topic issues of education and inequality.

This class gave me a real chance at independent anthropological work as a sophomore. It is a large time commitment (tons of reading) but so worthwhile if you have any interest in education--school policy or culture--and what it means for the rest of society.
This class is a great course that I recommend for anyone interested in ethnography or education.
yes, but know that it is heavy on ethnography. It is not just a general course about education; it is about education as viewed through the specific research lens of ethnography
prereqs: Students should have a background (coursework or other experience) in anthropology, sociology, education or related fields..
descrip: Social scientists use ethnographic methods to describe and analyze the range and variation of daily interactions in schools. Ethnographic study allows researchers the opportunity to examine power dynamics that influence the daily life of students, teachers, administrators and parents. Vivid, critical ethnography helps us discover how cultural traditions, expectations, and opportunities are passed down to the next generation and how they impact school outcomes. This class will explore educational ethnography and students will complete observations hours in local schools and prepare a descriptive, mini-ethnography of a school community.

title: Intermediate Urdu I
prereqs: HIN/URD 101 and 102 or equivalent proficiency in either language.
descrip: This course is a continuation of HIN/URD 102, concentrating on Urdu. Students beginning with intermediate proficiency in either Urdu or Hindi will be brought to an advanced level in Urdu in all four skills. The Urdu script will be introduced and an emphasis will be placed on strengthening literacy skills. After completing the course, students will be able to read or comprehend through listening, a variety of authentic Urdu texts and media materials. Various aspects of the target culture will be integrated with instruction. Activities will be conducted in Urdu and classes will be interactive.

title: Introduction to World Literature: Leaving Home Throughout the Ages
descrip: Why does the act of leaving home generate literary masterpieces around the globe? What are the painful and productive aspects of displacement? This course takes a cross-cultural and cross-temporal approach to questions of exile and migration, following their depiction across centuries and continents in famous novels, stories, poems, and essays from East and West. We will read classic works alongside contemporary novels, and narratives of homecoming alongside narratives of no return, looking closely at the concepts of home, identity, language, and memory. This course is an excellent introduction to comparative literature and world literature.

title: Comparative Race/Ethnicity in the United States
descrip: This course examines the historical approaches to multiracial and multiethnic interactions in the United States. By focusing on the constructions of race and ethnicity through a comparative lens, privileges and societal hierarchy becomes more pronounced and difference more nuanced. Some of the central themes of the course are identity, citizenship, and migration. The majority of readings are from 1850 to the present.

title: International Monetary Theory and Policy I
descrip: This sequence (with ECO 554) develops core models of international finance and open-economy macroeconomics, and surveys selected current research topics in the field. Topics treated in the first semester include: the intertemporal approach to the current account; the determination of real exchange rates, and purchasing power parity; international CAPM and uncovered interest rate parity; sovereign debt crisis; speculative attacks and liquidity crises; international risk sharing and capital flows, home bias, and the stability of the international financial system.

title: American Images
reviews: Come to class and take notes!
Definitely, definitely take this course! DeLue is an incredible professor and it is absolutely worth it to take at least one course taught by her during your time at Princeton.
Enjoy the lectures and readings.
Go to each lecture, those cover materials not always found in the textbook or the supplementary reading materials.
Go to lecture, even if it seems boring. Don't bother doing any of the textbook readings, just the primary sources, and you'll be more than prepared for the final.
Go to the lectures, they are very important and interesting.

I would recommend that students keep up with readings because there is never that many and they are helpful in providing context for the lectures. Students should also never be afraid to ask questions, especially about assignments.
Much more of an art history course than an American studies course.

Professor DeLue is an incredible and engaging lecturer. She will provide you with new, weird, and yet totally fascinating takes on various works of art, and pull them all into a totally absorbing narrative about US History.

Plus she's just about the nicest lady around.
TAKE IT!  Professor DeLue is so fun and engaging.  She challenges her students without being too demanding.
Take it!
Take it, especially if you have no experience with the subject matter. It was a bit elementary but very interesting topic and Professor DeLue's amazing.
Take this course if Professor DeLue is teaching it, she's literally phenomenal.
Take this course if you're interested in the ties between American art and history!
This class doesn't even require a love or knowledge of art, it covers many different topics of study--it is simply directed by images of American interest.

This course is great for someone just interested in learning more about American Art. Having no prior art experience I thought this course covered the basics and went beyond, but there was never a point where I felt lost.
This is equally an art course and a history course, and very interesting if you have a passing interest in either. Professor DeLue is funny and interesting, and the coursework is not very difficult.
Would take, very relaxed.
Yes
take it!
descrip: This course examines America through the lens of its images. Pictures created by Americans of all stripes in all periods have been integral to the shaping of American history, culture, and identity. By examining a wide range of image types--from the fine arts and photography to the built environment, scientific illustration, film, and digital media--and by considering these images in terms of their historical, political, social, intellectual, and global contexts, "American Images" will offer both a sweeping and a detailed portrait of America through the rich, sometimes strange history of its art and visual culture.

title: The Smart Band-Aid
descrip: Please see website

title: Poetics - The Other Literary Traditions of the British Isles
descrip: English currently dominates the literary life of the United Kingdom but, historically, the British Archipelago has always been far from monoglot. Other languages and their poetic traditions have had a formative influence on English from its earliest times. The first British war poem, Y Gododdin, was written in Welsh about a battle fought in Scotland. This seminar considers the influence of Welsh, Irish, Gaelic and Scots poetry on the English. It takes in Latin as a lingua franca until the end of WWI and explores the contemporary influence of Indian, Pakistani, Polish and Romani writing on modern verse.

title: Philosophical Analysis from 1900 to 1950
reviews: Definitely take it if you're interested. Whether or not you will like it will probably depend a lot on whether you like the specific philosophers you're studying.
Difficult but the instructors are awesome and really help you to understand some difficult and important material.
Don't go in if you aren't really smart.
Go to lecture and understand the material? Ha.
Halvorson is a wonderful professor - very clear, engaging and funny. Readings are very dense and very difficult but Halvorson is clear enough you don't have to do them to appreciate the material
I would definitely take it if you are a philosophy major
Read texts closely--match with lecture material.
Take it!

Take it! Professor Halvorson is my favorite professor so far at Princeton. He's super down-to-earth and helpful, and he teaches you to charitably examine philosophical projects that might otherwise seem obscure or unnecessary. The material is also interesting because it applies to how you view your world, the extent to which you can communicate with others about your worldview, science and math, etc., and delves into some of the ideas that revolutionized philosophy as we know it today. You don't need extensive background in philosophy to do well, and the work is engaging and the workload relatively light. Great class all around!
Take it.
Take it.  It's a good class.  Don't do anything ahead of time.  Also, focus on the really big ideas and one or two readings to write your paper on.
Take the course! Take anything Professor Halvorson is teaching. You won't regret it.
Take this course if you're studying philosophy. If you're just interested in philosophy (like me), take this course. If you don't want to engage with difficult subjects, don't take this course.
Take this course. You'll love it.

The best course I have taken at Princeton so far. This course forces you to think in a critical manner about the most fundamental philosophical problems of truth, language, meaning, and the like. I could not recommend this enough.

The course material is challenging, but gaining a better understanding of logical positivism really shapes how you view science, language, and basically the world. Professor Halvorson is awesome - very knowledgeable, very open to questions and conversations, and an engaging lecturer. Take this class if you enjoy philosophy and aren't afraid of some rather dense scientific and mathematical arguments and readings.

This course was challenging, engaging, and rewarding. The years between 1900 and 1950 were arguably the most transformative in making philosophy what it is today, and it was fascinating learning about the development of philosophy at this time. Above all though, I truly believe that professors and preceptors truly make or break courses, and both Professor Halvorson and Robbie Hirsch were absolutely incredible. They were able to break down very difficult material and make it interesting and thought-provoking. Plus, they are both immensely intelligent and interesting people (go to their office hours, you won't regret it).
Overall--great class taught by amazing people
This is a very good philosophy class for mathy people, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. Halvorson is a wonderful teacher.
descrip: A study of analytic philosophy in the first half of the 20th century. Topics include include the early analytic paradigm of Russell, the logical atomism of Russell and early Wittgenstein, logical positivism and logical empiricism (inluding Schlick, Carnap, etc.), the development of the semantic perspective (including Tarski), and Quine's proposal to naturalize philosophy. The course will focus on changing ideas about the methods and aims of philosophy in an intellectual climate dominated by scientific advances.

title: Public Economics
reviews: A classic Bogan class. Interesting material and not too difficult.

Bogan is a wonderfully caring professor and has strong opinions on the material. She's definitely at her best in precepts  -- lectures could occasionally be a little disorganized or dry. Overall, it's a good course and teaches you things that are useful to know as an informed citizen. If you're not sure if you want to take this, I'd recommend looking into Harvey Rosen's courses as a similar option.
Definitely take this class if you want a strong understanding of what viable solutions for a lot of the U.S. government's problems.
Definitely take this course.
Definitely take this course. Attend lecture, do the packet readings and be prepared for an awesome course.
Do all the packet readings and know the lecture materials really well
Great class if Bogan is teaching it.
Great class if you want to understand the economics behind basically every single public policy issue out there. Very helpful if you want to sound smart at a dinner table.
I would totally recommend any Princeton student to take this course because it is relevant to real-world happenings.
If you want an easy course take it, but the lectures will be painful and you should be prepared just to memorize facts. There are other Public Econ courses out there that you will get much more from.

It's a lot more work than I expected-- although it's only readings and not math-based like some other econ classes, the amount of detail that one must know for doing well on exams can be a challenge. For some, Bogan's style is their cup of tea and it is easy for them...it depends on the person! overall, though, good class and I certainly learned a ton. And as for the humanity of the professor- I'd say Bogan is pretty good:) She is one of the most sincere professors in the econ department and is always willing to stay late after office to answer her students' questions.

Just take it. You will learn many things about education, health, crime, environment and some practical things such as how to raise children, i.e. the importance of prenatal and postnatal care of infants. Get into groups of 3 and divide the readings among yourselves.
Make time for the readings and visit office hours!
Professor Bogan does an amazing job of distilling long readings down to the important pieces that you need to know, so even though a lot of material is covered it still feels manageable.

TAKE IT! You will become a much more well-informed American citizen once you do. A class that actually matters and from which you can use the material learned outside of college. A recommendation though would be to split up the readings with one or two people as they can be over bearing sometimes and Prof. Bogan likes to ask questions about them on tests.
Take it

Take the course. Not sure it lives up to its reputation as one of the best courses on campus, but certainly an interesting course that left me with a better informed more thoughtful view of the world.
Take this course! Bogan is a great lecturer and definitely worth learning from. The span of topics is very ambitious, but the course really does cover everything it says it will.
Teaches you the research behind a lot of policy issues. I feel better prepared to engage in political discussions, to make decisions in elections and to evaluate policy from an economic perspective.

The readings were the best part of the course and were the way that you actually learned all of the material and the nuances of different policies. Without doing the readings, Bogan's lectures seemed scattered and a bit unfocused. Even though she posts the slides online, you really had to attend lecture to understand them. But the readings were enough to do well in the course without attending lecture. The psets were very easy (30-60 min per week) after you completed the readings. The midterm and final were fair and based on what we learned as the sample midterms indicate. Precept was discussion-based and focused on the readings (Bogan led 4 out of the 11 precepts). Not that hard of a class but don't skip the readings since they are very interesting. Lecture not essential.

To do this class right requires a lot of reading. That said, this was one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton and the one that I've learned the most from. You learn and become conversant in the major viewpoints of all of the main policy debates our country is currently engaged in. And Professor Bogan is phenomenal as always!
Yes, but it's a lot, lot of work!
work hard, attend lecture, and enjoy it!
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101.
descrip: The role of government in promoting efficiency and equity in the U.S. economy. Conditions when markets fail to be efficient. Problems with government allocation of resources. Economic analysis and public policies regarding health care, education, poverty, the environment, financial regulations and other important issues.

title: Critical Perspectives in Global Health
reviews: Awesome class - very engaging and insightful!
Don't expect this class to be easy or not much work, it takes A LOT of time.
Engage yourself in the readings and in the lectures, because you will get a lot out of taking the time to really think about the questions asked by the lectures and the texts.
Go to lecture as it helps you understand the topic. Prioritize the important readings as you will probably not finish all of it.

Great course. Even if you have to take it as a requirement, it is an enjoyable one. Pay attention to the lectures because they are interesting (especially the guest lectures), and keep up with the readings.
Great intro to global health.

Highly recommend this course. Joao is a wonderful professor and incredibly passionate about what he does. There is a ridiculous amount of reading (especially in the first half of the semester) so be prepared (or doing the readings over the summer!)

I definitely recommend this course if you have any interest in global health. The material is very interesting and easy to engage with. Very low workload, accessible and enthusiastic teaching staff. Definitely one of the best overall courses that I've taken at Princeton.
I thought this class was great. It's a lot of reading but a lot of interesting material. I personally found Professor Biehl to be fascinating to listen to.
