I took this as a non GHP certificate person and I still enjoyed it. It's a fair amount of work and lots of reading. Professor Biehl is wonderful and definitely the best part of the course. There were lots of very interesting guest lecturers as well.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone- the field of global health is so broad and encompasses so many different aspects which cater to the many different interests of students. The teaching staff is so amazing and work to make sure the class appeals to everyone.

If you have any interest in global health or human rights, this class is probably a good pick for you! There is a lot of reading, but it is interesting. Lectures are good as well. Professor Biehl is really passionate and excited about his class.
If you haven't taken a course on global health before, I would 100% recommend it. If you're very familiar with the field, I'd say you should find something more specific/advanced,

In the beginning of the semester, there are way too many readings to finish. If you feel up for it, find out which books you'll have to read front-to-back and read them the summer before you take the class, then skim them for important points when they come up in class.
Make sure you allocate enough time to delve into the readings and be able to make connects between arguments.
Manage the readings; go to lectures!
Only take this class for GHP requirement.
Really good class to learn more about important public health concepts and topics.
Stay engaged. Ask questions, contribute in precept, and really take time to think about those presentations and papers and posts.
Stay up with the readings for the first half of the semester - it's a lot but you will get a lot out of it. Second half you can skim as long as you go to lecture and pay a lot of attention.
Super interesting course - introduces you to the incredibly complex field of global health.
TAKE IT! A lot of reading, but it's worth it. And go to lecture-- it's the best part.
TAKE IT! YOU'll love it!!
Take it, even if you do not intend to pursue to certificate program!  The topic is very relevant today, and definitely good knowledge that everyone should be aware of.
Take it, you'll love it!
Take it. Joao is great.  Get Bharat as a preceptor.
Take this class and gain a whole other comprehensive perspective on the social and political determinants of health that are extremely important in medicine.
Take this class! Biehl is great!
Take this class, It is an interesting course taught by a truly awesome professor. Workload is a bit heavier than expected though so beware.

Take this course if you are interested in global health! Prof. Biehl is an expert and he is so sweet. He laughs and jokes throughout his lectures and truly cares about his students and their engagement. The reading load is heavy, but the only assignments are weekly discussion board posts and a midterm paper. Use your preceptor as a resource and be engaged in class and you will do well.
Take this course. Alecia is also a great preceptor! All of them are!
Take this if you are getting the GHP certificate.

Taking this course was an extremely rewarding and fulfilling experience. Prof. Biehl is the most charismatic and genuine professor I have had at Princeton. He is quite reasonable, and he does not believe in pushing grades down. Biehl is personally invested in his students' experience with the class, as are the preceptors.
The professor was super enthusiastic that every lecture got you even more passionate and excited on global health and related matters. Also, the preceptor was amazing and very helpful!
The reading isn't all necessary.
There's a lot of reading, so give yourself enough time for this course!

This is a great course to take even if you're not in the GHP certificate program.  There are a lot of cool guest speakers who come in, which makes lectures entertaining.  Professor Biehl piles up the readings in the first half of the course so after spring break the workload is very light.
This is a truly fantastic course if you're interested in global health and the professors and visiting lectures are fascinating and engaging.
This is a very well-organized and well-taught course. Readings can be excessive though.
Triage the readings if they do not reduce the volume of them.
Try to balance out the readings as much as possible.
Try to read all the readings and explore sides of the argument not offered in the readings.

You probably have to take it as a GHP certificate student. That's not to say that it's a bad course. The first half has a LOT of reading though, so be prepared for that and try not to fall behind. The weekly responses aren't too bad, but can get a little frustrating when you have a super busy week.
n/a
descrip: This course introduces students to pressing disease and health care problems worldwide and examines efforts currently underway to address them. Taking an interdisciplinary approach, the course identifies the main actors, institutions, practices, and forms of knowledge production at work in the 'global health system' today, and explores the environmental, social, political, and economic factors that shape patterns and variations in disease and health across societies. We will scrutinize the value systems that underpin specific paradigms in the policy and science of global health and place present-day developments in historical perspective.

title: Quantitative Analysis I
descrip: This is a first course in statistics for social scientists. Students will learn to explore data creatively and to conduct straightforward statistical analyses. Basic probability and statistical theory will also be taught. There is no prerequisite except high school mathematics and a willingness to learn elementary calculus.

title: Classical Japanese Theater
descrip: In this course we study four major forms of pre-modern Japanese drama: Noh, Kyogen, Kabuki and Bunraku. These dramatic forms have close relation to other aspects of Japanese culture, especially literature and music, and give voice to a wide range of human experience within the context of an intricately articulated body of conventions, with surprises. No knowledge of Japanese is expected. We will devote a significant portion of our time to studying performances on DVD and/or VHS. We will learn about the history of Japanese drama, its aesthetic values, its relation to other arts, its inspirations in Buddhist and Shinto belief.

title: Computational Physics Seminar
reviews: I would recommend learning Python on your own before entering this class. Be comfortable with the language so that you can devote more time to understanding the numerical methods and the physics applications.
If you want to learn about physics, take a real physics class.  Ditto to programming.  This was not effective for either and Galbiati created a lot of unnecessary stress.
Not much work or pressure. You could do all of it independently, or you can do it with some more structure and TA help.
prereqs: PHY 104 or PHY 106 or permission of instructor.
descrip: Introduction to the use of computers in physics research. The two main themes of the course are the difficulty of analyzing even simple physics problems with pen and paper, and the application of numerical programming to such problems. Methods include numerical integration, least-squares fitting, Fourier transforms, and Monte Carlo simulation. Students will engage in scientific programming, graphing, and some visualization. Examples are intentionally drawn from various fields of physics not normally explored by sophomores, including cosmology, condensed matter, and elementary particle physics.

title: Studies in Chinese Religions - Popular Chinese Religion
descrip: Critical examination of enduring and recent scholarship on popular Chinese religion, ethnography, and modernity. Designed for graduate students preparing for general examinations or research in Chinese religion. Open to others with permission of the instructor.

title: The Dreamkeepers: Education Reform and the Urban Teaching Experience
descrip: Please see website

title: The Study of Comparative Politics
descrip: A general introduction to the field of comparative politics, with an emphasis on principal theoretical approaches and major problems and theories.

title: Thinking Translation: Language Transfer and Cultural Communication
reviews:
A nice survey course on translation theory.
Definitely a class to consider if you're interested in questions surrounding translation. Keep in mind though that you don't do any personal translations in the class.
Definitely take it if interested in looking at translation in a multidimensional way.
Do listen, it's fascinating
Don't be afraid to ask questions during lecture in addition to contributing during precept.

I would definitely encourage anyone interested in language and intercultural studies to take this class.  It was a great introduction to translation studies, so it was definitely accessible to students in any field.
If you are even a little interested in translation, you should definitely take the course.
OK. Good 5th class. Minimal workload, and the guest lecturers are great. Material itself is not very interesting.
Take it if you have an extra class and enjoy theoretical discussions.

Take it if you're looking for a general survey course in TRA, or if you're interested in the certificate. Be ware though, the course does not go very deeply into any of the topics it touches upon so if you want to learn more about anything in translation in general, you're better off looking for courses tailored to your interests. 

Also remember to attend precepts and lectures. They compose a ridiculous portion of your grade.

Take it!! Very interesting. Not just translation theory, but other cool things like film translation, translation and art, translation in wild places like Papua New Guinea, etc. Almost every week there was a super interesting (and often renowned) guest lecturer. You can't get better than that.
Take it. It's marvelous
Take this class, especially if you are still an undecided major. It is interesting and will give you a taste of so many different professions.

Take this course!! The guest lecturers are so amazing and you learn so much about all the different ways translation plays an important role in everything from law to science to literature. Not an "easy" course but not killer hard either.

This is a really interesting class to take if you are interested in a general overview of different topics within translation. There is a weekly online Blackboard post, a take-home midterm, and a final paper. Sheera is a great precept leader and is really nice and funny.
descrip: What is translation? What is a language? So essential and widespread is translation today that it has become a central analytic term for the contact of cultures, and a paradigm for studying many different aspects of our multilingual world. This course will consider translation as it appeared in the past, but especially as it constructs everyday life in the contemporary world. It will look at issues of anthropology, artificial intelligence, diplomacy, film, law and literature that involve interlingual and intercultural communication. Students should acquire an understanding of the problems and practices of modern translation.

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
reviews: Definitely take it!
Learn about the projects and take this course if one is of particular interest to you.
Take it

This is a really cool class that lets you work and contribute to a multi-semester project! I think it's a great way for non-engineers to contribute. The classes all are pretty informal, and the people are really amazing.
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

title: Roman Literature: Selected Author or Authors - Ovid's Metamorphoses
reviews: Definitely take this if you're interested in Latin
Do your best to keep on top of the workload: translation AND reading.  It'll make class discussion very rewarding.

Great class! The Metamorphoses is a wonderful text, and the class is a good mixture of translation and discussion. The only thing that was troubling for me was that the discussions can sometimes be a bit esoteric and hard to follow.
Lots of work, but definitely worth it!

Ovid is probably one of the most fun authors to read. This course had a significant amount of reading more week, but that's to be expected for a 300 level Latin class. Feldherr is great. Definitely take it if you like poetry.

Professor Feldherr is wonderful, but he also has very high standards for coursework. This stems from the passion with which he approaches Latin, and Ovid in particular. Thus, the course is particularly rewarding for those who have several hours a week to focus on fine-tuning translation, and the quizzes are important too. Make sure to meet with the professors before you turn in papers for the class! All in all, a fantastic course.
TAKE IT. Feldherr   Ovid = best Latin class.
Take it!

This course will help you to understand Roman myth and culture on a much deeper level. Professor Feldherr's comments about the text are challenging and insightful, and will surely help you in other classes by being able to associate events and myths and to draw appropriate references to other aspects in literature, both ancient and more modern. I loved this course!  10/10
prereqs: LAT 108 or an equivalent Latin placement..
descrip: Extensive selections of Ovid's epic about change will be read in Latin and the entire poem in English. In addition we will explore recent scholarship that has itself transformed our perceptions of the place of Ovid's work in the history of Latin Literature and sample the rich tradition of imitating, adapting, and translating Ovid, with a particular emphasis on modern and contemporary versions.

title: Landmarks of European Identity
reviews: Come with things you're prepared to say.
Think about possible discussion points before class, and if possible read the material more than once.
This class is only interesting if you do the readings.

This is one of the best courses you will ever encounter at Princeton! I strongly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in questions of Europe, national identity, and the relationship between arts and politics. The aesthetics of the class are superbe, gathering the great contemporary thinkers of European theory throughout the semester.
descrip: This course gives a broad and inter-disciplinary perspective on some of the very diverse cultural and historical roots of European identity. It examines contemporary debates over contested identity in the light of long historical trajectories in which identities were continually defined and reshaped. It is conceived as an introduction to many of the courses in Princeton dealing with European issues. The landmarks include, but are not restricted to, written texts. They include Machiavelli, Montesquieu, Marx and J.S. Mill, but also Fra Angelico, Beethoven and Thomas Mann. One three-hour seminar.

title: Plasma Waves and Instabilities
reviews: Keep up with the lectures, readings and assignments.
Keep up with the reading and start working on problems early. It is good to read from multiple sources.
Make a strong commitment to keeping up with the course. An initially small deficit in understanding or preparation will grow wildly due to the pace of this course.
This class is worth taking.
spend enough time on the problem sets.
descrip: Wave phenomena in a cold magnetized plasma, including resonances, cut-offs, mode conversion, drift waves, weak collisions, energy transport and finite temperature effects over a wide range of frequencies. Development of the full hot plasma model for waves in locally homogeneous plasmas, including collisionless damping mechanisms such as Landau, cyclotron and TTMP damping, velocity-space instabilities and Nyquist analysis, hot plasma mode conversion, and Bernstein waves. Applications to plasma diagnostics, radiofrequency plasma heating and noninductive current drive, and magnetospheric propagation.

title: Dare to Know: The Age of Enlightenment
reviews: Great course! Especially if you are interested in the 18th century.
Make sure you're comfortable reading and writing in French, and be prepared for some awesome discussions.
Prof. Lee is wonderful, you will learn a lot from her.
Yes, absolutely take a class by Professor Natasha Lee, even if not this particular one. She is very stimulating, the workload is not heavy at all and the themes and ideas are very interestng.
the professor is not the best at replying to emails but the topic is pretty amazing.
descrip: What is the Enlightenment? By the end of the eighteenth century, Europeans had traveled the entire globe and the French Revolution had transformed the face of France. This course investigates the era of change and radical thought that precipitated this momentous event. Through novels, fiction, and contemporary theory and film, we'll explore the hopes and shortcomings of the intellectual movement known as Les Lumieres. Topics include A Dream of Democracy, Globalizing the Enlightenment, Debates on Race and Sexuality, and Courtly Passions. Texts by Montesquieu, Rousseau, Diderot, Wollestonecraft, and others.

title: Quantitative Analysis and Politics
reviews: Although this class is very interesting, be prepared to do a lot of work! It will be worth it, but if you do not have at least a slight interest in the material and data analysis then do not take this class. Make sure to have a head start on all your problem sets and be sure to study thoroughly for quizzes. Also work in groups when working with R.
Challenging course, especially if you have never coded before. Start problem sets on time, go to lectures/precepts, and go to McGraw study hall.
Go to office hours, focus, and start on handouts and problem sets as early as possible! Also, definitely use study halls.
Great course, but I hesitate to recommend it unconditionally because it was really Professor Ratkovic and the amazing preceptors who made the course.

I highly recommend this course, particularly if you have previously taken COS 126. It has its difficult parts, and it has some long hours, but it presents some good material and is very useful if you have any interest in conducting studies of you own for a JP or senior Thesis.

I loved learning R, but I wish grading had been more transparent and wish that the quality of the preceptors was more even; Mary Kroeger, for example, was awesome! My preceptor, on the other hand, was sort of dismissive and did not lead her precept sessions well.
I recommend only for students who have any sort of social research interest. Also, would be good for those students to do a bit of work in R before beginning - makes life easier.
IF you are good at math the stats is a breeze. The programming is difficult for a beginner, but perhaps easy for anyone with experience. Textbooks not necessary

If you have a COS126 background, this will be pretty smooth. If not, do your best to understand every line of sample code in the handouts and clarify questions early so you won't be thrown off guard by the problem sets. only a very tiny bit of math is involved in this class, and very little statistical theory (as the class is aimed at learning R and applying concepts practically to social science research), so know what you want out of a stats class before deciding. I personally really enjoyed the class and think I learned a lot that I can use in the future; Prof Ratkovic is very kind and receptive to feedback.
If you need a stats requirement, take this course. Be engaged and you will do well. Your work actually correlates to your grade in this class.
If you need to take it, don't hesiitate, it's a good class. However, it's not such a thrilling course that you must have the experience of taking it if it's not relevant to your major or other goals.

Is it hard? yes. But you will learn very useful things that you can apply in your JP and Thesis, and as long as you keep up with lecture/the handouts you should be fine. They give you all the tools you need to do well in the class.
It gives you good skills if you commit to not fall behind or be hesitant about asking for help.

It's not a walk in the park, but it's nowhere near as hard as people make it out to be. Still wonder about the effect of R coding on my knowledge of statistics - should we have focused on probability more and code less?

Keep up with the material, and do not be afraid to ask for help from preceptors, Prof. Ratkovic, or McGraw Study Hall tutors. R can be tricky to figure out, so make sure to start early on Problem Sets
Lots of time, but well worth it
Only take this course if you have an interest in politics and statistics. The problem sets are too hard and time consuming if you're just looking to get a stats class out of the way.
Prepare for many sleepless nights, McGraw devoted evenings, and mental breakdowns BUT if you make it through, it feels like a billion bucks.
Spend time learning R yourself, and ask the instructors to help clarify expectations on short-answer questions that require explanations.
Start everything early. Come time around problem set, this might take up a lot of time. Otherwise it is a reasonable work load with a lot of educational reward.
Take it if you want to be as entertained as you can be by statistics and if you are interested in gaining the skill of learning R.
Take it!
Take it! Don't procrastinate
Take it! Go to all the lectures/precepts as they are helpful. Definitely get help from the prof (if it's Ratkovic again) or preceptor (esp Lauren M) for problem sets.
Take it, because it is rewarding, but prepare for a lot of individual work to come.

Take it. This is an incredible course and Professor Ratkovic is remarkable. The readings aren't even necessary because Professor Ratkovic does such a good job covering the material in class. He's hilarious, incredibly intelligent, open to questions, and I could go on about him. I knew nothing about R going in and came out with significant knowledge and confidence in my coding skills. 
TAKE IT!!!!!

Take this course for WWS prerequisite. It is very difficult, but you will learn a lot and come out with some skills in R and stats. Don't be afraid to go to office hours, they will help you and you'll get to know some cool statisticians. Go to lecture because its much more helpful than the textbook. It's a good class and i'd highly recommend.
Take this course if you'd like an interesting statistics course or if you'd like to learn R

Take this course with friends who you can work on the problem sets and study with. It's not so bad if you work together! But do not take this course unless you have to. Although it's probably helpful to get some exposure to R for your independent work
Take this course!  The workload was not bad, but if you are coming in with no COS/coding background at all, you might have some trouble with R.  Otherwise, material was pretty straightforward.

Take this if you need a stats class.  You will learn R and focus on analyzing the data in political papers. The preceptors are good for the most part (they get that stats can be a challenge for social science people) and Professor Ratkovic is fairly entertaining and approachable.

This class is difficult but ultimately rewarding if you put in the work. Don't necessarily do the readings, but go to every lecture, precept and review session provided. Work with others on problem sets, rely on McGraw, and understand that there's a huge learning curve with using R at the beginning of the course.
This class isn't great, don't take it unless you have to. They never really teach you how to use R, so the problem sets are very confusing.

This course is a very good introduction to statistical concepts and using R in statistics. It is also very challenging, and while it does not require computer programming experience, those who had experience were better off in the course than others. You should take it if you don't have a very busy schedule because this course takes a lot of time and effort, but it's very worth it.
This course requires lots of time. It took me days to complete the problem sets. You really just need to go to McGraw and office hours to hustle through it.

This course sometimes gets a bad rep for being difficult but I honestly didn't think it was that bad and I enjoyed it so much more than I expected I would. Statistics is by far the most useful math I have learned in my life so far and has a lot of real-world applications. This class connects the math to recent and relevant political events very well. Professor Ratkovic is an interesting and amusing lecturer and tends to teach concepts through examples, which I found really helpful.
This is a difficult course, but you do learn a lot of skills you can apply to the real world and general research. Take it.
This is a great course, and its coding portion will be very helpful to analyze data for JPs or Senior Theses.
This is an interesting course for students studying political issues.
This is my favorite course so far and easy if you put the time in.
This is useful knowledge to have for any career related to politics.
Very difficult course, but very informative and helpful for independent work
Very interesting, challenging, time consuming but worth it.
i would recommend this course if you're interested in stats, but it is difficult and there's definitely a learning curve
not super exciting or stimulating material but extremely helpful in learning how to work with R for JP's and Thesis work
really great class. Learn about R which is fun.
required a lot of R knowledge
prereqs: High school algebra. Familiarity with elementary probability theory and computer programming is useful, but not required..
descrip: Which countries are more likely to erupt in civil conflict? Does government aid increase support for incumbent politicians? Who is more likely to win the next election? Assessing questions like these, and others beyond political science, requires an understanding of statistical inference. This course provides the foundation necessary to conduct statistical analyses in the social sciences. The course will focus on statistical concepts, including probability, causality, estimation, and inference. Combining programming, statistical theory, and real world datasets, this course will introduce students to the basic principles of data analysis.

title: Jewish American Literature: Where Are You Going, Where Have You Been?
descrip: Please see website

title: Modern Political Theory
reviews: A great introduction to the thought of essential political theorists.
Amazing class, beitz for prez
Attend all the lectures!

Beitz is an excellent lecturer -- clear and engaging. Don't miss out on these lectures, and pay attention! Try to keep up with the reading, but make sure to take thorough lecture notes above all. A great PDF class for general interest, and a crucial and informative class for any philosophy or politics major.
Definitely take this class if you are interested in the material and have time to do the readings.
Do not take this class along with any other reading classes! Apart from that, very good class for anyone interested in Politics
Do the readings and attend all lectures. It is worth it.
Find a more interesting class.
I took this class because of the reading list and I wasn't disappointed. Take it!

I went into the class without any expectations, given I had no background in politics. Hands down, this is one of the most amazing courses I have ever taken, and Professor Beitz is one of the greatest professors. Take this class!
I would definitely recommend this course

I would take this course if you are very interested in political philosophy of Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, Mill, and Rawls. If you are not that interested in political philosophy or just trying to fill a requirement you might not find the course that interesting.
I'd advise them to take it. The material in this course is fundamental to the way we live and offers a lot of opportunities to think deeply about how society is structured.
If you are interested in politics or political theory, I would recommend taking this course. It is a fairly straight-forward political theory class, and you should not expect any curveballs.
It is what it says it is. Not a huge amount of work.
Make appointments with your preceptor to talk about your papers and anything you're confused about.
Organize your schedule in order to provide ample time for reading!
Take it. This course is a great opportunity to read and really understand some of the most influential political theorists of the last several centuries. Plus it's not so hard.
Take the class if you are interested and love reading

Take the course especially if you're interested in political theory. Professor Beitz is AMAZING and a fantastic lecturer. He is really genuinely kind, truly an intellect, sparks your curiosity, and even provides handouts in every class. He turns a boring old political theorist into an intriguing puzzle that you'll want to find out more about. Really amazing.
This class is great

This is a good opportunity to think about great political philosophers in interesting ways--Prof Beitz does a good job of presenting things in unorthodox ways. That said, I didn't go to too many lectures, because that really wasn't so necessary to success in the class. Prof. Beitz's voice is really nice and it put me to sleep sometimes. He's very smart though and the subject is critical. Recommended for pol/philosophy types.
there are better politics courses in the department.
this is one where you have to do the readings AND come to lectures, so be committed to taking the course if you're going to take it
descrip: A study and critique of the philosophical foundations of modern democratic liberalism based on a close reading and analysis of texts by theorists such as Hobbes, Locke, Hume, Rousseau, Mill, Marx and Rawls.

title: Special Topics in the History of Philosophy - Nietzsche
descrip: A general approach to Nietzsche's philosophy, with emphasis on his views on human action, the nature of morality, the significance of art, and the good life.

title: Mass, Momentum, and Energy Transport
reviews: Attend precepts, read the lecture notes and text book chapters ideally while doing the corresponding psets but at least before the exams.
Don't take it unless absolutely necessary
I would never take this class willingly.
It is definitely a hard class.

It seemed like everyone dreaded transport, but honestly, I think this is the best departmental I've taken thus far. It is extremely well taught and if you put in enough effort, it really isn't that bad.
It's a required course for CBE majors, so there's not much of a choice there.
It's not as tough as everyone makes it out to be! The material is really interesting.
Keep up with notes, practice a lot
Make sure to go in and get help if you need it.
Most people won't take it unless they are CBE but if you want to explore a CBE class this is the one!
My favorite CBE class so far. Brynildsen is an amazing professor. Definitely a harder CBE class...requires a lot of math. But it's very doable.
One of my favorite CBE courses; that being said, it seems to be either you love it or you hate it.
Only take this as a CBE student. It is required and you'll just need to get through it.

People say that this class is harder than sep. They lie. If you go to lecture, read the notes Brynildsen gives you, and do the problem sets you will be fine. Brynildsen is the man. He actually seems to enjoy teaching the class. The topic is much more interesting than 245 and 250. Maybe even thermo.
Read the lecture notes
Read the lecture notes ahead of time so that you can learn everything during class and answer the questions when you get called on.
Skip lectures and read notes if you want. You can. Read them slow though, and make sure you understand.
Stay on top of the work
The course is interesting, but the problem sets are long.
The material is useful but I am not sure whether you should take it from a CBE department, though I've heard bad things about the material from other departments too.
This is a required course, but it is very informative and enjoyable as long as you keep up with the lectures.
When all the material comes together realize how cool the class really is. Work hard and appreciate the material
Work in groups.
You have no choice but it's amazing!
prereqs: CBE 245, CBE 246, and MAE 305. MAE 305 or MAT 427 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: Course will survey modeling and solution methods for the transport of fluids, heat and chemical species in response to differences in pressure, temperature and concentration. Both steady state and transient behavior will be examined.Topics include fluid statics; conservation equations for mass, momentum and energy; dimensional analysis; viscous flow at high and low Reynolds number; thermal conduction; convective heat and mass transfer, correlations; diffusion and interphase mass transfer. Working knowledge of calculus, linear algebra and ordinary differential equations is assumed.

title: Engineering in the Modern World
reviews: Do the readings.
Good STL to take - decent time commitment for labs.
Great STL for non science people

I advise you to take this course with labs only if you are willing to put in your share- you will leave feeling bad about yourself if you put a classmate in the position of either working their butt off more than they need to or not doing as well as they can because you don't pull your weight. Don't be that kid.

I wanted to take an STL that would actually teach me something even if I didn't pursue further courses in the department. This class did that. I sincerely feel like I understand American history better and in a way that is more relevant to my current experience of America; the industrialization of this country has giant impacts on the way we are both a high-functioning and extremely dysfunctional when it comes to our increasingly urban culture. Lectures were fine - they vacillated between rambling and a bunch of information all at once, which sometimes became frustrating. Overall though I think he did a very good job of giving information that wasn't really contained by the slides so that I felt like coming to lecture was not a waste of time. Labs were interesting - definitely brought the material to me in a way I could understand/visualize better which I appreciated. The radio/resonance section was especially fascinating to see in action. If you need an STL that's not a waste of your time but isn't, like, Gen Chem - take this.
I would recommend this course for humanities majors who need a laboratory science requirement, and for science majors who need a humanities requirement.
If you are just interested in fulfilling a distribution requirement, there are better classes. The class does not feel like it was well put together.
If you are not PDFing it, think twice. It is a lot of information and many of your peers and lab partners will be pdfing it and won't be as much into the class as you.
If you need an STL, take this course
It is a good, useful stl to get under your belt if you need one

It is what it is:  a PDF-friendly distribution requirement.  If you show up to a few of the lectures and prepare for the exams, you should get your P.  Labs were painful but often didn't last the whole period.
Pay attention to lecture
Should be taken if not particularly strong in math/science. Should be a little interested in history.
Stay on top of the work and you'll do fine.
Take it for your STL. It is interesting. Not as easy as other STL's but if you put in a couple of hours a week, you can definitely get an A.
Take structures in engineering (bridges) instead. Don't be fooled, this isn't the actual bridges

Take the course! Lots of good material and definitely not too difficult. Make sure you find good lab partners who will contribute if you do the labs, or else your two other partners will do nothing and you'll be stuck writing 17-page lab reports by yourself every other week.
This is a good course for non-engineers to learn some highly applicable engineering concepts and have fun while doing so.
actually DO the readings -- it'll be helpful later on for midterm and final. and make like short outlines of the readings to!
very easy to PDF
descrip: Lectures and readings focus on bridges, railroads, power plants, steamboats, telegraph, highways, automobiles, aircraft, computers, and the microchip. We study some of the most important engineering innovations since the Industrial Revolution. The laboratory centers on technical analysis that is the foundation for design of these major innovations. The experiments are modeled after those carried out by the innovators themselves, whose ideas are explored in the light of the social environment within which they worked.

title: Seminar in American Politics - Presidential Power: Strategies of Governance
reviews: A pretty chill class that leaves you with a good understanding of the Presidency.
Great course.
I strongly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in American Politics and the office of the President.

It's a mediocre class and mostly explores "under what circumstances do presidents do things" rather than "how should presidents do things." Prompts are very vague, and because all assignments were due on Dean's Date (Cameron said he was too busy to grade so we might as well turn them in late), I had no clue how well I was doing in the class. I got no feedback whatsoever from Cameron during the semester. He treats the seminar as a lecture. He talks for the first half, and someone gives a case study in the second. Sometimes his lectures are good, and sometimes they are disorganized and all over the place. The material ranges from very interesting to very dry. I don't feel like I learned that much, and I don't feel like Cameron put much effort into teaching the class. Slides were often half-finished or taken from his other courses, and the final exam prompt was literally copy-pasted from the syllabus. The workload is pretty light though, and you can definitely get by without doing all the readings thoroughly. Only take this if your are VERY interested in presidents. Some material is quite fascinating, and Cameron's a decent professor if he decides to put effort into teaching.

Pretty interesting subject matter, and good readings. The assignments are relatively easy and enjoyable to complete, and you have a fair degree of autonomy in choosing what to write about/present on. I wish the seminars had been a little more engaging though.
Take it!!! The prof is super nice and the was the work is distributed over the semester makes it a really great course
prereqs: Completion of the Politics analytical requirement is helpful but not required..
descrip: This course examines how presidents use power, focusing on the strategic context of the presidency and the tools of presidential governance: what they are, how they work, how to use them effectively, and with what consequences. The emphasis is on the "nuts and bolts" of what modern presidents do. Students conduct case studies of presidential power in action.

title: Studies in the American Novel - Modernism and Retro-Realism
descrip: This course examines twentieth-century fiction of the past half-century, to explore the swerve among forms of modernist and post-modernist experimentation, back to a more self-contained "retro-realism." One question we address is what failed in modernism? Did it simply hit a limit, or are there new narrative adventures to pursue?

title: Introduction to Nonlinear Dynamics
reviews: Definitely take it if you're considering it. It's a great course where you'll learn really cool material that's broadly applicable and you can put as much time as you want into it.

Definitely take this class if you enjoy math even slightly! Professor Kevrekidis is an amazing professor and he really cares about the material and teaching it well. The class was not stressful as it only had 4 homeworks and a Dean's Date project. The project involved choosing a topic and exploring it with the tools you learn in the class. It was surprisingly fun. TLDR: a wonderful, low-stress class where you'll learn a lot of cool math.
Excellent course.

Nonlinear dynamics is useful to know, since there are many applications in physics, chem, and bio. The work load for this class is mainly problems sets (approx. every other week) and a final project (topic of your choice). I learned a lot from each problem set, partly because the preceptor was extremely helpful and made sure I understood the concepts. Professor Kevrekidis is a kind professor and brings his humor to lecture.

Professor Kevrekidis is one of the most understandable and clear lecturers I have seen at Princeton. There is not much homework and one fun project at the end of the semester. Great course that you should take if you are interested in learning the basics of how to analyze nonlinear dynamical systems but don't want a giant time commitment.
Read the book - it helps a lot.
Take it! You don't need to be a math god to understand what is going on and you can tailor the project to suit you.  Not too much work during the year, just a big deans date project.

Take this class with Yannis! He's a very good professor. He may be imprecise at times, but that's because he values explaining his intuition to you. Just ask a question if you're not sure what he means.
Take this if you are good at differential equations and liked Professor Stone. It's a similar vibe.
prereqs: Knowledge of linear algebra (MAT 204) and ordinary differential equations (MAE 305 or MAT 427). Some computing experience is required for this course..
descrip: An introduction to the phenomenology of nonlinear dynamic behavior with emphasis on models of actual physical, chemical, and biological systems, involving an interdisciplinary approach to ideas from mathematics, computing, and modeling. The common features of the development of chaotic behavior in both mathematical models and experimental studies are stressed, and the use of modern data-mining tools to analyze dynamic data will be explored.

title: Advanced Algorithm Design
reviews: Difficult
Good
If you are interested in statistics, randomized algorithms, or any theoretically rigorous ways to handle large, high dimensional data, then take this course. You will learn a lot.
It is an inspiring and hard course for self-motivated students who are interested in theoretical computer science.

It's a really interesting class, and the exposure to modern-day algorithms is great!  You'll really gain great intuition for working with approximation algorithms.  However, the course is very demanding and is definitely among the most time-consuming classes I've taken at Princeton, so be prepared to invest an incredible amount of time.
It's hard...
Make sure you have the recommended background, work with others as often as you can
Requires strong background in theoretical computer science and math
Take this class if you're interesting in the best research in algorithms over the past 25 years. The problem sets are difficult, but you learn a lot.

Take this class if youre confident in your math/algorithms skills. You'll gain a very good survey over an important area in lots of computation today. Be aware that it will help to have a partner on problem sets, and that you  may need to look things up (but this is encouraged). In fact, one of the best skills I got from the class was the ability to find and parse new information quickly from papers and the like (online textbooks)  in order to figure out how to solve problems.
The homeworks in this class were incredibly time consuming and the material was very in depth.
The problem sets were too time-consuming and difficult. There were weekly problem sessions but the TA was not helpful. That being said, I learned a lot from this course.

This course is a lot of work but totally worth it. I came out with a much better understanding of randomized algorithms and linear algebra. Be prepared to do a lot of work, but you have to take this if you like theory.

This course is among the hardest I have taken as a CS undergrad at Princeton.  Each of the 5 problem sets takes on the order of 20 hours, and my group spent an additional 70  hours each our final project in lieu of a final.  Very rewarding course in the end.  Get a problem set group and prepare to buckle down and learn a lot!  I am not the best at theory, but I have taken several theory classes (best to have done more than just 340).  Seriously consider your workload for the semester, as 521 eats time.
This course is extremely difficult, but the material is also pretty interesting.  Only take it if the rest of your classes require fairly little work.

This course requires relatively high background of theory if you don't want to be so struggling. Nevertheless, not like most of the other theory course, this course is very interesting and inspiring. You gonna learn a lot, even related with real application, from this course.
This is a great course but a lot of work.
descrip: Advanced methods of algorithmic design and analysis: data structures, network flows, and linear programming. Solution of linear programs: Karmarkar and Ellipsoid algorithms. Probabilistic techniques. A selection of topics from on-line computation, approximation algorithms for NP-hard problems, number theoretic algorithms, geometric algorithms, and parallel computation.

title: Topics in Postcolonial Literature - Postcolonial Cities
reviews: Definitely take this class if you are interested in politics. Even if you don't think English is your "thing," this class is still great.
For theory buffs. But if you like thinking about how things work, how systems perpetuate, how language is used to describe, how cities are constructed by metal and thought-- then take this course
TAKE THIS or any class with Gikandi really -- he will really challenge you (in a non scary way) to think. He also really cares about his students and respects your opinions a lot!
Take this if you're interested in non-white, non-British English writing.
descrip: Addresses the literature of several cities that have been central in shaping the modern imagination: Bombay, Cairo, Lagos, and Johannesburg. It will explore how the emergence of these global cities has transformed the meaning of urban landscapes and their representation in literature. The course will also examine how migrant writers from Africa and the Caribbean have transformed old cities such as London and New York. How does the city shape the form of writing? How does language itself transform the meaning of the urban experience? How does this literature challenge some of the leading theories on space and modern identity?

title: International Financial History
reviews: Complete the readings and engage fully in the discussions.

Don't be afraid! Financial history as a discipline is often seen--quite unfairly--as number crunching, dead white guyism, a relic of now old-fashioned historiographical schools. Nothing can be further from the truth! And in any event, anyone interested in the history of capitalism NEEDS to take this course, both to understand finance and capital and to be able to more effectively critique a protean field.
Even if you are intimidated by finance/economics, this is a wonderful course. Writing assignments are tailored to your interests within the syllabus.
descrip: The course examines financial innovation and its consequences from the early modern period to present: it examines the evolution of trading practices, bills of exchange, government bonds, equities, banking activity, derivatives markets, securitization. How do these evolve in particular state or national settings, how are the practices regulated, how do they relate to broader processes of economic development and to state formation? What happens as financial instruments are traded across state boundaries, and how does an international financial order evolve? What are the effects of international capital mobility?

title: Human Adaptation
reviews: Ask as many questions as possible during lab.
Be sure to take concise notes.
Definitely take this course to fulfill your STL. While not as easy as some of the other STL courses, it is certainly far more interesting.
Do it if you want
Don't take this course
Great and interesting course if you're looking to fulfill your STL. If you're interesting in the biology of the human body, and the way it has evolved over millions of years, this is for you!
I would recommend the course as a meaningful STL to humanities students.
If you are taking this solely for your STL, be prepared to P/D/F it.  Lecture and lab seem relaxed, but grading is harsh.  Works well as a 5th, P/D/F class.  A minimal work/minimal learning course.
It's all good, but don't buy a lab-book. You don't need it.
Labs are not too hard, lectures are interesting. Good for a humanities-oriented student trying to fulfill a requirement or interested in incorporating some science into their schedule.
Only take this if you are actually fascinated by specific logistics of human anatomy. It's a lot of names that I found difficult to find fascinating.
PDF

Professor Monge has an extraordinary wealth of knowledge, and her interest in the subject matter is contagious -- the lectures are interesting and generally pretty relevant even for those not interested in science. Great STL for people not usually that science-inclined!
Take it if interested in human evolution and if you need a lab (the lab reports are done in class and not later) which was great. However, the lectures weren't always very organized.
Take it if you need a lab requirement or are into anthropology.

Take this course if you are pre-health or simply interested in human adaptation! As long as you attend lectures, understand lab exercises, and stay on top of the readings (some readings can be a bit irrelevant), this course should be fairly easy for you as the workload is very light. Just make sure your answers on exams and labs are very detailed because grading is not easy.
Take this if you dig biology. It's not a super hectic amount of work, and can be interesting.
The course has definitely gone downhill since Prof. Mann left. Give it time, it might bounce back.

The course, despite being a bit scattered (readings, labs, and lectures did not always relate), was interesting. Monge is an engaging lecturer, and Selinsky is an excellent and approachable lab instructor.
The lectures were really important in order to be able to succeed in the class.
The workload is not that large and the lectures actually really cool! I'm a big fan of Monge.
This course is a fun one to take - especially for prospective anthropology majors.
This is a pretty easy way to get your STL especially if you aren't a science person. You don't really need to do all of the readings. Just go to lecture and take good notes.
Very good class, not easy but not a lot of work. Interesting class and the labs tend to be straightforward/fun.
definitely take it if you are interested in the subject matter
take it, it's good, janet is awesome and the content is interesting. assuming the lab grades are okay, you should be able to  do well
descrip: Human adaptation focuses on human anatomy and behavior from an evolutionary perspective. Lectures and weekly laboratory sessions focus on the evolution of the human brain, dentition and skeleton to provide students with a practical understanding of the anatomy and function of the human body and its evolution, as well as some of its biological limitations. No science background is required on the part of the student.

title: Heat Transfer
reviews: Definitely my favorite course from this term; possibly my favorite course at Princeton altogether.

If you are going to be doing anything with heat transfer in your career, I highly recommend this. Professor Nosenchuck is clear in lecture and reasonable with assignments. The material is interesting and useful for those to which it is applicable.

If you have any interest in heat transfer, take this course! It is well taught, rewarding, and interesting. The problem sets are challenging but not too time consuming (~6-8 hours a week) and you will come out of it feeling like you really know useful content that you can apply to the real world.
TAKE IT! Prof. Nosenchuck is a boss and arguably, one of the best classes I have taken here.
Take it!! Instead of fluids!!

Take this class as a junior or even a sophomore if you're an ambitious MAE. It's not going to overload your schedule like some other departmentals would, but it's extremely useful and interesting material. Professor Nosenchuck is great!

Take this course if you're interested in numeric simulation since it provides a good introduction for it. I took both heat transfer and fluid dynamics and I'd probably say that heat transfer is slightly better taught with the added bonus of learning about simulation.
Take this course! Go to the lectures and precepts. Ask questions. Do the textbook readings. Start the problem sets as early as you can.
Take this if you are MAE
Take this instead of fluids if you're only doing ME.
prereqs: MAE 221 and MAE 222, or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course will cover fundamentals of heat transfer and applications to practical problems in energy conversion and conservation, electronics, and biological systems. Emphasis will be on developing a physical and analytical understanding of conductive, convective, and radiative heat transfer, as well as design of heat exchangers and heat transfer systems involving phase change in process and energy applications. Students will develop an ability to apply governing principles and physical intuition to solve multi-mode heat transfer problems.

title: Microeconomic Policy
descrip: oh, dear

title: Design of Reinforced Concrete Structures
reviews: Awesome class.
Challenging but good departmental.

Great course, great prof. Be on time to class. Rich Garlock has high expectations - meet them. At the same time, he's pretty lenient in terms of student work: we didn't do so well on our 2 midterms so he gave us second chances to redeem ourselves (e.g. redo a problem to get some points back, do a retake and he'll average the 2 scores, etc.). He definitely values understanding/learning more than pure grades.
I would suggest that students always come prepared to lecture by reading the relevant chapter in the book beforehand. Also, students should go to office hours.
Pretty good course if you like design.
Prof. Garlock is very helpful and organized.
Really pay attention in lecture (and to whatever Mr. Garlock keeps repeating because that means that its important stuff). Ask lots of questions!
prereqs: CEE 205.
descrip: Materials in reinforced concrete. Flexural analysis and design of beams. Shear and diagonal tension in beams. Short columns. Frames. Serviceability. Bond, anchorage and development length. Slabs. Special topics. Introduction to design of steel structures.

title: Education Policy in the United States
reviews: Contribute to the discussion so you can get the most out of class.

If you're interested in US education at all, take this course! If you want to be a teacher you should definitely take this course. The workload is really reasonable and you learn so much every seminar!
Keep up with readings
Take notes on all the readings as you will need them for the final paper.

This is a very good course if you are interested in learning a lot about different challenges in U.S. education policy and thinking critically about them. Be prepared to do the (manageable) readings and formulate opinions, because you will be asked to weigh in during class discussions.
You;ll learn a lot but the grading is pretty hard.
descrip: This course will consider some of the major issues in education policy, with particular focus on attempts to secure equal educational opportunity. It will include discussions of desegregation and resource equity, education for immigrants and the handicapped, school choice and school reform, ability grouping and preferences in college admission.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Engineering - RF and High-speed Circuits and Systems
reviews: If you do not have enough knowledge about the circuit, then do not take this course

The course is interesting and work load is proper. You might find it is hard to hit all the requirements at your first attempt on the term project, but it is worthy to take some time to do more literature research and to think about potential solution carefully. You will gain a whole view of designing RF circuit after you finish the term project.
prereqs: Basic understanding of semiconductor devices, analog circuits, electromagnetism and Fourier and Laplace analysis..
descrip: The course covers topics related to design of high-frequency and high-speed circuits, both at the transistor and system-level, with emphasis on design of modern RF and wireless communication ICs. The topics covered are basic RF design concepts, modern integrated circuit technologies (such as SiGe and CMOS), fundamental limitations of speed of operation of transistors, high-frequency and wideband amplifiers, low-noise amplifiers, concepts of impedance matching, physics of noise, frequency-translational circuits such as mixers, oscillators and phase noise, frequency-synthesis and phase-locked loops.

title: Photography and the Nation in the Hispanic World
reviews: I would definitely take it, because both the subject and the professor are great.
It gives a good and very interesting history of photography and nationalism, but seminar can be a bit slow and the weekly commentaries are pretty long.
Take this course!
The weekly commentaries are more than you expect because they require lots of research despite being short.
prereqs: At least one 200-level course above SPA 209 or instructor's permission..
descrip: An examination of the ways photography has worked in the construction of the historical, political, social and subjective dimensions of some nations and their citizens in the Hispanic world from the end of the 19th century to our times. Among the issues to be examined are: photographing the national subject; recording history; the foreign gaze; war and propaganda (the Spanish-American war, the Mexican revolution, the Spanish Civil War); the margins of the city; sexuality and abjection.

title: Music of Africa
descrip: Introduction to the vocal and instrumental music of Africa, south of the Sahara. Topics include the place of music in society, the influence of language on musical composition, principles of rhythmic organization, urban popular music, and "art" music as a response to colonialism.

title: Property, Wealth, and Equality
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Method and Logic in Quantitative Biology
reviews: Amazing course. Don't be worried about the fact that it's a 500 level -- it's worth doing and a lot of fun. There's a decent amount of MatLab coding for the psets, but not much else in terms of prerequisites, and the huge variety in people who take it means that there's a lot of avenues to get help if you need it.
Definitely take.
Do not take if you have not taken differential equations, and linear algebra.
Do the readings, be prepared for class. Best way to get the most out of it.
Great course
I would strongly recommend the course for students interested in biology-related research, no matter in what stage of education they are in.
If Ned Wingreen is teaching, the course will be very good, worth your time if you are interested in quantitative biology at all.

If you don't have an extensive math background, you will have to work much harder than those who do to complete the problems sets. I would suggest meeting people who have a stronger math background in the class and working with them to complete the problem sets. Also, go to every office hour/ TA precept-- these were very helpful.
Recommended
Take it!
This course is great for reading classic papers!  Just be sure to double-check what the prof says.  A couple of papers are fringe, so be aware.
Yes, definitely, a must for anyone considering doing quantitative bio-related things in the future
You'll get as much out of this class as you put in.
prereqs: Prior knowledge of calculus (differential equations) and linear algebra..
descrip: Close reading of published papers illustrating the principles, achievements, and difficulties that lie at the interface of theory and experiment in biology. Two important papers, read in advance by all students, will be considered each week; the emphasis will be on discussion with students as opposed to formal lectures. Topics include: cooperativity, robust adaptation, kinetic proofreading, sequence analysis, clustering, phylogenetics, analysis of fluctuations, and maximum likelihood methods. A general tutorial on Matlab and specific tutorials for the four homework assignments will be available.

title: Religion and Critical Thought Workshop
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on current student and faculty research in religion and critical thought, designed primarily for graduate students working on dissertations and general examination essays on the philosophy of religion, religious ethics, and the role of religion in politics. Note: REL 518 (fall) and REL 519 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: Quantitative Principles in Cell and Molecular Biology
reviews: Although it was very specific, I felt that the topics discussed were crucial to developing a strong foundation for biology through basic principles found in the physical sciences. One of the most unique biology courses I have taken, and it may not be for everyone.
Be sure to attend every lecture to get the most out of the class.
Be sure to attend lectures and keep up with readings because most of the information can't be found in the textbook.
Don't get the textbook. Understand the derivations as soon as they appear.
Go to lecture and take good notes!

I definitely recommend this course over MOL/EEB 214 if the student is willing to try something new. While essential AP biology fundamentals are discussed, this is done so quickly so we can apply them to more specific situations. Always attend lectures, though, because what is lectured is often not found in the book, and the PowerPoints are not exactly descriptive in themselves. It really depends on how well you take notes.
I would recommend this class only if you have a strong interest in biology.
I would say this is an excellent course, but I was not particularly interested even though the material was very interesting.
If you like physics, take this over MOL 215. However, be warned: very intelligent people take this class, so the curve will likely be more harsh.
It is a lot of quantitative material which can sometimes be dense, but interesting.

It says quantitative in the course title and it is. However, considering that biology is moving toward computation, I would strongly recommend this course. It's well structured and learning the underlying math and applications of math was really interesting and definitely made biology more interesting than before. Labs are more interesting than MOL 214, but are not as chill. Celeste is also an awesome lecturer.
It's tough. Only do it if you're willing to accept a potential B or being confused more so than others. If you're med school, don't do this.

MOL 215 is a great challenge for students considering advancing their studies in science. It prepares you for higher-level thinking in science as well as the ability to take apart and dissect research papers.
Make sure to do the readings on Blackboard! they really helped me understand some of the concepts!
Offers really nice mathematical insight into the memorization you did in AP bio.

Sometimes this class doesn't feel like a biology class at all. Some days its physics, other chemistry, and there's even some electrical engineering thrown in a the end. Needless to say, the course keeps you on your toes and introduces you to a more analytical perspective on molecular biology, and research sciences in general.
Standard introductory course.
Take it if you have to. If not, don't. Find a good lab partner so you can do labs together. Much more manageable that way.
Take it, it's fun, definitely less need to memorize than MOL 214 and quite interesting

Take this course if you want a biology class that is conceptual and does not involve rote memorization (you will be specifically told that you are not supposed to be memorizing for this course). Also, ask questions and go to office hours if you need it! Office hours are super helpful, and will definitely clarify things that you're confused with.

Take this course, you will not regret it. One of the best courses I've taken, would definitely recommend to anyone interested in MOL and does not like memorizing. Also would recommend to all CBE as this class is super relevant.
There is a lot of math involved, but it is still a very fun course. There isn't a huge emphasis on memorization.

This course is so much fun! Almost no memorization is needed and the material is super cool and cutting edge. I would highly recommend taking this class if you have any interest in modern molecular or cellular biology. (But perhaps not the best class to take if you're premed, the topics are not standard ones.)
This course is very hard.  Very, very difficult.  Really.  You will learn to think about biology in a completely different way.

This was a very good course. I am glad, from what I have heard of the two, that I took this over MOL 215 as there was more of an emphasis on the mechanisms behind the biology. 
I would recommend having a relatively strong math and other science background. A good understanding of chemistry, and a liking of math is helpful. Knowing probability would also help, but you can learn what you need to know from the class. I really liked all three professors. 

I thought the labs were interesting overall, though sometimes tedious. The workload was not terrible, although sometimes the weekly lab reports took quite a few hours. Take the practice tests. For the first few topics, definitely read the textbook (DNA replication, etc.).
YES. Take this over MOL 214 if you're deciding between the two; you won't regret it. It is so much more engaging.
Yes! Its hard but I think it was worth it, especially if you really love biology!
would definitely recommend over 214
prereqs: AP Biology, Physics, Calculus..
descrip: Central concepts and experiments in cellular, molecular, and developmental biology with an emphasis on underlying physical and engineering principles. Topics include important insights into the genetic code; energetics and cellular organization; communication, feeding, and signaling between cells; ideas about feedback loops and cellular organization; problems and solutions in development; and the organization of large cellular systems, such as the nervous and immune systems. Satisfies the requirement for entrance into the Department and the requirement for entrance into medical school.

title: Special Topics in Investment Science - Trading and Risk Management
reviews: Go specially for the intuition
Great course.
I would suggest taking this course if you have an interest in learning about different aspects of finance
It gives an other understanding of the market and is very helpful understanding the products too
It is interesting but lectures are not good.
Recommend to take it
Take the course as a complement to hard courses.
The class is interesting, but you won't learn much.
The class won't be given anymore
The topics covered in class are interesting, but the course is not well-structured.
Very interesting course. Would recommend. Not a lot of material covered however.
Will benefit more from the course if you're well versed with financial terms and concepts already.
Will recommend this course
great
descrip: The course explores the modelling, measuring and managing of financial risk - i.e., differentiating between a good trade and a bad one. Emphasis will be placed on illustrating the modelling needs and strategies on the buy side vs. the sell side. Practical applications will be drawn from all asset classes. Convexity and time scale considerations will be addressed and risk management will be discussed with respect to RV and macro strategies. Coursework will focus on assessing risk/reward and identifying market opportunities. Entropy techniques and discretization issues will also be introduced. Guest speakers: experts from hedge funds and banks.

title: International Economics
descrip: Survey course in international economics for non-specialists. The first half covers microeconomic topics such as trade theory and policy, multilateral trade negotiations and regional economic integration. The second half addresses macroeconomic topics such as current account imbalances, exchange rates, and international financial crises. The course stresses concepts and real-world applications rather than formal models. Prerequisite: 511b and 512b (concurrently).

title: Thermodynamics
reviews: Be prepared for problem sets with inane grading patterns
Do lots of practice problems
Do problems in the book for greater practice.

Do the readings in addition to going to lecture in order to actually learn all of the material expected.  Expect the design project and labs to be only loosely defined and have the requirements change on you.
Don't do this unless necessary.
Go to class and do the readings. Learn how to code in Python, because you'll be using it a lot!

Go to lectures, even if they don't seem helpful at first. Also, don't ignore Dan when he tells you to use CoolProps on the problem sets. If you don't, it will come back and bite you for the Design Project.
I recommend staying up to date with the textbook but not getting too caught up in the specifics.

I think a student would appreciate this class much more as a prospective MAE major and considering it as background context for other engineering courses. My experience was that I found it difficult to get an idea of how to approach problems until the end of the course, so it seems that working problem sets and asking all and any questions in office hours will probably help you the most.

If they're taking this, it's probably for the departmental. I'd say it will probably be a struggle since thermo is hard, but hopefully they will find a way to enjoy it since the lectures and labs are well organized and delivered.
It was interesting

It's a departmental, so if you're in here you're most likely a sophomore MAE who will be intrigued by the material. Be prepared for a lot of work, though. Dan-Dan the Thermo Man is an okay lecturer, and Mike is fantastic.

It's required for MAE, and not many other people take it, but there is material that could be interesting for other majors, especially people with interest in COS, ELE, MSE, CEE, ENE, and ENV. It's not as hard as some people claim, but there are times when it gets tedious or frustrating. Professor Steingart is very attentive to students' needs (usually replies to emails within 10 minutes) and will probably be a bit more organized when he has a few more years of experience teaching the class. Final project was building a gun to shoot a marshmallow with pressure from a vinegar-baking soda reaction. Labs involve a lot of coding in Python, but nothing extremely complex.
Read the book stay on top of homework.
Read the textbook, its very helpful. Understanding concepts and various models are the most important part for exams.
Stay on top of the readings
Take it if you have to!
Take it if you need to otherwise I dont know why you would be taking it...
The advice won't be given to them since I have never received advice from this type of form, so I decline to comment.

The course is difficult but can be done well if you put in the work - definitely reach out to your professor and ask early on if you don't understand since material builds on past material and the pace picks up quickly during the later half of the semester.

The professor is a nice person, but terrible at lecturing. Lectures were unhelpful, and were pretty useless. This is a difficult subject to teach (and learn), but it shouldn't be this difficult. Also, if you are used to conventions from physics and chemistry, leave them outside-I brought them in with me and that was a big mistake--you will just get very confused. I wouldn't recommend taking this class unless you need to.

This class is obviously taught by a first/second year professor, so take that into account.  Things will probably get better in later years.  DO NOT TAKE THIS UNLESS YOU ARE AN ENGINEER.  The material covered here is basically a combination of the week in PHY 103 where you do energy balance and CHM 201 where you use enthalpy and entropy.  Currently, the labs are rather boring with a potentially fun final lab project.  Also, EVERYTHING in the class requires coding in PYTHON.  Just a warning.  You will be learning another language in this class.  However, the work isn't too bad.  Just annoying and time consuming.
You have to take it.
You have to take this if you're MAE so there's really no point in reading what previous students thought about it. Dan's a good professor and will give you an extension whenever you need one.
be prepared to teach yourself a lot of the course material
prereqs: PHY 103 and MAT 201. MAT 201 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: Heat and work in physical systems. Concepts of energy conversion and entropy, primarily from a macroscopic viewpoint. Efficiency of different thermodynamic cycles, with applications to everyday life including both renewable and classical energy sources. In the laboratory, students will carry out experiments in the fields of analog electronics and thermodynamics.

title: Politics of Intimacy, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Acting, Being, Doing, and Making: Introduction to Performance Studies
reviews: Definitely take it--it was refreshing and interesting and I'll take what I've learned here and apply it to the rest of my academic career and beyond.
Fun and the three hours fly by.
Go for it!

I took this class because I knew Professors Wolf and Dolan to be some of the best in the THR Department, as well as literally some of the seminal thinkers/writers of the Performance Studies field. I felt very engaged with their thoughts and most of the thoughts in our readings, but unfortunately I somehow felt relatively disengaged by the actual class a lot of the time. Overall, it was an extremely fruitful and significant intellectual engagement, and I think it has contributed gigantically to both my academic and artistic trajectories. Even if you think Performance Studies has nothing to do with your literary interests, I think a lot of the literature in this class can turn your world upside-down. But something about the reading occasionally felt like slogging; I am aware that other students felt the same way. I think we all ended up agreeing that the class is worthwhile, but perhaps it's not as constantly-engaging as we hoped it'd be.
Jill and Stacy are two of the best professors I've had. I didn't end up loving the material, but I'm glad I got to work with them.

Just be aware when making your schedule that this class is a larger time commitment than a lot of other classes. Definitely take it! Just try not to take too many other intense courses at the same time.
Stacy and Jill are fantastic. The course is definitely work. Don't take it if you want to "hang out."
Take it! And if you're not a theater-y person, go in with an open mind and take risks! It'll pay off.
Take it! And take any class with Profs. Dolan and Wolf!

This class is probably not for everyone. Some might call the issues and readings presented in the class "bullshit". Although I was a convert before the class started, I found the class to be a wonderful wake-up call to the reality of our day-to-day existence in an academic context. Performance is the work of our living, and it's easy to fall in to the scriptocentric culture of academia which places textual literacy in a place superior to embodied literacy.

This has by far been one of my favorite courses at Princeton. It has exceeded so much of my hopes of what a classroom could do and be for me as an artist and an academic.
This is a course that has the potential to be extremely personally relevant for those that feel so inclined to bring their whole selves into the classroom. I highly recommend seeking opportunities to take these personal leaps-- I walked away from my writing assignments with a strong sense of work ethic. Furthermore, doing so really led to a strong sense of class community, which was a pleasant outcome for so many of us!
its intense. be intense
descrip: A hands-on approach to this interdisciplinary field. In addition to key readings in performance theory, we will attend theatre and concerts and sporting events, visit museums, attend community celebrations, observe people's behaviors in restaurants and on the street. We will analyze live performance, adapting techniques applied to written texts to space- and time-based events. We will also practice ethnographic methods to collect stories to adapt for performance and address the role of the participant-observer as a corollary to the scholar-artist, which requires thinking about ethics and the inherent social responsibilities of this work.

title: Twentieth Century Chinese Literature in Translation: Affective Landscapes
reviews: Definitely take if you want the opportunity to read literature that intersects with important historical/national changes in Chinese history. One of the better seminars I've taken here!
Definitely take it.
Take it! Chinese literature is really great. Three hour seminars are long, but I found the conversations in class to be very interesting.
descrip: This course provides an introduction to twentieth century and contemporary Chinese literature, under the theme "Affective Landscapes." We explore the social, political, and gendered meanings of "landscapes," including utopia, dystopia, home, nature, cityscape, and dreamscape. As we trace the development of modern Chinese literature, we will study how the portrayal of landscape reveals literature's changing relationship with the state, the community, and dominant ideology. We begin with early twentieth century writer Lu Xun's vivid depiction of a cannibalistic village and end with contemporary noir thriller and environmentalist works.

title: The 17th Century
reviews: As someone with no previous experience with poetry or the 17th century, I learned a lot and really enjoyed taking full advantage of the liberal arts side of my education.
