Take it, but keep in mind that discussions tend to go on tangents and are heavy with context. Nigel is always very easy to reach (he responds to emails with lightning speed) and enthusiastic, and the class serves as much as an introduction to him as it does to 17th century verse and prose
Take this class! Professor Smith is so wonderful--he is a fantastic professor.
Try to develop a relationship with Professor Smith - he knows so much about the period and can really help nuance your ideas on the readings and literature in general.
descrip: The 17th century remains the definitive period for modern literature: many poets from T.S. Eliot to Paul Muldoon and Susan Stewart takes crucial inspiration from this time. We will explore Donne, Jonson, Herbert, Marvell, Milton and others in the context of the periods volatile intellectual and political currents, but with an emphasis in literary creativity and originality in a number of genre forms.

title: Neuroscience: from molecules to systems to behavior
reviews: Be prepared when given a problem set to have to stop everything else you are doing because you are given little notice for an assignment that takes many, many hours to complete (especially if you are new to Matlab).
I would say be prepared to have no work due and then suddenly a lot of homework all at once for this course. That part was unpredictable. Overall, they would learn a lot though.
It isn't worth getting to stressed out over, but it is an awesome course, and I got more out of it than I think many grad students do out of their coursework!
It was a helpful course.

Take extremely good notes - this is the current overview of the field, and the material you learn cannot be found in any one textbook. Start the homeworks early. 
Best if you have a basic background in molecular and cellular biology.
The optional readings were sometimes very helpful for the course, they're definitely worth at least a skim!
descrip: A survey of modern neuroscience in lecture format combining theoretical and computational/quantitative approaches. Topics include cellular neurophysiology, neuroanatomy, neural circuits and dynamics, neural development and plasticity, sensory systems, genetic model systems, and molecular neuroscience. This is one-half of a double-credit core course required of all Neuroscience Ph.D. students.

title: Modern Solid Mechanics
reviews: Always be prepared before each lecture in case there is a quiz!
Congrats on making it through physics 103 and 104. This stuff is way more interesting
Go to lectures and work on the psets with friends. Most of the people in your class will be in your department anyway, so get to know them.

Great class.  This class is basically an extension of the week in PHY 103 where you cover equilibrium.  The problems can get tedious, but not overwhelmingly difficult.  Would not recommend unless you are a STEM type person.  If so, yeah, go ahead and take it.
Great for MAEs.

I would definitely recommend it if you have an interest in analyzing structures. And if you're taking it because it's required, I'd recommend taking advantage of office hours and going over textbook examples (like, actually reading the textbook).

If they're taking this course, it's probably for a departmental. I'd say it is a great class and you'll learn a lot from it, but be aware that the later psets are not a start-the-night-before-it's-due kind.
If you are MAE you have to take it, but I still strongly recommend.
If you're taking this class, it's probably required. But go to class, and go to precept - they're interesting and helpful.
It's a pretty good course to understand how the structures around you function.
Overall a good MAE course
Professor Haataja is a great professor.  I strongly recommend going into his office hours and asking the TA's for help. Don't bother buying the textbook though. It is entirely useless.
Professor Haataja is awesome!
Read the textbook and go over examples as concepts are learned. Have a deep conceptual understanding of material in additional a practical understanding.
Start many of the problem sets early.
Take advantage of the resources available to you in this course.
Take it for Mikko. He's fantastic - and the material, though difficult, is interesting to boot.
Take it if you need it.
Take the course. Go to office hours.
The advice won't be given to them since I have never received advice from this type of form, so I decline to comment.
This course is interesting and really well taught! Definitely get to know Professor Miko and your TA!
This is a great class. Professor Haataja is a great teacher and does a good job keeping the class engaged.
This is a great course for students interesting in solid structures. The assignments are reasonable and the lectures are great.
Work with classmates to make sure you don't lose any points
Yes!

You're taking this either because A) you're an MAE (congrats!) or B) you're a CEE who couldn't make the 205 precept work or maybe wants to focus more on structural concepts. No matter what boat you're in, don't worry: Mikko is fantastic. He keeps a great classroom tone while lecturing and is very helpful and generous with extensions. Work together to solve the problem sets and understand the concepts and you'll do just fine.
take it
prereqs: MAT 104 and PHY 103.
descrip: Fundamental principles of solid mechanics: equilibrium equations, reactions, internal forces, stress, strain, Hooke's law, torsion, beam bending and deflection, and analysis of stress and deformation in simple structures. Integrates aspects of solid mechanics that have applications to mechanical and aerospace structures (engines and wings), as well as to microelectronic and biomedical devices (thin films and artificial hearts). Topics include stress concentration, fracture, plasticity, and thermal expansion. The course synthesizes descriptive observations, mathematical theories, and engineering consequences.

title: Topics in Early Chinese Art and Archaeology - Historiography of Chinese Bronzes
descrip: The historiography of ancient Chinese bronzes, with particular focus on (a) the interpretation of recent archaeological discoveries, and (b) the application of western art-historical methods to ancient non-western material culture.

title: Zionism:The Intellectual History of Jewish Nationalism
reviews: Definitely. Prof. Gribetz is an amazing professor and is really engaged in students work. He is really nice and the work is fascinating. This seminar changes your perspective on everything.
Do all the readings, and when asked, give your opinion in class. Despite the political nature of the subject, I found the class to be very open and accepting of all different viewpoints.
I would recommend taking this course if the student had prior interest. Professor Gribetz is willing to go out of his way to assist students and is genuinely interested in your success in the class.

This was probably the best course I've taken at Princeton. Extremely interesting material, and Professor Gribetz is always there for you to answer questions or discuss any of the material. Highly recommended.
take it only if you really want to learn about Zionism
descrip: This course explores why, since the late 18th century, Jews and non-Jews alike have asked if the Jews are a nation and why people answer differently, inviting students to think about the origins of nationalism and the relationship between nations and other groups - religions, 'races,' ethnicities, and states. Learn about those who insisted that the Jews are not a separate nation and consider the different motivations for rejecting the nationhood of the Jews. We will examine the varieties of Jewish nationalisms that arose at the end of the 19th century, including Diaspora nationalism, territorialism, and especially Zionism.

title: Japanese Society and Culture
reviews: An interesting survery of Japanese society. Sometimes the readings and facts seem outdated, and the lectures a little scattered, but it's a really easy SA! If you need another class and have an interest in Japan, I say take it!
Definitely take this class even if at first you don't think that you are interested in the subject matter.
Definitely take this course if you have even the smallest interest in Japanese culture.

I would recommend this course, with the knowledge that the readings do need to be read quite closely. It definitely imparts a feeling of Japan and the notion of the structured society which is really interesting.
If you are at all interested in learning about Japan or another culture, I would recommend this class! It is very interesting to learn to see things from another perspective.
If you're interested in the material, take it, not a very difficult course but a lot of reading.
It's fun and a good way to fill a distribution requirement.
Prepare for exams carefully and make sure you know specific dates and facts.
do the readings
descrip: During the decades after World War II, Japan became the world's second largest economy and a highly educated, technologized society. While Americans once regarded Japan as a land of "corporate warriors," today Japan has become known for its popular cultural critiques of environmental destruction and for a gentler variety of capitalism that has weathered economic downturns while preserving a high quality of life for its people. We explore key social issues in Japan today: the contemporary "birth strike," gender and popular culture, civil society, medical ethics, difference and disability, adolescence and education.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Islam and Politics in India and Pakistan
descrip: The course studies the relationship between Islam and politics from two points of view - keeping the Pakistani situation in mind. First, we examine the 'muslim strategies' of political parties, including the Congress and state parties, as well as 'Muslim parties' like the Muslim League in Kerala. Second, we pay attention to forms of Muslim (de)radicalisation outside party politics by focusing on the bifurcation of the Jama'at-e-Islami (which has been prepared to play the democratic game) and SIMI (a Muslim student union).

title: Ecosystems and Global Change
descrip: An introduction to the study of how humans are affecting complex ecological systems at local to global scales. Students will examine nutrient cycling, energy flow, and evolutionary processes, with emphasis on experimental approaches and comparisons between terrestrial, freshwater, and marine ecosystems. Particular attention will be on human influences-climate change, biofuels, biodiversity loss, eutrophication, and acid rain. Lectures cover theoretical elements and examples from the primary literature. The laboratory is organized around local ecosystems in which students conduct independent group research projects.

title: International Development
reviews: After two weeks of class I knew the class would be uneventful - and I was right. Stay away. Politics in Developing Countries with Lieberman is a better option.
I would only recommend this class to those interested in understanding development from an economic and theoretical point of view.
Take it if you are interested in international development. Can give you a lot of ideas about JPs and Senior Thesis.
Take it if you are interested in the subject generally. It is more quantitative than you would initially think.

The math isn't at all difficult, and the underlying subject is obviously fascinating. That said, interesting material gets lost in poor organization and generally bland presentation. Adsera can be frustrating to understand, too. The textbook for the class is great, however, so definitely order it and read the chapters. They're often far more clear than lectures.
descrip: This course will focus on less developed countries and will consider topics such as economic growth and personal well-being; economic inequality and poverty; intra-household resource allocation and gender inequality; fertility and population change, credit markets and microfinance; labor markets and trade policy. The course will tackle these issues both theoretically and empirically.

title: Introduction to Genomics and Computational Molecular Biology
reviews: An interesting class that explores an array of methods for using computational techniques to understand biological processes.
Be prepared to work hard, learn a lot, and have fun. Do not take if you are not interested in this field.
Learn R before taking the class.
Make sure you have at least some coding experience, and by some, I mean actually be somewhat proficient in some language coming in.
Take it only if you need to brush up on the basics of computational genomics, and only audit if you're short on time.
This course, structured as a seminar, offers plenty of resources to learn about modern biology.  Make sure to do the assignments as a group, since the wording can be ambiguous at times.
Try to keep the big picture in mind as you work through the coding problem sets.
descrip: Introduction to basic computational methods used for problems arising in molecular biology. Topics include computational approaches to: sequence similarity and alignment, phylogenic inference, gene recognition, gene expression analysis, structure prediction, and whole- and cross-genome analysis.

title: Chemical Reactor Engineering
reviews: Brush up on calculus and probability before starting the course. Read through the lectures and work the examples out by yourself before class.
Expect inconsistency and distance from the instructor. Be prepared to deal with your own problems. Otherwise the course curriculum itself is helpful and usually interesting.
descrip: Stoichiometry. Reaction kinetics and mechanisms. Types of chemical reactors. Steady-state and dynamic behavior of reactors. Mixing and non-ideal reactors. Porous catalysts. Stability and multiplicity. Multiphase reactors.

title: Microeconomic Theory: A Mathematical Approach
reviews: An uninspiring but useful course on microeconomics. Not too difficult if economics or math are your thing. My complaint is that this course is pretty computational (not hard) but puts little effort into sharpening your economic intuition. I would like a more qualitative understanding of the theory in addition to the rigorous mathematical details.
Be careful of the curves in the exam.
Definitely worth taking. Having never done ECO 300, I realize this advice may seem one-sided, but 310 is certainly doable if you know basic calculus.
Do the problem sets thoroughly, they help with exams
Do your problem sets!!
Don't be intimidated. Do find a good group of people to work on psets with and definitely go to office hours, particularly Pesendorfer's
Don't drop the course even if the first problem set is hard for you.
Don't get behind. It's not an easy course.
Don't take it if you don't have to.
Don't take it unless you either really love math or have to for a requirement.  I did not enjoy it.
Dont take unless necessary.
Find some folks to do the problem sets with and make sure you understand all of the questions before the exams.

For math majors/people in technical disciplines - this is a fairly easy class. It's not too difficult to go through the semester without attending class, glancing at the lecture notes, and doing the hwk (or not - it's not worth very much...). Just do lots of practice exams/questions for studying before exams.
GO TO CLASS he is a good explainer even if lectures arent always thrilling. if you go to class the class is very manageable
Go to all lectures, do the problem sets to the best of your ability and try to find a group that will help you with problem sets!
Go to office hours.
Go to precept and look online for videos explaining problems.
Go to precept.
Go to precepts as they help a lot.
Great curve, but material gets really dry really fast and it just feels tedious going to class
I would avoid it
I would just recommend keeping up with the material, as the course covers a rather large variety of topics.
I would recommend this course if the student is interested in pursuing a certificate in Finance. I found the grading very fair (in fact, rather generous).
I would strongly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in a more mathematical and rigorous approach to economics.
I would tell them to take their time on the psets and start early
I wouldn't take this class if you're not an econ major.
It is a good ECON course.
It is not an interesting class. Granted it isn't a very hard class either. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone because you don't really learn anything interesting. It is dry and not worth the time.

It's a relatively interesting and not too difficult class. If you know how to take a derivative it shouldn't be difficult. Econ majors: don't be afraid of the 'Math approach' in the title, there wasn't too much math in it. Engineer/someone who doesn't like writing papers: it'll be an easy SA for you.
It's alright. The second half is a lot better once you get to game theory. Some of the stuff is pretty interesting, but the lectures are pretty dry. It's not easy but not incredibly hard
It's really tough.

Know the very basics of calculus and how to solve algebraic equations. Force yourself to pay attention in lecture, but don't be mad at yourself if you cannot manage to stay engaged no matter how much effort you put into being focused. Sometimes there are questions on the lecture slides, and I would recommend taking note of the answers when the professor explains them for future review. Definitely attend precept - it will help a lot with homework. Go over past exams to prepare for the midterm and final.
Make sure you have a somewhat strong math background, as it is very quantitatively based; it can get a bit dry at times (technical formulas) but overall is pretty interesting.

Most of the people who take this class are either Math-track Econ or ORFE, so you really have no choice when taking this. It is very math-y and proof-based, so beware. The slides are really comprehensive, and Wolfgang just ends up reading the slides during lecture, so going to lecture is pretty much optional.

Most people take this class out of necessity, but it gives a good understanding of microeconomics for people who prefer a mathematical approach. Exams are hard and problem sets take a good amount of time, but overall it's not an absurd workload.
Necessary for an ORFE or econ major, get a precept early in the week, find a great study group, and make the most out of the answers released to the p-sets and exams.

Not a difficult class at all, especially if you have a mathematical background. The range of levels in the class is huge, so the curve is fairly generous. Pesendorfer is a really chill guy, though lectures aren't really that necessary since he posts up all the notes, and they're pretty self-explanatory when doing the homework.

Only take if you have to. The lectures are dry. The concepts you learn are too abstract to be useful later. I don't think the work is worth it, especially compared to ECO 362 and future classes you take.
Only take it for the certificate or if required
Pay attention if you can, and understand how the math works.
Practice more questions and you will be fine.
Some interesting material is covered. If you're not that interested in finance, the second half in particularly may not be that enjoyable.

Take ECO 300
310 isnt worth it
Take if required.
Take it - it's definitely interesting and it provides a basic yet worthwhile mathematical approach.
Take it because you have to or want to. It's not too hard and is at times interesting.
Take it if Prof. Pesendorfer is teaching it! Find a partner to work with and read the lecture slides!
Take it if you like the subject matter.
Take it if you like to think a bit
Take it if you must - lectures could have been a lot more interesting and the material could have been better taught
Take it if you really like theoretical economics. The math isn't actually that bad if you've taken calculus. Hard part is actually learning the theories and being able to make equations out of them.
Take it, especially if mathematically inclined, easy (SA).
Take the class if you're considering it, but make sure you put in work.
Take with Prof. Pesendolfer! Much more interesting and he's a great lecturer.

The course is mostly taking about first derivatives, so it seemed more calculus than economics, but the game theory stuff is interesting, the second half of the course is more interesting than the first half, the lectures are not too engaging but the lecture slides are fantastic so you can not go to lectures and just learn from them. It is an OK course if you want to take the course just out of interest.
The material is pretty dry and hard to understand at times, so ask questions.
This course is mostly math, which by default makes it more fun and easier than ECO300 if you like math. If you don't, it probably won't be fun, and will just be difficult.
This is a very challenging course, so I would recommend it only to students who are very serious about pursuing a Finance Certificate or Economics major with a math-track.

This is not a well-taught course. Professor Pesendorfer really does not know how to explain things well. It is a shame because the material itself would have been quite interesting in the hands of a different professor. I would recommend against taking it with him unless you have to.
Very mathematical course. Makes microeconomic concepts, which are all pretty basic, very challenging with proofs and calculations. Take if required.

While it may be tempting to skip lectures and just read the lecture notes on BB, it really pays to go to lectures since Professor Pesendorfer really takes the effort to explain and expand upon everything (he doesn't really read from the slides and what you read on the slides is only like 25% of what is being explained in lectures). The psets are really hard and time consuming, but the grading is pretty lenient. Overall, this is a really great class! Pesendorfer is amazing!
Work a lot of problems outside of the class.
don't take it unless you have to
meh
sure
take it
prereqs: ECO 100 and MAT 175 or MAT 201. Not required for concentrators..
descrip: This course presents the economic theory of individual and firm behavior using mathematical tools including calculus. The course will emphasize applications of microeconomic theory to consumer choices, output and production of firms, market interaction and equilibrium.

title: Ethics and Technology: Engineering in the Real World
descrip: This course examines engineering as a profession and the responsibilities of that profession to society. Professional responsibilities of engineers are compared to those of lawyers, doctors, scientists and businessmen. Ethical theories are introduced as frameworks to guide decisions of technology implementation. Simple quantitative decision making concepts, including risk-benefit analysis, are introduced as a method for engineers to make ethically optimal choices.

title: Playing Against Type
descrip: This workshop course for actors, directors and scholars rehearses how to play with and against "type" in performance. The course uses scene- and monologue-study to press upon the limits of the conventions of typecasting. Course participants will experiment with cross-gender and cross-cultural casting; mask improvisation; conceptual casting; and performing across age, size, and ability. Throughout, the course engages relevant scholarly literature assessing the transformational act of taking on a role and uses in-class exercises, presentations and performances to press theory into practice (and vice versa).

title: Techniques and Methods of Social Science
descrip: This seminar has three objectives: 1) to introduce students to a variety of research designs, including survey research, experiments, ethnography, network analysis, historical/comparative methods, and 'big data,' 2) to familiarize students with the strengths and weaknesses of various designs, and 3) to teach students how to write a research proposal, including how to formulate a researchable question, how to motivate the questions, and how to describe an analysis plan.

title: Fourth-Year Modern Chinese I
reviews: Don't stop at 300-level Chinese! 300-level may seem a lackluster because you cover a lot of topics about politics and economics but 400-level is better. You get to read about Chinese literature and relevant societal issues. Not much new grammar is introduced because at this point, you've learned much of the grammar in Chinese. This class helps you refine your Chinese language skills. Zhou laoshi and Yang laoshi are also the sweetest and always make you laugh in class. Strongly recommend!
I would tell them that they should only take this course if they hope to pursue a certificate since it is already a high level course.
If you want to keep up your language skills, it's great. But it's a ton a time and work and requires constant attention.
It's a lot of work, but probably one of the best languages to take at Princeton.

Same old Chinese class pretty much for the beginning, but the second half of the semester introduces interesting works by important Chinese scholars, as well as some interesting short stories and plays, although the vocabulary covered in these is much more shumian.
Take it! The readings are much more interesting than previous years!
Take it.
Take this class!
This is a good course to continue learning Chinese. Yet, if you have been taking this Princeton Chinese for a long time, you may get a bit frustrated.

Try and memorize all of the characters and don't be afraid to ask Questions. Talk in class and be excited about your ability to speak Chinese. Speak loud like you're in a cafe in Sichuan and mahjong is being played on all sides and you have to show the world you can really say the fourth tone and not sound like a complete laowai. Embrace it and don't fret on not knowing how to write a character if you know what it means in spoken Chinese, but do make an effort.
a must take if you're interested in continuing to learn chinese. more diverse material such as small stories, plays, and movies covered, rather than typical excerpts from earlier levels.
prereqs: CHI 303-304 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Reading and discussion of selections from Chinese scholarly journals and newspapers on contemporary Chinese political, economic, and social issues.

title: Introduction to American Politics, Part I: Political Behavior
descrip: Part of a two-course sequence of the core curriculum in American politics. Provides an introductory survey of American political behavior through a sample of major theories and methods in the study of citizens' views and actions regarding politics. Course begins with consideration of classic studies and proceeds to current works.

title: Introductory Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
reviews: A fair amount of work towards the end with projects and such, but if you stick with it you'll be on your way to knowing the language.

Absolutely take this class, especially if Prof. Loveless is teaching it. You WILL learn the language, and you will have a great time with a professor who is fun and enthusiastic. Attending the weekly language tables and game nights is also great fun and practice, although they are not necessary.
Be engaged!
Boa sorte!
Definitely take this if you are interested in learning Portuguese.

For someone who already speaks Spanish, Portuguese is a great choice for adding another language. This course doesn't mess around too much - it really develops your skills fast and does a good job of making you comfortable in Portuguese after only a few months.
I strongly recommend this course because it is stimulating and because you are able to see a significant improvement in understanding this language week by week
I would advise them to practice speaking the language even outside of class, and I would advise to go to all the lecture classes.

If you are interested in Portuguese at all I highly recommend this class and if you speak Spanish and want an interesting fifth class or something new then I also recommend it. Megwen is amazing and its true that the Portuguese department is so much fun and just wants you to learn for the joy of it.
It requires a lot of time but it is a very good class.
It's a great classroom environment and you truly get to learn a new language.
Make sure that you take the homework seriously and review materials every night and review the materials for the next class, otherwise you'll feel significantly underprepared.
Seek out tutors, language tables, and the professor to keep working on your speaking and listening
Take it!
Take it! You'll learn Portuguese and have fun doing it.
Take it.
Take the class if you want to be introduced to Portuguese, but keep in mind that grammar is studied almost entirely outside of the classroom
This class if for Spanish speakers, and I do not think that a student who does not speak spanish well would be able to keep up with the fast pace.
When taking this course, it is very easy to neglect studying the conjugations. Don't neglect those and you will be fine.
already encouraged two of my friends to take this class next semester!
awesome course. take it with Megwen!
prereqs: SPA 107 or instructor's permission..
descrip: Normally open to students already proficient in Spanish, this course uses that knowledge as a basis for the accelerated learning of Portuguese. Emphasis on the concurrent development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills. The two-semester sequence POR 108-109 is designed to provide in only one year of study a command of the language sufficient for travel and research in Brazil and Portugal.

title: Egyptian Colloquial Arabic
reviews: Definitely take this course if you are studying/ have studied Arabic.  This course is so much fun and it will make you laugh a lot, but you will still learn so much in just one semester!  Professor elsayed is amazing- he will always be there to give you additional help and he is very passionate about Arabic.  He will help you learn a lot and improve your speaking skills.  If you want to seriously study Arabic, a course in a dialect is very important--particularly Egyptian as it is the most spoken and popular dialect across the middle east.
I would definitely recommend this course for its applicability to real life situations.
If you have any interest in learning Egyptian, take it
Only take it if Tarek is still teaching it. GO SEE TAREK EACH WEEK. You'll learn mad life lessons and practice your Arabic.
Take it. You won't regret it.

Tarek is the best Arabic professor I have had at Princeton, and in his class helped me to take my speaking from very stilted and uncomfortable to much more natural. He is always available for one-on-one conversations, and has a very keen sense for what is practical to learn for the purposes of colloquial usage of Arabic.
prereqs: A minimum of two years study of Modern Standard Arabic (equivalent to completion of ARA 107) or NES permission..
descrip: An introduction to the spoken dialects of Egypt, particularly of Cairo. Students in this course are assumed to have a functional, working knowledge of classical Arabic, and the course will focus on developing the ability to use conversational language in common, everyday situations.

title: American Literature: 1930-Present
reviews: A good class to take if you like reading!
Attend lecture-- Mitchell will only instate a final exam if lecture attendance is consistently low.

Disclaimer: I'm recommending this course based only on the books and precept - I didn't go to the lectures.  If lecture's your thing then I don't know that I'd recommend this class: I found Professor Mitchell's lectures very difficult both to follow and engage with, which is why I didn't go.  However the books were absolutely fantastic, and precepts (with Jesse) were generally enjoyable.  The papers aren't all that bad since you can write pretty much about whatever you want, and supposedly the final isn't a big deal either.  So, overall, good course, take it if you want to read the books, not for the lectures.
Do all of the readings and attend every lecture!
Do the readings and go to lecture! Prof. Mitchell is awesome.
Do the readings! They're awesome.

Don't take a "great books" course: all you will retain will be a few talking points about a bunch of very different books that you read hastily because you had to read one every week. Also, if you are genuinely interested in literature, don't take a general-interest course like this one because 75% of the class is just trying to get their LA out of the way and does not know what a metaphor is.

For some reason, this class has very high ratings. Mitchell masks lectures which hardly have any content in poetic and rhetorical flair. By and large, lecture amounts to mentioning a theme, pointing out passages vaguely connected by that theme, transitioning without warning to another unrelated theme--hopping from Sparknotes motif to motif without actually talking about any substance. If you are looking for a class with lectures that present a thesis and defend it based on the text, do not take this class. Read these amazing books on your own and talk to your friends over coffee about them.
Get in the professor's precept. He puts so much work into his students, and really inspires you to put equal work in.
Great class
Great course. You get out of it what you put in of course.
Great reading list, good lectures, not too difficult. If you want to fit an English class in to your schedule but 19th cent lit sounds dry, I would go with this course.

I needed another ENG departmental and this fit into my schedule, so at first it was a placeholder. Then when I started asking around, I found that Lee Mitchell is acclaimed by ENG concentrators as one of the best lecturers in the department, so I stuck with it. I am very glad I did. Mitchell has fascinating insights and knows how to present them; I don't think he gave a lecture that I didn't leave chewing on a thought he presented for at least the next couple days. Plus, his method of picking out individual quotes makes a lot of sense for the format of the class and gives an extra push to make sure you go to lecture if only for exam purposes, etc. I was inspired to work harder on my writing for Mitchell than I have been by almost any other professor at this University. He has high standards but knows how to push students toward them in a constructive way. I worked hard for him because he felt I could do better than my first paper and I wanted to prove him right.
I would definitely take this course!
If the reading list appeals to you, I would definitely recommend sitting in on a few lectures.

ONE OF THE BEST ENGLISH CLASSES I'VE EVER TAKEN. Lee Mitchell is an incredibly poetic lecturer who's speaking style opens up your mind. I am not an english major, although I've always had an interest in modernist literature, and this course definitely solidified that. It's a course to take if you want to add some beauty to your life! TAKE IT
Only take it if you can bear with the uninteresting lectures. Fantastic readings.
Only take this class if you plan to read the books and attend lecture.
Plenty of reading if you are going to do it all, but the vast majority of the novels are a pleasure to read.
Professor Mitchell and an excellent reading list combine to make this class a necessity for anyone who enjoys reading.
Professor Mitchell is  a fantastic lecturer and the reading list is excellent?a must take.
Read all the books over the summer, and make sure to get a good preceptor.
Read the books and go to lecture, obviously.

Read the books because they're wonderful. Don't expect to get too much from lectures, even if they're amazing during the first month or two of the course. Mitchell is a lot better with the earlier writers than with the more contemporary stuff. Go for a flashy rather than a well-considered thesis when writing your papers.
TAKE IT
Take any course with Lee Mitchell, the best professor I have encountered at Princeton. An amazingly inspiring speaker, and the reading list is incredible
Take as a primer to the 20th century scene of American literature.
Take it if you love American literature or would love to get an introduction to it. The readings are all wisely chosen, and the preceptors are great.
Take it if you're an English major, or if you want to discuss Lolita, Beloved, Maus, etc. in precept.
Take it!
Take this class to have an excuse to read great literature, but don't expect life-changing insights from the lectures.
Take this course! It was a lot of fun and not a lot of work at all, felt like book club I was getting a grade for

Take this course.  It has been one of my favorites so far and the novels were great.  Professor Mitchell is one of the best lecturers I have ever had and will really open your eyes to everything you read.
Take this course. Do the reading. Go to lecture. Get in Professor Mitchell's precept.
Take this course. Your understanding of 20th-century American art and culture will increase exponentially because of this course.

This class is wonderful- the reading list is incredible. Just make sure you have enough time to focus on writing the papers and clarify with the professor beforehand what he would like from the paper. Go to office hours and discuss your writing style with him before turning the midterm paper in.
This is a fantastic course, as long as one does all of the reading.
This is a great class. If you are at all interested in modern literature, definitely take this class.
This was a good class overall, especially for a distribution requirement, and the books overall were good and fun to read.
descrip: A study of eleven modern American writers over eighty years that emphasizes the transition from modernism to postmodernism to retro-realism.

title: Mathematics in Engineering I
reviews: Attend lectures, complete assignments; precepts are generally pretty helpful
Attend office hours. Make use of the online materials provided, and start your problem sets early.
Come to lecture because it is very helpful.
Course is challenging, but Professor Stone does a great job presenting the material and cares a lot about his students.
Definitely attend lecture and office hours. Professor Stone is an awesome teacher, and is a great resource.

Definitely take this course if if fulfills a necessary math credit (but do it with Professor Stone!!!!) - it is useful, very well taught and Professor Stone brings such passion to his class. However, make sure you have time to commit and take advantage of optional precepts and office hours.
Difficult
Difficult, but if you must take it, do it with Stone.
Do the readings, Go to lecture, Start Problem sets early
Don't be afraid of TA office hours!  They are there to help, and dam they can really help.  Homework is the toughest part of this course, so stay on it!
Don't take it unless you need to it's not an easy course.
Don't take unless required, then take in Spring.

Don't waste money on the textbook - Professor Stone provides notes that are equivalent to the textbook. Take good notes. Go to precept and keep up with the course as it goes along - you will be surprised by how much you will learn.

Due to the difficulty of the course, I would only recommend it if you're an engineer, physics major, etc., but if this course is a requirement or even a math elective for you, I would highly highly recommend it. Professor Stone is probably the best math teacher I have ever had, even in a 150-student lecture hall. Use his 200-page supernotes instead of a textbook, and go to office hours. You'll learn so much, it's an excellent course.
Everyone needs to take this class, and they need to take it with Stone. It is the best class I have taken at Princeton.
Go to Howard Stone's office hours as he is a fascinating professor.
Go to lecture, and don't get behind! It's very hard and often very confusing, but also rewarding, because you learn a lot.
Go to precepts!
Good meat-and-potatoes DiffEq course.
HARD, only take it if you love math and/or need it to graduate.
Hard.
Howard Stone is a great professor and has really engaging lectures.  Don't bother buying the textbooks though. His lecture notes are all the textbook you will need.
Howard Stone was a great instructor. I learned so much from lecture. And his notes online were really helpful
I would definitely recommend taking this class with Professor Stone. This is one of the best classes I have ever take at Princeton.
I would highly, highly recommend taking this class with Prof. Stone.
I would tell them to absolutely take it if they like math, and to take it when Prof Stone is teaching it. Then I would say to not buy a textbook and use the lecture notes.
If you even have a vague interest in differential equations, take this class. It is absolutely amazing, and Professor Stone is a brilliant and fun lecturer.

If you're taking this, it's probably for a departmental. However, as a choice for a higher maths class, I think this one is great as it covers fundamental ideas that spring up in a lot of engineering disciplines and prepares you for PDEs in 306, if you are so inclined. Great for learning applied math.
It is worth taking if you are interested in math.
It's a fun class and you learn how to solve ODEs.

It's a relatively difficult class, but Stone makes it worth it. Great lectures that really help you understand, followed by difficult problem sets-- the type you bond over. You'll struggle and learn a lot, and you definitely won't regret it.
It's really tough, especially the exams, but you'll learn a ton!
It's very challenging and goes fast but it's taught very well and is a rewarding class
Look forward to Prof. Stone's lectures. P-sets are difficult, but collaboration is allowed and always reach out to instructors for help if needed.
Make sure to go to lecture, and review material. Stone's lecture notes are a helpful supplement as well.
Must take class.
Prof. Stone is great! Start problem sets early.
Psets require a lot of calculations, but not that much critical thinking.  I've learned a lot of useful stuff.
Recommended if you're interested in the sciences / engineering and want the mathematical background needed to deal with differential equations.
Start work early, go to office hours if you need to, ask questions in class and become friends with professor Stone!

Stay caught up with the readings, watch the optional video lectures before lectures, attend all the lectures, start on the problem sets early. Do the practice exams TWICE. The second time through will really help solidify the material and develop muscle memory for solving differential equations in an exam scenario.

Stone is a lecturer who knows what he's doing.  The class is straightforward and easy if you pay attention.  Just make sure to watch the online lecture or read the online notes if you miss a class.  For a physics student, it's not too hard to get an A.  Very relevant material for deathmech!

Stone is very good. However, if you're taking this class because of a genuine interest in differential equations and are looking for something a bit more rigorous, I would recommend APC 350 or any of the offerings the Math Department has.
Study/go over problem sets with a group
TAKE IT
TAKE THIS COURSE! It's really great and Professor Stone cares a lot about his students.

TAKE. TAKE TAKE TAKE Diff EQ with Howard Stone. Differential Equations is a blank slate that very easily could be colored ugly, as with other math courses (201, 202) that engineers have to take. Diff is different. Stone is a WIZARD - the man commands the stage with flair and endearing quirks. He truly cares about his students, explains difficult concepts with ease, and crafts equations and concepts into an engaging story. The course is set up for you to succeed - the material is hard, but office hours, piazza, lectures, everything is there to help you through. One of the best lecturers I've had at Princeton, which is ridiculous considering it's a difficult math course. Stone is that good. TAKE THIS COURSE. Do not take it in the spring; take it in the fall with Stone, the ONEEEEE and only.
Take it - make sure it's with Stone though, he's great. Definitely a nice easy upper level maths requirement.
Take it if you're willing to put in the work!
Take it with Howard Stone.
Take it with Professor Stone
Take it with Professor Stone if you can!
Take it with Professor Stone.

Take it! It's fun and a new type of math you probably haven't encountered. Stone is a lot better than the other professor from what I've heard so go for fall. It's very applied so easy to pick up intuitively.
Take it! Stone is awesome and wants to learn everybody's names/majors. Consistent psets and tests.
Take the course if it is taught by Howard Stone. He is an amazing lecturer and person! A lot of work at the beginning but gets better by the end!
Take this course

Take this course with Howard Stone if you can. His lecture are clear and engaging, some of the best I've had at Princeton to date. The problem sets are excellent for helping you learn the material. Work on them with friends and don't do them the night before, because we had a lot of long nights rushing to get them done. Take all the practice exams and be careful about your algebra when you take exams, but the partial grading is very generous. Sit in the front and take lots of notes if you have Professor Stone. Budget enough time and you'll do well and enjoy this course.
Take this course with Professor Stone! Don't take it with anyone else.
Take this course with Professor Stone! Even if you're not BSE it's an awesome class and you'll learn a ton.
Take this course with Professor Stone. He's able to turn what could be very dry material into a pretty interesting and readily applicable class.
Take this course!
The book is unnecessary if the class is taken with Stone. Do attend all lectures.

The course a fair bit of work but it is probably the best course I will ever take at Princeton. It is extremely well organized and the psets are also well designed. Take it with Prof. Stone in the fall though, his passion for the subject will make the course feel completely different. It is harder with him than with the prof. in the spring but it is completely worth the extra effort to take it with him. He is AMAZING! Go to his office hours and read his lecture notes and you will do well
The homework will take a long time, but if you do it all and do it well you should do well on the tests.

The lectures are not only interesting, but also well-taught. Prof. Stone goes through a lot of topics and examples in class, so it's important to pay attention to those. The problem sets can be very time-consuming, so be prepared for that.
This course is difficult but worth it. I highly recommend Professor Stone as a teacher.
This course will take a lot of work - but is also very rewarding. Don't underestimate the amount of time it takes to thoroughly understand material.

This is a very difficult course, but Professor Stone is an amazing lecturer. I wouldn't want anybody else teaching me these concepts for the first time. I've heard that this is generally considered the more difficult semester to take diff eqs, but in my opinion it is worth the difficulty. I wouldn't necessarily recommend this course if it isn't explicitly required by your major, but if it is, I would strongly recommend taking it with Professor Stone.

This is one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. Prof. Stone is clear and super organized, so you knew exactly what to expect. He really cared for the students and is very helpful during office hours. The problem sets could take a long time, but gave you a good understanding of the material and made sure you kept up each week and were a good use of your time. It wasn't just busy work as many math/orf/econ psets could be. The exams were fair. I learned a lot in this class and wish all quantitative courses at Princeton could be this organized and well taught. I heard Prof. Stone is much harder than the other professor, but honestly, you'll learn a lot more and get more out of the class with him.

To anybody (especially an engineer) that needs to fulfill a 300-level Mathematics course, I would highly recommend MAE 305. What it lacks in mathematical rigor, it more than makes up for it in real-world applicability. And Professor Stone is just a wonderful lecturer for the course.
To take it in the fall with Howard Stone because he is an incredibly intelligent, passionate man who will challenge you in an extremely rewarding way.
Understand that this course is a large amount of work, but it is well taught and will give you valuable information as you continue your studies as an engineer.

Unless you need this for a departmental, I would recommend against it.  At this level, the material is simply too much for people outside the field.  For those of you in engineering, the material is presented in a practical context and makes sense to the engineering mind.  This makes it a lot easier to grasp the concepts and it can be somewhat fun when you look at something and see the practical applications of DifEq.  This in not like the MAT classes that only present the material in theoretical and general contexts.
Work on psets in groups. Really master the concepts, then work lots of practice problems.
great course. take it with professor Stone.
take advantage of the TA's and office hours
take dis
take it.
prereqs: MAT 201 or MAT 203 and MAT 202 or MAT 204. Open to freshmen with instructor's permission only..
descrip: A treatment of the theory and applications of ordinary differential equations with an introduction to partial differential equations. The objective is to provide the student with an ability to solve standard problems in this field.

title: History: An Introduction to the Discipline
reviews: A lot of work, but take it for Grafton and for a high-level overview of how historians approach and write different types of history.
Absolutely take this. Professor Grafton is the most amazing person, and I learned so much from this class.
Grafton is god! If you're serious about history, humanities, or social science method, you've got to take this course. It's a Princeton right of passage.
I would tell any student to take this class. I honestly feel that this is how the 1st year junior seminar should be structured, and every history major should take a course like this one.
If you are a serious history student, this course is a must have.
No matter what major you take, this class will help you understand how history is done.
Read early and often, and read with a critical but respectful eye. Grafton makes the class worthwhile.
TAKE IT!! IT'S FANTASTIC.

TAKE THIS CLASS. Grafton is an absolute legend, and for good reason. This course is one of the best I've taken at Princeton, and definitely the best history class. Don't miss the opportunity to take this class - you will not regret taking it!

Take it!  Grafton is delightful, and the other students are some of the most engaged on campus.  Worth it for the discussions alone--and be sure to go to office hours, if only to hang out with Professor Grafton.
Take it! I know it says ?An Introduction? but I would recommend taking this after having taken a few other history courses before: the exposure there will be very helpful in this class
Take it.

This class is the best I've taken at Princeton. Professor Grafton is a phenomenal professor who truly loves teaching. Readings are difficult, but I can honestly say I've grown immensely as a reader and thinker as a result of taking this class. If you're serious about history or want a truly fantastic seminar experience, take this class.

sophomores and juniors should not be intimidated. i say better sooner than rather be exposed to this good stuff. its talked about like its a capstone class intended for seniors but if you allow this exposure early on it will inspire you in cool directions
descrip: This course, designed for seniors and juniors in the History Department but open to others, will offer an introduction to the discipline of history. Through a series of case studies, students will learn how historians frame problems, ranging in scale from the history of the world to the lives of individuals, and in time from millennia to single years; examine the kinds of evidence and argument that historians employ; study the intellectual and literary problems involved in constructing a substantial piece of historical writing; and investigate the relations between history and memory in the late twentieth century.

title: Remembering the Future
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Spanish Language and Culture through Cinema
reviews: An enjoyable course with a relatively low workload.
Be prepared to write a lot and participate in discussion.  The people and participation can make or break the class.  Otherwise, it was one of my favorite classes.
Definitely take it! The movies are interesting and the class is designed in a fun and open environment.
Definitely take it. Professor Villena-Garrido is really fantastic, a fair grader, and willing to help if you reach out for it.
Enjoy!
Francisco is the best! Take any of your spanish classes with him if you can help it
Go for it. It's probably more fun than a usual Spanish class. But its work for sure.
I strongly recommend taking this class. It is not as grammar-oriented as 100 level classes, and you will develop your speaking and compression skills immensely.
I would advise students to pay close attention to the movies and speak a lot in class.
Make sure to stay up to speed on the movies. But definitely take this class!
Make sure to use specific scene analytics with the vocab we studied  when writing the essays.
Participate as much as possible and don't be afraid to speak up.
Pay close attention to the comments that the professor gives you on your work in order to improve your spanish.
Since there isn't much work for the first half of the semester, really spend a lot of time on the Tableros. The workload increases a lot second semester.
Students NEED TO TALK in class. Students staying quite often made class discussions painful. I wish we had all participated more.
TAKE IT

TAKE IT. Very rewarding class and Gorka is supportive and very approachable. Every class was well-structured and we always had a good time. It is a fair amount of work because you have to do a lot of presentations, but it's so worth it.
Take it - really interesting. You will learn a lot about Spanish Cinema and the culture behind it. If you are willing to put in work you should be able to get an A- definitely.
Take it if you like Spanish and like movies
Take it! Even if you haven't studied Spanish in a while, Professor Terreros does an excellent job of catching you up.

Take it!!! I haven't taken Spanish in 4 years and jumped right into this class, and was able to pick up the language again very quickly. It can be a lot of work, especially at the end of the semester, but watching/analyzing movies is really fun
Take it.
Take this course if you have an interest in film and want to improve your Spanish! The films are great, your Spanish will improve, and class is pretty fun.
This course was my favorite class that I took this year and among the best classes I've taken here at Princeton. If you have the chance to take it, absolutely do. You won't regret it.

This is not an easy-breezy class (there is  ~200-400 word response every week, 4 presentations and a few final projects), but it's also not super hard. It is, however, immensely engaging and definitely worth it.
Very structured course. By no means is this a course you can slack off in. Just because it's movies doesn't guarantee a good grade. It does help improve Spanish

Watching films in Spanish is an incredible way to improve your skills, certainly better than the standard sit in a classroom/do worksheets method. Gorka is super fun, one of the best teachers I've had here at Princeton.
prereqs: SPA 107 (with instructor's permission) or SPA 108. Also open to students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or a satisfactory AP/SAT score (AP5/SP SAT ST 760)..
descrip: A course designed to improve speaking abilities while learning about Hispanic cultures and cinema in context. The course aims to provide the students with lexical and grammatical tools to allow them to engage in formal and informal discussion on a variety of topics informed by the films provided. Additionally, there will be several writing exercises throughout the semester that will help students improve their writing abilities. By the end of the course, students should have a better command of all linguistic skills, especially listening comprehension, fluidity and accuracy in their speech.

title: Freud on the Psychological Foundations of the Mind
reviews: Although it may take a little time to get into it, this course is a wonderful survey of Freud's theory of the mind through looking at just his work. The readings are surprisingly approachable and enjoyable, and Prof. Sugarman offers excellent insight into the works after having studied them for many years. I personally feel that my logical thinking skills have been sharpened by this course, and I highly recommend this course to anyone who may have even a passing interest in Freud.
Coming from an engineering student, this class was great!!!
Do your readings and don't be afraid to ask questions.
Good class if you're interested in Freud. Sugarman is not an easy greater. Very little work. The readings are short (like 10 pgs) but require a slow read
Great class!!!
I am not a humanities person but I LOVED this class. Highly recommended for an EC

I would absolutely recommend this course to people who are interested in thinking from a philosophical perspective. However, that being said, many people who are primarily interested in science in my class also seemed to really enjoy it.
Take this course. Sugarman is very inviting, fair, and knows a lot about Freud. You get really up close and personal with his texts and that's about all. Very interesting.
The professor is great.. as long as you do the readings and sustain an interest by asking thoughtful questions the class is a real pleasure
This course will be very frustrating at times but is a worthwhile challenge with a very approachable professor.
descrip: Freud is approached as a systematic thinker dedicated to discovering the basic principles of human mental life. For Freud these basic principles concern what impels human thought and behavior. What moves us to think and act? What is it to think and act? Emphasis is placed on the close study and critical analysis of texts, with particular attention to the underlying structure of the arguments.

title: Science, Technology and Public Policy
descrip: Please see website

title: Responsible Conduct of Research in Chemistry (Half-Term)
descrip: Discussion and evaluation of the role professional researchers play in dealing wtih the reporting of research, responsible authorship, human and animal studies, misconduct and fraud in science, intellectual property, and professional conduct in scientific relationships. Participants are expected to read the materials and cases prior to each meeting. Successful completion is based on regular attendance and active participation in discussion. This half-term course is designed to satisfy federal funding agencies' requirements for training in the ethical practice of scientists. Required for chemistry graduate students/post-docs.

title: Beginning Czech I
descrip: Introductory course designed to teach the basic aspects of Czech grammar, vocabulary, and communication in a variety of situations. The course aims to teach all four language skills: reading, writing, listening comprehension, and speaking. No credit is given for CZE101 unless followed by CZE102.

title: Directed Research II
descrip: This seminar is a continuation of ORF 509. Each student writes a report and presents research results. For doctoral students, the course must be completed one semester prior to taking the general examinations.

title: Artificial Intelligence
reviews: A lot of self teaching will be done.  Work gets harder after the beginning of the semester.  Very useful algorithms will be learned but no fun will be had.  Took this with 3 other COS classes and I had no free time.

After all the negative reviews this class has, I was very skeptical. However, I actually really liked it. I think I learned a lot, and Xiaoyan Li presented the material very clearly. A moderate amount of work for CS department, but having assignments due every week is kind of annoying. The written ones are much harder than programming. Maybe comparable to 226
Avoid like the plague if Dr. Li is teaching it. Interesting material, awful presentation.
Awesome class. Textbook is super useful. Lectures depend heavily on who will teach but they all stick to the same syllabus and homeworks.

Be aware that the lectures move slowly and are fairly dry: this can be both good but also a little of a drag. Assignments take a fair amount of time each week but not unreasonable. Also, although this may change from year to year, the communication from instructors was HORRENDOUS (particularly on Piazza); this may have been made worse by the fact that I don't think any of them were native speakers. When you approach them in person, they are friendly; but as far as helping with assignments, or even just clarifying instructions, their communication was very poor.
Brief ML, mostly agent-based AI techniques.  If you've taken ORF309 and ORF350 (maybe COS424), this class will be very manageable.

Disappointing class. The topic seems very interesting but the class wasn't. A lot of homework, and even with pop quizzes I preferred reading the textbook over lectures. Friends told me not to take this class, and I wish I had listened. Maybe it would be better with Schapire.
Do not take with Xiaoyan.  She it terrible
Don't fret about understanding 100% of the material - R&N is extremely dense and comprehensive, and there is no need for you to understand all of it.
Don't get lulled into a false sense of security with the first couple of weeks. The course gets very challenging very fast.
Don't slack off, and start early. Interesting class to take though, but definitely a good chunk of work.
Don't take this course if Xiaoyan Li is lecturing.

Don't take this course if Xiaoyan is teaching again. You can't skip the largely useless lectures because she randomly gives in class quizzes. However, the textbook and assignments are fantastic. I probably would have even learned more if I just read the textbook instead of going to lectures.
Fair final exam. Maciej was great. The professor made a good effort.

Here is the situation we were placed in right before the final exams
- no comprehensive class notes
- no assignment solutions or feedback (some haven't even been returned yet) 
- no exam solutions
- no review session
- an incomprehensibly dense textbook
- 30min less on the exam, just because the Professor decided so
- 3 assignment deadlines within 3 days of getting back from christmas break not to mention a programming assignment due in 2 hours before the JP deadline

In short, take this class at the risk of your own happiness and sanity because I assure you, no matter how sweet Xiaoyan may seem she is incredibly unresponsive to feedback and even more unsympathetic.

Honestly, its interesting material, but wasn't taught very well. It's kind of a lot of work with alternating written and programming assignments. I'd recommend it if you are interested in AI but plan on learning mostly from the book.

I would highly recommend this course if you're interested in machine learning/AI/Big Data. Otherwise, you'll be frustrated by this course since it requires a lot of time and energy to understand the big picture and to work out the little details.
I would not recommend this course if taught by Professor Li. If you are interested in the topic, I would recommend finding a coursera version or taking the one offered on MIT's open courseware.

I wouldn't take this course with Xiaoyan Li.  Lectures were boring, and people stopped going after the first few.  Some of the assignments were interesting, but for the most part they were more writing than programming focused, without a lot of room for individual thought.  There are many more interesting classes in the department.
If Prof. Xiaoyan is teaching the class, then I would strongly encourage you to wait until another Prof. teaches it.

If you're interested in about learning Artificial Intelligence, take this course - it is a good course. Be aware that the material is fairly mathematical and may take some extra studying if math is not your thing.
Interesting material presented in as dull a way as possible. Quality strongly depends on lecturer.
Interesting topics, but don't take it if it's going to be as poorly instructed as it was this semester. Not worth it.

Interesting topics, programming assignments are well-organized and straightforward, the book's pretty good, and written assignments are annoying but okay. But the lecturer...would not recommend Xiaoyin at all. The class is a lot more fun if you take it with a group of friends ( ?? ?? ??)
Interesting, but Prof. Li wasn't great. if you like probability this is a good course for you
Is very interesting and workload isn't the heaviest (more than 226 but less than 217), take if interested
It depends on who is teaching, but if you are not interested in the material, don't take this class. If you are, then know that that is what will most likely be motivating you
It is worth taking it, but it requires a lot of work.

It's only Professor Li's first time teaching, and while she enjoys teaching the course, a lot of the material is not clearly presented, and the COS-essential Piazza is not well attended to. The assignments are confusing and time consuming. Only take if you're super super interested in the subject matter, or you're in for a world of hurt.
Keep up with the readings.
Lecture isn't really useful (although there are small pop quizzes) if you read the textbook.

Lectures with Li are very hard to follow and uninteresting and make the class seem less interesting than they are. I would recommend this class for the p-sets which are interesting. I hope lectures are improved, both quality of delivery and content.

Like any class, there were some interesting and not-so-interesting parts of AI. Many lectures felt like they were mostly tedious applications of algorithms to toy problems, which wasn't quite what I expected. That said, a lot is covered in the course of the semester, so I could see much of it being applicable to other classes and independent work. In particular, the machine learning section was great.

NEVER EVER EVER TAKE A COURSE WITH PROFESSOR LI, LIKE EVER!!! If I could recommend even more strongly against this course I would. This course has gone more than just downhill since Schapire stopped teaching it; it has driven straight off a cliff. The only saving grace of this class (if there was one) was that the textbook is solid and the assignments were designed by Schapire, and are thus interesting and informative. But that doesn't excuse the fact that lectures were entirely worthless except for the in-class quizzes, which were the only way that Professor Li could get students to come at all. I used to be interested in AI research, but this course all but ruined it for me. Avoid at all costs, at least until a competent professor starts teaching it again.

Nothing special. Exams are a bit memorization-heavy. Due to the structure of the course (not sure how easily this could be amended), it feels like lectures don't add much (the main learning is reading the textbook and doing assignments), which is unfortunate.
One of the worst classes I have taken at Princeton. Lectures are terrible and some course policies are baffling. It's a nice course content wise but everything else is terrible.
Really depends on the instructor, but since the material is good and the assignments won't change, take it when it's convenient for you. Rob Schapire come back!!
Start assignments early.
Take it if you're interested in AI and are a good self-learner.
Take it only if Schapire is teaching, unless you want to have to learn most of the material on your own
Take it with Schapire
Take the course even if schapire is not teaching it anymore. It's a good course.
The assignments and readings (which are essential) are a lot of work, but could be worth it if you're intensely interested in the subject/want to do research in AI
The book is great, the assignments are great, and Professor Li is very friendly and kind.
The course is time consuming but worth the effort

This course is a great introduction to AI and machine learning. The weekly assignments are a lot of work, so you need to manage your time well for this course. But you will get a lot out of the programming assignments, and out of some of the written assignments. Reading the book and going to lectures is a must for this course, and be prepared to do some math.
This course is good.
This is a solid introduction to AI, and I enjoyed most of the work involved. Lecture is not great, but the readings and programming assignments are very productive. Not just for COS majors.
Very interesting subject material. Good book. Not a crazy amount of work.

Wait for better instructors. Very poor teaching was a big turn-off. Preceptors did not respond to my email (even after I sent reminder emails) - in particular, I sent an email the day a HW was assigned and there was still no response even after a reminder email 2 weeks down the line, when the assignment was due.

Grades were artificially lowered; you could follow the assignment spec exactly, nail style and performance, and still have 7/10 as the "starting value" for your grade.

Lectures were difficult to understand (from both the side of comprehension and communication). There wasn't much effort to keep it involved.

Problem sets, assignments, and the readings were good, though, on their own.

Whether or not you should take this course depends immensely on who is teaching it.  Professor Li was hard to understand, and hewed closely to the textbook, so I usually skipped lectures and learned the material on my own.  On the other hand, I've heard that Rob Schapire (when he was still here) was a great lecturer.

I took the course because I wanted to learn the material: search algorithms, logic, Bayesian networks, HMMs, and machine learning are all really cool.  I had cursory knowledge about all of these subjects beforehand, but taking this class forced me to finally sit down, work through problems, and understand the methods on a deep level.  That's what I expected when I signed up for this course, and that's what I got.  

On the other hand, so long as Professor Li is teaching this course, if there's another COS class that you really do want to take, you should probably take that one instead.
Work hard. Your peers will be very smart.
Would take this course if you're interested in machine learning/artificial intelligence. The material is very good.

Xiaoyan Li is a terrible lecturer. She appeared unknowledgeable and unprepared. What she wrote on the blackboard was unintelligible; what she said was obfuscated by a heavy asian accent. The grading was inconsistent, and often misgraded (they would correct in office hours but still). The material is interesting, but if she is leading, AVOID XIAOYAN LI AT ALL COSTS. Princeton deserves better.

Xiaoyan Li is the worst lecturer I've had here. Material is interesting but very hard, and there are more problem sets than any class should have. Great topic, but if avoid any class Li is teaching like the plague or you'll regret it.

You could probably get about the same benefit from going through the programming assignments yourself and reading the textbook. Not super terrible, but there are really better options in the COS department.
You'll learn a lot taking this course.  Xiaoyan Li didn't do much to make it exciting or engaging, but if you're willing to pay attention, you'll get the necessary information.
You'll learn the algorithms, but don't expect to have fun doing so
if xiaoyan is teaching again, I'd look elsewhere
yes
you still want to take this class even if reviews on it are poor
prereqs: COS 226.
descrip: The fundamental principles, algorithms and techniques of modern artificial intelligence research and practice. Likely topics include: problem solving using search, game playing, logical inference, probabilistic reasoning in the presence of uncertainty, hidden Markov models, speech recognition, Markov decision processes, machine learning.

title: Taiko Drumming Workshop: Japanese and North American Perspectives
reviews: Being rhythmically inclined is a big part of the class and be ready for it being more physically demanding than you're expecting. Definitely take if interested!

Definitely take this class!! Watanabe-sensei is just amazing at teaching drumming, and it is such a good workout and powerful too. Hopefully the discussions get up to par with the drumming part, but as of now you don't really need to do a lot of the readings - just do some so you can talk about it in class.
Do it! Worth every second.
Great class if offered. Be ready to move
Great course if you are interested in learning beginner taiko. A whole new way to look at Asian American perspective.
I would definitely recommend this course!
If you are really interested in learning taiko, this is an amazing course!

If you're interested in music and Japan, this is a good course to take. I enjoyed the taiko drumming portion of the class as a musician, and liked the discussions as someone interested in Japanese culture. I learned a lot of about the culture that I might not have learned otherwise, so take it if you're interested in that kind of stuff.
Take this course if you're interested in percussion, but expect to practice outside of class to do well.
This class isn't a blowoff by any means, but it has a fairly low time commitment; take it if you have a very busy semester and need an interesting, low-intensity class.
This course is one of the best I've taken at Princeton. It was a great combination of fun and engaging (learning how to play) and learning about the culture behind taiko.
descrip: This course explores the socio-cultural meanings of taiko (Japanese drum), from its uses in traditional Japanese music (gagaku, kabuki, festival music) through its development as a choreographic ensemble in postwar Japan and a site for Asian-American identity. Students participate in a hands-on workshop, learning techniques and three pieces of traditional modern styles, and in seminars on the history and cultural implications of taiko in the Japanese and Asian-American experience.

title: Water: Keystone for Sustainable Development
descrip: Please see website

title: Literature and Society - The Cognitive Puzzle of Literary Experience
descrip: Recent work in "Literary Darwinism" and cognitive cultural studies has attempted, often clumsily and with limited success, to explain or explain away, the origin and function of literary experience. The clumsiness comes from a rejection of earlier literary-theoretical, philosophical and psychoanalytic insights of considerable and often irreducible subtlety. This interdisciplinary course explores the deep ideas those insights can contribute to the kinds of cognitive and evolutionary approaches to human social experience now being worked out in the fields as varied as philosophical decision theory, behavioral economics, and theory of mind.

title: Workshop in Social Policy
descrip: A course required for and limited to students in the Joint Degree program in Social Policy. Papers drafted in the year-long course WWS 590a,b,c,d must be revised and submitted to the workshop leader by August 20. Papers will be provided to an expert reader outside of the Princeton faculty, who is invited to join the seminar for sessions devoted to each student paper. Each student will present his/her own paper and simultaneously contribute written critiques of one another's papers. By the end of the term, students will be required to submit their papers for publication to a leading journal.

title: Formal Political Analysis II
prereqs: POL 575.
descrip: Further development of the analytical tools used in formal political analysis, with special attention given to the role of information, uncertainty, and dynamics in the design and performance of political institutions. Readings emphasize the current research literature. Typical applications include participation, legislative structure, political campaigns, multiparty government, and the interaction of economics and politics.

title: Precalculus/Prestatistics
reviews: Ask questions
Do not assume that because this is a pre-calculus course it will be extremely easy. The course requires hard work.
Do not take it unless you are passionate about calculus or have no other way to fulfill your requirement.

I would recommend this class if you felt pretty weak at math in high school and don't want to jump in to more demanding courses, especially if you're trying to just get your QR over with. I took AP Cal in high school and still found this class challenging at times, so don't think that you're necessarily "dumbing" yourself down by taking this class. Part of the challenge was that it had been two years at this point since I took a pre-cal class, but on the same note a lot of the information comes back to you in bits and pieces so it should definitely be an A if you put the work in.

If you haven't taken math for a long time, but used to like it, this class can be quite enjoyable. Professor Howard is very nice and ready to help. Also, this class is pretty small, but there's not a lot of pressure to speak up, which can be the best of both worlds.
Jumping straight into Calculus I would likely be a safer bet.
Prepare to do mostly everything on your own outside of class.
Study a lot and go to office hours.
Take the time to read the chapters
descrip: An intensive and rigorous treatment of algebra and trigonometry as preparation for further courses in calculus or statistics. Topics include functions and their graphs, equations involving polynomial and rational functions, exponentials, logarithms and trigonometry.

title: Electronic Devices
reviews: I recommend this course
If you are interested in electronic device, this is the course you must take.
It is great for beginner in learning electronic devices. For the student who has background in physics and devices, it is also great to try a different view on designing electronic devices.
basic semiconductor knowledge required
descrip: Introduction to principles of electron behavior in semiconductors and applications to device physics. Band diagrams, Metal-semiconductor contacts, Schottky barriers, p-n junctions. MOS electronics, FET's, bipolar transistor, solar cell, detector, LED, microwave devices.

title: The Revolution will not be Televised
reviews: I thought it was quite a lot of work (you could choose to not do it, but you would miss out on the material). If you're interested in the reading list, then absolutely take it.
Not if you're interested in political revolutions. Thought might be interesting perspective, but I failed to see connection between political and social.
There is a lot of reading.
descrip: What is revolutionary change today?
