Present discontents have been attributed to heightened inequality and worker exploitation, expanded global trade and permeable national borders, increased circulation of ideas through new media, and the undermining of forms of traditional authority. Revolutionary programs (e.g., as led by Marx, Lenin, Mao) exist as social projects of political and sexual emancipation, but they tend not to be informed by theories of ritual and everyday culture. In this course we will consider these theories as we explore revolutionary impulses from the Arab Spring, Ukraine, and the 1960's Americas.

title: Introduction to Macroeconomics
reviews: -stay on top of your work
A lot of people have to take this course, and it isn't terrible, but it is poorly organized and led, so unless you have a huge interest in macroeconomics, it's probably not worth it.
Be in Nik's precept! And if you have no idea what's going on, make use of McGraw and your many classmates who have taken economics courses before.
Be prepared to learn by yourself.
Bogan is an amazing teacher, and you will have a wonderful time learning about the connection between theoretical economics and the real world.
Chill out
Cram study before test as it is a lot of memorization.

Do Psets and take lecture notes no matter what

There are many tricky questions on the exams that ask you give you two statements and asks whether one, both, or none are correct. Along with class lectures, you're expected to read Economist articles and other articles for precept (read: there's a lot of reading). I wish Prof. Bogan told us sooner that the final may be worth more if you do considerably better on it than your midterm. I may have kept engaged in the class and gotten more out of it if I didn't PDF.

title: Introduction to the Mechanics and Dynamics of Soft Living Matter
reviews: Do the readings because there are some points for participation. Start the final proposal early, it's a lot of work.
I recommend to take this course if you want to learn something about the basic physic of cells.
People who are interested in understanding biological problems from the perspective of physics, this class is very informative.
To spend time reading the papers and fitting the concepts together because that can be very satisfying.
descrip: This course introduces the concepts of soft condensed matter and their use in understanding the mechanical properties, dynamic behavior, and self-assembly of living biological materials. We will take an engineering approach that emphasizes the application of fundamental physical concepts to a diverse set of problems taken from the literature, including mechanical properties of biopolymers and the cytoskeleton, directed and random molecular motion within cells, aggregation and collective movement of cells, and phase transitions and critical behavior in the self-assembly of lipid membranes and intracellular structures.

title: Topics in Germanic Literatures - Revolution, Science, Violence: Remixing Georg Buchner
prereqs: GER 107 or equivalent.
descrip: By the time of his death at 23, Georg Buchner had written three of the wildest masterpieces of German literature: Danton's Tod, Woyzeck, Lenz. His life was just as wild: not only was Buchner a prodigy in the new field of biology, he was a revolutionary activist whose political writings led him to be accused of treason. This class will follow a principle already at work in Buchner's writings which are all remixes of other texts. Alongside his own works and sources, we will also examine his aftermath; where there is radicality in German letters there is reference to Buchner-- from Brecht and Celan to Herzog and Jelinek.

title: The Politics of Modern Islam
reviews: Attend lecture every week, and do the readings to fill in your gaps of understanding. Would highly recommend!

Be prepared for some brutally long and difficult readings.  Professor Haykel gives good lectures though, so if you're interested in learning about Islam and the Middle East then this class could be worth taking.
Beware of the readings that can be a little tedious, but Professor Haykel really knows his stuff and I feel like I have a much better grip on Middle Eastern Politics now.

DEFINITELY TAKE THIS CLASS, but DO NOT TAKE HAYKEL's PRECEPT: Haykel's precept was a big disappointment for me (speaking as someone who nudged my way into it as it was his only section). The precept is basically another class (30 students), and solely consisted of other students presenting the material, so at best it was more like a Q&A with Haykel rather than a vibrant discussion to reinforce understanding. Finally, the other preceptor did a lot of test preparation (through preparing guides etc), which did not happen at all in Haykel's precept.

Definitely keep up with the readings. Though it may seem hard to do on a weekly basis, they pile up and are practically impenetrable if you just begin wading through them in anticipation of the midterm and final. Also, the ideas set forth by Professor Haykel as well as those espoused by the authors we read actually make for some very interesting conversations if everyone comes to class having reviewed the lecture notes in addition to the readings. It may also help to write some brief notes on each of the syllabus questions for each week as an informal test for yourself.
Definitely take it if you are remotely interested in Middle East politics. Professor Haykel is amazing!
Do the readings. Come to lecture. Definitely take this course!

prereqs: Open to all and no pre-requisites for taking the course..
descrip: This course examines the political dimensions of Islam. This will involve a study of the nature of Islamic political theory, the relationship between the religious and political establishments, the characteristics of an Islamic state, the radicalization of Sunni and Shi'i thought, and the compatibility of Islam and the nation-state, democracy, and constitutionalism, among other topics. Students will be introduced to the complex and polemical phenomenon of political Islam. The examples will be drawn mainly, though not exclusively, from cases and writings from the Middle East.

title: States, Democracies, Nations
descrip: This course surveys major topics and theoretical contributions in the construction of political order, the choice of constitutional regimes and the sources of citizens? compliance. The courses examines: the formation and development of the modern state; democracy; authoritarianism; revolution and political stability; legitimacy and compliance; nationalism; and macro theories of political change. With the explicit goal of exploring how research in comparative politics should be pursued in the future, each session assigns readings from both traditional macrohistorical and qualitative research and more recent analytical models.

title: From Jesus to Constantine: How Christianity Began
reviews: AWESOME CLASS, TAKE IT
Ask the basic questions and feel free to say exactly what you think, even if you think it might be stupid or insensitive. Pagels is definitely one of our best professors, too.
Do it! It was a great class. Not too much work, but really interesting overall.

First of all, Pagels is awesome. Get into her precept if you can. It really does make a difference. Secondly, I was planning on PDFing this class because as a science major, I was unfamiliar with taking humanities classes and writing essays. However, the class is really interesting if you're at all interested in Christianity, early texts, historiography. I decided not to PDF in the end because I was putting a lot of effort into the papers and actually enjoying it. The final paper is a great opportunity to research something that interests you personally. Pagels is just one of those teachers that is super encouraging and you don't even feel like you're being graded because she is so engaging. You can see that she really knows her stuff and also enjoys what she does.
GREAT HA!
Go to office hours earlier in the semester to talk with Professor Pagels. She is wonderful.

I would advise them to take it if they are interested in learning about Christianity, though you definitely do not have to be religious to take the class.  You will learn a lot and think about interesting issues concerning Christianity!
It's interesting stuff, so just enjoy the hell out of it.
Just make sure you take everything Professor Pagels says with a grain of salt.
Pretty good HA and good stuff to learn about!  Professor is approachable and well-known.  Readings are sometimes overwhelming but overall a generally low pressure course.
Prof. Pagels is THE authority on this subject: take this class with her and you'll learn a lot.
TAKE IT!
Take it if you have any interest in the subject.
Take it!

Take this class, it's awesome!! Go to the lectures, not just because you should, but because they're always interesting! It was like reading a a good book chapter by chapter and you didn't want to miss a chapter of it! In papers and responses, really engage the texts with original questions you have and thoughts. Prof. Pagels is such a knowledgeable teacher, she finds papers that show deep interest and strong engagement very rewarding.

The course was great. Exactly what I was looking for. Makes you very familiar with Christianity, regardless of your religion. Also, its not condescending of other religions, actually shows a lot of the negative aspects about Christianity as well as the positives. Great historical view on the religion, exactly like the title suggests. Take this class over Christian Ethics if you want to know how the religion came to be.

This class is analogous to the popular press history books that the professor has written--superficial and sensationalist. Having taken coursework in early Christianity I was very disappointed by this class. The analysis of the canonical gospels that was presented was minimal or absent. It usually went something like "Mark uses this word and Luke uses this word--how inconsistent! Let's move on." The dating of the texts were not discussed at all, dates were just assigned and questions as to where the dates came from were not answered. 

The canonization process was oversimplified and often misrepresented in lecture. Pagels seemed to think that certain Church Fathers were singularly responsible for the acceptance or rejection of certain texts, in spite of them having no legitimate means of exercising power over the church. The use of specific gospel traditions in the works of the apostolic fathers was not discussed. 

Pagels frequently pointed out the biases of certain scholars (Schweitzer, for example) but seemed very comfortable ignoring her own. I was surprised by the derision with witch she spoke about the role of women expressed in several canonical texts. By all means she can disagree with them, but making passive aggressive statements about them sounded childish. 

Some of the paper topics were ridiculous. "Imagine you are making a movie about early Christianity" began one of them. I felt like I was in middle school again. Don't take this class, it is a waste of time. Just buy one of Pagels's books instead.

This course is a GREAT way to discover early Christianity. The lectures and readings were wonderful, but the precepts were a bit weak. To fully take advantage of this course be sure to take the initiative to encourage active and energetic discussions during precepts.

This is a fantastic course, and the lectures are very engaging.  Just be prepared to put in a lot of time -- there are 6 essays, along with weekly readings and responses (~500 words each).  If you can fit this into your schedule, take it!

This is a great class to fulfill distribution requirements or just to take for fun. There isn't much work on a day to day basis besides the readings which often you can skim to get the general ideas presented. Professor Pagels know what she is talking about and her interpretation of early Christianity is fascinating.

This is a great class to take for your HA if you're at all interested learning about Christianity.  The readings are manageable, the assignments are very manageable, and Professor Pagels is a wonderful person.  There are people in the class who come from all different perspectives regarding Christianity, I feel that that's very much respected and appreciated.

This is a great course that you shouldn't be intimidated by even if you're coming with little background in Christianity (though I don't think it would be boring to somebody more familiar with the subject material)

This is a great course. If you have any interest in Christianity, this is the perfect way to provide yourself with a solid historical basis on how the religion began, and provides a lot of insight on how it became what it is today. Pagels is a great lecturer and the subject matter is fascinating
descrip: How did the movement that began with a few followers of Jesus of Nazareth become a world religion? We will investigate the earliest primary sources, gospels & historical accounts, Jewish & Roman, showing what was known about Jesus--including secret gospels; letters written to & from Roman emperors about whether to kill Christians to stop the movement; first hand accounts of trials, prison diaries, & martyrdoms; what Jesus & Paul said about sexual practices & gender; what converts wrote about why they chose Christianity, despite the dangers; how emperor Constantine--and, shortly after, Augustine--influenced what we know as Christianity today.

2. Go to lecture if the theory of all of it interests you.
3. Start relatively early on the homework--even  though some of them may not be conceptually very hard, they still require a lot of deliverables that take time to assemble.

Don't take this course unless it's required. I don't know what's happening next year because Prevost is allegedly retiring and Serguei, the best preceptor, is graduating. Start assignments as early as you can. Use Piazza. It wasn't as terrible as some people made it out to be, but do expect to spend 10-20 hours on psets each week. Good luck.
I would highly recommend not being scared away by previous reviews of this course.  Unlike the rumors say, the class is very helpful for future work, has a reasonable workload, and is well taught.
Only take it if you have to.
Start early on the problem sets and work neatly.

The level of difficulty of the problem sets is not actually that high, but requires a lot of tedious detailed work. The precepts are extremely helpful as are the preceptors. Having taking both this course and Statics, I would recommend MAEs to take this instead as the material covered is really different and I think this course is better suited for MAEs.
The only thing you need to be successful in this course is attending classes and reading the course notes.

You probably have to take it. You'll learn a lot, but be prepared to spend an inordinate amount of time on the problem sets. Pay attention in precept, read the course notes when you get stuck, and use Piazza.
You'll grow in attention to detail.
its time consuming but incredibly worth it.
prereqs: CEE 205/MAE 223 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Basic concepts of matrix structural analysis. Direct stiffness method. Axial force member. Beam bending member. Formation of element stiffness matrix. Assembling of global stiffness matrix. Introduction of boundary conditions. Solution of linear algebraic equations. Special analysis procedures. The finite element method. Introduction and basic formulation. Heat diffusion, plane stress and plane strain elasticity problems. Plate bending problems. The use and implementation of structural analysis and finite element computer codes using MATLAB is emphasized throughout the course.

title: Introduction to Architectural Thinking
reviews: Alright introduction to Architecture, readings are far from necessary and going to every other lecture will keep the lectures interesting
Ask the preceptors questions they are helpful in telling you about the debates.

Depending on your preceptor, you probably won't need to keep up on all the readings (especially since there are too many of them to realistically complete them all every week). However, the info pairs nicely with some of the topics in lecture, and you'll find that the content from one helps clarify the ideas in the other, and vice versa. The class was structured this semester around "debates" (historic vs. innovative, tectonic vs. representative,etc). which you'll spend a few lectures on before having to write an assignment on your thoughts. Stan called these "position papers," which can be a little misleading since some debates are hard to really take a stance on because the two sides often don't oppose perfectly. Generally, my advice would be to just watch your time with those assignments, especially in the 2nd half of the semester when they are closely spaced (about one every other week; there are 5 in the term in total). They're only meant to be about 300 words, but you'll probably go over that and will also have to include photos to support your ideas, so they take time. Ultimately, you probably have to be a little less concrete of a thinker and be open to a more interpretative and abstract course. If you're interested in architecture in general, I think you'll enjoy it but it might not be what you're expecting in terms of just learning what makes a building attractive, or being taught how to design a structure.

Gives an overall view of different buildings by different architects. The subject matter can be quite theoretical which is fine for someone who really likes talking about such issues or who wants to be an architecture major. This could be a good distribution requirement if you find yourself interested in the subject.
Have fun!
Highly recommend if you are remotely interested in architecture. Did not cover as much architecture as I imagined, but very informative.
I suggest to go to lecture as much as possible because Stan explains the topics in a more understandable way than most of the readings.
I would advise the other students that they don't have to do all of the readings to get something out of the class.
I would recommend that students should be prepared to memorize visuals, as this is a visual course.
I would take this even if you aren't an architecture major.  I learned a lot about buildings both around the world and on campus. Would recommend.
If you are unwilling to buy into the notion that buildings can communicate meaning, then don't take this class
It gives you an enlightened perspective on viewing architecture.
Look at some of the readings first and maybe shop the class to see if this is the type of material you would be interested in.

Moderate-workload introduction to architecture. This is NOT a history of architecture class, so be warned. Gets dense in theory in places, but isn't too much work day-to-day. A good course to fill a distribution requirement.
Take if you are interested in architecture theory!
Take this course if you have a general interest in design and are able to work with more abstract concepts. Stay open minded and you will get something out of the course.
This class is interesting, but it's a lot of work and *very* theoretical.

This course is not too difficult, but be aware that it is more comparable to an art history class than anything else. A lot of how much I enjoyed the class depended on how much I aesthetically enjoyed the projects we were examining. The five debates the class is centralized on can be confusing, but the material is interesting enough.

This course requires a lot of reading which was actively discussed in my precept so that is something to take into consideration.  Also the midterm exam is a very specific type of memorization under timed conditions that might not work for every type of student which is important to think about since it is 35% of your overall grade.

This is a good class to take for distribution requirements, especially if you have ever taken a different architecture course before. It really helped me connect and interpret many classes I had already completed. It is light course load and very straight forward how to perform well.
Very interesting, reading not too crucial and a reasonable amount of work.
Visit an art museum before the course to see some early modern works,  Modern art is referenced significantly.
take it only if you like to theorize about architecture/have to because of major requirement
descrip: The objective of this course is to provide a broad overview of the discipline of architecture: its history, theories, methodologies; its manners of thinking and working. Rather than a chronological survey, the course will be organized thematically, with examples drawn from a range of historical periods as well as contemporary practice. Through lectures, readings, and discussions every student will acquire a working knowledge of key texts, buildings and architectural concepts.

title: Contemporary Latin America in Literature and Visual Arts
reviews: Anyone interested in Latin America should take a class with Professor Draper - she is an exceptional and engaging professor.

If you're interested in Latin American literature, this is a great survey course of sorts. Someone said at the end that they thought we'd be reading a lot of Garcia Marquez when they first signed up, and that is absolutely not what we did, even though Garcia Marquez is great. But that's awesome because we got to look at magical realism critically and read other awesome authors like Roberto Bola?o, Clarice Lispector, and even Junot Diaz. Professor Draper doesn't insert herself into class discussions too much, but when she does, you should listen.
Some of the readings can be pretty long, so it helps to divide them chunk by chunk every single day.
Take it! Professor Draper is amazing and the material is fantastic.
descrip: This course is an introduction to contemporary Latin American literature & visual arts with a transatlantic perspective. Placing special emphasis on the changing relationships between aesthetics & politics, it analyzes different genres & artistic styles that emerge with new forms of imagining the relations between culture & politics, from the 1960s to the present. Readings will include critical texts on minor literature's, transatlantic connections, new social movements as well as literature dealing with situationism, romance reportagem, indigenous movements, testimonio, zapatism, etc. Texts will be available in the original & translation.

title: Narrative Techniques in Freud's Great Case Histories
descrip: Please see website

title: The American Dance Experience and Africanist Dance Practices
reviews: Absolutely take this class! The professor is fun, the cultural aspects of dance are fascinating, and you make friends!
I would recommend this course to anyone who is willing to try something new.  The work load is light outside of the classroom.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!! It has been the most fun and interesting and engaging course I have taken at Princeton.
Take it!
Take it! Great PDF, great work out, great professor, great way to branch out and try something new, great way to learn more about the stories behind dance
Take it. It's so much fun.
Take this course!

This is one of those classes where you'll be surprised that they're giving you a credit because it's something that you might just do for fun. Class time isn't a burden but rather a great break from the rest of Princeton's generally sedentary classes.
prereqs: Some form of social dancing, good, natural movement aptitude, or former dance training. This is an OPEN ENROLLMENT course..
descrip: A studio course introducing students to American dance aesthetics and practices, with a focus on how its evolution has been influenced by African American choreographers and dancers. An ongoing study of movement practices from traditional African dances and those of the African diaspora, touching on American jazz dance, modern dance, and American ballet. Studio work will be complemented by readings, video viewings, guest speakers, and dance studies.

title: New Media 1400-1900
reviews: Definitely take this course, even if you aren't lacking in HA's. This class was the highlight of my semester. I don't even know how to begin talking about how fascinating the material and how we approached the material were.
Do the readings and try to take the blogs seriouslyl.

Don't worry about your language ability when considering this class--everyone speaks decently well but nobody is fluent and so class discussion is perfectly understandable. Be warned, she puts the most difficult reading close to the beginning of the course. Otherwise, you get to work with 500 year-old books and it's a really neat course!

Katie is a good professor, and I've enjoyed all of my classes with her--she is kind, fair, and helpful. I didn't have a media studies background before but found the content interesting (and we got to touch super old books, including a leaf from a Gutenberg bible!) If you're looking for a French course, I say go for it.

Take it (or any other courses of this vein with her)! This is a really fun course. Mme. Chenoweth is a great teacher and she manages to combine discussion and lecture and readings and papers in the perfect proportions, and she's extremely helpful and fun to have leading the class. The assignments are all very open-ended, so if you focus on the things that interest you, you'll end up with a course that gives you exactly what you wanted. Keep on top of things but it isn't an onerous workload at all. Be open-minded and prepared to learn a lot.
Take it!

This course is cool because it combines history and media theory and does it in French.  You don't need to have a background in media studies to get a lot out of the class (but you will walk away with one!)
This has been one of my favorite courses I have ever taken at Princeton. Katie is such a great professor, and this course is SO interesting. Take it!
prereqs: 200-level French course or permission of instructor..
descrip: This course studies the history, theory, and aesthetics of "new media" in France and beyond between 1400 and 1900. We look closely at moments when textual and visual media that are now "old" were first emerging, from the printing press in the Renaissance to the Lumiere brothers' cinematographe in 1895. How did early users perceive, adopt, and shape these new media technologies? How did each medium transform the existing cultural landscape? What can this history tell us about contemporary new media? Course integrates regular visits to libraries and archives on campus for hands-on interaction with historical media objects and technologies.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: Don't.
I highly recommend the class but i would say that he or she would need to prepare herself to really push the projects forward when working in the class.

It's not right for everyone. I would only recommend it to those with a high level of discourse, interested in economic systems, urbanism, sociology, etc. There are many people in the school who really just are not cut out for it.
Recommend, but make sure you're willing to accept the methodology (research vs. thinking-though-making/designing).
Unless a student has a particular interest in the instructor or studio prompt, I would not recommend this course.

When selecting a studio, it is important to consider what type of project you might develop during the semester.  An integrated studio might allow you to continuously develop a single project, but in a studio such as this one you might spend a large portion of the semester determining what constitutes a relevant project.
descrip: Explores architecture as a social art and the spatial organization of the human environment. Projects include a broad range of problem types, including individual buildings, groups of buildings, urban districts, and landscapes.

title: The Quantum World
reviews: Always go to Liang's optional review sessions.

Avoid this course if you can. Read the textbook before attending lectures, and work on the problem sets a little bit at a time instead of trying to do all of the questions the night before the assignment is due.
Be sure to go to the TA for help if you need. This course is extremely difficult, and one can't afford to get behind.
Don't take it until the change the structure.
Don't take unless free time or a chemistry concentrator
Good Pchem class for chemistry majors.
If you think you can be really engaged by quantum, take 405 instead.
Interesting but conceptually challenging. Reading the book and attending precepts were essential to really learning the concepts.
Only take it if you have to. Go to precept and review sessions. Liang is an amazing TA.

READ THE TEXTBOOK. It really isn't that bad. The math may be tedious, but the concepts are pretty straightforward. I felt it wasn't as bad as people said it would be. Take it if you're looking to fulfill the physical chem requirement or if you just want an introduction to quantum mechanics.
Read the textbook since lectures with Jun and Herschel are not very helpful.
Take it if Liang is involved!  I really enjoyed learning the fundamentals behind a lot of the stuff that is taught in general chemistry.

The course material is interesting but hard to conceptualize. Lectures, while not entirely useful, should not be missed as grasping the material will be much harder than it already is. Attend precept and ask questions. Liang is extremely available and helpful, and really wants you to do well. If picking between quantum and thermo, would recommend thermo as the physical chemistry requirement in terms of how well it is taught.

Unlike in the past, 305 is actually taught decently well. Of course, this will change for you because our TA, Liang, who's finishing his phd in may, made it such a great course. The lectures are fast-pased and you'll have no idea what was just covered until you sit down to do your pset and have reviewed your notes carefully along with the book. I recommend TMP chem's and  BU chem YouTube channels for a good review if you're a visual learner like me.  The course is hard, but take it, especially if you're a chemistry major. Sure, you'll get bits of it in 407 and some other courses, but you'll never appreciate chemistry as a whole without a course in QM.
While MAT 201 and 202 are not prerequisites for the course, it is strongly recommended for a reason... As someone with limited math knowledge, I struggled with this course.
You have to be comfortable with math to take quantum mechanics, regardless of what the course says.
keep up with the material by doing the reading and the problem sets thoroughly.  Ask questions when you are confused!
take it because you have to and suffer through it.
take it if you must, but it's a lot of work
prereqs: CHM 202 or CHM 204 or CHM 215; MAT 102 or MAT 104; PHY 101 or AP Physics in high school credit..
descrip: Introduction to quantum mechanics, surveying applications in chemistry, physics, and spectroscopy.

title: Taboo and Transgression
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to Syriac
descrip: A systematic introduction to Syriac language. Close reading of selected passages of Syriac texts.

title: Screenwriting II: Adaptation
reviews: Creative writing courses have a tendency to fall to the wayside, given that it's only P/D/F, so only take courses that you can really invest in.
Take it.
Take the course if you really want to learn how to tell a story - as well as learn what sort of stories ask to be told through a visual medium.
Try your hardest!
You get out as much as you put in.
prereqs: Interested students complete a creative writing application (please visit the program website) by attaching a statement about why they want to take the course and, optionally, a 3-4 page creative writing sample in any genre. Application deadline is April 11, 2014..
descrip: This course will introduce students to Screenwriting Adaptation techniques, focusing primarily on the challenges of adapting "true stories" pulled from various non-fiction sources. The class will address the ethics of adaptation, questions and techniques surrounding the need to fictionalize truth for dramatic purposes, as well as touching on the differences between fictional and nonfictional original materials. Students will be exposed to various contemporary non-fiction adaptations, and will write a short film (under 15 pages) and one longer project (30 pages).

title: Design and Behavior of Steel Structures
reviews: Strongly recommend for anyone that is thinking about going into the field of structural engineering and designing structures.
Take it if you want to go into structural engineering.
Taking it as a junior is hard.
This is a great design course. You will understand where all of the code actually comes from after taking this class.
prereqs: CEE205 and CEE312.
descrip: Topics in the design and analysis of steel structures are covered such as geometric properties and stresses of built-up shapes, columns (including plate buckling), beams, tension members, beam-columns.

title: Social and Political Lives of Humor, The
descrip: See Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Solar Energy Conversion
reviews: Absolutely avoid. Take MAE 328: Energy for  a Greenhouse-Constrained World for a reasonable, well-defined introduction to renewable energy technologies. When Wagner taught this class, the lecture material looked pretty good, but all of the assignments were unrelated, ill-conceived, and a poor use of everyone's time.
Anyone interested in energy and renewables MUST take this course.

I highly recommend this course as a survey of renewable energy concepts, and covers basic realms of power generation as well as the basic scientific principles and challenges behind each one. The lectures are interesting, and Professor Wagner knows a lot about renewable energy, particularly Solar PV. When considering this course, it might be useful to know the following:

? The problem sets require a lot of thought and time, but are not computationally difficult. They are largely open ended questions about estimating different aspects of implementing new technologies.
? Labs are not difficult, and are flexibly timed.
? There is very little numerical feedback on grading, although problem sets receive specific and general qualitative feedback.
If you like renewable energy, take this class
If you're at all interested in energy, take this course. Work load is what you make it, could be easy could be hard. Great professor and great attention.
prereqs: Completed freshman science or engineering courses (MAT 104, PHY 104, CHM 207). Open to others by permission of instructor..
descrip: Principles and design of solar energy conversion systems. Quantity and availability of solar energy. Physics and chemistry of solar energy conversion: solar optics, optical excitation, capture of excited energy, and transport of excitations or electronic charge. Conversion methods: thermal, wind,photoelectric, photoelectrochemical, photosynthetic, biomass. Storing solar energy. 3 lectures, 1 lab, 1 lab precept per week. Lab accessible 24/7.

title: Contemporary Korean Language and Culture I
reviews: Definitely take this course, especially if you don't have much opportunity to use Korean outside the classroom.
Doing the readings helps with the quizzes.
Not easy, especially jumping from 3rd year to 4th year but rewarding.
She grades fairly, and tracks how much you've improved from beginning to end.
Take it. You will not regret it.
This is a class where the more you try the more you will definitely take away. Its an opportunity to really start to understand the culture as well as the advance vocabulary of Korea.
prereqs: KOR 302 or Instructor's permission..
descrip: The 4th-year language course is designed to accelerate students' proficiency to the high-advanced level and to promote a deeper level of understanding of Korea and its people. A wide range of sociolinguistic and sociocultural issues are covered through the use of various media resources (e.g., dramas, films, songs, commercials, newspapers, websites) as well as short essays. Classroom discussion are conducted in Korean.

title: Probability and Stochastic Systems
reviews: .Definitely take this class if Prof. Handel is teaching it. He is amazing at explaining the material and will make this class a blast.
A  course if Ramon van Handel is teaching. I've taken several MAT and ORF courses and he has been by far the best lecturer I've had.
A great course for ORF and non-ORF alike. Take it.

A great, well-taught, well-designed course overall. Problem sets are significantly harder than exams, and the big homework assigned over winter break can be pretty soul-crushing. Van Handel is a fantastic lecturer who writes very thorough and helpful lecture notes.
Actually understand  material.
Be aware this is a very demanding course when deciding whether to take it! It is excellently taught however.

Be prepared to put in the work, very competitive class and your peers will really push the curve. Challenging and difficult. One of the best organized courses I have taken at Princeton, but also one of the most frustrating.

Before attempting the homework, make sure you fully understand the relevant topics. Make a "summary sheet" of sorts containing the basic ideas of the chapter - doing this really helped me put the concepts of the course together.
Best taught ORF class in Pton.
Collaborate on the problem sets, as they will otherwise take a very long time to finish.

Definitely a difficult course, and I would probably not recommend taking it "for fun" if you're not an ORF major. However, the material is interesting if you choose to invest the time needed to take it all in, and I think it taught me a lot. The professor and TAs are always there if you need their support.
Definitely find some sort of additional reference material, like the textbook that was advised not to be used.
Definitely recommend if you are up for a challenge.
Definitely take it if you're interested in probability at all.
Definitely take it.
Definitely take this class. You might struggle but it is very well taught.
Difficult, but very rewarding. Exams were clear and straight-forward.
Do not take it unless you absolutely have to.
Do your problem sets in a study group and always refresh your understanding of the previously taught materials to cement your understanding, or you will get lost.
Don't take it unless you have to or are very good with probability.
Don't take unless you're MAT or ORFE.
Excellent course for an introduction to probability theory. Teaches you to think like a probabilist while not getting tied down with rigorous theory.
Extremely difficult class that's could be more rewarding than it actually is.

Find a study group early on in the semester or you won't be able to do the problem sets. At all. Make sure you understand the material conceptually rather than just memorizing formulas. Just getting the right answer in the problem sets and exams won't cut it.
Get excited to learn!
Go for it - if you like this stuff, you'll probably enjoy the class.
Go hard.
Go to Kobey, Firdevs or Georgina's precept. Attend office hours. Don't fall behind.
Great Professor and creative problem sets.
Great course, even better than what it has been in the past. Everyone should take it. Took as a COS senior, loved it. Take it with 340 and you'll connect things in your mind and have brain blasts.
Great course, must be willing to put in time and effort

I don't really recommend it unless you have to take it for ORF or have a strong math background. Was a lot of work and unnecessary stress, especially the problem sets. Find a good group to work on the p sets with, you'll need help
I found the class very difficult but it is a very interesting class.
I would strongly recommend this course for a challenge.
I wouldn't recommend taking this class just for fun because it is extremely time consuming. But if you need to take it, Professor van Handel is a very good teacher.
If Prof. van Handel is teaching, definitely take if you are interested. Very clear and helpful professor.
If van Handel is lecturing, I couldn't recommend this course more.
If you are interested in probabilities and stochastics, take the class! You will not regret.
If you're confident in your math abilities and are interested in probability theory this class is good for you.  However, plan on spending a lot of time working on it.
It is a difficult course, BUT Professor van Handel is the best professor I've had and you learn so much from this course. Worth the time and pain.
It is a very hard course but with Professor van Handel I would say it is worth it.

It's a fantastic course. Handel is the best lecturer ever. He's super entertaining, fantastic at explaining concepts, and gives the most hilarious example problems. Before I took this class, I didn't realize lectures could actually be extremely entertaining, but Handel is by far the best lecturer I've ever had. The problem sets are difficult, but the TA's are extremely helpful at office hours. The class itself doesn't take much more time than, say, MAT 201 or MAT 202, but definitely I feel like it's harder to do them on time because I have to always work around the schedule of office hours or else I can't get help with them. (and unless you are a math genius you will probably need quite a bit of help on most of the problems) The midterms are not bad at all, and are much easier than the homeworks. There are lots of non-ORF majors in this class, and many people who haven't taken ORF 245, so if you're concerned about not knowing anything about statistics, it really isn't much of a problem. Take it!!!

It's a fascinating, though challenging course ? if you don't plan on making it your 1st or 2nd biggest academic priority, plan on P/D/F-ing it. That said, you learn an insane amount of probability theory extremely quickly, which is very useful if you're studying either the social or natural sciences.
It's a hard class. But you will learn a ton and I don't think I've ever dealt with a more impressively organized, structured class.
It's challenging but rewarding. You will learn a lot. Take it.

It's not easy, and it;s not a course you can just cram for at the end, as HW is every week and an important part of the grade.  But there are ample resources for help that you should take advatage of, and you will leave the class with an intutitve understadning of probabity and how to apply these concepts to real world situations
Keep up, go to office hours
Lecture notes are great. Van Handel does present material very well, but you lose nothing by not going to lecture and reading the lecture notes instead.
Loved this class!! Problem sets take time and office hours. Ramon is great!!! Be comfortable with math and enjoy probability and you will like this class more :)
Need to take if you are a quant person

ORF 309 will push you down and slowly build you back up again. Ramon is one of the best lecturers at Princeton, and manages to keep you on the edge of your seat during every lecture. Be prepared to work hard and learn a lot.
Only take if you are going to be an orf major
Only take if you have serious interest in topic.
Only take it if you have to. Giant homework over winter break was pretty evil
Prepare for work!
Professor van Handel is a great lecturer. He made everything crystal clear and he was also funny. I would highly recommend taking the class with him.

Ramon is a great lecturer -- he really helps you understand the intuition, which is *crucial* for probability. It was much more straightforward than I had anticipated. Psets require time and working with a group is recommended -- they taught me a lot. Exams are straightforward.
Read the notes and start problem sets early.
Really nice introduction to probability. Professor van Handel is very clear and engaging, and the work is difficult, but manageable. Lots of support available outside of lecture.
Start the Big Homework early!
Strongly recommend this course to people who like logics and numbers. Lots of interesting mathematical ideas are covered in this course.
Study early for the exams and go to office hours!
TAKE IT
TAKE IT!
TAKE IT! ESPECIALLY WITH RAMON VAN HANDEL

TAKE THIS COURSE. Professor Van Handel is an AMAZING teacher. He presents everything so clearly and has this way of making very difficult concepts seem entirely manageable and natural. The organization in this class is fantastic, preceptors are almost always available to help with problem sets, problem sets are useful, lecture notes are posted online and soo helpful. This is one of the most challenging courses I've taken at Princeton, but also the most rewarding. This class is HARD, but if you put in the effort and are truly interesting in learning some super cool probability theory, then this class will be infinitely rewarding
Take if you have a lot of time. Including lectures, precept, and weekly problem set, expect to put in 15 hours a week at minimum.

Take it if Ramon is teaching. It is a great class and you definitely learn the basics of probability. Don't expect the course to be very rigorous though. Most of the problems are very computationally heavy.
Take it if you are any kind of engineer
Take it if you are decent at math / are interested. Its a very good class
Take it if you have to
Take it if you must. Very challenging
Take it if you're interested in probability-esque structures that occur in the real world.
Take it if you're serious about it.
Take it take it take it! It's very challenging, but very well taught, and it's nice to use more of your brain's capacities from time to time !
Take it with Ramon! He's really funny and understandable.

Take it with van Handel! He is a wonderful lecturer and mentor, and is also extremely kind and helpful during office hours. I've also had great experiences with the TAs, Firdevs, Georgina, Cagin, Nana...who were all really helpful and responsive. Probability is a very interesting field and this course has now made me want to take higher level probability theory courses.
Take it!
Take it! Don't be discouraged by those who say it's too hard!
Take it! Go to office hours.
Take it!!!
Take it. It will change your life.
Take it. Ramon is amazing and so is Cagin. But be warned that it is extremely difficult. Still worth taking though.
Take this course if you are interested in probability!

Take this course!! Make sure you have time, at least 10 hours a week for the problem sets. Also beware the final problem set which took MINIMUM 40 hours and on AVERAGE 55 hours (this is not an exaggeration, I promise) to complete. But if van Handel is still teaching, his lectures are AMAZING and you truly walk away from this course feeling like you understand the world a lot better.
Take this! It's a great class! Not overly difficult, but certainly challenging and rewarding.
Takes a lot of time, take if departmental or necessary for other class. General interest class would be a huge commitment (my mistake).

Taking ORF 309 was the second most valuable educational experience in my life, second only to being potty trained at the age of two.  I would enthusiastically recommend this course to anyone who thinks that doing stuff with numbers can be fun.  So what makes ORF 309 so great?

1.  It's useful.  I'm a junior in the COS department, and I took this course because I wanted to understand machine learning.  I had taken COS 424 (machine learning) the previous spring, and had felt embarrassed that I couldn't follow many of the proofs that required manipulating probability distributions.  It's one thing to be *acquainted* with the laws of probability, but it's another thing to really feel them in your bones.  ORF 309 makes you fluent in probability.

Also, if you're interested in a job in quantitative finance (or at least want to leave the option open) this course would come in handy for interviews.  

2.  It's entertaining.  Probability questions are just really, really fun to solve.

3.  It's not that hard.  Ramon van Handel is an incredible teacher and a gifted explainer.  He makes probability easy.  Coming into this course, I was uneasy, because I had often heard ORF 309 compared to COS 340, which was for sure a hard class.  This is not a good comparison.  ORF 309 is much easier.  If you put in the effort (go to office hours, collaborate with a group), there's no reason why you can't get every homework question right.  And the exams generally have straightforward questions.

All around, this was an amazing course.
The course is difficult. Attend lectures and precepts and do as many problems as you can
This class is not worth it. Perhaps it was because it was van Handel's first year teaching it, but I struggled to pass, even with the PDF option.
This class is really hard. Van Handel was a good lecturer. Precepts are pretty useless.

This course is difficult: even if you plan to PDF this course, expect to put the same amount of work for a regular class. I highly reccommend working in a study group. The assignments expect a certain mathematical rigor, and if you aren't used to it, its easy to make wrong fundamental assumptions if you try to lone wolf the assignments / exam studying
This is a challenging class, but definitely worth the time and effort. I got a lot out of it and I would definitely recommend taking it.

This is a great and interesting course, but it's SO hard!!! Professor van Handel is an amazing lecturer, so don't miss his lectures. Also go to like every office hours there is, to figure out the p-set (start early cause it will take very very long!!!)

This is a super well-run course. Professor van Handel is an amazing lecturer and the preceptors all know their stuff! While the psets were really challenging, I feel like I got a lot out of the course.
This is a time consuming, but excellent class. You will learn so much, but most importantly, you will learn how to think. By far one of my favorite classes at Princeton.
This is an okay class. Be sure to find friends to collaborate with on the problem sets. Study hard for the midterm and final.
Try to understand well the concepts. Ask for help (for example, schedule and appointment with Professor can Handel).
Very interesting course but also very very very hard.
Very useful course, take it early.
Would recommend even to non-ORFE majors with fairly quantitative backgrounds.

You should take the course. You will learn so much. Be prepared for the psets though.
If you pdf, it will be one of the best pdf classes ever (you learn a lot while keeping low stress.)
definitely make sure you do the practice problems for test prep
make sure you understand the notes.
take it, especially if van handel is teaching it.
van Handel is great as a lecturer. Tough course on the whole, but if you go into it knowing that it's tough, then you'll be fine.
prereqs: MAT 201 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: An introduction to probability and its applications. Random variables, expectation, independence. Poisson processes, Markov chains, and Brownian motion. Stochastic models of queues, population dynamics, and reliability.

title: Milton: Poetry and Revolution
descrip: A thorough investigation of the making of Milton's poetry and prose in the context of the British and European events that shaped his life and writing and in which he participated: The civil war and the political and religious revolution that followed. We consider Milton's writings also by comparison with his contemporaries, including Marvell, Hobbes, Lucy Hutchinson, Henrick, Galileo, Spinoza, and our contemporaries, such as Geoffrey Hill and Antonio Negri.

title: Extramural Research Internship
descrip: One-term full time research internship at a host institution to perform scholarly research directly relevant to a student's dissertation work. Research objectives will be determined by the student's advisor in consultation with the outside host. Monthly progress reports and a final paper are required. Enrollment limited to post-generals students. Students will be permitted to enroll in this one-semester course at most twice. Participation will be considered exceptional.

title: An Integrated, Quantitative Introduction to the Natural Sciences I
reviews: A strong background knowledge in at least one of the sciences (especially physics or biology) is highly recommended. Apart from that, general knowledge on all of the sciences helps a lot. This class focuses on mathematical models and quantitative descriptions of natural phenomena, and not on the fundamental concepts of the sciences themselves. You will learned applied math to physics, biology, and some chemistry, not the subjects themselves. Be prepared for heavy workloads and self-learning on some unclear topics. Lab reports are intense, too, but awesome learning experiences.
Be prepared for school work unlike any you have ever seen before.
Beware.

Definitely learned a lot in this class, from both the lecture component and the lab component. But I would recommend with reservation, according to your own plan of study. Sometimes you will definitely feel the time you spent on something is not worth it, sometimes things are not well connected or reasonably well addressed, and a lot of the material you might need for your major (i.e. physics and chem) is not covered. My general feeling is that ISC ultimately serves molbio because its mission is to connect biological sciences with physical sciences, and if you are a molbio major this is definitely the best program for you. But if you are a physics major or a chem major, not everything you need to know is covered and sometimes your effort is wasted when the course is not structured so well or the material is not connected so well. For example, I like physics much more than all the others, and I think the physics in ISC is not enough and not comparable to that in 105-106. I would have taken MAT215 and PHY105 instead of ISC if I were to start freshman year all over again, because now I know I like physics. But I still love ISC and learned a lot and the holistic experience is still worth it. Not as intimidating as you might have heard. If you don't know what you want to major in you can give it a try, but if you know you are more inclined to math and physics (actually I know before freshman year), I would not highly recommend ISC. Take MAT215 with PHY105.
Do not take it unless you are sure you want to. It takes up the vast vast majority of your time and destroys self esteem.
Don't worry too much: learn as much as you can, but don't expect to finish every single assignment perfectly.
Evaluated in ISC 232 form.

Former students and professors alike will warn you that this is an extremely difficult course. They are not exaggerating. ISC is probably the hardest course you can take freshman year. I'm not sure if it's worth it for everyone. It was worth it for me, but I struggled very much to get through it. That been said, it's extremely interesting and very very cool, which is why students keep taking it. I would suggest taking it, but only if you'd feel comfortable dropping out if it became too hard for you.
Get ready to spend the majority, if not all, of your time in this class.
Have a strong physics background.

In the hours before the final problem set was due, I was camping out in Icahn with some classmates, trying to finish the assignment. It was hard. Frustrating. I scribbled down some integrals, but I wasn't really sure what was going on. The person beside me was rushing to wrap up a particularly long question. "I can't wait to be done with this problem set," someone said. We grumbled in unison and rhetorically wondered aloud why we signed up for this class in the first place. Would have had so much more free time. Would have spared ourselves for so much agony. Someone asked, "yo, are you all doing ISC next semester?" There was a short pause as we stared at each other, but the answer was a unanimous yes. We giggled at ourselves, (sorta) finished the problem set, and walked out to a beautiful December evening.

The thing about ISC is that although it is difficult and time-consuming, what we've been learning is just so fascinating it draws us in for another semester. The people in it - classmates, instructors, TAs, ISC alumni - also contributes to why I enjoy the class. I learned a lot this semester, but any bit of arrogance I had walking in was neatly shattered. 

If this sounds a freshman year you would appreciate, give ISC a shot. Come in with a strong background in relevant skills - calculus, physics, MATLAB, java, group work - and your life will be easier. Try it out anyway even if you don't but don't be afraid to drop. Recommended with great caution.

It is more work than you can imagine. You think you can handle it, but you probably can't. Your GPA in other classes will suffer greatly. Everyone has wanted to dropp the course multiple times, even after dropp/add ends. You don't really find out what you're getting into until three weeks before the midterm. When it's 2AM in Icahn on a Thursday, you'll hate life, but at least there will be 20 other people hating life with you.

This course is a rollercoaster. It will provide some of the greatest lows in your Princeton experience: I remember one post-pset dinner where a student sat down and said "Fuck ISC." Everyone agreed.

On the other hand, it will also provide some of the greatest highs in your Princeton experience: understanding what statistical mechanics is all about, realizing you can actually model a real-world system, and many more.

If you take this course, you will be sacrificing 1) your GPA in other courses, 2) your quality of life (sleep, food, etc.), 3) your ability to participate in extracurriculars. I'm still not sure if that was worth the benefits for me. Only you can decide that for yourself.

Not sure I can really describe the nature of the course in the time I have right now. It will dominate your life. It will also teach you how to be a scientist. The community is the best part. The professors and your fellow students will become your biffles.
Read the books!!!!, do labs early, and have fun! I repeat, have fun!
Stay on top of stuff
Take it but beware of the course load. Don't be discouraged by the difficult first few weeks. It gets better!

The absolute only way I would recommend this would be if you're a possible physics major with AP bio/chem/physics. ISC is worth it only if you already know the concepts and are willing to spend a year working like crazy for physics and killing your social life. Not worth it. This is the point in life when giving up is not actually giving up, but a very admirable and sane option.

The class is very time consuming and very difficult. There is a lot to be learned but it requires dedication. I would ask former students and really consider if you want to have be so dedicated to one class. Make sure you have a solid math foundation.

The rumors about this course are all TRUE. This course will suck away your social life and opportunities for activities outside of ISC for a solid year, but the rewards are worth it: everyone becomes very tight, you learn skills that are unmatched in other equivalent courses, everything is LaTeXed, and it is a valuable pathway into a variety of other disciplines. In the end, the choice is up to you, but feel free to ask us if you have questions.

Think very hard about how hard you want to work your first semester and how good your math preparation is. If you are interested in quantitative bio and are ready to devote your first year to science, then in that case I recommend it fully!

This course is a lot of physics (and therefore a lot of math), with quantitative applications in biology (and a bit in chemistry). Try your best to start the problems sets early in the week when they're first announced so that you can actually ask the TA's questions during the Wednesday night problem sessions or go to their office hours for clarification (which you'll almost definitely need on some of the material). Also, try your very hardest (though it doesn't usually work) to not leave lab reports to the weekend before they are do; if you do this (as I often ended up doing), your weekend will be miserable and you will get very little sleep. Perhaps the material will come more easily to you / you'll be faster at working through the problem sets than I was; otherwise, you probably won't be getting a lot of sleep. Despite the heavy workload, some of the professors are wonderful, the material is generally fascinating, and you'll form strong bonds with your other classmates. Don't be afraid at the start to work together with your classmates!! And know that there ARE resources (TA's, professors, office hours, peer tutors, etc.) to help you if you are having trouble with the material; that being said, it can often be difficult to arrange your time suitably in order to take full advantage of these resources. Also, you really have to be invested and committed to take this course, as you WILL end up having to devote the majority of your academic time and efforts to it (so don't just decide to take it on a whim). On the whole, though, I feel as though this course has given me a much better understanding of what science and scientific inquiry actually involve, and has changed the way I approach scientific problem solving. Oh, and the labs are fantastic (and while the lab reports can be a pain, at least you feel as though you are doing something legitimately worthwhile and are learning clear skills by doing so)!

This course is extremely difficult and will take almost all of your time. That said, it is also extremely rewarding and has been one of the best academic experiences I have ever had. If you are prepared to commit to the course, it will be amazing, but if not, it will probably be impossible.

This course is just as demanding if not more demanding than what people say. It was definitely far more time consuming than I expected. However, the course did indeed achieve its expressed purpose of changing my perspective on science. The class really is integrated rather than multidisciplinary, and it felt as though they taught us how to think scientifically more than just content. I found this method of teaching to be particularly intelligent since learning content can be done without too much difficulty on one's own time but having one's perspective on an entire field that many of us identify with is a more rare and valuable opportunity this course provides. Very little memorization is required and what we do end up remembering is due to it coming up repeated during the course rather than deliberate rote memorization. The course content is developed very mathematically and model-orientated rather than fact or observation orientated. It definitely is a class that teaches us how to think like a scientist in that they show us the thought process behind derivations and models, and the lab portion of the course demands us write quite professional looking lab reports and give good guidance on how to do so. As a warning, the class demands a ton of work but the grading seems to be fair. I highly recommend the course for anyone interested in either becoming a scientist or learning how to think scientifically.

This course is more work than you can imagine. That being said, taking ISC was the best decision I could have made during the beginning of my freshman year. I am so privileged to have such a talented group of classmates, and truly believe that I could not have been a part of such a great scientific community in the equivalent introductory science courses offered at Princeton.

To get the most out of this class you should already have a solid background in all of the sciences (AP Biology, Chemistry, and Physics C). The workload is immense so be prepared to dedicate many long nights to this class.
prereqs: Familiarity with the calculus at the level of MAT 103/4 or Advanced Placement Calculus BC, solid high school physics and chemistry courses..
descrip: An integrated, mathematically and computationally sophisticated introduction to physics, chemistry, molecular biology, and computer science. This year long, four course sequence is a multidisciplinary course taught across multiple departments with the following faculty: T. Gregor, J. Shaevitz (PHY); P. Debenedetti, S. Shvartsman (CBE); J. Rabinowitz, H. Yang (CHM); P. Andolfatto (EEB); E. Wieschaus (MOL); O. Troyanskaya (COS); C. Broedersz, A. Leifer, B. Machta (LSI Fellows); J. Gadd (LSI). Five hours of lecture, one three-hour lab, one three-hour precept, one required evening problem session.

title: Democratic Theory
reviews: Be wary of this class. It is hard to do well in and the material can be at times a little dry. Make sure you know what you're getting yourself into with a political theory class.
DO the reading!  Think for yourself about what the philosophers are saying!
Definitely take it! It will force you to consider many important questions.

Definitely take this course if you are at all interested in the subject material, which traces the development of democratic theory from ancient ancient political thinkers to modern times. Professor Pettit is one of Princeton's better lecturers and the preceptors are all excellent.  The class is not too difficult, with less reading and fewer graded assignments  than most classes.  So I particularly recommend the class as an easier 5th course.
Do the readings after going to lecture.
Do the readings as needed for the midterm and papers. Lecture notes are helpful
Do the readings, they are too good to pass up.
Get your hands on the lecture notes. Also, if your preceptor distributes lists of important quotes from the readings, those are super helpful for papers!
Great course!
Highly recommended.
I am not going into politics, but I am glad I took this because it forces you to think about freedom and the other democratic concepts that allow you to pursue your interests in the first place.

I would recommend this course to anyone who thinks they might be interested in politics or even just wants to know more about where democracy came from. Professor Pettit is a great lecturer, the preceptors want to help you learn, and the subject matter is really interesting.

I would suggest taking another political theory survey course before this one because this course is by no means easy. It is incredibly interesting and well taught, but if you find the material itself boring, then you will have a hard time getting through it. However, if you know that this is something that you are interested in, Professor Pettit is the man you want to study with.

If you are unsure of whether you are interested  in philosophy, do not take this class. There are other philosophy classes that represent the subject better and are more analytical. However, if you enjoy politics, this class may force you to look at political concepts in a more abstract way.

If you have any interest in political theory whatsoever, take this course! Professor Pettit is a wonderful lecturer and extremely friendly and approachable. If possible, try to do the readings AFTER the lecture; a lot of people tended to get much more out of them that way.

If you're looking for an EM to take, don't be scared by the fact that it's a 300-level course and is non-PDF. I took it for my distribution and I found it very interesting. The workload was not too heavy, and if you just do the readings and assignments you should be fine. I felt like I came out of the class trained to think about political systems, so in that sense it was pretty good.
Interesting. To get the most out of the course, you really have to do the readings. But you definitely don't need to to just get a P.
It is harder than it sounds, but worth the work if you're interested.

It's a good class to have the theoretical background in democratic thought. Lecture is not always the most interesting but the readings and assignments are fair and it is important for students interested in politics to know. (Also, John was a great preceptor if you can have him.)
It's a lot of reading, but he paints a good picture of the main scholars out there. He's a fair grader. I'd recommend to anyone interested in politics; it's a necessary class.
Its a good PHI/POL departmental if you haven't engaged with classic political texts yet.

Look for other POL classes first. It's decent, not great. Grades are fair and assignments not especially difficult. A sketch of Pettit's readings which are provided at the beginning of each lecture are all you need to study.. but not particularly interesting as a class after the midterm.
Only take it if you know you are interested in ancient political theory and philosophy.
Pretty chill class and you get to read a lot of famous philosophers' works.
Professor Pettit is an excellent lecturer and the course provides an interesting and organized analysis of the history of democratic theory.

Professor Pettit suggests particular reads of texts that befit his narrative of political intellectual history. It would be worthwhile to read through the texts wholly and carefully to allow for more critical thought regarding the issues at hand. Note that the entirety of the latter half of the course, Professor Pettit's theoretical analysis of the subject matter, is all available in his recently published "Just Freedom."
Take it if you're interested in political theory, particularly democracy.
Take it!
Take it, it's not too hard.
Take it. Go to lectures/precepts and at least do some of the reading.
Take the class!! Pettit is awesome.
Take this Course

Take this class. It is highly manageable, with readings as more of a way to guide your understanding of the arc of political theory, centered on notions of democracy. The more you read and attend lectures, the more meaningful everything will be, especially in the last couple of weeks when you look at modern democracies and problems. Lastly, Prof. Pettit and Preceptor John DiIulio are both magnificent. Highly recommend.
The lectures and the readings had a lot of crossover, doing one might be enough.

The reading load is fairly manageable, if dense. Prof. Pettit's lectures are good, but you've definitely got to go and be really committed to paying attention to follow him. A solid POL distribution requirement.
The readings are dense, but do them, and do not fall behind.  The course moves more quickly than you think

This course focuses almost completely on theory, and not really on how theories have been implemented, so much of the course is extremely abstract. If that's your thing, go for it, but it wasn't really my thing.
This is a great introduction to political theory. Take the course and do the readings.
This is an engaging course with a focus on close readings and group discussion.
This is an interesting and valuable course for anyone interested in politics.
Use lecture notes to help derive the real meanings of long reading assignments. Don't lose these notes, they are the most valuable part of the class.

Whether you have only a vague interest in democratic theory or want to be a Political Theory major, this is a must-take course! Plus,  Prof. Pettit teaches in Australia half the time, so you should seize the rare opportunity to take his class. The papers, tests, and readings are fair and engaging, and Pettit really cares about his students.
Would recommend this class if willing to grapple with tough concepts.
would recommend
descrip: This course will introduce students to the principal historical figures in thinking about democracy: Aristotle, Hobbes, Rousseau, Mill, Schumpeter and others. But the rationale of the course is philosophical rather than historical. Let democracy require that government be of the people, by the people and for the people: that the people be the ultimate governing authority, that they be the agents by whom government is conducted, and that they be the beneficiaries in whose interest government is exercised. The aim of the course will be to see whether there is a plausible and appealing sense in which those conditions can be fulfilled.

title: Designing Real Systems
reviews: Be prepared to get challenged - just like every other ELE class.
Don't take unless you need to
I mean, if you're ELE, you have to take it, but don't dread it because it's a really great class!
If you're ELE, it's no longer painful and actually very helpful! If you're not ELE, you aren't taking it!
If you're ELE, you don't have a choice.  The course is fine, and you'll learn a lot.  If you're not ELE I wouldn't recommend it.
It's a requirement for ELE anyway, so if you're an ELE, you have to take it. I enjoyed it though, a lot of good material synthesizes everything from sophomore year.
It's a work in progress. The profs are nice people and they mean well. You also don't have a choice. I recommend, because ELE's a cool major, but not necessarily from this class.

Keep in mind that (at least for next year) there are four different professors with very different teaching styles. Use this course as an opportunity to "try them out", and don't be too discouraged if you can't follow one too well?

Taking COS217 will help you a lot in this course. Other than that you will learn fundamental Electrical Engineering problem solving skills that you will develop during the semester(so "preparation for that needed").
This class made me want to give up ELE and caused me to develop a strong resentment for labs. And in feeling this way, I was certainly not alone.

Well, obviously ELE majors are required to take this, and other than ELE majors this class is more or less only taken by people who are ELE majors in all but name. If you're one of those people, you know who you are so you don't need a recommendation from me.
You have to take it if you're ELE. Good luck.
prereqs: ELE 201.
descrip: This course focuses on the science, engineering, and design of the highly integrated systems that dominate many of today's devices. Analysis of systems, sub-systems, and basic principles will be covered, with an emphasis on hardware-software optimization, sampling and digitization, signal and noise, feedback and control, and communication.

title: Systematic Ethics
descrip: A graduate course on practical reasoning.

title: Claims and Evidence in Sociology
reviews: Ask to meet with Rachael or your preceptor if you ever need guidance.  Also don't be afraid to ask questions, even if Rachael is mean about it.  And do your best on every assignment, because they really will help you on your paper.
Be flexible with ideas and diligent about writing assignments.
Do all of the assignments!
GET RACHAEL FOR PRECEPT
Get ready to write a lot.
Get to know the lecturer very well.
Get your data as early as possible so you have time to figure out how to analyze it.
I mean, everyone who's in it has to take it. But it's a surprisingly good class and it will help you SO MUCH with your independent work if you pay attention and keep up.
I would recommend that you do well on the weekly assignments because it will make doing the final paper much easier.
If you're a sociology major, you have to take this course.  It's not so bad!
Obviously only take it if you're a soc major.
One of the reasons to be a soc major!
Only take it if you have to... and you do, since you are a SOC major.
Rachael is awesome but the course itself is boring.
Show up to class. She grades attendance. Go to her office hours, and get to know her.
Take this course if you are a sociology major, if you don't you're screwed.  Otherwise you can't, so that's too bad.
The department really cares about you!

This class is for junior Sociology majors. Make sure to follow all directions on the assignments. DO all the assignments. Each of them are a separate part of your paper, and if you do them very well, all you have to at the end is put them all together. Also, (especially if you have Rachael) silence your phone, because if it goes off during class, you get to buy everyone candy. So if you don't like spending money...
You have to take it, so take it!  It's good and if you put effort into the weekly assignments it will help you when it comes time for the final paper.
have a precept with heather. always attend lecture -- rachael makes class really interesting regardless of what the subject matter is.
prereqs: SOC 101 or another 200-level sociology course.
descrip: This is a course on the logic of social research. We discuss how sociologists apply a specific approach of inquiry we call "science" to analyze and explain social behavior. While surveying a wide range of methods, we will learn how research questions can be answered by using various combinations of theory, methods, and data. Three assumptions about society will be examined: 1) Durkheimian notion of "society as a thing"; 2) society as a composite of variables; 3) society as a meaning-producing process. Students will learn how to formulate a research question and how to marshal empirical data to make a sociological argument.

title: Advanced Quantum Mechanics
descrip: This is a one-semester course in advanced quantum mechanics. The emphasis is on systems with many degrees of freedom: dynamics, mixed states, entanglement, measurement, coherent states.

title: Posture and Imposture in Romanticism - Chameleon Poets: Posture and Imposture in the Romantic Age
descrip: "What shocks the virtuous philosopher, delights the camelion poet," wrote Keats, while Byron declared that "there's a sure market for imposture." Even as the Romantics cultivated the posture of poetic authenticity, they also invented avatars, disguises, doppelgangers, shape-shifters and shameless frauds. In readings of Wordsworth, Byron, Keats, Hemans, Robinson, Equiano, Hogg, and Scott, we explore the dialectic between posture and imposture in the Romantic age as an allegory of form, a theater of the self, and a triumph of Romantic irony. Discussion frequently focuses on approaches to teaching these texts.

title: Analysis II: Complex Analysis
reviews: Avoid this course if taught by Rordnianski. Self-study with the textbook (Stein and Shakarchi, Complex Analysis) is a reasonable alternative.
If Stein teaches this again, take it with him.
If you are a math major you don't have an excuse not to take this course.

Keep slightly ahead of the lectures in the readings?this way, you can answer Rodnianski's in-class questions more easily. He covers chapters 1 through 5 and then skips to chapter 8. Be warned?he assigns copious amounts of problems (not exercises) from the textbook, so the homework is often far more difficult than the lectures would imply.

Prof. Rodnianski lectures well - he forces you to think for yourself while still providing important insight. However, the professor's commitment to the course was questionable. It was pretty obvious he'd rather not be teaching.

The class itself is pretty tough, but offers some rewarding material. Take it if you were confident with real analysis.
Rodnianski is a good lecturer, but he can often be unaccommodating to students. The problem sets and midterm were extremely difficult. You will learn a lot in this class, however.
Start problem sets early and do the readings.
Take it with Stein if possible.
Take it! It's a good class (hard but rewarding). Make sure to start the problem sets early and do the reading though.
The material is quite interesting, but just don't take this class with Igor Rodnianski!!!
This class is really difficult.

This is a good required class. Stein's book is awesome. I would recommend studying it in detail.
