Rodnianski is pretty good teacher (though very blunt and often hard to communicate with - there were no office hours, didn't respond to emails, and I don't even think the teacher met the preceptor or grader until halfway through the course (if ever...).

This is a very great course and Stein's book is amazing. Igor is a great lecturer but is not approachable at all for questions and neither was the preceptor. TBH the grader was the only one who actually cared about us. But the material is very interesting and very elegant. I recommend taking it with Stein if he still is teaching. If you are taking it with Igor, expect no help from the teacher.
You are probably only taking this if you are a math major fulfilling the complex requirement.

You will have to work much more independently in this course. In most other math courses, office hours are a great resource, but Professor Rodnianski doesn't hold them and is not particularly eager about helping students with the problem sets.
psets are hard. read the proofs in the book so you know what's actually going on
prereqs: MAT215 or MAT 218 or equivalent..
descrip: Study of functions of a complex variable, with emphasis on interrelations with other parts of mathematics. Cauchy's theorems, singularities, contour integration, power series, infinite products. The gamma and zeta functions and the prime number theorem. Elliptic functions, theta functions, Jacobi's triple product and combinatorics. This course is the second semester of a four-semester sequence, but may be taken independently of the other semesters.

title: Evolutionary Biology
reviews: DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE! Unless you're an EEB major like me, in which case you have no choice.
Don't take the course if you don't have to. Expect things to be poorly organized.
I would try to avoid this class if possible. But not the worst if only choice to fulfill the evolution requirement.

I wouldn't take it unless you have to for EEB. Material itself is interesting, but lectures are monotonous and precepts are pretty boring and unhelpful. Also very frustrating that your final grades essentially comes from 2 grades: midterm and final. This gives students little room for error, and the professor didn't tell us what letter grades the midterm distribution correlated to so no one really knew how they were doing in the class. Very little work involved in this class because the textbook and assigned readings are useless, but unless you can pay attention to monotonous lectures (with material that is sometimes unclear and even contradictory) and then remember them for the 2 graded assessments you have, you're out of luck. This class needs to be revamped because it has potential, but just kind of misses.
If vonHoldt is the lecturer do not take it.
If you have to take this course, I'm sorry. If not, just don't do it. There are lots of other courses that talk in much more interesting ways about evolution.
If you're EEB, it's required. Do whatever you have to to survive lecture, and read the book after.
If you're considering EEB as a major, don't base it off this course. EEB is awesome. If you're just taking an EEB course out of interest, take a different one.
It is a fairly challenging course but the material is interesting ad also essential to understanding evolution.
It's an important subject but Professor vonHoldt does not do a good job teaching it.
Not super interesting, but not terrible either.
Only take this class if you have to.
Read the book and try to get as much as you can from that because you wont get much from lecture.
Sorry that you are still required to sit through this :(
Take it if you have to
Take the course.
Take this course if you are an EEB major.  That's all.

The material is definitely important for EEB majors to know. If you want to do well, make sure you read the textbook and use lecture to solidify what you learn from the book. Do the practice problems.
The workload is lighter, but make sure you have some personal interest in evolution or the material can be quite dry at times.

This class has the potential to be very interesting and stimulating.  However, the course does not reach its full potential the way it is taught as of now with Professor von Holdt.  In fact, it reaches very little of its potential.  I think those that succeeded in this class are students that have and undying interest in this material and have endless patience and persistence to wade through the murky, inconsistent material presented in lecture and precept, and read the textbook consistently throughout the semester to find out and remember what we were actually supposed to know. The majority of students are just not like that and even for those devoted individuals, finding that information was way more difficult than it should have been.  Given how prolific von Holdt is in her field she should be a wealth of knowledge but I think she's unable to present the material in a logical manner and design an actual course. Lectures are boring and difficult to follow.  My preceptor didn't do a great job of explaining the gaps in our knowledge left by lectures.  von Holdt can be difficult to approach at times and has sent some passive aggressive emails but I think at the end of the day she means well.  Just read the textbook, do problems that are presented at the back of each textbook chapter, and go to her for clarification.

This course is fine. Some of the topics are dry, such as the equations involving quantitative genetics, but the material is not too difficult, and concepts are explained well for the most part. I would recommend following along in the textbook to reinforce ideas, although it is not always clear which section of the textbook the lectures correspond to.
This is not a good course; if you are interested in the topic, the course is badly taught and too slow, and if you aren't, it is tedious.
Try and discuss the material as much as possible. The lingo and way of thinking is really important to get accustomed to.
You have to take this if you are EEB because it is the only EVO. Otherwise, there are better bio classes available.
avoid this class at all class, but you can't, becuase it's required. the best lecture of the whole class was the guest lecture
don't take it unless you have to
take it if you're interested in evolution. The material is interesting and possibly very useful in the years to come
prereqs: EEB 211 and any course in molecular biology or equivalent (e.g. 214 or 215).
descrip: All life on Earth has evolved and continues to evolve. This course will explore evolution at both the molecular and organismal level. We will examine the features that are universal to all life and that document its descent from a common ancestor that lived over 3 billion years ago. Topics include the origin of life, the evidence for natural selection, methods for reconstructing evolutionary history using DNA, population genetics, genome evolution, speciation, extinction, and human origins. This course will provide you with the basic tools to understand how evolution works and can produce the incredible diversity of life on our planet.

title: Topics in Medieval Philosophy - Theories of the Soul
prereqs: Course also open to advanced undergraduates, with permission of instructor..
descrip: Late medieval theories of the soul, focusing on Aquinas, Scotus, and Ockham, with guest appearances from minor figures when they shed light on problems.

title: Introduction to PDE
prereqs: Introduction to Real Analysis (MAT320) or equivalent, or consent of instructor..
descrip: The course is a basic introductory graduate course in partial differential equations. Topics include: Laplacian, properties of harmonic functions, boundary value problems, wave equation, heat equation, Schrodinger equation, hyperbolic conservation laws, Hamilton-Jacobi equations, basic function spaces and inequalities, regularity theory for second order elliptic linear PDE, De Giorgi method, basic harmonic analysis methods, linear evolution equations, existence, uniqueness and regularity results for classes of nonlinear PDE with applications to equations of interest in differential geometry.

title: Social and Political Lives of Humor, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Reading Literature: Fiction
reviews: Although I really enjoyed this class, I would only recommend it if you're a perspective English major or decided English major and need to take it. The novels are interesting, but the course serves mainly as a broad survey of narrative fiction and I don't think there's much depth there. If you're looking for a good English class, there are so many more specific/in-depth ones out there!
Be sure to talk through your paper ideas before hand- the office hours are super helpful.
Do all the readings. Have fun with the material.
Do the reading. You'll feel much more comfortable in precept and have a lot more to offer.
Don't check out the books for this course from the library. I recommend actually buying them at Labyrinth so you can read them over and over again in the future.
Go to office hours before the papers because she is really helpful one on one and try to get in her precept too.

I would definitely recommend this class. Professor Chihaya gives great lectures, and Robert is a wonderful preceptor. It is a lot of reading, so maybe don't take it if you have a very reading-heavy schedule. But otherwise, go for it!

I would definitely recommend this course for any prospective English majors, and maybe anyone else who is interested in relatively modern literature. The course material was super interesting and went through a whole section of history to show a sort of evolution of literature.
If Chihaya is teaching it, take it!!!! She is an incredible lecturer.
If you're enrolled in the course already, you are making good life decisions, son.
If you're not taking it as a prereq maybe choose a more specific class, but this is a great one anyway. Professor Chihaya is really awesome.

It is ~a book a week, so if you have time, get started on the reading list beforehand. That's pretty standard advice for English classes, I think. Also, some of the works are available online, which is really handy, but you'll still need some way of obtaining the proper citations from the edition that the professor specifies (like borrowing a friend's copy).
It's a great class! Very well taught, interesting lectures and precept discussions, good reading list and generally interesting. Professor Chihaya is an awesome professor and is very approachable.

Plan out when you will do the readings since you have to finish one 200pg book each week and be sure to highlight or take down any parts of the book that stood out to you or you really reflected on. That will help with writing the Blackboard posts. And do not try to fake your way through the post because you didn't read the book, it's really obvious when compared to other student's posts. Do the readings and you'll be fine.

Read the books and take notes on important passages, you're going to want to be able to reference them in precept, your blackboard posts, and your papers. Try to stay awake during lectures, especially if you want to know the professor's take on a novel.
Take if you like fiction
Take it for your 200 level pre req. Great reading list usually and not too much work
Take the course!
Take this course if you are genuinely interested in the readings you will do. Otherwise it's a bit much. It's a LOT of reading. Try to get the booklist ahead of time and do reading in advance.

The reading list for this course is very "accessible" in my opinion. None of the books are too dense, and most are quite fun to read. Additionally, Professor Chihaya does an excellent job of providing her own considerable insight while allowing for students to cultivate their own views as well.
prereqs: Prospective concentrators are required to take ENG 200 and one course from the following: ENG 205, 206, 207, 208..
descrip: The making and interpretation of fictions are among our everyday activities, whether or not we realize it; however, we don't always consider what "fiction" is, or what it means. This course will introduce students to the diverse and specific forms fiction takes in literature, with emphasis on the novel and film. We will interrogate the act of creating fictions, and the impact a fictional world can make on a reader. Along the way, we will continually consider two deceptively simple questions: what does fiction do to us? What can fiction do for us?

title: Topics in 20th-Century Art
reviews: How much you put into the class will be how much you gain out of it.
It's specific but great.

Take it if you are interested in questioning whatever preconceived notions you may hold of art, the creative process, art history, museums, the curatorial process. The course is experimental not only in that it studies experimental art, but also in that it experiments with the idea of placing students in a position of power, and giving them the independence to conceive of a vision for an exhibition and actually bring that vision to fruition.
Take it!
Take it. It works best if you'e invested and interested not if you're simply just trying to sit in casually.
descrip: Exhibiting Experimentalism: Experimental art by definition involves process, discovery, contingency, and the possibility of failure. Museums, by contrast, are institutions traditionally dedicated to the care and preservation of artifacts with permanent value. What then are the possibilities for experiencing experimental work within a museum? Using recent acquisitions of contemporary art by the Princeton University Art Museum as case studies, students will investigate questions of historiography, pedagogy, transgression, critical exhibition practices, and curatorial ethics, culminating in the organization of an exhibition at the museum.

title: Imagining Childhood
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Policy Analysis: Selected Topics (Half-Term) - State and Local Finance
descrip: Examines budgeting and finance at the state and local level of government. Topics include: budget structure and process; decision makers within the political and economic environment; debt, capital planning and bond financing; revenue structures supporting expenditures. Tax policy and associated tradeoffs between tax equity and efficiency and spending and program needs are also examined. Two case studies are utilized---one related to state and local tax policy and one related to budgetary decision-making.

title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to Western Culture I: Literature and the Arts
reviews: But only if you are actually interested in/enjoy the humanities - painful (think, readings) if you aren't. If you are not a humanities major, also good for fulfilling distribution requirements - but you should still be interested or else the readings will be tough.

HUM is impossible and amazing and beautiful and frustrating and rewarding. Read as much as you can, but don't sweat skimming--it's inevitable. It's going to suck, and you'll hate it, but you'll also love it in some sick way. Make sure you really stay on one passage for the papers-- they will give you c's. Not reading won't really catch up to you until the final, so be consistent in at least reading some of all the books. The best part of the course will really happen outside of it-- the community you build and all the awesome lunch/late meal/late-night discussions you'll have with fellow HUMies. Take the course. You'll regret it, and yet you really won't be able to stay away.

I found these reviews very helpful when I was picking courses so I will give here a lengthier review. HUM is slightly less challenging than what many of us expected. In fact, this course is indeed "what you want out of it" in that you really do have quite a bit of leeway in regards to how you spend your time doing the work, thereby making the tremendous amount of reading more manageable and interesting. For example, if you are particularly interested in philosophy, you can speed read the history and literature to get the flavor of the author and text but then slow down and digest all the philosophy, then write all of your essays on philosophy, spend time talking to the philosophy professors, etc. Thus if you're interested in either history, literature, or philosophy (or some combination but not necessarily but potentially all) then I highly recommend HUM. The course truly is about the books with the lectures, precepts, and essays as supplementary so if you have the discipline perhaps this course isn't absolutely necessary since one could simply read all the books but having the structured course and guidance was valuable. One particular benefit from reading the books in HUM I didn't realize going in was that every time we read a text by some author, we have by that point already read many of the texts that the author himself read which gave great context to understanding the text but also was enjoyable since we were following an incredible intellectual journey of western thought. Fair warning though, it seems that HUM gives out lower grades than what one would hope for, so I must say, having the perspective of taking HUM to change your view on things and introduce you to new ideas and personal improvement is definitely healthier and less stressful than focusing on grades. Highly recommended nevertheless!

I would recommend against taking this course. You read a lot of great works, but you may have to wade through things you're less interested in. The lectures are good but at ONE LECTURE A BOOK you won't get much out of it.

If you are a humanities lover, take it!! And if you don't feel ready as a freshman, do it as a  sophomore. After being super on-the-fence, I finally decided to take the class and am so glad I did. The readings are amazing and thought-provoking, and in an ideal world, every educated person would be familiar with them. The lectures are excellent, with top-notch professors who also provide insight into pedagogical differences as they each handle the texts in their own ways. The precepts are really special, with a much higher level of student engagement than in other courses I've taken here, and it's easy to make HUM friends both inside and outside the classroom. The papers are hard to write, but practicing them definitely helps you improve your essay-writing abilities in general, and the workload of the course is manageable (much more manageable than people make it out to be--don't be scared!). HUM feels like a bigger experience, something more than a class, and you get to delve into the texts to a substantial degree despite the survey nature of the course. Advice for when you take HUM: Don't fall behind on readings by more than a couple of days, or you will lose motivation to catch up and get swamped. If you can, set aside time so that you finish the reading for a particular lecture one day before that lecture, leaving yourself a little buffer room for unforeseen interruptions to your reading schedule. And definitely do as much of the readings as you can! This course revolves around the texts, and I think personally engaging with the books is key to fully enjoying lectures and precepts.

If you are considering a major in Classics, Comp Lit, English, Philosophy, Politics, Religion, Sociology, or History (like me!), this is a must-take, as it covers (broadly) all of Western Civilization for the last few thousand years. You should also take it if you want to be a well-read, knowledgeable person in general. Some students may complain about the workload, but I tell you, it is well worth it. You will almost certainly never read this much, and this well, on your own.
If you are considering this course, you should take it if possible. Be prepared for a lot of reading, but other than that there is not much work.

If you are even remotely considering taking the HUM Sequence, you absolutely must do it. I know many students who regret not taking HUM, whereas no one in HUM regrets having taken it. This is a once in a lifetime educational opportunity to learn from some of Princeton's best professors about incredible works that form the foundation of so many other disciplines. Suggestions are to be sure you do the summer reading, plan a consistent reading schedule (you get much more out of the class if you do the readings before lecture), utilize the Writing Center and your grader's office hours for the papers, and to come to precepts with prepared quotes you'd like to discuss. Just be on top of your game and be efficient with your time and you'll be fine. Remember this is a double class, so while it may seem like an insane amount of work, it is very doable if you are focused and committed.

It is a lot of work and you will spend a lot of time reading, especially if you do all of the reading. But if you're willing to put in the time and effort it is by far the most rewarding class I have taken at Princeton
It is a lot of work, but good time management and inspiration to read make the workload feel negligible.

It's a very particular experience - if you really want to get a sense of an era and of the whole broad history of Western thought, you'll love HUM. You have to be willing to put in the work, but the professors honestly go really easy on us overall and talking to them twice a week is honestly worth the price of admission. HUM will really educate you and bond you with a great, tight group of people.
It's an insane amount of work. If you want to read the material then it's worth it.
It's so worth the time and energy invested, I can't think of a single person I wouldn't recommend this course to.

KNOW HOW TO READ THE TEXTS. (You will learn how to read/skim over the course of the year.) Regardless, HUM is an extremely time consuming course, and should be treated as such. Don't cheat yourself by skimping on the effort you can put in. You are surrounding yourself with some of the most intellectually stimulating classmates in your year (or the year above), and also are attending lectures given by 6  professors (some guest lecturers!) who are experts in their respective fields. Enjoy the course for the experience, don't stress too much over the grades. Your enthusiasm and effort are the best things you can bring to the course; even if you have little to no experience in the literature or fields of study of this course (like I didn't), I am certain you will still enjoy the course immensely and perform well as well.

Only take this class if you are interested in the subject matter and believe that you have the time to read and think about most of the works. If you have the time and interest, this class is unbeatable.
READ EVERYTHING. It's all work that you want to have read anyway
Read for overall understanding.
Stay a week ahead of the readings and you won't be stressed.
Stay on top of the reading because, otherwise, the pace of the class will leave you in the dust.
TAKE IT. ABSOLUTELY TAKE IT.
Take HUM, if you can; the essays are difficult, but the reward of reading great texts is more than worth the effort required for this calss.
Take HUM- you will learn from some of the best professors and meet a lot of great people. It's really an excellent class.

Take HUM. My freshman first semester (and I'm sure this will apply to my second) was largely shaped by HUM. I made such wonderful friends - the HUM community is very close-knit - and met such wonderful professors that I probably wouldn't have come into contact with otherwise. The reading is certainly manageable if you don't let it pile up week after week, and the books are so iconic and interesting that it isn't too difficult to push through it. The one thing I wish I had done more of is go to more office hours, because the professors are really approachable, helpful, and knowledgeable. I loved HUM - everyone I know loved HUM - and you'll probably love it, too.
Take it!!! It's difficult but so worth it. The professors and lectures are great and it's a really special way to start your academic career at Princeton.

The course is intensive, but not undoable. 400 pages a week sounds daunting at first, but you get used to it rather quickly. That HUM is a double course also makes up for this. Definitely not unmanageable with an otherwise normal schedule, just be sure you really have the drive to commit to these works - i.e. fundamental texts of the Western Canon. The course moves very quickly, so it's easy to get behind. Don't necessarily expect to fully understand all any of the works have to offer from this course. HUM is more of a tasty platter of hors d'oeuvres than it is a series of entrees. You will get a thorough introduction to each work on the syllabus, which for me only increased my desire to revisit them later.

This class is not meant to closely analyze every work that you are assigned to read.  Understand the nature of the course - gleaning a general overview of western civilization- and enjoy the course for what it is meant to be.

This is the best opportunity available to incoming freshman here. I would highly recommend you consider taking it if you have even the remotest interest in the works read. If you're willing to put in the time to do the readings and papers, it will be an incredible course. It might seem overwhelming when you see 400-600 pages a week and your friends might discourage you from taking it, but remember that it is a double course and if you enjoy it the course won't feel like much work at all. TAKE IT
You should take it!
prereqs: This course is primarily directed to exceptional freshmen, but sophomores are also welcome to apply. Further information about the course and application instructions are available at http://humanities.princeton.edu. The course fulfills the prerequisite for the certificate in Interdisciplinary Studies in the Humanities..
descrip: This course, along with HUM 217, form the first part of an intensive yearlong exploration of the landmark achievements of the Western intellectual tradition. With an interdisciplinary team of faculty drawn from the humanities and social sciences, students examine pivotal texts, events, and artifacts of European civilization from antiquity to the middle ages as part of an ongoing cultural conversation. The course is enhanced by guest lectures and cultural excursions to museums, concerts, and plays. The two courses, taken together, total six hours a week and fulfill distribution requirements in both LA and HA.

title: African American Literature: Origins to 1910
reviews: Be sure to do the readings, but don't stress too much if you can't get to it. Get to know Prof. Brown and work with him. He's very understanding and wants all of his students to succeed. He also has a wide breadth of knowledge about English lit, Af Am lit, and the law.

Take it if you have any interest in AAS or literature, but I guess that's an obvious comment. Prof. Brown is already good as a new professor at Princeton and will become great once he has a few years under his belt.
Take it if you need to.
Take it.
Try hard to participate.
descrip: This introductory course focuses on texts from the mid-eighteenth century through the early 20th century; it will cover early texts such as poetry by Phillis Wheatley & Paul Laurence Dunbar; oratory by David Walker, Sojourner Truth; slave narratives by Frederick Douglass, Harriet Jacobs; spirituals; black theatre by Pauline Hopkins, Bert Williams; fiction by Charles Chesnutt, James Weldon Johnson; & non-fiction by W.E.B.DuBois, Anna Julia Cooper, Booker T. Washington. The course explores how black literature engages with the politics of cultural identity formation, notions of freedom, citizenship, and aesthetic forms.

title: Graphic Design: Visual Form
reviews: Don't expect to learn practical knowledge of Adobe products so much as theory; the practical stuff you will mostly have to pick up on your own.

It's a good class with a very friendly professor. It's the kind of class where learning is done by self-exploration, and if you haven't taken a class like that before I recommend that this be the first one.
Set aside time in the evenings to go into the studio, preferable during the scheduled time.
Strongly recommend if you want to take an introductory class on graphic design
TAKE IT.
Take it!
Take this course with David and get to know him!

The course is a little bit theoretical.  Don't expect it to (directly) teach you how to become a freelance graphic/web designer.  Instead, expect to read a bunch of historical essays about ways to think about design (including gestalt psychology).  Also expect assignments like "design a black-and-white symbol that means 'stop', without using conventions like an X or a raised hand".

That said, I really enjoyed the course.  Even if it doesn't focus on practical training, I loved that it got me thinking about design for a solid chunk of time each week.  And Professor Reinfurt is super nice, knowledgeable, and helpful!
descrip: This course introduces students to techniques for decoding and creating graphic messages in a variety of media, and delves into issues related to visual literacy through the hands-on making and analysis of graphic form. Graphic design relies on mastering the subtle manipulation of abstract shapes and developing sensitivity to the relationships between them. Students are exposed to graphics from the late 19th-century to the present in slide lectures. Studio assignments and group critique will foster an individual ability to realize sophisticated forms and motivate these towards carrying specific meanings.

title: The Politics of Development
reviews: A good class, but the mix of nit-picky quizzes, 3 essays, and a final can get a bit overwhelming. For people who love theory, remember that this is a WWS class, so there is a lot of "problem-solving."
Definitely interesting but don't take it unless it is going to be your hardest class because she puts a lot on your plate

Do not take it. Widner was extremely passive aggressive in emails about how many questions she had to field for papers that were entirely her fault. Changed instructions to a paper within a few days of it being due. If you have other options I would recommend against this course.
Do not take this course.
Do the readings - at least skim them
Don't take it with this prof unless you have to.
Find another WWS departmental.
Go to lecture. Don't take if you're not in WWS or politics.
Good POL class, but definitely take a 200 POL class and perhaps ECO 100 before you enter this one. If you have a genuine interest in development, this is the course for you.
Good introduction to theoretical framework for development. Reasonable course load.
Great departmental course. Well taught and interesting.

I am not required to take this course, but wanted to learn something new.  I thought that I definitely learned something and the workload was very manageable.  Not the easiest course but certainly not the hardest.
I heard this class was taught a lot better in the years before when there was a different professor. Material is good, teaching staff not so much
I would recommend another student take this course.
I would recommend this course to anyone with even a passing interest in the study of economic development.

If Jennifer Widner is teaching this class DON'T take it. In fact, don't take it at all if you're frustrated by the Western-perspective that pervades most classes at Princeton, but views on developing countries in particular. But especially don't take it with Widner--the lectures are terrible, the way the course is run is insane (3 blackboard quizzes, 3 papers due at random times depending on what paper option you have to do which are 8-10 pages and 1.5 spaced AND a final), and the readings, while interesting, are often overwhelming. Just to further discourage you, some Jennifer Widner quotes, "poor Africa," "I can't pronounce this...any Koreans in the class?" "Botswana was a happy story of colonialism"...I hope I've made my case.

If Professor Widner is teaching it, it is a must-take course for any POL, WWS, HIS majors. I think a lot of other majors would still get a lot out of the course, but I am biased towards being fascinated by the material because I'm a WWS major. Loved it, papers were doable and flexible, which is fantastic. Readings were long some times, but I managed to do it for the most part during my busiest semester, so that shouldn't be a concern.
If you are interested in developmental issues, take this course. Professor Widner is a great lecturer and if you can get into her precept, do it!
If you're interested in working in development, this course is fantastic. Prof Widner is great, take advantage of office hours.
Interesting topics. Readings were much more helpful than lecture.
Isn't as good as the description sounds.
It is an interesting course. It does have three papers and three auto-graded quizzes so plan accordingly.
My favorite course so far at Princeton! Not too challenging if you stay on top of the weekly readings. If you're interested in development, definitely take this class!
Not great but required for WWS so w/e
Plan the papers in advance.
Prepare to do a lot of work. There are 3 papers, 3 quizzes and a final. It's crazy.

Read all the material.
Write your essays in advance.
Ask other preceptors for help because the professor was often too busy.
Really dig into the concepts, and think about real life examples.
Still a fine class to take
Still fairly interesting subject matter

TAKE THIS COURSE! It is a challenge but you will learn so much. The lectures are engaging, and the readings are interesting. There is a fair amount of written work, but the essays are manageable and interesting. GET MARCUS AS A PRECEPTOR!
Take good lecture notes!
Take it if you are at all interested in development!

Take it if you need to, but be warned that it might be more work than you bargained for. It is interesting and makes you think hard, but be ready for disorganized assignments and late feedback on written work
Take it if you're interested in development at all. It'll open your eyes to a lot of different perspectives that you'd probably never deeply considered before.
Take it just because the material is super interesting, but the organization was poor and it was way more work than it should have been.
Take it! Keep up with the readings.
Take it! Prof. Widner demands a lot of work, but if you put it, you'll get back a lot!!
Take the class if you are interested in development, but definitely be willing to think hard and form your own opinions about the class
Take!
The best decision I made was to work with other students in a team. I do not imagine that I could have possibly passed the course if I had not.

The concepts of this class have the potential to be interesting, but unless Widner is not teaching it or she consolidates the structure of the course significantly, I would avoid this class. The amount of work put in for the hazy understandings of the key issues was not a reasonable trade. Perhaps just read Why Nations Fail and call it a day.
This course can be a bit dry and difficult to understand in the beginning but I really enjoyed it by the end of it! Take it if you'd like to get a broad overview of international development.
This course is very interesting and will introduce wide array of ideas about development.
This is a good course if you want to learn about development theories and applications.
Unless you have an econ background don't take this class.
if you can pdf, take it!
prereqs: Not open to freshmen without permission of instructor..
descrip: This course investigates the key political drivers of human development through careful consideration of theory and comparative analysis. Explores the effects of geography, colonial heritage, and ethnic diversity, on state formation, state capacity, and economic development.

title: Quantitative Analysis (Advanced)
descrip: Statistical analysis with applications to public policy. The course begins with an introduction to probability theory followed by discussion of statistical methods for estimating the quantitative effects of changes in policy variables. Regression methods appropriate for the analysis of observational data and data from randomized controlled experiments are stressed. The basic level (507B) assumes a fluency in high school algebra and some familiarity with calculus, while the advanced level (507C) assumes a fluency in calculus.

title: Microeconomic Analysis: Basic
descrip: Course develops an understanding of basic microeconomic tools. Emphasis is placed on how these tools can be used for policy analysis. Students need not have taken any other economics courses, but should have a good command of algebra and be familiar with basic calculus concepts, although proficiency in calculus is not necessary.

title: Dante's Inferno: A guide to hell (and back)
descrip: Please see website

title: From DNA to Human Complexity
reviews: Do not just memorize the notes....think of different scenarios in which you could apply what you learned to real life situations. This will really be helpful come exam time.
Does a good job for what it is: a science course for a non-science major. Pretty light work load.
Go to every lecture.
Go to lecture because they're fun and you won't be able to get enough info for the test from the slides.
Good STL but there are probably more interesting and easier STLs

Good STL course for Humanities kids. I did well in AP Bio but still got information out of this class without having to work that hard. Go to lecture and you probably won't have to PDF it if you've taken AP Bio before. Heather and Bonnie are great, I highly recommend this course.

I actually enjoyed biology after taking this class. Heather is an awesome lecturer, but Eric could not teach at all. I didn't understand anything when he lectured. Heather was very understandable and made things clear. Bonnie was really funny, but not necessarily a great explainer. The labs were pretty interesting and fun though!
I took an STL even as a BSE because I've always been interested in genetics. Totally worth it! The lecturers are beyond amazing and they're backed by a very dedicated and helpful TA-team.
I would advise carefully going over the lecture slides to review for the exams.
I would highly recommend this course to anyone, including those who have never liked science before. The class is much more that just an STL.
I would highly recommend this course.  The material is fascinating yet relatively easy to grasp, the professors are phenomenal, and the labs are fun and easy.
I would strongly recommend it if they have a general interest in biology and are in need of an STL. The course is good and very interactive. It's impossible to not learn something interesting.
If you need an STL, this is a fine one. It isn't easy, but it is doable.
If you're PDFing your STL, it might as well be this one.

If you're looking for a manageable STL where you also learn a lot, take this course! It's taught by the best professors in the MOL department, and they actually really care about you and the course, even though it's for non-science majors. Definitely highly recommended!

If you're planning to PDF an STL, this course will do the job. If you're not very good at biology, you can still pass by doing well in labs and taking notes in the lecture. If you don't plan to PDF, you will probably have to supplement your notes with other readings and ask a lot of questions because a lot of material is covered in a very short amount of time. The class isn't well-organized, and I found that the tests require a lot of rote memorization, so be prepared for that.
If you're taking it to fill an STL, great. If you want really inspiring, thought provoking science, look elsewhere.
It was fun, didn't require an unreasonable amount of work.
It's a good course staffed by good professors and teaches you biology and basic scientific literacy, and even for someone with no biology experience, it's totally manageable.
It's okay if you're just looking for an STL.
Know that most kids are coming in with an AP Bio background.
No matter what you are majoring in, take this course! It is fantastic and you will learn so much valuable information that applies to relevant issues.
Not as easy as people make it to be.
Really awesome class - hardly any work, tons of cool and valuable information about how the body works.
Really prioritize when taking notes from the slide shows.
Take it for a good STL. Teaching quality is good and overall material is interesting.
Take it if you are a non-science person needing an interesting and engaging STL.

Take it if you need to fulfill your STL. I am not a science person, and I took biology six years ago, and I didn't have to kill myself with this course. The lectures are really interesting, and the lecturers are great. In lab, you do real science! I strongly recommend this class.
Take it if you're interested in the mystery of life!
Take it!
Take it, but you will have to put in more effort than you necessarily anticipate if you want to get a better-than-mediocre grade
Take it: just make sure to study a lot for the final and don't take for granted that courses will have ended a month beforehand so it is hard to go back and memorize everything.
take if you want an easy STL class and are interested in bio
descrip: This lecture and laboratory course will acquaint non-biology majors with the theory and practice of modern molecular biology, with a focus on biological topics of current public interest. Topics include: structure of DNA, RNA, proteins, genomes and an overview of state-of-the-art technologies including cloning, recombinant DNA and PCR. The course will address how recent scientific advances affect issues relevant to human biology including forensics, stem cells, molecular evolution and the genetic basis of human traits and behaviors such as obesity and aggression.

title: Post-War French Social Theory
reviews: I would recommend this course to those with a solid grounding in philosophical texts.
It is interesting, but be prepared for very hard readings and discussions.
yes.
descrip: Using the works of thinkers such as Sartre, Merleau, Ponty, Aron, Ricoeur, Levi-Strauss, Foucault and Bourdieu, the course will present students with some of the conflicting images of Western society as viewed by these thinkers. This course will introduce students to these authors with emphasis on their departure from traditional schools of thought and the consequences of their ideas on the production of knowledge about societies. Topics will include: relation of social thought to literary criticism and theories of social description.

title: Narratives of Identity in the Other Europe: Reading Culture in the Balkans
descrip: Please see website

title: Studies in Modern Arab History - Readings in Islamic Revivalism, Islamist Politics and Law
descrip: This course aims to survey a variety of historical and religious texts in Arabic. Students must have mastery of advanced Arabic. Some of the texts that will be studied have been edited and published, others remain in manuscript form.

title: Advanced Spanish Language and Style
reviews: Alberto is an amazing teacher. He makes the subject matter very interesting. I really enjoyed the class. Also, he is very understanding and tries to avoid assigning too much work during midterms.
Alberto is great and it is an interesting class in terms of learning about the finer points of spanish conversation etc.
Alberto is great! Take this class - you will improve.
Do the readings and take notes on them since you will need them for the take home exam!
Good but requires a decent amount of work outside of class.
Make sure you do the readings before you come to class, or else you will not be able to contribute to the discussion.

Start the papers early, and make sure you do all the readings. Not only are they very helpful for learning Spanish and understanding what is spoken about in class but they are on really interesting topics so you will miss out by not doing the readings.
Strongly recommend if you are good at Spanish and want to learn about language.
Take it!
Take it!!! Alberto is a wonderful teacher and I think that he is able to completely engage students to learn more an to improve their spanish.
Take this class!! Alberto is amazing and you will learn a ton!
Take this course you will love Alberto!!
This class is awesome! The material is really interesting, though the title may sound bland. Alberto is one of the best! Take this class for sure.
This is an interesting course with a light workload, and Alberto is a really great professor.

This was a really interesting course and a welcoming environment in which to practice Spanish (although there wasn't much focus on grammar or specific ways to improve our writing in Spanish). Alberto is extremely kind and helpful, and the class was not dry at all - in fact, the material we discussed was really interesting and deepened my appreciation of Spanish and languages in general. Take it!
prereqs: SPA 207 or 209; or another 200-level Spanish course with instructor's permission. Students who have completed their Spanish language requirement through the Department's placement test or an AP 5/SP SAT ST 760 score can take the course only with instructor's permission..
descrip: SPA 307 is an advanced language course. Its main purpose is to develop and reinforce accuracy and fluency in both writing and speaking Spanish. Students will also learn to identify linguistic features that characterize different genres, as well as social and cultural factors that aid in the interpretation and understanding of different texts and types of speech. More specifically, the course aims at providing the tools for discourse analysis, raising awareness of the social and ideological values that permeate discursive practices, and developing autonomy and proficiency as an advanced learner of Spanish language.

title: Writing a World: Encounters With Difference, 1650-1850
descrip: After 1650, empire, slavery, emigration, commerce, exploration, and tourism all increased the number and range of people crossing oceans and continents. This in turn gave rise to a wealth of different narratives on encountering new cultures and peoples. Focusing on individuals moving in and out of Britain, this seminar explores what it means to change places and to observe difference, and how we can best understand texts emerging from this.

title: Game Theory
reviews: I would recommend this course
descrip: This course provides a broad treatment of game theory and its applications, particularly in economics. Coverage includes such topics as: common knowledge and rationality, refinements of Nash equilibrium, auctions, bargaining, mechanism design, dynamic games, and reputation. This follows up on the introduction to game theory provided in the microeconomic sequence.

title: Law and Economics
reviews: Definitely an interesting class that covers a lot of important material. Lectures are good, but beware that assignments can be difficult and frustrating.
Excellent for your mind, not so much for your gpa. grading is tough.
Go to office hours!

Good material, good lectures. Problem sets are graded arbitrarily and they're hard as a general rule. There's no precept and there are only 4 problem sets which are individually worth 9% of your grade so the first time you're engaging with the material is on the problem set and you're not allowed to work with anybody else so it's actually quite hard.
Grading is extremely, extremely arbitrary, but the material is interesting. You don't really need to do the readings until you get the assignments.
I would tell them to take it as it is interesting and taught well. I picked up on the topics and subjects well and enjoyed the material!
Interesting class where not too much economic knowledge is needed.
Law & Economics is quite an interesting course. I'm in the History Department, and I did fine. Problems sets are graded in a very nitpicky way, however, and it is extremely important to go to lecture

On the one hand, you learn a ton and Professor Leonard is a great and informative lecturer.  On the other hand, problem sets are frustrating and arbitrarily graded, and the strict "no cooperation with anyone on assignments, even preceptors" policy makes it hard to actually learn from the homework assignments.  All in all, take it if you're willing to suffer through some miserable assignments but want to learn about the economics of law.
Take as a distribution requirement but be prepared to spend hours on the problem sets and take home exams.
Take it if you need a non-mathy departmental. Otherwise, idk why you'd want to do so many LONG assignments with little guidance, no precept for discussion, and arbitrary grading.
Take it if you're interested in material taught in classes.
Take it only if you're really interested in law. Grading was very poor.
Take this course. Leonard makes it.
Take.
The lecture and subject matter is quite interesting. The psets are ok, but the curve is just set rather low
The lectures and the professor are great! The assignments are long and tedious and are graded harshly.

The take home assignments add a really nice balance to your schedule. Professor Leonard is really helpful and willing to chat. Take advantage of office hours when problem sets are due. Readings aren't necessary unless you are confused.

With just take-home assignments, this course is a good departmental to take in terms of workload. The material is interesting and something different from your traditional economics classes. Be sure to do the readings and learn fast how grading works.
Would strongly recommend. Leonard is a great professor and makes the subject extremely interesting. Grading can be a little arbitrary, but I got a lot out of the class.
workload is light and lectures are interesting.
prereqs: ECO 100. Course not required for concentrators..
descrip: An introduction to the economics of law. Application of price theory and welfare analysis to problems and actual cases in the common law - property, contracts, torts - and to criminal and constitutional law. Topics include the Coase Theorem, intellectual property, inalienable goods, product liability, crime and punishment, and social choice theory.

title: Studies in French Language and Style
reviews: Ask grammar questions as you have them, keep up on readings, take good class notes and focus on specific vocabulary to each story in order to help grow your knowledge of the language.

Definitely do it, but also consider the syllabus. I know I personally lost interest in the course because I much prefer other topics to fiction literature. Professor Wampole is a great professor to take a course with. Also, this course is less language focused and is more about learning how to read more complicated French text.
Definitely do the readings and watch the movies and study the grammar on your own!
Definitely participate in class- the more you contribute to discussions, the more you get out of them.

Definitely take it if you have an interest in improving your French skills and thinking in the language. It's a great survey of different sorts of French literature and film. Definitely go to office hours for final drafts of papers; Professor Wampole is extremely helpful and you can tell she wants students to learn French thoroughly as well as absorb contemporary French culture (which also includes older texts and films).
Do all of the assignments before class so you will be prepared for discussions. Engage as much as you can in the discussions. Your speaking skills will improve greatly if you do so.
Do not think you can do the minimum in this class if you really want to make your French better.
Don't be afraid to speak during class - everyone makes grammatical errors! Once you actually take risks it becomes easier to speak French.
Good class
If you want to continue to develop your French and have the time for many small, daily reading and grammar assignments, go for it!
It's a course to take if you are thinking about the certificate.
It's a good class but everyone's experience with French differs vastly.
It's a very light workload and so definitely maneagable.

Make sure to do all the readings and watch all of the films--it makes the class discussion more interesting, and you will be able to participate! Also, study groups are helpful for preparing for tests.
Make sure to read the assigned texts or watch the assigned films, so that you have more ideas to add to the class discussion.
Material is very interesting, thorough coverage of grammar. Professors are great. Up to us to participate as much as possible in class to get the most out of it though.
Necessary in the sequence of French classes to move on to more advanced ones, this class is not a throwaway if you are diligent with the often engaging readings.
Not too overwhelming with work, take it if you have a general interest in French literature and want to become better at speaking French.
Strongly recommend if you're interested in French language/culture.
Take it if you have to, there's honestly no reason to take a grammar class for fun. Don't take it if you're just trying to gauge if you want to continue taking French if you're on the borderline.
Take it!
Take this class if you want to continue your study of French and specifically focus on texts/movies as opposed to grammar!
Take this if you are looking to get back into French. It is interesting and improves language skills without a huge emphasis on small/tedious grammar details.
The course is fun and not too time-consuming. Professor Gottschall is approachable. Take it!

The syllabus for this course is incontestably great. If you have a genuine appreciation for french language and culture already, on your own, then you will surely enjoy this course. It's very much dependent on the degree to which you choose to challenge yourself, I think.

This course is a very good first step in going beyond just the language requirement. Do all the readings and watch all the films, because the exams are all about that. Enjoy yourself, because the general theme is all things unreal and imaginative. The professor is happy to help with any difficulties you may have.
This is a good, interesting course; however, if you are not solid at french already, do not expect to get better. You do not work on grammar/pronunciation nearly as much as I would have liked.

This was a good class to take after 108 before moving on to take more advanced French classes. The structure was very similar to that of 105 and 108, and there were three exams, three essays, and a take-home exam at the end. Grading was fair, and the readings were interesting. The topic was "fantasy" when I took it, and it was really interesting!
You'l be fine if you passed the AP. Doesn't require much grammar, but really important to review it.
Your French will improve during the course if you put in the time and effort. Ultimately, 207 is about what you put in.
very ok. easy. took it as my 5th class, but my French did not improve and maybe went downhill...
you have to do the work, but it's a great course for improving proficiency if you do
prereqs: FRE 107, FRE 108, or placement based on placement test..
descrip: A study of French contemporary culture and society. Intensive oral and written study of vocabulary, grammar, and idiomatic expressions prepares students for advanced courses in French literature and civilization and for working programs in French-speaking countries. Small class format. Strong emphasis on discussion. Film series. Intensive practical training in oral and written French.

title: Electromagnetism: Principles and Problem Solving (Half Term)
reviews: Same comments as in the mechanics class evaluation
Take as it does help to study for prelims.

The way it is currently, it would be rather difficult to pick up material that you don't know from the class. And for those students who know the material, going to the class is kinda moot unless you want to see a different approach to solving the questions.

The professor is good at helping you if you have very specific questions, so if you are really regimented and do problems and need someone to help you with small conceptual problems, this is a good class to do that in.
Um... hard to say. I guess I'd advise that student to try out the lectures, but study on their own if they don't work out for him/her.
You will do yourself a favor by doing problems that Haldane plans on doing ahead of time so you will make more sense of his explanations.
descrip: A graduate-level review of electromagnetism emphasizing problem-solving.

title: Archaic and Classical Greece
reviews: At first I was convinced that I would hate this class because I thought that I didn't like history. But, the material is super engaging, the reading is really not bad at all, and this class does not require a ton of work per week. This class actually helped me realize that I want to be a history major. Even if you don't want to major in history TAKE IT!! It's such a great class overall!
Do the primary readings and its a very interesting and enjoyable course
Excellent history course, teaches you a lot about Greek history / ancient world history in general. Not too much work, although the reading can be dry.
Fairly interesting course--only real complaint is that we don't get to cover Hellenistic Greece--too much time spent on Archaic Greece, of which very little is still known.
I would advise making a timeline starting from the beginning of the semester. It will help for the midterm and final to have a sense of the sequence of events.
If you have interest in the time period, take this course.
Interesting, enjoyable course. Do the readings.
It helps to be interested in Greek history and literature.
It's a good course to fulfill the HA requirement, and probably in general if one is interested in archaic and classical Greece.

It's a great course overall. Totally manageable amount of work. Perfect if you need an HA requirement. Definitely do the readings! They cover all the material you need to know and are surprisingly entertaining (especially Herodotus - the guy is a comic genius). Professor Domingo's lectures are story-like. He does an awesome job weaving different topics together and connecting with the broader themes of the course.

It's definitely a good history course to take that fulfills a distribution requirement and provides interesting material without being too demanding. Keep on top of the reading and you should do fine.
Just to the readings, all of them! That way, you'll always be on track with the lectures and material. It's not a hard course, and it's actually very rewarding.
Keep up with the reading and go to lectures because they are very interesting.
Keep up with the readings.
No specific advice, do the readings especially the Martin stuff.
TAKE THIS CLASS. Not too hard but so so so interesting. The professor is FANTASTIC.
Take it, I was very happy with it
Take it. Very interesting and not a lot of work.
Take the course with Prof. Domingo Gygax! Do the readings, attend lectures and precepts, and you'll be fine.
Take the course. It is very interesting and a good class to fulfill a departmental. Also, it is not too time consuming either.

This is a great course. There is not a huge amount of work over the semester, but the Dean's date paper and the final exam are clearly two huge burdens later on. I LOVED Professor Domingo and he clearly knew a lot about the topic. I only wish I had the chance to go to his office hours over the semester! Great course.
Very fair course. Go to lecture, take good notes, do the readings and it will be fairly easy.
take it
try to get Professor Domingo as your preceptor
descrip: The social, political, and cultural history of ancient Greece from ca.750 B.C. through the time of the Peloponnesian War (404 B.C.). Special attention is paid to the emergence of the distinctively Greek form of political organization, the city state, and to democracy, imperialism, social practices, and cultural developments. Emphasis is placed on study of the ancient sources, methods of source analysis, and historical reasoning.

title: Econometrics: A Mathematical Approach
reviews: Definitely take ECO 312 with Professor Honore, by far one of the best professors at Princeton, and easily makes the class well worth your time.

Don't need to go to lecture or precept, do the practice tests. You probably will get something wrong on the test because you'll get blindsided and going to class won't help. Just make sure you don't make stupid mistakes. Curve is not favorable considering this class is considered much harder than ECO 302, but the class itself is tbh not that hard. However, if this class did not cover too much material, I shudder to think how little is being taught in ECO 302.
Econ majors should take this one over 302, because its not that much more math. Otherwise, don't bother.
Fairly easy, not much material, but really boring.
I think that it's easy to be intimidated by this course, but it's really not bad. The math involved is not that difficult, so try it out first and then decide between this and 302.

If preceptors are the same, Dan Goetz is better than Yulong Wang. Honore is probably the better teacher for this class. If you like proving things mathematically, this class would be good for you, but you can get by being less math-oriented.
If you have to take 302 or 312, take this class.
If you're interested in how econometric tools are derived, would highly recommend.
Incredible class. Learned SO much and the professor is so passionate about the material.
It's a useful introduction to econometrics, but it isn't a good course. Take it anyway, though.
Just stay on top of your material and it should be fine.
Make sure you brush up on your stats!
Make sure you understand problem sets as you do them.

Take it and make sure that you keep up with the material and lectures throughout ( = actually understand the material). 312 is not so much more difficult than 302, the difference is that you are also told the why this is true part and not only that this is what it is. Especially take it if Prof. Honore is teaching, he is awesome.
Take it with Bo Honore--he is the man and really thorough with his teaching.
The class has a lot of former math majors, so be prepared to be shown up in lecture/precept. The material is rather dry but I trust it will be useful in the future. For the grade, take 302.

The class seems to be filled with ORF or MAT majors - take his into account when deciding whether you'd benefit from this course or not. It is definitely a good subject to know, but it is undeniably a lot of work.
This course isn't necessary unless you need economics core classes or just want to do econometric research. If you fall into that group, then go ahead.

You learn the same statistical concepts in this class and 302, but you also learn the mathematical derivations of those concepts in this class. You will be prepared to do research with both, so I would only take this course if you're interested in math. Overall, 312 was less challenging than expected, and was a very helpful course.
definitely take it. You learn a lot and if you're an economics major or intend to work with data, this course is perfect. it's not as scary as it seems.
prereqs: ECO 100, ECO 101, ECO 202 (or ORF 245), MAT 175 (or 201 and 202).
descrip: This course is an introduction to econometrics. Econometrics is a sub-discipline of statistics that provides methods for inferring economic structure from data. This course has two goals. The first goal is to give you means to evaluate an econometric analysis critically and logically. Second, you should be able to analyze a data set methodically and comprehensively using the tools of econometrics.

title: Child Language Acquisition
descrip: Please see website

title: Creative Writing (Poetry)
reviews: 100% take
A fun class that will help improve your writing, but you only get out of it what you put into it.
Absolutely take it if you have any interest whatsoever in writing poetry.

Basically this course is worth it if you like poetry and want a low-effort class. I didn't get much out of the class, other than being exposed to some good modern poetry in the readings and hearing feedback from the professor (peer feedback, which takes up most of the classes, isn't very helpful...)
Catherine was great.
Creative Writing classes are great at Princeton. Take them if you can. Professor Smith is particularly great as a teacher.
Definitely take it, especially if you are looking to satisfy a distribution requirement.
Do your work ahead of time, so you can present the best work possible!
Everyone loves poetry class - Take it with Michael Dickman if you get a chance!

For creative writers, this class is a must-take, and with Professor Wheeler it is a great opportunity for growth.  What you get is determined by what you put in, so the class will be very unfulfilling despite being decently easy if you put in almost no effort; however, that will lessen the quality of the experience for everyone else in your workshop.  But if you challenge yourself in small ways throughout the course, you'll be amazed by how much you can learn.
Have an open mind and don't be afraid to write something you've ever been unsure of or too scared to. You'll get as much out of this as you'll put in - I recommend you jump in.
Have fun in this course - be adventurous and try new things! Take the constructive criticisms well and use them to improve your work. You will get as much as you put into it!
Have fun!
I highly recommend Susan Wheeler! She is always charitable yet constructive in her opinions. The workshop itself is what you put into it.
I think every student at Princeton should take at least one creative writing course, even better if its poetry. It really made me change the way I read and write poetry.
I would definitely take this course - the professor is great with feedback (and so were my peers). Also, the assignments are interesting and very manageable.
I would definitely take this course!  Tracy is an absolutely wonderful teacher.
I would say to definitely take the class if you are at all interested in writing poetry. I learned a lot about myself as a poet and how I can improve.

If you are interested in poetry, take this class. There is no pressure and Prof. Smith is one of the best teachers. The three hours went by very quickly. As someone who had not written a lot of poetry in the past, I feel I learned a lot about the craft through the assignments, readings, and in-class discussions.
If you want to write better poetry, have a great poetry role model, and have a pension for modernism, take this course as soon as you possibly can.
It's a great course, and very interesting.

Keep on top your portfolio! Do not put off writing your final poems to the end because chances are you will forget a lot of the feedback you received. The best thing to do would be revise drafts as you go along, or at least revise the drafts you enjoyed the most.
Michael Dickman's great, and the pace/structure of this course is awesome.
Professor Dickman takes a genuine interest in your writing and loves to talk about it. Your writing can really grow in his class.
Professor Wheeler is great.  Take the class.  Just do it.
Read as much of the provided material as you can and attend the public readings!
Stop thinking and take it! Especially with Professor Smith. She is a wonderfully warm person and an incredible poet to boot. One of the best experiences of my undergrad here.
Take it if you're genuinely interested in improving as a poet; else don't waste your own and others' time.
Take it seriously. There's no reason not to put yourself out there.
Take it!
Take it! Susan Wheeler is a good prof, who will take the time to help you explore you own personal poetic interest.
Take it, if you are interested in poetry. The best class I have ever taken at Princeton.
Take it.
Take it. It's good for the soul
Take it. Prof. Dickman is the best human.
Take this class no matter what, but also make sure you're not going to take it with a PDF attitude. Prof. Wheeler is wonderful and fun!
Take this class, and don't be afraid to really let go in an assignment!
Take this course for an LA, for a 5th class, or if you have room in your schedule to explore new subject matter.
Take this course if you are generally interested in poetry and wish to develop new ways to read and write.
Take this course if you enjoy creative writing or want to learn, and are willing to push yourselves!

Take this course with Professor Smith! She is very patient and encouraging. She provides really interesting weekly prompts to guide your poetic compositions, which help you to try out a diverse range of forms and subjects. This was a wonderful, non-intimidating introduction to writing poetry.
Take this course! Professor Wheeler is great!
Take this course. Put in time and effort. You will learn. You will be excited.
Take this seriously. If you try to write a poem at the last minute it will be workshopped and dissected and you will have an excruciating time sitting there knowing your work is inadequate.
Tracy Smith is amazing in every way.
Write your poem day its assigned and work through drafts before workshop
Yay
Yes. Take it!
You get out what you put in
You get what you put into this course. Had I not been engaged, it probably would not have been as good as it was.
You will get a lot out of this course if you put in the effort!
You'll learn a lot about what you can do, and have a great time becoming better writers with your classmates.
come in with an extremely open mind
definitely take this course
prereqs: Interested students complete a Creative Writing Program application (please visit the program website) by attaching four pages of original poetry or (optionally) a paragraph explaining why they would like to take the course. Please note that this course cannot be audited. Application deadline is April 11, 2014. Accepted students will be able to enroll in SCORE May 19th-23rd..
descrip: Practice in the original composition of poetry supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. This class is open to beginning and intermediate students by application.

title: Princeton and Slavery
descrip: Research seminar focused on Princeton University's historical connections to the institution of slavery. The class will work toward creating a report that details the slave-holding practices of Princeton faculty and students, examines campus debates about slavery, and investigates whether money derived from slave labor contributed to the early growth of the school. Class will meet in Mudd Library.

title: Survey of Population Problems
reviews: Even if you are an undergrad, you should take this course. There is a fair amount of reading, but this was the most interesting and insightful class I have taken at Princeton. It will make you a smarter person and teach you about a whole host of phenomena which you think you have common sense about (why people have many/few kids, why people immigrate, what makes a society "healthy", and more) and teach you what the experts have to say.
I would recommend this course if you have an interst in demography.

Try to read everything thoroughly but focus on the main substantive themes. Also, when it is your turn to lead discussion, pick topics you are most interested in because you will inevitably read more intently for these topics and that will be useful in both exams and your own education.
descrip: Survey of past and current trends in the growth of the population of the world and of selected regions. Analysis of the components of growth and their determinants. The social and economic consequences of population change.

title: History of Ecology and Environmentalism
descrip: The word 'ecology' evokes the scientific discipline that studies the interactions between and among organisms and their environments, and also resonates with the environmental movement of the sixties, green politics, and conservation. This course explores the historical development of ecology as a professional science, before turning to the political and social ramifications of ecological ideas. Throughout the course, we will situate the history of ecological ideas in their cultural, political, and social context.

title: Graduate Seminar in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
reviews: Read the abstracts before the seminar so that you know what the talk is about.
Take this course
descrip: A seminar of graduate students and staff presenting the results of their research and recent advances in flight, space, and surface transportation; fluid mechanics; energy conversion; propulsion; combustion; environmental studies; applied physics; and materials sciences. There is one seminar per week and participation at presentations by distinguished outside speakers.

title: Beginner's German I
reviews: A great introductory German course for graduate students.
Absolutely take this class! The German department at Princeton is spectacular and the intro classes are very well-taught; you don't want to miss out on it.

An excellent course with a brilliant new curriculum designed by Professor Rankin (Der:Die:Das). I can already hold a basic conversation after only one semester. Professor Rankin is approachable and will be happy to help you. You learn the most useful German vocabulary (so practical)!
As a student who had no previous knowledge of the German language, my ability to speak, write, and read in German increased tremendously while taking this fun and engaging class.

DO IT DO IT DO IT. You won't regret it for a second. Jump in there and don't be afraid to speak! Mistakes pave the way to success in any language?especially one you're just picking up?but Rankin will push you to do your best every day.
Definitely take it if you are interested in learning German.
Definitely.
Do it! It is nightly work, perhaps 30min or so, but highly rewarding as a 101 class.
Do it! Just remember that you're gonna have to give quite a bit of time to starting a language fresh.
Do not get discouraged in the beginning if german is new to you. You will catch up and you will start speaking german more fluently as long as you keep up with the material.
Don't take this class.
German is not a very easy language, but if you really like it and think you really need it, this course is a very good way to get started.
Great class... Saskia was awesome and prepares you well to become a comfortable german speaker in higher levels

Great course, huge fan.  Put in the right amount of work daily (pretty minimal) and show up to class awake and this class will pay off tremendously.  Professor Rankin is a fantastic professor and the new der/die/das course he introduced was great.
Great introductory language class, you will be surprised at how much you can learn over just one semester of instruction

Heavily consider the time of the section. The 9am section that I took could feel a little dreary some days. Also, study vocab actively, and look to practice speaking with other students as often as possible. Don't hesitate to seek a tutor if you need the extra help. The beginning of the course is a little daunting, but after a week or so it becomes much easier to understand, think, and communicate in the language.
I strongly recommend taking this class.
I strongly recommend this course!
I would recommend this course if you have an interest in German and are willing to put in a decent amount of work for a 101 class.
I would say absolutely take this course! It is somewhat work-intensive but in no way overwhelming, and will yield immediate and gratifying results.

I would tell another student to be ready for an exciting challenge. Also, I would suggest finding someone they can regularly speak (or even text in) German with. This is incredibly helpful for improving grammar and overall comfortability speaking

If you are interested in beginning a language, I would highly recommend this course.  The course demands a little bit of work every day; as long as you keep up with assignments and engage in class, it will be a fruitful experience!
If you have the chance to take German with Rankin, do it. He's an incredible teacher.
If you want to pick up german or if you just want a quick review before heading into higher classes, then this is the class for you.
If you're a graduate student, I'll strongly recommend this class if you want to learn fast how to read a German text.
Keep up and speak as much as possible.
Keep up with the assignments and learn the vocab.
Learn your grammar and vocab as soon as it is assigned! This will make class participation a lot easier and help you in the long run.
Make sure to be motivated enough to do the work daily.

PLEASE TAKE GERMAN WITH PROF. RANKIN! This is an absolutely amazing course. I suck at languages but this class was a lot of fun and I got so much help. It is definitely worth it! And it isn't a bad course for first year student.
Pay attention to everything and know your vocabulary!
Please take this course. This was the best course I've taken at Princeton by far.

Professor Rankin's class is amazing. We learned so much, and although there is homework that you should be doing every day (which doesn't really get turned in), it's important to keep up with the pace of the class and constantly review.
Recommend if interested in learning German.
Sign up for Rankin's course.
Study constantly.

TAKE THIS COURSE. The ddd sequence and Professor Rankin are absolutely amazing - the best language learning experience I've ever had. Do it.
Do stay on top of the vocab and do the exercises as you go!
Take "der-die-das" with Professor Rankin! He does an amazing job of making even the not-so-exciting parts of learning a new language interesting like grammar. And lectures were crystal clear.
Take German with Professor Rankin!!
Take it!
Take it!  Even if you don't get James Rankin, the other instructors are also of high quality!
Take it! But you must be willing to put in the work because German is a pretty tough language.
Take it!! Der Die Das is great, Professor Rankin is amazing. I've never been in a language class nearly as good as this one.

Take this course with Jamie Rankin for sure. He will make you love German and turn a difficult language into your next passion. Definitely take the der/die/das section if you have the option, as it is convenient and interesting, and feels more useful in learning the language.

The best method I found to memorize the grand amount of vocabulary you need to learn is to use Quizlet, an online flashcards app. Every time you learn a new word try to associate to something in your life so you can remember it easier.
The effectiveness of this course depends on how much work you are willing to put into it. And what professor you get is a matter of luck, I suppose. (I was very lucky.)

This class rocks! If you have a genuine interest in languages, and maybe want to go to Princeton in Munich at some point in your life, take it. Professor Rankin worked very hard on the curriculum, and he is awesome.
practice everyday! Whether vocabulary or grammar. And go to office hours!
review steadily
see Professor Rankin early and often with questions.
