prereqs: Normally no credit given for GER 101 unless followed by GER 102. An afternoon section of GER 101 will focus on reading skills, in addition to oral communication, and is limited to graduate students. All participants, including graduate students, must be fully enrolled in the course..
descrip: The course lays a foundation for functional acquisition of German. Class time is devoted to language tasks that will foster communicative competence and will emphasize listening and reading strategies, vocabulary acquisition, authentic input, and oral production. Conducted in German.

title: Philosophy of Religion
reviews: A great, high-level introduction to some topics in analytic theology, with a heavy focus on metaphysics.
A very interesting course that covers a lot of important topics.  Hogan can be very critical of religion, which is good to know beforehand if you are a person of faith.

Avoid this class. There are plenty of better courses offered in the philosophy department. If you do decide to take the class, Professor Hogan assumes a strong background in logic, which is difficult in a department that does not offer that many logic courses.

Do NOT take this with Professor Hogan.  He's bigoted against theists -- especially Catholics.  His grading is biased.  He makes no time for students outside of class (even if you have another class during his office hours.)  It's not a good class with him at the helm.
Do the readings and meet with the professor about papers.

Great class to take for general interest or if you're a major student. Topics covered are relevant both to philosophy of religion as well as other interesting fields of philosophy including epistemology, ethics, and metaphysics
If you have any interest in religion or are religious, this could be a very interesting course.
It is definitely worthwhile to put in the effort to read the readings thoroughly and participate in class - you won't be disappointed!
Take it; solid philosophy course
This is a great course if you are interested in philosophy of religion.  Hogan is a great lecturer.
To some people I would say they must take this class, but there are some other people I would not recommend it to.  So it really just depends on the type of person.
Try to participate as much as you can in the class debates.
prereqs: One Philosophy course..
descrip: An examination of the possibility and nature of religious knowledge, from both historical and systematic (analytic) points of view. We will read discussions of religious belief by several key figures in the history of western philosophy (e.g. Cicero, Aquinas, Hume, and Kant), as well as by contemporary philosophers (e.g. Johnston, Lewis, Plantinga, van Fraassen). Throughout the course, emphasis will be placed on using the tools of analytic philosophy in order to clarify the issues and to arrive at convincing conclusions about them.

title: Theories of Housing and Urbanism
reviews: Do all of the readings before class. ALL OF THEM.
Take it.
take it if you like the readings.
descrip: The seminar will explore theories of urbanism and housing by reading canonical writers who have created distinctive and influential ideas about urbanism and housing from the nineteenth century to the present. The writers are architects, planners, and social scientists. The theories are interdisciplinary. One or two major works will be discussed each week. We will critically evaluate their relevance and significance for architecture now. Topics include: modernism, technological futurism, density, the new urbanism, the networked city, landscape urbanism, and sustainable urbanism.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Algorithmic Mechanism Design
descrip: Course covers a number of contemporary topics on algorithmic game theory and mechanism design. Potential topics include reductions from mechanism design to algorithm design, the price of anarchy, mechanism design without money, and information elicitation mechanisms. Emphasis will be placed on the algorithmic aspects of these problems.

title: Energy and Commodities Markets
reviews: A challenging but great course if you enjoyed ORF 355 (with Sircar). The assignments can be difficult but you are given a lot of time so it's definitely OK. Overall the material is difficult but the workload is not heavy. Warning: If Jacob Funk is the TA I wouldn't take it.
Don't take unless you're in dire need of a departmental or if you love commodities
I would probably not recommend it. Not as good as 335 and psets can be really hard. You don't learn that much about energy and commodities except through presentations by your peers.
Take this if Sircar is teaching it. Hard course but Sircar's classes are always worth it.

This course is pretty much the follow-up to 335, and it is much harder. Problem sets took a really long time but I usually learned a lot. Professor Sircar is a great lecturer and is always really clear. He is also very approachable and interesting to talk to.
This is a great course, but the material is tough if you are not prepared to spend time understanding it
classic sircar class as usual. lots of math, but good notes and good teaching.
take it if you enjoyed orf335.
prereqs: ORF335 or instructor's permission required.
descrip: This course is an introduction to commodities markets (energy, metals, agricultural products) and issues related to renewable energy sources such as solar and wind power, and carbon emissions. Energy and other commodities represent an increasingly important asset class, in addition to significantly impacting the economy and policy decisions. Emphasis will be on the application of Financial Mathematics to a variety of different products and markets. Topics include: energy prices (including oil and electricity); cap and trade markets; storable vs non-storable commodities; financialization of commodities markets; applications of game theory.

title: Problems in French History - 20th Century France
descrip: Readings in the political, social, and cultural history of twentieth-century France are the focus of this course. Topics include: the Founding of the Third Republic, the First and Second World Wars, the crisis of democracy in the interwar decades; postwar reconstruction; decolonization, 1968.

title: Econometric Research Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: Directed Research I
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out research and presents the results. Directed Research is normally taken during the first year of study.

title: Into the Wild
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Accelerated Honors Analysis I
reviews: Be prepared to do a lot of work, but in the end this course is exceptionally rewarding.
Don't slack off. The material isn't necessarily hard, but you should know the basics down solid.
Great class if you have a solid math background.

If you have not already taken multivariable calculus and/or linear algebra and/or have participated to high level math competitions, be very careful before taking that class because it will be the case of almost all of the other students.
If you want to be a math major, this course is a must!!! The course is very well designed.
If you're very interested in a math major and willing to put in the work, take the course. Otherwise, it'll be a lot of hard work.
Know what you're getting into. It's a very difficult class, and be willing to make a strong commitment to it if you want it to be rewarding.
Read the book, thoroughly!
Read the notes carefully.
Take this if you are considering being a math major, and already have some experience with proof-based mathematics.
Take this only if you have already done a fair bit of Multi variable Calculus, Linear algebra and a reasonable amount of proof based math. Otherwise, 215 is a better place to start.
The course is difficult but if you put in the time it is intriguing.
You really should take this course if you are considering becoming a math major. Covers a lot of material in a unique sequence and very well-presented.
prereqs: Some acquaintance with calculus in one variable is helpful..
descrip: Rigorous theoretical introduction to the foundations of analysis in one and several variables: basic set theory, vector spaces, metric and topological spaces, continuous and differential mapping between n-dimensional real vector spaces. Normally followed by MAT218.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Poverty and Inequality in OECD Countries
descrip: What can we learn from the analysis of inequality, and poverty and from research on social exclusion in the OECD countries? We analyze the role differences in institutions (i.e. labor market regulations,) and policies (i.e. child benefits, minimum wage, migration policies) across these countries play in observed outcomes. We first focus on poverty and deprivation among children, then on problems of youth and adolescents; family formation and household structure, labor market participation and wage structure, migration and other dimensions of adulthood.

title: History with Objects and Landscapes
descrip: Do you ever wonder how and why the objects and landscapes you pass every day or see from a plane got to be as they are now? This seminar teaches you how to "read" things and built and unbuilt landscapes, and how historical archaeologists, anthropologists, historical ecologists and historians have used the material realm to understand the past in ways they could not through written records alone. The course is local and global in focus, covering different epochs of human societies in Princeton, its environs, and the broader world. You will be able to practice new material literacy skills in field trips and in projects for public audiences.

title: Calculus II
reviews:
1.) You will have to study for math.
2.) Office hours are very helpful. 
3.) Review notes after class. 
4.) Consider taking MAT 103 if you think you might not have a very strong foundation in Calc 1. There is no time for review.
Always do your psets, as well as previous years' quizzes/midterms/finals to better prepare yourself.
Always stay on top of the material. The step from the problem sets to the quizzes is much larger than you think so you can never be over-prepared.
At times Benoit's voice becomes monotonous, so it may be hard to pay attention towards the end of class. However, his office hours are very helpful.
Attend review sessions and seek help if one is struggling. A lot work will be put into this class and having a deep understanding of the material is key.
Be prepared to learn a lot by yourself.
Be prepared to work. It is a hard class but it is doable.
Challenging but worth it.
Definitely go to office hours, even if you don't have questions. Just listening to other peoples questions and practicing the harder problems will teach you things you didn't know you didn't know.
Do a lot of practice problems.
Do every practice problem you can. There are hundreds of tricks and exceptions that you will never know of unless you do every problem.

Do not fall behind. Pre-read the textbook/look up things online BEFORE the class otherwise you will spend most of the class trying to figure out what's going on and what we're trying to do instead of how to actually do it.
Do the problem sets and don't hesitate to collaborate on studying and practice questions!
Do work ahead of times when possible.
Do you like math? If not, don't take the course!
Doing practice problems constantly will help you understand the material better, because reading and understanding the material is one thing, but applying it is different.
Don't be afraid to go to office hours!  And when preparing for exams, the best thing to do is take the past exams!
Don't be afraid to use outside resources and read ahead whenever you get the chance.
Don't expect it to be easy just because you've been good at math in the past.
Don't fall behind, and go to class.
Even if you get a 5 on Calc AB, I would recommend taking 103.
Every math class at Princeton is very difficult.  Try your best to go to class, do the problem sets, and practice as much as you can.  Office hours are more helpful than you think.
Exams were tougher than problem sets, manageable workload although not too interesting.
Get Javier as your instructor and you'll be set.
Go To Office Hours. Javier Gomez-Serrano is quality, I recommend him as an instructor.
Go to as many office hours times as possible so you can go through as many different problems as possible and eliminate doubts about certain areas if the material you are unsure of.
Go to class, pay attention
Go to every class and spend time on the problem sets.
Go to every lecture and takes notes.
Go to office hours, do a LOT of practice problems/quizzes before quizzes, the midterm, and the final.
Go to office hours, take it with Javier
Go to office hours/ mcgraw
Go to the McGraw center for help!
Good Calc II course. Moves quickly, but good.
Great course, especially if you have Javier as an instructor.
Have AP credit? USE IT!
Have more than one math textbook.

I would advise a student who didn't have to take this course for a requirement to stay away from it unless he/she especially enjoys math. I do, so I liked the class. I fear that a student who doesn't like math will not like Math 104.

I would advise other students to find a study group early on in the semester to work on the problem sets with. This is essential to both learning the material and doing well on the assignments. Also, students should definitely seek out the professor during office hours if they are having trouble with a particular assignment or topic.
I would recommend taking the class, especially with Javier. It was difficult for me, but I also learned a lot, and it made me excited to continue my courses in math at Princeton.
I would recommend that they have a strong understanding of pre-calc and BC topics and stay on top of the weekly homework assignments so they are prepared for the quizzes.

I would say that if he plans to study something related to natural science, he should take it because it reviews important basic material and provides the basis for future classes. If not, I would suggest that he took some other course from the mathematics department that is perhaps more engaging.
I would say that it is important to stay on track with the course--if you're having trouble with a concept, work with other people or go to office hours to clear things up.
I would say to stay on top of the work. To do many practice problems and take practice finals and quizzes as well as redo the homework before tests.

If you can, TAKE IT WITH JAVIER. He is seriously an incredible professor and human being.
In general, go to office hours and review sessions when you can. Office hours are often very helpful.
If you take the class try and get Javier as your preceptor. He is the best.

If you took calculus AB and did well in it (got a 5) this course will probably teach you a good deal you didn't know about integrals, series, imaginary numbers, and differential equations. The concepts are relatively easy, but if you take this course you will see how simple concepts can be applied to create fairly difficult problems. If you like math though, it should be fun and if Javier is still teaching it you should try to get him as your professor or at least go to his office hours.

If you were good at math in high school, this is a different deal. This type of math is teaching it to yourself and needing to understand it on all cylinders in order to do well. If you are good at that, then you should be fine.
If you're interested in math, give it a shot. Just remember to study hard for exams and quizzes, they're definitely tough.
It is important to understand the homework and that makes the class much easier.
It's a hard class, but you'll learn a lot of math. Make sure to work at it.
It's a struggle but it's worth it
It's difficult but manageable! I'd highly recommend it
Its math.
Javier Gomez-Serrano is a great prof--if you have the opportunity to take his class, take advantage
Keep up with the work, study and do a lot of practice problems from Ed Nelson's math 104 page.

MAT 104 isn't a fun course, especially if you're not a math person. However, if you practice enough outside of class and go to office hours, you can succeed. If you have to take MAT 104, I'd recommend taking Professor Gomez-Serrano's class. Even though he has an accent, he's actually very clear with his reasoning and willing to explain things multiple times. However, he goes through the material much faster than the other professors do.
Make sure to attend each class, read the textbook, and absolutely go to office hours if you have any questions whatsoever.
Make sure to be prepared for low percentages on the exams.
Make sure to do a lot of practice on your own

Make sure to get Gomez-Seranno. The book is not a replacement for class as it is hard to follow. If you have taken B/C before and din't quite test out the class in fairly easy while still bringing a lot of new material

Make sure you sign up for Javier Gomez Serrano's course if he is teaching it. He makes the course excellent. The course itself is fine. If you have already taken calc BC and aren't sure whether to take this or a higher level, I would recommend this course. I understand calculus much better now than I did after taking BC, even though I got a 5 on the AP exam and could have placed out. It's also nice to have some background in whatever math course you start with, because the math tests here are basically all the edge cases and trick questions the topic could possibly offer.
Make sure you understand the topics at hand before you move on to other ones and don't be afraid to ask for help.
Much harder than high school calculus.
Only do so if you are willing to put in a lot of work into the class.

Pay attention in class and supplement that with reading the textbook and you should be perfectly fine.  Don't get intimidated by the quizzes and tests, they look way harder than they actually are, so just prepare yourself adequately.
Pick your professor wisely.
Prepare to do a lot of work, the class is challenging, but rewarding
Read the book and go to McGraw.
Read the lesson before the class.
Seek out challenging practice problems and just do a ton of them.  And don't leave class without your questions answered.  The classes are small enough.
Slightly fast paced for me, and it is necessary to study some concepts on your own time. If you are fine with that, however, this course is excellent for learning Calculus II concepts.

Start going to office hours immediately. It's where the professor goes over all the problems that give you trouble or have some trick to them that the examples don't require. Practice is key to mastering the material in this course.

Stay on top of the textbook readings and all other assignments because with each passing topic, previous ones are not pushed to the waste side, but are actively incorporated.  In essence, don't shy away from asking questions and going to office hours.
Students should go to office hours and McGraw for clearer explanations of concepts.
Study a lot and attend office hours.
Study hard and go to all the lectures.
TAKE IT WITH JAVIER.

TAKE THIS CLASS WITH ADAM LEVINE! He is BY FAR the best instructor (I shopped around the first few weeks) and probably one of my favorite teachers ever. He is super enthusiastic and willing to answer questions. He goes at a great pace, and shows us why things are true rather than just writing down facts. In general, quizzes and exams are difficult, but the curve is extremely generous.
Take it only if you are heavily inclined towards mathematics.
Take it only if you have to.
Take it, do homework to learn for the quiz rather than to get full credit on the homework
Take it. Do the problem sets. Go to office hours.
Take only if you have to .
Take the course! I know that you might be scared because there are engineers in the course, but it is so worth it!
Take this course
Take time to study for all assessments.
Teaches fundamental skills of calculus
The advice I would give is to take advantage of your Professor's office hours and the many review sessions they offer you .
There isn't really an alternative. The workload is challenging, but manageable with other classes.
This class will not be easy, but the material is interesting and engaging, I would recommend it.
This course is quite fast paced. You must stay on top of things, even if you've taken Calc BC before.

When preparing for exams, take as many practice quizzes as you can because those will often be the only thing that resembles the quizzes you will take. The problem sets are baby steps to learning the material, but the key to mastering the quizzes is learning how to deal with the the "curve balls"
Yes, especially with my Professor.
You should pay attention in lecture and do the homework.
do assignments early and you won't ever feel lost, course is super reasonable
get javier as a professor
if you can place out with bc credit, do it. very challenging.
javier is awesome
work consistently
prereqs: MAT103 or equivalent..
descrip: Continuation of MAT103. Topics include techniques of integration, arclength, area, volume, convergence of series and improper integrals, L'Hopital's rule, power series and Taylor's theorem, introduction to differential equations and complex numbers.

title: Special Topics in Creative Writing - How to Write a Novel in Twelve Weeks (or at least make a start)
reviews: Make sure you allot at least an hour a day for this class. Writing takes time!

STICK TO THE SCHEDULE! 300 words a day is not a big deal; don't make it out to be a hulk in your head. Just get it done, when you wake up maybe, and spend the rest of your day unfettered. Yeah, 300 words/day is neither a hulk nor a fetter--don't think of it that way--learn from my mistake. Even a good 300 words should only take about a half hour of concentrated focus, I think. 

If possible, write ahead. I wouldn't encourage you to write ahead every week, as that's kind of antithetical to the point--the point being that you're supposed to learn to write every day, get into a schedule, and eventually become Stephen King churning out 2000 words a day cold--but if you anticipate a busy week, do it and you'll be glad. 

I think it might have been helpful for me to come in with a plot. But it's hard to say. Maybe if I had tried to stick to a prefabricated plot, I would have felt hemmed in. Just follow your instincts, I guess.

Take it. By far one of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. If you're serious about being a novelist or anything related to fiction writing, you'll love it. Professor Choi is always constructive and honest in her feedback. It's fun and laidback but serious about the work at the same time. A great blend.
The course is what you make of it. If you write 300 words a day, then you'll come out of it with a substantial manuscript.
prereqs: Not open to Freshman or Grad Students -- This course is limited to advanced writing students who have previously completed at least two 200 level writing courses. Please visit the Creative Writing Program website for application information. Application deadline is April 11, 2014..
descrip: This advanced workshop will be devoted to the novel. What makes a novel? How do novels work? Most important, how do we write one? Participants will arrive with a novel in prospect (in other words, an idea) or even a novel already in progress, will produce a minimum of eight draft pages per week, and will have their novels-in-progress workshopped by the group. In addition we will read at least three canonical novels of the past century to see what we can learn about why they succeed. Each participant's goal will be as much of a rough draft as possible of his or her novel-in-progress.

title: Topics in Literature and Philosophy - Negations
descrip: An exploration of some of the domains of writing and thought in which terms and ideas of negation acquire a crucial importance. Subjects that may be discussed include the grammar of negation in languages; logical treatments of negation; psychoanalytic concepts of negation, repression and disavowal; the aesthetics of je ne sais quoi; the idea of the non-finito in art; negative theology. Particular attention will be paid to the problem of "indefinite negation" and Kant's "infinite judgment."

title: Topics in Biological Chemistry - Chemical Tools to Study Biological Systems
reviews: Do not take this class unless you are very well versed in chemistry and biology.  Pretty tough

If you are interested in the ways that chemistry and biology intersect, then take this course. It is a well-organized course that surveys the broad field of chemical biology and provides a taste of current research in this area.
go to the class.
descrip: This class emphasizes the use of chemical approaches to investigate and manipulate biological processes at the biochemical, the cellular, and the organismal level. The purpose is to provide chemical biologists with modern chemical methods. The class will then discuss how these methods can be applied to study different biological problems, highlighting important questions in biology. Typically a paper from the current literature will be presented and discussed by the students each class. Grades are based on problem sets, a midterm exam, a literature presentation, and a research proposal.

title: U.S. Women Writers
descrip: An exploration of the literary works of women writers in the United States with an emphasis on the role gender has played and continues to play in the development of literary movements and genres. Our examination of both canonical and non-canonical writings will focus on the formation of feminist literary conventions in the 19th century and their transformations in the 20th and 21st centuries. Our reading will include romantic tales, ghost stories, realistic stories, novels of immigration, thrillers, works for children, autobiographical mythmaking, poetry, and graphic novels.

title: Readings in Classical Arabic Literature
descrip: A reading of selections of poetry and prose. Problems of narrative, poetics, and the like may be discussed according to the interests of the class.

title: Introduction to Dance Across Cultures
prereqs: No prior dance experience is necessary to succeed in this course..
descrip: This studio course will have us travel from temples and courtyards to clubs, streets, and stages around the world to better understand the diversity of dance. Featuring movement practices such as Bharata Natyam, Butoh, Rumba, and Burmese dance, this course introduces students to dance across cultures and historical periods while questioning categories such as classical, traditional, ethnic, folk, and world dance. The course meets twice a week; activities will include dance assignments, readings, discussions, and viewings of filmed and live performances. Guest artists will teach different dance forms. No prior dance experience is necessary.

title: Introduction to Spanish-English Translation
reviews: Don't underestimate translations!
Easy and interesting class. Definitely take it. Sylvia is great.

I would recommend using Sylvia as a resource because she really is very valuable. It is all very subjective, so if you need concrete and definite answers, this is not the course for you. Pay attention to detail.
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish language course or instructor's permission. Freshmen: Please contact Sylvia Zetterstrand (szetters@princeton.edu) if course is full..
descrip: This course offers an introduction to translation practice for the Spanish-English language pair, focusing primarily on the task of translating from Spanish into English. The course is conducted in Spanish and follows a communicative approach to translation, with a good balance between theory and praxis. Materials are drawn from a range of disciplines, such as humanities, social sciences, popular culture, and the media. Students are encouraged to think critically and creatively about language, and will heighten their awareness of the linguistic, textual and cultural differences between English and Spanish.

title: Themes in World History, 1300-1850
descrip: This seminar covers classical and contemporary debates and historiography of world history, from the making of world systems, to the rise and fall of empires, to global revolution and the onset of modernity.

title: Selected Topics in Theoretical High-Energy Physics - Strings, Black Holes and Gauge Theories
reviews: I recommend this course for everybody studying High Energy Theory, at least for cultural reasons if none other

The course was very inspiring and presented the beauty behind so many topics in high energy theory.  The lectures were great but they required some prior knowledge of the topics. They were inspiring rather than pedagogical. It was probably the course that stimulated my intellectual curiosity the most during my stay at Princeton. While we had some homework questions given during class, it would have been useful to have a periodic problem set which would give an introduction to the next topic we were going to discuss.
descrip: Discussion of modern tools of Quantum Field Theory and their applications, ranging from polymers to black holes.

title: Introduction to Japanese Film and Culture: Sensory Anarchy and Postwar Democracy
reviews: Enjoy the films!
Get in a consistent rhythm with the weekly responses so you don't fall behind. Always go to lecture because I think he secretly takes attendance.
I highly recommend this course. The films are wonderful and crazy. Moreover, they are a comprehensive collection that work well together.
I liked it,

I would say that anyone who is even remotely interested in film or Japanese culture would do well to take this class, as I - a half-Japanese person myself - received a better understanding of my own heritage while simultaneously working on rigorous film criticism.
Keep up with the films/readings.
TAKE IT
TAKE IT.
Take it.

This is a fun class for those interested in Japanese history/culture, but most of the movies are not well-known in this country (and some are downright trippy), so don't take this if you just want to watch samurai/ninja/Japanese monster movies because that's not how it's gon be.

This is a great course to fulfill the LA requirement. There's a movie and response each week; movie takes about 1-2 hours and responses really can only be done after precept, and usually the precept day coincides with the due date, so this class shouldn't take more than 4-5 hours a week. The responses are pretty informal, so don't stress about that. Listen in precept and you'll know exactly what to write. But do have a general sense of what's going on in the class because everything builds up to the final paper.
Very good course, films are all interesting and the readings provide a nice historical background
Yes!!
descrip: This course examines Japanese film and culture to explore the dynamic transformations of sensibility, perception and affect wrought in the postwar remaking of Japan. Introducing the history and development of postwar Japanese film, this course engages works that offer critical perspective on Japan's rapid economic development and troubled democracy. Spanning major genres, such as melodrama, avant-garde, comedy, kaiju (giant monster), yakuza, horror and anime, we will investigate postwar culture through the vivid sensory anarchy of films that illuminated the problems and possibilities of Japan's most transformative period.

title: Ecology: Species Interactions, Biodiversity and Society
reviews: Absolutely take this class if you have any interest in nature, conservation, and the way the species of the world interact with each other. Alternatively, just take it because Pringle is hilarious and inspiring and generally really cool. Lectures are very interesting and you'll learn a lot! But be warned that there is a fair bit of work involved, mostly in 2 big lab projects.

DO IT. TAKE THIS CLASS.
Go to all the lectures (especially the last one). Ask questions. Start working on the independent projects as soon as you can, and stay on top of your other work.
And really, stay engaged. I got a lot out of it.
Definitely take it
Definitely take this class if you have any interest at all in biology or the environment.
Even though it's a requirement for EEB majors, it's an awesome course! A lot of work, but Rob is awesome.

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone; the lectures are engaging and the readings are extremely interesting. This class is a must-take for anyone considering a graduate degree in biology.
No matter what major you are, take the class. Surprisingly inspirational. The last lecture has stuck with me for a long time.
No matter what your major DEFINITELY TAKE THIS CLASS! It is SO interesting and will change the way you see the world
Prof. Pringle is a great teacher and an entertaining lecturer, but the lab portion was disorganized and frustrating. Still worth taking the class though.
Take if you are interested in ecology and conservation! Pringle is a great lecturer.
Take it!!
Take it. Don't read anything else. Take the course.
Take the class but once you're out of class, don't ask questions.
The lab assignments are a lot of work, but Rob's lectures are really a fascinating introduction to the field as a whole. If the subject interests you and you have the time, absolutely worth it.
The lectures are great but the labs are a ton of work and not that interesting so bear that in mind before signing up.
This is a great course. I really enjoyed it.
This is probably the best class that I have taken at Princeton. Professor Pringle is an amazing lecturer. After taking this class, I truly think my worldview has changed for the better.

You have to take this course if you are EEB. and even if you are not and just want to expose yourself to an excellent professor and a really cool subject that is presented super well, take it as well.
ehh
prereqs: EEB 211 or equivalent. Although the course is not heavily mathematical, it is quantitative; students should be prepared to apply basic principles of statistics and graphical analysis..
descrip: How do wild organisms interact with each other, their physical environments, and human societies? Lectures will examine a series of fundamental topics in ecology--herbivory, predation, competition, mutualism, species invasions, biogeographic patterns, extinction, climate change, and conservation, among others--through the lens of case studies drawn from all over the world. Readings will provide background information necessary to contextualize these case studies and clarify the linkages between them. Laboratories and fieldwork will explore the process of translating observations and data into an understanding of how the natural world works.

title: Honors Analysis (Single Variable)
reviews: Be prepared to work. But it is very rewarding.

Contrary to the rumors, you do not need to be a math genius to take this class. All you need is a willingness to work and a determination to  do well. Go to office hours, as Professor McConnell is extremely helpful. Do your problem sets early, and do not be intimidated! Analysis is really beautiful stuff if you put your mind to it!
Don't take it unless you are strongly considering being a math major. Prepared for a lot of work, but even greater reward.
Go to office hours. Find a study group. It is possible to survive this course with no prior rigorous mathematics experience, but it will take a significant amount of time and dedication.

I think that it's a hard course, probably only for people who really want to learn math. I would say that one thing to do is definitively attend all the classes if possible, as missing anything makes it extremely difficult to catch up, as, at least for me, it required a long time of watching the professor explain proofs and stuff to get how they worked.
I very much enjoyed this class, but only if one is truly interested in math and is willing to put in the time. I spent as much time on MAT 215 as I did on my other three classes put together.

I would tell them to take it if they have the time and the interest to dedicate themselves to it. I would of course recommend the course to people interested in mathematics, however I would never recommend it with the same teacher that taught me.

If they are teach this course again using Apostol, AVOID IT LIKE THE PLAGUE. MAT 215 is a needlessly painful introduction to rigorous maths. The problem sets are needlessly long and painful, the TAs (at least this year) were completely incompetent, and Rudin is a far better textbook for this topic than Apostol. The only saving grace this year was Professor McConnell, who is a great lecturer who clearly explains the material.
If you are interested in proof-based mathematics, want to major in math, or take a challenging yet immensely rewarding class, then take MAT 215.

If you are serious about mathematics, then this is the course that you will spend the most of your time on, and these problem sets will be what you pull all-nighters for, and the people you meet in this class will be the ones you eventually find are your closest friends. You don't need BC calculus or even AB (although they are helpful in providing intuition) because mathematics here is literally proved from the bottom up. This is probably my favorite class this semester, but it's not a course for the weak. I recall one girl who said that one of the reasons she's taking this is for the knowledge gained at the end and the ability to say "I survived MAT 215." This class consumes you, but at the end, what emerges is a new you with a different way of thinking, and I think that is completely worth it.
It's a great intro to proof-based math.
Keep up with the work. Do your psets. Don't rely on others.

Look. You know if you should take this class or not. Have you been going to bath camp since 2nd grade? Did you take calculus in middle school? If so, you're with the clear majority of the class.

Did you follow a normal high school track, get As in honors math classes, but didn't necessarily go home and read university level papers for fun? Probably shouldn't take this class.

MAT 215 changed after they split MAT 216 into a completely different course. Don't be fooled, it is still a tough course. If you want to do well, expect to put in 12 hours a week at least, between homework and learning the material. I say take the course. Also, the first few problem sets can be a shock to the system. Then it becomes a personal choice, either hang with it or decide it's not for you. You really won't be able to make that decision until after you'd gone through the first two weeks, so shop it at least.

MAT 215 was definitely different this semester than in years past. Professor Chang used Apostol instead of Rudin, so I feel like the course lost some of its character - we skipped over all of the topology stuff at the beginning (no metric spaces or Heine-Borel) that I believe is still covered in 216. (This may have been intended when they formally split 215's "fast track" into a separate course - I don't know.) As a result, the course was basically returning to AP Calculus BC and proving everything rigorously - not bad, just different. The textbook is more verbose than Rudin, which may be good or bad depending on your personal preference. Professor Chang's lectures are slow but informative, though people seemed to prefer McConnell. Go to the problem sessions for help on problem sets. Hope that you won't have to do massive long division to evaluate a Taylor series by hand on a problem set (this happened). The midterm was reasonable. As a sophomore taking the class after having taken 203-204 freshman year (econ major considering grad school), I might have had a slight edge in the beginning from having experience with proofs, but freshman math majors are smart cookies and the playing field quickly evened out. If you're choosing between 215 and 216, know that 215 is rigorous calculus and that 216 is the Rudin-level course with basic topology. If you're a sophomore, take either to build character and rigorous thinking ability. (Also a good QR requirement if anybody needs one.)
Read as slowly as you have to until you understand perfectly. Go to office hours and review sessions. Never fall behind.

Start the problem set and reading on the night it is released. Go to office hours, the review sessions with UCA's were unhelpful for me. Take good notes and go to each class. Find resources online as this class moves fast (especially Epsilon Delta proofs) know how to "prove it" and how to calculate. You'll survive. Oh, and TAKE CLASS WITH MCCONNELL, HE IS THE BEST. Do NOT TAKE CLASS WITH CHANG. BIG NO NO.
Take it if you are interested in math completely different than regular high school math.
Take it!
Take the course if you think you would like doing rigorous mathematics. If you have had proof-writing experience in the past, it is best that you take 216, for your own sake.
Take this class if you are really interested in mathematics. However, do keep in mind that this class takes a lot of time.
Take this course

Take this if you are interested in math, feel you are very good at it/have interest, but don't have as much experience with proofs. Even if you do have experience with proofs, it is challenging, and most certainly worth taking. Professor McConnell is an EXTREMELY good teacher, and was very popular with all of us, so if he is teaching it, that is a BIG extra reason to sign up! But only take this if you are genuinely interested in math; you will regret it if you aren't. It's a wonderful course overall!

The course is very hard.  Very, very difficult.
The homework is a bit tedious.
If McConnell is your teacher, you are in for a treat.
This is a demanding class. Try to completely understand each and every problem of the homework. Go to office hours.

This is a great course if you are looking to extend your knowledge of calculus into a more rigorous setting. For those who have no proof-based mathematics experience, this course is somewhat of a jump at the beginning. For those with some proof-based math experience, this course fits well. For those with much proof-based experience and experience at national and international mathematics competitions, you would probably be more engaged by the accelerated version (MAT 216) of this course.

What could I possibly say? If you're interested in math as a major, take this course. If you're even considering it, take this course. Even if you don't like math that much, take this course. In general, take this course. I had no (I mean, literally 0) experience with proofs before this course. And yet, the impeccable lectures and great textbook gave them a beauty I had never seen before. That being said, be prepared to work. And I mean, a LOT, especially in the first few weeks. These problem sets are not for the faint-hearted. But, if you make it through, you will, in no way, regret your decision. This is, for practically everyone, an absolute must-take class.

You can take this class even if you're not interested in a math major/minor, but you have to keep up with the effort of the math majors to survive the curve. Be prepared for at least 15-20 hours per problem set. If you want to do better than average, start the problem sets early in the week and go out of your way to ask for help when you're stuck. It's absolutely possible to pass this class with a respectable grade, so don't be terrified, but definitely don't try to cram a week's work into one or two days.
descrip: An introduction to the mathematicsal discipline of analysis, to prepare for higher-level course work in the department. Topics include rigorous epsilon-delta treatment of limits, convergence, and uniform convergence of sequences and series. Continuity, uniform continuity, and differentiability of functions. The Heine-Borel Theorem. The Rieman integral, conditions for integrability of functions and term by term differentiation and integration of series of functions, Taylor's Theorem.

title: Introduction to Chemical Instrumentation
reviews: I would definitely recommend this course if you need an introduction to NMR spectroscopy because there is a great deal of practical information. Just make sure to sit in the front of the class because his handwriting can be a little hard to decipher and he doesn't speak very loudly.
Review each lecture notes, record the lectures if necessary. Ask questions.
Would definitely recommend, although be sure to take very good notes as some of the topics covered can be difficult to research independently later.
descrip: This course covers the application of selected analytical instrumentation to modern chemical/biochemical research, including materials science and environmental and medicinal chemistry. Primary emphasis: NMR methods; data processing and spectrum analysis; integration with mass spectrometry; X-ray diffraction; IR, UV, and EPR spectroscopy; chiroptical techniques. Practical problem solving exercises for identification and characterization of molecular structure and dynamics using in-house examples are a significant part of the curriculum. Recommended for graduate students, and junior and senior undergraduates.

title: Intermediate Polish
prereqs: First year Polish (PLS101 and 102 or equivalent)..
descrip: The course reviews, strengthens, and upgrades the knowledge from the first year of language acquisition (PLS101 and 102, or equivalent). While enhancing their familiarity with Polish grammatical structures, students will also develop a broader vocabulary and more idiomatic patterns of expression. All linguistic skills (speaking, reading, writing, listening comprehension) will be practiced, but the main emphasis will be on communicative competence, as well as on a closer acquaintance with Poland's culture and everyday life.

title: A Nation of Immigrants
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Electronic Methods in Experimental Physics
reviews: Do the readings!
It's actually a really great course for seniors in the physics department. Minimal time commitment, but instructive and fun.
Prepare for the labs! Otherwise you gain little by being there. And use the room on off days, to get a feel for things without trying to keep pace.
Take this for an easy class where you learn a lot
This course is awesome. It is a small time commitment, but you learn a lot and you learn it well. I highly recommend it to everybody who will need to design electronic circuits in the future.
if you don't mind the friday afternoon lab, it's an interesting, easy class to take
descrip: This course is targeted for graduate students from all departments and undergraduate physics majors. The seminar introduces students to the basic techniques of electronics and instrumentation used to conduct experiments in the physical sciences. The course begins by teaching a foundation in analog and digital circuits including programmable digital logic devices using an iPad interface for data acquisition. Students develop measurement techniques in a wide range of experimental areas.

title: Elementary Modern Greek I
reviews: Look over each lesson before coming to class - when I had the time to do that it helped immensely.
Study the day's vocabulary every night!
Take Modern Greek if you have any interest in Greece or Greek culture. It is an amazingly expressive language, and it is a great challenge for English speakers.
Take it. Be ready for lots of personal attention and tons of learning.
descrip: To set the foundations for acquiring a command of spoken and written Modern Greek. Equal emphasis will be given to speaking, reading, and writing.

title: Mineralogy
reviews: Attending lectures is always a good idea - some material is not on the slides that comes up later, and particularly first half, it can be helpful to see the concepts applied firsthand.
Definitely take it. This course defied my expectations and was truly fascinating.

Go to lecture and ask questions if you're confused.  Also make yourself continuously review the material throughout the semester and contextualize new information.  If you don't, you'll end up at the end of the semester with a huge amount of material you have to process all at once.
I would take it. It's a pretty good course, not too hard, and useful for geology. Also it stretches your spacial reasoning skills. But...it is mineralogy.
If you have an interest in geology and/or gemology, you must take this course.
Lots of busy work but an interesting and manageable course.

Mineralogy spends the first half of the semester studying principles of symmetry and the second half of the semester learning to identify minerals. Professor Duffy really cares about the course. The class contains very little math. While I mostly enjoyed learning to identify minerals, sometimes it was monotonous.

Take it! Minerals make up the ground that we live on, so it's just great knowledge to have. The professors/TA's in this class are also superb, and the material is very well organized. Just the right amount of work.
Take it! Professor Duffy is super nice, and the labs and lectures are really interesting.

Take it. Work hard in lab. Don't buy the text book until you need to. Also I feel that prerequisites aren't very strong for this, everything was taught thoroughly and only basic chemistry and maths was required.
Take the course if you're at all interested in solid earth chemistry. Make sure you ask a lot of questions about theory/physics stuff! You'll learn a lot more that way.
Take this if you're interested in exploring geology.
prereqs: Introductory Chemistry and one Geosciences introductory course (GEO 202, 203, or freshman seminar related to the field of geoscience) or instructor permission..
descrip: A survey of the structure and crystal chemistry of major rock-forming minerals. Topics include: symmetry, crystallography, physical and chemical properties of minerals, mineral thermodynamics, environmental mineralogy, and techniques of modern mineralogy.

title: Stolen Years: Youth under the Nazis in World War II
reviews: Do all the readings! It really helps.
Keep up with the readings, it really matters in class discussion.  Also, doing the film journal as you watch them would be really helpful at the end of the course.
TAKE THIS COURSE.
TAKE THIS COURSE. Professor Zeitlin is very fair and the readings are incredibly interesting. I would never have read or watched any of the movies without taking this course.
Take it!
Take it. You won't regret it. And read everything, no matter what.

The movies are actually quite interesting, even though you definitely need to be prepared to pay attention to them.  If you enjoy learning about WWII and the Holocaust I definitely recommend taking this course though

You don't have to necessarily do all the readings, just make sure you skim before you go to class and definitely watch the film for the week before you go to class. You have the luxury of choosing your own essay topics so choose a book that you've really read in depth to focus on. And it's best to start your film journal as early as possible!
prereqs: Attendance at seminars and films..
descrip: This course examines the gendered experiences of childhood & adolescence under the Nazis in World War II as witnessed, remembered, and represented in texts and images through a variety of genres and different nationalities. We include historical studies, diaries, testimonies, memoirs, fiction (semi-autobiographical or otherwise), photos, and film (documentary & feature) of 1st and 2d generations. While we focus on the fate of Jewish youth, who were deliberate targets of genocidal policy, not just unintended victims, we will also attend to others in the occupied countries. In final projects, students may elect to study other theaters of war.

title: Research Seminar in Cognitive Psychology
descrip: Current research and issues in sensation, perception, and cognition. Ongoing research by seminar participants, research methodology, and current issues in the literature are discussed.

title: Great Economic Challenges of 2014
descrip: Please see website

title: Separations in Chemical Engineering and Biotechnology
reviews: 250 is pretty straightforward, stay on top of it and try to keep the big picture in mind when you are working on problems about details of certain processes.
A similar class to CBE 245 - study it well and go to class.
Attend all lectures as you will miss valuable information that is not in books.
Better than thermo, but can be a drag.
Definitely go to lecture. This is one of those classes where if you go to lecture it makes a lot of sense and is very manageable (almost easy), and if you don't, it's very hard.
Don't expect it to be much tougher than 245. Take it sophomore year!
Go to class, there is a participation component to grading and you can only get the notes by being in class.
Go to lectures, office hours. Begin psets in advance (definitely not the night before they are due!)
I don't think it is a particularly fun class but the workload is not too bad.
I would never take it willingly. The material is not that interesting.
If you're CBE, you'll have to take this course no matter what.
Only take it if you have to.
Only take this if you're a CBE major. Just get through it.
The course is fine, but be prepared for a couple of long problem sets.
aaa. Stay on top of your stuff, don't fall behind, TA's OH's are your best bet. Easier than 246, but not a walk in the park.
go to class.
prereqs: CBE 245 and CBE 246. MAE 305 and CHM 303 may be taken concurrently..
descrip: This course covers the theory and practice of separations technologies used in the chemical and biochemical industry. Both equilibrium and rate-based separations will be discussed including distillation and chromatography as the primary examples. The first two-thirds of the course will focus on traditional chemical separations while the remainder of the course will be devoted to bioseparations.

title: Beginner's French I
reviews:
- memorize vocab
-this will be hard if you have never taken french before
Be actively engaged about speaking in class and reviewing what you learn by doing all the homework exercises and whatever else may be useful for review in the book.
Consistent effort is important. Make sure you memorize the grammar and vocabs consistently and you would be more than fine.
Definitely recommend!
Definitely take it! French is an essential academic language.
Definitely take this class with Madame Perrier.
Do not take the M-F 9am course
Do take it, though make sure you have the time to devote to it. A supplemental grammar book might be useful to acquire.
Do the home work! Pay attention during class, this is vital.
I started French knowing Spanish already, but like all language classes at Princeton, I was amazed at how quickly we moved and how much I felt I had learned in just one semester. Do it!
I would advise another student taking this course to always go to class and study the vocabulary every night.

I would encourage other students to be active participants in this course. Since this is a language course, the key to excelling is to be bold enough to participate so that you can make sure you are saying the right things in the right manner.
I would highly recommend Alex as instructor.

I would recommend other students stay on top of syllabus work for each class.  I found that they helped me prepare for each class period ahead of time so that I got as much out of meeting with our instructor as I could.
I'd definitely take this course if you're interested in French. I loved it. It exceeded my expectations. I can't speak for all teachers, but I was taught by a graduate student and she was remarkable.
If you have never taken French before you are going to have to work extremely hard to keep up and if you've taken it before you don't really have to work much.

If you haven't been exposed to the language previously, you must be prepared to put in a lot of effort. I came out of this class with a solid french foundation, and I found it very enjoyable. Would certainly recommend!

If you want to learn French, take a shot! Prof. Perrier's 101 class is fantastic and you'll probably want to take more French after. She is an excellent teacher and is always willing to help you develop your language skills.
It is a great course to learn the basics of the French language.  As long as you stay on top of the lessons, the frequency of the assessments shouldn't bother you.

It is an excellent course for both beginners and for those with some background in French. Professor Perrier is an amazing instructor and I would recommend this class to anyone who would like to learn the French language and learn about the French culture.
It's a solid language course, no complaints.
Keep up with the work so you don't fall behind
Make sure to actually spend at least an hour each day reviewing what you have learned that day or previously and practice speaking French any chance you get.
Make sure to keep up with the vocab.
Make sure you keep up with the homework, and don't try to cram the night before the test! Prepare the whole week for it!

Make sure you keep up with the material because it does move quickly, but even if you fall behind a little it is more than possible to catch up. For language classes especially, it is to your benefit that you complete the recommended exercises in the book / given in class.
My advice is to take this course if you are truly engaged in learning french and are willing to be engaged in class and for assignments.
Organizing study groups with classmates can be very helpful in addition to individual exercises and written homework.
Read the book as much as you can.
Read the stuff and do the homework. Have fun with it.
STUDY FOR THE QUIZZES. They're not to be underestimated. I would alto recommend getting used to meeting with the professor from the beginning if you have trouble.
Speak french every day.
Stay on top of the vocabulary, because there are a lot of words in each chapter, and it is difficult to catch up if you fall behind.
Study groups are extremely helpful if this is your very first time taking this language.
Take if you want to learn french/need to learn a language
Take it!
Take it! It is a great start to French language!
Take it.
Take it. Great way to learn a language.
Take this but prepare to work hard for it
Take this course. Homework for a max of 20 minutes a night, a fun class to start your day.
This course will make you love French. Do your homework and study if you actually want to benefit from it.
This is a well structured course that will teach you basic french.
Try to speak as much conversational french as possible if you want to learn.
You have to be motivated to learn a lot on your own to succeed, but a very relaxed, pleasant class to take.
great class
not bad
take it if you want to learn French
take it!
prereqs: Students having studied French previously must take the Princeton French Language placement test. No credit is given for FRE 101 unless it is followed by FRE 102. The afternoon section of FRE 101 (C05) will focus on reading skills, in addition to oral communication, and is limited to graduate students and seniors..
descrip: This class develops the basic structures and vocabulary for understanding, speaking, writing, and reading in French. Classroom activities foster communication and cultural competence through comprehension and grammar exercises, skits, conversation and the use of a variety of audio-visual materials.

title: High-Tech Entrepreneurship
reviews: Definitely take it. Really fascinating and useful information. Loved Kuenne; he's a great guy and he cares about his students
Fantastic course. Highly recommend it.
Great course (interesting material and projects, and well taught), but beware, you need to participate a lot to get a good grade.
If you get the opportunity, definitely take it.  Might suck if you're naturally a quiet person though.
If you want to learn about the world of entrepreneurship, there may be no better resource at Princeton than this course. Take it.
If you're interested in entrepreneurship, then definitely take this course. Its somewhat on the large side, which isn't ideal, but its still good.
It is the kind of class that can change/help you figure out/confirm what you want to do in life. Take it!
MUST TAKE. Unlike any other Princeton course. Kuenne is one of the most inspirational professors I have had. Conducted like what I assume business school is like. Great cases.
One of my favorite classes at Princeton. Prof Kuenne is super accessible outside class and is a great teacher. Definitely, definitely take this class.
Participate as much as you can during class (lecture) and don't be shy to voice your opinions.
Simply do it - Kuenne is an amazing individual, and his passion is infectious. It's not onerous, it's very interesting, and surprisingly enough, entrepreneurship can be taught well!
Take it - it's interesting and you learn a lot and the Professor is very engaged in the students. Really cool guest speakers.
Take it if unexposed to the concepts of entrepreneurship
Take it!

Take it! Prof Kuenne is great. Participation counts for a lot in this class, and you'll have to read a short and usually very interesting case study before each class. Teaches you a ton, and Kuenne is very nice to get to know -- he has a lot of wisdom to share.
Take this course if you are interested in starting a business - it gives you the tools to figure out how to take your idea and make it into something that generates value.
Take this course if you are interested in the tech sector or generally want to learn about the process of starting, financing, and growing a (tech) business.
Take this course!!! Kuenne is an amazing lecturer, mentor and role model.
This class is a good and inspiring class for general entrepreneurship.  Be aware that that a lot of the cases covered don't actually have to do with tech startups.

This is a fantastic course with great teaching and guest lectures. Take it if you're interested in studying entrepreneurship and understanding the fundamentals of launching a business. Pay attention to your class participation.

This is an excellent course! Be warned, though, that there is a decent amount of work. The work includes readings that you have to do to participate in class and a midterm and final project. However, this is a very good course and I strongly recommend it!
This is one of the few courses where even a bad grade is worth the knowledge you will gain. Take it!
Try to participate as early and often in lectures, as this is one of the challenges in such a large class. Enjoy this class, it's definitely (and unfortunately) one of a kind at Princeton!
Very good class. Mostly readings and discussion. Good guest lecturers; worth taking.
Very interesting at times, not so much at others, but I would definitely recommend the course.
Wasn't a huge fan of the grading scheme (1/3 participation) since that put a lot of pressure on trying to throw in a good comment or two each class rather than just trying to get a lot out of it
interesting course, learned a lot
prereqs: Enrollment for the course is by written application bit.ly/ELE491App, deadline is April 14..
descrip: This hands-on course introduces students to analysis and actions required to launch and commercialize a tech company, through the use of Harvard Business School cases, visits from entrepreneurs, and two "field assignments". You will learn conceptual frameworks and analytical techniques for evaluating technologies, markets, and commercialization strategies. Additionally, you will learn how to attract and motivate the resources needed to start a company (e.g. people, corporate partners and venture capital), prepare business plans, structure relationships, refine product-market fit, and create and grow enterprise value.

title: Financial Risk Management
reviews: A good overview of financial risk. Know how to code.
Ask the preceptors for advice if you're an undergrad

I thoroughly enjoyed this course. If you liked optimization, orf 307, you will like this course.  Psets are easy and quick.  If you are interested in wealth management or risk management then the course is very interesting.  Not very time consuming.  Highly recommend for finance oriented ORF majors

If you are interested in the material take it.  Mulvey and his TAs are helpful and pretty understanding with workload.  Definitely a lot easier if you have prior MatLab knowledge.  Also you definitely need to be good with Excel.
your hw and lectures are the same as orf 311. they are the same course and both taught by mulvey.
prereqs: ORF 245, ORF 335 or ECO 465 (concurrent enrollment okay) or instructor's permission required.
descrip: This course covers the basic concepts of modeling, measuring and managing financial risks. Topics include portfolio optimization (mean variance approach and expected utility), interest rate risk, pricing and hedging in incomplete markets, indifference pricing, risk measures, systemic risk.

title: Conflict in Africa
reviews: If you are interested in the subject matter, definitely take it, it's like no other course offered. Truthfully it does help a little to have some knowledge of Africa beforehand, but it didn't hinder me overmuch.
This is a good class if you want a basic understanding of African conflicts, not too demanding and the readings were pretty interesting.
only take it if you're prepared to do ALOT of reading and writing
descrip: Examines selected aspects on conflict in primarily sub-Saharan Africa. We focus on issues such as: theories of conflict; types of actors; behavior, especially civilian victimization; how conflicts end; and the moral evaluation of conflict. Cases and comparisons include: the 1998 Great Lakes Conflict; the child and corporate soldier in Sierra Leone and Uganda; causes and patterns of civilian victimization; the current conflict in Zimbabwe; and the problems of accountability as experienced by the International Criminal Court and the South African Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

title: China, 1850 to the Present
reviews: A great class on modern Chinese history. Definitely take it if you have any interest. The course consists of a decent amount of work, including a final paper and final, but it is worth it.
A lot of reading but interesting material. You'll definitely learn a lot of valuable information about China.
Absolutely take this course if you have any interest in modern China, or are just looking for a great HA.
Be ready to do a lot of reading, or else you will not fully benefit from the course.

Great course!!! So so interesting, well executed, very organized. I learned so much. Professor Chen had great lectures and I was always excited to attend class. Not too much work, but watch out because the last few weeks in January get intense with the final paper and exam.

HIS 325 (Modern China) is one of the courses that I'm most glad that I ended up taking at Princeton, primarily because of Professor Chen. I took it primarily as a way to learn about China (of which I knew nothing before taking this course). Professor Chen a clear lecturer and put great effort into making sure her students learn a lot from the class. For example, she was always willing to help students during the writing process. Moreover, she's quite sharp and one the best preceptor I've had at Princeton. I should note that she has high standards and is tough on grading, but you can learn a lot if you're willing to put in the time.
Highly recommend! Talk with preceptors in advance of writing papers.
I would recommend this class, the readings are ok and there are only two papers. I like Professor Chen
Prof. Chen is super cool and really sharp and her lectures are really good. A good class to learn about China!
Read the textbook and don't miss lectures!
TAKE IT
TAKE THIS COURSE IT'S SO GOOD Janet Chen is a boss and it's really well organized. Beware that it has a paper/final tho
Take it if you're really interested but be prepared for a lot of work, and make sure to really focus on the readings.
Take it to understand the next great superpower. Every student should take this class. Very practical!
Take it! It provokes more questions than it gives you answers, but that's a good thing.
Take it! It's awesome. It requires work though so consider P/D/Fing it if you're not using for a requirement.
Take this course!!!!!!! a great HA

This class taught me a lot about modern Chinese history and how its current society came to be.  There is a lot of reading and essay writing for this course, but the knowledge I gained was well worth it.
To attend all of the lectures and stay on top of the weekly reading because there is quite a lot of it.  It is, however, easy to do this because the topic is so interesting.
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the history of modern China, from imperial dynasty to Republic, from the Red Guards to red capitalists. Through primary sources in translation, we will explore political and social revolutions, transformations in intellectual life and culture, as well as competing explanations for events such as the rise of the Communist Party and the Cultural Revolution. Major themes include: the impact of imperialism and war, tensions between governance and dissent, the emergence of nationalism, and the significance of China's history for its present and future.

title: Economics of Labor
reviews: Definitely take this if you are considering applied micro. It would probably be possible for an undergrad to take also, if they already had research ideas they were considering.
I would recommend
Try to do the key readings before the lecture.
descrip: An examination of the economics of the labor market, especially the forces determining the supply of and demand for labor, the level of unemployment, labor mobility, the structure of relative wages, and the general level of wages.

title: Architecture Design Studio
reviews: Be open-minded and brave.
Make decisions quickly and produce work to elicit feedback from Michael.
Michael Meredith is a weird, weird guy. Get ready.
Plan for fast projects.
descrip: Design Studio

title: French Literature: Approaches to the Language of Literary Texts
reviews: Do the readings.
Ensure that participate in class, make at least one comment each class. For each paper or presentation, make an appointment with the professor to go over your plans and the topic in detail.

If you have a particular interest in literature, then take it, but if you're just looking for a French class and are not very interested in lit, then I would suggest you find another, more engaging 200 level course.
It's a 1.5-hour discussion course, so participation and talking in class is very important. We go through literature and theatre and poetry, so there's a pretty good range of readings.
Probably take 207 first for speaking
Take it but be prepared to work hard.

This is a great introduction into French literature. In terms of other 200-level French courses, it is at an appropriate level in that the readings are not too difficult, but they are still challenging, and I know that my French skills greatly improved by taking this course. My only complaint is that the class can sometimes drag on, especially if other students don't do the readings and it's just awkwardly silent.

Though the professor does a good job with helping us think about the readings, I personally did not enjoy most of the readings we had (shallow characters, etc.) and so had a hard time enjoying the class. I'd take it if you think you will like the readings in the reading list, but because this class is so much based on what we read it was hard for me to feel particularly about the class.
don't take this class. a lot of work and not interesting
prereqs: FRE 107 or FRE 108 or permission of instructor. Course conducted entirely in French..
descrip: This course is meant to introduce students to great works of French literature from a range of historical periods and to provide them with methods for literary interpretation through close reading of these texts. The course syllabus is organized around common themes and generic categories. This course is invaluable preparation for more advanced and specialized 300-level courses. Classroom discussion, free exchange encouraged.

title: Modern Dance: Beginning Technique and Choreography
reviews: Be aware that this is not "just a dance course". To get the most out of this course you really have to devote just as much work time as you would to an academic class.
Do not be afraid to move in new and different ways!
I would tell another student that if they want to learn about composition and expand their understandings of movement, they should take this course.
If you're scared to take this class, don't be. I've had no experience and loved every second of it.

Really be present in each of the classes regardless of the millions of other things you have to do because when you are present, your dancing improves immediately and the course becomes a fun two hours every other day.
Take it, and go in with an open mind
prereqs: DAN 209 or permission of instructor. Interview with faculty for placement in composition section from April 7-18, 2014. To arrange an interview, email Professor Lazier (rlazier@) or Professor Fehlandt (fehlandt@) and send a list of any previous composition experience at Princeton..
descrip: Dance technique and choreography for beginning and intermediate levels. Technique class will emphasize placement and the increase of movement efficiency through proper alignment. Students will also explore dancing to different rhythms, tempos and styles of music while emphasizing weight of the body and its relationship to space and gravity. In choreography class students will develop their understanding of the ways in which structural elements and movement vocabularies contribute to a dance's overarching impact and content. Readings and viewings broaden students understanding of dance's position in the world of art and ideas.

title: Elementary Hebrew I
reviews: Anna Grinfeld is an amazing teacher. This is by far the best language course I have taken in my life. Classes are interesting and engaging, and the teacher will often add some historical or linguistic context to the material learned in class. I started out knowing the Hebrew alphabet and a few words because of my Jewish background.
If you have little or no knowledge of modern hebrew this is a great place to start!
Must study outside of just doing the homework. Reviewing vocal and grammar daily is what will help to develop your language skills the most and not loose pace with the rest of the class.
prereqs: No credit is given for HEB 101 unless it is followed by HEB 102..
descrip: To develop the skills of reading, speaking, comprehending and writing. The main emphasis is on acquiring communicative proficiency and therefore, Hebrew is progressively employed as the classroom language. A solid grammatical basis and awareness of the idiomatic usage of the language will be emphasized. Classroom activities include conversation, grammar exercises and reading. Towards the middle of the semester, an Israeli movie is shown, discussed and critized through a written assignment.

title: Subcultures
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Cinema and Culture - Work and Love, Play and Politics in Spanish Cinema
reviews: Angel is an amazing professor! He's so patient and forgiving. The films that we watched in this course are also great. I don't think that I got an A in this class, but I strongly recommend it for anyone who likes film!
Definitely watch the movies and participate in class

I would highly recommend this course for people who are proficient in Spanish. It is intellectually stimulating and is great practice for writing papers in another language. Watch all of the films and stay on top of the work and it is a very rewarding class.
Take it if you're interested in Spanish! Otherwise don't
This course was really provocative so you have to be willing to voice your opinion to thrive in this course.
Try to speak up in class. It helps a lot to get practice.
take the time to really think about the movie. Watch twice if necessary.
prereqs: One 200-level course above SPA 209 or instructor's permission..
descrip: An exploration of some of the most distinctive themes in Spanish films of the last fifty years. Topics to be discussed, among others: political repression; the modernization of Spain since the 1960s; the perversions of love; the world as a stage; new sexualities; the redefinition of gender roles; uncanny worlds.

title: Topics in Social and Personality Psychology - The Psychology of Poverty
reviews: Good course if the subject matter interests you.  Very academic - all we did was read papers.
Great class to take for an interdisciplinary perspective on poverty.
He is definitely available for help and discussion of your project proposals.  I regret not taking advantage of that help until the end.
It was very little work (4 hours a week outside of class roughly).
TAKE IT. One of the best courses I've ever taken at Princeton.
Take it if you're interested in the subject matter. Johannes is a sincerely nice person, and wants to see you succeed!

This course is way more behavioral economics than psychology! It's mostly a research methods seminar. You'll come out of it remembering more about econometrics and how to build your own study than how poor people make decisions.
this class is far more technical than you might expect. very interesting, but certainly not an overview course on poverty - little if any lecturing takes place.
prereqs: Students should come with a basic understanding of statistics. Familiarity with multivariate regression and instrumental variables will be essential for understanding many of the economic papers; however, prior familiarity with these methods is not required..
descrip: The course explores the relationship between poverty, psychology, and economic choice. In particular, we will ask whether poverty has psychological consequences, and whether these, in turn, affect economic decision-making. The course draws on material and methods from psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and development economics, including both lab and field experiements in both developed and developing countries.

title: Beginning Bosnian-Croatian-Serbian I
reviews: BCS is awesome and you're guaranteed a small class.
Highly recommend if you are interesting in learning BCS!
If you want to learn BCS, take it with Beissinger!
prereqs: Knowledge of another Slavic language is not required..
descrip: An introduction to BCS, the primary language of the former Yugoslavia (also called Serbo-Croatian), this course develops the four major language skills: speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.
