Class time is devoted to mastering conversational skills, grammar explanations, oral drilling, and reading a variety of texts--popular writing, fiction, poetry, and expository prose. Covers the fundamentals of BCS grammar (verbal conjugations, aspect, the primary verbal tenses, and all cases); high-frequency vocabulary will be progressively learned and reinforced. No credit is given for BCS 101 unless followed by BCS 102.

title: Introduction to Real Analysis
reviews: Avoid.
Covers the basics (first 4 chapters of Stein III, plus an introduction to Fourier stuff). Niels Moeller is very friendly, communicative, and helpful.
Do the readings - most important. And go to problem sessions.

I thought I wasn't going to like real analysis, but now I do. Niels is awesome: he's super nice and tries to make the lectures interesting. The problem sets were difficult BUT doable (which makes it satisfying imo). Take this class if someone good is teaching it--if you put in the effort, it's really worthwhile.

I took this course because MAT 425 seemed a bit too hard for my mathematical skill/background, and I think this was a good choice. Like the course description said, this course focused on the major topics without getting too lost in the small details. Niels was a great professor, and really responsive to the way his students learn best.

If you're thinking about real analysis, take this course! Niels is a great guy and makes the class more engaging / interesting (because, to be honest, real analysis probably isn't the most exciting math class you can take). Stein's book is good but it's pretty dense and not easy to digest mathematically (in fact some of the homework problems were rewriting and completing some of the proofs in the book so that they make sense). The class may be a bit uneven in the way we cover the book; for example, up until midterm week we were working on Chapter 1 and did a tiny bit of 2, then during the next couple of weeks we went over Chapter 2 and Chapter 3 and for the rest of the semester we worked on Chapter 4 (Hilbert spaces & Fourier series). I have to say the last part was probably the best one. Overall the course starts off easy, then it picks up but it never becomes too much to handle. Take home exams have a reasonable difficulty. Recommended!

Speaking as a COS major and someone who has taken proof-based classes here (MAT 217 and COS 340) but not MAT 215: This class was very tough. After working hard, I often could finish only half the psets. If using Stein, be very careful not to get lost in chapter 2 -- it's very important! Also, important tips: review sequences and series, and memorize as many counterexamples (function convergence, continuity, etc.) as possible. I took this class with Niels, who cares a lot but is not easy to understand in lectures. Lastly, Hilbert spaces are cool.

Take this class for the real analysis math departmental if you don't want to slave over lengthy problem sets. The amount of work in this class is very manageable, and the resources provided to the students (e.g. problem sessions, Piazza, professor's notes) were very helpful. The course generally follows Stein and Shakarchi, so you don't miss too much if you miss a class.

To my understanding, this is one of the easier 300 level math courses at Princeton. Unlike most other courses I have taken here, we only did 4 chapters of the textbook, which made the pace of the class more manageable. Niels really made the course great. He was a good lecturer and had reasonable expectations. He would also frequently answer my Piazza questions with paragraphs or even pages. If he's teaching, I have to recommend it very highly.
Work hard.
prereqs: MAT 201 and 202 or equivalent..
descrip: Introduction to real analysis, including the theory of Lebesgue measure and integration on the line and n-dimensional space, and the theory of Fourier series and Hilbert spaces.

title: Thesis Studio
descrip: Thesis studio

title: Endless Romance: From Daphnis and Chloe to Lolita
descrip: Please see website

title: Wind Engineering and Structural Dynamics
prereqs: Undergraduate-level Probability and Statistics, Differential Equations, and, preferably, Fluid Mechanics and Structural Dynamics..
descrip: Students learn how to account for wind effects in structural design to ensure that the performance of structures subjected to the action of wind are adequate during their anticipated life from the standpoint of both structural safety and serviceability.Three linked topics are discussed:(1) the wind environment,(2) the relation between that environment and the forces it induces on the structure, and (3) the behavior of the structure under the action of these forces.

title: Recent Research in Population Biology
reviews: Don't be afraid of speaking up. It is a discussion based course and you will be losing out if you choose not to speak up.

Take a lot of time to think about what readings you want to bring to the table. It is often difficult to take this time, but go talk to Henry or Corina if you are unsure of how to go about choosing your topic of discussion or what papers to assign. Some one-on-one discussion about this may prove very helpful.
prereqs: Course is limited to graduate students only..
descrip: Systematic reviews of recent literature in areas of ecology, evolution, and animal behavior. The general survey of literature is supplemented with detailed discussion of selected research papers of unusual importance and significance. (This is a core course.)

title: Advanced Theatrical Design
reviews: Give this course your all to really get the most out of it!  As it is a pass/fail course it may be tempting to put it on the back burner for the sake of other courses, but you'd be remiss to not take advantage of a whole semester with Jane and Anya there to help you and teach you as much or as little as you'd like.  If you're at all interested in theater design, take this course!
Take this if you are interested in theater and design. Know that it is a lot of work though.
This course is a HUGE amount of work, but totally rewarding if you put in the time and effort. Don't pass up the opportunity to work with these incredible designers.
prereqs: A previous course in Set, Lighting, or Costume Design or instructor permission. For admission, please contact Professor Tim Vasen at: tvasen@princeton.edu.
descrip: This course bridges the gap between students taking introductory design courses in set, costume or lighting design, and successfully designing a production on campus. The course is designed to endow students with practical skills that will enable them to actually design a production, and to support them in making technical decisions as well as in collaborating and communicating with the rest of the creative team and the technical staff. The course will combine an exploration of visual story-telling and creative collaboration with a grounding in the practical and communicative skills necessary to create the physical world of a production.

title: Biochemistry
reviews: 2nd half of this course is so much harder than the first.
Awesome course
Be prepared for lots of memorization, but the material is super interesting.
Be ready to memorize stuff.  The lectures and precepts are good for understanding and encountering the concepts, but to do well in the class, it's about memorizing the information.

Biochem is much more enjoyable than MOL 214 or Orgo because it synthesizes the material and the way Prof Hughson teaches the course gives you a big picture of what you're learning so it actually makes sense. That being said, it's a lot of material so I would only take if you're premed or genuinely interested in biochem
Biochemistry isn't that bad. Some memorization, but overall, not overwhelming.
Definitely a class where you will learn a great deal. Requires a great deal of effort, but completely worth it.
Definitely more biology oriented than orgo, aka more memorization. Overall a good course. Hughson is a good lecturer and his presentation of the material is excellently organized.
Definitely really learn the lecture notes for the exams!
Definitely take it if you are considering it especially if Professor Hughson is teaching it!  It is a lot of work though and meets during reading period
Difficult course, but well-taught.
Difficult, but necessary for pre-med. Be prepared for very fast pace.
Do it do it do it do it best teacher best book best course
Do the readings, stay on top of your work. It's too much to memorize right before an exam
Don't fear this class if you have to take it (and chances are that's why you're taking it). It's hard, and it's a lot of memorization, but it's taught well and graded fairly and transparently.
Don't take five classes while taking this class. This class requires a lot of studying time.
Don't take it unless you have to. It sucks your soul.
Don't take it unless you need to because it is difficult. But that said, Hughson is AMAZING, and it is taught extremely well.
Dowon Dan Kim would know

For a requirement class, it's really really great. Hughson is a great professor and the TA's are fantastic and helpful. Give it a shot, it's not Organic Chemistry Redux; it's a lot more biology, and the orgo that is included is pretty interesting!

For many students, the beginning of the course will be a review of familiar topics. Don't let that get to your head - it gets very difficult after the first few weeks. There is a lot of memorization - start it early.

Go to lectures. If you take more time to memorize things, start early!! You'll find yourself drowning in enzyme names and structures and pathways and amino acids if you wait until the last minute. Focus on understanding the connections and overlap in everything you learn, and you only need to understand the details for things that Prof. Hughson mentions in lecture. I would also suggest keeping up with the readings as hard as it is to. It may sometimes feel like repeat of the lectures or extra information, but it really helps you understand and review concepts. Ask questions as you have them because the course is all interconnected; the concepts later on will refer to things from earlier in the course. As someone who really struggled in organic chemistry, I was very nervous for this course, but it was actually very interesting and applicable immediately to understanding how our bodies work.
Go to review sessions, participate in precept and put as much work into problem sets as possible, as they are good preparation for exams.
Good course. A lot of work. Should get a lot our of it though
Good luck.
Great class to learn all the basics of biochemistry. Just don't fall behind. It is very hard to catch up. Reading the book is super important.
Great course, but very difficult so keep up!

Hughson is a hilarious lecturer and makes biochemistry very interesting. As a premedical student, I found this class to be extremely interesting because it's actually relevant to medicine and helps you understand what exactly is happening to your body. It was a lot of fun and I continue to make biochem references in daily life!

I found this class very enjoyable. I found it important to read the assigned book sections before the lectures. Also, don't wait until the last minute to start memorizing the amino acids and glycolysis.
I really like the class.
I think this course is well taught. Make sure you seek help if you start getting confused.

I took this class because I needed to. But by the end, I wanted to. Compared to orgo, biochem is just as rigorous but more concrete and contextual. Metabolism is fascinating and beautiful, a miracle and a science, an orchestra so well conducted that the tune of a single instrument is as striking as the whole.
I was surprised by how much I liked this course. It's not easy but Professor Hughson did a great job teaching the material in an effective, clear, and engaging way.
I would tell them to take this course if they are at all interested in the topic.  It was well-organized, fairly graded, and interesting.

I wouldn't suggest taking this for the STN because it's not an easy course. But I'd say it's a good course for science majors in general and can be quite interesting at times, especially when we talk about metabolic processes in the bigger context of the body.
I wouldn't take it unless you need to for a requirement of some sort

If you didn't like organic chemistry, don't give up hope! Biochemistry is more biology with chemistry thrown in than chemistry with biology. Prof. Hughson is an excellent lecturer, and the textbook is actually readable. Keep in mind, though, that as a mostly-biology course, memorization is unavoidable at times.
If you gotta take it...you gotta take it. Try to enjoy it.
If you're at all interested in biochem, then this is a good course to take. Prof Hughson is a great lecturer with a good sense of humor. Everything is very well-structured.
It's a good course!  Review your notes for the clicker questions.
It's a hard competitive class. Read the textbook. Start studying for the second exam as soon as the first one is over.
It's really well taught :)
It's tough. But it's more enjoyable than orgo.
Its a hard class so dont take it unless you have to but its BY FAR the best taught premed class!
Keep up with readings/material as best as you can because the course is entirely cumulative
Keep up with the material
Keep up with the readings and go to office hours for Professor Hughson or TA if you are ever confused.
Lots of memorization.
Make sure that you keep up with each lecture's material as you go along, especially because of the clicker questions that are asked about the previous lecture each class.
Make sure you get the right preceptor. Makes a big difference.
Make sure you keep up! You have to teach yourself a lot.
Memorize stuff! Memorize it all!
Most people take this because it's required, but if you have a general interest in biology and/or chemistry and are willing to work hard, you should take this because you will learn a ton!
Not as difficult as rumored. Professor Hughson is one of the best professors at the university. Definitely try to get Sophia as your preceptor! Study hard for the exams!
Not as hard as everyone says

Okay, you probably have to take this. If you don't here a brief rundown. Pros: Hughson as a lecturer. Problem sets are graded for completion, NOT correctness. Cons: Clicker questions in lecture. No feedback on problem sets. Boring and often useless precepts, which are graded for participation.
Premed
Prof Hughson is great!

READ THE BOOK. KEEP UP WITH THE COURSE. Otherwise, you'll be left behind and screwed... Go to office hours - Prof. Hughson is incredibly clear and straightforward. 

Disclaimer: This course is difficult though. Like a lot b/c of all the pre-med students and MOL students.
READ THE TEXTBOOK. For real, it gets covered on problem sets & exams. Go to lectures. Take Clicker Q's seriously.
Read the textbook.
So, so much better than organic chemistry - don't give up hope, premeds! It's a lot of work, and definitely hard, but so worth it.
Stay on top of the topics presented throughout the semester and do the optional problem sets, as they really help for exams.
Study a lot and go to every lecture.
Study hard! Really go through the notes/textbook readings carefully, memorize what you can, and practice problems.
Take advantage of all the help and resources you can; it's worth it.
Take if you need to take biochem
Take it if you have to. Otherwise not worth the time/brain capacity.
Take it! It's pretty awesome.
Take this course- I know there's a lot of memorizing, but you'll learn so much about things that you were given a surface layer explanation for in the past.
Take this if you have interest in the subject. Tests and assignments are fair. Well organized course.
The class is so hard, please stay on top of reading for the class. It's a must.
The course was a lot more work and harder than my other classes. STUDY for exams using a variety of different materials and PAY ATTENTION during class.

The material can be tough to put together and does require quite a bit of memorization. Most students have to take the course as a requirement, but I think it can be a really interesting class with material that gives you a better understanding of how biology works.
There is a lot of material so don't fall behind.

There's a lot of information in this course, but Prof Hughson does a good job of teaching it.

NOTE: I did not read the book and did fine in the course. What I did was memorized his notes and the lectures, and checked the exam study guides for stuff that wasn't covered.

This class is very well organized. Fred is a fantastic lecturer, and he manages to keep what would be an overwhelming and incessant amount of information interesting and well-structured. This class by its nature involves a lot of memorization, but the organization and the lectures make it much more student-friendly. Of the pre-med courses, this one is by far the least torturous.
This class is well-organized and very interesting, as it brings together the basics from mol 214 and orgo in the context of the human body.
This course is a lot of memorization - much different from orgo
This course is a lot of work. It is necessary to keep up constantly because it is very easy to fall behind.

This course is relatively well taught, but I would not recommend taking this class if you do not need to take it. Exams are quite difficult, and students are responsible for memorizing large amounts of detailed information.
This course is very enjoyable and you will learn a lot from Professor Hughson's lectures. Take the time to read the textbook and keep up with the material.
This is a really well-organized, taught, and generally interesting course!

This is an amazing course and the material is very interesting! Any MOL major should take this course, not only because it is required, but also because it provides very useful and interesting and amazing background information important for any scientist. Professor Hughson is a great professor and the lectures are enjoyable, although Fridays at 1:30 kind of suck. Stay on top of the material and be prepared for the two exams because I promise you that exam week will be hell. There is a lot of information and it takes time to 1) go through it all and (more importantly) 2) understand and connect the material which is necessary if you want to do well on the exams. Recap: Amazing course, great professor, very challenging but very rewarding!
This was my favorite class at Princeton. Hughson is really organized and easy to pay attention to. Worth the work.

This was not an awful mol requirement, and it was actually pretty interesting at times. The information is important, and you feel like you have learned a lot by the end. However, the exams were a bit unreasonable, and the clicker questions were tough.
This was one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton! It's so well-taught (Prof. Hughson is really enthusiastic and clear). Definitely take it, even though it covers a lot of material.
Tough class where there is so much memorization it is easy to lose site of why you are studying this subject.
Work hard.

Yes this course is important for Pre-med. But it's important to recognize that this class can take the principles of what you learned in Orgo and translate them into a way of rationalizing how people react to different biological states. You'll need to take it but take a step back and recognize how important and exciting this course can be.

You do learn a lot about biochem, metabolism etc. But it's really really hard and time consuming. 
If you are mol or pre-med, just try to enjoy it.
You're taking this course because you have to.  Very well taught and very challenging.  Buy a clicker.
hard but great
it's a tough class, they say it's because you need to keep up, but in reality it's because there is a huge gap between what they teach you and then what they test you on.
lot of memorization
prereqs: MOL 214/215 and CHM 304/304B.
descrip: Fundamental concepts of biomolecular structure and function will be discussed, with an emphasis on principles of thermodynamics, binding and catalysis. A major portion of the course will focus on metabolism and its logic and regulation.

title: Princeton Atelier - Pay Attention: The Art of Here and Now
reviews: I completely recommend taking an atelier course, especially for the vast breadth of knowledge acquired on the specific subject of the course.
Since this class was ATL, I don't think it will be offered again.  If it were, I would advise other students to really engage in the readings to get the most out of the seminars.
prereqs: Students from Theater, Computer Science, Psychology, Sociology, Visual Arts, Philosophy, Dance, Creative Writing are especially encouraged to apply. Applications are available on the Atelier website: http://www.princeton.edu/arts/arts_at_princeton/princeton_atelier/. Deadlines are posted on the website. Other 80% is based on students final creative project..
descrip: In a world where technology shapes the way we think, it is hard to free ourselves from it. How are we changing to accommodate the open faucet of information? How has our ability to pay attention transformed? Marianne Weems, director of NYC-based Builders Association ensemble will work with students to investigate the area of 'presentism'. Working in a cross-disciplinary mode, students are invited to examine their experience of the 'here and now' through readings, discussion, games, and blogging.

title: Investigative Journalism - Accountability Reporting
reviews: Definitely take it - there's a field trip to Washington and it's a ton of fun.

If you're interested in journalism, this class is great. You learn a lot of widely applicable journalistic skills. Ultimately, you may decide that investigative journalism is not your thing (it's hard!), but Professor Stephens is an awesome, warm teacher, and a lot of the skills you learn will come in handy in other contexts.
Research, not writing.  Do not take with other challenging classes.
Take it!

There are a lot of reasons to take this class: Professor Stephens is a fantastic professor, the small-class setting allows for close interaction, and you'll get the chance to investigate a topic that interests you throughout the semester.
This is relevant both as an aspiring journalist and as someone who wants to be a conscientious member of society and consumer of good journalism. Basically, everyone should take it.
it's lots of work so prepare to spend time reading/preparing for class as well as working on a long semester project, like a JP or mini thesis. lots of work.
prereqs: Enrollment by application - see course web address.
descrip: Students will learn the sophisticated reporting, research and interviewing techniques that investigative reporters use to root out corruption in public and private institutions. While learning to produce compelling news pieces, students will discover how these tools can be used to advantage in other fields and everyday life. In addition to exploring new models of journalism (crowd-sourcing, social networking), we will visit The Washington Post and meet with some of the nation's most successful investigative journalists.

title: Organic Materials for Photonics & Electronics
reviews: Definitely take this course if you work in an area related to organic electronics.  Consider taking this course if you want to improve your understanding of electronic devices, organic solid-state physics, etc.
Great course, thank you.
Highly recommend.
I would recommend this course, but just be prepared to cover a lot of material.
If you are not good in chemistry, do not take this course

Read the textbook and talk to professors. 
Engage in class discussion as much as possible
descrip: An introduction to organic materials with application to active electronic and photonic devices. Basic concepts and terminology in organic materials, and electronic and optical structure-property relationships are discussed. Charge transport, light emission and photoinduced charge transfer are examined. Finally, archetype organic devices as light emitting diodes, photodetectors, solar cells and transistors are described.

title: Feminist Media Studies /Media Representations of Feminism
reviews: Definitely take it, but be prepared to have to self-organize a lot and direct your own study in the direction you'd like it to go.

This is a great class! Professor Deem is extremely helpful and so knowledgeable. She really pushed us to recognize the nuances and complexities of the topics we each independently explored. Speaking at the symposium was an incredible experience.

This is a great class! You'll focus the entire semester on a single topic that you choose to research, and the entire class is an experience of collaborative work, feedback, presentation, presentation-planning, and heated debates about feminism in the media. It was a little disorganized at times, but it's super chill while at the same time being really serious. The students in this class are so much fun - so opinionated and willing to have good discussions about equality and feminism and everything else.
descrip: Feminist Media Studies/Media Representations of Feminism considers discourses of feminism that are not usually put in direct conversation. Feminist studies of media are a rich and varied field of inquiry, while feminism itself is a recurring object of media fascination. In public, media stories of feminism circulate as authoritative. Feminist arguments often become public spectacles where the media simultaneously leers at and dismisses feminist speech. In the process, these spectacularly public representations of feminism reduce the multiplicity of feminist positions and voices.

title: Socrates: Moral Philosophy and the Philosophical Life
descrip: Please see website

title: Senior Independent Work
prereqs: Open to MAE (senior) concentrators only.
descrip: Senior independent work is the culminating experience for the mechanical and aerospace engineering programs. Students select a subject and adviser, define the problem to be studied and propose a work plan. Projects include elements of engineering design, defined as devising a system, component, or process to meet desired needs. A list of possible subjects of particular interest to faculty and staff members is provided. Students must submit a written final report and present their results to faculty, staff, fellow students, and guests.

title: National Security Policy
descrip: Examines the changing meaning of "national security" and the various policies and institutions through which states may seek to enhance it. Emphasis is on the formation and implementation of national security policy by the U.S. government.

title: American Comics
reviews: Awesome class. No artistic background necessary. Quality syllabus and laid back professor
Definitely take this. It is really interesting and fun.
I would take this class. A good one if you need another writing class.

If you're interested in interpreting comics through a literary lens, this is the class for you. Although you can geek out with the professor on any sort of comics  you want during office hours, class is reserved for scholarly view on indie comics.
Ok to PDF, probably wouldnt want to take for a grade. Requires a lot.
Read the texts (they're interesting!) and attend precepts and lectures
Regardless of your interest in comics, it's definitely a course to take!
Stay up on the readings. They're fun to read. Use the writing center fellow too. They're very helpful to work out an idea into a full paper.
Take any course with Professor Ball if he comes back!
Take good notes in the lecture because Professor Ball really has some good notes about it.
Take it!
Take it!!!!! Or at least read the books on the list because they are so worthwhile.
Take it, and do the readings, even the ones you don't like, because you might end up finding something to appreciate in them!
Take this class, it is both an excellent mix of not a overwhelming amount of work and great times in class.
Take this course if you are a comics fan and want to study comics in depth.
The course is a very interesting class, highly recommend.
This is a really good course to take as an elective. The readings are really fun, and the written work isn't too demanding. It was a great break from everything else going on.
This was a great, fun class to fulfill the literature requirement.
descrip: This course will survey comics in contemporary American literature, including graphic novels, animated films, and conventional novels about comics artists. Among the questions we will ask: Can comics become literature? How does the grammar of comics function and how does its mode of simultaneous seeing and reading complicate literary analysis? What relationship exists between comics, film, and other 21st-century narrative media? We'll be assessing these questions against the larger landscape of contemporary American literature, while developing the core skills of literary analysis, critical thinking, and argument-based writing.

title: Evaluation of Demographic Research
reviews: pick a dissertation that is very close to what you might be doing in the future
prereqs: Prerequisites: POP 501 and POP 502, or instructor's permission.
descrip: Course is designed for doctoral students in their third year of a specialization in demography. One objective of the course is to examine critically how researchers tackle demographic research questions. A second related goal is to explore the construction of a dissertation and a research paper.

title: Seminar in International Politics
descrip: A general introduction to the field of international relations, with an emphasis on the principal theoretical approaches and major problems and theories in the field. Students emerge from the course with an ability to situate theories and empirical claims in the broader historical, conceptual and empirical context of debates and literatures.

title: Modern Islamic Political Thought
descrip: An examination of major facets of Islamic political thought from the late nineteenth century to the present in a broadly comparative framework and against the backdrop of medieval Islamic thought. Topics include: the "fragmentation" of religious authority and its consequences for Muslim politics; conceptions of the shari'a and of the Islamic state; and Islamist discourses on gender, violence, and relations with non-Muslims.

title: Queer Theory
descrip: In this course, we will read extensively in the interdisciplinary field of queer theory, from its emergence two decades ago to its present-day articulations. We will explore what is meant by "queer," what relation it may or may not have to "homosexuality" and "gay" and lesbian," and what challenges it poses to a politics of identity. We will also interrogate the category of "theory" itself--what it is, what it does, and what kinds of literary or historical interventions it can perform. Particular attention will be paid to the queering and de-queering of public space.

title: Advanced French Language and Style
reviews: Do the grammar and make an effort to study it outside of class. Come prepared to speak as in any language class. You will get a lot out of it.
Take it!

Take this course with Christopher Davis. He knows how to teach effectively and he makes every class worthwhile. I am an Econ major, but this course was one of the best courses I've taken at Princeton so far. The workload is fair, and the engagement in the classroom is something I never really experienced before in other classes.
prereqs: A 200-level French course or permission of instructor..
descrip: To improve spoken and written French through comparative study of English and French grammatical and syntactic structures, literary translation, and reading of non-literary texts.

title: Economic Analysis of Development (Advanced)
descrip: Considers theories and evidence to explain processes of economic development; examines theories of economic growth, and the two-way links between development and poverty, inequality, social institutions, and the family. Policy debates on education, health, and social policy, and governmental and international aid are also covered.

title: Advanced Turkish: Selected Readings in Historical and Literary Texts
prereqs: Students are expected to have a sufficient command of Turkish language intermediate/upper intermediate level) to fulfill the reading and writing assignments. See instructor for further information.
descrip: This course introduces a wide variety of reading material (newspaper, memoir, letter, short story, diary etc.) to strengthen students' abilities in understanding and evaluating modern Turkish texts. Information on selected authors and their works will provide a general view on the Ottoman/Turkish cultural, literary and historical panorama. The analysis and discussions of the texts in class will serve to build fluency.

title: Advanced Logic
reviews: Be aware that this is a challenging class just like any other upper-level math class. Burgess' lectures can be very fast and hard to follow, although he can also be brilliant and witty at times. If Thomas Barrett is precepting, get in his precept--a good preceptor who helps explain the material and balance out Burgess' rapid-fire style makes the class worth it. As a philosophy major with not as much background in math, this class was very challenging and did take a lot of time. The concepts were neat though and worth learning.
Don't take this unless you're interested and have a help mechanism. If Barrett is the TA still, then take the course. He is awesome.
None
Recommended as an elective for concentrators in math, and possibly even as an additional QR requirement for others, such as COS or PHY majors.
Take it.

This class assumes quite a bit of mathematical maturity. If you've taken a proof-based math class here, it won't be too challenging. The workload is minimal compared to courses in the mathematics department but the material is recondite and dense. I would recommend to anyone with and interest in foundations of math.
Use other sources besides the reading to understand the material, and go to office hours frequently (especially if Thomas Barrett is still the preceptor for this course the next time it gets taught)
prereqs: Some previous study of logic or mathematical maturity..
descrip: An introduction to axiomatic set theory, up to the proof of the consistency of the axiom of choice.

title: Introduction to Atmospheric Sciences
reviews: An excellent introductory course to atmospheric science. Although it is "introductory", it does get quite sophisticated, but is always very interesting. Professor Fueglistaler is also a friendly, approachable, and knowledgeable professor.
Don't. If you take it, you'll have to teach yourself atmospheric science. Ech.
I would recommend taking this course. It provides a strong foundation in atmospheric science and introduces many complex concepts.
It's often hard to follow lectures.
It's pretty boring unless you're genuinely interested in the subject - seems like something only a GEO major would enjoy

This class is a well-taught, interesting course about observable physical phenomena.  If you like general science, but not lots of abstract calculation, this is a great course for you.  However, you will need some math and physics, so if you're coming to the class without that background, expect to need a lot of help.
This course is not impossible to get through without previous Matlab experience.  Our AI, Jaya, put a lot of effort into showing students some of the fundamentals during office hours.
descrip: An introduction to atmospheric sciences. This course discusses aspects of weather and climate both from a phenomenological and analytical point of view. The course balances overview lectures (also covering topics that have high media coverage like the "Ozone Hole" and "Global Warming") with a few in-depth analyses of selected aspects. Lectures are complemented with homework based on real data, demonstrating basic data analysis techniques employed in atmospheric sciences.

title: Projects in Vocal Performance - Opera Performance
reviews: Highly recommend any singers to try this out!!
If at all someone is interested in being in an opera, this is a great place to start.
It's an amazing opportunity and you get to work with some of Princeton's best musicians!
It's really fun, even if you're only a small part.
Learn the score learn the score learn the score learn the score. Sing to the recording. A lot.
TAKE IT!
Take it if you love singing and opera. You'll learn a lot. This is one of the most fun courses I've taken here.

The production really depends on its students. Pull your weight, know your music, study and constantly try to improve on your character, and engage with the professionals for help, and the course will be an amazing experience. Give them something to work with, and they'll give back. The more you do earlier on, the better off you'll be. The course has the potential to be an incredible experience and incredibly rewarding, as it was for me.
prereqs: Enrollment is by application and audition (early May 2014). Audition sign-up sheets will be made available online. Contact Gabriel Crouch for more details. You should prepare to sing one operatic aria of your choice. Additionally, those trying out for certain lead roles will be required to sing a pre-designated excerpt from that role. These excerpts will be made available in the department office after Spring Break 2014..
descrip: This is a performance class, designed to prepare students for fully staged presentations of two complete Operas, through rehearsal and coaching. Students will be expected to learn their roles alone, so that class time can be used efficiently and effectively in fine-tuning individual parts, blocking and ensemble rehearsal.

title: Readings in African American History
descrip: This course is designed to introduce graduate students to the literature of African-American History, from the colonial era up to more recent times. Major themes and debates will be highlighted. The course should help students to define interests within the field to pursue further study and research and also to aid preparation for examinations.

title: Renaissance and Baroque Architecture
descrip: European architecture from 1420 to the mid-18th century with particular emphasis on its historical and social background. Various architectural styles - Renaissance, baroque, and rococo - are studied in terms of important architects and buildings especially of Italy, France, and England.

title: Intermediate Modern Greek
prereqs: HLS 102 or permission of instructor.
descrip: To improve the students' oral and written skills and introduce them to themes in the Hellenic tradition through readings in Modern Greek literature.

title: Introduction to the Study of African American Cultural Practices
reviews: Be sure to attend lecture and do readings. You will be grateful you did. you will learn so much and be challenged!
Be willing to be engaged in precept. You'll get a lot more out of it by being involved in discussions rather than simply listening.
Definitely take this course to get a broad sense of the subject, and enjoy a great class!
Do all of the readings and try to get Professor Glaude as your preceptor.
Good PDF
Highly recommend

I highly recommend taking this course if you are at all interested in African American Studies. As an intro course, it will give you a good sense of the field and the important literary works. Definitely take it if Prof. Glaude is teaching!
I think that it is a class that everyone should take at some point in time.

If you are interested in AAS just for general interest I would not suggest that you take this course because there is not enough time to fully discuss anything really, also it tends to be very religion-centric so if that's not your thing, you might want to rethink taking the course. Professor Glaude is amazing though, he keeps the subject matter very interesting and keeps everyone rapt throughout the lecture.

If you have never taken an African American Studies class, I think this would be a great start because it lays the foundation for so many other courses within the field of African American Studies.  Professor Glaude is a wonderful lecturer and his lecture style is like none other because he is able to engage and capture his audience.
It's important to know. Take it.
Just do the readings, pay attention, and do not be afraid to ask for help.
Just make sure you attend lecture. He is such a great lecturer.
Not a hard course but the lectures and readings are worth it.
Pay as close attention as possible in lecture! this will be the most interesting and engaging part of the course.

Prepare for precept (and hope others do too) otherwise you won't get much out of it.
Talk to preceptor/professor about ideas for papers and really demand (nicely, obvi) solid, substantial feedback (they'll give it).
Prof. Glaude is amazing! Make sure to get in his precept! The readings for this course are amazing. A great introduction to African American Studies.

Professor Glaude is a fantastic lecturer, and I felt the class gave a good introduction to some of the fundamental works in African American studies. Though the reading is fairly heavy and often complex/hard to understand, the class is definitely worthwhile and important.
Professor Glaude is a great lecturer and I would make sure that you get him as your preceptor.
Professor Glaude is one of the most impressive professor's I've had at Princeton, worth hearing from a man who is so passionate about his subject.
Read as much of the material as possible. Also, go to officer hours, because Professor Glaude is such a great teacher to speak with.
Read, talk to Glaude, ask provocative questions, and write compelling papers.
Stay on top of the readings--they can be a bit much at times, but they are well worth it.
Students should use precept time as wisely as possible to form questions and become comfortable with the material.
Take the course! Professor Glaude is a great lecturer!

Take this course! You will think deeply about race, identity and the way it affects/has affected our life in America. Don't be intimidated by how profound Prof Glaude is. He's super understanding and approachable.
Take this course. Work is very manageable and you learn something important in the process.

This is a great course.  Professor Glaude is an amazing lecturer and teacher.  He cares not only about the content of his course, but ensuring his students grow as learners and thinkers.  The readings were well chosen, interesting, and mostly enjoyable.  Whether you're working towards an AAS certificate or not, take this class.  You won't regret it.
take this course, Glaude is awesome and super willing to work with the students
descrip: This course examines the past and present, the doings and the sufferings of Americans of African descent from a multidisciplinary perspective. It highlights the ways in which serious intellectual scrutiny of the agency of black people in the United States help redefine what it means to be American, new world, modern and post modern

title: Introduction to African Literature and Film
reviews: Definitely take it! Belcher is great. It'll be a fun and engaging class, and you'll share great ideas and experiences with your classmates!
Do the reading assignments and watch the films; else it is like going to a book club without having read the material.
Enjoy the class !
TAKE IT
Take it if you want to learn about African literature for the first time.
Take this class! It will greatly improve your writing and critical thinking skills while exposing you to very interesting films and texts.
descrip: African literature and films have been a vital (but often unacknowledged) stream in and stimulant to the global traffic in invention. Nigerian literature is one of the great literatures of the 20th century. Ethiopian literature is one of the oldest in the world. South Africans have won more Nobel Prizes for Literature in the past forty years than authors from any other country. Senegalese films include some of the finest films ever made. In this course, we will study the richness and diversity of foundational African texts (some in translation), while foregrounding questions of aesthetics, style, and humor.

title: Creative Writing (Fiction)
reviews: A once in a lifetime opportunity, but you will only get as much as you put in. Be proactive about revising your work and seek comments outside of class.
APPLY TO THE CREATIVE WRITING PROGRAM!
Be careful with your grammar!

Be invested in creative writing as it is, on its own, on your own. Taking a class which meets once a week and which is PDF can cause you to marginalize the work in this class, which defeats the purpose of taking such a subject.
Creative Writing has been my most fulfilling class at Princeton, and Fiona is an incredible teacher who truly motivated me to try to be great.
Definitely take a creative writing course if you have interest in writing!
Definitely take it with Hanna Pylvainen! The best course I've taken at Princeton so far.
Definitely take this course if you can. Make sure to give yourself plenty of time to write so that you make your workshops worth it.
Definitely take! Really good practice in creative writing and a great opportunity for feedback.
Fiona Maazel is great! If you want to learn about what makes good fiction work, this is the class for you.
For anyone who believes in the importance of stories in our lives, and who wants to spend a couple hours every week in the presence of a greatness and some creative peers, TAKE A CWR COURSE!
Highly recommend

I strongly recommend taking a creative writing class here at Princeton. I had never written fiction before, and found it challenging, but exciting to try writing in a safe environment. Chang Rae Lee gave great feedback for each piece I wrote and was especially good at teaching me how to read with the eyes of a writer. Two small gripes: CWR classes are very much you get out of it what you put into it, so it can be frustrating to realize during the semester that you aren't producing your best work if you don't put in consistent writing time; and class discussion/workshops are very much driven by student participation, so if other members of your class aren't big on discussing the story of the work or other class member's work, classes can be challenging to get through. 

That being said, I think CWR classes are a must take?I'm already planning on my next one!
I would advise that they work on assignments early.
I would only take this course if you actually enjoy creative writing. If you do, though, it's a great stress-free class!
I would strongly recommend this course to other students. It will make you a better writer and make you fall even more in love with creative writing than you were before.

If you are at all interested in creative writing, and especially if you are interested in writing realistic fiction, definitely take this course. Your work will be heavily criticized and you will improve drastically as a writer.
It is up to you to make the most of it. Since it is P/D/F, there is a temptation not to prioritize it. However, by leaving your writing to the last minute, you won't enjoy it.

It's a good fourth or fifth class to take when you have a semester with a lot of other difficult classes. However, I didn't feel like I got as much out of the class as I could have because I ended up doing work for this class at the last minute. Workshops felt repetitive near the end of the semester.

No matter which professor you get, this course will be really fun and a great experience. Be aware that you will have you create a lot of material, and that writing will take quite a bit of time, so make sure you don't slack off!
Only take if you actually have an interest in creative writing.

Participate! Don't be intimidated by the teacher. The fact that they're teaching here means that they want to help, so ask them questions whenever you have any and be honest in your critiques of other students.
Plan out your writing time wisely or you'll be rushing to find creative inspiration at the last minute, which is always difficult and never satisfying.

Professor Choi is excellent - kind, thoughtful, and an exceptional author. I would absolutely suggest taking a beginning fiction course with her. I had never written fiction before, and she helped me to improve my writing and my confidence in my work in just a semester.
Professor Choi is very well-organized and gives detailed, constructive, helpful feedback. The class is great! take it if you enjoy writing creatively, or just making up stories in your head.
Professor Eugenides gives very honest, and sometimes harsh feedback. However, he is very interested in helping you improve your writing, and is a great resource to consult for assignments.
Professor Lee is very nice and his classes are relatively well structured. However, if you don't get along with your group of students, the course can be quite awkward/unenjoyable.
Start on the short stories when you have a lot of time so you can actually turn in something that represents good work.
TAKE THIS COURSE!!!!!!

Take full advantage of this special opportunity. It's one of those classes you get what you put into it. I regret not putting in as much effort in the earlier segment of the class and only producing mediocre stories, only to realize how much more fruitful it would've been if I consistently tried my best.
Take it
Take it and push yourself to write something brand new.
Take it if you like writing and want a low-key, low-stress course. Beyond easy as a fifth.
Take it if you love creative writing and reading!
Take it!
Take it! And start working on your assignments earlier rather than later.
Take it! If you can get Hanna Pylvainen you should, but I'm sure with any professor it would be a great class.
Take it! Writing 3 stories and reading others' for workshop actually takes more time than it sounds, but is definitely worth it.
Take it, it's the best class.
Take it. You won't be disappointed.
Take this class because it's great. It's not just an Easy Pass. You'll learn about yourself and your peers. It will also be your favorite class.
Take this course if you are at all interested in creative writing/reading!! Highly recommend.

Take this course if you have any interest in writing fiction. Even if you have very little experience, or a lot, this course is extraordinarily enjoyable and you can learn so much about your own, and others', writing.
Take this course if you think you are at all interested in creative writing!

Take this course!  Susan's great, the small class size is amazing too.  The course is super engaging and you learn a lot, but it is also just the right amount of work (low pressure but still a decent amount) for a PDF class.
Take this course. Prof Maazel is a great teacher, and knows what she is doing when it comes to teaching creative writing. She actively crafts lessons, and works on specific elements of craft.

This is a wonderful course; the environment is ideal for creative writing, the stories that we read are great, and the professor did a great job of helping us analyze them. I just wish the professor spent more time on actually giving us concrete lessons on improving our writing.

This was my favorite course of my Princeton career so far. If you ever have any space in your schedule, take Creative Writing and definitely pick Hanna if she's teaching. This is fun and the work load is totally manageable.

To any aspiring writers: TAKE. THIS. COURSE. Where else will you have the chance for your works to be critiqued on a weekly basis by Pulitzer Prize-winning authors? The creative writing department is yet another gleaming gem of Princeton's.
Try to take the class with other engaging students.

Very enjoyable and little work. I don't think we were taught that much, but I definitely improved just by practicing. A good way to get time to write. I recommend finding a friend (not necessarily in the class) to read your work before you submit it so you can make revisions before it's workshopped in class. You'll get a lot more out of it if you bring a good story to class.
excellent
take it for the P homie
prereqs: Please visit the Lewis Center Creative Writing website for application information. Application deadline is April 11, 2014. Accepted students will be able to enroll in SCORE May 19th-23rd..
descrip: The curriculum allows the student to develop writing skills, provides an introduction to the possibilities of contemporary literature and offers a perspective on the place of literature among the liberal arts. Criticism by practicing writers and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature.

title: Structure of the Stars
reviews: It will be meaningful to prepare well before the class.
Open your ears and partake of the knowledge of this instructor!
descrip: Theoretical and numerical analysis of the structure of stars and their evolution. Topics include a survey of the physical process important for stellar interiors (equation of state, nuclear reactions, transport phenomena); and the integrated properties of stars and their evolution.

title: Introductory Sculpture
reviews: Definitely take this course if you are interested and start working diligently on all sculptures immediately.
Even though you may have not taken an art course before or consider yourself an artist, take it because it will engage your own feelings about art and open it to other thoughts.

I highly recommend taking this class as a way to learn new and unique skills and apply learning to a completely new format and setting. Never in any other context would I have been able to learn how to work with plaster, wood, metals, among many other materials, and I believe that this class perfectly accomplishes what a Princeton class should strive to do; teach us unique skills and competences.
If you have the time take the class it is very interesting.
Take it! One of my favorite courses at Princeton

This is a great class! Especially if you have no art experience and don't mind/enjoy working with your hands.
Martha will teach you a lot.
this is a very time consuming course! only take it if you are willing to give 9 hours a week
descrip: A studio introduction to sculpture, particularly the study of form, space, and the influence of a wide variety of materials and processes on the visual properties of sculpture leading to the development of an understanding of contemporary sculpture and a basic technical facility in wood working, mold making, casting and metal working.

title: Vaccination and Society: Ethics, Politics, and Public Health
descrip: Please see freshman seminars website

title: Introduction to Latin American Cultures
reviews:
1. pay attention in class. It's hard at first because its taught entirely in Spanish but Profesora covers everything important to do with each reading
2. do the readings (even the difficult ones-you won't regret it)
3. Try to speak up in class. I didn't do as much as I should and I kind of regret it

Although the class is interesting Professor Nouzeilles is a busy person and therefore sometimes gave us the prompt for an essay a day or two before it was due. It was stressful. Also, she doesn't respond as quickly to emails so if its something important make sure the subject of your email reflects that.
Definitely take the course and meet with Profesora Nouzeilles individually and pay attention to her commentary in class.
Don't take it just because the course title sounds like what you want to study.
Go to office hours always.
I strongly recommend this course to students who are looking to familiarize themselves with reading and writing about literature in Spanish and have a general interest in Latin America.

Keep up with the readings and the journal entries! Also, give yourself sufficient time to write the essays, as analyzing and writing about class material in another language can be difficult and painstaking at times.
Make sure to do the readings and have at least one insightful thing to contribute to the discussion.
Take this course if you are at all interested in Latin American culture--it provides an engaging overview with a wonderful professor.
Take this course, you will improve your Spanish writing skills
good course! not that hard, but interesting. Professor Nouzeilles is great too.
prereqs: SPA 207 or higher, or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course offers an introduction to modern Spanish American literatures and cultures. Through a wide spectrum of materials (essays, fiction, poetry, film, and art), students will study some of the most relevant issues in Latin American modern history, such as modernity, history, memory, and gender politics. The list includes works by Nobel Prize winners Gabriela Mistral and Gabriel Garcia Marquez, and artists such as Rivera and Kahlo. Students are strongly encouraged to read at least one complete classic Latin American book in English or Spanish.

title: Nonlinear Optics
prereqs: ELE 351 or ELE 352 or Permission Of Instructor..
descrip: Introduction to nonlinear optics, second harmonic generation, parametric amplification and oscillation, the electro-optic effect, third order nonlinearities, phase-conjugate optics, photorefractive nonlinear optics, solitons.

title: Data Structures and Graph Algorithms
reviews: Skip this one. While Tarjan is brilliant one-on-one, he's not a great lecturer (even in a class of 8). We never got any feedback on any of the work we turned in and the final project was pretty vague.
Take this course if you are interested in graph algorithms, and you are ok with being confused at times, as the material discussed is truly some of the most recent work being done in the field.

You learn about data structures and related algorithms in this course. The small class size allows for a bit more discussion than in a normal lecture, which adds some. Otherwise, you can probably tell if you'll like the class or not from the syllabus and first class.
prereqs: COS 423 or equivalent.
descrip: Topics selected from important recent results in the areas of data structures and graph algorithms. Possible themes to be explored include amortization, persistence, and randomness in algorithm design and analysis.

title: Behavioral Finance
reviews: Do not take this course unless you want to waste a lot of time.
Hong is an expert in this topic. Not all topics are interesting.
I recommend this course to those who are going to work in trading and asset management. It's very helpful in understand people's behaviors in finance.
Take that
Very interesting class as it allows the student to gain a different perspective from the way finance is usually taught.
attend lectures and pay attention to the intuition of the homeworks
prereqs: ECO 562 recommended.
descrip: Traditional economics and finance typically use the simple "rational actor" model, where people perfectly maximize, and efficient financial markets. We will present models that are psychologically more realistic than this standard model. About 30% of the course will be devoted to economics, 70% to finance. Applications to economics will include decision theory, happiness, fairness, and neuroeconomics. Applications to finance will include theory and evidence on investor psychology, predictability of the stock market and other markets, limits to arbitrage, bubbles and crashes, experimental finance, and behavioral corporate finance

title: Film and Television Review: The Princeton Buffer
reviews: A very fun course. If you're interested in this kind of writing, definitely take it!
DO IT.
Highly recommended. It's fun, low stress, and great for people who like television and film, and enjoy writing about it.

Professor Fuss is quite witty and very supportive and caring of her students. The format of this class is very free, and in many ways more similar to an extracurricular than a formal class with readings/lectures. Please only take this class if you genuinely love films and want to write for a blog.
TAKE IT! This is an incredible class and sadly there are not many others like it at Princeton. You will not regret it!
Take it seriously.
Take this! One of the best classes I've taken at Princeton. Really easy, both in terms of the amount of work and how enjoyable the work is. If you like movies and writing this is a MUST.

This is a wonderful course for anyone particularly interested in the topic.  The format, assignments, etc. are pretty different from other courses, which makes for nice variety.  Classes are typically used for informal discussions and editing reviews, both of which are pretty enjoyable.  It's definitely satisfying to see different things come together over the course of the semester and I'm glad I was able to be a part of it.  Honestly, this must be the only class I've ever looked forward to attending every week.
This is one of the best courses I have taken at Princeton
You should really take this course if you have any interest in writing for a publication.
prereqs: To apply, please send an email to Diana Fuss (dfuss@princeton.edu) with a note about your interest in writing, in film or television, or in both. There are no prerequisites for this course, though preference will be given to students with strong writing skills or an interest in journalism. Students from any major are welcome to apply..
descrip: This course will continue to build the university's new film and television review, The Princeton Buffer (https://princetonbuffer.princeton.edu/). Participants will function as editorial board members for the blog, providing content, deciding policies, and shaping opinion. Combining both individual and collaborative exercises, coursework will focus on writing and editing reviews of film, television, and video as we experiment with new ways to think, talk, and blog about media.

title: Tea, Large Jars, Warriors, and Merchants in Sixteenth-century Japan
reviews: I doubt this will be offered again since Chigusa is going back to its home in DC, but if it is you should absolutely take it. Great Professor, great material!
Take it! It's a wonderful course. It will help you to understand not only chanoyu but also some very important issues in art history, for example, what is a work of art.

Take this course if you are interested in learning about the history of the Japanese tea ceremony!  There is quite a bit of reading and a long final paper, but the quality of this class is superb, and you will enjoying doing things unavailable in most other classes here at Princeton.  Our class was able to interact with old objects in museum storage and talk to cool guests.
descrip: The seminar is taught in conjunction with a special exhibition at the Art Museum, "Chigusa and the Art of Tea in Japan," and examines the diverse arts employed in the pre-modern Japanese practice of chanoyu (tea ceremony), including ceramics, paintings, and architecture. Among the topics considered are the physical and conceptual adaptations of objects for chanoyu, the practice of bestowing proper names on inanimate things, tea men's invention of a new aesthetic ideal, and their creation of multi-media ensembles. The seminar emphasizes the study (and use) of actual tea objects, and readings include translations of pre-modern chanoyu texts.

title: Viruses: Strategy and Tactics
reviews: Definitely take this course if you are interested in virology. Both the lectures and precepts were taught well. You do need to put in a good amount of time to learn all the material for the midterm and final, but you really do learn a lot.

Take if you have any interest in Virology. Goes well with either MOL or EEB Immunology. I took EEB327, and the information I learned in that class was pretty helpful for the second half of the semester in Virology.

Take it! It will make you think about viruses in a whole new way. I have been amazed by how well I can explain simple facts about say flu vaccines or what is going in my own body or that of a friend or family member when we get sick.
Take it. You learn a lot. Exams are straightforward for the most part. It does feel like you are competing with the other students because there is still a curve.

Take this course! It will require a lot of memorization so if you're not into that, I would advise against it, but the material is very intriguing. Also, of all the exams I have ever taken at Princeton, the virology exam felt the most fair and enjoyable.
Take this if you're interested in viruses.
This is an interesting course with a lot of value, however, expect to put a lot of time in as there is a lot you need to memorize to be able to take the exams.
take it!
prereqs: MOL 342 or MOL 348 or Permission of Instructor. No courses in the biological sciences or other departmental courses may be taken Pass/D/Fail by molecular biology concentrators..
descrip: Viruses are unique parasites of living cells and may be the most abundant, highest evolved life forms on the planet. The general strategies encoded by all known viral genomes are discussed using selected viruses as examples. The first half of the course covers the molecular biology (the tactics) inherent in these strategies. The second half introduces the biology of engagement of viruses with host defenses, what happens when viral infection leads to disease, vaccines and antiviral drugs, and the evolution of infectious agents and emergence of new viruses.

title: Policy Making in America
reviews: A really good class for learning about American politics, and probably will be even better once the kinks are worked out from the first year.
All Politics majors MUST take this class.

Be careful about this course. Midterms were not returned until after the PDF deadline, so I would caution anyone who is planning on PDFing against taking this class. When I asked for feedback on the midterm in order to make my decision, I was given a range; my final grade wasn't even within the range given, so I feel that the same range was given to anyone. That said, good lectures & readings. Should be a fairly easy class for anyone who has a background knowledge of the American political system.
Don't get Ben as a preceptor. Don't need to do the lecture reading, do the precept readings. Go to lecture thats basically all you need to do well for the final!
Eh, don't take it. The professor seems like he would be wonderful in a seminar, but the lecture was incredibly disorganized.
Enjoyable course.
I would recommend this course to others, provided they are interested in politics and independently motivated to engage with the material.
I would recommend this course. Its interesting, fun, and not too difficult.
If you are interested in the specific subject, take it. It is, in my opinion, not an excellent class, or very engaging. It might not be a lot of work, but it is also not very easy.
If you are really interested in the material then take it, but be prepared for some awful lectures
Important to come to lecture having done the readings
Interesting class, even if there is a lot of reading and a ton of information crammed in to every single lecture.
It's okay - take if interested. Better if you have previous policy background.

Lecture is probably the best part of this class. because you learn a lot about policymaking. it is pretty straightforward though so if you have already taken something on american policymaking i would skip it.
Professor Cameron is an exceptional instructor. The course in engaging. Completing readings and closely following lectures ensures success.
Read read read!
Really easy class to PDF. Very surface level, so don't take it if you're looking for real depth.
Really interesting course, with a very manageable amount of work
TAKE THIS CLASS TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT.  INTERESTED IN POLITICS? ENGAGING PROFESSOR? TAKE IT!
Take it!
Take it.
Take it. It's real-world stuff, rather than the theory-based material that every other Princeton politics class relies on. It's super interesting.
Take this class.  Professor Cameron is very nice and a good teacher.
Take this course even if you are not a Politics major.  This course is a must for any American citizen.

This was a very interesting and very easy politics class. The readings are unnecessary, and you only have to do a take home midterm and take home final. Neither of which were particularly difficult. This was the first year this course was offered and I expect it to get better in the future.

This was not my favorite politics class, but the material is relevant and useful. Lectures/readings are fine, and precept material was usually interesting. It's a little dry at times, but not particularly difficult. Be aware that timely feedback/grading is NOT Cameron's strong suit.
prereqs: None.
descrip: This course provides a realistic introduction to how public policy is made in the United States today. It examines how people (voters, activists, wealthy individuals, lobbyists, politicians, bureaucrats, and judges), organizations (interest groups, firms, unions, foundations, think tanks, political parties, and the media) and political institutions (Congress, the presidency, the bureaucracy, and the judiciary) come together to create and implement public policy. The course combines social science theory and systematic empirical evidence with case studies, and provides students with tools of proven usefulness for practical political analysis.

title: Race, Religion, and the Harlem Renaissance
descrip: The Harlem Renaissance is most often depicted as "the flowering of African American arts and literature." It can also be characterized as a period when diverse forms of African American religious expressions, ideologies, and institutions emerged. This course explores the literature of the Harlem Renaissance as a means to understand the pivotal intersection of race and religion during this time of black cultural production.

title: Microeconomics Theory Workshop
reviews: If you are interested in theory you should take this course.
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: El Genero Negro: Crime Fiction
reviews: Don't just breeze through it, actually absorb stuff

I would read the syllabus and clarify expectations about the reflections and written work. Also, being at least conversationally fluent in Spanish would be very helpful if not required before taking a Spanish literature class.
Rachel was a great professor. She really does care about her students and is super helpful.
Really interesting material, and Rachel is a great professor!
prereqs: SPA 207 or higher; or instructor's permission.
descrip: This course is an introduction to crime fiction from early 20th-century "locked room" mysteries to 21st century narco-narratives. It examines short stories, novels, films and critical writings about detective and crime fiction in Latin America and Spain. Topics include the genre's links to high and low literature, to film and to historical contexts such as immigration, state crime, drug culture and globalization. Authors include Roberto Arlt, Maria Elvira Bermudez, Adolfo Bioy Casares, Roberto Bolano, Jorge Luis Borges, Alicia Gimenez Bartlett, Leonardo Padura Fuentes, Ricardo Piglia, Fernando Vallejo, and others.

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Engineering - Kernel Methods for Machine Learning
descrip: Course foundation is built on linear algebra, statistical learning theory, pattern recognition and artificial intelligence. It provides a diversified learning experience for graduate students in computer science, electrical engineering, financial engineering and applied statistics. Students with prior exposure to linear algebra, statistical theory and convex optimization learn an integrated understanding of the underlying principles and potential applications of kernel-based unsupervised and supervised learning models. This course demonstrates how machine learning models can be integrated into a recognition application system.

title: Inverse Methods: Theory and Applications
reviews: A valuable and well-taught course.
It is a fantastic class if you want to learn inversion modeling.
prereqs: Multivariable calculus, linear algebra..
descrip: Course treats inverse problems from both theoretical and applied perspectives. Students learn to develop the necessary theory to pose, interpret, and solve inverse problems, focusing on topics including error characterization, linear and non-linear methods, approximations, Kalman filters, use of prior constraints, and observing system design. Concepts are illustrated with examples from the current literature on the Earth's carbon cycle.

title: Junior Seminar in Critical Writing
reviews: Choose a seminar that applies to your interests (for me, children's literature/young adult demographic of modern hollywood franchises) in a way that will deepen your understanding of that interest.
Consider reading everything Melville has written in advance over the summer, then cruising through the semester with ease--this seems like the smart thing to have done.
Do it. Also, study abroad in London. It's such a fantastic opportunity that so few students take advantage of.
Do the busywork, and read assignments carefully.
Do the reading and you'll be fine!
Do the readings, stay on top of the research exercises as they help you prepare for the fall JP.
Find a junior seminar covering subject matter that you find interesting.  I found Baldwin quite interesting, so the course was great.
First, study abroad. Second, if you invest yourself in this material both inside and outside of the classroom you will truly appreciate your semester in London.
Good course.
Great course, I think that studying James Baldwin is so incredibly important so one should consider taking this course!
High standards, but absolutely worth it. An English major's dream.

I don't recommend taking a class with Professor Nishikawa. He's just bland and simplistic and not understanding of other people's opinions and there are much better ways to spend your time at Princeton.

I was placed into this seminar, but I am so ridiculously glad for the happy accident of my placement. This course ended up being the one with which I was hands-down most engaged this semester. Professor Kotin is a superb instructor. He made me feel both comfortable and inspired in the seminar room from day one. His transparency about the difficulties of his teaching/our taking the course (the oxymoron of teaching one how to do independent work, how to multitask the exploration of a text and research methods, etc.) was an extremely smart way to handle it; rather than feel infantilized or overwhelmed I felt my classmates and I stepped up to face these challenges alongside him and see how much we could collectively glean from the process. In particular, Professor Kotin's treatment of deadlines was a very positive learning experience for us because we found that moving them was often less productive for our overall process and that ultimately we were very, very grateful for all the papers we'd written leading up to our final work on the JP during December. I think these are lessons I will sincerely internalize as I move forward in writing my spring JP and eventually my thesis.
I would definitely recommend this junior seminar. It is a lot of work but very worthwhile.

It's a good reading list if you really want to get to know Melville well. Since Prof. Kotin is really laid-back and doesn't like to control the conversation, this could be the most annoying three hours of your week depending on the people in your class.
Make sure to do all the readings carefully, as this course gives you the opportunity to delve deeply into them and teaches you how to form and defend arguments about the texts.
Melville is fascinating, and Professor Kotin does a really nice job bringing the text to life.
Professor Nishikawa is a fantastic discussion leader and a top-rate JP advisor. Five out of five stars.
Sarah Anderson is incredible
Stay on top of your reading, work hard, and enjoy!
Susan Wolfson is awesome.
Take it at least to take on some really great texts/ideas
Take it if you're really into Baldwin/African American studies. If you don't enjoy talking about race matters for three hours straight, then stay away.
Take it!! And go to London!
Take it.
Take this course if Professor Kotin is teaching it. It has been one of my most fulfilling courses  at Princeton so far.

Take this course with Professor Anderson, even if you do not think you will be interested in the readings on the syllabus. Prof. Anderson is extremely flexible when it comes to selecting JP topics and could not be more supportive during what can be a daunting process. You will never regret having her for your first JP advisor. She also leads really engaging discussions during seminar time!

The junior seminar for the Princeton in London program varies per professor. Professor DiBattista taught the course very well, provided an excellent reading list, and stimulated my interest in Modernist London.
descrip: Students learn to write clear and persuasive criticism in a workshop setting while becoming familiar with a variety of critical practices and research methods. The course culminates in the writing of a junior paper. Each section will pursue its own topic: students are assigned according to choices made during sophomore sign-ins. Required of all English majors.

title: Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics
reviews: Definitely take it if you like the subject area! Just keep in mind that it is a graduate course, with 50% of the grade coming from PSets and 50% from the Final exam.
I like this course, hope you could choose it.

If they have already taken a basic solid state course they could get something out of this course and fulfill a requirement. If they haven't ever taken such a course before, they may get lost. If they have a solid understanding of the material, they may not learn much (it's introductory, which is not a bad thing).
If you are interested in CMT, you should take it.
If you are interested in condensed matter physics, I recommend this course.
It is a class those who major in CMP should take.
It is a reasonable amount of work but it is generally interesting and a worthwhile use of time.
The workload is reasonable, and engaging with the subject via the problems is crucial for gaining anything from the sometimes opaque text or lectures.
descrip: Electronic structure of crystals, phonons, transport and magnetic properties, screening in metals, and superconductivity.

title: Fundamentals of the Geosciences I
descrip: A year-long survey, in sequence, of fundamental papers in the geosciences. Topics in 505 (Fall) include the origin and interior of the Earth, plate tectonics, geodynamics, the history of life on Earth, the composition of the Earth, its oceans and atmospheres, past climate.
