Topics in 506 (Spring) include present and future climate, biogeochemical processes in the ocean, geochemical cycles, orogenies, thermochronology, rock fracture and seismicity. A core course for all beginning graduate students in the geosciences.

title: Sophomore Independent Work
prereqs: For each project, the requirements are set in consultation with the faculty advisor, and depend somewhat on the nature of the project. An oral presentation during Reading Period (as per departmental schedule) and a written final report is required. A copy of the report must be turned into the ELE Undergraduate Office by Dean's Date. Details of requirements are available from the ELE Undergraduate Office. This course is open to qualified sophomores provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a state-of-the-art project in electrical engineering. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the students. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor. There is no formal reading list; however, a literature search is a normal part of most projects.

title: Experiencing India through Bollywood
reviews: Be engaged, participate fully and really try to come in with an open mind.
Fauzia is a boss <3
Fauzia is great teacher and really nice to her students!
Great class! Definitely take it if you are interested at all in learning about the history of India and Indian culture today. Fauzia is wonderful and taking the class with her makes it especially fun
Take it!

Take it! You get to watch some classic Indian movies, critically discuss them and think about the kind of India they present. You will never be able to watch another Bollywood film again without thinking of all the social issues and presumptions the film is silently making about India. Professor Fauzia is really sweet and will help you find more movies for your final research paper (if you don't have much background with India or Bollywood)
Take it. Now. This is a chill and fun class where you actually learn things about India.
Take this course.

This course was amazing. If you have interest in India/Bollywood, taking it is a no-brainer. If not, it's still totally worth taking. You will learn so much about India through a fun medium, and you'll learn how to view Bollywood movies through a critical lens.
descrip: India produces more films than any other country in the world, and nothing captures the minds and imagination of the Indian public the way Bollywood does. Bollywood films have not only showcased various social, political, and cultural aspects of Indian life, they have also arguably presented a critical response to them. This course will provide students with a window into Indian society and culture as depicted in some of the most popular and influential Bollywood films. Films will be chosen to represent major cultural themes and trends since Independence.

title: Practice Teaching
prereqs: Admission to the Teacher Preparation Program is usually required. Application for fieldwork placement must be made in advance. Completion of Pre-professional portfolio..
descrip: Supervised practice teaching (a minimum of 12 weeks) in a secondary school. Teaching is done under the supervision of an accomplished teacher and a program staff member who regularly observe and discuss the student's practice teaching. Students gain firsthand experience in developing teaching strategies, planning and implementing instruction, assessing student learning, and classroom management. Must be taken concurrently with TPP 401.

title: Master's Project I
descrip: Under the direction of a Bendheim affiliated faculty member, students carry out a master's project, write a report, and present the results in the form of a poster or an oral presentation in front of an examining committee.

title: Intensive Korean I
prereqs: KOR 103 and KOR 108 are designed as a year-long sequence. The credit for KOR 103 will not be given unless it is followed by KOR 108. Students who have completed both courses will be considered to have fulfilled the language requirement equivalent to completing 2-year study of a foreign language..
descrip: The first part of Intensive Korean is designed for heritage students who have already had considerable amount of exposure to the Korean language and culture but have not received any formal instruction before their arriving at Princeton. It covers the 1st Year Korean material focusing on vocabulary building, grammar, reading and writing. The students who have successfully completed KOR 103 and KOR 108 will be placed in the 3rd or 4th year Korean if they wish to continue.

title: Proseminar in Basic Problems in Psychology: Cognitive Psychology
descrip: Cognitive Proseminar: Introduction to graduate level cognitive psychology and cognitive neuroscience for first year graduate students in psychology. Course serves as the basis for more advanced graduate courses on specific topics in this area.

title: Migration and the Literary Imagination
reviews: Do it. It's enjoyable and gave me a greater understanding of a very important event in American history.
descrip: This course will explore the various meanings of The Great Migration and mobility found in 20th century African American literature. Through careful historical and literary analysis, we will examine the significant impact migration has had on African American writers and the ways it has framed their literary representations of modern black life.

title: Autobiography and Identity
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Mythmakers, The
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: American Revolutions
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Introduction to Moral Philosophy
reviews: A difficult course, poorly planned. Lectures are fine - Smith is engaging and Kohler is succinct and organized; however, this is not the kind of class which will get you excited about philosophy.
A great course for anyone interested in philosophy

DON'T TAKE THIS COURSE if you find it less than interesting in the first two weeks. It really doesn't get any better. This course has high reviews but it is certainly NOT an interesting easy course. The precept system is useless and the readings are boring. The subject itself is very interesting but it is presented poorly. The professors are nice but the course is run poorly.

Definitely take the course if you are remotely interested in philosophy. It is a very good starting point and it is not too difficult. Go to the lectures, especially Smith's part, and talk to your preceptor before writing and before turning in your papers. Do the readings, but read smart, as in skim through, do not rigorously read every sentence, because you will never be able to make it.

Definitely take this course if you want a factual understanding of historical philosophy, but there isn't that much discussion-based analysis or personal development. The last lecture makes the whole course worth it.

Do not skip lectures. The material is very well presented, and if you simply want to pass the class, taking decent lecture and precept notes, and reading the material for the specific essay closely, are easily enough to receive a good grade. On the other hand, if you want to get the most out of the class, it is absolutely essential to do at least all of the core readings for each topic.
Do not take this course unless you are extremely interested in meta-ethics.
Do the reading every week. Stay on top of your work. Meet with preceptor long before paper is due and revise.
Do the readings and go to class.  Start your paper in advance.  Look up philosophy papers online to get a better idea of what will be expected of you.
Do the readings or you will have a bad time

Do the readings with a study group, go to precept and ask questions. Consult your preceptor with questions about the papers - get feedback on an outline etc. Solid intro to moral though - def take it if you're at all interested in morality and applications of it.

Don't do the readings. Attend 50 - 80% of lectures. Do the readings relevant to the paper topics after they are assigned. You will be able to get an easy A without a large time commitment. Don't expect anything revolutionary or for lectures to be terribly interesting.
Don't read anything except for when you write the papers.
Don't take this course unless you have to.
Easy course. Just do readings for paper and can survive precept without reading.

Go to lecture if you can - not because it is absolutely necessary but because it is taught by some very interesting people. I really enjoyed lecture and the material. I also really liked how the material was taught outside of/without regard of religion. I wanted to learn about morality itself not what certain religions say that it is. The course did an excellent job with this. Take this if you want to get an EM out of the way and want to learn something interesting in the process.
Go to precepts. Most will be learned there.
Good grounding in basic philosophy.
Good introduction class, fairly easy but not extremely engaging if you are interested in philosophy. Participation in precepts is really what makes this class interesting.
I might go for a smaller philosophy class, not a big lecture one. It makes it more engaging and interesting.

I think the material itself was better than the course.  It did change how I think about morality, but the change had more to do with a handful of specific readings and conversations in precept than the quality of the course on the whole.  To that end, I almost never went to lecture.
I took this as an EM. The 3 papers were pretty fun to write and made me think hard about my incoherent moral framework. They're also doable without going to lecture or precept. Would recommend.

I was trying to think of the best way to describe this course and I think this is it: it feels like something out of high school. What I mean is that the lectures just go over the reading, and really nothing else. The paper prompts are what you would except to see on an high school exam. It seemed that more people were PDFing this class than were taking it for a grade. So if you are looking for a serious philosophy course, keep on looking. If you are looking for an easy EC, I still say keep on looking, because in a class as large as this, it is hard to get an A. If you are looking for a class which you can PDF with during very little work than you have found it, but that being the case, I would say don't take it for that reason either.
I would advise students to talk to preceptors about their papers in advance.

I would definitely recommend this course! Unfortunately, Professor Smith will not be teaching this course next year, although I think the ideas we covered were a great overview for someone looking to take a philosophy course. I would say that a student should take full advantage of the readings and keep up with course - it is really worthwhile to follow the ideas throughout the semester instead of just catching up at the end.
I would recommend taking another course to fulfill the requirement.
I would recommend this course.  It's good to pdf, or if you're just interested in ethics or philosophy.  It's not terribly hard pdfing or not.
I would recommend trying a different philosophy course if it is philosophy that you want to try.
I would take this course. It's a fairly easy course that has interesting material and, as long as you stay on top of the readings, makes sense and provides thought-provoking discussions.
I'd definitely recommend this class to anyone who was looking for an EM. Great class.
If you enjoy philosophy, it's a good class

If you have to take this course, do it, you'll do fine as long as you do the readings, come to lecture and write your papers after talking to the professors or your preceptor. If you don't have to take this course, don't. There are many other better philosophy courses here.
If you like philosophy or have never taken a philosophy course but think you might like it, I don't think you can go too far wrong taking this course.

If you need a course to fulfill the EM requirement, look elsewhere. This course is completely boring and I've heard even from Philosophy majors that this is a horrible course to start with if you're even minutely interested in Philosophy. The lectures are useless and the readings are useless. If you take this class, what you need to do is either drop it, or PDF it, and then read all of the lecture notes online. If they use powerpoint presentations, go to lecture, but if not, then good luck because listening to someone delineate these concepts is as hard as reading about the concepts themselves. As for grading, the grading is fair I would say. Yet, very little is actually taught in regards to writing the essays, so once again, you're on your own.

If you think you can successfully write a basic philosophy paper (summarizing a reading and providing a basic counterargument) this course will be a breeze for you. Provided that lecture notes/slides continue to be posted on Blackboard, there is no need at all to go to lecture, and precept will probably be annoying because there's always that one opinionated kid who just wants to debate abortion, but this class is overall an incredibly easy A for the distribution requirement. However, having taken it, I'm now looking at courses and seeing EMs that look waaay more interesting. Look around before settling on this one! It'll contribute to a less-than-fascinating semester.
If you're experienced with philosophy beyond the idea of it take this course.
If you're interested in morals and ethics, this is a pretty good course. Tough to pay attention to for the whole thing though.
It's a great survey course, but it is, after all, just a survey course - don't expect to go too deep into any of the material.
It's a pretty good EM, but by no means a walk in the park.

It's hard to recommend this course to future students, because Smith really made this course. I took this class because Smith gave a talk at my eating club's roundtable. The question of where our morals come from fascinated me, and so I decided to take this over Ethics & Public Policy. SMITH WAS A FANTASTIC LECTURER. Every lecture was incredibly stimulating, lecture handouts were amazing, and I learned so much more than I ever could have gotten out of from reading on my own. Profs like Smith are why I'm going to miss Princeton so much. Get Smith for your preceptor, too, whichever course he teaches. He's excellent at leading discussion, provoking thought, challenging assumptions, and making you a better thinker. Kohler was ok. In fact, I think he probably would have seemed much better if he wasn't constantly being compared to Smith. Lectures were slightly dry, and mostly just summaries of the readings. Since applied ethics is not a very complex field, this made lecture somewhat useless if you had done the readings (unlike metaethics, where you could do the readings and still not understand them).
LOVED this class.  It's the reason why I'm a philosophy major.
Make sure you're not in Professor Kohler's precept.
Michael Smith is amazing. Sebastian is not.
N/A
None
Only take this course if Michael Smith teaches the whole thing; he is a great lecturer and very engaging.
Only take this course if you need it is required by a certificate/major you're pursuing!
Please take it, especially if Michael Smith is teaching! You'll learn a lot from this class that you can apply in your daily life, too!
Read. You should do the readings, or at least skim them.

Readings can be very long and I wouldn't say they were all necessary if you attend lecture. If anything, skim for the main idea, attend lectures, and everything should work out fine. Be an active participant in class because otherwise, precepts can be a nightmare.

Really engage in precepts because that is where you will be able to better deconstruct arguments presented. Consult with preceptors ahead of time about philosophy paper format and writing if you haven't written a philosophy paper before as they have helpful insight.

Recommend, unless you're super against pondering the meaning of life/things of that sort because then you'll feel like going to lecture is a waste of time. But if you're open-minded enough, it's a really interesting course.
Show up to all the lectures.
Start your essays early.

TAKE!! As soon as you can!!! I took this as a senior and I only WISH I took it sooner because I probably would have become a philosophy major. I absolutely loved how the course molds you to be a better thinker and formulate your arguments more succinctly. Smith's lectures are amazing - he has a conversation with the class, doesn't just talk at us. He pauses for questions, gives us time to think, and doesn't go by powerpoint slides. He also gives us a handout which is super useful - that way you can just listen to what he's saying instead of worrying about writing every word down. The co-prof, Kohler, reads off the slides which made them a little boring but useful if you can't make it to class. I had precept with Ali and it was just one big debate every week and I LOVED IT.

Take Intro to Moral if you want a class that is easy to PDF, have good writing skills and want an easy A, or actually like Philosophy. As for me, I have lost respect for the discipline after taking this course. Lectures and readings were torture. Some people say that the writing assignments were grade harshly, but if you're a good writer they're not tough at all.
Take it -- it's not difficult and it's worth learning.
Take it if Smith is teaching. He is a much better lecturer than Kohler, who was awkward and unengaging
Take it if you like to argue and are a good logical thinker.  It's really not too hard either.
Take it if you want a not time consuming class.
Take it!
Take it! It's a lot of fun and an interesting way to fulfill an EM requirement.
Take the course if Smith is still teaching it. It's interesting and well-taught
Take the course. You'll learn a ton about humanity and yourself.

Take this course at some point while at Princeton. It helps you to look at the world from a different perspective. What is right or wrong for you to do? What should you do? Why should you do one thing over another? It helps you to look at different parts of your life and see if maybe you should adjust your actions or pursuits to pursue better goals.

Take this course if you like the subject and be prepared to analyze certain directions in philosophy in three essays (at least this was the structure our year) using classic texts.
The midterm is in December, which is a plus! There was a final paper instead of a final exam.
Take this course; you will learn a lot and enjoy it.

Taking this course is important for everyone, not just students in the humanities. If you go in with an open mind it can really change your perspective on the way we think about morality in general and how it applies to day-to-day life.

Talk to your preceptor about your papers before they are due. It really helps improve your paper especially because the first paper is the hardest due to not knowing the quality expected. Also the test at the end is a joke that you could just review the handouts to be prepared for.
The course is a strong survey of normative ethics. I suggest taking before 307.

The course is challenging at times, but extremely interesting. The papers, if done with care and effort, will help develop writing skills that are extremely useful across all departments. Easy B, definitely worth taking.
There are other better philosophy courses.
This class is very introductory, so its information is pretty good, but somewhat surface-level compared to other philosophy classes.

This course is a good EM. It is not too difficult and it is very interesting. Professor Smith is a great professor (and Professor Kohler is kind of boring but very clear which is great for philosophy). Ali Fatollahi is also a great preceptor. If you want to really learn something, you should have an interest in morals and ethics. The class spans from if morals even exist to practical ethics )like abortion, euthanasia and more) so it's a lot of interesting material. However, you can do well without that but it wouldn't be a fun class for you.
This is a good class to take if you are trying to fulfill a distributional requirement or just want to see what a philosophy class is like.

This is a great course for anyone slightly interested in moral philosophy who wants a fun, manageable course. There are not many assignments, and the reading load is light (but don't try to read philosophy when you're exhausted, because it won't make any sense!). Smith's been teaching the course for a long time, and Sebastian was also a great lecturer. The course really got me thinking about the way I think and live, so I think it's very valuable if you have the room to take it!
Try to read and keep up with the material if you can.
Unless you are very interested in philosophy I would not recommend.  Boring material and some terrible preceptors involved.
Use the lecture notes as an outline when doing the readings to clarify concepts.
Very easy EM. You barely have to do any readings to answer the essay prompts.
Would recommend against taking course for STEM-inclined students looking to fulfill a distribution requirement.

Writing a philosophy paper is different from writing a paper for any other class; make sure you figure this out early on.  Seek help from your preceptor when you can!  Some topics are difficult to wrap your head around.
You can learn how to write a philosophy paper!

You have to take this class ? the material can be dry at times, but by the end of the semester, I found myself with a significantly greater appreciation for philosophical thinking and the complexity of morality and doing what is "right".
You might get bored.
good foundation course for people interested in philosophy
it's pretty easy, and moderately interesting. take it if you need an EM, don't take ti because you think it'll be a super great interesting experience.
prereqs: Course open to freshmen..
descrip: Can questions about what is right or wrong have real answers independent of any sort of divine authority? Are there moral principles that any rational person must recognize, or is morality essentially an expression of our feelings or a product of our culture? Are we morally required to do our part in making the world as good as it can be, or does morality give us permission to pursue our own peculiar enthusiasms and interests? What should we do about deception, unwanted pregnancies, and world hunger? This course will provide an overview of these and other issues in moral philosophy.

title: Tonal Syntax
prereqs: MUS 205 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: An in-depth study of tonal counterpoint.

title: Combustion Theory
descrip: Theoretical aspects of combustion: the conservation equations of chemically-reacting flows; activation energy asymptotics; chemical and dynamic structures of laminar premixed and nonpremixed flames; aerodynamics and stabilization of flames; pattern formation and geometry of flame surfaces; ignition, extinction, and flammability phenomena; turbulent combustion; boundary layer combustion; droplet, particle, and spray combustion; and detonation and flame stabilization in supersonic flows.

title: Portfolio Theory and Asset Management
prereqs: FIN 501 and FIN 522..
descrip: Covers a number of advanced topics related to asset management and asset pricing. Topics include mean-variance analysis, CAPM, APT, market efficiency, delegated money management, stock return predictability, bubbles and crashes, social interaction and investor behavior, security analysts and investor relations, and mutual fund performance and organization.

title: Tragic Drama - Aeschylus' Agamemnon
prereqs: CLG 105 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A close reading of one Greek tragedy, with supplementary readings (in English and Greek) illustrating the genre and its context.

title: Behavioral Finance
reviews: Definitely take. Harrison Hong is one of the best professors at Princeton
Harrison's lectures are great. Definitely take it with him. Learned a ton about how finance actually works in the real world, not just in theory. Also read a lot of interesting papers.

If you're good at math, take it. If you're not good at math, but interested in learning more about finance in a way that is interesting and probably unlike your other class experiences here, you should take it as well. I would recommend using a PDF on it in that case and not sign up for a tough semester.
Interesting course, great prof
Take it to learn some cool models
Take it! It's tough if you take it with Hong, but that's when you really get the most out of it.
Take it.

Take this course if you are interested in the subject material. The lectures are great and the way Professor Hong teaches is really applicable. The homework assignments can be algebraically complex, but are not conceptually hard.
You MUST take this class. Hong will be the best lecturer you ever have and the material is incredibly interesting.
prereqs: ECO 300 or ECO 310 required. ECO 310 and ECO 362 recommended..
descrip: Traditional finance typically considers that financial markets are efficient because investors are rational and maximize their expected utility from consumption. This course departs from this view and discusses how inefficiencies arise due to psychology and limits to arbitrage. The psychology of investors shapes their preferences and may impair their judgment. Whether these psychological factors have an impact on financial markets ultimately depends on arbitrageurs' ability to fight against mispricings. These issues will be covered through lectures and class games and will allow discussions about cognitive illusions and speculative bubbles.

title: Second Language Acquisition and Pedagogy
descrip: Readings and discussion in classroom application of SLA theory. Focus on quantitative as well as interpretive analysis. Primary audience is the current teaching staff of GER 101, but others are welcome. In English.

title: Topics in the History and Theory of Architecture
reviews: Architecture seniors have to take it. That's okay though, because it's a good course.
Do all the work. Put in a lot of effort.
Engage in discussions! There are so many things you can bring to the table with your unique background.
Lucia makes this course a delight!
You have to take this or you can't take it.
descrip: We will consider that a successful thesis entails the meeting of a socio-cultural problematic with a specific disciplinary issue, that the confluence and exchange between these external and internal situations can instigate an original contribution to architectural knowledge and technique. The "newness" of this contribution comes through a particular kind of repetition, a wily swerve within the established canon. The seminar will introduce disciplinary methods and themes through close readings of architectural texts and objects and will provide a workshop for the testing and elaboration of architectural polemics through directed research.

title: Topics in the Renaissance - Utopia: Fiction and Critique
descrip: Thomas More's Utopia (1516) is one of the central texts of English and European humanism. This course introduces More's complex meditation on the ideal republic, and on the relation of philosophy to politics, through a close analysis of his text and through a survey of later Utopias from the seventeenth through nineteenth centuries. Authors include More, Shakespeare, Bacon, Cavendish, Bellamy, and Morris.

title: Introduction to Movement and Dance
reviews: Be open minded and prepared to take on new challenges.
Be prepared to do a lot of work--you learn a lot but just because this is a PDF only class it does not mean it is a joke!

Definitely take it - great exposure to dance. Be prepared though for some chill class sessions though - won't teach you EVERYTHING about how to move, but if you want to get out of your comfort zone, this is it!
Definitely take it - it could also be fun to take with friends.

I think this is the sort of class that some people would absolutely love, but I had mixed feelings about it.  Compared to DAN 207 (the ballet class), this was much less instructive (by design, it is more introspective).  Most assignments (lots of informal journal entries, a couple short papers, and an end-of-term choreography) and "movement" sessions in class were pretty open ended, which can make things really easy to get through if you don't mind being insincere or really time consuming/taxing if you give the expected amount of consideration (I honestly think most people select the former).  Aynsley is very nice and very enthusiastic.
I would certainly recommend the course but warn them about the length of some assignments. However I often enthusiastically endorse this course!
I would highly recommend this course to anyone.

I would say that this course is meant for people just getting into dance who have not already had any training. However, I think it is a great class even for people with previous dance training, as it expands students' creativity with regards to movement.

Jump in! It's probably the only class in Princeton where you can sleep, yell, jump, cry, or slap the floor in class and not get in trouble. Allow yourself to take full advantage of this opportunity, even if it feels awkward at first.
Take it but know that there is work outside of class that can be annoying and time-consuming
Take it!
Take it! It's really a wonderful class (by far my favorite class this semester).
Take it. Lot of fun, and a great source of stress relief during the week.
Take the course. Best PDF only class/

This course is different than any other course you will likely take at Princeton. For that reason, I would highly suggest you take it. It will open you up to a different way of looking at your body and movement. Plus, by giving you a break from the fast-paced nature of life at Princeton, it will aid in your other areas of study.
This is the best course at Princeton.
Use it as a way to be less stressed, but still do the readings and stuff.
Very good for fulfilling the LA requirement.  Will definitely go away feeling more confident about movement.
descrip: Designed for people with little or no previous training in dance, the class will be a mixture of movement techniques, improvisation, choreography, observing, writing and discussing. Students will investigate their own movement patterns and delve into many facets of dance and cultural questions surrounding it. We will explore the role of dancer, choreographer, audience member, and critic in relation to such topics as aesthetic questions, politics, identity, religion, and complex views of the human body.

title: Social Organization of Cities
descrip: A review of the historical emergence and social evolution of cities and urban life. Course presents current theories regarding the ecological and social structure of urban areas, and how urban social organization affects the behavior and well-being of human beings who live and work in cities.

title: International Trade
prereqs: WWS 300 or ECO 300, or ECO 310.
descrip: This course concerns the microeconomics of international trade and trade policy. The first part explores the determinants and effects of trade in progressively more general models of trade. The second part studies various instruments of trade policy and the arguments for and against free trade. Topics covered include: Does growth in developing countries benefit or hurt developed countries?; the distributional consequences of trade liberalization; the impact of trade liberalization on productivity and welfare; labor migration; multinationals and outsourcing; regional economic integration; and trade policy in developing countries.

title: Global History (1850s - Present)
reviews: Budget time wisely regarding the reading; 800-1000  pages a week cannot be done in just one or two nights! And take copious notes on the reading so that discussion is easier.
Heavy reading load--learn to skim effectively and develop a system for note-taking while reading that allows you to get the major themes without slowing you down.
If you are prepared to read more than you have ever read before, then I cannot recommend this class enough.
Nothing particular.
Very demanding reading load, but the payoff is very high

You will learn a lot from Professor Kotkin in this course. Professor Kotkin's thoughts and insights are very interesting and useful. They are the best part of the course. Keep in mind that there is no discussion per se. The reading load will be impossible to keep up with, but read what you can and you will still get something out of it. The course uses a political/diplomatic history approach. If you are interested in other approaches you will not find them here, but you will learn a lot about Professor Kotkin's views on different methods.
descrip: This seminar offers a history of global interactions roughly since the 1850s, combining an analytical framework with an overarching narrative. It singles out geopolitics, political economy, empire, networks and exchange, warfare and welfare, and oil. Key themes include the Anglo-German antagonism, the U.S.-Japan clash, the rise and fall of global communism, the German story and the European Union, the fall and rise of China, and America's global predominance and partnerships.

title: Psychology of Gender
reviews: Definitely take it if you want to fulfill the AB requirement and are interested in gender studies! It is super fun!
Definitely take this course, especially if you are interested in the psychology and gender studies.
Definitely take this course.
Don't bother taking to PDF it's not worth it. Prof is brilliant but Asieh as a preceptor was never engaged.

Easy course if you go to class. 
Study guides help very much with the tests. Take if you are a psych major!!!!!

Go to lecture!! Prof Brynildsen posts lecture slides but you really do need to take notes on what she's actually saying in class. Overall this is a great course and she's an amazing professor, take the class!!
Go to lectures and ask the professor questions if you have any.

I would definitely recommend this class to other students- the material is extremely interesting, and the presentation assignment is fun to do. I would just recommend that those students attend all classes to make sure they don't miss any of the details about the studies, and study the details of each study before the exams.
I would recommend this course.
I would take this course if you are interested in gender inequality, psychology, or if you find sex differences to be interesting.
If you're interested in the topic, definitely take the course.
Interesting but tedious.
It's a great course to take, even if you're only mildly interested in psychology.

It's not a difficult class, but if you are not passionate about gender psychology, do not take it. I don't think I learned anything new and a lot of stereotypes about gender were confirmed, which I was disappointed about.
Lectures need to be attended. Exams are from the lectures so go to them. Prof. B. is so nice and she speaks with great clarity, so she will explain concepts simply put.
Not too difficult if you go to lecture. Learned some things but much of the information is knowledge that can be guessed with some basic context.
Professor is great, but do not take if it's with the same preceptor.
Really interesting and applicable subject matter - think all students should take this course
Really interesting material.
Take it
Take it. Why not really
Take this class! It is a delight. You learn a lot in a low stress environment.
Take this class! Keiko is a great lecturer, it's not much work, and above all it's interesting.

The readings overlap with lecture to the point of irrelevancy but the subject is an interesting one. Take it if you wan to learn about gender psych but not if you are looking for a stimulating psych course.
This is a good course for introductory information on gender psychology and gender studies - it provides a good, general background and knowledge set.
This is the easiest EC you can take, but it's also super interesting! TAKE IT!
Would recommend for anyone in any concentration--a great, relevant course.
Yes def if you want an easy EC.
easy and interesting, why not take it?
interesting subject matter. got me thinking more about gender as a societal role versus an inherent characteristic. But the class is, overall, understimulating
please take it!! most interesting psych class I've taken as a psych major.
solid psych course.
take it!
descrip: Gender is a topic with which everybody feels intimately familiar. Indeed, people hold strong beliefs about how women and men are similar to and different from each other and about why gender differences exist. This course holds those beliefs up to scientific scrutiny, examining major theories and empirical findings in psychological research on gender. Topics include empirical comparisons of men and women, gender stereotypes and their perpetuation, and the role of gender and gendered beliefs in interpersonal relationships and physical and psychological well-being.

title: Remembering the Future
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Creative Writing (Literary Translation)
prereqs: This class is available for 300-level credit, by application only for any student who has previously taken two 200-level workshops in the Creative Writing Program. Students must have a fluency in a language in addition to English. Applications must include 3-4 pages of either original literary translation or original work from their previous workshops. See the Creative Writing website for application information. Please note this course cannot be audited and is not open to Freshmen. Application deadline is April 11, 2014..
descrip: Advanced practice in the translation of literary works from another language into English supplemented by the reading and analysis of standard works. Criticism by professionals and talented peers encourages the student's growth as both creator and reader of literature. Students MUST be fluent in their chosen language.

title: Electronic Literature: Lineage, Theory, and Contemporary Practice
reviews: I'm a big fan of this class. If you're interested in not an overwhelming amount of week-to-week work but a chance to do an exciting and creative independent project at the midterm and final, this is a great class for you. Emphasis is definitely more on creativity and freedom of thought than struggling for a good grade. Take it!
This class will make you want to change your major, and then become extremely sad when you realize that there is no electronic literature major.
prereqs: Desired but not required: Experience with creative writing, as well as one authoring platform, such as any social media platform; WordPress; HTML; CSS; Processing; Twine, JavaScript, or any programming language. Some knowledge of literary criticism is also helpful but not required..
descrip: Electronic Literature: Lineage, Theory, and Contemporary Practice will explore electronic literature, including print antecedents, generative literature, interactive fiction, hypertext literature, social media-based literature, electronic manuscripts and digital visual poetry. Lectures, dialog, discussion, and student presentations on theoretical, critical, and historical aspects of electronic and avant-garde literature will alternate and intertwine with lectures, dialog, and student traversals/projects that investigate the creative practice of writing electronic literature.

title: Roman Lyric and Elegiac Poetry - Propertius & Tibullus
descrip: All the works of Propertius and Tibullus will be read closely. We will also survey scholarly approaches to this poetry.

title: Black & White Photography
reviews: Be prepared to commit a lot of time to the course.
I would advise you to take this course if you have a serious love for photography and are willing to put a lot of time into your work.
I would definitely take this if you have any interest in film photography and are willing to dedicate the time to take pictures and spend extra time in the lab.

If you want to learn a new skill and have time to do it, then take this class. People say that it takes more time than it actually does- but really the time commitment is manageable and its more fun to spend time printing pictures than to be doing problem sets. Professor Lawson is fair and very clear- try to listen to what she is looking for and incorporate it. If you like photography and art in general, this class is a great way to expand your basic skills and have fun while doing it.
It is a huge time commitment outside of class, but if you are truly interested in taking photography, then it is definitely worth it.
Only take if you have a load of time.
Take the course! But keep in mind that the course is not an 'easy A' and requires time. But it is a rewarding experience if you do.
This course has been one of my favorite courses at Princeton and has given me a new hobby and passion
take if you're interested in photography. don't expect this to be easy - it takes a lot of time
descrip: An introduction to the processes of photography through a series of problems directed toward the handling of light-sensitive material, camera, and printing. Weekly laboratory sessions will explore the critical issues of the medium in relation to both student work and the work of guest photographers. One three-hour class and approximately three hours of independent laboratory.

title: Medieval Greek Literature
descrip: The subject of this course will be medieval Greek Romantic fiction. We will read translations of the four surviving novels written in twelfth-century Constantinople in a bid to answer questions about the link between eroticism and the novel, truth and invention in the middle ages, who read fiction and why, and what role, if any, did the medieval or Byzantine Romances have in the story of the European novel. Above all, we will seek to recover some of the pleasure felt by the medieval readers and audiences of these novels.

title: Intermediate Studies in Acting: Scene Study II
reviews: Anyone wanting a theatre certificate should take this course!
Definitely take this course if you are interested in theatre and have taken THR 201. Mark is an amazing teacher to get to know and he will help you grow as an actor.
If you want to find out how to be a better person, and even if you don't have an interest in theatre, take this course. Mark Nelson is the best theatre professor at Princeton.
TAKE IT TAKE IT TAKE IT. Mark is phenomenal.
Take it! No question.

You will gain so much from Mark and the THR 301 process.  If you want to explore and hone your acting skills, open up onstage, gain confidence, learn about yourself, or just enjoy the acting process, you would be missing an incredible opportunity by looking over this class.  Logistically speaking, it is a very low stress class, excluding the moments right before you perform, and has little to know outside of class work.  Must take.
prereqs: THR 201 and Program Director's permission. Please contact Professor Tim Vasen (tvasen@princeton.edu) for enrollment permission..
descrip: A continuation of THR 201: Guide students in ways to develop a role and to explore important texts and characters in an imaginative and honest manner.

title: Intermediate Hindi I
prereqs: HIN/URD 101 and 102 (Elementary Hindi-Urdu I and II) or the instructor's permission..
descrip: This course continues training in reading, writing, speaking and listening. Students will learn to read and understand texts in Hindi on familiar topics, to speak confidently and effectively in a wide range of common situations, to write concise texts expressing their thoughts and views, and to acquire general familiarity with the cultural context in which Hindi is used. Students will engage in interactive and collaborative task-based activities in the classroom.

title: Ethnographic Tradition (Half-Term)
descrip: First in a sequence of four modules designed to train graduate students in ethnographic methods. This class introduces students to classical and contemporary works of ethnography that exemplify the contributions this method has made to sociological theory. Weekly readings are drawn from texts on topics such as the social ecology of the city, the study of the self, race and ethnicity, organizational ethnography, disasters, and social movements. Students who select to do original research papers over the course of the entire sequence begin their preparation in this class.

title: Economics and Politics
descrip: Focused on analytical models of political institutions, this course is organized around canonical models and their applications. These include: voting models, menu auctions, models of reputation and cheap talk games. These models are used to explain patterns of participation in elections, institutions of congress, lobbying, payments to special interest groups and other observed phenomena.

title: Topics in Ancient History - Slavery in the Roman World
reviews: Definitely take - work load is easy to manage, and the class itself is very interesting in terms of material. Professor Shaw couldn't be nicer and his lectures are enjoyable/relaxing to follow along.

Do the readings!!
Readings are a great help.
Excellent class. This class is basically like story time with your favorite grandpa. Professor Shaw is extremely kind and helpful. This class also has a very low workload.
I would take this course if you are interested in ancient history or the comparative history of slavery
Paying attention in lectures and picking an interesting topic for the research paper are the most important things. Everything is very doable if you put in enough effort.
Professor Shaw is awesome.  So is the class.  Take it.
Read the lecture notes after class to review. Keep up to speed with the concepts.
Take it! An excellent course.

This course is really interesting and Professor Shaw is an amazing lecturer. Although there aren't prerequisites, I would suggest having some background in ancient history (for example HIS218: The Roman Republic) as basic concepts covered in introductory courses aren't covered in depth in this course. Professor Shaw is great about answering questions, but the slavery material is better understood within a context of Roman history.
This is a great class. I would recommend having some basic ancient history knowledge.
You should definitely take this course.
descrip: This course considers the problem of slavery in the Roman world, from the early Republic to the end of the Empire. There will be some coverage of the background developments in the slave system under the earlier age of the Greek city-states. A wide range of subjects concerning slavery in Roman society will be considered including the causes of the creation of the Roman slave system, the ways in which it was maintained, its main social and economic functions, and the problem of resistance to servitude.

title: Topics in Policy Analysis (Half-Term) - Economics and Ethics: Social Justice and Policy
descrip: The course presents the economic concepts involved in the evaluation of the socio-economic effects of public policies. It shows how concrete measures and indicators are grounded on ethical principles. It is organized around central ethical debates: Is there an efficiency-equity trade-off? Are there legitimate inequalities? How much priority should be given to the worse-off? Are interpersonal comparisons of well-being impossible? Why not maximize happiness? Should we discount future generations?

title: Problems in Latin Literature - Boethius
descrip: The aim of this course is to make a careful study of Boethius' thought, giving particular attention to his Consolatio and the questions of historical context and Boethius' role in the assimilation of Greek and Roman literature and thought. Weekly meetings will be divided between lectures, presentations, and analysis of texts.

title: Special Topics in Information Sciences and Systems - Quantum Information Theory
descrip: This class builds quantum information theory "from the ground up" connecting it to classical information theory at each step of the way. No prior expertise is assumed, though familiarity with information theory is a plus.

title: Planning Theory and Process
descrip: Introduction to the theory and practice of planning. Analysis and discussion are devoted to planning models, planning decisions, and alternative planning roles. Focused study of comprehensive and strategic planning, community participation, new urbanism concepts, equity concerns, and planning at local, regional, and state levels.

title: Sexuality, Public Culture and Medicine in East Asia
reviews: Don't try to do all the readings in one night.

I would definitely recommend this seminar if you are the slightest bit interested in the development of sexuality in East Asia, or if you'd like to learn more about East Asian public culture. Professor Zhang can be stoic sometimes, but he's actually extremely funny and entertaining when the students put in the effort to drive the discussion.

It's a very interesting course if you're at all interested in gender studies, sexuality, and East Asia. It was mostly focused on China, which I didn't mind. You learn a lot not just about sexuality issues but also China in general.
Take it!
Take this course if you are interested in sexuality and its discourse in East Asia (especially China).
The course is really interesting, and might seem a bit slow or odd at the beginning, but is in fact very engaging as the semester gets going.
descrip: This course addresses "sexuality" in relation to public culture and medical practices in contemporary East Asia (China, Japan and Korea). While discussing important theories, this course emphasizes social, cultural and historical contexts of sexual practices, such as China's post-Mao sexual revolution, Japan's emerging new femininity and masculinity, Korean aspiration for love. In showing the construction of normality/abnormality, this course highlights the centrality of sexual desire to one's subjectivity and continuous endeavors for the wellbeing of the population, communities and individuals and for the value of difference.

title: Advanced Analysis
prereqs: MAT325 and MAT335 or equivalent..
descrip: The course covers the essentials of the first eleven chapters of the textbook, "Analysis" by Lieb and Loss. Topics include Lebesque integrals, Measure Theory, L^p Spaces, Fourier Transforms, Distributions, Potential Theory, and some illustrative examples of applications of these topics.

title: Clues, Evidence, Detection: Law Stories
reviews: A really interesting, fairly low-key class. The readings and movies were fun and doing them usually felt like a break from doing other work.

All the readings you have to do and movies you have to watch are really interesting - it won't feel like you're doing work. Good for a chill 5th class if you need it. Makes you think about law in a cool way
Best class on campus
Did not learn much. You might have a strong interest upon looking at the introduction of the course and the reading list, but the actual experience might not be what you expect.
Do all of the reading, but focus on the readings that aren't court cases because they are used on the exam.
Do all the readings!! They're super interesting!
Do all the readings, but don't worry about knowing every single detail of the stories you read. The big pictures are more important.
Do all the readings. Look up case briefs for the law cases because they'll help you narrow down the key details about each case.
Do the readings, if only for your own personal interest, it's totally worth it!
Don't take it. I didn't really learn anything unfortunately...
Don't worry about getting every detail of the longer court cases, just understand the narrative of the case and each judge's arguments, and the rest will be discussed in class.

Fascinating reading and excellent lectures made this course a worthwhile experience. The papers are very reasonable for non-humanities majors. As a physics student, I feel that I have a deeper understanding of the influence of narrative in law cases which will enhance my appreciation of the legal complexity in society.
Good EC, not too much work
Great class to PDF.
I would take this class. The readings are very interesting and the workload is very light.
If you don't think you'll do the readings, don't bother signing up because the readings are what makes the course so engaging.

If you're looking for a fun and not-extremely-challenging but still intellectually stimulating course, take it (especially if you are looking for an EM -- the two essays aren't very long)! Professor Brooks is a great lecturer. There's a wide diversity of students in different fields in this class, so it's really a mixed bag -- but that brings a lot of different viewpoints to discussions in precept!
It is a good class to take if you wish to learn more about court procedures and how a variety of cases could be tried in the modern day court system.
It's a highly interesting and fairly easy course. Lots of reading and the lectures can be hit-or-miss, but you will enjoy yourself and you don't need to work that hard to do well.
Take it because it's enjoyable! You really have a great opportunity to flex your close-reading muscles on interesting material in a welcoming space.
Take it!
Take it! Be ready to read a lot, but it's worth it.
Take it!! Especially if you enjoy reading/watching movies as assignments, they are essential for getting the most out of lecture/precept.
Take it.  take it.
Take this class! It's fun and engaging. The readings are interesting and the papers are manageable.
Take this course. You won't regret it. One of the best courses I've taken at Princeton.
The readings are interesting, and the precepts are great (I attended more than one). You may have to struggle to pay attention during lecture though.
This class has really great readings, but the lectures can be really boring. Precept with Matthew is AMAZING, but again lectures are boring. Good PDF class as the readings are interesting

This is my favorite humanities course here at Princeton. As a chem major, I was worried that it would be inaccessible, but the class was engaging and thought-provoking. Do not take this class for an easy EM, but take it if you want to gain a new perspective on literature and its connection with law.

You will get by if you genuinely like law, but not literature. The opposite is also likely true. But expect pretty outlandish opinions on the law from a Professor who is much more a literature guy than a law guy.
descrip: The seminar will look at stories in the law and about the law: court cases that turn on competing versions of a story, and how narrative "conviction" comes about, as well as fictional and non-fiction accounts of mystery, crime, investigation, and detection in literature and film. The course will introduce students to some issues in criminal law and procedure as well as to the analysis of narrative.

title: Elementary Chinese I
reviews: A lot of work and will take a substantial amount of time each week to keep up.
A lot of work, but amazing amazing amazing.
Always do your work, and attend every class you can.  Only take this class if you are serious about learning Chinese.
Be prepared for the course to escalate in difficulty halfway through the course. Don't procrastinate on memorizing the vocabulary.
Be prepared to work and be happy doing it. You will be rewarded for it. It is worth it, I promise.
Be sure to study every week. Don't cram it in before tests because that doesn't help you learn the material at all, much less, learn to speak the language.
Best class ever. They pushed me to think outside the box.

Chinese is one of the best courses you can take at Princeton. If you genuinely care about the language, you will get SO much out of this class. Even if you don't...the teachers are so good at what they do, I'm sure some of it will rub off. Keep a running list of characters you've studied and review every week or so. Once you get into the second half of the semester, old characters start coming up on quizzes again.
Definitely take this course if you're interested. Be warned though that it is a fair bit of work that you have to accomplish yourself, and there won't be any hand holding.
Don't focus on taking notes in class. Just listen, and work on your speaking ability.
Hard to imagine any modern language being taught better than Chinese is at Princeton.
I think they have to be prepared to jump into the language and dedicate themselves at improving themselves.
I would advise future students to practice a little bit every day to succeed in the class. I think that the student should also heavily study directly from the textbook.
I would recommend taking Chinese. It is hard at first, but the language is very interesting and engaging.

If you don't already know chinese, expect a bumpy ride. many "beginners" have actually taken chinese, so you will be at a distinct disadvantage. that being said, the class is great. you need to put in 100% effort to get the most out of it. this class is no joke.

If you have never taken Chinese before, take a second (or more) and think twice before taking this course. For those who truly want to learn Chinese and become fluent in 4 semesters, there is no better place to do that than Princeton and you will learn so much each semester. However, the journey to fluency will be incredibly difficult, and you'll see your peers who have previous experience with Chinese soaring ahead of you as you struggle to get even the most basic concepts and characters down. If you want to take Chinese as your language, be prepared to work incredibly hard (at least 30 min-an hour a day or more) and face lots of struggles and difficulties. Make sure your heart is in it and you really are motivated to learn Chinese! If it isn't and you aren't motivated, it will be a long semester and, like me, you'll be considering dropping it after only one semester.
If you like Chinese culture or you are thinking about a future that involves learning Chinese (business, medicine, marriage), take this class. Be forewarned though: this class is not easy.
It's a lot of work, but it's worth it because it will help you master the language.
Keep reviewing previous lessons.
Know that Chinese will be a class of primary focus - try not to take too many other classes that take up time.
Practice everyday.
Read your textbook daily and practice characters with higher frequency than is recommended by the weekly assignment
Study every day!! You WILL forget characters if you aren't consistent.
TAKE IT!
Take it !! Lots of work but rewarding
Take it if you like learning a language, if not then don't.

Take this course if you have an interest in learning Chinese. If Chinese competes with other languages you might want to learn, or if you are afraid it might be too hard, don't worry and take it. However, there will be some time invested in the course.
Take this course! Even if it may seem hard at first, if you are diligent in keeping up, then it will pay off in the end!
The two things that really helped me throughout this course were using flashcards and constantly going over the characters each day.
This course is a lot of work. I really enjoyed it, but as a BSE I am still wondering is taking it was the best choice time-wise. Attend Chinese tables.

This course is designed for people who have taken he language for 3-5 years. It moves extremely fast and there's not a lot of time to marinate on new concepts or practice them a lot. Also, in terms of "learning", it's 100% on you to learn the characters on your own, and  most of the lessons as well. Class feels more like a quick review of the book that they expect you to learn on your own, as opposed to a genuine teaching experience, which is really frustrating and not helpful if you've never taken the language before.
This course is extremely difficult, but well taught and rewarding. Take it only if you are fully dedicated to learning Chinese to fluency. I do not see anyone doing this as a side project.
This course is extremely rigorous but extremely well taught.
Tough but enjoyable.
Try to have fun in class! If you anticipate getting bored, it'll be boring -- but if you joke around with the teachers (in a good way) and have fun, it will be very fun.
Very hard but worth it if you really want to learn Chinese.
You'll definitely become fluent in Chinese over the next few years.
go to chinese table
highly recommended to everyone who wants to learn chinese. No prior knowledge required.
if you're willing to do the work its a great course.
prereqs: No credit is given for CHI 101 unless it is followed by CHI 102..
descrip: An intensive introductory course in modern spoken and written Chinese, stressing oral-aural facility and the analysis of structure.

title: The Western Way of War
reviews: A lot of reading, but worth it!
Absolutely take this course. It was incredible!
Be wary of the readings, they are very long and there is a ton of them.
Definitely take this class!!
Definitely take this course even if it remotely interests you. You will not regret it.
Do it. Love it.

Flawless course, if you are the least bit interested in the general topic of War then take this class, but if not don't let the broadness of the topic intimidate you. War encompasses components of international relations, strategy, statistics, history, and so much more. It is very easy to find students from STEM backgrounds interacting with Social Science Majors in this class because the topic is interesting to people from many different backgrounds, and ways of thinking.
Go to the lectures.
I think this is a great class to take even if you aren't a sociology major.
I would recommend this course to every student, regardless of their department or interest.
I'd strongly recommend they take this course - students are unlikely to find a class better taught.
IT IS AMAZING!!! Prof. Centeno is the best! This was a really fun, low-key class.
If it is offered again, 100% take it. It is well worth your time. The workload is light and the class itself is amazing. It is unforgettable and very intellectually stimulating.

If this course is ever offered again, do not hesitate to take it. Professor Centeno is one of the best lecturers I've had. Andrew is simply the best preceptor I've ever had here. His experiences as a Navy SEAL put all of the content in to real, personal context. This course has the best readings of any course I've taken. I don't know what more I can say, except that I simply cannot imagine my Princeton studies without this course. Might be a good time to mention that I'm a Neuro major and just took this for interest. This is one of those classes that reminds me why I chose to come here out of all the other schools. I hope every Princeton student has the opportunity to take this course. Now I just I had more room in my schedule for classes like this.
Read as much as you can.
TAKE IT AND NEVER LOOK BACK IT'S SO SO GREAT WOO
Take it!
Take it! I loved the course and Professor Centeno is an amazing lecturer!
Take it! Its great
Take it, do the readings, and enjoy!

Take this class definitely!!! Its super interesting and engaging. Don't be overwhelmed by the amount of reading, it is definitely doable. You dont really have to do all of the readings, though they are mostly really interesting. Lectures and precepts are awesome. Take it.
Take this class!!
Take this course if you care at all about civilization.
This class is amazing. You learn so much from Professor Centeno. His lectures and the readings are super engaging.

This course is awesome. The material is fascinating and Centeno is a great lecturer, though I don't think he's teaching it anymore. Good for PDF, but you won't get a bad grade if you don't. A lot of readings--a book per week--but they're very interesting.
This is a good PDF. It is possible to do well in the course, but will require a good amount of work. The work entails readings and writing and thoroughly preparing for exams. Not an "easy A"

This is a phenomenal course, and Professor Centeno is a great lecturer! However, there is a lot of weekly reading, so be prepared for the amount of work needed. If you are looking to fulfill an HA distribution requirement, this is the course to take!!

This is a rather easy class that is very engaging and taught by wonderful people.  Do not be intimidated by the readings.  Just skim them, but when you have to write one of your papers on it try to actually read it.  YOU CANNOT GO WRONG WITH THIS COURSE.
This is a really great course! Though it can be a lot of work, it is definitely worth it.
This was an excellent and fascinating course with reasonable work load. I recommend taking it so you have a better understanding of warfare in general and know what the military does.

make sure to keep up with the readings, and ATTEND ALL THE LECTURES! you won't regret it. seriously. You will find the course will expand your concept of modern warfare, international relations, and the importance of the role of our generation.
take it
there's a whole lot of reading, so be prepared for that.
descrip: A historical and analytical overview of war focusing on the origins and consequences of organized violence, the experience of battle, the creation and behavior of warriors, and the future of such conflicts.

title: Satire: Mockery and Reform from Aristophanes to South Park
reviews: Absolutely take it and DO THE READING!
Do the readings, attend class, think hard about the topics.
Don't take it unless you have to.
Have fun! And choose wisely for which weeks you're responding to, because some works are definitely harder than others.

I would say overall a good choice to fulfill a British Foundations requirement if that's generally not your thing. Does make you think about contemporary satire in what I think are useful and productive and intellectually-satisfying ways-- highly relevant to a lot of the stuff saturating our culture now.
You should take this course, and try to think outside the box.
descrip: The course traces the history of satire from Aristophanes to South Park, with a special focus on English satire in the Renaissance and 18th century. Narrowly defined, satire is a genre that ridicules human follies and vices in order to reform them. We will discuss the intent and efficacy of satire, the relation between satire and authority, and the role of the audience as target and participant. Required authors include Chaucer, Shakespeare, Donne, Jonson, Swift, Pope, and Byron, and American satirists Twain, Bierce, and Mencken. The last two weeks will cover 20th- and 21st-century satirical forms in film, cartoons, journalism, and stand-up.

title: Modern Latin America since 1810
descrip: Course examines interactions between states and citizens since Latin American independence with an additional consideration of the region's integration into global economic and political systems.

title: Ethnography, Evidence and Experience
prereqs: No prerequisites. Assumes basic general knowledge of the scope and aims of sociocultural anthropology, cultural studies or other ethnographic inquiry, and/or intercultural or international experience. For students lacking such preparation, any 200-level course in anthropology (or a related field's introductory course) may be taken concurrently. (ANT301, The Ethnographer's Craft in Spr 2015, is intended to supplement ANT300 but either course may be taken separately. Together they are designed to help prepare students for independent ethnographic research.).
descrip: This seminar relates key concepts in anthropology (e.g., culture, society, power, meaning) to everyday experience, with the aim of fostering students' ability to think analytically across diverse cultural fields. We alternate between classic theoretical texts and "dossiers" of highly current readings about issues both familiar to students (from experiences at home or abroad) and relevant to ethnographic research and writing. For example: digital media, embodied knowledge, language, ritual and symbols, textual interpretation, and modern forms of power and inequality.

title: Research Topics in QCB
reviews: Absolutely take it. It really helps you in preparing presentations and in scientific writing. I say go for it.

Definitely take this class if you are interested in taking research a step farther. It really helped me learn about how to present science in an accessible manner. This course is much, much improved from Project Lab. Of course, if you want the certificate you have to take this class - go for the certificate if you've done all that ISC/completed the requirements! It's pretty worth it.
Make sure you're able to put in a lot of time into your independent work in lab.
Take it! It will challenge you in entirely new ways, transform how you see and present and write about science, and give you excellent exposure to research in general.
Take this class, but only if you are willing to put in some work.  Otherwise, you will get nothing out of it.
prereqs: ISC231-234 and ISC235-236 (the latter can be taken concurrently). Students must choose their research labs in the spring of their sophomore year and be engaged in the research from the start of the Fall semester..
descrip: This class is aimed at Juniors pursuing the QCB Certificate. In this course, we will discuss the independent research projects that the juniors are performing in order to provide guidance and feedback. We will emphasize critical thinking about experiments and large dataset analysis along with the ability to clearly communicate one's research. Students will present background research (journal club style presentations) and progress reports. Written work will consist of an NSF-style proposal and an NIH-style grant proposal/research paper.

title: Religion in the Americas Workshop
descrip: A weekly, year-long workshop focused on the current research of visiting presenters, current students, and faculty in American religious history. The workshop is designed primarily for Ph.D. students in the field, but is open as well to undergraduate concentrators with a strong background in the study of American religion and culture. Note: REL 523 (fall) and REL 524 (spring) constitute this year-long workshop. In order to receive credit and/or a grade, students must take the course both semesters.

title: History of Architectural Theory
reviews: Actively involve oneself with the readings, toward a kind of self-selection and evaluation of the theories at hand. To not simply read the theories, but to read through them toward a personal understanding of the contemporary discipline seemed most productive.

Anyone that's ready to keep up with the readings and attend lectures should take this course. Lectures are the key to knowing what to expect on the exams and papers. Go to the review sessions before the exams.

Assume the level of involvement with a seminar combined with the time commitment of a lecture. The course is unique in its treatment of high level overviews and fine grain analysis, engagement with both will be the most rewarding.

Be careful with this class. Lucia gives good lectures, the readings are great BUT if its too large it will suck. Lucia doesn't seem to pick up the slack, so you just won't get any feedback on your assignments. Also the final exam is brutal. She casually mentioned it in class, then drops 8-10 pages on you in 4 days. With no way to prepare for it. Good Luck!
Definitely do the readings
Go ahead and read, its rewarding.
Great if you are interested in going in-depth with architecture
Have a fair knowledge of Architectural history before venturing into this one

Highlight specific quotes and maybe even retype them for yourself. I definitely best understood the readings for the week I was intended to present- precisely because I collected the quotes I found particularly insightful.

I heard many of my classmates complain about the perceived lack of feedback on papers and assignments. I arranged a meeting with our AI to get feedback when needed. This was available to all students yet many didn't seek out the help. I would reiterate that this was available by request.
I would highly recommend this course to majors and non-majors alike.
If you don't care about getting feedback, no problem. It's a good foundation in theory.

Lucia's lectures are fast-paced, dynamic, and simply wonderful as long as you are always paying attention! You will learn a TON from this class, and if you're an architecture student you'll find yourself asking why you never learned this all earlier :)
Take great notes during lecture and on readings. Keep up with the syllabus. Don't expect feedback on written work.
Take it. Record the classes though because you will want to return to them as its just too much to take in.
This course provide view a overall view of architecture theory.
prereqs: Course open to undergraduate and graduate students. Of particular interest to art history, history, and architecture students. No prerequisites, but HIS 211, ART 333 and ART 322 are strongly recommended as background..
descrip: This course offers a history of architectural theory, criticism, and historiography from the Renaissance to the present, emphasizing the texts, media and institutions that have supported architecture's claim to modernity since the late 17th Century. Architectural thought is examined in its social and cultural context as it relates both to the Western philosophical tradition and to design method and practice.

title: Junior Seminar: Introduction to Comparative Literature
reviews: Even though it's required, this is definitely a class you should look forward to!

I had low expectations for this course but, although I wasn't astounded or anything, with Professor Reeves this year and Aia co-teaching it wasn't bad at all. If you are set on being a COM major this is the only required class and it is worth sitting through. Other than that expect the syllabus to be all over the place, regardless of who is teaching. Lack of unity is the main issue this class has.

I would recommend that COM majors approach this class with an open mind.  It ended up being a lot more interesting than I anticipated, considering it's a required course for all majors.  I think the course definitely taught me a lot about the field's complexity and its broader applicability to our world.
Meet with the professor and TA to discuss papers.
Of course you won't get to choose who the professor is, but Professor Reeves is the  best.
Prof. Reeves is very fun, and I enjoyed going through this departmental with her.
Reeves is a great professor, and you will enjoy being in class with her!
This is a departmental...

This is a great introduction to some of the important themes discussed in the field of comparative literature. This course will definitely give you an idea of whether you belong in the department and what kind of studies you wish to pursue for your remaining semesters as a complit major.
descrip: What does it mean to read comparatively across languages, disciplines, and media? How does Comparative Literature relate to the many cultures, traditions, and literary conventions of a globalized world? Where does translation fit into this scenario? We will address these questions and others by examining Comparative Literature as an historical institution and an evolving discipline. Readings will include a variety of genres such as travel writing, fiction, poetry, literary history and critical theory; the seminar schedule will also accommodate the parallel process of the first junior paper.

title: 20th-Century Japanese History
reviews: If this is in your area of interest, or even if it is tangentially related, I thoroughly recommend it. You will not regret taking a course with Professor Garon, at the very least.
Tough reading load but would definitely learn a lot from that.
descrip: Readings in Japanese political, social, and economic history. Topics include transwar continuity and change, political economy, labor, gender issues, culture and state, religion, Japanese expansion and colonialism, the Allied Occupation of Japan and "social management," and transnational-historical approaches to studying Japan. Some readings in Japanese (optional for those who do not specialize in Japanese history).

title: Constitutional Interpretation
reviews: Addresses some really important issues and gets you thinking in new ways (no matter what your starting point was) about our Constitution - definitely worth taking.

Best course at Princeton. Lecture is like listening to a captivating narrative weaving history, con-law, pol-theory etc together. I was always excited for lecture and precept. RPG is a great preceptor too.

Definitely take this course. Although it carries an infamous reputation as a GPA destroyer, this is simply not true. Getting a B is within reach for any student willing to put in a reasonable amount of effort, and a grade higher than a B is without doubt possible for those willing to put in more effort. The lectures are legendary and the subject matter is extremely interesting.

Even if you get frustrated by the clearly conservative perspectives being reflected 90% of the time, you will learn a lot by taking this course. The work is interesting, and the assignments are actually very creative and fun.
Go to all the lectures!
I regret not having been more engaged in precept and doing more readings.

I took this course because people kept on telling me that it was the best course at Princeton. After taking it, I'm pretty sure that's true. This class is more than just a law class. It's really a class on the American system -- what are the principles that underlie our system of government? If you're at all interested in this, you should take this class. Robert George has a reputation for being the best lecturer on campus, and it's well-deserved. Every lecture was incredibly engaging, and 80 minute lectures seemed way shorter than most 50 minute lectures. George is also an incredibly good preceptor as well, and you should get in his precept. He really gets to know everyone, and he's brilliant. Yes, this class is graded very harshly. That being said, I didn't think that any of the comments I got on my papers were undeserved. If you do good work, believe it or not, you will get an A. Besides, one class is like 3% of your overall GPA. I think even Yale Law will overlook one B.

If you are *really* interested in the constitution and have a background in it, then this course will probably be more fulfilling. If you want to learn about the constitution and want a class where the preceptors and professor are open to helping students learn the material for the exams and papers, then I would not recommend this class.

If you are interested in American history or politics you should take this course. I'd strongly recommend taking it in conjunction with Democratic Theory. The two together give a perfect balance of theory and practice.
It is a lot of reading and work, but it is truly worth it if you are interested in the subject matter.
It's hard, but take it!
No. Take Civil Liberties if you want a course with Professor George. Con Interp is poorly organized, has unnecessarily long readings, harsh grading and boring precepts.
