One gains the most from this course by fully investing oneself in it. People who do not commit to the readings or assignments will find it unfulfilling and too challenging. Although it is not an easy A, the content of the course makes the work extremely worthwhile.
TAKE IT!!!

TAKE THIS COURSE. Everyone at Princeton should take a course with Professor George before they leave. Everything about this course was well-organized and structured, and it will cause you to think about constitutional interpretation in a completely different way. Highly, highly recommend.
TAKE THIS COURSE. The work is definitely worth it, whether you get an A or not!

Take it if you have an interest in the subject and are willing to work hard. I wouldn't recommend this course for someone who is just looking to take a politics course, though. The material is challenging and it takes a lot of effort to do well/

Take it if you like Con law and you are prepared to deal with some super-conservative BS, ambitious Woody Woo types and members of the Robbie George cult of personality. The subject matter is really interesting, and if you focus on really understanding the principles, you can get a lot out of the course.
Take it!
Take it! Constitutional Interpretation provides a fundamental understanding of the subject. Whether or not you are interested in politics, I would highly recommend the course.

Take it. Professor George is a great lecturer and you will learn a lot, especially if you haven't had exposure to constitutional law yet, but even if you have (I had taken a constitutional law seminar with President Eisgruber before taking the class). Grading is really tough, but the writing center definitely helped me, as did going to my friends and talking to them about the paper topics (if your preceptor allows this).

Take the course. I felt as if I was the only Conservative in my precept. It was clear that the other students entered the semester with pre-conceived notions of the "Living and Breathing Constitution" taught to them while in high school. That said, it was also very clear that the students began to qualify their stances based on legal framework and precedence over the course of the semester.
Take this class, but be prepared to devote lots of time to the readings, otherwise you just won't get out of this class what you would otherwise.
Take this course, but don't believe all the hype.
Take this course. Lots of work, but take it.
The course is not as hard as it is reputed to be. That said, it takes some discipline to work on the essays over winter break - manage your time well.

This class actually changed my understanding of the constitution, and provided balanced inquiry into modern issues of con. interp. It is very rewarding but the volume of reading and workload is tremendous. The rumors of rigorous grading are all true and expect to put in long hours to get an A.

This course marks everyone down half a letter grade to maintain it's reputation. It's key ideas are pretty much exhausted by the midterm after which there's just a frustrating set upon set of legal maneuvering to wade through.

This is a course every Princetonian and every American should take. I think I learned more from this one class than I learned from every other course combined this semester. Worth the work and the pain. There's nothing like it.
Very harsh grading, but a good course to take if you are Politics or thinking about law school. 2-hr precepts are tough, but try to get George
You should take it but only if you're prepared to get below an A and to work really hard for the B .
difficult, time-consuming course, but worth it
it's not the hard, but the grading is a little harsh
descrip: A study of the structure of the American constitutional system and of the meaning of key constitutional provisions. Competing ideas about constitutional interpretation is a central focus of the course.

title: Religion and Public Life
descrip: Presentation and critical discussion of empirical research in progress by participants. Focuses on the use of social science methods in the study of religion and on applications of recently published work about religion and society. Includes an emphasis on religion and public policy in the U. S. and in comparative perspective.

title: A History of the World since 1300
reviews: A nice overview of the history of the world since 1300. I hadn't taken a history class since I was 15 years old; this was a good re-introduction class.
Adelman is a fantastic lecturer!  Definitely also try to get into his precept - he makes the course very worthwhile.
Do expect some 4-6 hours per week to watch lectures and read the textbook and readings, but you can get by on less.
Dont take it!
I think this class was an important class to learn an in depth and overall history to the present.

It is certainly an interesting 200-level class, and Professor Adelman is a great lecturer.  However, there are so many moving parts that you have to accomplish each week that the work becomes a burden rather than intellectually exciting.
It's an interesting course.
Its a great history to take if you need a departmental.
Make sure to read the chapter before the weekly lecture. And try to stay on top of the online lectures to the best of your ability.
My only advice is for students to understand that what they are learning is very broad...there is not much detail involved because there is so much information to cover.
Only take it if you're actually interested in history. A lot of work and make sure you're ready to put the work in. Don't take it strictly to fulfill distribution requirements.
Prepare for a lot of work, but if you love the subject, it is beyond worth it.
Stay on top of readings, and understanding of general themes and processes.
Take it if you are interested in history but it is a very broad course.

Take it if you are interested in world history or are a history major. Isn't that in depth (obviously) but can be interesting. Watch all lectures, annoying that they are online. Also - labs are frustrating but do them well.
Take it. Great history course.
Take this course!
Take this if you are very interested in how different events in history are interconnected.

This was, by far, my favorite class this semester. It provides a great introduction to themes in global history, which may be especially appealing for students who have not taken many history classes in the past. The NovoEd assignments are extremely interesting, and it's really cool to receive feedback on work from other students across the globe. If you are at all interested in learning about world history, take this class!
Very engaging course
Watch the lectures
Watch the lectures, do the readings, and participate.
not as easy as it sounds. make sure you get Adelman's precept.
pdf this class and it will be a much better experience
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: An introduction to the history of the modern world, this course traces the global processes that connected regions with each other from the time of Genghis Khan to the present. The major themes of the course include the environmental impact of human development, the role of wars and empires in shaping world power, and the transformations of global trade, finance, and migration.

title: Asset Pricing I: Pricing Models and Derivatives
reviews: Come to a lecture and see if you like it.
Don't take it unless you love theoritical asset pricing
Expect the theoretical foundation but not a practical pricing course
It is a good first approach of Asset pricing
Not really useful in real life
Some knowledge of theoretical maths, particularly linear algebra and optimisation would be good.
This course should only be taken if requirement or if interested in very abstract  theory.
take it also as an undergrad
descrip: An introduction to the modern theory of asset pricing. Topics include: No arbitrage, Arrow-Debreu prices and equivalent martingale measure; security structure and market completeness; mean-variance analysis, Beta-Pricing, CAPM; and introduction to derivative pricing.

title: Topics in Discrete Mathematics - Graph Minors
prereqs: Undergrads must obtain permission of instructor..
descrip: This course is a survey of the Graph Minors project of Robertson and the speaker, and some recent extensions. The main topics are graph path-width and tree-width, and extensions used for the Graph Minors project; some description of how this is used to solve the k vertex-disjoint paths problem in a graph; containment relations for digraphs, and particularly for tournaments; a recent solution of the k vertex-disjoint directed paths problem in tournaments; graph well-quasi-ordering, and tournament well-quasi-ordering.

title: Apocalypse Now
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Geometry - Conformally covariant operators and their associated Q-curvatures
descrip: This course covers the following: The CR conformal Laplacian and the scalar curvature equation, the fourth order Paneitz operator on a conformal 4-manifold and the fourth order CR Panietz operator of CR 3-manifold. The positivity property, the CR embedding problem and the CR positive mass theorem and its relation with the d-bar equation, the solution of the CR Yamabe equation, the new operator on the pluriharmonic functions and its associated Q-curvature, the Q-curvature integral and the Burns-Epstein invariant.

title: Model Memoirs: The Life Stories of International Fashion Models
reviews: A good AAS course that actually ended up being useful for my thesis but interest in the subject is important or you may get really bored or even annoyed. The readings are interesting enough, and the workload is light with only a midterm and final paper.
Definitely recommend.  I didn't have any background in fashion, but it was really fun to learn about and read memoirs. Very enjoyable and fun class.
Definitely take it if you can!
Genuinely participate in class. Offer thoughtful insight and you'll learn a lot about society today.

Great class to take. Professor Perry is wonderful. You don't need to know all about fashion to take this course. You should take it if you are interested in learning about modeling, entertainment, current events/media. Take it if you can!
Great course, definitely suggest taking it.

Keep up with the readings so that you are better able to provide insightful (emphasis on insight) comments. However, reading everything that is assigned or a lot of or some of what is assigned will not necessarily help you with writing the papers, which make up more of the grade than participation, according to the syllabus.
Take it - and be surprised!

Take this course if you are genuinely interested in the subject matter. This course is very focused on a specific topic and background knowledge might be helpful (although it is not absolutely necessary).

This class depends on the enrolled students as that generally determines the direction of the conversations. Professor Perry is stellar and always provides invaluable input. Because the students in this class were mostly interested in the superficial aspects of fashion rather than the more nuanced issues of race, gender, class, etc, the class was not as fulfilling as I had hoped. But overall, it's a good course because it's Imani Perry.

This is not Professor Perry's area of expertise -- I took the class to take a course from her but wish I had taken one of her more critical race studies courses. The course bothered me most weeks -- wasn't academic enough and I didn't feel that motivated to do the reading as a result.
take it!
takeeee it. hardly any work and its super interesting
descrip: Explores the life-writing of American, African, and Asian women in the fashion industry as a launching point for thinking about race, gender, and class. How do ethnicity and femininity intersect? How are authenticity and difference commodified? How do women construct identities through narrative and negotiate their relationships to their bodies, families, and nations? This course will include guest lectures by fashion editors and models; discussions of contemporary television programs, global fashion, and cultural studies; and student self-narratives about their relationships with cultural standards of beauty, whether vexed or not.

title: AESTHETICS, TECTONICS, and MATERIALITY in Semper?s Theoretical Writings
reviews: If you are interested in the topic, you will come away with a thorough insight of it following Professor's tutelage.
Misreadings are rewarded with comments, either to clarify or expand. The difficulty of the material is offset by Spyros's enthusiasm and willingness to decipher.
Strongly recommend - if not out of interest or curiosity, then to experience Prof. Papapetros's "bible study" style classes.
Take a class with this professor
descrip: An in depth survey of Gottfried Semper's theoretical writings including a close reading of his Style in the Technical and Tectonic Arts or Practical Aesthetics, as well as the architect's writings on the basic elements of architecture, ornament, industrial arts, and his general theory of form. Semper's texts are set in context by readings in philosophy, anthropology, natural science, and political theory by authors from Semper's circle and are implemented by an analysis of recent texts on tectonics, aesthetics, as well as form theory, object oriented ontology, new materialism, and the philosophy of the anthropocene.

title: Self to Selfies
descrip: Please see freshman seminars website

title: Seminar in American Politics - Gender and American Politics
reviews: Definitely take this class. Prof. Mendelberg is the best, the readings are great, and you will never get bored during the class discussions.
This class was interesting and it's great, but you shouldn't take it if you're not willing to work hard.
Though the final paper is challenging, the readings and class discussions make the class extremely worthwhile. Professor Mendelberg is fantastic and the material is extremely relevant and engaging.

You have to be really interested in the material. But if you are, this is a great class for you. Three-hours always flew by and Professor Mendelberg is a great teacher. Stay on top of your work, space it out--especially when it comes to the final project! There are lots of deadlines for class drafts and such but you have to make the effort to create deadlines for yourself in between the class dates.
just an okay course
descrip: This course examines the intersection of gender and politics in the United States.

title: French Romanticism
reviews: I definitely would recommend taking this course if you feel comfortable reading in French.  The discussions and readings were very interesting, and I think the content would appeal to a wide range of students.

The readings are essential to class discussion; it is therefore fundamental to complete them all. Deep engagement with the readings while they are being completed on a weekly basis will assist you in your written assignments, which require a deep understanding of the texts.

This is a thorough and solid introduction to thematic French literature, as romanticism was one of the most grounding movements that ushered in modernism. There is variety from novels to poems, but beware, readings of longer works can be difficult. The discussion/lectures by Prof. Rentzou are enlightening and engaging, giving a lot to think about.
prereqs: FRE 207 or Permission of the Instructor..
descrip: This course studies literature, arts, and culture which manifest the Romantic vision and sensibility that was shaped in the French Revolution and diffused by the rise of bourgeois-industrial society. The course stresses poetry, the novel, and art, placing them in the context of the history of ideas. Romanticism is viewed in its relation with the past (classicism) but also with regard to the new modernist aesthetic emerging after the second half of the 19th century (e.g. Baudelaire). Close analysis of texts is combined with a broader perspective on the cultural significance of the movement.

title: Physics for Future Leaders
reviews: It's a great STN or STL. Professor Steinhardt is great and his lectures are quite enjoyable even if you really don't like science, and if you do, even better. The course definitely isn't that difficult. Take it!
It's easy. Take this if you hate math and have never done well at science, because it's terrific for that. Don't take it if you feel like you get science.
Prof Steinhardt is incredible. Labs were good too
Take it for a lab if you're interested in
Take it for the lab, graded fairly and interesting

This is a good course to take for the lab requirement if you are not that interested in science, because the labs are entirely self-contained (no lab reports, etc.). Though Professor Steinhardt is an engaging lecturer, the lectures do not adequately prepare you for the assignments, which are always confusing even though they should be simple. This class too often attempts to simplify extremely complicated concepts that really can't be simplified.
prereqs: Math skills at the level of high school algebra are assumed. No prior classes in physics or astronomy are necessary..
descrip: What do future leaders of our society need to know about physics and technology? The course is designed for non-scientists who will someday become our influential citizens and decision-makers. Whatever the field of endeavor, they will be faced with important decisions in which physics and technology play an important role. The purpose of this course is to present the key principles and the basic physical reasoning needed to interpret scientific and technical information and to make the best decisions. Topics include energy and power, atomic and subatomic matter, wave-like phenomena and light, and Einstein's theory of relativity.

title: Race, Gender, and Representation
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Princeton Atelier - Dance on Camera/DIY
reviews: Fun, low-stress course. Take it if you have an interest in dance, visual arts, or video production and want to try something new!
I recommend taking it! I really liked it.

If you are looking for an intense dance class or an intense film class, this is not it. It focuses on the intersection of dance and video so it delves on the interesting parts such as composition and framing a lot with respect to how dance is portrayed on the film medium.
prereqs: Open enrollment..
descrip: Dance on camera has a different impact than dance on stage - how can we explore this form that arguably has a bigger audience than live performance? How can we make and distribute dance on camera using equipment that is readily available and low cost? This studio course supports students to create video projects featuring the body in motion; results may be art installations, dance videos or video art. Graphic artist/Princeton Fellow Danielle Aubert and choreographer/professor Susan Marshall will lead workshops in movement and in the use of sound and motion-editing software.

title: Conservation Biology
reviews: I would take this if you are interested in the concepts and need it as a requirement.  Definitely go to precepts if Adam is the TA.
Lecture can be boring, but Martha and Adam are cool. It's a laid back class, relevant for a lot of different EEB classes.
Take if you are genuinely interested
prereqs: EEB 211.
descrip: An in-depth exposure to topics in conservation biology emphasizing the application of scientific concepts to our understanding of the problems that threaten endangered species and ecosystems. Topics include island biogeography, population genetics and viability, landscape ecology, reserve design, and endangered species recovery. To a lesser degree, this course will address some of the political, economic, and cultural aspects of conservation.

title: Elementary Korean I
reviews: Definitely take this course! It's fairly easy, although the workload can be a bit heavy at times. But the teachers are all really great, and do a good job of teaching you the language.
Go over all the grammar points and exceptions to them.
I think it is recommended if you want a class that will give you a introduction to korean. The class is very engaging and helpful.

If you are at all interested in the Korean language or culture, TAKE THIS CLASS. Yes, it's five days a week, as all intro-level language courses all, but you really feel as though you are making tangible progress in learning a language. As someone who'd only studied Romance languages prior to this, it was fascinating to learn a new writing system and grammar. The professors are AMAZING -- so funny and sweet -- and the cultural activities are great (music videos, kimbap workshop)!

If you are looking to take the easiest class that you will ever take at Princeton, this is it. Do not expect your language skills to improve vastly. It is a "no pain, no gain" course. The teachers are so nice and welcoming, will allow you to retake quizzes periodically, will move homework due dates later, and will not assign much in the way of homework, or require much in the way of direct participation. Professor Suh is extremely friendly and plays music videos before each class to lighten the mood. I appreciated the Korean teachers' attitude towards teaching and welcoming attitude of no critical judgement towards students. However, I personally was dissatisfied because I learned much less than I expected to.
Just be consistent in doing a bit of homework and reading through the text book every day. You'll be just fine!
Korean is a great language to learn and the professors make it fun and exciting
Learning Korean here is more easygoing than learning some other languages, yet you still learn a lot and get a great foundation in the language. Highly recommend!
TAKE IT IF YOU HAVE ANY INTEREST!
Take Korean!
Take advantage of the intimate, interactive drill sessions to get the most out of the course.
Take it if you want to learn Korean! Beware--this class is a lot of work, though. 2 quizzes a week, 2-3 hw's a week. Class every day. But you make friends who are also interested in Korean! :)
Take it!
Take it! Korean is fun, the professor/instructors are fun, the pace is good, and overall it was a really enjoyably and relaxing class for me.
Take it.
Terrible curve, so no room for mistakes.  Technically an easy class...
The teachers are great, helpful, and understanding. Expect to put a bit of time into the course if you haven't studied any related languages before, though.
Well-taught course. Korean is a fun language. Requires work, but not slaving away. Beware of the kids that take 101 when they should be in 103. Don't let them intimidate you too much. Graded fairly
awesome fun class. less work than chinese, more fun in class and you can still learn a good amount.
prereqs: No credit is given for KOR 101 unless it is followed by KOR 102. This is a 5 day/week course..
descrip: Elementary Korean is designed for beginning students who intend to build a solid foundation for further study in the Korean language. The course provides four balanced language skills - listening, speaking, reading, and writing - needed for basic communication. It emphasizes the ability to use Korean appropriately and introduces students to useful information concerning culture and daily life in Korea.

title: Introduction to Materials
reviews: I would recommend this course if you are interested in conducting research even remotely related to materials science, as it gives a good basic introduction to the discipline.
It is a great introductory course to take if you are interested in material science
It's difficult, but it's worth it.
Lots of work.
Take this class if you want to learn a lot about a wide variety of topics in materials science.
the lighting in the classroom is dark and makes me feel sleepy
descrip: Emphasizes the connection between microstructural features of materials and their properties, and how processing conditions control structure. Topics include atomic bonding, crystal structure, thermodynamics, phase diagrams, defects, microstructure, diffusion, phase transformations, nucleation, coarsening, glasses, elastic and plastic deformation, fracture, sol-gel processing, sintering, and composites.

title: Junior Seminar - Writing as Technology
reviews: 1) Use Prof. Keulemans' Reading Guide, 2) Have your own interests in mind, because the course covers such a broad spectrum of East Asia-related topics
Definitely take it! Professor Keulemans is a great professor and he'll present the material very well!
If you're going to be an EAS major, you're going to take EAS 300, which will be different from this. N/A
Nothing in particular.

This is obviously required if you are an EAS major. I'm not sure who will be teaching it next year, but rest assured Professor Keulemans was incredible. He's extremely knowledgable and approachable. This class will expose you to other areas of East Asia that are not in your concentration through readings and movies. It will expand your understanding of East Asia as a whole and be of great use to you in finding a topic for your junior paper and successfully executing it.
Well, you've gotta take it, but it's awesome, so you're in luck!
descrip: This class prepares students for the junior and senior thesis in East Asian Studies by introducing the necessary skills in research and writing. To do so, the class consists exercises that teach students to utilize library, web, and faculty resources while at the same time asking students to think about how to plan and compose a thesis effectively. Thematically, the class pursues this goal by investigating the writing system, a unifying feature once shared by all three East Asian cultures. Topics pursued include writing as magic, voice and text, authorship, calligraphy, dictionaries, printing, copyright, tattoos, and texting.

title: Introduction to Critical Theory - Critical Latina/o Studies
descrip: This course investigates the history and futurity of Latina/o Studies in the greater humanities. We will read canonical texts in Latina/o Studies and reanimate their influential if still undertheorized interventions. We will supplement these readings with recent work that opens up the field's familiar ontological coordinates. As we reimagine the field's key words and tropes, we will expand its methodological repertoire for the study of race, migration, and ethnicity in America. By placing these critical efforts in living relation to Latina/o performance, we will cultivate a sense of play to approach the new creative waves of Latinidad.

title: International Political Economy
reviews: DO THE READINGS.

I'd recommend this class. The one thing I'd say though is that I took this class without any background in econ, which made it slightly harder to learn some of the concepts that other students were already well-versed in.

If you are interested in how rich and poor countries behave with each other and how the WTO, World Bank, and the IMF feature in their interactions, this could be a great introductory course. The workload is manageable and Professor Ahmed is super organized and friendly.
Make sure you do the readings and look at/write good lecture notes, otherwise you will fall very far behind very quickly.
Take it if you have an interest in international organizations.

The material was great and opened up a new way of thinking. If the same professor is teaching, lectures might be a little rocky but I would still recommend going as they often can even replace the readings.
The material was great.
The readings are very interesting, but the lectures are dull and the grading is arbitrary. Take it if you're really interested in IPE. If not, take another course.
This class was actually kind of cool. A lot of material, but useful material
don't take the class unless you want to learn more about basic IPE
descrip: This course explores the following questions: who wins and who loses from globalization of trade and finance? Who sets the rules under which the game of international capitalism is played? How powerful are international organizations like the WTO or the IMF, nation-states, or NGOs? These issues are explored with reference to economic and political theories, history and contemporary events.

title: Elementary Hindi and Urdu I
reviews: Do the homework.

Excellent class if you have any interest in Hindi, Indian languages, or South Asia. Also gives good cultural background in addition to the language skills. Fauzia ji is an excellent, hardworking, but also laid back teacher.
Just keep an open mind and just try to participate as much as possible!
TAKE IT! Its a great course and you learn a new interesting language!
There's a lot of individual attention, so I feel like it's a good atmosphere to learn a language. She's good, but there will be mostly self studying.
descrip: This introductory proficiency-based course in Hindi and Urdu allows students to acquire linguistic skills in culturally authentic contexts. Students will learn to communicate in a variety of everyday situations. Hindi and Urdu share a basic grammar and core vocabulary but differ in terms of scripts and some cultural markers. There will be equal emphasis on both scripts and cultures; parallel written materials will be provided in both scripts. Students are expected to develop proficiency in one script of their choice, and are encouraged to learn both. Classes will be interactive.

title: Computational Design
reviews: Be prepared for a very steep learning curve for all the programs you'll encounter, but it is rewarding and worth it in the end.

Computational design might sound intimidating, but this is an introductory course and the professor knows that. You can expect all the help you need with your projects and you will learn a lot, enough to feel confident moving forward. Architecture students should take this course because the skills learned here will be useful to you moving forward in the major.

If you take the time to learn the programs and put effort in on your projects, this course is really productive. Don't be afraid to approach Axel with problems. It can take up a lot of time if you don't pace yourself well.
No. No. Do not take this course. Do not take this course. Do not take this course. Find another way. Beg for another way. But do not take this course.

Take this course if you're ready to challenge yourself and dive into learning what works for you in the design process. Definitely keep in mind though, that if you have no experience with design, you'll have to constantly push yourself.
You only get out of this course what you put in. Begin work on the projects early and ask Axel and the teaching assistant many questions as they have a lot of interesting and helpful knowledge.
You will learn a lot if you are willing to put in the work. The pace is very quick  so expect a lot of work!
prereqs: Open to Arch and Civ Arch students ONLY. If seminar is oversubscribed, enrollment will be based on seniority..
descrip: This course is an introduction to computational design using a range of design concepts from NURBS modeling, simple programming and parametric modeling to basic digital fabrication and electronics. Through a series of computational exercises, presentations, and in-class discussions, we will investigate the evolving relationship between models of design and generative design issues of technology and culture in architecture.

title: The Apostle Paul in Text and Context: His Letters, His Communities, and His Interpreters
reviews: Absolutely do it! Make sure you do all the readings because otherwise you won't get nearly as much out of the class.

Absolutely take this course. Professor Luijendijk is one of the best professors you could possibly hope to befriend here at Princeton, the trip to Greece is unbelievable (you will become super close to everyone in your class and that will make the seminar way more fun during the second half of the semester), and the subject matter is actually extremely fascinating.
I highly recommend this course! Professor Luijendijk is amazing! This class is a great chance to delve deeply into Pauline texts and scholarship!

Prof. Luijendijk is fantastic. She is very interested in the material world as well as the role of women in the ancient world. She cares a lot about her students and the class is very enjoyable. Going to Greece with her was absolutely amazing!
TAKE IT.
TAKE THIS COURSE if you are truly interested in the topic! It will change your life for the better, and you will meet a wonderful professor and a wonderful, unique group of classmates.

TAKE THIS COURSE! It is more than worth applying to. It was possibly my favorite class I've taken at Princeton. I made many great friends and learned about the past, as well as present life in Greece.
Take it regardless of prior experience in religious studies.
Take it. Professor Luijendijk is amazing

Take this class if Professor Luijendijk is teaching it. This class will help you understand some basic arguments and flaws within Pauline scholarship in the past. Moreover, Professor Luijendijk is extremely loving and will help make you a better student--she has truly enriched my time at Princeton.
The experience of a lifetime - take it.
The scope of the course goes far beyond just Apostle Paul. Take only if you're interested in the history and the culture of late antiquity.
prereqs: Previous work in either Religion, Classics, Art and Archaeology, or ancient History..
descrip: In this seminar we will: 1) study the New Testament letters of the apostle Paul in their first-century context and their earliest interpretations; and 2) explore recent trends in Pauline scholarship, including the New Perspective. We will pay special attention to archaeological finds from the Pauline cities, which help us understand better the cultural, political, and religious milieu in which the letters were received and read. Over Fall break (October 23- November 2) the class will travel to Greece and visit the archaeological sites of the cities with early Christ-communities and other important or relevant sites.

title: Topics in Theory & Practice (Half-Term) - Peopling Critical Theory
descrip: This seminar explores how contemporary anthropologists study, think, and write about power, agency, and the nature of social change, and probe the various theoretical frameworks that inform their work. We will engage scholars who mine ethnography as a mode of expression through multiple media and for diverse publics. Through which means can we illuminate both political-economic and personal realities-in-flux, and how can we bring this plasticity and unfinishedness into our storytelling? How does ethnography challenge present-day regimes of veridiction and how can the lives of our subjects become alternative figures of thought and critique?

title: Colonial Latin America to 1810
reviews: Attend all the lectures and do all the reading. Falling behind even a tiny bit would make it hard to get a grasp of the material, as the course packs a lot into its 12 weeks.
Awesome professor!! Prof Candiani is amazing, and so fun, and she makes class interesting- she makes you laugh. Definitely would recommend trying to get into the professor's precept!

Be prepared to rethink what you thought you knew about Latin America. Don't be afraid to get to know Professor Candiani. She's intimidating and will call you out on bs but will challenge you to think differently and critically and is actually very nice.
Don't be afraid to challenge your assumptions.
Great class.
Take it - if Vera's teaching it!

The course is fast-paced, so make sure to keep up and attend all lectures. Prof. Candiani is a great lecturer and you'll learn a ton. If you're at all interested in Latin America, this is a necessary course to take!
The info can be hard to follow but this is a great pre-modern or non western course and she's such a cool professor that it's a really enjoyable class

This class is a little tough and you do have to work at it in going to lecture and doing the readings but it is also very rewarding and you learn a lot. Professor Candiani is amazing and really knows her material and is passionate about it so if you have any interest in history or Latin America I highly recommend this class.

You will almost never be bored with Professor Candiani in the classroom. She's an energetic professor with a lot of personality. She goes pretty fast but gives out helpful lecture notes. The material can be a bit dry, but it was also sometimes really fascinating. This is a great way to build some foundational knowledge if you're interested in Latin America.

take it if you are interested in the time period and gaining a greater understanding of latin america that you might not necessarily see in the mainstream media. also have an open mind and be prepared to question your own ways of thinking about latin america's present (one of the best parts of history in my opinion). the class focuses a lot on material, political and economic history which is prof candiani's area of interest and was a little challenging for me at first, but it is an important part of history and i feel like i am now more comfortable applying those lens to any historical study i do.
take it, be prepared for an amazingly unorthodox professor (if with Candiani)
prereqs: P/D/F option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: This course begins with the origins and consolidation of the Aztec, Inca and Iberian polities and ends with the severance of colonial ties. It combines an overview of the political economy of the region over three centuries with a study of how social groups interacted among themselves and with imperial rule over time through accommodation and conflict. We pay special attention to comparisons and contrasts -- centers and frontiers of settlement, urban and rural life, indigenous and African populations, religion and transgression, Portuguese and Spanish models of rule -- and to long-term processes and implications of environmental change.

title: Econometrics
reviews: Do not take this course with Prof. Evdokimov if you can avoid it. It was poorly taught, and the problem sets were extremely long and tedious. The only way I got through this course successfully was by relying on the textbook and help from the TAs during precept and office hours.
Do the problem sets and start them ahead of time.
Don't bother going to lectures. Not helpful and incredibly boring.
Don't unless departmental.
Dont take it if you dont have to

Even if you're interested in econometrics, it will be difficult to get much out of lectures. Go to office hours and find a preceptor who explains material in a way that you understand because going to lecture often feels likes sitting in a room for an hour and half doing nothing.
Get a study group.
Go to office hours.

I would tell other students that they need to be the most engaged in their classes. Understanding the material in precept equates to a deeper understanding of that presented in lecture, whether you attended them or not.
If you're an econ major, you have to take it. It's not that bad, very necessary to know for any and all research.
If your taking this course you probably dont really have a choice.
Interesting material but don't take it with Evdokimov I've heard the other guy is way better.
It's tough
It's very dry, don't take it unless you need to

Material was great but lectures got boring towards the end AND IT WAS BECAUSE Evdokimov stopped doing math on the blackboard and the lecture devolved into him just reading off the lecture slides. The lecture would've been more interesting if we had incentives to pay attention (such as math on the blackboard like at the beginning of the semester).
Not as bad as people say. The problem sets are actually interesting. Mark and Sharon are great preceptors if you can get them - makes the course much more enjoyable. Lecture is a waste of time.
Not the most interesting class, but if you go to lecture and do the readings you can learn a lot.
Only take if required.
Pretty easy. Gives you a good introduction to STATA stuff which is useful for JP work. Try to take it sophomore rather than junior year.
Read the textbook for a better understanding of the concepts.
Some interesting things. Definitely learn practical technical skills.
Study hard, go to office hours.
Take it if you have to for Econ. It's all about how to run regressions and each chapters introduces more and more complex regression models.
Take it if you need to or if you have a strong interest in regression models...
The lectures arent great. Precepts matter way more.

The material is interesting and very useful for understanding econometrics-based research (which is A LOT of research) and for doing independent work. But the lectures are SO boring. Most people didn't attend and few who did paid attention.
Useful class
Very useful course for the JP. A necessary evil for economics majors, but definitely helpful for academic research and understanding regression analysis (also great for learning STATA!)
Well it's a departmental, so you're only going to take this if you're doing Econ.
Won't be a fun class, but it has to be done. Interesting but not exciting material.
You have to take it, so just work hard.
You have to take this course, so good luck
You probably have to take it... Not that hard, definitely take over 312.
n/a
sda
take it only if you have to
take it only if you have to. office hours are very helpful
prereqs: ECO 202 (or ORF 245) and MAT 103.
descrip: Develop facility with basic econometric methods and the ability to apply them to actual problems and understand their application in other substantive course work in economics.

title: Classical Sociological Theory
descrip: The development of sociological theory through the early 20th Century with an emphasis on the problem of social order. Course begins with an introduction to the Enlightenment, followed by critical authors of the first half of the 19th Century (Hegel, Clausewitz, and Tocqueville). The central part of the course focuses on Marx and Weber with some attention to Mill, Durkheim, and Simmel. We conclude with consideration of some work in the early part of the past century (Freud, Elias, Frankfurt School).

title: Sociological Research Methods
reviews: A great way to fulfill a QR or stats requirement
Engage with this course especially if you're considering doing statistical analysis for your JP or thesis!  It's really helpful.

For a statistics course, its very approachable for people with no background in the material (i.e. History majors).  For Sociology majors, it's annoying but could be helpful if you need to use statistics for your independent work.

Go to all the lectures and precepts, and make sure you understand everything on a conceptual level before you try to do the homework.  I recommend Statistics for Dummies if you're a slow reader like me.
Got to office hours. Check homework with other students and/or your preceptor to make sure you understand concepts.
Great course, Professor Lawrence is awesome and really cared about the students.
I doubt you'll find a better stats course on campus. Matt's awesome. Take it!

I took this course because I needed a statistics course and this one had the best reviews. Prof Lawrence is always willing to help. Best advice I can give is to work on the problem sets and homework assignments ahead of time. The smallest mistake can cost you hours the night before an assignment is due!
I was terrified of taking statistics, but Matt made it incredible approachable. If you can, take it (or any other class) with him.
I would recommend going to office hours whenever possible.
I would recommend the course if someone needs a QR or is interested in SOC. It's definitely an easier QR class for AB students if they have stat or computer science experience.

If Prof Lawrence is teaching it, definitely take the course! He's a pretty great guy, and you learn the basic stats you need to learn without having it be too rigorous. I recommend for the EEB stats requirement.
If you are a SOC major, take this to fulfill your statistics requirement. Professor Lawrence makes it worthwhile.
It is easy to fall behind in this course.  Go to precepts so that you can understand both the course material and keep up with R!
It's a good, easy QR and doesn't require too much work.
Not overwhelming, solid work.
Precepts are helpful- attend them! If you are struggling with R, it is always best to ask for help instead of trying to figure it out on your own- much more efficient!
Slow paced, but also not for those who don't like stats.
Take it if you need a stats course for anything!
Take it if you need to take a Stats class.
Take it! As long as you put in effort, you will succeed. Also, don't be afraid to reach out to Matt when stuck. He loves to help people!
Take the problem sets seriously and seek help while doing them.
Take this course!  Even for non Soc majors looking for a QR, this is a great choice if Matt is the professor!
This is a great introductory stats course.
Totally take it!
Use Tom Short's R Reference Card. Go to lectures. Go to precepts. Find a study buddy or someone in case you need help understanding R.
Well structured class.  If you've coded before you'll find it pretty easy.  Lectures aren't crucial - I only went to the first one.
Yes take it. Pretty good class despite being a distribution requirement.
You do not need the book

i struggled! i did not think there was enough good clear guidance for non-math people, especially in teaching what coding is and how to do it, on a very basic level. i found it easy to get lost and hard to figure things out. i did like matt and cheng though, and the material was occasionally interesting
it's a great stats course for any social science major. professor lawrence is great and the homework and problem sets are really manageable.
this course is great. take it!
descrip: Most research in sociology is quantitative, and it is important for students at a minimum to be able to critically evaluate published quantitative research. Ideally, students should also be able to conduct empirical research involving statistical methods. This course provides the foundation for both goals. The course focuses specifically on how to determine, apply, and interpret statistical methods appropriate for answering a sociological research question given a particular set of data. Basic probability theory is introduced as a building block of statistical reasoning, and a variety of commonly-used statistical tests are developed.

title: Taboo and Transgression
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Seminar. Types of Ideology and Literary Form - Pornography, Gender and the Rise of the Novel in Europe
reviews: Take this class if you are interested in 18th century literature. Also reading about a lot of sexual content
descrip: Open to graduate and undergraduate students interested in understanding the origins of the modern novel, this seminar examines the profound historical, theoretical and formal connections between the development of pornography as a distinct category of representation and the development of the novel as a literary genre during the Enlightenment. We will also explore the continuing resonances of those connections today. Readings in current criticism, history and theory of the novel and pornography will accompany primary readings.

title: Fixed Income: Models and Applications
prereqs: ECO 362 or FIN 501, ECO 465 (concurrent enrollment is acceptable) Multivariate Calculus, Introduction Probability/Statistics.
descrip: This course will deal with no-arbitrage models of contracts based on interest rates including bonds, forward and future contracts, swaps, options and other derivatives. We will develop the theory of arbitrage-free pricing of financial assets in discrete and continuous time, as well as many special models that can be used to price and hedge fixed income securities.

title: Environmental Change, Poverty, and Conflict
reviews: Extraordinary learning opportunity and professor van der Vink is phenomenal. But overwhelming workload every single week - it was more time-consuming than my JP...
Frustrating and time-consuming. You'll learn a fair bit, but at a large cost in terms of time and energy. It's difficult to say if it's worth it - it was for some in the class, and not for others.

I'm not sure if Professor van der Vink is teaching this course anymore, but just in case I'll write my advice. He will challenge you and push you to work very hard, but in the end the class is worth it. You will definitely learn a lot about research methods and about data visualization, representation and analysis. If you are interested in learning how to manipulate a lot of data and visualize it through GIS, I would recommend taking the course. Also, they really aren't kidding about the amount of time this course takes.
Only take this course if you are willing to devote a lot of time. You cannot hand in sloppy work or just slide by in this class.
Take this course only if you have the time and interest and patience.
The course is a lot of work, and sometimes pretty tedious.  Worth taking, but only if you can put the time in and really want a research-based course.
descrip: We will evaluate the environmental, political, social, and economic impacts of climate change on development, poverty-reduction, civil violence, and conflict. Students work in teams integrating climate prediction models with environmental, social, and economic parameters to identify fragile populations that are becoming increasingly at risk due to climate change. Class results submitted for publication and presented to appropriate policy-makers and/or business leaders.

title: Social Psychology
reviews: A solid, fairly easy intro psych course. Good for non-psych majors. Very easy to do well as long as you study lecture material. Reading is essentially option; textbook is worthless - don't even buy it.
Attend all lectures, textbook isn't really needed/ used.
Be prepared to study efficiently and independently; form good study habits from day one
Boring

Definitely take this class. Awesome and engaging class for a SA credit. Not too much work and excellent reading. Materials from lecture definitely has a far reaching impact. You will definitely develop a new outlook of social interactions.

Definitely take this course with Professor Shelton. She's a great lecturer and the material is super interesting. Make sure you're in a good precept, though, or else it'll just be painful to go every week.
Do the readings, learn the first half of the course and you will be fine.
Don't take it.
Even if you're not doing anything in psych, this is a class relevant to life
Fascinating materials and the course does not have too much work to it!
Go to all the lectures. Exams are easy.
Go to lecture
Go to lecture! they are really interesting. The tests are kinda hard, so not necessarily an easy class.
Good, general knowledge to have. These are topics that you can apply to everyday life and your studies. A good SA, too.
Great class! Prof. Shelton is a great lecturer, and the workload is really light.
Have fun, and go to lecture.
I don't recommend or recommend against this course. If you find the social psychology to be interesting, then take it. If not, don't
I enjoyed the course, would recommend if people are interested in psychology.

I highly recommend taking this course. Professor Shelton is amazing, and you will never be bored during lecture. This is a CBLI class, so you get to do a semester-long community service project. It is an social psychology is a fascinating topic.
I recommend this course. It is interesting and you will learn a lot about social psychology, which can be very relevant to real life. Professor Shelton is an engaging lecturer.
I think this year's iteration of the course had a harder midterm than other years but the project was pretty cool and did not take too much time. It is a good PDF course.
I would encourage other students to attend all lectures and keep up with the book readings.
I would highly recommend this class. The lectures were great. If you do the readings and go to lecture, the class will be very reasonable.
I would tell them to simply do the readings and go to lectures and they will be fine.
If Master Shelton is teaching the course, take it. It is one of the best taught classes I have had at Princeton, and it was fun, too!
If it is a CBLI course, take it! Such a good project. Course is great psych course and a good intro.
It is a good class to take as a fifth class. It isn't hard to do well in, but is still interesting and fulfilling.
It is more work than you think it is. You will spend a lot of time on you social intervention projects.
It's a good course! Not very 'scientific'; definitely more psychology than neuroscience.
It's a good distribution requirement, make sure to go to lecture!
It's decent if you like the subject.
It's very pertinent to today's world events!

Just go to the lectures! I wouldn't worry about taking notes so much, just listen and jot down a few notes. You get so much out of the lecture by just listening! And if you listen, you can always go back and just remember the lecture from the slides.
Keep up on readings and attend lectures!
Make friends with your preceptor.

Make sure to underline the experiments that she deems important to know because they might show up on the midterm.  But more importantly, learn the vocab instead of focussing on the actual experiments.
Memorize the important concepts and terms form the lecture slides.

Nice survey course of social psych concepts. Very organized, lecture slides provided, interesting material, AND you actually apply the concepts in the final project. Prof Shelton is also really sweet. Good class.
People think this is an easy class, but there are a lot of expectations, so you need to be ready to take on the challenge.
Pretty good class
Really interesting material, engaging lectures, difficult exams.
Shelton is wonderful

TAKE THIS!!!! There are so many random and interesting things that you learn that you will realize are a part of everyday life. It's quite easy, and as long as you GO TO LECTURE, you'll be fine for all assessments and papers.
Take a different course. This isn't worth it.
Take it if you want a somewhat challenging course that is fun and interesting.
Take it!
Take it! Super chill. A lot of fun, too. Professor Shelton is awesome and the material isn't challenging to understand at all.
Take it.
Take it; you'll learn a lot and it's a really fair class.
Take the course!
Take the course! Complete all readings and make connections between the material and your daily interactions for  great experience!

Take this class if you are genuinely interested in the topic. In order to get the most out of the class: do the readings before lecture, take diligent notes during the lecture, and do the precept readings. Then, during lecture when Professor Shelton says something you are already familiar with, that is when the real learning and internalizing of the material happens.
Take this class if you're interested in basic human interactions. A lot of this is intuitive, but interesting to learn nonetheless.
Take this class! It's so interesting! It's a great SA! Professor Shelton is wonderful!
Take this course if it's with Professor Shelton!!! Watch out for the midterm though.
Take this course! It's fun, interesting and the work load is really light.
The class in taught very well, but the material is intuitive and not especially engaging.
The concepts are not too hard to understand and they help you understand the way you think and others think better. I would recommend that you take this course.

The course is an excellent survey of social psychology - the lectures and precepts are very organized and present captivating subjects. It's helpful to attend all lectures and stay on top of the social intervention assignments.

The course is extremely reasonable, not too much of a time commitment, and enjoyable. Though much of the material seems like common sense in hindsight, it is worth taking and fun to apply to your life.
The exams are based on the lectures, textbook, and precept readings so it is important to study all of them thoroughly for the exams.
The midterm was very difficult, but everything else was very straightforward and fair.

This class actually has a lot of cool topics that you get to explore via fun, low-commitment reading and precept exercises. The midterm determines a sizable portion of your final grade, so make sure to study for it! As a pre-med, I would recommend taking dev psych or ab psych to better prepare you for the 2015 MCAT, however. Nevertheless, the material in this class is very interesting, and Kaite is a wonderful preceptor.

This class is very enjoyable and relatively chill so long as you stay on top of the readings on a week to week basis and don't have to cram textbook reading before the midterms and finals. Professor Shelton is very sweet.
This class was interesting, well taught, and changed the way I view many aspects of social interaction. I'd recommend it, but would also warn that the material can feel very vague at times.

This is a fairly chill course, but stay on top of the reading! Although exams test mainly lecture material, you'll need the readings to supplement what you've learned. You don't want to be reading hundreds of textbook pages right before an exam. You should be able to do very well if you have a solid grasp of lecture material.
This is a great course and the material is fascinating. Prof. Shelton is a wonderful teacher!  The workload is very manageable and enjoyable to do.

This is a great course that will actually apply to your every day life. It is not a huge work load and it is interesting. The project with community partners is interesting and makes the paper seem actually meaningful. 
If Kyle happens to still be a preceptor, by all means take his precept! He made this class fantastic!
This is an easy course. Take it if you need it for a distribution requirement.

This is an interesting survey class but the workload isn't that light for a PDF class because you have a dean's date paper, presentation, 4 hour study participation requirement, and weekly reading responses.
This is not a difficult course, but it does require effort. The material is somewhat dry, but you will learn how to apply it to real-world situations.
This would be a good PDF. To do well, however, you really need to keep up with the readings and lectures. It was interesting and useful material was covered.
Thought it was an interesting course but it's introductory, so many concepts were covered in a short amount of time. If you want to just get a feel for the many topics, then take the course!
To do well on exams you need to memorize the theories and study names. Reading the textbook is awesome and useful. The paper takes a lot of work but is graded easily.
Try to ask yourself why you are taking the course. Personally, I don't think I gained a lot of thought-provoking insights because most of the concepts feels to common sense.
Unless you are extremely interested in the social psych, don't take it.
Wonderful course. Most exam content comes from lecture, so show up and take good notes. As a non-psych major I found this class extremely interesting and very practical.
Workload is heavier than you think, and expect to put in more effort.
study for the tests from definition to TERM not term to definition!!!
take it if you are looking for an easy class that will also teach you some interesting practical things
take it if you're interested - stay on top of the readings
very interesting material, we see it every day. lectures are engaging, although sometimes get repetitive since they follow the same model.
descrip: The scientific study of social behavior, with an emphasis on social interaction and group influence. Topics covered will include social perception, the formation of attitudes and prejudice, attraction, conformity and obedience, altruism and aggression, and group dynamics.

title: Climate Change and Extreme Weather in the Garden State
reviews: Be flexible.
DrZ is eccentric for sure.. it will be an experience

Express how you're feeling and propose ideas to make the class work better. Dr. Z is very flexible and accommodating. Take advantage of the fact that you're working on a real, helpful project that will benefit people's lives.
It is a good course, and a good way to engage in the topics outside the classroom.

It's great! It was engaging and I think I learned a lot but the workload was completely manageable. Only thing is that it's a pretty disorganized class. This could just be because it's the first time the class is being offered.
Take this course!  The professor was sometimes disorganized, but the material was interesting, the workload was not bad, and the community project made the work we were doing feel valuable.
descrip: Hurricanes, intense rainstorms, and floods are becoming more common, along with frequent intense heat waves. Have you ever wondered whether the enormous scale and damage from Hurricane Sandy had anything to do with climate change? This course will examine the potential link between climate change and extreme weather, the interdependency of natural and built environments, and urgent need for sustainable management. Lectures, interactive exercises and projects blend science, policy and social issues. Real-world efforts include trips to the NJ shore to study impacts of Hurricane Sandy, active recovery endeavors and ways to prevent future losses.

title: Topics in Arithmetic Geometry - Rational Points on Curves
descrip: This course covers current topics in Arithmetic Geometry. For Fall 2013, we will cover some classical results about rational points on curves over number fields, including the Hasse principle on curves of genus 0, the Morell-Weil theorem on elliptic curves, and the Faltings' theorem on genus greater than 1. If time permits, we will discuss some recent results (and attempts) on the BSD and ABC conjectures.

title: Ethnographic Methods
reviews: Carol Stack was only here for the semester, that said, if you are interested in ethnography this seems like a must take.
Carol was a visiting professor, but she honestly made this class so amazing. Take this class!
Definitely take this course!  Professor Stack is incredible smart and funny but most importantly she really cares about teaching each student as much as she can.
Professor Stack is a great teacher and cares very much about her students and the work that she does. I really liked the way she approached Ethnography and would highly recommend her class.
Take this!
descrip: This course attempts to introduce students to the ethnographic field methods approach and the essence of "practice" by examining and constructing field notes and analyzing the data discovered in the field. The primary emphasis will be on locating participant observation techniques and writing. Throughout the course the instructor will engage the students using lectures and group discussions to talk about doing and writing ethnography and issuesof social responsibility.

title: Policy Research Seminar
reviews: ABSOLUTELY take this class. Professor Armstrong is engaging, supportive, and a wonderful mentor. Her seminars are interesting and lively, and the material is incredibly relevant.
Avoid it if you can. It was long, and late at night, and not engaging.
Be prepared to complete a lot of work but also learn a lot!
Definitely try to take a class with Prof Mody.  He is great.
Definitely would recommend this particular research seminar to anyone interested in health. Maternal and child health in the US is relevant to everyone, regardless of gender.
Do the reading, expect to be challenged on your opinions, but most of all, enjoy it.
Do the readings and keep up with research
Don't put off your draft. Take the class seriously. Choose a good prof (Keohane was one of the best I've had at Princeton).
For WWS juniors, I think the Maternal and Child Health seminar was very interesting and if you could see yourself writing a JP on a topic that falls under that umbrella, definitely take the course.
I hated the quant lab
I would recommend this course if you are interested in economic history with a little bit of speculation about the future thrown in.
If you would like an excellent, excellent JP mentor, I believe Prof. Keohane is truly one of the best.
It's a lot of work, but it's worth it. Professor Mody is really involved and cares about your JP a lot.
Keep up with your JP work!
Necessary
Need to take for WWS...

Professor Boix is more than just a seminar professor and Junior Paper advisor. Get to know him, ask him to lunch, and learn more about his role in foreign affairs. He's one of my favorite professors on campus. 

Don't hesitate to reach out for help with your general statistical questions. Amanda is there to help.

Quantitative research is really really interesting but you have to put up with the awful quantitative lab which seemed like way more work than the qualitative lab and almost made it seem unfair that both are graded equally.
Start your JP early and spread the work out over the semester.
Start your JP early.
Take a class with Armstrong she is fantastic but a pretty hard grader. Do qualitative methods lab if you don't want a lot of stress- very chill and Dov is great!
Take a course with Robert Keohane if you have the chance. Also try to get into any class that Dov is assisting with!
Take a seminar on a topic that you are interested in.

Take anything with Professor Keohane (!!!!) and make sure not to underestimate the time for research labs. Especially with Advanced Quantitative - definitely take it if you want a Stats refresher and want to be able to interpret data!
Take it with Professor Canes-Wrone. You'll have a great time and be first in line to have private meetings with important politicians and policy-makers as well.
Take it. This was my favorite class I have taken at Princeton.
Taking a policy seminar was a good experience. It helped me understand the interaction between policy and the topic of our course.

This is an awesome course. Take it if you're interested in economic development. Professor Mody is really intense-- he might intimidate you at first, but don't worry. He's a great professor. He pushes everyone so that they can do their best.
Well, you have to take it. Professor Boix is pretty cool. Try and learn some stats.
YES! Take this course it's great.

Yes, if you are up for an intense challenge. Prof Mody will definitely make you a better person. It gets rough sometimes, but it's definitely worth it and you'll come out with a great JP and lots of life lessons learned.
You have to take it, so it doesn't really matter. The topic was interesting, but Professor Milner wasn't very helpful.
You have to take it, so really cross your fingers for a topic you enjoy and a professor you find engaging. I had Prof. Meunier and she was great.
descrip: The junior policy research seminar serves to introduce departmental majors to the tools, methods, and interpretations employed in policy research and writing. Students may choose from a range of topics.

title: Principles of Quantum Engineering
reviews: Be prepared for a challenge.  There's a lot of math and you'll be expected to have a thorough understanding of calculus and some understanding of differential equations.  Go to office hours.  Find people to work with.  You'll learn a lot.
Be ready for math
Go to office hours whenever possible for help on the psets
prereqs: (PHY 103 or PHY 105) and (PHY 104 or PHY 106). Knowledge of linear algebra and differential equations helpful..
descrip: This course is designed to provide an understanding of the basic principles underlying quantum mechanics, with an eye toward applications in solid-state and nanophotonic devices. Fundamental concepts associated with quantum and optical waves will be discussed, including issues of behavior localization, propagation and interference of waves in various settings. These will be introduced in the context of exciting developments/results at the frontiers of research! Students will leave the course with a broad and solid foundation to take more specific courses for solid-state photonics and quantum electronics. (e.g. ELE 441, 442, 453).

title: Urbanism and Urban Policy
reviews: Don't get tied up in the short answers of the midterm. Be ultra-specific.
Easy and interesting. Don't worry about the readings because lecture reteaches all the readings. Lecture is dull.
Ehhh I wouldn't take it.  Massey isn't as great as everyone says he is.
I recommend focusing on the lectures because they successfully summarize much of what one is supposed to glean from the readings.
I would advise them to look over the lecture slides as to guide their reading for the week.
Keep up with the readings!
N/A
Read material on time so you can engage in precepts properly
Really interesting class and a must-take if you're at all interested in urban studies.

Take it if you're super interested in urban studies. I took it with Massey, and we talked about his book for like 4 weeks meaning that we had to read a book a week for the rest which was kind of a lot. Then you have a 15-20 page paper for deans date and a final, so it's not some easy intro course with no work. Some of the stuff is pretty interesting though

Take this course if you are considering WWS, Politics, Sociology, or have an interest in urban studies. There were individuals in the course who were engineering students who wanted to work in urban development and took the course. If you think you would be interested, definitely take this course. It covers  the evolution of mankind from hunters and gathers to post-industrial urbanites. There are concepts of science, physiology, sociology, politics, and history infused in the course.
Take this course if you're interested in urban policy issues like gentrification, suburbanization, and globalization.

The subject is interesting, but unless the course is reorganized, it's too weird and  to be worthwhile. Maybe still worthwhile if you're really interested in the material, cause I will remember some of it but unless you're really excited about it you might be better served reading the books on your own.

There is a lot of reading so practice SKIMMING--definitely need it for this class. Also, review lecture slides for the midterm and final--they are immensely useful since there's a lot of information and it can be hard to type all at once since Professor Massey speaks quickly; if there are certain points you missed in your notes, the lecture slides are a great way to fill in gaps and review the details you might have missed
There's a lot of reading!

This class turned me off of an Urban Studies certificate. I was mistaken to think it would be about policy. Most of the material was very abstract. The course was very poorly taught and unorganized. I recommend against taking it.
descrip: Introduces students to social scientific thinking on cities and urbanism and then builds on this base to consider and evaluate various approaches to urban policy.

title: Abnormal Psychology
reviews: Always try to keep up with the reading and take thorough notes on your reading.
Attend all of the precepts and read the assigned textbook readings after lectures.

Fun, interesting! Decent PDF.

Honestly I didn't have time to put into the course. I attended maybe 3 lectures in total and I knew I could pass if I P/D/Fed and read the textbook before the exams. I just took it for an SA. Precepts were pretty boring.

I would advise to carefully read the chapters of the textbook.
I would only take this class if you can take it PDF.

I would tell the student that it all makes sense, but a lot of memorization is involved.
It is not too hard to comprehend but the exams and paper will take some time.

Not a huge workload. If you're interested in abnormal psychology and feel as though you would be willing to read the book?perhaps the most efficient way of getting all the material vs. going to lectures?then this is a decent class.

Only take this if you absolutely have to or if you're sure you're going to PDF it. There is a ridiculous amount of reading and the lectures are boring. You have to put in too much work and get very little from it.
Read the textbook every week!
Read up because the exams do not come from lecture.
Read your textbook!
Semi-repetitive structure, but overall an interesting class. I would recommend.
Study only the textbook for exams.
Take Dr. Blackmore's precept!!!!

Take it as a psych major but be prepared for memorization
Take it if you like the material, but the lectures aren't the best.
Take it if you're looking for an easy class.
Take it only if you're interested. If you're gonna PDF, you still have to read, otherwise you'll be hopeless on the exams.
Take it!!
Take it, but pick it up early as it fills up quickly. It's incredibly interesting, even if you're only mildly interested.
Take notes from the textbook, and participate in precept!
Take this class!
Take this course. It is a lot of interesting subject matter with very little out of class work required.
The exam goes into a level of detail you might not expect from how things are presented in lecture. Make sure you read the book.
The exams weren't hard before this year. Depends on the instructor.
The material is interesting, but the way it's taught isn't. Combined with aggravating exams, I'd recommend against taking it.
The topics are interesting and the workload is very light.
Think about the concepts, and not necessarily the details.
This class is not an easy A, as many believe. However, It is possible. Many people ended up PDFing the course, although it was really interesting.
This class is relatively interesting just by nature of its subject matter. Workload wasn't strenuous. I'd recommend if you have a casual interest in psych.
This class is terrible. Avoid at all costs.

This course is boring. It felt like a waste of time for me, and my initial interest in the field quickly faded away. If you are looking for an SA, take econ. If you are looking for psychology, check that neuroscience is not the thing you are actually interested in.
This course was super interesting and has changed the way I view mental health. I really recommend this to anybody, despite the fact that it can be difficult.

This course, for a science-y one, was relatively easy with very little workload. Totally good PDF, but would not take much effort to get an A I would say and if you had the time. I would take it for the grade.
This is a good course to take as a distribution requirement.

This is a very good course, especially for non-majors (like myself) who have no prior background in psychology. It's a lot of memorization, but the material is very interesting. If you are fascinated by the boundaries of human behavior, this is a good course to take.
This is a very interesting course.  Spokas lectures slowly and deliberately; make sure to write down everything she says.  Read the textbook before the tests.

Unless you are PDFing it READ EVERYTHING. The exams had a lot of obscure facts that you needed to memorize from the textbook.

While the material could be interesting, the way in which it was presented was not. The exams were unfair and unless you like having no idea how you are going to do in the class until you receive your final grade, choose another class.
decent class, not too bad to pdf
excellent
keep updated on readings and make outlines, attendance at lectures aren't really necessary to do well in the class. exams test very finnicky details from the book
stay on top of the readings bc it will make writing the final paper easier. read the textbook for exams -- material will definitely be on the exam from those readings!
take if you must. otherwise, there are more interesting classes and better uses of your time.
take this class!!!!!
try to stick through it despite the lectures
