title: Advanced Spanish
reviews:
1.) Prepare for homework every day.
2.) Attend the language tables or try to find a friend who speaks spanish and practice!
3.) Don't be afraid to talk in class-just say what you think even if you don't know a word!

Definitely get involved in class discussions because it really improves your speaking and comprehension, as well as gives you a better class participation grade; do the homework and grammar exercises; and practice whenever you get the chance.
Definitely take this class, the material is interesting and Liz is a great teacher!
Do all the grammar exercises when they're assigned.
Do the homework. It's much easier than trying to BS the classes.
Do your homework!
Don't be afraid to ask for help; better sooner than later, too.
Enjoy it.
Find extra grammar exercises online to do on your own
Great and enjoyable. Less emphasis on formal learning. If you are someone who likes to learn language while engaging yourself with social issues in the spanish communities, this is a great course.
Great course! Take it, especially with Senora Monserrat Borres. She is awesome!
Have fun! Engage!
I loved it so much! I came to class excited because I got a great professor and the funniest class mates. My knowledge of Spanish grammar also improved a great amount.

I would advise students to ask questions in class about new grammar topics because they tend to come up again later. Any student who wants to significantly improve their grammar and incorporate more complex grammar into their writing would benefit from this course.
If you have to take this class, get this professor. All the work is standardized but the professor has so much control in class and makes the difference of the world.
If you were placed in 108 and are unsure if you can handle it or haven't taken Spanish for a year, you will probably be fine. It will require some work, but the classes can be fun.
It's a good class and not bad if you need to fulfill a requirement.

It's the next step in learning Spanish.  You're not going to come out of it fluent, but it's not a waste of time, and if you have Monse it's really helpful.  Also don't take it at 9am because that's rough and it made me dread a class I think I otherwise would've loved.
Keep up with the daily readings and assignments, because they are covered a lot in the midterm.
Keeping up-to-date on grammatical material is beneficial.
Liz is a great teacher. This course helped me improve my grammar and speaking skills and inspired me to pursue a certificate in Spanish.
Make sure you give yourself time out of class to do the homework, especially the grammar, because it's crucial to do well on the exams. Go to the teacher if you need help!
Participate in class as much as you can.
Participate zealously in class, and seek appointments for working on assignments.
Practice the language!

Profesora Bores is excellent! The class is extremely well organized and she makes it fun, but also extremely helpful. I hadn't taken Spanish the year prior to taking this course, so I was worried that it would be too difficult despite placing into it, yet I was very pleased with the instruction and assignments. Assignments are challenging and she expects quality work of course, but  grading is fair.

SPA 108 is a really great course, and you learn much more about culture and the small nuances in language. I think it helps a lot, and my professor was wonderful at not only teaching, but also helping us through any difficulties. I don't believe she'll be teaching next year, but I recommend this class all the same!
Stay engaged in the course and you will enjoy it and do well in it.

Take it! Even though for some of you it is required, SPA 108 will help you improve a lot. Monserrat is an amazing professor, and she really nice too, so go to her office hours as much as possible. The class is mainly focused on reading and writing, though there will be oral examinations/presentations, so remember to brush up on your speaking ability in your free time.
Take it.

Take this class with Professor Hochberg. She is an incredible teacher and will help you improve your language skills. Some of the assignments may be busy-work, but all in all, this class is very interesting and attempts to avoid being solely focused on grammar.
Take this course if you are interested in advancing your Spanish but be prepared for a lot of work

The only advice I could think of is to take the time to do the grammar exercises. You'll get as much of this course as you put in. Also, do not hesitate to talk to Monserrat, she is really sweet and ready to help about anything.

This class considerably improved my Spanish speaking, listening, and grammar. It could be a little dull for students who only want to take this for their language requirement. However, if you're actually interested in the language, it is a pretty low-stress and helpful class!

This course work is manageable and if you go to class, hand in all of the grammar assignments, and participate it is pretty straightforward. The short essays and oral presentations were very manageable. I would recommend this course.
This is a great class. I would highly recommend it to anyone that is interested in Spanish. You will learn a lot and your writing will improve.
Work hard
Would recommend.
prereqs: SPA 105 or satisfactory score on the Department's Spanish language placement test..
descrip: An advanced course that consolidates comprehension of oral and written Spanish and develops fluency and precision in speaking and writing. The course aims to broaden vocabulary and improve grammatical accuracy while providing opportunities to engage in oral and written communication. Through the interpretation and analysis of texts, images, film, paintings and songs, students will explore the Spanish speaking cultural identity in Los Angeles and Mexico City.

title: Ethics and Public Policy
reviews: A helpful course for anyone interested in the classic political theories and current controversial political issues
Anyone interest in Ethics and public policy should take this course. Makes you reconsider assumptions you make immediately about whats right and wrong in the context of other considerations.

As much as it might be a pain if you end up with the preceptor I got because of bad luck, I would recommend that you go to precept because you are graded for participation in them. Overall though, I would really recommend taking this class because it gets a distribution and prereq for WWS out of the way along with the chance to have 2x50mintues of awesome lecturing a week.
Awesome class, great combination of topics, not too much work.

Be sure you know what you're signing up for: know that the "ethics" in the title of the class is underemphasized -- though we discuss ethical dilemmas, we don't really explore them in absolutist/consequentialist terms after the first few weeks. This course is helpful if you're trying to learn the basics of political theory, though I think if you're more theory-oriented, you should definitely take a class in the politics department as opposed to the WWS.

Decent course to PDF as a fifth class. Very few actual assignments (2 papers, a midterm, and a final). The midterm and final are jokes, so it's really only the papers. You don't really need to keep up with the readings either (although you should if you want to get something out of the course).

Definitely go to lecture and take detailed notes.  The exams are very straightforward while the papers will require a good amount of time to formulate a solid, convincing argument.  Try seeing if you can write a draft of the paper and get feedback from your preceptor before turning it in.
Definitely take it, Shaw is fantastic and the papers are fun to write.
Definitely take it, so relevant and interesting and Professor Shaw is a great lecturer.
Definitely take it. Fantastic lectures and readings.
Definitely take this course if you have any interest in policy - it gives a whole new perspective on the way that we choose policy. Professor Shaw is great.
Definitely take this course with Keith Shaw. He is an amazing professor, the concepts covered are interesting and relevant to everyday life and the work load is completely manageable.
Definitely take! Keith Shaw was amazing!!
Do the readings
Do the readings.
Do the readings.  Not only will it help you do well in the course, but it will enhance your understanding of real-life current events.  Make sure to participate frequently in precept!
Go to lecture with Keith. He makes all the concepts much easier to understand.
I loved it very much and think you should take it too!

I loved this course, Keith Shaw is a great and engaging lecturer and the course itself really wasn't a ton of work. If you're looking for an EM or just an interesting 4th or 5th class, I highly recommend it.
I would advise against this class if you're taking it out of general interest. It's a lot of work and the grading is pretty strict

I would recommend taking this class, very interesting material and good survey of political thought. However, I would definitely not recommend it to freshmen. The papers could be difficult for freshmen to do well on, especially without writing sem as Shaw was the previous director at the writing center and the topics could get complex.

If Prof. Shaw is teaching, take the course. His lectures are extremely engaging and you'll learn a lot about how to interpret and think through contemporary ethical issues (think Ferguson, climate change legislation, etc).

If the course description sounds interesting to you, take it! Professor Shaw is a funny, engaging, knowledgable lecturer and is very honest about what he expects. The papers are challenging, but the exams are easy if you pay attention in class and review the material.
Interesting lectures, but it is hard to follow the lectures.
It is an interesting course and valuable if you are considering a major in politics or Woody Woo. It clarifies a lot of problems/event we hear about in the media and Washington.
It's a good class, but if you're a non-major, watch out for the curve.  It's a WWS required course, so the curve is very tough for a non-major.  PDF-ing is fine though.
It's a great class that's very informative.
Keep up with the material and participate in precept and you will get a lot out of it! Also write your papers on topics you are actually interested in.
Make sure to schedule appointments with your preceptor before handing in assignments.
Read the reading assignments actively and work on the essays.
Really good course regardless of major - interesting readings, great precept discussions!

Stay on top of the readings! Make sure to continually apply the philosophies learned in lecture to the issues discussed during the second half of the semester. Also learn to distinguish between Absolutist and Consequentialist decision-making. While the papers were a bit more complicated and difficult, the midterm and final exams were pretty straight-forward, given that the student has attended lectures and read the readings.
Sure
Take it :) Best HA
Take it with Shaw - he's an awesome lecturer.

Take it! Professor Shaw is awesome, and I can honestly say that this course taught me a new way of thinking/helped me learn how to approach ethical dilemmas. The reading load is very light (rare for WWS) and exams are a breeze if you go to lecture.
Take it.
Take it; it's very intriguing
Take notes on the readings!
Take this class!
Take this course! The material is approachable and applicable, Keith Shaw's lectures are excellent, the workload isn't too bad, and overall, the course is really stimulating for any major.
This course was more focused on political theory than ethics.

This is a decent introductory ethics class.  I would recommend taking another one, not because this one was bad, but because others are better (intro to moral and practical ethics come to mind).  They have more philosophical rigor (which in my view is the important thing to take away from an ethics class in terms of a skill) than this one, while still having teh applied ethics section needed for public policy.
dont get simon
take this!!!
descrip: The course examines major moral controversies in public life and differing conceptions of justice and the common good. It seeks to help students develop the skills required for thinking and writing about the ethical considerations that ought to shape public institutions, guide public authorities, and inform the public's judgments. The course will focus on issues particularly challenging for advanced, pluralist democracies such as the USA, such as terrorism and torture, vice crimes and paternalistic legislation, taxes and income inequality, surveillance and privacy, climate change, and the place, if any, of religious argument in politics

title: Modern French Fiction
reviews: Take it!
Take it! It's chill and insightful!

This course requires a moderate-heavy amount of work. Luckily, it's all interesting, stimulating and rewarding. Prof. Trezise is an excellent guide through the complexities of French Fiction -- take it!
prereqs: One 200-level French literature course.
descrip: French fiction from 1850 to the present in translation.

title: Behind the Scenes: Inside the Princeton University Art Museum
descrip: Please see website

title: Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS): Non-credit
reviews: Before taking this course research the projects that are currently being worked on in class, only take this if you have a genuine interest in the projects or have a viable project proposal of your own. If this class is for you and can be very rewarding.
Take it if you like project-based learning!
You should take this
prereqs: Juniors only (except for sophomores who have completed EGR 251)..
descrip: In the Engineering Projects in Community Service (EPICS) program, students earn academic credit for their participation in multidisciplinary design teams that solve technology-based problems for local not-for-profit organizations. The teams are: multidisciplinary--drawing students from across engineering and around the university; vertically-integrated--maintaining a mix of sophomores through seniors each semester; and long-term--each student may participate in a project for up to six semesters. The continuity, technical depth, and disciplinary breadth of these teams enable delivery of projects of significant benefit to the community.

profs.name: Esther Roseli da Costa Azevedo Meyer

title: Anxious Megalopolis: Shanghai's Urban Cultures (1842 - to the present)
reviews: Amazing, once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.

I would highly recommend this class to any student interested in the topic. In spite of possible preconceptions, the class was actually comprised of only two art history students. The seminar included students majoring in mathematics, ORFE, computer science, international relations, politics, economics, anthropology, and psychology. This abundance of backgrounds truly contributed to the diversity of points of view and opinions, and ultimately enriched our discussions.
Take it!
Take it.
Take it. NO other words. The trip is incredible and I LOVED the group of people who were selected for the class.

The trip is really great and makes the class unparalleled in quality, but you must be prepared to do reading. I would recommend those with a strong interest in Asia enroll. Otherwise, it might be hard to catch up.

This class was one of the best classes I took at Princeton. If it is offered again, I would highly encourage you to apply to it. Class discussions are very thought-provoking and interesting. It is led by the students, so you are learning from your peers. The trip is absolutely the best of the course. You learn a lot. Esther and Cary are both great! I highly enjoyed being in this class.

This is a great course. It is really import an tot do the readings so you can contribute to class discussions, even if you just skim them when you have not time. t feels terrible to feel like you have little to say for the entire three hours because you did not do the readings. The discussions in this class are on fire, and if you want to be intellectually stimulated for an entire three hours, it is the perfect class to take.

Though the class focuses on Shanghai, it helped me gain a better understanding of urban spaces in China in general. Class discussions were often good, though the amount of reading was usually overwhelming. However, knowing that we would be in Shanghai beforehand and the knowledge we gained while there, really gave the class a layer of depth not always found in other classes. The trip was excellent, and not too overwhelming in terms of academic time during the week. Seems like it may not be offered again though.
descrip: In the nineteenth century, Shanghai grew to become a bustling port, colonialist beachhead, hub of international commerce in the 30s, and a major testing ground for contemporary architecture today. As a crucial interface between East and West, this city was a place where national and transnational cultures fought and flourished, and stereotypes were forged and discarded. This seminar will cover the emergence of Shanghai's vibrant urban culture as it evolved into the complex megalopolis of today. There will be a trip to Shanghai over fall break funded by the department.

title: Classical Historiography for Chinese and East Asian History, 1000-1900 (Tokyo)
descrip: This 'research seminar' is part of a series of pre-modern classical bibliography courses in Chinese and Japanese studies that are offered in the EAS Department on a regular basis. These offerings address in different years: "Early China" (Martin Kern); and "Late Imperial China/Tokugawa Japan" (Elman). THINK SMALL!!! It is being offered at the University of Tokyo in Fall 2014 for EAS graduate students studying in Tokyo as a part of the exchange.

title: Topics in Development - Global Challenges of Infection, Burden & Control
descrip: An exploration of the biological, public health and global dimensions of infectious disease. The basic features of human-microbe interactions by examining several viral, bacterial and parasitic infections are analyzed.. Emphasis includes biology, burden of illness and domestic and global forces shaping the expanding threat. Control strategies, including chemotherapy, vaccines and environmental changes; and the role of international organizations such as WHO, UNICEF, and GAVI and the major philanthropies, are considered.

title: Linear and Convex Optimization
reviews: For any body that can wait to take the course in the future (without any cost) I would recommend to wait. But for those one (like me) who need to take the course at a specific time, I wouldn't recommend waiting for any cost. So, I am not "Neutral" but I'll choose neutral.
Go for it.
If you have a general interest in learning linear optimization, I would recommend taking this course. However, the homeworks are fairly time-consuming.
If you need to lay some foundation in convex optimization, then this course can prepare you the necessary topics.
Must be comfortable with very mathematical proofs.
Review the midterm exam carefully.
This is a good course to attend as you can learn a lot without a heavy workload.
This is not just a linear optimization course. It covers a lot of interesting topics.
take it, it's useful.
descrip: Topics discussed include: the simplex method and its complexity, degeneracy, duality, the revised simplex method, convex analysis, game theory, network flows, primal-dual interior point methods, first order optimality conditions, Newton's method, KKT conditions, quadratic programming, and convex optimization. A broad spectrum of applications are presented.

title: Microeconomic Analysis (Advanced)
prereqs: A working knowledge of basic calculus and ease with algebraic manipulation are prerequisites of the course..
descrip: This course is an introduction to the use of microeconomics for the analysis of public policy on an advanced level. The emphasis is on both the intuitive and formal logic of economic principles, a deeper perspective on the impacts of typical policy measures, and an introduction to the use of professional microeconomic tools to assess and weigh these policy impacts. One goal is to move students towards the ability to read professional microeconomic literature with appreciation of both its contributions and foibles.

title: Readings in Early Modern Japanese History
descrip: A survey of major issues in the historiography of early modern Japan and Meiji Japan (1600-1890).

title: Advanced Design and Behavior of Steel Structures
reviews: Go to office hours every week and keep up with the material.
Invest in the Steen Construction Manual and good stack of post-it notes.
professor Garlock focuses more on theory than just following the code, don't just mechanically follow the procedure it's important to understand the theory too!
descrip: Advanced topics in the design and analysis of steel structures are covered. These topics include local and global stability, second-order effects of combined bending and axial loads, torsion, and structural design for fire.

title: American Noir
descrip: Please see website

title: Digital Signal Processing
reviews: A solid overview of digital signal processing. Worth taking if you want to brush up on your filter design or signals.
Ask questions, pay attention, and make sure you understand everything in the lecture notes.
Go for it.
Good for students who want a general understanding of a wide variety of topics in DSP, but it isn't a course for someone looking to gain a deeper understanding of the topic.

I found it to be a really good of ELE 201 and an excellent introduction to high level signal processing. It doesn't deal in depth with the mathematical aspects of it but it provides you the a whole lot of DSP techniques that Electrial Engineers are using today and in the past.
Take it! But he's retiring, so I'm not sure who's going to teach it next year.
descrip: The lectures will cover: (1) Basic principles of digital signal processing. (2) Design of digital filters. (3) Fourier analysis and the fast Fourier transform. (4) Roundoff errors in digital signal processing. (5) Applications of digital signal processing.

title: East European Literature and Politics
reviews:
Do the readings, they're wonderful!
And take advantage of office hours.
Everybody who is interested in Eastern Europe, authoritarianism, transition process and the role of literature the society should take this course.
I recommend you take this course if you are interested in geopolitics, politics in literature, or the effect of politics in society.
Keep up with the reading.

TAKE THIS COURSE! Professor Gross teaches this incredibly interesting course by delving into diverse and fascinating sources, as well as by helping  to lead the discussions with compelling recollections and perceptive ideas.
Take it!
Take it! Professor Gross is awesome and it is a very interesting course even if you do not have any background in slavic literature.
Take the time to understand the readings, as long as it may take, or else you'll show up to the seminar discussions "empty-handed."
Take this course if you have an interest in Slavic or Eastern European history, literature or politics. You won't be disappointed.

Take this course!  The literary tradition of East Europe is fascinating, yet tragically under-appreciated, so you owe it to yourself to explore these rewarding texts. Professor Gross is a great teacher and person, and will take the time to talk to you individually should you have any questions about papers, or the material in general.  Really, don't hesitate to take this course!

Take this course! Even if you know nothing about Eastern Europe and have never heard of any of the authors on the reading list, this class will definitely be worth your time. Professor Gross is a reservoir of knowledge on the topic, and she genuinely cares about engaging students' intellectual curiosity. And the reading list is FANTASTIC, so be sure to give yourself time to read the assigned reading every week. Even if you never read any of the authors again after this course (and hopefully you will, they're so interesting!), the experience of reading and discussing them with Professor Gross will be so valuable in itself.

You must do the reading or there is no point in showing up to class. Don't be afraid to disagree with Prof. Gross (who is a wealth of knowledge) if you have evidence to back you up. Speak up and enjoy reading and discussing some of the greatest works of Eastern/Central Europe.
take it if you're interested in Eastern Europe, history and politics
descrip: The seminar will analyze the way totalitarian oppression was represented and resisted in literature of the second part of East-Central European 20th century. We will look through the lens of literature at the main political and historical issues that afflicted Poland, Hungary, Czech Republic, Slovakia, Romania and other countries of the region. We will study texts (essays, memoirs, novels, short stories, plays, and poems) which offered various ways to resist moral and political oppression. The authors will include George Orwell, Franz Kafka (as a precursor), Hannah Arendt, Vaclav Havel, Tadeusz Borowski, Bertolt Brecht, Heda Kovaly.

title: Independent Study I
prereqs: Must fill out Independent Study form signed by Advisor & DGS. Bring signed form to Minmin Fan in E-211..
descrip: Under the direction of a faculty member, each student carries out independent study. Prior to course registration, students must complete a departmental Graduate Independent Study form that describes the work being undertaken, and have the form approved by the supervising faculty member and the Director of Graduate Studies.

title: Mathematical Methods of Engineering Analysis I
reviews: Don't fall behind
It needs some math background.
Not poorly taught, but also not interesting.

Start assignments early, back up all of your assumptions, and show all of your work. A lot of material is covered so try to follow as best as you can. Read the course handbook before class if possible.
Use the notes and other references, as well as collaborating with other students, for the homework!
You have to, so either make the most of it, or struggle
descrip: Methods of mathematical analysis for the solution of problems in physics and engineering. Topics include an introduction to functional analysis, linear analysis & eigenvalue problems for matrices & linear operators, Sturm-Liouville theory, Green's functions for the solution of linear ordinary differential equations and Poisson's equation, and the calculus of variations, and the inverse and implicit function theorems.

title: Living with Animals
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Independent Project I
descrip: Directed study for Master of Engineering students. The topic is proposed by the student and must be approved by the student's research advisor and have received approval from the MAE Graduate Committee.

title: The Colonization of North America
reviews: Definitely take it - Professor Warren is an engaging lecturer and offers a refreshing look at the often oversimplified process of colonization. Exams are very fair, and papers are thought-provoking and enjoyable if you start early. A wonderful history course and valuable for anyone to take, regardless of their major.
Good course if you are interested in American history.Quite a lot of work if you aren't interested in the subject matter.
I think you will find the course really enjoyable if you're interested in American history. Wendy Warren is a phenomenal lecturer!
I would take it
I would tell them to keep up with the readings and definitely make sure to take good notes during lecture since there is no textbook.

Professor Warren is truly great; she knows what she's talking about but is also a really good teacher overall. Her lectures are well-structured and her style is open to a lot of student engagement and commentary. Just know that it's a 0-tech zone, so you'll have to write quickly if you tend to put down a lot on your paper like I do. The readings can be confusing because they are actually original sources from the time period, and not merely textbook passages. This means lots of colonial-era English which can be difficult to get through at times, especially when you have to read 100 to 200 pages of it. But overall, really cool class that will change the way you see colonization for good. Definitely not a bad choice for an HA.
TAKE THIS COURSE. You will fall in love with history.
Take if you need an early American history class because Professor Warren is a great professor.
Take it if interested in seeing the colonization of North America from different perspectives (Native Americans, slaves, etc).

Take this course!! The material is inherently interesting and the area is understudied. Professor Warren is a very thoughtful professor who gives great lectures and really cares about the students in the class.
Take this course-- interesting and engaging!
Take this!!!

The material can be pretty interesting. The readings are okay. The test are VERY fair - might seem intimidating at first, since it is an in-class history midterm/final, but all the questions are lay-ups. I strongly recommend getting Prof. Warren as a preceptor, because she is a very fair grader as well, but you have to be ready to participate in precept and must do all the readings - it is pretty obvious when you don't. Sometimes you can get stuck with the young preceptor who refuses to give a good grade on a paper because well, giving low grades is only power that they have, so they take full advantage of it, so I recommend trying to get in her precept.
There is a lot of reading and the papers are graded harshly. But the exams, midterm specifically, are not that hard, and if you come to class you should be fine.
This is a great course for any student, history major or not. You HAVE to go to lectures though. There is no "official" textbook, so without the lectures you will be lost.

This was a great and interesting course. Professor Warren is engaging and fair and the workload is manageable. This is one of the few Princeton courses where I feel like I have really walked away knowing the material.

Very well taught course, with some interesting additions. Would highly recommend to those new to US history (because it DOES turn into a US history course) and it has some interesting tidbits for those who took APUS. Prof. Warren also adds a philosophical element to the course which can be cool or frustrating depending on what type of historian you are,
prereqs: PDF option is not available for History concentrators..
descrip: In the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries, North America saw the convergence of Native Americans, Africans, and Europeans. This course explores the effects of that historic meeting, telling a story that encompasses both well-known events and people (Plymouth Rock, the Pilgrims, Benjamin Franklin), and lesser known stories (the Yamassee War, King Philip's War, the lives of Olaudah Equiano and Mary Rowlandson). Colonization is a bloody, frightening, and fraught endeavor; by the end of this class, you will understand what was won and what was lost, and by whom, in the struggle to control North America.

title: Introduction to Sociology
reviews: A pretty good SA, but not a walk in the park.
An easy PDF class, but hard to get an actual A.
As long as you go to lecture with an open mind you'll really love this course!
Be sure not to fall behind on the concepts, know them well.
DO THE READINGS!
Definitely stay on top of readings. I did all of the readings on time and it made everything so much easier.
Definitely take it.
Definitely take this course- regardless of what you plan on studying, it is relevant to every field. It brings up issues that are important to explore and Prof Duneir is a great professor!

Do all your readings and try not to fall behind on the readings. Try to apply the concepts learned to your daily lives. Take this class. You will love this class and Professor Duneier. I am taking another course with Professor Duneier next semester!!!!!!
Do the readings and keep notes, useful for midterm and final
Do the readings and talk in precept!
Do the readings every week.
Do the readings, but focus on lecture notes
Do the readings.
Don't bother with the readings until it's time to study for the exam.
Don't get bogged down by the details of the readings, just try to get a sense of the main ideas.
Don't waste time doing some of the readings because they are not all discussed.
Go to lecture
Go to lecture.
Good distribution course especially for those interested in what sociology is about!

I definitely recommend this course.  Duneier is an amazing lecturer, and the course material is interesting and engaging even for a non sociology major like myself who took the course to fill a distribution requirement.
I feel like I haven't learned anything, but I nevertheless enjoyed lectures and reading about various topics. Definitely recommend.
I highly recommend this course for anyone especially if you think you're interested in sociology or psychology. Professor Duneier is great and keeps the class engaging.

I think it is a good class to get a intro to sociology and  get a really good understanding of the way the relationship between people and the deeper meanings of them, and how they evolved from history.

I would advise other students to take this course very seriously and to read all the assigned materials. Failure to do so might result in a student falling behind, and for this class, falling behind may be very detrimental, especially when exams approach.
I would make sure you've really got a genuine interest in the material before taking it. Don't take it just to fulfill the distribution requirement. You're only hurting yourself that way.
I would recommend they do all of the readings and do not feel excessively forced to go to lecture; it is very important to be engaged in precept.
I would strongly recommend this class. The workload is very minimal, the material is very easy and so interesting, and professor Duneier really is the best.
I would tell other students to go to lecture because it really helps understanding the readings.
If you have any interest this would be a great course.
If you like sociology, take it. If you want an interesting SA, look somewhere else.
It is a great course.
It was a really wonderful introduction to sociology. Lectures and guests were interesting and the readings were excellent.
Its a good class! but a lot of reading.
Keep up with the readings!
Make brief outlines of the readings to prepare in advance for exams.
Make study groups! Do practice exams! Try and get into Prof. Duneier's precept because it's awesome.
Make sure to pick out the essential topics in each reading, as there can often be lots of frivolous material. Really focus your studies on lecture notes and then use the readings as examples.
Make sure you have a good preceptor, and actually do the readings.
No reason not to take if you have an interest in SOC
Only take it because it is a prerequisite for other, more interesting soc courses.  If you don't plan on taking other soc courses and are not a soc major then don't take it.
Participate in precept

Pretty chill course. Topics are pretty scattered, so perhaps a higher level soc class might be more interesting and easier to follow.  Try to keep up with the readings, if not, at least go to lecture.
Stay on top of the reading and go to lecture.

Students should really read all of the articles so that the tests are easier for them. Make study groups and get many people to write summaries and the main points of the articles so that you could study for midterms or finals.
TAKE IT. If Mitch is teaching.
Take it even if you're not interested in becoming a soc major. Will help change your outlook on major social issues and make your opinions more relevant
Take it if you want a course with a light work load.
Take it to see if you're interested in the subject, not a great class though
Take it!
Take it! It is thought-provoking and complex, but not too difficult that it is discouraging.

Take it! Prof. Duneier is an amazing lecturer, and the course is a fantastic overview of sociology. Fun, interesting, low courseload. Be careful when it gets to exam time though, you will basically be writing essays--so be familiar with the readings and especially the lectures! Lectures are important--they cover some stuff that are not in the readings. Joel is an amazing preceptor, so if he's still precepting this course, get him if you can.
Take it, do the readings for your own personal learning, attend lectures. Great class.
Take it, it is a good class!
Take it. Great course, much is learned, interesting, necessary for learning about society.
Take the class! Prof. Duneier is one of a kind!
Take the course if looking for a distribution requirement or interested in sociology. Professor Duneier is a great lecturer.
Take this class if you are planning on becoming a sociology major. If you are just taking a sociology class for interest, take a look at other classes first.
Take this class if you have an interest in sociology. Great professor, interesting readings, and nothing too hard, but makes you think about certain social phenomena in new ways.
Take this class if you need the requirement. The professor is great.
Take this class if you would like to have a nice foundation in sociology.
Take this class.  Mitch is awesome.  The material is awesome. and It's really interesting.
Take this course
Take this course if you don't mind a lack of structure at times. It is easy material and the professor wants to see you do well.
Take this course if you're interested in Sociology. Not a ton of work, and grading isn't too hard.
Take this course if you're looking for a cool, basic overview of what sociology is.
Take this course!
Take this course! The workload is manageable if you stay on top of it. Professor Duneier is fantastic, and you learn a lot about what is going on around you!

Take this course!! It is very relevant to the real-world and provides meaningful information that you should retain throughout life. The workload is very manageable as long as you stay on top of the readings!
Take this course!! The work load was pretty moderate, and the topic is super interesting. Professor Duneier is a really really great lecturer too.
Take this course, it will make you love lecture classes.

Take this if it's with Professor Duneier. He is amazing and the lectures are super interesting. There's a lot of reading, but it's all really interesting so you get through it pretty quick. The Sidewalk subjects visit at the end of the course if priceless.
The advice won't be given to them since I have never received advice from this type of form, so I decline to comment.

The course is a great introductory course! For me, I took the course because I was interested in race, class, and inequality. However, one has to keep in mind that the course is still sociology and takes a very broad perspective on these issues, focusing on analyzing issues from a societal standpoint. 

The course did seem a little unstructured because the syllabus constantly changed and a course like sociology doesn't have a clear curriculum.

The best part was the lectures. I genuinely enjoyed going to class because Professor Duneier taught in a very casual manner from his arm chair. As one of the top ethnographers in our country, he also provides a very unique and insightful perspective.
The course was a great introduction to sociology. I feel as if there could be a bit more transparency when it comes to grading, but overall it was an excellent course. Very easy to PDF.
There is a lot of reading, but that is the main homework.
This course is interesting and laid back. Professor Duneier is a great lecturer and there is a low workload for this class.

This course is oddly organized; sometimes you'll only have 10 pgs to read for the week, and other times Prof. Dunieir assigns 300  pgs for the next two days. Prof. Dunieir is a very engaging professor, however!

This course provides a good introduction to the study of sociology. However, you will only get out what you put into the course. The readings are interesting, albeit unnecessarily long at times. It's up to you to decide whether to do them or not. Overall, I would recommend this course to anyone who's interested in learning about sociology.
This is a fairly easy survey course that anyone interested in sociology would enjoy.  The midterm and the final and massive portions of your grade so do the readings to prepare for those.
Try to find another SA if you don't need SOC 101. Steer clear of intro courses in general. Arum Park is a good preceptor. If you take it, do yourself a favor and actually read the material assigned.
Very interesting class, take it!
Very manageable course. There were never any surprises on the tests and for the most part the content was really interesting.
Very manageable workload, interesting, broad range of topics
Write down everything in lectures.
Write your weekly memos thoughtfully, because thinking about each week's concepts in a meaningful way will help you to engage with the class and to prepare for the final.
Yes I would advise other students to take this course.
Yes! good class!

You need to go to lecture and do the readings. I think the grading depends largely on how much information you can throw at them that comes from both lecture and the readings. Not particularly difficult. Definitely do the readings because they are important.
You should definitely take this course.
recommend
take it
take it if you are interested in sociology
descrip: This course introduces sociology as a subject with a key role to play in modern intellectual culture and a central place within the social sciences. A range of topics such as race, class, gender, deviance, ethnocentrism, crime, families, urban life, social interaction, and social inequality will be covered. Lectures are intended to inspire students to draw on their sociological imagination to become more publicly involved and directly engaged in the real world.

title: Exhibition Issues and Methods
reviews: You either have to take this or can't take it.
wooohooo yay seniors! yay pam! yay art!
prereqs: Open to senior Program 2 students in Art and Archaeology and VIS certificate students..
descrip: This seminar provides senior ART Program 2 and VIS certificate students a context for investigating and discussing contemporary art exhibition practices. Over the course of the semester, students will develop a greater understanding of their art, their influences, and their aesthetic underpinnings by considering them alongside readings, visiting artist lectures, writing assignments, and field trips to current exhibitions. Approaches to exhibition design, publicity, and audience will also be addressed. Assigned readings will challenge received ideas of what art is and what the form and content of an exhibition might entail.

title: Synchrotron and Neutron Studies of Materials
reviews: I would recommend this course if you are interested more in the theory behind neutron studies of materials, not just actually using them.
I would recommend those who are interested in material science in general and particularly those who are interested in learning advanced experimental techniques to consider the course
I would take it. The material is tricky, but the workload isn't higher than it needs to be and the class itself is very interesting.
If you don't have prior experience with these techniques it would be helpful to do some reading on them before the lectures so you can follow the lectures more easily.
It is a good introduction to synchrotron techniques.
Just audit.
Reading the textbook material before lectures was very helpful to understanding the lecture material in class.
Spend time on the labs; they'll teach you a lot.  Lectures will be a little confusing if you have little background in advanced physics/chemistry.
Take the course if you are interested/or will be doing work with scattering/diffraction experiments.

This course is probably the best way to get exposure to synchrotron and neutron based techniques which are immensely powerful for addressing a broad range of research questions.  The class (in particular the lab component) is a serious time commitment.
This is a very good primer course on x-ray and neutron topics. Definitely give it a try.
descrip: Topics include an introduction to radiation generation at synchrotron and neutron facilities, elastic scattering techniques, inelastic scattering techniques, imaging and spectroscopy. Specific techniques include X-ray and neutron diffraction, small-angle scattering, inelastic neutron scattering, reflectometry, tomography, microscopy, fluorescence and infrared imaging, and photoemission spectroscopy. Emphasis is placed on application of the techniques for uncovering the material structure-property relationship, including energy storage devices, sustainable concrete, CO2 storage, magnetic materials, mesostructured materials and nanoparticles.

title: Developmental Psychology
reviews: A fun class - definitely enjoyable, but can do well without going to class or even reading textbook if you've taken other psych classes
Absolutely take this class, it's been my favorite class at Princeton so far.
An easy fifth course and interesting.

An interesting class content-wise. Not one in which you can blow off the lecture or readings as the exams draw from both and often have very specific questions. Not too difficult otherwise and Professor Lew Williams is an engaging lecturer. He's also very approachable and friendly. A solidly good class.
Definitely take it if you're looking to take just one psychology class, developmental psychology is really an interesting topic and the workload is pretty light.
Definitely take it!
Definitely take this course! Prof. Lew-Williams is one of the best profs I've had at Princeton thus far. The material is relevant and interesting, and the course is not to be missed!
Dev psych is a really interesting topic to study in order to see how much our lives are shaped by our childhoods, and Casey is a wonderful professor.
Do the readings on time and take notes. LOts of memorization.
Do the weekly experimental reports. They present the creative and very intelligent ways in which psychologists attempt to quantify seemingly unquantifiable qualities of human nature and behaviors.
Don't take this course if you're just trying to get an easy A. you have to work
Don't take this course with Professor Lew Williams; though he is well intentioned the class itself was a general waste of time. This is not a challenging class, but it is pretty unpleasant to be in.

Fairly easy course, especially if you're PDFing. There aren't too many assignments, and they're all pretty short. Lecture slides are sparse, so you definitely need to attend lecture if you want to do well (and aren't just trying to pass). The final exam asked for weirdly specific details from the textbook and lecture.
For babies and non babies alike, this course will expand your knowledge and you will be a better person because of it. Babies: get to lecture early so you can snag a stroller-designated seat!!
Fun and interesting class - definitely make sure to go to lecture! There are also more group assignments than previous years.
Go to all the lectures!
Go to all the lectures.  Doing the readings will help ensure good exam grades.
Go to every lecture and take really good notes.
Go to lecture!

Go to lectures because they are interesting. Also, questions on the tests are often from the lecture powerpoint which do not disclose on the conclusions of certain experiments on the slides. So, taking notes is helpful. I PDF the class and I did not find it at all difficult, though it is difficult to get a really good grade for those of you who are not planning on PDFing.
Going to the lectures and doing the reading is what helped me do well.
Good class, especially if you are interested in psychology.

Great class - definitely take if you have any interest in developmental psychology. Definitely do the textbook reading. If you do  the reading and pay any sort of attention in lecture, you'll be just fine.
Great class to take if you want to learn more about children.
Great course
Great course - lots of fun and not too much work.
Great course! Interesting lectures and not too much work-- would definitely recommend.
I loved this course. Take it if you have the slightest interest in babies or children.  Go to lecture, it's really fun and make sure you know all the key terms (not just the concepts!) for the exam.

I took it because I was interested in learning about child development and I thought it would be useful for the future. I'd also heard good things about past management of the class. After taking it, I wasn't impressed with the preceptors or the Dean's Date Assignment (writing an imaginary journal article seems useless). I did learn a lot from the readings, though I realize I could have done this on my own time or by auditing the class. I think there are probably better ECs out there.
I would recommend it as a very interesting course, but I wouldn't recommend it as a p/d/f course because there is a substantial amount of work.
I wouldn't take it unless it is a requirement.

I'd only take it if you're looking for a distributional requirement. Do note that instead of having 3 exams, there are now 2 exams and a bunch of short paper assignments. Casey is a good teacher and the class had some interesting parts to it, but overall it wasn't mind-blowing.

If Prof. Lew-Williams is teaching the class, absolutely take it. It was more work than expected, but I thoroughly enjoyed the class. Lew-Williams is engaging and passionate about the material, and lectures were fantastic.
If Professor Casey Lew-Williams is teaching this course, take it!
If you're interested in psych, try to find a different course.
Interesting course with a great professor. Casey seems to really care about what he's teaching and does a great job of presenting the information in an engaging way.
Interesting topic and engaging Professor. Not terribly easy however
Interesting, not too hard, and you'll come away with some new insights about life.
It was interesting!
It's a low workload and sufficiently interesting distro.

Low-key way to fulfill an EC, but a lot of busy work if you're PDFing and precepts are useless and a waste of time (more so than in any other course I've ever taken, so beware).  Lectures can be fun and entertaining though, and the professor clearly cares about his subject and students.
Make sure to do the readings and study the vocal and make sure you know it well.
Make sure you do the readings very thoroughly and don't take the class if you don't think you will want to put the time in.
Only take it if you really care about the subject.  I would not recommend it.
Only take this if you are going to take it seriously and be prepared to do a lot of unassigned reading.

Overall the course was great. It was not too challenging but and you could get by without putting in a ton of effort, but if you really tried you would learn a lot and I think enjoy the material quite a bit.
Pay particular attention to the studies covered in the lectures and try to memorize the important ones.

Phenomenal class. Fascinating subject material, and if Casey Lew-Williams is teaching it, this should be a no-brainer. Casey is an absolute all-star professor -- incredibly passionate lecturer, smart guy, friendly professor. Haven't taken the final yet, but the midterm was not too terribly painful, and the other assignments are open-ended and painless. Big fan of this course and of Casey.
Pretty interesting course but gets repetitive.
Pretty intersting about what you'd expect.
Read the book and go to lecture and read the precept readings.
Read the text thoroughly! Learn the studies mentioned in lecture.
Really engaging professor, but its not super easy like it used to be. Interesting and good class to take though, not a terrible workload.
Students interested in the subject should take the class.
TAKE IT
TAKE THIS CLASS. LEW WILLIAMS IS AWESOME!

TAKE this course!!! It is interesting and is a reasonable workload! There is no need to do excessive work in order to learn something valuable!!! I believe this course is one of those courses where, without stressing yourself out too much, you can learn things that will positively influence many aspects of your life!
Take for an easy psych course
Take it
Take it as a distribution requirement.
Take it but focus on theories, names and key words in the textbook.

Take it if Professor Lew-Williams is teaching! There are lots of assignments to compose your grade so not everything depends on the midterm and final. The midterm is super reasonable. The professor gives excellent lectures (some people didn't like them, but I did). It's interesting material. You get to watch baby videos. Take it!
Take it if the material looks interesting to you.
Take it if you like Psychology, nice class.
Take it!
Take it! Not difficult and very interesting. Professor Lew-Williams was a great lecturer
Take it!! It's interesting, engaging, and useful and it's an easy distribution requirement to fulfill!
Take it!!!!!!! Cute babies.
Take the class if you have an interest in children or children psychology.
Take the class! The materials is very interesting, and it makes as a good not-too-stressful 5th class.
Take this - it's easy, fun, and better with Casey Lew-Williams than I would've thought dev psych could be
Take this class, it's a lot of fun and the readings are interesting and short. The workload is not bad at all and Professor Lew-Willams is extremely passionate about the subject.
Take this class. You'll enjoy it very much.
Take this course if you want an easy, boring distribution requirement. Otherwise I wouldn't recommend it.
Take this course! Casey is an amazing professor, and the subject matter is very interesting.
Take this course! It's not too hard, and it's quite interesting.

Take this course! The professor is amazing and you'll have a ton of fun learning not just about babies/how they think but also about social structures in our society. My advice would be to pay attention in lecture and take good notes - the lectures are the most valuable part.
Take this course- It is very relevant, not very challenging, and Prof Lew Williams is a really awesome guy who is very passionate about this subject!
The course is okay, but there are more interesting psychology classes to take.  This class is NOT and easy A; Lew-Williams upped the difficulty and took away the curve.
The lectures and readings are important. The theoretical concepts can be a bit tricky to understand, so make sure to read over them carefully.
There are probably other psych courses you will enjoy more, even if children and psychology are your particular interest.
This is a fun, non-stressful class. Makes a great PDF for distributional requirements. Casey is a great professor.

This is a great EC if you're at all interested in kids.  It sufficiently balances historical theories with modern experiments and applications to social issues.  Professor Lew-Williams is really enthusiastic about what he does and often includes videos or funny examples to keep lectures interesting.  This class is especially cool if you're familiar with young children and can draw connections to things you've seen previously.  The midterm and non-cumulative final are both an hour long, and assignments are not very demanding while providing a lot of freedom for creativity.
This is a great course - you will learn a lot of things about child development that you did not expect, and Professor Lew-Williams is great!!
Try to make the most out of your precept and pay attention in lecture!
Yes, great class.
Yes, it's a good into to psychology.
You should take this course if the topic genuinely interests you. It's a fun course.
easy enough but there are better courses to fill requirement
take it.
descrip: Babies, who look like helpless blobs, are capable of impressive feats of learning. 3-year-olds, who can't tie their own shoes, know an astounding amount of information about their environments. We will focus on landmark studies that elucidate how children's biology, cognition, language, and social experiences interact to set the stage for what we do and who we are. Is the baby's world a 'blooming, buzzing confusion', or do babies enter the world prepared to make sense of their environments? How can we understand the collaboration between nature and nurture? What changes over development from infancy to adolescence, and what remains constant?

title: Cellular and Systems Neuroscience
reviews: Go for it if you're into light computational neuro. Otherwise, there are probably other courses that might be better.
I would say take this course. It gives you a look into more mathematical ways of describing some of the interesting concepts learned in the introductory courses.
Take it
Take it!
Take it! You truly learn about neuroscience rather than neuro/psych. The content is incredibly interesting!
Take it. The materials is interesting.
This course is engineering friendly

this version of the course was not terribly difficult. felt like a slightly mathier version of neu 258, but didn't really get deeply into the equations. mostly did computations with them, which is very basic.
prereqs: MOL 214 or 215, PSY 258 and MAT 103, or instructor's permission. A basic familiarity with simple electrical circuits (as presented in PHY104 or ELE 203) is expected..
descrip: A survey of fundamental principles in neurobiology at the biophysical, cellular, and system levels. Lectures will address the basis of the action potential, synaptic transmission and plasticity, local circuit computation, sensory physiology, and motor control. A central theme will be the understanding of systems phenomena in terms of cellular mechanisms.

title: Readings in Modern Chinese Intellectual History
reviews: Awesome course; lots of work but really interesting and worth it
Be well-prepared for the oral reports since those are really important.
I would recommend this class to other students.

If you're on the fence, I think you should just take it. Just know that you unfortunately cannot PDF it.  But overall best Chinese class I've taken (out of like 7 or 8) and one of my favorite classes at Princeton. Highly political/intellectual
Interesting content. I enjoyed studying Chinese and academic content at the same time. Leaps and bounds more interesting than fourth year.
Not very valuable for a Chinese student.
Take it if you're interested! Professor Chou is amazing!

Take this class if you are interested in learning more about Chinese literature! Zhou Laoshi is excellent and the weekly essays keep you on your toes. If you put effort in, your writing skills and ability to communicate effectively will certainly improve!

This course is perfect for anyone who already has a commanding knowledge of Chinese, but still wants to improve his/her language skills and is genuinely interested in learning about Chinese intellectualism leading up to the Cultural Revolution.
Try to do the readings, but it will be hard to complete them all. This really is an intellectual history course, so take it if you want to discuss relatively abstract intellectual issues.
Very, very difficult course for none native speakers due to the time commitment necessary. However, I think the assistance it provided in improving reading comprehension was invaluable.
prereqs: CHI 403, 404, 405 and 406, or Instructor's permission.
descrip: Designed to give students who have had advanced training in modern Chinese an opportunity for directed readings in their own fields. The focus of readings is modern Chinese intellectual history. One class, two hours of discussion

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Science - Shape Analysis
descrip: Study of methods for analyzing shapes in 3D scanned data with a focus on deriving high-level structure and semantics from raw spatial data.

title: The American Family in Law and Society
reviews: A highly enjoyable class for early birds!
A lot of reading.  But if you are interested in the material then its not difficult to get through.

AMAZING CLASS!!! A must-take for anyone interested in improving their legal reasoning skills or with a general interest in the intersection of law, families, and society. Prof Rosen is brilliant, kind, and super funny!
Absolutely take this course! Rosen is probably one of the absolute best professors this place has to offer!
Annotate the cases for future reference and to refer back to the text

Barely any work. Only graded assignments are a take-home midterm essay and take-home final essay. That said, participation is required in class, so don't take it if you don't want to speak a lot. Interesting topics though.
Do all of the readings. It will help you understand the lectures and get involved in class.
Do the readings and participate in class.
Do the readings and speak in class
Do the readings because having a background knowledge of the cases upon entering class will allow you to be more engaged, participate, and learn more
Do the readings!  It'll be so easy to participate in class if you do, and they're never too long or dense.  You'll enjoy the class so much more if you come to it prepared!

First of all, go to class. I had no idea that class participation was 20% of your overall grade (it was not stated on the syllabus) and had I known, I would've forced myself to go every time. I know 8:30am is a bit daunting, but manageable. Also, hand-write your notes and don't use your laptop because I've been easily distracted, especially because he does not write anything on the board or provide notes.
I would merely advise that the class is less anthropology-based and more focused on constitutional and legal issues.
Interesting course.
It's a great course if you're interested in going into law or otherwise! Relaxed lecture style and the readings are more or less engaging. Take it if you want to read historical cases in family law!
Keep up with the readings, and make sure to use key words.
Learn the legal terms and primary laws he discusses early on! Attend class!

Lectures are great! Although its early, its worth getting up for! Readings are extremely interesting so it shouldn't be a hardship reading them. Professor Rosen is great and I regret not participating more or going to office hours.

Make sure to read the cases on a weekly basis and maybe make an outline of what issues come up in which cases so that for the take homes you can look back at the list instead of having to go through all your papers to find relevant cases.

Really taught me how courts function and build their cases, because the class involves reading a huge volume of abridged court cases. The structure was: read two to four court cases before each lecture and then discuss those cases in the lecture.
TAKE IT if you have any interest in legal processes, Supreme Court decisions, or (most pertinently) family law!!!!
Take it if you like law!
Take it!
Take it! Great professor and a very easy class if you listen in lecture and follow a similar structure of analyzing cases. Very light work load.
Take it! We look at relevant issues and while we of course focus on family-related topics, we also learn how to approach legal and social questions.
Take it.
Take this course.  Professor Rosen is great.

Take this even if you don't know anything about the field, it's a fantastic course regardless of your subject area, and allows you to develop the critical thinking that's good for anything and everything.
This class will teach you how to think about court cases as a lawyer or a judge would. Perhaps more of a law class than an anthropology class.

This is not an anthropology class. It's a class on American family law, which is interesting, but you're not going to learn about anthropology. Doing well is pretty straightforward. Take it if you want to learn more about how to think legally. It's not a "must-take" though.
Very helpful class, especially if considering law school
definitely take the course even if you aren't necessarily interested in law. the cases you go over in class really get you thinking about modern issues regarding family law.
descrip: The course will focus on the conflicts occasioned by changing family patterns, the role of technology in conflicts over procreation and rights of the fetus, the meaning of property and its impact on divorce settlements, and the comparative development of laws of inheritance and incest. Multicultural issues will also figure prominently in the course.

title: Introduction to Psychology
reviews: Ask Dowon Dan Kim
Be prepared for a lot of coding in lab, but if psychology is something that you are very interested in, definitely take the course!
Be prepared for computer programming in labs!
Be ready to code.
Do all of the readings.
Do not take the course unless fulfilling requirement.
Do not take this class.
Do not take this course if you want an easy STL. You will work very hard.
Do the readings and go to the review sessions. Ask for help in labs if you need it.

Don't even think about taking it unless you have taken a statistics course at Princeton. I took and excelled in AP Statistics last year in high school and did not know how to do anything in the statistical program we used. While many of the lectures and readings were genuinely interesting, the lab section of this course completely ruined it for me, and not to mention, devastated my grade.
Don't expect an easy class
Don't take it unless you have to.
Easy, laid-back course, and is pretty interesting.
Either attend lecture and take copious notes or thoroughly read the assigned readings.
Go to lecture and you should be okay. Make sure you put a lot of effort into labs because those can shockingly end up hurting you in the end.

Go to lecture. Study the slides and readings closely for exams, as Prof. Gould definitely does like to test you on some of the smaller details. Labs are mostly awful, and the grading on assignments oftentimes seems random. Maybe wait a few years to take this course once they figure things out. But if you need an STL, the courseload is extremely light, and it seems nearly impossible to get less than a B, although weirdly difficult to do much better than that.
Go to lectures, since they will also prepare you for the exams. Also, talk to your lab instructors so that you can fully understand each assignment.
Go to the lectures & take notes! It'll help you a ton with the exams.
Hopefully the new labs will be improved by the next time this course is taught. But the lectures are really great.
I hope they change the curriculum because this class needs a change. Not too bad, but not too good
I strongly recommend this course, as I believe that the current issues will be worked out for the future. It is very relevant information and therefore a course worth taking.
I think it is a great course to take to fulfill your lab requirement, but it does take a solid amount of time and effort to do well.
I would advise another student to make sure he has experience using data processing software, and is confident doing so.
I would advise other students to review lectures weekly and to work to understand what they're doing in lab, rather than go through the motions.
I would really consider your expertise in R studio.  The labs are difficult for a beginner.
I would recommend that other students take this course. It is a good foundation in psychology, and a very interesting class.

I would say go to class. It's a bit difficult to get the material you missed if you do miss class, and it's pretty much impossible to get any extra stuff that the professor may have just said out loud.
If you are comfortable with R and statistics, the labs will be no problem for you. Overall, this was a good course to get an STL out of the way, but only the lectures were engaging.

If you are interested in psychology and want to take a broad class in it, take this one! Professor Gould is awesome and this class is a great introduction to the field. However, the labs were often boring and sometimes stressful, so be wary of them.
If you don't know statistics or coding I wouldn't take this just because the labs wrongly assume you know both those things and they're not formal pre-recs.

If you stick it out through the first part of the semester the labs get better. If you are taking the class to get the requirement out of the way then definitely take it because the lectures and material of the course is interesting enough to make up for the flaws.

If you take it, you must be interested in psychology otherwise you will be very bored.
Moreover, for the lab, I recommend some background computer programming knowledge.

If you're planning to take this course, be aware that the exams (1 midterm and 1 final) are only based on the lecture and anything in the textbook that was also mentioned in the lecture. Therefore, don't focus too much on the textbook. If you want to do well in this class, study your notes from the lecture as well as the articles on recent psychology experiments (can be found on Black Board). Professor Gould also posts her power points on Black Board, so you can always jot down notes on anything you missed during class. Lastly, don't forget that you have to participate in (approximately 4) psychology experiments for course credit throughout the semester. If you don't complete the research requirement by Dean's Date, you'll fail the course, so don't leave it to the last minute!
It is a great course to cover the science with a lab requirement.
It's a decent way to get the lab requirement done. The lectures are really interesting. Lab is awful
Lab is a lot of work, but lectures make it worth it!
Lecture is great - engaging and easy to understand - but lab is a real pain.
Lectures are awesome but in terms of the lab: go in with coding knowledge or be prepared to be discouraged and do poorly.

Lectures were very good. Slightly boring at times, but she is very organized and covers the material extremely well. Textbook readings aren't super important, but there will questions on the articles assigned. Labs, however, were bad. You are expected to know R and there is way too much material to cover in 3 hours. Definitely try and get Adam Brockett as a lab instructor. He's the best! Super chill and helpful, minimizes the work you have to do, and is very accessible outside of class.
Make sure you understand that the lab and lectures are like taking two separate classes.

My recommendation of this course depends entirely on whether it is taken with the lab or not. If not, take it. It is essential to anyone's basic medical and scientific literacy. If with the lab, you will not enjoy your semester unless you have prior statistical and computing experience.

My year was the first year with a revamped set of labs, and the labs were not set up very well.
