If Gould is teaching, the lectures will be ok but a little dry and uninteresting.
Not very representative of psychology in general--if looking for a PSY class out of general interest, try a different course first.
Only take it once they change the setup back to the way it was.
Please be careful on your lab reports.
Prof. Gould is awesome! Her lectures are engaging, and she is really nice. However, the newly structured labs are disorganized and boring.

Prof. Gould really cares and is one of the best in her field. If you go to lecture, you will do well on the exams, which are quite straightforward. Her grading on free response is pretty tough, though, and there is a lot of neuroscience content in the first half. WATCH OUT FOR THE LAB. It had a lot of coding content, and assignments were often not well written.
Take it for the STL, stay for the practical knowledge you'll gain for the future.
Take it if you have to.  The lab is quite hard at times, however.
Take it if you need it, but it is not an easy A.
Take it if you need to - Gould's lectures are kind of boring but the material is generally useful/interesting!
Take it only if you're interested in psych.
Take it! It's a great class that will really show you a lot about the general areas of psychology. It's a good, broad course that has some very interesting material.
Take this class for your lab requirement. Yes, it's a good amount of work for an intro class, but you get a lot out of it.
The course is harder than previous years but still manageable.

The labs are completely unrelated to lecture. They completely revamped PSY101 this summer so the labs became much more difficult, but they were nonetheless very educational and interesting. Don't take it because you think it's the easiest STL. It still requires lots of work. Jonathan Berliner was a great AI and was INCREDIBLY helpful. Lectures can get boring with Gould's voice, but the material is still interesting. NEVER READ THE BOOK. She tests ONLY on lecture material, so just attend lecture and take notes.
The labs take more effort than expected, so plan accordingly.
There are easier ways to fulfill your STL. Don't do this cause you can't PDF it.
This course is a good weeder in that it helps you to understand if you like the material of psychology and the different types of psychology that is out there to study.
Try to get out of the lab component
Unexpectedly difficult labs, lectures are interesting. Make sure you know what you are getting into, it's not your easy lab course anymore
You can't PDF this class

be sure you really want to take this class
don't take it just to satisfy STL requirement
descrip: The study of human nature from the viewpoint of psychological science. Topics range from the biological bases of human perception, thought and action to the social-psychological determinants of individual and group behavior. This course is a prerequisite for majoring in psychology and can also be used to satisfy the science and technology with laboratory general education requirement.

title: Environmental Geochemistry: Chemistry of the Natural Systems
reviews: A great course - definitely worth taking.  Not a lot of work, and you learn a LOT.  I think this is a good course for people who need a little brushing up on basic chemistry - it may have been dull for a chemistry major.  As a non chemistry major who enjoyed intro chem, I thought it was great.
Go to lecture and go to office hours.  This class is more than manageable if you put in the effort and use the resources that are made readily available to you.
Great course if you're interested in the topic. Do not skip lecture. Be sure to seek help on the problems sets if you need it.

I believe that anyone considering geoscience for more than just the fun trips should take this class. It is a good survey course and shows that it is more than just a major that makes you memorize stuff about rocks. There is a lot more to just the "earth science" that we learned in high school/middle school and this class was very good at showing us this.
I would highly recommend this class.
It is a good course, even if you do not have much or any GEO background. Take it! You will learn a lot.
It's sort of a niche class. If you are really interested in the material, for sure take it. If not, you'll probably have trouble staying engaged.
Really interesting, chill pace - take it!

Satish is one of the best professors I've had - he is so approachable and helpful, and you learn so much while realizing how important and relevant everything you've learned is. Also, if the TA is still Emily Gilson, go to her - she's great too!!
Satish is really cool and interesting!
Take it! Take full advantage of Satish because he is always more than willing to help.

The class is very interesting and explains many phenomena we see in daily life (basically, cool stuff). It doesn't require a lot of chemistry or geo background, but you might have trouble if you've never taken something equivalent to AP Chemistry or CHM 201/2 before. You need to attend all lectures and take good notes (or get notes from a classmate). There isn't a textbook, and all the testable material comes from lectures. It's a fun course. Take it!
Utilize ask questions to Professor Myneni he is very good at explaining difficult processes.
prereqs: Introductory chemistry (CHM 201 or AP chemistry).
descrip: Covers topics including origin of elements; formation of the Earth; evolution of the atmosphere and oceans; atomic theory and chemical bonding; crystal chemistry and ionic substitution in crystals; reaction equilibria and kinetics in aqueous and biological systems; chemistry of high-temperature melts and crystallization process; and chemistry of the atmosphere, soil, marine and riverine environments. The biogeochemistry of contaminants and their influence on the environment will also be discussed.

title: Hegel's Phenomenology of Spirit
reviews: Do it. You'll never get a more supportive, engaging chance to read Hegel, and you don't want to do that on your own.
If you are interested in continental philosophy and want to be introduced to pragmatism while still trying to figure out what the heck is so important about Hegel, this is the class for you.
Play close attention to the readings, and review your notes from past weeks before attending class.
Take it only if you really want to read the whole Phenomenology, and be prepared to be disappointed at that. That being said, the class itself is perfectly agreeable.
Worth the time and the struggle
prereqs: The course is intended for graduate students and undergraduates with at least some previous coursework in philosophy, political theory, or religious thought..
descrip: This seminar will focus on the conceptions of knowledge, recognition, ethical life, value conflict, freedom, morality, religion, and the Absolute developed in G.W.F. Hegel's most influential book, The Phenomenology of Spirit, which we will be reading in English translation.

title: Topics in Tonal Theory - 19th-Century Song
descrip: This is a seminar devoted to such topics as theoretical models, analytical procedures, and the relationship of each to theories of composition and performance. The specific emphasis is on the analysis of 19th-century German songs. We look at multiple settings of the same poem, as well as several famous song cycles.

title: Explaining Values
reviews: A thought provoking class focusing on the question of free will, determinism, and moral responsibility
Challenging but worth it. Makes you think about crime and punishment in new interesting ways. A pretty chill seminar.

Definitely take the class! Even if you don't have such a great background in philosophy, Prof. McGeer makes abstract topics very approachable. And you'll learn a lot of things that will make you re-think concepts and everyday interactions!
Do not take this lightly, you will get nothing out of it. Take it out of a strong interest or departmental and you will be rewarded if you give it significant attention.

Don't. Ethical philosophy sucks, and VM refuses to let anyone come up with their own ideas. Discussions are just a guessing game to what she thinks, and she'll shut you down unless you agree with her. Also, she never fucking responds to emails.
Only take this course if you are interested in free will and how that affects moral responsibility.
Take this if you love yourself; don't take it if you hate yourself.
This is a good course to take for anyone interested in understanding the philosophical issues pertaining to free will, moral responsibility, and the penal system.
prereqs: One other course in Philosophy or permission of instructor.
descrip: This seminar will focus on the philosophy of responsibility, blame and punishment. It will examine how human interactions are permeated by evaluative understandings of agency and responsibility, and whether such evaluative understandings are well grounded. It will consider what implications this has for inter-personal relations, as well as for social institutions such as criminal justice. We will approach these issues from a multi-disciplinary perspective, examining how philosophical, scientific and institutional considerations can be brought into useful contact with one another.

title: Advanced Inorganic Chemistry
reviews: A very good course to learn and have fun.
Attend all the lectures and make sure you can do all the homework problems, if not keep practicing.
Definitely take this class.
Take it. It really isn't as hard as it sounds. You learn a lot and you'll enjoy yourself.
descrip: A detailed examination of bonding and structure in transition metal complexes will be undertaken. A variety of modern physical methods will be discussed in this context. Chemical reactivity, including ligand substitution reactions, charge transfer reactions and photochemical processes, will be investigated based on electronic structure considerations. Examples will be drawn from the current literature.

title: Introduction to the Quantum Theory
reviews: Do not fall behind like I did at times, read the textbook and lecture notes and start the problem sets early! Do not be afraid to ask questions.
Huse is a good lecturer. Challenging homeworks and exams but you'll learn a lot.
I would not recommend this class unless you thoroughly enjoyed PHY 208.

If you're considering this class, you more than likely have to take it. It's a super fascinating field but it is immensely challenging. If you're up to it, go for it; if you have to take it, focus on what you learn.

It is very hard and time consuming, but also quite rewarding. Some topics - such as WKB approximation and scattering- are quite dry - but others - such as quantizing EM, entanglement, and the adiabatic approximation - are very cool.
Professor Huse is a very good teacher. The first half of the class builds on PHY208, but the second half felt like it ran out of things to do.
Take it if you want an extremely thorough and challenging course in quantum mechanics.  The hardest course I have taken here yet.

This course made me seriously reconsider my decision to be a physics major. Many problem sets were near impossible, and we were left struggling trying to understand difficult concepts from poorly handwritten lecture notes. This class was way harder than 205 or 208. There's not much you can do about it though. It is a departmental and you will have bad teachers.  do the homework and you'll probably get a B.

This is a required course for the major, but was not fun at all. Extremely demanding and difficult, without any real intellectual reward or interest you might have found in the first semester of quantum.
This professor tells you how to approach physics.
You probably need to take it; if it's with Prof. Huse, be aware that it will not be as much review as it may have been in other semesters. Start psets early, and do them in groups

You should take it if you're a physics major, but otherwise think twice. It's interesting but 208 is more so, and it deals with some nitty-gritty QM that isn't that fascinating. Also, be prepared for an extraordinary workload, even in terms of physics classes.
prereqs: PHY 208.
descrip: This course is a continuation of PHY 208. We will continue to develop the formalism of quantum mechanics and to explore its basis. We will apply our methods to phenomena from atomic, high energy, and condensed matter physics.

title: Philosophical Analysis Using Argument Maps
descrip: Please see website

title: Themes in World History 1300-1850: The Mediterranean
reviews: Be prepared. Do the work. Don't be afraid to approach the professor if you're having a hard time. Do it sooner rather than later to give yourself more time to improve.
She is an expert on the Mediterranean, the Ottomans, early modern Greeks and the issues/future of maritime history so take her course if any of these are relevant to you
descrip: This course introduces students to the recent theoretical literature on the history of the sea as well as the current historiography on the early modern (1300-1850) Mediterranean. Students are expected to write a research paper for the course. Wide latitude is given in order to accommodate student interest.

title: History of Anthropological Theory
reviews: Don't forget to post your discussion questions! :)
I was worried about taking this class as a senior, but I actually think it worked wonderfully that way - it helped me connect the dots between all the readings I did in my other Anthropology classes.

I would only recommend this course to anthropology students or students who are seriously interested in anthropology. I think you'll get the most out of it if you've done actual field work to refer to.
Take this course if you're really interested in anthropology. Try to take it especially if it's being taught as a seminar like this year.
Take this if you want to learn what anthropology is/can be.
prereqs: One course in Anthropology or instructor's permission..
descrip: This course is an introduction to fundamental theories and debates in social/cultural anthropology. We will examine the national and colonial origins of anthropology, considering how western encounters with non-western peoples in the 19th-20th centuries opened questions about human kinship, history, economy, religion, language, sexuality, and personhood that continue to shape the horizons of our thought today. We will study this inheritance critically, exploring the changing concepts, methods, and ethics of anthropological research and writing, and evaluate their bearing on questions of power, justice, and identity in the present.

title: Architecture and Democracy
reviews: A very interesting class with a great professor, but make sure that you are interested in architecture more than democracy when you take it.
Class is definitely geared more towards politics than architecture so be prepared to learn a lot about political theory and political processes

This is a great course. Very interesting if you are at all interested in how cities work within a democratic structure. Brings forward compelling ideas that you wouldn't think about necessarily in other classes.
descrip: What kind of public architecture is appropriate for a democracy? Should public spaces and buildings reflect democratic values - such as transparency and accessibility - or is the crucial requirement for democratic architecture that the process of arriving at decisions about the built environment is as participatory as possible? Is gentrification somehow un-democratic? The course will introduce students to different theories of democracy, to different approaches to architecture, and to many examples of architecture and urban planning from around the world, via images and films. Might include a field trip.

title: Elementary Arabic I
reviews: Be prepared for a lot of homework, but don't skip anything because it really helps pound the lessons in. Arabic is a tough language for anglophones to learn, but it isn't impossible!
Challenging but don't be afraid to take a chance if you really want to learn the language.

Definitely prepare for the lessons ahead of time if you have the time, because at least you won't be totally lost in class. Professor Hefter follows the course schedule pretty well. I would definitely take advantage of the listening resources provided with the textbook.
Definitely take it with Nancy Coffin.
Definitely try to take an Arabic course with Tarek, he will make you love the language and culture, and makes you want to come to class every day!
Do the homework and learn the vocab, if you are interested in learning the language it requires time and if you aren't taking it to really learn Arabic, then it's a waste of time.
Don't be scared of Arabic! It's difficult but you can handle it.
Don't get bogged down by all the work! You can do it!
Hold on to your hat and be prepared to put some serious elbow grease into this. Do not take it if you do not really have a passion for it- but great professors and grit will pull you through.
If you are looking for a rewarding but challenging class, take this course.

If you are willing to put in ~2-3 hours a night for the first month of the semester, and ~1-2 hour subsequently, you will do fine in the class and have a great time as Elsayed is a pleasure to be around. Arabic is seriously not that difficult of a language at this level, the alphabet is almost exactly phonetic and the level of instruction is challenging but super manageable.
It is a very manageable introduction to what seems at first a very difficult language.
It really is essential to keep up with the work, because it is so fast paced. Especially vocab.

It's difficult because of using a completely new alphabet, but Prof. Husen and all of the Arabic teachers do a great job of teaching you how to read and write in the first month of the course. It's an excellent and very interesting course, and you learn a lot.
Make sure to complete all homework on time, constantly review vocab, and take advantage of office hours.
Taek it. Arabic is a fantastic language.
Take Arabic, especially with Professor Nancy! You will be challenged, but you will also learn so much and you will finish the semester feeling so engaged and accomplished.
Take it. It's a great introduction to the language. You know you want to.
Take it. Work hard at it. Arabic is a beautiful language and this is the best place to learn it. The Arabic team is so helpful and the lecture/ drill set up works really well.
The course as a whole is very well-organized, proceeds at a reasonable pace, and does a fine job of introducing Arabic.  If Tarek is teaching it, take his section for sure.
great teacher to take the class with.
prereqs: No credit is given for ARA 101 unless it is followed by ARA 102..
descrip: This class develops the basic structures and vocabulary for understanding, speaking, writing and reading Modern Standard Arabic, the shared formal variety of Arabic used throughout the Arab world. Students will also gain some familiarity with both Egyptian and Syrian colloquial dialects. Classroom activities are designed to foster communication and cultural competence through comprehension and grammar exercises, skits, conversation, and the use of a variety of audio-visual materials.

title: The Forgotten Ghetto
descrip: Please see website

title: Advanced Topics in Computer Engineering - Trustworthy Computing
reviews: Beginning of the class was much more relaxed, but then suddenly we had many presentations and other things that needed to be done.
It is an interesting class. Some assignments were unnecessary.The focus is mostly on architecture. Ask the instructor to specify the assignments beforehand.
It is really worth taking if you have interests in security and privacy. Prof. Lee is nice and always gave useful suggestions.
It's boring
It's very good for who is also interested in the security and privacy issues.
This course is good.
descrip: Current topics in trustworthy computing, especially hardware-enabled trust and security. Topics include enabling hardware to thwart attacks (e.g., with randomization), measuring and characterizing normal software-hardware behavior, hardware that does not leak information, building cryptographic support into computers, dynamic information flow tracking, building resilient computers that operate under both faults and attacks, multicore security, secure virtual machines and secure cloud storage.

title: Moscow/Petersburg: Russia in Two Capitals
reviews: If you're interested in Russia and Russian history, it's a good class to take.  You're level of enjoyment may depend on the other students in the class. Professor Reischl is very enthusiastic, easy to talk to, and knows the material well.
Recommended
Take this course if you are at all interested in Russia or are simply looking to explore a new part of the world alongside a great teacher or within a discussion based setting.
descrip: "Moscow/Petersburg: Russia through Two Capitals." This interdisciplinary course explores Russian culture through Russia's two capitals: Moscow and St. Petersburg. We will traverse these cityscapes as historical, cultural, and mythological spaces - from the past to the present day - in literary works, historical accounts, art, and film. We will investigate the sites of key landmarks, including the Moscow metro, the Hermitage and Red Square, in order to excavate the layers of cultural history which underlie contemporary Russian identity.

title: Mathematical Methods of Engineering Analysis II
reviews: Do not use the assigned textbook. Look for example problems online or in other textbooks
If you are interested in enhancing your math background as a researcher in engineering, you should definitely take this course.
They should not take it.
This is very useful math course for engineering students.
Very useful course. Professor was very helpful.
You're basically on your own. Get a different textbook and read everything you can find on the internet. Do all the problem sets twice so you understand what he's trying to convey.
descrip: Solutions of ordinary differential, partial differential and finite difference equations with emphasis on second order linear partial differential equations and their applications. Topics include special functions, eigenvalues and eigenfunctions, Sturm-Liouville analysis, Green's functions, explicit and implicit finite difference methods, stability analysis, transform methods, asymptotic analysis.

title: Molecular and Cellular Immunology
reviews: Do NOT take this if you have a passing interest in immunology. Take the EEB immune systems class.
If you are interested in immunology, take the course - you will learn it. If you aren't, then make sure you are motivated enough to learn it.
If you're interested in immunology/immune systems/pre-med - TAKE THIS COURSE. So great.
It's a huge amount of material presented in a pretty uninteresting way. I learned a lot, but it wasn't easy or fun.
It's super interesting and if you're good at memorization or learning biological narratives, its quite manageable.
Keep up with the readings!
Pay attention to lecture. Put some work into the case study presentations in precept.

Take this course - it is a really interesting subject and you will learn a lot from the class. Do not take it if you want an easy upper level MOL class. It requires a lot of reading and dedication to the class, but that being said, it was really enjoyable.
Take this if you're interested in immunology, pre-med or not. It's an excellent course, but might get away from non-MOL majors a bit.
prereqs: MOL 214 or MOL215.
descrip: A broad survey of the field of immunology and the mammalian immune system. The cellular and molecular basis of innate and acquired immunity will be discussed in detail. The course will provide frequent exemplars drawn from human biology in health and disease.

title: Design with Nanotechnologies
reviews: I will recommend it to others

It might be a little bit hard to follow the course at the first, especially for the new definitions and algorithms. However, looking back those knowledge after a few weeks, you could find the skeleton of the whole knowledge system and get a clear understanding.
Reading textbook helps a lot. Even some chapters that Prof. Jha didn't assign.
The title of the course could be a bit misleading, but it worth to take if you are doing logic design, computer architecture or circuits.
prereqs: ELE 206: Introduction to Logic Design.
descrip: Introduction to emerging technologies; FinFEts: from device to chip multiprocessor; quantum and reversible logic; nanowire based logic; carbon nanotube based logic; fault models for emerging technologies and testing; fault tolerance; 3D IC design.

title: The Philosophy of Urban History
reviews: A course that is reading and lecture intensive but a very stimulating topic. And, as always, it's a great opportunity to learn from one of the world's greats.
Don't get bent out of shape when DeLanda doesn't get to know you. Don't expect him to hold your hand, he is just trying to teach you a way of thinking.
I highly recommend the class for students looking for a philosophy class that can relate very well with architecture.
If one is looking for a course with very minimal coursework and limited interaction with the professor?that is, if one wants to be lectured to?this course might be worth taking.
Take it and it could do something to improve the way you think and view the world.
descrip: The class introduces students to the branch of the philosophy of history that specializes in cities. Cities are social entities that exist at an intermediate scale between the micro-level of individuals and the macro-level of society as a whole. Social science has tended to focus at those two extremes, while the intermediate meso-level has been neglected. The philosophy of urban history aims at remedying this situation, stressing not only the role of cities as historical actors, but also the role of other meso-level social entities from local communities and institutional organizations to urban regions and provinces.

title: Readings in Kiswahili Literature and East African Culture
prereqs: SWA 101 through SWA 107, or permission of instructor.
descrip: This advanced Kiswahili course will help students gain a higher level of language proficiency by applying grammatical skills learned in Elementary and Intermediate Kiswahili to topics addressing the language and culture of the Swahili speakers in East Africa. Coursework will focus on readings, writings, and oral performance activities on selected issues related to the history, geography, politics, language, literature, and cultural practices of the people of Kenya, Tanzania, and other Swahili speaking regions of Eastern Africa.

title: Integrated Building Studios
reviews: Enjoy!
Take this if you are required to take an integrated studio.
descrip: Explores architecture as a social art and the spatial organization of the human environment. Projects include a broad range of problem types, including individual buildings, groups of buildings, urban districts, and landscapes.

title: Junior Independent Work
prereqs: For each project, the requirements are set in consultation with the faculty advisor, and depend somewhat on the nature of the project. An oral presentation during Reading Period (as per departmental schedule) and a written final report is required. A copy of the report must be turned into the ELE Undergraduate Office Dean's Date. Details of requirements are available from the ELE Undergraduate Office. This course is open to qualified sophomores as well as juniors, provided they are adequately prepared..
descrip: Provides an opportunity for a student to concentrate on a "state-of-the-art" project in electrical engineering. Topics may be selected from suggestions by faculty members or proposed by the students. The final choice must be approved by the faculty advisor. There is no formal reading list; however, a literature search is a normal part of most projects.

title: Implementations of Quantum Information
reviews: Good course, especially if you are an experimentalist working in quantum information/quantum computing.
Take this course if you are really interested in this subject, otherwise it might just be a waste of your time
descrip: An overview of several approaches to implementing quantum information and computation, touching briefly on quantum algorithms, but the main focus being physical systems. In particular, the course discusses what makes a good quantum system, the physics behind the leading implementations, and the limitations on each. Topics covered will include: superconducting qubits, electron and nuclear spin qubits, and ion trap qubits, as well as descriptions of gate-based, adiabatic, and topologically protected quantum architectures.

title: Introduction to Programming Systems
reviews: 10/10 would recommend

A great intro to lower level programming, and Dondero is very good at explaining the topics. The assignments (especially towards the end of the year) can take a long time, but this class will make you a better overall programmer
Absolutely take this course. Assignments can take a while, but it is really satisfying when you finally get the solution.
Attend lectures and precepts
Be careful of the amount of time it takes to debug an assignment, and start early.
Be prepared for boredom.

Be prepared to spend A LOT of time on assignments. The assignments require you to be nit-picky about your code and that's a huge time suck. I took it for the certificate but I regret that decision. Don't take it unless you're a COS major because you won't think it's a good investment of your time otherwise.
Be prepared to spend a lot of time on this class. Go to lecture, start assignments early, and don't be afraid to ask for help.

Be ready for a very full class. Precepts do not rehash what you heard in lecture. Both lectures and precepts are stuffed with unique information and the assignments are long and detail-oriented. This will take up a lot of time, so consider that when selecting classes to go with it.
Be wary of the workload, but this class is extremely informative and interesting.
Bob Dondero is the best lecturer -- he explains things so well! Don't be scared, the class is much easier than COS 226 conceptually. Start shell early, it takes a lot of time.

COS 217 is an excellent course. I'm not incredibly interested in systems programming and will probably stay away from it after this, but I'm glad I took the course because I learned a lot about the gears that keep any application running below the surface. Assembly is hard; start early on that assignment and on buffer overrun, which also uses it. Exams are not like the assignments, so be sure to do a lot of reading of the textbook and try and remember even things that may seem superfluous or that you'd be able to look up on the man pages. Make friends in precept so you can get a good partner for buffer overrun and heap manager. Expect debugging to take a long time, and expect the course to take more of your time than 126 or 226 did (I recommend taking it fall semester so you have winter break for the final project), but expect also to learn a ton.
Definitely make sure this is on the classes you prioritize and do the readings and make sure to look at all of the resources given to you to complete assignments.

Definitely start assignments way, WAY early. Don't be afraid to approach the professor and preceptor with questions, because you probably will have to. Utilize all the myriad of resources you have available.
Definitely take it. Not as hard as people say, and after taking it you truly understand computers.

Definitely take it. You have to if you're a cos major or getting the certificate, but it's really a very well done class and gives great insight. Both Petras and Bob are excellent and incredibly devoted.

Definitely take this class. It will be one of your challenging courses, but the rewards is definitely worth the hard work, and your programming skills will improve significantly. Do try to review the lecture slides before and after every lecture, and go to office hours immediately to clear up any conceptual questions.
Definitely take this course if you are interested in learning more about how computers really work at a lower level, but be prepared for the course load.
Definitely take this course! The programming assignments can be a lot of work, so start early, but you are given everything necessary to complete the assignments.
Definitely take this course. Start assignments early and don't be afraid to ask your preceptor for help. Office hours are very valuable.
Do the readings, and start your assignments early. Attend lectures, definitely, and you have to attend the precepts if you want guidance on how to do the assignments.
Do the readings, go to lecture, and you'll learn a lot. It's worth it.
Don't take this class during a particularly busy semester.
Dondero is a great lecturer.  I would highly recommend Iasonas Petras as a preceptor.
Dondero is the savior.

Even if you have no desire to go further in systems programming, this course is a must for everyone. Dondero is an fantastic lecturer, and the whole course is well-organized and thoughtfully structured, which is important for the conveying of this somewhat complex subject. The course essentially bridges the gap between the high-level and abstract programming we are used to and the physical machine itself. But be prepared to put in a fair amount of work on the assignments, and for the exams, make sure you understand all the quirks and nuances of the C language.
Get a head start on all of your assignments. And go to office hours! Don't be afraid to ask questions or get something clarified.
Get assignments done eaerly
Get into Dondero's precept--it is everything it is hyped up to be!!!
Good class but time consuming - only take if you are interested in lower level computer programming or are a COS major or certificate.
Good class, interesting assignments, but they TAKE TIME.

Great CS course - systems are really interesting and this is a great way to feel like you are really learning from the bottom up rather than just layering on top without really getting the fundamentals.  Grading can be a little confusing and assignments vague at times, but you'll learn a lot so it may not matter too much.
Great class, but a lot of work.
Great introduction to systems.  Hopefully you'll get Dondero.
Harder than 226. Lots of memorizing
Honestly only take this if you're trying to get the certificate or be a major. I hated it.
Huge time sink.

I think this course is mostly only taken by students who have take it (like COS majors), and I always heard that it was a really hard course before I took it, but honestly that was over-exaggerated and I don't think it will be as bad you'd expect it to be
I would definitely take it!
I would not suggest this to someone as a casual course, but for a COS major I would tell them to manage their time properly and they will not have a hard time with the course.
I would recommend it, but just be aware that PDF is not allowed and it is a large time sink. I wouldn't take it with a large courseload or any other very time consuming class, which is what I did.
If you are at all interested in computers and their inner workings, take this class. It's not as hard as you've probably heard it is. It's comparable to other COS classes.
If you get Dondero for your precept, you're at an advantage, because he explains things really well. Go to his office hours if you need help

If you have done COS 126 and are considering some computer science path take this course as soon as possible. Don't let rumors of it being hard intimidate you. Even if it gets hard there so much help(from precepts to office hours) that you will come out understanding and doing so much more than you thought you could.

If you have to take it you have to take it - basically COS majors/minors. You'll suffer but you'll come out more knowledgable on the other side. You can afford not to go to lecture or buy the book, but definitely go to precept and start early on the assignments!!! It's not like 126 where you get it done in 2 hours. If you're not at least considering doing a certificate steer well clear, it'll just be unnecessary pain.
If you liked COS 126 and want to continue in computer science, I highly recommend taking this course.

If you took COS 126 and are looking to take a higher level COS class, go with 226 over 217.  If you do take 217, keep up with the lectures and get started on the assignments early as they are usually very time consuming.
If you're at all interested in learning computer science beyond COS 126, take this course! It's extremely thorough and well-taught.

If you're taking this course, you're probably getting a  COS degree or certificate so its required. Either way, if you plan to do anything with COS in the future, the things you learn in this course is essential.
It is definitely a course worth taking if you are at all interested in the systems side of COS. Even if you have to take this course as a major it is very friendly.
It is important to start your assignments early.
It takes time and is not an easy course, but is not what many hype it up to be. More difficult than COS226, but with much more ample time to properly allocate your time.

It taught a lot about structures and how to organize code, as well as the history and backend to a lot of things that people generally don't know too much about, but which can be useful still when working at a higher level.
It was a great course to take. I would recommend it to others who enjoy low-level coding.
It won't be easy, but it will be worth it.

It's a fantastic course, and although assignments do take longer than in 226, they are easier to understand, and the material in the class is easy to understand as well so you don't have to spend as much time on learning the material. Also the readings aren't really necessary. Try to get Dondero as your preceptor because he's so helpful with explaining the most important concepts, and really takes the time to help his students at office hours (and goes overtime), even if he is super-busy. However, overall I was not as interested in the material of the class as 226, so depending on whether you like easy classes that are tedious(cos 217), or hard classes that are less time-consuming(cos 226), you may or may not like the class.
It's a good class.
Its an interesting course - make sure you understand every lecture slide to do well on the tests.
Medicine. One of the hardest courses at Princeton but you will also learn the most in this class. Not for someone who's not serious about coding.
None.
Not always fun, but very useful.

Not bad at all. Frankly, I really enjoyed it. Coming straight from COS 126 and hearing all the negatives surrounding 217, I was not optimistic. But after taking this course, and having Dondero as a preceptor, I definitely feel like it was much better than what most people say. Some of the assignments may seem overwhelming, but the latter ones are pretty straightforward. Personally, I liked learning the lower level languages and really understanding how abstract concepts actually get executed. If possible, get started on assignments early and try to get Dondero if he's precepting. Otherwise, follow the suggestions on the assignment page and post questions on Piazza.

Of course, it's a COS departmental, so COS majors have to take it. Doing well on the exams is mainly about memorising most of the details mentioned on the lecture slides/in class. You come out having learned a lot more about the system-level functioning of computers, which I think is just as important as understanding algorithms.
Only take if actually interested in the material.
Only take this course without other major coding classes. I made the (huge) mistake of taking this with 226 and my grades reflect that.
Piazza can be helpful.

Pragmatically this course is hard to evaluate. This course is exciting, challenging, stimulating, and once you're done, you really feel like you've learned a lot. 
On the other hand, this course is incredibly difficult and does drain a lot of time. It's not unfair in its time drain, but it's still a drain. If you like computer science, you're interested in pursuing further studies in computer science, if you want to have any kind of relationship to computer science further than its a thing that I know exists, this class is strongly recommended. Otherwise, probably not.

Really teaches you how computer systems work, which is vital knowledge for anyone interested in computer science. More so time consuming than it is challenging, but it is very time consuming in debugging.

Required for COS majors, but non COS should take this too if you?re interested in how the computer works in the lower levels. Assignments are mostly instructional and don?t allow for much creativity until the final assignment. Find a good preceptor who knows what he/she is teaching, because you?ll find it much easier if you can get the concepts in precept rather than on your own. The class is fast paced and builds on itself very rapidly so at all costs DON?T FALL BEHIND. You?ll be much more equipped to deal with the underlying machinery of computers after this class.
Sign up for a precept after lecture. Start assignments early, they can take a lot more time than in 126/226 because of complex bugs.
Start assignments EARLY. The Shell program will take you a full work week to complete, so do it over the winter break.

Start assignments early, particularly the final assignment. It will save you lots of tears. At least skim the readings when you are doing the assignments or before lecture. It will help you tremendously in saving time and for exams. Enjoyable class, not sure if it is worth it if you aren't a COS major, but lower level concepts are definitely interesting.
Start assignments early.
Start early!

Start the assignments early, as you never know when you will encounter a bug and it can be extremely difficult to pinpoint even the smallest bugs. Don't take this class with 5 classes, because it is extremely time consuming.
Start the assignments early. They take a long time, especially if you have a hard bug to find. But its a great class, have fun with it!

THIS IS A GREAT COURSE! Start on the assignments early, especially right after the last precept you have that's relevant to the current assignment. If you're working on it before the last relevant precept and you get stuck, wait until that precept because often major questions you have will be answered in upcoming relevant precepts.

Take 217! If Dondero lectures again, then you owe it to yourself to take this class. The lecture slides are excellent when combined with the required reading. If you end up with Dondero as a preceptor as well, then you'll do very well on all your assignments. The assignments take about 2-2.5 days on average (with your other classes included) so it's best to do them as soon as possible. If you get really, really stuck, you can send him the code and he'll go out of his way and annotate it for you like an English paper! I mean who does that?? Overall, the course is very well-organized so I highly recommend it!
Take it if it have to only because it's a lot of work. Still, it is very well designed and taught.

Take it if you are interested in computer systems and aren't taking a brutal schedule already. The assignments are tough and make you want to pull your hair out sometime, but making a bash shell in the final assignment is unbelievably rewarding. The course is also one of the most organized and well run that I've had at Princeton, which makes it extremely easy to study and get help. I highly recommend Prof. Dondero and Raghav Sethi as a preceptor.
Take it if you have a lot of time. It feels like 1.5 classes.
Take it if you have the time. It's great. A lot of work, but not that bad if you're willing to put the time in. Make sure to do well on the assignments and understand them thoroughly.
Take it if you have to! Start early on the programs!
Take it if you want to do anything that involves a lot of programming
Take it! It is a little bit challenging but the knowledge you learn in this course will be really helpful in the future.
Take it! It's a lot of fun if you like coding, and you learn so much about how computers work. Start on the assignments early, especially the ones after midterms.
Take it! It's not as bad as everyone says - it's can be a lot of hours of work, but that's because of debugging. The material itself isn't that difficult.
Take it, be prepared to spend many hours on assignments.
Take it.
Take it. In the fall. Do the shell assignment over Christmas break. Also do the assembly assignment over fall break.
Take it. You'll become a better programmer and understand how your computer works, sort of.
Take the class if and only if Robert Dondero is teaching.
Take this class if you are pursuing a COS certificate and obviously a major, but think twice if you aren't very interested in computer science. It's a lot of work but very rewarding in the end.

Take this course if you want to gain insight into how your computer actually works under the hood. Dondero is a great lecturer. And get Raghav if he's still teaching a precept next year -- he's awesome.
Take this course!
Take this only you need to for a COS degree. Otherwise, take a different, more useful COS class.s

The assignments are difficult as others will say but there is a lot of support and even the Assembly assignment has good documentation on how to complete the assignment.  Don't be afraid to shop precepts if you can.  Finding a good preceptor is really helpful.
The class has a bad reputation for being a lot of work. It's really not that bad.

This class takes a considerable amount of time, mostly devoted to assignments, but if you pay close attention to lectures and the conceptual level, you will spend less time on assignments, because they are truly tied in really well to lecture material.

This is a VERY time consuming class. Start the assignments early and go to office hours. Keep up with the work and pay attention in precepts when they go over the assignments. Also, stay organized with all the handouts that are given, they are helpful if you can find where you put them!

This is a fantastic course. Definitely learnt a lot about programming systems and emerged as a better programmer. Don't worry about not having enough experience in programming before coming into the course. They really make sure to teach you everything you need to know / use.

This is a fantastic course. Yes, the programming assignments can be grueling, but the material is so well organized. Dondero is amazing and truly cares about his students. He loves teaching. If you're a COS major, you have to take it, but it's such an important class to learn how a computer functions. It's a ton of work, so if you don't have to take it and want a light schedule, COS 217 is not for you. Nonetheless, if you have any interest in computer systems, you'll have a great time. Overall, very rewarding experience and you learn a ton.
This is a great course - Dondero is a good lecturer, and the material is very interesting. Be prepared to spend a lot of time - usually a minimum of 15 hours per week outside of class.
This is a rewarding but very time-consuming and challenging course.
This is definitely one of the most well-taught classes I've taken at Princeton. I would highly recommend it if you're interested in computer science.

This is easily the best course I have taken at Princeton thus far. However, be careful about the amount of work you're taking on - if this will be a heavy semester, then I would think twice about this class if you do not have experience in computer science. For an experienced programmer, though, still be prepared to spend a good deal of time on the assignments.
This is the worst experience of my life. Take this class and die.
Very hard class, but quite interesting overall. Take it, but make it your hardest class in a given semester.

We had Dondero as lecturer. It's a great class, and effort is rewarded. That means, go to lecture, be awake during lecture, do the readings, go to office hours for debugging, and then ask questions. There's no lack of resources, but you DO NEED TO HAVE TIME TO MAKE USE OF THOSE RESOURCES. But you'll learn a lot, and maybe make a few friends with the partner assignments.
Work hard and you will learn a lot.
You have to take this course. The assignments will take you a long time, but they are rewarding. I didn't learn anything in lecture, but who knows, you might.

You learn a ton of information packed tightly into a short semester, so be sure not to leave your assignments till the last moment. Everything they teach you will come up in an assignment or an exam. If you don't understand something in precept, ask for clarification right away. I've probably learned more from this course than any other course I've taken at Princeton. Overall, very rewarding and strongly recommended. Beware: much harder than COS 226. The assignments are very large.
You probably have to do it to learn these things, but this class isn't a lot of fun.
You're probably taking this because you have to, and it will be difficult, but it's also a fascinating course 90% of the time.
considerable time commitment, but a valuable course if you are motivated to learn this specific side of computer science
hard!!!!!!!!!! very very difficult but worth it
only if you are a cos major
take it if you love cos
prereqs: COS 126 (recommended), or approval by COS placement officer..
descrip: Introduction to programming systems, including modular programming, advanced program design, programming style, test, debugging and performance tuning; machine languages and assembly language; and use of system call services.

title: The Rise of France: French Literature, Culture, and Society from the Beginnings to 1789
reviews: Be prepared to read large amounts of challenging texts, but also to engage with some of the most interesting literature of pre-Revolutionary France
Do not take this course unless you are already extremely proficient in French. It will not help improve your speaking or writing.
If you're interested in the topic and have a fairly strong reading ability, this might be a good one for you to take.
Make sure that your level of French is good enough to benefit from it.
Take it
prereqs: Prerequisites: FRE 107, FRE 108, or equivalent, or permission of Instructor..
descrip: This course introduces students to French literature, history and culture from the Middle Ages to the French Revolution by focusing on the themes of travel, exploration and exchange. From the medieval literature of quest and crusade through Early Modern and Enlightenment narratives of travel to the Americas and Asia, we will examine how French cultural and political consciousness develops through representations of exoticism and otherness. Texts to be read include: La Chanson de Roland, Le Devisement du Monde of Marco Polo, Les Lettres Persanes of Montesquieu and Voltaire's classic Candide. Readings, discussion and written work in French.

title: General Physics I
reviews: A good preceptor makes all the difference.  Other than that, listen during lectures, complete the assignments, and study for quizzes.  The course is very well-organized, so you should be able to do okay.  The labs are some of the most boring three-hour spans you will ever experience, but you just have to get through them.
Always study for the quizzes, they are harder than you think.
Ask questions in class!
Attend all lectures !
Attend all the precepts.
Attend every precept because you can ask questions and keep up with the material.

Attend precept. It is much more helpful than the lectures. Also, be double careful when submitting your problem sets online, a misplacement of a parentheses can yield the wrong results. Preparation for the course will take a lot of time, but if you space yourself out you'll be fine.
Attend precepts and spend time on the problem sets.
Be sure to read from the textbook.
Be warned it is a time-consuming and intensive course.
Before lecture, it would probably be best to read the textbook so it's not wasted time.
Course instruction is unclear, so don't take the class unless you've already taken some sort of physics before. I would not have understood what was going on if I had not taken physics before.
DON'T DO BSE.
Definitely make sure to keep up with the material! The course moves quickly.
Definitely worth it. Don't believe all the horror stories about the labs. They are not at all fun, but they get better as the semester goes on.

Difficult course. Don't take unless you have to. If you do, get Professor Bernevig. He is both amusing and genuinely helpful and engaging. Labs are utterly useless and often infuriating, so just accept that and count them down until the end.
Do a lot of book problems.
Do a lot of practice outside of the homework problems as it is necessary to prepare for the exams.
Do as many supplementary problems as possible. Write lab notes before going to lab to ensure that you know what you are going to do (saves time)
Do every homework before it is due. Make use of office hours. GO TO PRECEPT.

Do practice problems often. Get the Expert Ta out of the way early in the week and don't stress about it.
Do problem sets in advance.
Do your assignments and go to office hours.You get as much back as you put into this course.

Don't fall behind from the start, almost impossible to get back on track later on.

Get Dr. Visnjic as preceptor, and make sure you understand everything in precept.  Go to office hours if you need help,
Get Pufu as your preceptor! He is adorable and helps you solve hard problems. He also does a great pre-quiz review on Mondays before the weekly quiz

Great class! Labs are annoying and lectures can be rough. But I enjoyed the material covered and the way we were tested on it very much!

I recommend that they read the textbook previous to lecture.
I would advise them to keep track of the online homework due dates and do the assignments before they are due so you can follow along in class easier.

I would suggest that if a student wanted to take this course and was sufficiently interested in the subject matter that they should do so.

I would tell another student to make sure he/she attends all classes, as they are instrumental in learning to work problems. For engineers, this course is crucial. I am not sure that I would take it if I were an AB student not interested in physics, as it does demand a lot of time.

This course is pretty simple and would be a decent STL.
This course is very interesting and you will learn a lot.  It can definitely be difficult at times, but you will get a lot out of it if you put in effort.
