title: Advanced Organic Chemistry
reviews: Attend all lectures!!

I strongly recommend the biosynthesis half of this course. Professor Groves is a great lecturer and you will learn a lot about some amazing things. Unless Professor Reider's half of the course becomes more organized, you won't learn much.
I you are well-versed in organic chemistry and like it, definitely take it.  Be ready to listen in class and catch on the details the professors want you to remember
Make sure you understand everything from the lectures!
Take this course if you are very interested in synthetic organic chemistry.

Take this, but more for the topics than for the actual puzzle-solving of Organic Chemistry from 303/304. If you enjoyed that, there won't be as much opportunity for that here. The class is relaxed and overall enjoyable. Ask a lot of question, because the professors are really knowledgeable!

This was a very good course, but also it was disorganized at times. You often will not know what is expected, especially for the exams. 
However, Professor Reider is a very interesting lecturer, as is Professor Groves, and you will be introduced to a lot of great synthetic chemists and come to understand a lot about how real world problems lead to synthesis, biosynthesis of medicines and other molecules. 
There is a problem set every other week, so overall it is not too much work. However, the problem sets can be hard and unclear, so leave time to ask questions of the TAs.
prereqs: CHM 301 and CHM 302, or CHM 303 and CHM 304, or equivalent laboratory courses..
descrip: A selection of advanced topics in organic chemistry, including organic synthesis, organic reaction mechanisms, biosynthetic pathways, and elements of modern drug design.

title: Topics in Low Dimensional Topology - Symplectic techniques in low-dimensional topology
prereqs: The course will assume familiarity with basic differential topology and Morse theory..
descrip: This course covers current topics in Low Dimensional Topology. For Fall 2013, this course focuses on invariants for low-dimensional manifolds derived from methods of symplectic geometry. We will discuss Floer homology from the point of view of grid diagrams, Heegaard Floer homology, and bordered Floer homology.

title: Design, Synthesis, and Optimization of Chemical Processes
reviews: Absolutely take it. It is a lot of work, but it is extremely important, and the real world application is evident in every assignment. The project prepares you for an extremely advanced level of chemical engineering, utilizing optimization at the highest degree that could be taught.
Be prepared to spend long hours in the design lab and get close to your design partners. Go to office hours a lot and get all the help you can get from your TA!

Be prepared to treat Design like a part time job. Don't be surprised if you work on it 20 hours a week. For the first report - split up the readings and do them ahead of time. Don't worry about understanding all of it, just get through it and discuss with your group. Start simulations as soon as you can and get started early on the GAMS assignment. A lot of this advice might be irrelevant since Floudas is gone, but just in case, this is what I found helpful.

This course is unwieldy, time-consuming, and mind-numbing. Take breaks and stay sane. Embrace living in the Equad because if it isn't already, it's your home now. You've made it this far with CBE, you can do it.

CBE 442 was not the worst experience of my life.

Do not scoff! Do not roll your eyes! I do not jest! Like you, I have known loss, heartbreak, deceit, and disillusionment. In comparison, Design was trivial. A mere grain of sand added to the pile of bricks on my heart.

However.

However? but no. I cannot begin there. For you to understand the impact of Design on my life, you must first understand me, at least a little. For how do we explain ourselves but through narrative?

I came to Princeton, wide-eyed and eager, ready to dive into CBE, the major of my choice. I will not lie to you ? CBE is not an easy road. I watched many of my peers leave their CBE homeland for greener pastures and whiter shores. But as much as I enjoyed complaining about it, I thrived on the struggle. I thought Reactors was interesting. I enjoyed Core Lab! I didn?t expect senior year to be much different. I had read the reviews of Design ? who hasn?t? I knew what people said. But I also knew that CBE is a major populated with people who don?t really want to be here, who would rather be bioengineers or materials scientists or environmental engineers. I assumed they were the Design detractors. So I opened my mind and my heart to Design.

The first three or four weeks were easy. Easier, certainly, than Thermo was at the time. I thought I was safe. Even the first report, which caused me to set a new record for how late I stayed up, was pleasant in its way. Then came AspenPlus, and eight straight evenings spent in the Design Lab. Then I broke the staying-up-late record I had set just a few weeks before to finish the second report. Then came the third exam. Then the third report, on which my partners and I spent an estimated 200 hours over the first seven days of reading period.
 
To you CBE juniors, sophomores, and freshmen: thank your lucky sigmas that Professor Floudas will not be teaching Design next year, and pray to whatever gamma you worship that the next professor will look upon you with more pity and generosity.

Pros
-	Cried three times ? very cleansing for my tear ducts!
-	I now realize that I am capable of surviving every mental and emotional hurdle I am likely to face in my professional career.
-	My feeling that I am superior to students in almost every other major at this school has solidified into a certainty.

Cons
-	The scars on my soul will never fade. 

Let me be serious now. Design is not a bad class, nor is its professor evil. Someday I might even be grateful for it, as we are grateful for any experience that strengthens us. But Design 2014-2015 made me suffer, when I did not want to suffer. I did not want the major I chose to punish me for my choice. To the CBE major in general: if you bite the hand that feeds you, you will not survive the lean winter. (To AIChE, the organization responsible in part: ditto. To Princeton: it?s time to make a Bioengineering major. And a Materials Science major. Your students are certainly paying enough.) To the next design professor: do not let the way things were dictate how they shall be.
 
Logan Matthews, you deserve a shout-out for making this class six times more bearable. The state of New Jersey is sorry to see you go. The state of Texas, and the world, is lucky to have you.

Future Designers: CHOOSE A GOOD GROUP! My partners and I worked well together and had fun, and I love them all the more for all we accomplished together.
One last thing: I have long thought that Princeton students unreasonably think they are entitled to A?s, but to everyone who has turned out a halfway decent Design report and not failed the exams: Floudas may not have seen fit to give you an A on your transcript, but you are a winner.

Choose your group members well! Make sure everyone works similarly--work ethic, the time in the day you work best, etc. Also, make sure you establish early on in the process what your expectations are for one another. This will definitely make it easier later on! Also, it can't be stressed enough how important it is to start the project EARLY! You will definitely run into computer issues that will take a lot longer than you think to resolve. Take advantage of the office hours. Try to enjoy the process because otherwise you will find it miserable--think positively!

Don't take it unless you're a senior in CBE ... which means you're stuck anyway. Course requires too much effort for a semester (waay more than HUM sequence); On the project, TAs are instructed to give as little guidance as possible, which means they sometimes avoid answering your questions / don't give you complete answers... which can be annoying.
Get started on all of the tasks early, and the TA's are super helpful. ASPEN is a pain, I felt like I built more character from it than brains.

Hopefully, now that a new professor is teaching the course, it will be a bit easier. Regardless, be sure to start the design project early, and try to get partners with whom you get along really well, especially during prolonged periods of stress.

I don't know what it will be like now that Floudas isn't teaching it anymore, but this year it was 4 exams and the project (only worth 35% of the grade). Some of the exams are fine but some are harder. Floudas never released past finals or assigned psets so you won't really know what to expect. Just take good lecture notes. For the project, make sure you have a good group above all. That can completely change your experience. Start early. Do not underestimate the amount of time this project takes. Make sure your other classes are chill. There were so many weeks this semester where we were in the design lab day and night. Aspen is inherently a bitch and GAMS is so annoying, but if you put in a good amount of time and effort, you will survive. Everyone survives in the end. To be honest, I enjoyed the work and course material more than some of the other CBE classes I've taken. The project can be pretty interesting, you will bond so much with your fellow CBEs, and it is satisfying to have accomplished it all. Just keep pushing through, and you'll be okay in the end.
If you're CBE, be prepared to be very frustrated.
Interesting, but way way way too much work. Just get through it
It doesn't matter whether or not I recommend this course. You have to take it. It's super time consuming.
It is a struggle, but it's worth it.

Now that Floudas is gone, I am not sure how difficult the class will be. Important things are to get a group that has the same priorities and working schedule as you. Starting early is very important. Also, office hours will be super helpful, especially because the instructions are very general. And try to not waste away your fall semester on this class. The project is only a portion of the grade anyways.

Oh my goodness where do I even begin. For the past three years you've been hearing older students talk about how hard design is...everything you imagine it to be, it's 10x worse. 4 exams AND a project, and half the project deadlines are the same day as an exam...it's brutal. It's absolutely brutal. Don't expect to have much of a life during this course, just get cozy in design lab (at least they've let sunlight back into the room now). But try to enjoy it. Enjoy your group partners, and enjoy the late nights because it's the last time ever you're going to be together with your entire CBE class doing the late nights all in one room. Bring food with you to the lab because you'll get hungry. But don't leave a mess because then you'll get an email from the department lecturing you about leaving the room messy during the "occasional times you have to use design lab out of class hours". 

I sincerely wish you the best of luck.
Take really really good notes. Start early on projects.

This course tests endurance more than smarts, as in expect to spend your entire week in the design room the week the report is due and to pull a few all-nighters throughout the semester. I would make sure to study well for the exams since they are worth a good chunk of your grade. I learned a lot, but that was to be expected given how much time I spent on this class. Also, make sure you choose group members who actually do work and whom you work well with, otherwise your life will be 10x as miserable.

This course will probably be changing structurally, but if it does stay the same/is similar, here are some pointers. 

1. Have hope. This is the last required CBE class.
2. But also, just to keep you grounded, here's a stress gauge. Think core lab is bad? Multiply that by 10 and you'll get the first report for design. The rest scales exponentially.
3. Logistical stuff: Pick group members that have the same work ethic as you do. This may mean not working with your friends. Start early and go to office hours. Don't forget that you have other courses and don't forget that your group members have other courses. Don't have unrealistic expectations for your group members and don't get frustrated with them if you think they're not performing--they are trying their best too.

Treat the workload for this course as the equivalent of 3 normal courses. Expect to spend a lot of time in the design lab working on each of the projects. Get started early, and don't be shy about going to office hours. You will learn a lot, and you will become a lot closer with your classmates.
Well, good luck.
Work on design all the time.
You have no choice. Start on the projects early and be sure to go to office hours. This class is a real pain in the ass but you get a good sense of satisfaction when you're done.

You thought core lab was a lot work, haha. This is by far the most work intensive CBE course. It requires a lot of persistence and late nights. However, how it is taught may be different now since Professor Floudas is leaving. It is sad that the next classes of Princeton CBE students won't be able to take a course with him. He was my favorite professor in the entire department. This course has been the highlight of my CBE education.
You're a CBE.  You've come this far.  This is probably harder than any class you've ever taken before at Princeton, but it's not impossible.  Hang in there!
prereqs: CBE 341 and CBE 441..
descrip: Introduction to chemical process flow-sheeting; process simulation design, sizing and cost estimation of total processes; process economics; introduction to optimization, linear programming, integer programming, and nonlinear programming; heat integration methods, minimum utility cost, minimum number of units, network optimization.

title: Coding Theory and Random Graphs
reviews: Current iteration of the course is about 70% coding theory 30% random graphs.  Problem sets pretty difficult. Final project is rewarding.
Good course, do attend lectures
Take it if you are interested in the material
This is a great course with an awesome professor -- take this!

This was a really great survey course. I would recommend this to anyone who is interested in the topics covered. The course project is also a great opportunity to gain a more in-depth understanding of your favorite topic in coding or random graph theory.
a nice course
prereqs: Linear algebra and some exposure to probability theory.
descrip: This introductory course to coding theory and random graphs covers the basics in each field and the interplay between them. The coding part covers algebraic codes, distance bounds, polar codes, expander codes and LDPC codes. The random graph part covers threshold phenomena, connectivity, giant component, subgraph containment and sharp thresholds. Recent developments in random CSPs and community detection are also discussed, in particular the stochastic block model. The class is proof oriented. Some of the techniques presented are currently used in real-world applications, while others lie at the heart of network data science.

title: Research Seminar in Empirical Investigation
descrip: Preparation of research papers based on field observation, laboratory experiments, survey procedures, and secondary analysis of existing data banks.

title: Topics in Environmental Studies - Building American Style: Land-Use Policies and Rules
reviews: I would recommend that students do the readings, but would also caution that the Poppers bring a very particular perspective to the field, and that one needs to read more than one perspective to get a full picture of urban planning.
Minimal workload, pretty easy to BS something for class participation. But did I actually learn that much? Meh.
Take notes.
Take this course! Wonderful choice of a seminar.
This class is the best! Take it...Professors Popper have an awesome dynamic and make this class really fun.
Wonderful instructors; take this class if you are interested in the subject matter.
take it but there are classes that are better taught.
descrip: Americans have built and preserved an astounding variety of environments. The course examines the evolving complex of incentives and regulations that drove the choices of where and how places developed. It focuses on the emergence of land-use and environmental planning as a way to encourage or discourage growth and to mitigate or intensify its environmental, social, and economic effects.We will examine the latest tools for building and protecting the American landscape. Case studies include Southern California, New Haven, the American Great Plains, and others. Analysis will be from historical, policy-oriented, and predictive perspectives.

title: The Anthropology of Art
reviews: Rosen is always a great and interesting professor, but if you're not interested in art, you might find it a bit boring.
Take it! It's interesting, thought-provoking, workload is pleasant, and you get an inside peek at Princeton's amazing art collection.
Take it! Professor Rosen is an amazing professor.

This is a really interesting course that will probably make you think about art, museums, and similar topics in ways you never have before. The workload is quite low. Professor Rosen is really great to talk to.
You should take this course!  Professor Rosen is a great guy, and does a good job of creating an interesting seminar discussion.  The workload is highly manageable.
take it!
descrip: We will consider the relation of art to magic, religious ritual, and hierarchy and power within particular cultures. How have broad theories of 'primitive' art reflected our own culture's concern with analysing human nature, evolutionary theory, and the articulation of presumed psychological universals? How are such representations connected to ideas of time, narrative style, storytelling, political propaganda in specific cultures for which the holdings of the university museum are particularly appropriate? We will use materials from the Northwest Coast of North America, Australia, New Zealand, the Arctic, and early modern Europe.

title: Mitigating Climate Change
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Soccer and Latin America: Politics, History and Popular Culture
descrip: Please see website

title: Computing and Imaging in Architecture
reviews: Do not expect a computation seminar. Ryan will not lead you through tutorials. He will teach you how to find the information you need to teach yourself.
Go with an open mind. work a lot.
It is better to be familiar in some parts of the techniques that would be used in the course. Otherwise, it is hard to follow and also hard to let other student to cooperate with.
Know Processing (or Java) beforehand.
Take this course if you are knowledgeable enough to problem solve coding, electronics, etc. by yourself.
descrip: This course on digital media infrastructure will explore breaking technologies of fabrication, modeling and design based on production pipelines pioneered by the film and gaming industries--pipelines we will author in CATIA, McNeel's Rhino/Grasshopper, and Bentley's Generative Components. A series of formal experiments will be carried out each culminating in the fabrication of rapid prototypes using the CNC mill and the InVision 3D printer, explicitly challenging conventional modes of practice and seeking insight into new forms of organization, techniques and operative procedures.

title: Operations and Information Engineering
reviews: . The first half of the course is learning various OR-type things, like economic order quantity, newsvendor problem, etc. Second half is all OJ game, plus lectures you probably will skip since they don't have much to do with the game. I think it's better if everyone on your team can at least understand what everyone else is doing. This way you can help each other out instead of sitting around wondering what to do next and you can interface the stuff you work on with everyone else's better. Inevitably though people carve out pieces of the project for themselves, and only they understand what their piece does. It's important to maintain a good team atmosphere - if your team starts doing poorly, try not to hate each other. Teams essentially maintain their original rankings. So put a lot of effort into the first year of business, because if you start behind you will never recover. Rankings change only when a team makes a serious mistake and falls behind--this is more likely to happen on OJ bowl day. So it's important to rehearse what you'll do that day, and if you decide to automate decision making and analysis procedures, check to make sure that your code is bug-free. Unfortunately there are no OJ bowl day practice runs. Many teams end up building a simulator of the actual OJ game simulator, and in fact the instructors suggest that you do so. Do so, and make good choices about what language to write it in, how to make it extensible so that it accommodates any parameters you throw at it. It's up to you how closely the simulator mimics the actual simulator. Closer is harder of course. The expressiveness of an actual programming language beats the heck out of Excel, but you will end up using a decent amount of Excel, especially since your decisions and results come in Excel files. So learn to interface programming languages with Excel.
A very fun and interesting course.
Be prepared to invest a lot of time in the OJ game. Start early, because the first few runs can have a huge impact on the final standings.
Be prepared to spend much more time in the second half of the semester
Be prepared to work a lot and still not make a great grade, but if you're ORFE this class is required.  It's pretty interesting, but the midterm is tedious, as are the problem sets in the first half.
Don't take it if you're not an ORFE.  It's a lot of work.
Good luck on OJ Game!
Gotta take it if you're ORF... wouldn't take it if you're not. Budget lots of time for OJ game.

I found this class fun, and relatively light workload-wise (although OJ game is not insignificant). Obviously most people taking this class are doing it because it is mandatory, but I thought it was decent overall.

I would say take this course only if you have to for ORFE.  It's not the worst ORFE class I've taken but it is really time consuming in the second half of the course so you really have to be prepared to put in the time for the OJ game.
If its not required, do not take it. The assigned groups can be some new friends or can completely ruin your semester and it is a lot of work.

If you are not ORF, you have zero reason to be in this class. It is everything bad about the corporate workplace, that is, having to work with others who have their own schedules, having to work on something that makes no sense and is meaningless, and doing work that doesn't give any results, and none of the good, that is, getting paid and possibly making a difference or advancing your career. 

If you are ORF, and you're not really interested in finance/financial engineering, switch out. You're better off being ECO or COS or MAT and taking the ORF classes that are well taught and actually interest you and avoiding ORF 411, ORF 405, ORF 307, and ORF 245. And even if you're interested in finance, ECO might be a better route and will be more flexible.

The only way you might enjoy OJ game is if you like to work hard and win, have a great group that is smart and wants to work hard and wants to win, you love Powell, and you get lucky. Otherwise, you'll learn to hate a game that is opaque, makes no sense, takes a ton of work to get little to no results, has no meaningful application, isn't even a good application of the things you learn in class, has a finicky submission process, is stressful if you care about your grades and demotivating if you don't, is impossible to recover from if you mess up, and ends up only counting for 20% of your grade (with writeups and team evals counting for another 30%). You don't even learn anything, except all the different ways the sun can rise, or what you hate about group projects, or the mind of the person who wrote up the simulation (who left the university years ago), or that ORF was a mistake. 

I'm not gonna lie, Dr. Simao is a great guy (we didn't have Powell, except for one guest lecture where he wasn't happy with what the  guest lecturer talked about and kept asking him to talk about other things), but he can't redeem what an abomination the OJ game is. 

Believe it or not, this class did have lectures, which are okay if you think of it not as mind blowing models but just basic models to use as starting points and a framework to think about modeling in. But it's not that interesting and doesn't require a whole class to think about. All the same, you won't remember anything you learned in class, just how mind-blowingly stupid the OJ game is.
It's a core course so you have to take it. But still a decent course.

Just beware that the OJ game will be VERY time-consuming.  Try not to stress too much about your team's profit because it makes the game a lot more stressful than it needs to be.  Get a good leader and contribute to your group.

No pain, no gain. You probably have to take it as an ORFE Senior. Take it for Prof. Simao and the amount of care and effort he puts in to make the lectures exciting. Tips for the OJ game:
1. Force your team to start over Fall Break. If you're a leader, dont just send an email, make sure work actually gets done.
2. Think simply and strategically. Dont overthink it
3. Building a simulator is not as essential as some people will make it sound. Use all your resources to ensure your transportation optimization and purchasing strategy is being done the best it can.
4. Pricing is the name of the game. If you figure this out - you've got the game. Good luck!
ORF has to take the course.  OJ game is fun but super hard and challenging.  Get a good group

Obviously ORFE majors have to take this course. If you're not an ORFE major, take this course only if you're planning to put in the same, if not more, hours than your ORFE counterparts because the OJ game team section everybody is expected to pull his or her own weight.
Take the course if you enjoy competition; the  OJ Game is a competition and determines most of your grade.
The OJ game is a huge time commitment and will dominate the second-half of your semester. That being said, many students get a lot out of the experience.
The OJ game is rewarding but also extremely time consuming and exhausting. Overall still a very good experience, but the first half of the course was very disconnected from the second.
The midterm matters more than you think! Pretty well taught but the lectures are online so going to class is sometimes not necessary. There's a lot of overlap with ORF 418
The problem sets are not that thrilling but the OJ game is an outstanding learning experience if you have enough time to devote to it.
Unless you're an ORFE major or very committed to playing the OJ Game, don't take it.
You have to. Sucks for us.
You probably don't have a choice. The OJ game is very time consuming.

advice is most needed for the OJ game. the teams are assigned based on a "skill" assessment which is incredibly useless bc overconfident idiots will rate themselves highly at something, while someone who is actually really good at it may rate themselves low to increase their chances of having more skilled people on their team. when the teams were announced there was a notable reaction from the class re: two really good teams in particular, so clearly it's not working. There was pretty limited guidance on such a huge problem, so in retrospect the first few weeks/years of the game were probably 80% of the whole thing in terms of importance, bc not having a good strategy for just one run could ruin you bad enough that even making as much as everyone else in the second run would still be a setback you could never recover from.
the OJ game is a huge drain on your time but is so worth it - you'll learn a lot of really practical skills and if your group is good it'll be that much more fun.
prereqs: ORF 245/ECO 300, ORF 307/MAT 305, ORF 309.
descrip: The management of complex systems through the control of physical, financial and informational resources. The course focuses on developing mathematical models for resource allocation, with an emphasis on capturing the role of information in decisions. The course seeks to integrate skills in statistics, stochastics and optimization using applications drawn from problems in dynamic resource management which tests modeling skills and teamwork.

title: Advanced Russian through Film
reviews: Don't take this course unless you really like films. It isn't the best way to improve your Russian, as it lacks the structure of RUS 208 and meets only twice a week. Try to take some other course (maybe a graduate level course).
This class isn't much work and it's kind of fun to watch movies and talk about them. I took this after 207 and I had no trouble.
This is a great upper level course and introduction to Russian cinema. I'd highly recommend taking it if you are looking to expand your exposure to an important aspect of modern Russian culture!
Would definitely recommend it for people seriously interested in Russian.
prereqs: RUS 207 or Permission Of Instructor.
descrip: A language course based on Russian films and designed to develop a more sophisticated level of spoken and written Russian. Discussions of life in Russia, weekly compositions.

title: Funny Pictures: Caricature and Modernity
descrip: Please see website

title: International Trade Policy
descrip: Evaluates arguments for and against protection and adjustment assistance and considers topics chosen from the following: non-tariff barriers, dumping, embargo threats and trade warfare, and the political economy of trade policy formation. Special attention is given to trade problems of the less-developed countries, including North-South trade relations and commodity price stabilization. Prerequisite: 511c.

title: Life on Earth: Chaos and Clockwork of Biological Design
reviews: Ask a lab TA for help if you are having trouble with lab reports.
Be ready for tests to be graded ridiculously hard. Pre-med kids are nuts.
Concentrate on lecture material. Keep a running list of Take Home Points at the end of each lecture slide.

DON'T take unless you have to, or unless they change the format of the lectures. The exams are difficult to study for and I am sad I came away from this class learning less than I'd have liked to. Cool labs though
Definitely take it if interested in Biology. It's probably not the best choice to fulfill a distribution requirement, but I do recommend if interested in the topic. I learned a lot!
Do not be afraid to go to office hours.
Don't bother with the readings unless you're confused. Go to every lecture. Have fun!
Don't do it. (unless you're premed, in which case, why are you reading this?)

Don't spend too much extra time on the readings because they are not crucial.
Don't take it if you can avoid it

Don't try to cram the material before exams. It is far too comprehensive.
Enjoy the lectures and the labs--they are excellent with an open mind.
Even though the professors are great, this course requires working through some tedious material, and lab was very time consuming and not always rewarding.
Exams are difficult - studying all the material for weeks will get you halfway.
Exams are graded way too harshly. Have to go to lecture to get through this course.
Extremely interesting course. Exams and grading are somewhat arbitrary.
Go to lecture, and take good notes.  Fasten your seatbelts for some lectures, because they will leave you frustratingly confused at times.
Go to lecture, pay attention in lecture, only do the readings if you don't understand lecture.
Go to the lectures, they're extremely helpful. Keep all of your handouts for studying. It is not extremely important to do every reading, but that is not to say that the book should be neglected.

Great course with very interesting material. Professors Paccala and Rubenstein are great lecturers, always engaging and prepare you well for the test. Take really detailed notes. Lab is waste of time.
I can see how writing lab reports would be hard for humanities or social sciences people. Writing for science is a lot different.
I liked this course especially as a freshman coming into a science course, it was fair and easy to stay up to date.
I strongly recommend this course for anyone interested in evolution or biology in general.
I think it is a very interesting course and I really understand the relationship between evolution and math.
I would advise them to go to office hours.
I would suggest this.
I would tell them to spend time on their lab write-ups and GO TO LECTURE!
If EEB is a subject that really interests you, I think you'll really enjoy this course. If you not, though, it can sometimes feel a little overwhelming.

If you don't have to take this course, don't take it. For those who are required to take the course, go to the lectures and take good notes on the slides and especially the graphs (because they are sometimes drawn in convoluted ways and are hard to figure out later). The biggest advice I have is to study in groups before the exams or throughout the semester! This class is not like a lot of other science classes. You need to discuss with people, and the exams are completely essay (actually more writing than I've had to do for humanities exams). Also, sciences often have many theories that come together and have many possible angles, but in EEB 211 there is a "right" answer; be ready to make huge overarching conclusions and connections about things you learn even if you don't agree with them or if they might sound a little ridiculous. The textbook is not useful. The lab reports count for a pretty big portion of the final grade, so spend time on them (they also take longer than you think sometimes); the grading sometimes seems arbitrary, but you just have to deal and try your best to answer everything with exactly what they're looking for.
If you have a general interest in biology or you are looking to find a particular subfield of biology that interests you, then you would benefit from this course.
If you like bio, take it.
If you really want to learn EEB, taking an upper level course might be better.

If you're thinking about pre-med, you obviously have to take this course, but it doesn't have to be another course that you HAVE to take. I was told going into it that it was a terrible course, but I chose to go into the class with an open mind, and I definitely enjoyed it more because of this. Do the same and you'll be fine.
Interesting course but labs report grading was difficult to predict and exams are hard to prepare for in absence of example questions
Interesting topics, but very poorly designed course.
It is a pretty good class. I really enjoyed the labs that were outside, as well as the lectures which were engaging and connects well to daily life.
It's a good class with top-notch professors who give engaging lectures.
Keep up with all the lectures!
Keep up with the material. Go to all lectures.
Keep up with the readings and conceptually think through all concepts.
Lectures are fun. Exams are not.

Make sure to go to lecture. They award points for each clicker question, but most importantly you'll need to take good notes to study with for the final/midterm. Don't slack off when it comes to note taking in the course!
Make sure you attend all lectures.
Make sure you go to lecture and get a good lab instructor.
Only take it if you have to, which I think is why people take it anyway.
Pay very close attention in lecture
Perhaps the bane of me fall semester existence. Class and labs are poorly structured. Could write a whole paper on why I dislike this course.

Read all the lectures as you attend them. It's a LOT of material.
Recommend for pre-med or those still trying to find an STL credit.
STUDY! read the take home points adn memorize them
Schedule time with TA's to clarify, if need be coordinate with other students and their TA's to make sure you have the right information.

Study

Take it if you have to, but it's a really annoying course

Take it if you're premed

Take it!
Really fun, no stress
Just keep up with labs which are easy to get good grades on
Take it.

Take the course if you need to! It's still a hard class especially because of the tricky exams.

Take this course only as a pre-med requirement. This course could be significantly improved, and hopefully it will be in the future.

Take this course. That little voice in your head saying sciences are not your thing is lying. This is a FUN course.
Take this! Even though its usually taken as a departmental class, take it for your STL distribution. Very fun and engaging and it will blow your mind.
The course is interesting and straightforward. Pacala is a great lecturer, Rubenstein can be a little weird at times. Shout out to Craig, he was super chill and helpful.

The only reason to take this class is for Rubenstein (and for pre med i guess) and I'm not even sure he is worth it. If you do take this, just take amazing notes so that you have something to study of the final.
The tests are very detail oriented.
There are many interesting things to learn. Engage with the material and it's enjoyable. Also, reading The Selfish Gene is useful for the second part of the course
There is really no point to take this class unless you plan on being an EEB major or are Pre med.
This class ended up being more interesting than I expected. Go to lecture, as that is the material you will be tested on.

This class is affectionately dubbed the "bastard child of the sciences and the humanities". 
There is not much work, other than reading (1-2hrs/week max) and several lab report (usually given ten days to two weeks to complete). Lectures are decent, though personally, the material wasn't that interesting. Prof. Pacala and Rubenstein are very engaging, and if you are pre-med fulfilling a requirement, they make sure to connect it back to relevant material. 

Labs are quite different than what is expected, usually asking you to answer a broad and vague question rather than do calculations and data analysis. Avoid getting Kaia (she is super strict in her grading), and shoot for Tong or Trish, if they are all still teaching. 

Go to office hours, the professors love meeting students and are very approachable with questions.
This class is good amount of work so go into it with that understanding and go to office hours as much as possible
This class is interesting and does not seem like it is difficult at the time. However, the exams and labs are demanding.

This course gets mixed reviews and I think that it's because a lot of MOL pre-meds who have to take it simply have no desire to be here and don't enjoy learning about trees and animals and other things that don't pertain to medicine (and rightly so, I would probably be bothered as well).  But if you are slightly interested in the environment or life on earth outside of the human body, then this course is really interesting and exciting, and I would recommend it.  Labs are generally interesting, yet the write-ups can be a lot of work.  Exams are pretty hard, and in order to do well, you should learn the material as you go.
This course is an interesting approach to Evolution and Ecology. Take it if you need to and also if you are interested. I found it enjoyable.

This course is pretty relaxed and straight forward compared to other pre-med requirements. The lectures are interesting and cover a wide range of material. Stay on top of your labs, since they're worth the bulk of the grade. I would suggest reviewing lecture material about 2 weeks before an exam: it's easy to break into chunks. All the professors and TAs are really accessible so definitely reach out to them if you need clarification! But the learning in this class is mostly self-motivated as there are no problem sets or precepts.
Understand the big ideas.
You have to take it anyway. Not too bad.

You should most definitely take this course!!!!! It was absolutely amazing!!!!! It was one of the best courses I have taken here so far!!!!! To make it enjoyable, as in everything else, just stay on top of your work...look at notes regularly, go to office hours, sit back and enjoy lecture!
avoid if you can, it's just annoying to deal with.
don't take this unless you're pre-med or EEB major
if you don't have to, do not take this course.
record lectures, keep updated with information, three lectures a week is a lot of information to cover, study for exams purely from lectures
descrip: An examination of how life evolved and how organisms function. Design--'intelligent' and otherwise--will provide a unifying theme. Why do some microbes produce slime and others do not? Why are males brightly colored in some species, but in others females are the showy sex? Why do humans have knees that fail whereas horses and zebras do not? These and other 'why is it so' questions related to the origin and history of life, genetic code, biochemistry, physiology, morphology and body plans, sex and reproduction, cooperation, and ecosystems will be explored. This course is required of all EEB majors and fulfills a requirement for medical school.

title: Research Projects in Molecular Biology (Laboratory Rotations)
reviews: Go to all the lunch talks and get involved in the labs you are working in.
N/A
NA

This lab has an interesting social dynamic which makes it a little uncomfortable to be in. In addition, there are long hours in which I was not supported by my graduate student. In addition, she was passive aggressive and made the environment to say the least difficult to be in at times. Good lab, but theres something a little weird going on.
descrip: Students will perform research in the laboratories of two faculty advisers.

title: Visualizing Buddhism: Art, Religion, and Philosophy
reviews: Class if pretty work intensive. Will have to put in a great deal of effort to receive a good grade. Challenging, but worth it if you are interested in the topic.
Do all the readings and participate in class discussions.
Don't take this class, or any other course taught by Prof. Huntington.
Focus a lot in the lectures. Doing the readings is important but sometimes it's better to do them after the lecture, because you know what to look for.
Get ready to interpret your primary sources in the exact way he tells you to. Outside thinking is not that welcome.
Going to lectures is the best way to pass the course.
I would suggest engaging in the material.

If you're interested in Buddhism and have the opportunity to take a seminar class with Prof. Huntington, then I'd say try it out. But the setup of this class was really strange - 80 minutes twice a week of mostly lecture - and made for a class that wasn't as engaging as it could have been. Also, the course covered a TON, and as someone who's never studied Buddhism before, it was really hard to wrap my head around it all.
Only take this class if you have a very strong background in Buddhist religion and history, otherwise it won't really make sense/the material is hard to put in context.

Prof. Huntington is dedicated and meticulous. He lays out what he wants you to know, and he makes sure he's available outside of class for you. It's hard to fail, and the material makes for a very interesting introduction to Buddhism.

Professor Huntington was obviously very inexperienced when he taught this and as a result it was honestly a very bad class. Hopefully everyone gave him constructive criticism in their reviews though, so he might have gotten better by the time you're considering taking his class.
TAKE THIS CLASS AND DO ALL THE READINGS FOR IT.
Take it for distribution requirement and if you want an introduction to buddhism with some focus on art.
Take it if you have any interest in learning more about Tibetan Buddhism. You learn a lot from the class and the workload is manageable.
Take it if you have even a cursory interest in Buddhism. Everyone should study an Eastern religion like it at some point. Be prepared to engage with pieces of art a lot though.
descrip: Art, ritual, and material culture can be powerful expressions of religious belief. This course is organized around conceptual themes governing key philosophies, rituals and art forms in Himalayan Buddhism. Students will gain a basic introduction to Buddhist religion and history, as well as coming to understand the inestimable role of art and material culture in religion, seeing the ways in which artworks can express ideas, epitomize practices, and transmit beliefs. The course will involve topics from the past 2500 years, emphasizing regions of South Asia that include northern India, Nepal, and Tibet.

title: Cultures of Punishment
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Advanced Dance Performance and Choreographic Projects
reviews: Take technique courses with visiting choreographers !
you have to take it for the certificate, so do it!
prereqs: DAN 419/409 or equivalent experience. Interview with faculty for placement in composition section from April 7-18, 2014. To arrange an interview, email Professor Lazier (rlazier@) or Professor Fehlandt (fehlandt@) and send a list of any previous composition experience at Princeton. NOTE: Placement for Technique/Repertory component of class will be held Wednesday, September 10th from 4:30-6:20 at Hagan Dance Studio at 185 Nassau..
descrip: Advanced students will learn and perform dances that represent diverse approaches to contemporary choreography. Technique and Repertory classes encourage rich, subtle and stylistically accurate renditions of choreography and cultivate intelligent and imaginative artistic interpretations. In Choreography classes, students will develop senior thesis projects; they can choose to focus on choreographic development or enhancing artistry as a performer. Classes will foster individual choreographic practices and mentor students as they transfer a dance from the studio to stage. The course is required for all Seniors pursuing a Certificate in Dance.

title: The Ethics of Borders and Migration
reviews: Definitely take this course. The material is extremely interesting and the discussions are really engaging. You'll find that you have an opinion on pretty much every topic.
Highly recommend

I would recommend this course if you are interested in the topics of immigration and borders. It's really relevant with all the immigration and people moving all around the world. Professor Anna Stilz is really great as well!
Migration draws on a lot of other topics: democracy, self-determination, culture, global poverty, etc. It is a really valuable course for a huge range of interests.
Stilz is wonderful at facilitating a seminar, the subject is fascinating, thought-provoking, and important, and I hope you take it!

Take this course with Professor Stilz. She is one of the most intelligent professors I have had at Princeton, and this was one of my favorite courses. It is important and interesting to look at immigration issues through a theoretical lens, while still discussing practical issues that are also relevant to immigration policy. I learned so much, and the 3-hour session flew by because the discussions were so engaging. Don't miss out on this opportunity!

This course will make you realize how difficult it is to discuss border and migration without posing all kinds of other interdisciplinary questions, from political theory to economics to philosophy to sociology, to name only a few. The most rewarding course are often the ones that force you to question your own assumptions about a give topic. This course will (I think) do precisely this. Given the multifaceted nature of the topic as described above, this will mean rethinking many of your own views across disciplinary lines and as they pertain to many different issues in the modern world.
This was the first year this course was offered, so it may well improve. Try it out, but trust your gut instincts on whether or not to stay.
descrip: Migration places into sharp relief the question of how to balance the rights of sovereign states and their citizens against the claims of (often-needy) foreigners. Should self-governing peoples be free to set their own migration policies and control their territorial borders without interference? Or ought they instead to be constrained by a "human right to immigrate?" This course will attempt to answer these questions, in part by theorizing foundational issues of self-determination, boundaries, national culture, and membership. We will also take up contemporary debates about guestworkers, irregular migrants, refugees, and brain drain.

title: Readings in American History: Reconstruction to World War I
reviews: Definitely take it. Prof. Rix is a wonderful teacher and the course very stimulating.
I highly recommend taking a course with Professor Rix. She knows the period inside and out, and is engaging and insightful. She is highly committed to her students, and very approachable.

Keep a journal of interests for you to come back to afterward. The time period is really complex and it's easy to get lost in the complexity and multiplicity of perspectives. Keeping a journal will let you find our way back into what interested you later on.
Prepare for a hefty amount of reading and lots of class participation.

Take good reading notes.  When you're in a class with a large group of people who all have backgrounds in different aspects of American history, it's useful to be able to reference specific places in the readings to keep conversation on track and ensure that your comments are taken seriously.
descrip: A comprehensive introduction to the literature and problems of American History from the end of the Civil War through World War I.

title: Controversies in Clinical Psychology
reviews: Be prepared to work over breaks!
Despite how interesting the topic is, and the readings are, the course is not organized enough to be worth your time

If you are even vaguely considering going into ANY sort of clinical work after graduation (mental health related or not) you MUST take this course. You will soon realize that just about every field that deals with humans is directly affected by the field of clinical psych. Take this course

It's a decent course. A lot of interesting readings from different types of publications, a few papers that are frustratingly unstructured, and a precept that feels unnecessary for a 3-hr seminar. But Profs. Comer and Glat are great, so if you have the time to devote to digesting the readings, I'd take it.
It's interesting.
Take it, do the readings and try to participate as much as you can.
Take this course if you're interested in clinical psychology!
Talk in class; engage with other students and the profs.
The material covered in this course is very interesting and a great chance to apply information that you have both learned in other classes and experienced in real life to an academic subject.
The readings weren't really emphasized. You'll get more out of the class if you participate.

This course is very interesting and will change your perspective about the clinical field. The course is heavily based on essays so if you really struggle with that I recommend you see the professors before its due so that you can get feedback.
take it but it's not easy
take this if you are genuinely interested in psych
prereqs: PSY 207 or PSY 320..
descrip: The field of clinical psychology is currently marked by many controversies. This course will focus on the leading ones, highlighting one or two important controversies each week. We will explore each controversy in depth, examine both sides of the issue, and consider relevant research, ethical and legal concerns, implications for clinical practice and study, and broader societal implications. Controversies under examination will include: the ethics of mental health research, overprescription of psychotropic drugs, and the influence of insurance companies in therapy decisions.

title: Ethical Dimensions of Contemporary Russian Cinema
descrip: Exploration of the quest for moral values in Soviet and post-Soviet Russian cinema of the 1960's to the present. Topics include, among others, the effects of Stalinism; the struggle for freedom of individual conscience under totalitarianism; the artist's moral dilemmas in Soviet and post-Soviet society; materialism vs. spirituality. Films of Andrey Tarkovsky, Nikita Mikhalkov, Sergei Bodrov, Alexander Sokurov, Yuri Mamin, and others. Some attention to relevant American films (for instance, Woody Allen) and films from other cultures.

title: Introduction to the Architecture Profession
reviews: Look at the final project assignment in advance, and reference the precedent projects in the library.
Show up to classes - listen to bobs stories - and take his advice seriously
Strongly recommend
Take it! Ask questions. Get a head start on the final project.
Think of class as Monday morning storytime with Bob!
Try to go to sleep sunday night early if you can. The monday morning part is difficult since we often work very late.
Yes, for anyone who wants to have their own practice, this course is a must.
descrip: The carrying out of architectural services goes beyond design and involves an obligation to the public, to clients, to peers and employees. This course deals with the contracts, specifications, technical documentation, project management and construction administration phases of the architectural services.

title: Computers in Our World
reviews: A very rewarding class, but it can be tough at times. Not an easy A.
Be sure you are interested in the topics before taking the course just because someone told you it's an easy distribution requirement.
Easy pdf but don't expect to really learn anything useful.

GO TO OFFICE HOURS. Professor Kernighan is a very, very nice man, and your problem sets will take less than half the time they normally would and will get much better scores (at least if you're like me and math is not necessarily your forte). Also, print the slides and write down things he says that aren't on them--they show up on the exams fairly frequently.
Get a QR in   learn about the most important element of the information age: computers!
Go to lectures, try to do the problem sets on your own so you will be more prepared for the tests. If you are not a math minded person, expect a challenge, but it is rewarding.
Go to office hours! Don't space out in lecture!
Go to the professor if you need help, he was very open to students and helpful regardless of the questions.
Great Course, Id suggest it to a friend in search of a QR
Great course, put in a bit of effort.

Great if you're interested in learning about cos but have no experience and are afraid of 126! Kernighan is an incredible professor and is always available to meet outside of class during office hours. A truly great introductory course!

Hands down one of the best courses at Princeton University. Brian Kernighan is one of the best teachers at this school. Needless to say, the best QR class in town. Enjoy the lectures! I so wish I could take this course again.
I enjoyed the course but don't feel as if I learned much.

I would definitely recommend attending Professor Kernighan's office hours. He is an amazing professor and will help you understand anything you find confusing. Going to lab hours for the labs is also very helpful.

I wouldn't highly recommend this course, even if you are a Humanities major who wants to not take a Math course to fulfill your QR - I've heard great things about Environmental Decisionmaking though. 

The lectures were very difficult to follow because  of their scattered and often unrelated nature, the problem sets and exams difficult not only because of what random facts we were asked to know, but because the wording was so vague.

If you do take this class: cushion your grade with doing well on labs and problem sets so that when you bomb the midterm/final, you don't fail the course completely.
If you listen during lectures and do the problem sets and labs it's really not bad at all work wise. Professor Kernighan is very willing to help/talk outside of class.
If you need a QR, I'd recommend it

If you want to know more about computers or need a QR course, take it! It's a great class and Professor Kernighan is really good. Make sure to actually go to lecture and do well on the problem sets, and you will do well.

If you're looking for a low-key QR requirement, it's a great course. It does have a decent amount of work, since there's usually a lab and a p-set due every week, but with all that you end up pretty well-prepared for the midterm and the following assignments. It's great if you're interested in learning more about computers for everyday life, since he does a great job of presenting the information in an accessible way.
It's alot of work- take it if you are interested!
It's harder than you expect. Make sure you really understand the problem sets and mathematical concepts because they don't go away.
Keep up with the weekly reading in the textbook and go to office hours if you need help.
Memorization is not as important as making sure you understand the logic and how to solve the quantitative questions.
Not as easy as you'd think, but a solid P/D/F or distribution requirement for that tricky QR.
Professor Kernighan is absolutely the only reason you need to take this course, he could do anything but instead he is teaching us. Great guy, great course.
Take it - but don't assume it's going to be really easy! Kernighan is an amazing professor with great lectures, but you have to go to class to reap the benefits of this.
Take it!
Take it. Very manageable workload, Professor Kernighan is fantastic, interesting and practical subject.

Take notes on absolutely every random fact the professor mentions during lecture as this is all that will be on the final and if you have good class notes you can take them into the final with you so you don't even have to study.
Take this if you are a humanities person but want a QR that will actually give you skills you'll end up using. It will be challenging but worth it!
The textbook is very helpful! Start reading it from the beginning. Also- attend lectures!!

This is not an easy QR, you will definitely have to put in a lot of work just for a pass. The material is also somewhat difficult to grasp, so only go into the course if you genuinely are interested in learning about cos stuff, otherwise, this course will be a struggle for you.

This is one of those classes that everyone says you have to take but they are actually right for once. You will learn so much (if you don't know much about technology) but only as much as is needed/useful. Prof. Kernighan makes this class and you don't want to miss the opportunity to learn from him.
turn up to ever lecture because Professor Kernighan makes the topics much more understandable and interesting than independent reading
prereqs: Not intended for science/engineering/mathematics students. May not be taken for credit after COS 126 or higher..
descrip: Computers are all around us. How does this affect the world we live in? This course is a broad introduction to computing technology for humanities and social sciences students. Topics will be drawn from current issues and events, and will include discussion of how computers work; what programming is and why it is hard; how the Internet and the Web work; security and privacy.

title: Polymers
reviews: A great class to introduce you to polymers; professor really cares that you understand the information.
I would not recommend this class: it caused a lot of unnecessary stress.  But it does not have a final which is a plus.
It is a good class. Pay attention in lectures and really try to understand material from them. Problem sets really help in doing this. Tests are pretty hard and unforgiving.

It would be a perfect class for a higher level CBE course requirement (if you want to learn something too).
If you pdf the class, it will be one of the best classes ever.
Light workload, but exams and material are difficult.
Take it if you are at all interested in polymers.  Its a great mix of polymer properties and synthetic methods.  It is scientific without being too math heavy.
Take this course if you want to learn about polymers but pay attention and try to learn the material well on your own.
This is a very enjoyable course and you will learn a lot about polymers.  Take if interested in the subject.
prereqs: Prerequisite courses CHM 301 or 303, which may be taken concurrently, and MAT 104, or permission of the instructor..
descrip: Broad introduction to polymer science and technology, including polymer chemistry (major synthetic routes to polymers), polymer physics (solution and melt behavior, solid-state morphology and properties), and polymer engineering (overview of reaction engineering and melt processing methods).

title: Alchemy, Art and Science
descrip: Please see website

title: Philosophy and the Study of Religion
descrip: The impact of twentieth-century philosophical ideas on the academic study of religion: naturalism, phenomenology, hermeneutics, structuralism, Nietzschean genealogy, and American pragmatism, among other philosophical movements.

title: Art for Everyone
reviews: Don't take it if you dont like modern art.
Easy P/D/F that anyone could do.  It's better for everyone. if you take it somewhat seriously.  If you are interested in art, I would recommend taking it.
Take it
prereqs: Restriction: This course is not open to students who took VIS 472, Special Topics in Visual Arts - Art for Everyone.
descrip: This studio class will address the increasing social pressure on art to become more widely distributed, immediately accessible, and democratically produced. For the past fifty years, expanding definitions of what art might be fueled by a greater emphasis on active audience participation have encouraged an atmosphere in which anyone can claim to be an artist. Through studio work in a wide range of graphic and digital media, supported by readings and discussions, this class will take a hands-on approach to the question of whether art by everyone for everyone constitutes a dreamed-of utopia, a universal banality, or a cultural nightmare.

title: Topics in Number Theory - A Journey Towards the Herbrand-Ribet Theorem
prereqs: A comfortable knowledge of Galois Theory..
descrip: A course in algebraic number theory, consisting of two topics. The first topic is the algebraic number theory behind the statement of the Herbrand-Ribet theorem: number fields and their integer rings, local fields, global fields, the statement of class field theory. The second topic is one of the following five: The proof of the Herbrand-Ribet theorem, a proof of class field theory, the theory of cyclotomic fields, quadratic forms and higher composition laws (Bhargava 2001), or the basic theory of elliptic curves.

title: History of the American Workplace
reviews: Take it! You will learn so much in this class in an engaging and interactive setting.
Take this course if you want to learn about the intersection of work, politics, and culture. Be prepared to do a lot reading, but it will be worth it because the professors are great.
Take this course!

This course provides a fascinating introduction to and perspective into the history of American labor. Take this course if you have any interest in the history of American capitalism, labor, or business.
This is a great and very serious course--if you like labor history you'll love it.
Write about the workplace!
take it!!!
take this if you're at all interested in labor history or the history of work
descrip: This seminar introduces students to the history of work by focusing upon the history of the American workplace. Whether farm or factory, office or kitchen, assembly line or computer screen, the course explores the historical transformation of work through the examination of different kinds of workplaces. The seminar covers industrialization to the present, focusing upon such themes as the relationship between home and work, work and politics, work and identity, work and technology, and work and power.

title: Policy Workshop - Shaping American Policy in the Middle East
descrip: The US has faced a number of significant foreign policy challenges recently, often leading to ad hoc responses & crisis diplomacy. This workshop examines relevant academic literature & plethora of think tank reports; meet foreign policy analysts in the US & the region in order to craft a credible vision, policy & strategy for the next 10 years that can attract bipartisan support. Key issue areas include: Iran & the Gulf sub-region; relations with key allies; Israeli-Arab relations; fair, equitable, & sustainable economic growth; prospects for democratic change in the region.

title: Introduction to Comparative Literature
descrip: This course addresses recent developments in literary criticism, such as surface reading, distant reading, affect theory, print culture, necropolitics, queer futurity, melancholic historicism, animal studies, thing theory, systems theory, ecocriticism, critical race studies, world literature, theory from the south, critiques of neoliberalism, and so on. The class will not embrace a mastery posture toward theory, but an instrumental one, aiming to assist graduate students in conceptualizing their particular projects within and against current debates.

title: Everyday Stories
reviews: Definitely take it if you are interested in literature, everyday history or if you want to broaden your horizons in general
Do the reading, you will take away so much form the course.
Give yourself plenty of time to do the readings each week so that you have the opportunity to really reflect on them before going to class for discussion.
If you are willing to talk (and read) about the every day, I think you may find that the idea of it is not so everyday as every day seems to suggest.
The class touches upon all different issues, and you have a lot of creative room to really pursue your interests. Prof. Bowlby is super nice and helpful as well!

Very interesting course with an extremely nice professor who doesn't stand there and lecture for 3 hours. She lets everyone talk a bit about each reading and give their opinions. With only 2 papers, the course load is very light.
Yes you should take this course, It is fun and interesting.
descrip: "How was your day?" "Tell me about yourself." Such commonplace prompts draw out "everyday stories" of real, unremarkable life. But what counts as real life or unremarkable life, and what happens when it gets into literature, too? What parts of reality do everyday stories suppress or show up? Drawing on writers from Roland Barthes to Christopher Isherwood to Virginia Woolf, this course looks at novels, stories, diaries, and essays that present versions or theories of everyday life. Students will also be invited to experiment with their own stories or non-stories of the everyday.

title: Phonetics and Phonology
reviews: I would probably not advise the course because I found it not interesting and frustrating to take.

If the course is taught by P. Houghton, mind that it will be concentrated mainly on Optimality Theory and thus somewhat one-sided. As a whole, it's not a very difficult class, but you can learn a lot.
If you're interested in phonology take this course.

If you're interested in phonology, take it! It's not super hard, but you learn a lot and get a solid introduction into a linguistics topic that I don't think you get in other LIN classes at Princeton.
It's not much work and Houghton helps you a lot. Not always super interesting, but I would still recommend it especially as a fifth class.

Lighter workload makes the class very manageable if you stay on top of readings and classes. At the same time, you should consider different classes if you want an introduction to linguistics/don't want to study phonetics and phonology in general.

Not fantastic - expect to spend a lot of time in class doing rote work in Optimality Theory, and not a lot of time doing Phonetics and Phonology. Still, it was worth my time. Problem sets were decent. I'm not sure who will teach this course in the future, but if Professor Houghton is doing it again, I hope she will improve the lecture style.

Only take this course if you are majoring or minoring in linguistics, because otherwise you will be frustrated at how specific the course material is.  That said, the course itself is great.  It's not too much work and the problem sets are interesting and you learn a lot doing them!

Phonetics and Phonology are essential objects of study for any student of linguistics. But I would advise linguistics concentrators, if given the choice, to wait for a semester when the course is not taught as a course on OT rather than on Phonology per se. As for students with general interest in linguistics or EC-seekers, I'd suggest Intro to Linguistics or Syntax or any course on historical linguistics above this one in any semester, regardless of instructor/syllabus choices.
Phonology is an interesting topic, and Professor Houghton is a perfectly fine teacher. Take it if you're interested in the material.
Take it if you're interested. :)

The class focuses entirely on Optimality Theory, which is the professor's specialty.  This makes it feels rather disconnected from actual linguistic phenomena, so it'll feel really boring if you're taking it to learn more about languages.  It's also incredibly slow and precepts aren't really different from lectures.

This applies only if Prof. Houghton is visiting again to teach this course. Though she is kind and helpful as a professor, her course was on one very specific approach to phonology, optimality theory. No one realized this would be the case and we were all disappointed. Problem sets and course material were all frustrating. Even as a linguistics concentrator interested in phonology I regretted taking this class.
This class is good. If you do the work, you will get a good grade.

This class is not good. You will not learn about Phonetics and Phonology. You will not even learn about Optimality Theory. Rather, you will learn Optimality Theory as if it is incontrovertible gospel. It is likely that Professor Houghton will not be teaching it in the future, which means your experience would be entirely different from this year's and stands a chance of being good, but I beg of you, do not take this class unless it is a different professor. Houghton is nice, but this class is troubled. I love phonology, but this class periodically made me want to perform self-administered lobotomy just to mix things up a little.
This course is useful if you are considering doing independent work relating to OT phonology. Otherwise, you are better off reading up on phonology on your own.

What this course has managed to achieve in the field of bad courses is truly astonishing. It was fantastically, soul-crushingly uninteresting and infuriating in every single way, featuring poorly designed quizzes that thanks to the scoring algorithm are actually IMPOSSIBLE to answer correctly and focuses on an implausible fringe theory of the phenomenon while actively ignoring every remotely interesting area of the topic. It would not surprise me if this were the worst course ever offered in the history of Princeton.
prereqs: LIN 201 or permission of instructor..
descrip: Why does the accent move around in the words "finite", "infinite", "infinity", "infinitesimal", "infiniteness"? Could "tqnqnk" be a word in some human language? (Yes.) Phonologists study such facts to determine what a possible sound system is and the unconscious computations people perform in order to speak and comprehend utterances. A basic but fairly technical introduction to the science of speech sounds: their articulation, acoustic properties, and mental representation. Data and problems from diverse languages.

title: Reasoning about Computation
reviews: Be prepared for math proofs

Be prepared to spend a lot of time in this class.  If you put in the work you can succeed.  Be careful to not let this class consume all your time.  Find a good group.  Took this class with 3 other COS classes and it was a hell of a workload.
Best course for getting a truly algorithmic understanding of Computer Science. Helped me think about Interview questions, computer Science questions, and other problems in a much more structured way.
COS 340 isn't too bad if you have a good group.
DON'T TAKE UNLESS IT'S REQUIRED.
Don't be intimidated - just put in the work, and get help if you need it. I also would say don't put it off until the last possible semester, you may end up really liking it!
Find a good group to work with on the assignment. It honestly makes all the difference.

GET A GOOD WORKING GROUP (sometimes two people is better than 3). 

BE PREPARED TO WORK HARD. problem sets are relentless

THIS CLASS IS DOABLE. I am not a math person. I was dreading this class, but I am happy with how much I learned and I think  I enjoyed this class.
Get a good group. Friday night deadlines are tough, but you will get better at problem solving.
Get a good homework group! But don't rely on them too much or you'll be screwed for the midterms and final.
Get a good team, ideally with a math major. Otherwise you won't know how to do the psets and won't have anywhere to turn.
Great course. Difficult, but worth the time and the professors/preceptors are amazing.
Great way to learn CS math.
If it isn't required, seriously think about if this is a course you want to take.
If you already have a good mathematical background and familiarity with proofs you should skip it. Otherwise it's a really good introductory course!
If you like math take this course.
Interesting course. I wish it went deeper into some of the subject matter. Valuable if you want to become familiar with topics in mathematics relevant to computer science.
It's going to be hard, really time consuming but it's really a very different and new way of thinking
Lots of assumed knowledge.  If you don't have a strong mathematical background and need to take this as a departmental, make sure you take this with a group that does.

Make sure to look at problem sets early. Work in groups if you're looking for better grades. Work individually if you want to feel a better sense of accomplishment, but understand that the curve might not be favorable.
None

ORFE Major, Applied Math/COS minor. I thought this course was pretty easy actually. The homeworks are interesting and challenging. It's a survey class, so I didn't think any of the material was terribly difficult.
Psets take a loooong time. go to office hours. Hard course, but interesting proofs most of the time. Take it if you like proofs
Should have a solid math background before taking
Start problem sets the day they are releases. Get help often. Find a smart group to work with.
Start the problem sets early.
Take it because you need to; it's a decently insightful course but it's hugely let down by the way the problem sets are organized. The stress isn't worth the material you learn.
Take this class only if you have an active interest in CS theory, including proofs. Get prepared for a not-so-great curve and tough exercises.
This class proves there is no god.

This course starts out relatively easy and increases in difficulty throughout the semester. I felt that the grading was sometimes unnecessary harsh (such as taking points off for failing to prove trivial statements) because there would otherwise be no way to differentiate grades on assignments. Professor Braverman's lectures are very informative and there is a vast array of resources to help you understand the concepts.

This is pretty much a requirement for COS majors, which is the main reason you're probably taking it.  The course requires you to have a pretty strong mathematical background to do well, but if you put the effort in it'll be worth it - the material can be very interesting. Find a good group to work with on the problem sets and look at the questions early (even if you don't plan on starting them then) so you can mull over them (a lot of the times the answer came to me at random moments during the day).
You have to take it but if you can choose, take it with Braverman!
should probably only take if you need it
take it
take only if required as departmental. otherwise maybe not worth the time and effort.
prereqs: COS 126 and 226 (or sufficient mathematical background), and MAT 175, 202, 204. COS 226 can be taken along with COS 340 in the same term. Please contact the professor directly with any questions you may have..
descrip: An introduction to mathematical topics relevant to computer science. Combinatorics and probability will be covered in the context of computer science applications. The course will present a computer science approach to thinking and modeling through topics such as dealing with uncertainty in data and handling large data sets. Students will be introduced to fundamental concepts such as NP-completeness and cryptography that arise from the world view of efficient computation.

title: Econometric Modeling
reviews: With Professor Sims and Professor Watson. First half had a lot of good Bayesian methodologies (MCMC, etc.), "classic" applications (SVAR, etc.), and more creative ones. Second half was a good balance of both frequentist and Bayesian approaches to more "tricky" time series problems (instability over time, large datasets, etc.)
descrip: The construction, estimation, and testing of econometric models as a process, from theory to model formulation to estimation and testing and back to theory. Bridging the gap between theory and applied work. A series of topics in macroeconomics time series and microeconomic cross-sectional analysis: consumption at the household and aggregate level, commodity prices, nonparametric and parametrics estimation.

title: Chemical Kinetics
descrip: A survey of chemical kinetics. Kinetic measurements and experimental methods, reaction rate theory, molecular dynamics experiment and theory will be discussed. Both gas phase and condensed phase kinetic studies will be considered.

title: Introduction to the Middle East
reviews: A great class to take if you want to understand the region today!
A lot of emphasis on ancient history instead of modern history. Take it if you peter ancient history/ want a very broad and general overview of the area.

A very large breadth of material, especially in the second half of the semester, that is sometimes hard to follow in lecture or readings. But the examination and grading seems to take this into consideration and is pretty reasonable.
Choose your preceptor wisely.
Do the readings!
Enjoyable course.
Fun and not too difficult, but a lot of reading.

Good course for getting a general overview of Middle Eastern Politics.  Not too difficult, but also not too in depth, so if you are considering further study in the subject I would recommend a higher level course.
Good for a intro course to the topic, wouldn't recommend if you are already knowledgeable about the history of the Middle East
Great course! If you want to learn about the foundations of today's crises and the origins of Islam and the diversity of ideologies in the Middle East, this will help you out.
