Great lecturer and great preceptors as well, so  definitely take the course if you don't know that much about the Middle East and want to learn!
Have low expectations coming in, in terms of lecture quality--definitely take it if you need the departmental distribution.

I took this class hoping to gain some understanding of the current situation in the Middle East. I now realize that if this is your goal, it probably makes a lot more sense to take a course specifically on the modern Middle East or politics/current events. However, I gained a lot of understanding from this class that I did not expect to. I feel like it set me up for a more complete understanding if I do now choose to more closely follow current events in the Middle East, and I would definitely recommend it. It's pretty easy, lectures notes are somewhat necessary whether they're your own or someone else's, and readings, while kind of long, are usually fascinating if you care about the topic. It's a good intro for beginners. Take it with a friend!
I would make sure to create ties between the reading and the class work.

I would recommend this course as long as a student is willing to do the readings, pay very careful attention in lecture, and participate in precept. You can get a lot out of this class if you do those things.
If you are interested in having a foundation, and/or brushing up on the knowledge you already had from other courses, take this class. if not, try a more focused course
Interesting material but hard to follow.
It's a fantastic course if you want to learn about the history of the middle east, but if you are looking for more modern information I would not advise this course.
It's a great course. You learn a lot of intriguing history pertaining to current events in the Middle East.
It's an easier class with interesting material.

It's an excellent introduction to the Middle East. I feel like I know the entire history after studying for the final and taking the course, and I think it's extremely valuable and relevant information in this day and age. I loved it, everyone should take it for a really good overview of a complex and ancient territory.
It's ok as an intro, though if you already are interested in the region and know the basics, it'll be incredibly boring.

Make sure to stay on top of the readings the first half of the year. Readings in the second half of the year aren't terribly important. Also, make sure to speak during precept because precept discussion is 30% of the grade, which seems very high. Its best to focus on the different state models and their similarities and differences.
Only take if you are interested in the middle east. If not it will be a tough class to understand
Take it
Take it before taking more in depth history classes. I took this class after one on the effects of WWI on the Ottoman Empire and would have benefited having the background context this class gave me.
Take it if you want to gain a basic understanding of the Middle East.
Take it if you're not super interested in the middle East. For those with a keen interest, this course is a bit basic. For others, excellent course.
Take it maybe if someone else is teaching it, the information is good and it serves as a good intro to the Middle East
Take it! Requires a manageable amount of work and is very interesting
Take it! You'll learn a lot and the lectures are pretty fun. Try to get Cole as a preceptor but the others seem cool too. Professor Schayegh is awesome.
Take this course and do the readings. Keep the book when the course is done, because the readings in there are very interesting and important.
Take this course for sure!
Take this course if you want a general understand of the Middle East or have learned about it in the past, it offers a different perceptive through a historical narration.
Take this for a really good historical background and to better understand the current situation of the Middle East. You get a LOT of information in this course and I really enjoyed it.

The lectures are engaging and the readings are very crucial to understanding the details of the historical context (as well as doing well on exams). I would pay attention to certain key themes and terms, because they tend to reappear often throughout the course.

The readings are fairly dry and not incredibly interesting, but lectures are great. I took this class with no prior knowledge of the Middle East which made it a little difficult when we talked about the really ancient parts like the 1500s because I didn't even know where it would lead to. Schayegh is a great lecturer and knows a lot and Dror Weil is a nice and thoughtful lecturer. It's very broad which I didn't like but I should've expected that from an intro course. I am slightly more aware of the events unfolding there now but still not really.
Think about whether you want a really brief intro to tons of different things or if you would rather go in depth into a particular subject
This course is a good one for history department fulfillments. It's somewhat different in structure from other history classes, but I enjoyed it.

This course is interesting and you will learn a lot. Professor Schayegh is an engaging lecturer. Something I wish I'd known before signing up for the course: Professor Schayegh helped start a petition to divest from Israel on campus. Made me uncomfortable coming to a class where he was teaching about the Middle East.

This course provides a solid background for what's happening in the Middle East and introduces you to a lot of key concepts and key players in the region. For a survey course, it's surprisingly interesting. It doesn't go too deeply into concepts, but it is a helpful introduction.

This is probably one of the easiest history classes that you can take. It's also very interesting and important information to know- really did change the way that I read news about the Middle East. But it is very basic.

This was a great course. It's not super challenging, which is great because the work is actually manageable. It is very clear and well organized, and Cyrus is a very good lecturer compared to many I've had here over four years. I really recommend for people looking to understand the Middle East better, whether for fun or academic purposes. You will learn a lot quickly. I especially preferred the country profiles in the second half of the course.
You will scratch the surface of Middle Eastern history in this broad, yet engaging, course. Take it for an easy general interest course.
prereqs: Freshmen are encouraged to enroll..
descrip: A broad background that could help you understand the complicated relationship between the United States and the Middle East. We reach back into the Middle Eastern past--the rise of Islam, the Caliphate, the coming of the Turks, the European expansion, the discovery of oil--and use these developments to explain the unsettled political, social, economic, and religious landscape of the region today. Thus we will set ourselves to explain why Turkey is a secular republic whereas Iran is an Islamic one, why religious extremism has increased, why democratic aspirations erupted in an "Arab Spring," and what role oil plays in all this.

title: Civitas Foundation Finance Seminar
descrip: Drafts of papers, articles, and chapters of dissertations or books, prepared by graduate students, faculty members, or visiting scholars, are exposed to critical analysis by a series of seminars organized by field. The chief objectives are for the writers to receive the benefit of critical suggestions, for all participants to gain experience in criticism and uninhibited oral discussion, and for students and faculty members to become acquainted with the research work going on in the department. Third- and fourth-year graduate students are expected to attend; first-and second-year students and faculty members are invited to attend.

title: East Asian Humanities I: The Classical Foundations
reviews: Definitely don't wait until the last minute to do the projects--they will always be able to tell that you have. That being said, this is an interesting course, not a crazy amount of work. I would recommend.
Good way to fulfill EM distribution requirement if you don't like talking about ethics and morality.

Pre-modern East Asia is certainly an interesting topic, but I have neutral feelings about this course.  I think that its potential to develop lies in its being taught by different instructors (i.e. not Professors D'Haeseleer and Wakabayashi).  They were *fine* in most respects, but I do think they did little to keep the class organized or present the course goals clearly and reinforce them throughout the semester.
Quite a bit of busy work, but the course content is very rich.

Take this course if you are interested in gaining some initial exposure to a diverse body of Classical East Asian Literature. Be aware that this is a survey course, so there is little time for in depth investigation outside of individual projects. However, there are quite a number of written assignments (papers and group projects) for which you can dive into the literature, so be prepared for those too.

The professors are super nice and helpful, and they both explain really well. The workload is not too much, just make sure to do the annotations and articles some time before the deadline, so they don't pile up. The class is a little bit disorganized though, but it is a good class overall.
This is a great course to get a general overview of East Asian art, literature, and history, but it is very broad.
prereqs: First year students are welcome. The course requires no familiarity with East Asian history or languages..
descrip: An introduction to the literature, art, religion and philosophy of China and Japan and Korea from antiquity to ca. 1400, with a special focus on "the classics of literature and art". Readings are focused on primary texts in translation, and complemented by museum visits and films. Students are encouraged to enroll in HUM/EAS/COM 234 which will continue the course up to the present. First year students are welcome. No knowledge of East Asian languages or history required.

title: Educational Psychology
reviews: A really nice course - a lot of work with the observations, especially if you're not in tpp, but still well-taught and a good chance to do some practical application of psych, spans a lot
Absolutely worth taking.

I found this course very enjoyable.  It does require a lot of work with weekly response papers and 12 hours of school observations.  This work is good preparation, however, to become a future teacher.
It really is for people who want to teach-- it is not for psychology students
It's a lot of work, but good. Taken in conjunction with TPP 301 is hard though.
Take this, and participate! You get out of this class what you put into it.

This is a good course, and the subject matter is very interesting. If you choose to take this course, don't let the once-a-week meeting fool you. Three hours in a room with no windows can be REALLY LONG sometimes, and so the only way to keep in engaging is to come prepared. There is A LOT of reading required for this course, and make sure you have enough time to not only do those, but to do the weekly paper responses. They're crucial to your grade, and if you fall behind, it is very hard to catch up. I could have done significantly better in this course grade-wise if I had just been able to give the weekly work a little more time.

This is definitely an interesting course and very relevant if you want to enter the field of education in some way. The discussions are lively and the readings are interesting. However, be warned that there is a fair amount of work in this class and a need to visit local schools.
prereqs: This course is required for students enrolled in the Teacher Preparation Program (TPP). Priority is given to Juniors and Seniors in TPP. Other Juniors and Seniors may enroll only with permission of instructor..
descrip: Principles of psychology relevant to the theory and practice of education. Through selected readings, discussion, and classroom observations, students study theories of development, learning, cognition (including literacy), and motivation, as well as individual and group differences in these areas; assessment; and the social psychology of the classroom. The course focuses on how learning by children and adolescents at the elementary, middle, and secondary school levels is influenced by their own characteristics and experiences and the various contexts in which they learn: family, school, community and culture.

title: Elementary Swahili I
reviews: If you have any interest in East Africa: take it. If you have no interest in East Africa: take it. If you enjoy learning languages, Swahili is fairly easy to pick up and Mwalimu Mahiri is a fascinating man as well as an excellent teacher. He is genuinely interested in his students' success not only in his class, but in their entire Princeton experience and beyond.
It's a pretty easy question. Do you want to learn swahili or not?
Take it! Mahiri is the man, and I love Swahili so much that I'm going to Tanzania the entire summer. And this is coming from someone who hated languages his entire life.
descrip: An introduction to Kiswahili language and culture for students who have no prior knowledge of the language. The course is taught in Kiswahili and focuses on acquiring novice-level skills to perform basic communication functions in the culture of Swahili speakers. Instruction is through performance of cultural themes and experiential activities that enhance the four components of speaking, writing, listening, and reading. At the end of the course, students are expected to acquire simple grammatical skills to perform day-to-day interactions in the language and gain some insight into the culture of East Africa.

title: Advanced Russian Reading and Conversation I
reviews: Definitely take it!  But be proactive if you really want to improve your language skills (e.g. take time and put effort into the readings even if there is no written assignment; contribute as much as possible to discussions).
If you want to continue improving your Russian, this class will definitely help you with that, but it is somewhat overwhelming because it is seminar-style.

Language classes are tedious, but this course is really where the payoff of the first two years of memorizing occurs. The workload is completely reasonable if you plan ahead and stay organized. It is probably 1 or 2 more hours a week than the second year courses.
Take it if you are interested in taking your russian to the next level
Take this course if you have an interest in Russian language, literature and culture.
Take this course if you truly care about Russian and want to learn in-depth about the language and culture.
Take this if you want to continue studying Russian! Ksana is so nice and a great teacher.

This is really different from previous Russian classes at Princeton. Ksana teaches very differently from Mark. I thought it was better, but not everyone agrees. The tests and general organization of this course can be a little frustrating at times, but the readings are so, so good.
prereqs: RUS 107 or Permission of Instructor..
descrip: A literature/language course designed to further develop speaking and reading proficiency, comprehension and writing skills through substantial expansion of vocabulary, work on sentence structure, review of selected grammar topics, discussion of the literary texts, and work with a movie.

title: Studies in German Language and Style: Society, Politics, and Culture in Germany, 1890-1945
reviews: Definitely take it
Great course. The readings are good but can be challenging. I feel as if my German has improved a lot.
I would certainly recommend the course, but only take it if you are willing to participate in discussion.
Take it. Even if you don't consider the German department, it is worth taking.
prereqs: GER 107 or permission of the instructor..
descrip: This course will tackle exemplary works of modern German society and culture, including literature, art, film, essays, speeches, and autobiographies. It offers an introduction to the most important events and issues from the first half of the century: the foundation of the German state, Berlin as a modern metropolis, World War I, the rise of National Socialism. Intensive practice in spoken and written German with an emphasis on vocabulary acquisition and complex syntactical forms.

title: Seminar in American Politics - American Political Thought, The Colonial Era to the Civil War
reviews: Prof. Whittington is a great lecturer and great teacher -- readings are interesting too. But be prepared for a lot of writing and discussion.

Really savor the readings: often, because they were so short, I ironically didn't make time to get to them, and I wish I had had more time to read and really think about the issues at stake. Look forward to the discussions, and start early on the presentations and final paper: try to take initiative in meeting with and planning with the professor, as guidance may not be forthcoming.
descrip: This seminar will explore recurring themes and problems in American political thought. The course will draw on primary and secondary sources relating to the ideas and actions that have shaped the American conception of freedom, democracy, community, and nationhood. It will consider these works as contributions to political theory, but it will also focus on the relationship between political ideas and political and social events. The course will focus on the period from the colonial era through the Civil War.

title: Problems in Political Theory - From Kant to Hegel
descrip: Selected concepts and problems in political theory. A different topic is treated each year. Topics include justice, equality, liberty, obligation, participation, the nature of political theory, and approaches to interpretation of political theory. The theme for this term is From Kant to Hegel.

title: Elementary Japanese I
reviews: Be ready to work!  It's not an easy language to pick up for native English speakers, but you definitely get out what you put in.
Definitely take it!
Definitely take it.
Highly recommend if you have interest in Japanese and want to start with no prior knowledge.

If you are at all interested in Japan or East Asian language, definitely take this course. The professors are happy and fun to work with, the course material is useful, and you will learn a lot. Be sure to do all the assignments asked of you, and try to do extra on your own outside of the class to learn even more. Be aware, this IS a time commitment.
If you are interested in learning Japanese, then this course will be very helpful.
If you're interested in Japanese, take it!!
Incredibly taught! The course is a lot of fun. Easy if you spend more time on it.

It's a lot of work, but the quality of the language class is great and offers a very comprehensive experience. If you're very interested in the language and are willing to put in the work it's worth it.
Learn Kanji early, start using Wani Kani as soon as you learn hiragana, and go to office hours!
Make sure you enjoy the class.
Take it!
Take it! If you have never done any Japanese this is a perfect start!
Take the course when you are young, not as a graduate student like me.
Take this class, the instructors are amazing.

With the fast pace of the class, it felt like learning was a lifestyle. This isn't a bad thing though, and having to constantly think about how you can improve your Japanese I think is a habit that will help you in the long run. The instructors I think know this, and that's what makes the class good and effective. There is lots of support if you feel behind or unprepared, and if you have already taken Princeton classes before, then Japanese is something you can get used to easily.
if you have any doubts about a language requirement, this class will definitely dispel them. I was never a language-type student but this was one of my favorite classes ever.
prereqs: No credit is given for JPN 101 unless it is followed by JPN 102..
descrip: An intensive introduction to modern Japanese stressing oral-aural facility, but including an introduction to written Japanese.

title: Mind and Meditation
reviews: Do not take this class unless you need it for graduation.

Don't take this course simply because you want to meditate for homework. Even if you find the meditation to be a positive experience, that is really not the focus of the class, and there is very little guidance on how to meditate.
Don't take unless you're a religion major. It's really frustrating and feels more like a book club full of people who just blurt out random things tangentially related to the text.
Highly recommended -- awesome professor and you learn a lot!

It's an enjoyable course if you do the readings - but the thing is, there's a ton to read every week and it's easy to get lost in all the foreign words. This stuff is legitimately interesting but gets very repetitive. 

I wouldn't take it unless you're genuinely interested in the subject or are a religion major. You meditate outside of class every day, have weekly responses, and the seminar is usually just a group discussion on one or two of the assigned readings. There's a nice break in the middle of the class and an interesting guest lecturer.

Take it if you are disciplined to meditate for the entire course for 20 or so minutes a day.  You probably aren't disciplined enough.  Otherwise, take it if you are really interested in the subject.  Do the readings, but don't expect much from seminar.
Take it.
The class is badly structured. Arbitrary grading and class discussions that go nowhere make this a truly awful class.
meditate everyday -- it is probably the most enjoyable experience one can possibly have
descrip: This course examines the philosophy, history, and methods of Buddhist meditation. Primary readings will be Buddhist works on the nature of the mind and the role of meditation on the path to liberation (nirvana). We will ask how traditional Buddhist views have been reshaped by modern teachers, and we will interrogate the significance of current research on meditation in the fields of neuroscience, psychology and the philosophy of mind. In addition to other coursework, students will be practicing meditation and keeping a log and journal. Some coursework in Philosophy or Religion is expected.

title: Independent Study
descrip: Independent Study in the student's area of interest. The work must be conducted under the supervision of a faculty member and must result in a final paper. Permission of advisor and instructor are required. Open to sophomores and juniors. Must fill out Independent Study form.

title: Introduction to Ancient Philosophy
reviews: Definitely take it if you're interested in learning more about philosophy.

Definitely take this course. Professor Lorenz is an incredibly clear and concise lecturer, who is always willing to help. Get to know him if you take it! You will have very interesting discussions with him. These are important texts to read, and you want to hear Lorenz' take on them. Not too much work, so it was really an enjoyable class all around.
Do the readings and pay attention in lecture and you'll be fine. For people who like logic and philosophy, this is a great class.
Don't do the papers the night before.
Even if you aren't a philosophy major, this is a great intro course!
Go ahead! You'll learn plenty about ancient philosophical thought.
Good class to pdf
Good pdf option if you want to dip your toes into philosophy. That said, I liked this class a lot, ended up taking it for a grade.
Great PDF, especially for EC
Highly recommend.
I would recommend against it, the material was not nearly as interesting as I had anticipated
I would recommend the course to all. It is interesting and well-taught.

If you attend all the lectures, you will have no trouble understanding the material. Talk to your preceptor about the papers if you're having trouble. You will learn a lot from this class about the way the ancients viewed the world and why those views still resonate with philosophers today.
If you need this distribution requirement, I highly recommend that you take this course.

If you want to major in Philosophy, this is probably not the best intro course to take. If you are generally interested in knowing about ancient philosophy, this is a really good course, as long as you actually do the readings and go to the lectures.
It is a great class, in general subject and as a distribution requirement. Work load is not too heavy, and material is interesting.
It's a really chill class. Take it.
Nothing to write home about, but you'll get a basic grounding in ancient philosophical ideas.
Recommend as a distribution requirement.
Sit closely enough to see the board in lecture and stay engaged. Try not to skip them because they are hugely helpful when it comes to the papers.

Sometimes boring but if you do the readings and pay attention in lecture, it can be really interesting. I PDF'd this class and put maybe 1-2 hours of work into each easy and ended up getting B's/B-'s on papers, so if you're interested in philosophy, I'm sure that you could get an A/B  by putting in a little more effort.. Attend lectures....it helps at TON with writing the essays
Take it as a DR, but don't take as an upperclassmen in the PHI department.
Take it if you are into *ancient* philosophy.
Take it if you need an EC, but realize the written assignments can be very hit or miss, so it's not always as easy as everyone says.
Take the course!

Take this class if you are interested in philosophy. Make sure you are precise about understanding the arguments; often times you may feel you understand the argument but may be missing key details. Go to lectures, they are great.
The course is relatively easy on work, and thought-probing for people with an interest in philosophy.
The readings are very interesting so do them. They help to master the material.
This course may be a good way to approach philosophy. It's not painful at all and it can give you a taste so you know if philosophy is something that suits your brain.
This is a mediocre intro to phil class; if you take it try to get Keinan Greene as your preceptor
Write your papers early and talk them over with your preceptor.
take it if you want basic knowledge of philosophy
descrip: This course discusses the ideas and arguments of major ancient Greek philosophers and thereby introduces students to the history and continued relevance of the first centuries of western philosophy. Topics include the rise of cosmological speculation, the beginnings of philosophical ethics, Plato's moral theory and epistemology, Aristotle's philosophy of nature, metaphysics and ethics. The course ends with a survey of philosophical activity in the Hellenistic period.

title: Topics in the History and Theory of Architecture in Early-Modern Europe - The Rome of Giovanni Battista Piranesi
descrip: The focus of the seminar will be G.B. Piranesi (1720-1778), as architect, antiquarian, polemicist, dealer, and graphic artist. We will endeavor to see Piranesi in context, to understand his accomplishment against the background of his adopted city and the learned culture that flourished there. Piranesi's publications are well represented in Princeton collections, providing opportunities for those who wish to work closely with original sources.

title: Illusions, Delusions, and Neuroscience
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Pushkin, Gogol, Dostoevsky: Introduction to the Great Russian Novel
reviews: Do it if you even have the slightest interest in Russian lit.
Great course! Amazing readings and Watchel is a must have - very nice, approachable, and knows his Russian Literature!
Highly Recommend.

If you're vaguely interested in Russian literature/history/any kind of literature, then take the course. The readings are the best part, but are really complemented by learning about historical/literary context, and having discussions about them.
Keep up with the readings!
Russian literature is amazing. Take this course if you have the slightest interest. Papers are slightly difficult for someone who has never taken a literature course before, but it's worth it!
Russian novels are great, the workload is pretty light, I'd say take it.
Take it if you love this era of literature! Wachtel is a wonderful professor.
these are great books!
prereqs: Knowledge of Russian not required..
descrip: A survey in English of major literary developments and fictional texts in Russian culture from the early nineteenth century to the mid-19th century. The course concentrates on these master prose writters: Pushkin, Gogol, Lermontov, the early Dostoevsky.

title: Public Opinion
reviews: A pretty good politics course. I took it because I was thinking about being a woody woo major. It isn't a whole lot of work and it's fairly interesting. The stuff gets a little repetitive after a while, though.
A representative introduction to empirical political science.
Be sure to maintain organized notes; you'll frequently have to dig for older material when writing essays
Definitely take it if you are at all interested in politics. It has a strong psych/soc feel to it but I found that more enjoyable.
Don't take

Even if the subject material doesn't sound interesting to you at first, you still learn valuable information about the American public and the level of preparation/planning that went into this course is unparalleled.
Get ready for a heavy liberal agenda
Go to office hours

I really liked this class. The material is interesting and relevant (especially in terms of the results of past elections, etc), Professor Mendelberg is a really good lecturer, and the assignments actually link up with the course material. Also, Pavielle Haines was a great preceptor- she taught the material very well and really did a great job breaking down the readings.
I recommend.
I think that it's an amazing course that you should absolutely take if you want to learn more about public opinion and how it fits into our democracy.
I would take if you want a good POL course. Teaches you a lot about people, democracy and government.

In terms of workload, it's a pretty standard POL departmental.  Definitely worth taking if you're interested in politics, public opinion, and/or the media.  Do know that the final take-home is really just another paper, but I felt the workload in general was very reasonable (three short papers and a moderate reading load).
It's a good class. I'd say take it because it's interesting and not too hard.
It's a very well-organized and you will definitely learn a lot if you go to lectures. Definitely take it if you're interested in American democracy.
Leave yourself a lot of time to think through and complete the paper assignments.
Listen in lectures. Make sure you understand how different concepts connect.
Make sure to participate actively in class.
Take it, especially if you like campaigns and elections. Favorite class this semester, although I am a pol major.
Take this class if you have any interest in public policy. It is not hard to understand, but the data and information learned is interesting and is a good foundation for many areas of politics.
Take this class!  It's a really interesting look at public opinion and how the American public responds to politicians and policies.
definitely worth taking.
it is kind of boring. but you can get valuable information out of it.
take if you're really really interested in how public opinion forms and what influences different social groups' political opinions. But if you're not interested in the topic, it can be a little dry
take it
descrip: This course is an introduction to the study of American public opinion. We pay particular attention to the questions of where people get their opinions, to inequalities in public opinion, and to the public's competence to govern.

title: Introductory Playwriting
reviews: Please do yourself a favor and take this class. It has been one of my favorite classes that I've taken at Princeton. That being said, prepare to work hard. Whether you like it or not, you will end up spending a lot of time working on your independent work because you inevitably become attached to it.
Take the class. It'll be one of the most creative courses you take at Princeton.
The more time and work you put into each assignment, the more you will get out of them.
prereqs: Enrollment by interview with the instructor, Professor Robert Sandberg (rsand@Princeton.edu). Please contact Professor Sandberg for more information..
descrip: This is a workshop in the fundamentals of writing plays. Emphasis will be on solving problems of structure, dramatic action, and character. Attention will also be given to innerlife, language, atmosphere on stage, creating living dialogue, and examining the sources to be used in writing, etc.

title: Introduction to Geophysical Fluid Dynamics
reviews: Although the content is interesting from a fluid mechanics perspective, the way it is presented can be very frustrating and you will end up teaching yourself most of the material.
It's good material, but be prepared to rely on your own abilities in the second half.  If Dr. Griffies were to have taught it the whole semester, I would 100% recommend the class to anyone.

Look at who is teaching this class. If Griffies, I wholeheartedly recommend it, but you should be prepared to treat it seriously and put a lot of time into. If Garner, only take it if it is a requirement.
Make sure that you can get help on the problem sets from either the instructor, or better yet, other students in the class.
descrip: Physical principles fundamental to the theoretical, observational, and experimental study of the atmosphere and oceans. The equations of motion for rotating fluids. Hydrostatic and geostrophic balance. Conservation of potential vorticity. Introduction to quasi-geostrophic theory and baroclinic instability. Geophysical boundary layers. Rossby and gravity waves.

title: Evolution and Catastrophes
reviews: Always keep in mind the bigger picture when considering mass extinctions and other events. Be able to place things in a timeline in your mind.
An interesting time, but not the most bang for your buck!
Could be difficult if you lack a science background, but all in all an interesting course without any particularly difficult work
Definitely take it.
Gerta grades harshly because she has high expectations of you, not because she's trying to build a curve.

Great overview course of the evolutions throughout Earth history. Of course, the trip to Morocco is amazing, and you learn alot there (as well as have a great time!). The only minor problem is that the course lacks a little organization, but hopefully that will improve next year.
I was very confused about how this class was being evaluated right until the very end.

Make sure you email the TA frequently for help with assignments. Although assignments aren't usually difficult, it was hard to know exactly what the professor wanted and/or expected from the students in the class.
Take this course if you are considering being a GEO major; it really gives a good foundation and helps acquire skills that are needed in other courses.

gerta is a bit scatter-brained and her method of teaching isn't very clear, but the trip was phenomenal and she knows so much about the current state of the field and the science we were immersed in   has a phenomenal life story (ask her about it) so was a wonderful leader during our trip.
prereqs: One 200-level GEO course or Geosciences Freshman Seminar..
descrip: This course introduces students to the evolution of life and mass extinction's based on a broad survey of major events in Earth history as revealed by the fossil record. Concepts and techniques of paleontology are applied to all aspects, including colonization of the oceans, invasion of land, mass extinction's and evolutionary radiation's. The roles of major catastrophes in the history of life are evaluated, including meteorite impacts, volcanism, climate change, and oceanic anoxia.

title: Nomads, Nomadism and Nomadology
descrip: Please see freshman seminars website

title: Seminar in Comparative Politics - African Politics
descrip: One or more theoretical topics currently of major concern in comparative politics are treated.

title: Dance Performance Workshop: Intermediate Repertory and Choreography
reviews: Enjoy dance and taking creative risks. Don't be complacent, come to class on time, be willing to dive into choreography and have an open mind in dance.
If you have a love of dance, this is a great way to learn about the academia surrounding dance as well as an opportunity to perform.  This is time consuming, however.
Take if interested in working on technique!
This was a great class! If you are interested in dance take it.
prereqs: DAN 219/220, or equivalent. Interview with faculty for placement in composition section from April 7-18, 2014. To arrange an interview, email Professor Lazier (rlazier@) or Professor Fehlandt (fehlandt@) and send a list of any previous composition experience at Princeton. NOTE: Placement for Technique/Repertory component of class will be held Wednesday, September 10th from 4:30-6:20 at Hagan Dance Studio at 185 Nassau..
descrip: Intermediate dance technique and choreography, with a focus on contemporary practices. In technique, students will be challenged to increase their body's strength, coordination and alignment, and to develop awareness and range of motion in multiple spatial planes. The repertory component of this course calls on students' collaborative abilities as they work with faculty in the development a new dance. In choreography, students will work in movement-based laboratories to develop their fluency with a wide range of contemporary choreographic approaches. Readings and viewings contextualize the work culturally and historically.

title: Fakes, Frauds, and Charlatans
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Critical Theory - Comparative Literature Writing and Dissertation Colloquium
descrip: The Writing and Dissertation Colloquium is a biweekly forum for graduate students in Comparative Literature to share works in progress with other graduate students. The seminar welcomes drafts of your prospectus, article, dissertation chapter, conference paper, exam statement and grant or fellowship proposal. Work is pre-circulated. The 90 minute sessions, done in conjunction with a rotating COM faculty member, are designed to offer written and oral feedback.

title: Sex on the Brain
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Biological Physics
reviews: A very open-ended class that the more you put in, the more you'll get out of it.  Come to class having done the reading, and you'll learn a lot.  Not too high a workload either.

Read a few scholarly scientific articles before signing up to make sure you enjoy the assignments. If you do, this is a great class for you. Also, it helps if you know a decent amount of biology before taking the class.
Read the papers, prepare well for your presentation
Take it. Awesome class.
Take it. It's a great discussion class, and learning about Biophysics is a great idea. Some of the concepts will blow your mind.
prereqs: Introductory Physics (PHY 103/104, PHY 105/106, ISC 231-234).
descrip: Biological Physics is one of the fastest growing areas of physics. This course focuses on both experimental and theoretical physics approaches to understanding biological molecules, cells, and tissues. We will start with an overview of the forces present within a cell that govern the activity of enzymes and the motion of molecular motors and the cytoskeleton. We then move on to discuss physical processes on the cellular level that give rise to motility, tissue development and differentiation. Emphasis will be placed on both techniques and scientific concepts. Classes will be a combination of lectures and student presentations.

title: Genetics
reviews: Be prepared for a very long, tough journey.
Don't take it if you don't have to!

Don't take this class unless you absolutely have to. The lectures are not engaging, and the problem sets/exams just test how well you can remember specific formulas for how to solve certain problems. Just don't take it. Don't.
Get a buddy for psets, and good luck.
I wouldn't recommend it unless you need to take it.

If you have to take this course, you will probably enjoy it more than you think. The subject matter is very interesting, and the professors are passionate about their subject. However, I wouldn't take this for fun, just because the problem sets are certainly challenging and it can be difficult to sit through 80 minutes of lecture.

It's not as bad as everyone says it is. Find a group for p-sets; they WILL take forever and there's nothing you can do about it. The good thing is that they never change the content of p-sets and tests from year to year so try to find someone who's taken it for help.

Just don't. MOL majors, prepare to sleep through all your Genetics lectures because you spent a frustrating night with other frustrated students trying to chisel away at a problem set. Until the professors take a good look at their respective lectures styles, I can't recommend this course to anyone.
Make sure you understand how to solve all of the problems in the problem sets before taking the exam.
Not worth a class to take unless it's a requirement.
Only take this class if it's a requirement. It could be really interesting but is very poorly taught--one of the worst classes I've taken at Princeton.
Prepare for the midterm and final a lot!
Probably taking it because you have to
Put the time in to really understand what you're doing in the problem sets.
Set aside time for the problem sets. Try to enjoy them; they're not all awful and some are fun in a puzzle-solving way!
Study the practice tests and problem sets several times before you take the actual exam. Stay awake in lecture
Take only if a MOL major or interesting in genetics.

The main questions on exams are basically the same as practice exams. The only difference is the conceptual questions asked alongside the main questions. If you know how to do the main questions thats a 50% right there.
This class could be so interesting, but ends up being extremely frustrating. It is taught really poorly and rarely are you given enough resources to even teach yourself. Good luck.

This class is a major group effort. Make sure you do the problem sets with people and make friends if you don't know anyone. There are a lot of really difficult concepts that some people are better at than others, so it is really helpful to be able to learn from your peers. Also, I don't think I would have finished any of them without some group collaboration. Also, really study the problem sets and practice problems for the midterm and final. There are only so many types of problems that they can ask, so you want as much exposure as possible. Also, only take it if you have to or can PDF it. It is very challenging.

This course is incredibly hard, but ultimately fair. The midterm and final basically mirror the practice exams given out so be sure to drill those. Do ALL your problem sets - all the learning happens there. Also, make sure you get into a great precept and form a study group with people who share your level of commitment to the class and who are at your level in terms of understanding the material.
This course is very interesting. Go over the lecture notes before doing the problem sets and look in the textbook for additional information regarding the topic if needed.

Try to clear your schedule a little. Definitely requires a lot of work unless you are a genius at genetics. DO THE PSET and not just rely on other people doing the pset with you. Make sure you really understand how you got the answer.
Unless some large changes are made, this is not the best class for a student interested in the topic.
Unless you are a mol major or really interested in genetics, don't take this class if you don't have to.
Work hard and keep on top of the material. Ask a lot of questions.
make sure to read through all problem sets before an exam
prereqs: MOL 214 or 215 or by permission of instructor.
descrip: Basic principles of genetics illustrated with examples from prokaryote and eukaryote organisms with emphasis on classic genetic techniques. The evolving conception of the gene and genome will be the primary focus of the course. Selected advanced topics will include Drosophila developmental genetics, yeast cell biology and human disease.

title: International Monetary Economics
reviews: Easy course with very little work load. You will not come out of this class as an expert of monetary economics, but you'll at least be able to understand how it affects real world situations.
Not a hard class and very similar to macro. Professor Aguiar is great.
One of the more interesting Economics courses with one of the better professors.
Really interesting stuff.
Study and it's a rewarding, interesting, and not too difficult course.

Take it if you want to learn about macroeconomics and how the theory applies to various countries. It was a very interesting course and I learned a lot. The lecture slides were very good and the problem sets and exams were pretty straightforward too.

Take this class if you are interested in macro economics. Just from a very practical perspective, I feel like I am finally able to understand what the articles are saying in WSJ after taking this class.
The midterm and final are a bit too easy but the lectures are good. I found the material interesting.
Very dry, and not that different from the macro courses like ECO 301, except with a bit more detail on exchange rates, currencies, certain models, etc.
take it, sure
prereqs: ECO 100 and ECO 101. Course not required for concentrators..
descrip: This course studies topics in open-economy macroeconomics and international finance. Topics include Exchange Rates,Current Account Imbalances, Inflation, Sovereign Debt, and Open Economy Macroeconomics. The course will include economic theory as well as several applications.

title: Music of the Classical Period
reviews: Burnham is captivating lecturer. Just take the class. I promise it will be worth it.
Burnham is fantastic and enthusiastic lecturer, take this if you're remotely interested in classical music.
Definitely take this course, whether or not you are a music major. Enjoy the lectures of Professor Burnham and learn to share in his passion for the music.
Enjoyable, and not too time consuming.
Go to all the lectures!
Go to lectures, because they're very interesting, and you'll definitely learn something.  Do the readings; it may be a struggle, but you'll be a better person for having done it.

If you like classical music and want to look at it from a critical perspective and learn its history, this is a good course for that. Professor Burnham's lectures are really engaging and he knows the pieces well enough to point you to the interesting bits.
Please take this course. It will be an eye opening experience as you will hear classical music differently.

Pretty easy class. Prof Burnham is super nice but not the most inspiring lecturer. Make sure you like the classical period b/c there are listening exams and if all those alberti bass sound the same to you, you could be in trouble.
Take it with Scott Burnham!
Take it! Definitely take a class with professor Burnham
Take it.
Take this course for Burnham. If you must take one music class, take this one.
Take this, or anything that Prof. Burnham, teaches. And if you are interested in the Classical Period especially, he's the one you want to learn it from.

This class was a really enjoyable experience. It transformed my engaged but uninformed appreciation of classical music to one which is more refined, subtle, and enduring. I'd highly recommend it, especially if Scott Burnham is teaching it!
You can take this class even if you have no classical music training but if you take it you should try to make yourself listen to a lot of classical music because the more you listen the better.
You don't really have to go to lecture, but it's just so entertaining! Also really helpful for the listening quizzes...otherwise pretty light work load.

take it if you have any interest in spending a few hours of class every week listening to classical music. burnham is a great lecturer and tells all sorts of fun stories. the class was never too stressful, and the workload is very manageable
descrip: A comprehensive introduction to the historical, aesthetic, and stylistic issues of the music of the Viennese Classical period. Class discussions will focus on the critical analysis of selected musical works by Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven, as well as on the cultural context of the music.

title: Advanced Political Institutions
descrip: Designed to expose students to substantive and methodological controversies that are currently engaging scholars of political institutions. Integrates theoretical and quantitative skills by focusing on the processes of extracting hypotheses from formal models, stating hypotheses in a manner conducive to tests, collecting data, conducting tests, and making inferences. Assumes prior completion of POL 542.

title: Contemporary Critical Theories - Translating Violence/Translating Justice
descrip: This team-taught seminar examines contemporary postcoloniality and the dilemmas of decolonization in light of questions of translation. To what extent do theories and practices of translation and untranslatability inform our understanding of a globalized ostcoloniality? In what ways must the thinking and doing of translation be revised in these conditions? The class will focus on themes such as multilingual and multiethnic states, borders and checkpoints, ecological crisis, oil politics, primitive accumulation, debt, financialization, gendered violence and rape cultures, and figures of justice.

title: The Age of Rights: Nature, Enlightenment, and Revolution
reviews: If politics is your favorite subject, by all means take this class. Professor Edelstein is wonderful. I, however felt that the material was very dry.
Take this because it's interesting even though there's a lot of reading.
This is an engaging course with a focus on close readings and group discussion
descrip: The century that concluded with declarations of rights on both sides of the Atlantic witnessed a transformation in how people talked about rights. Previously a mostly philosophical discourse, rights talk entered the broader world of letters. But in some parts of the world (France in particular), this transformation also brought back Classical notions of natural right. This course explores how the modern language of rights emerged during the Enlightenment and Revolutionary periods, and also places this "Age of Rights" in a longer history stretching from Antiquity to the twentieth century.

title: Introductory Drawing
reviews: Definitely take it! Even if you are a beginner!

Don't take this class with Nathan if you are not already an artist.  If you already like your artwork and do not feel the need to improve but just want to draw for fun, take this class.  If you want any instruction or suggestions for your work, do not take this class with Nathan (maybe other sections are different? so do more research into other professors and ask around).  However, with no artistic background, I don't say that I regret taking it with him, because it definitely has sparked my interest; I just wish I had done some more research.
I heard the fall semester teacher was much better. Definitely take that one.
I wouldnt take it again
If you have a serious interest in art or just like to draw, you should find the time to take this course. It accommodates all skill levels.
If you want to learn how to draw, this is the class for you!
If you're interested in drawing, this will make you much better.

Make sure to set aside every week for the assignments because they can be time consuming and should not be rushed if you want them to be worthwhile. Do not be afraid to experiment. Eve is always supportive.
Take it
Take it with Nathan Carter!

Take it with Nathan if you can. Come to explore, great change of pace course. Still, with the larger projects be thinking and do research because he can tell if you threw something together at the last minute
Take it!
Take it, like there is no reason not to take it, it's a fun LA worst case scenario
Take this class! Professor Carter doesn't judge you based on your technical skill-- he just wants to see you have fun and try things out. He's the best.
Take this if you have any interest in drawing!

This class is a great class to take no matter your skill level.  There is not too much work outside of class but there are three main projects that you need to dedicate a lot of time and effort to.  Also Nathan is really interested in not only what the final piece looks like but also your process, research, and the thoughts behind the project.
This course is very dependent on which teacher you have.
This is a great course for anyone that wants to explore art, regardless of your level of skill.
To be ready for about three hours of homework a week that involve either reading or drawing.
You get out of the course what you put into it, if they are engaged and take it seriously its a really great course to take.
descrip: This course approaches drawing as a way of thinking and seeing. Students will be introduced to a range of drawing issues, as well as a variety of media, including charcoal, graphite, ink and oil stick. Subject matter includes still life, the figure, landscape and architecture. Representation, abstraction and working from imagination will be explored. A structured independent project will be given at the end of the semester.

title: Responsible Conduct in Research: A Course on Ethics in Engineering (Half-term)
prereqs: This course is required for graduate students in engineering who participate in federally funded research; the course is highly recommended and/or required for undergraduate students as well as post-doctoral researchers in engineering who participate in federally funded research. There are no prerequisites for attending the course..
descrip: This course educates the graduate student of engineering in the responsible conduct of research. The lectures provide theoretical background information as well as case studies about ethics in day-to-day research situations, in publishing and peer-review, in student-advisor relationships, in collaborative research, as well as in the big picture and considerations of long-term impact. The students are provided with resources to consult in ethical questions. In small-group discussions in research field-specific precepts, the theoretical concepts are made relevant to the individual students situations.

title: Introduction to Post-Classical Greek from the Late Antique to the Byzantine Era
reviews: Check back with the instructor if he would be able to offer a reading course for grads only instead.
Definitely take. Work load is very manageable, and Professor Bourbouhakis is great. Very nice man and knows the material as well any.

Do all of the translations. Pay attention in class; occasionally, Prof. Bourbouhakis will drop hints about what passages to expect on the exams, which can be beyond helpful, since otherwise it becomes a guessing game. Make summaries of the readings, or at least take notes when other people present their own summaries of the readings in class. Brush up on your grammar if needed; Prof. Bourbouhakis understandably doesn't spend much time on reviewing grammar in class. Also don't take this class with the expectation that you will be viewing the Septuagint and New Testament from anything other than a purely linguistic and historical viewpoint.

Don't take it with Bourbouhakis - you'll get more out of it if you sit down and read the New Testament and Septuagint on your own, without the benefit of his half-hour poetic rants on the simplest of ideas.
Familiarity with the Bible in general is a huge help. Make sure to take everything we read as important (don't assume that the Bible is the only focus of the course).
Instructor is very good at engaging on the primary source readings, so if you have the choice, privilege close attention to the primary source readings over the secondary material.
It's an excellent course for undergraduates, but graduate students should perhaps consider other options.

Prof. Bourbouhakis is one of the best teachers in the department -- not just pedagogically, but also his outlook on education. If you have a chance to take a class with him, don't hesitate! The material (mostly the Bible, but also some pagan texts) was fascinating, because this was a period of much change in language, semantics and religious make-up in the mediterranean.

Professor Bourbouhakis is incredibly knowledgeable. Although he very frequently lingers over tiny words/phrases/issues and will endlessly elaborate on them, despite the tedium I felt that by listening to him talk I learned a great lot about the development of the Greek language that I knew little about before, and actually integrated the information in a manner that a mere textbook wouldn't have allowed me to.
TAKE THIS CLASS. It's great and an easy A if you keep up with the reading.
This course is an excellent way to discover your interests and ways that you learn, both language and broader concepts.
prereqs: This course is open to all students with a good grasp of Greek grammar and syntax who have an interest in the development of Greek as a post-classical and Biblical language. Students from every department are welcome, graduates as well as undergraduates..
descrip: This course will focus on the Greek Bible and the emergence of a 'common' Greek language. We will read excerpts from the Septuagint (the Greek transl. of the Hebrew bible) and from the New Testament in order to understand how Greek evolved from the time of Alexander the Great to the Roman emperors so as to become the 'common tongue' (koine) of a Hellenized eastern Mediterranean world of Jews, Pagans, and Christians.

title: Population, Society and Public Policy
reviews: Don't do the readings.
Don't take it unless you really care about overpopulation
Go to lecture

I think the course was interesting and engaging and covered a wide array of material, so there is bound to be a topic that interests anyway (good for papers). The expectations are clear so even though it is a decent amount of work, it is manageable.
I would tell the student to assess his interest in demography. The course is a good introduction to population studies and can be a good opportunity to learn something new.

If you're interested in learning about basic demographic concepts and their importance/relevance to public policy areas you are interested in, take this class! It's manageable and Prof. Tienda and the preceptors are brimming with knowledge and enthusiasm!
Obviously you have to take this. It is an interesting course, but it does not cover the topics with much depth. This course is not difficult but not an easy A either.
PDF if you want to take it
Pay attention in lecture and keep up with the readings and you will be fine!
Recommend.
Review lecture notes after each class and also be sure to participate in precept, and ask questions as you go along rather than holding them in until the very end of the course.
Take it if you must, it should be a pretty easy way to get an A if you exert any effort.

Take it if you want an easy way to fulfill the Sociology/Psychology requirement for WWS! Honestly, would say it's better than Psych of Decision of Making. Also take it if you have any interest in anything related to population/demography (which is everything in policy essentially!)

Take this course if you are at all interested in the ways in which policy decisions are influenced. This is a large survey course that somehow still manages to be well rounded and it will provide any students with the tools needed to tackle the most controversial of contemporary issues.
Take this course! Even if population sounds like a dry topic, Professor Tienda really brings it to life and shows you how it impacts every other realm of policy.

Take this course. Prof. Tienda and the preceptors (Etienne and Marienne) are incredibly helpful and friendly. Note that Prof. Tienda likes papers that incredibly detailed oriented and draw on a lot of facts from research. So long as you do that and write rather concisely, you should do fine in the course's papers.
The course is really interesting, and other than the readings there's little out of class work.

The lectures and precepts are pretty laid back and interesting, but the grading on submitted work is much stricter than you'd expect based on lecture & precept. Not sure how this compares to other classes that could satisfy the same WWS departmental, but you can take this if you have any interest in learning demographic concepts (think birth rate, death rate, and population growth).
This course is very interesting and you will learn a lot! Make sure that you understand the precept exercises. This will help you with the problem sets.
Very interesting class. Tienda is a great Prof. and really wants you to learn! Not too difficult.
descrip: How long can humans live? Is marriage obsolete? How many people can planet earth support sustainably? Why does China have more boys than girls? Should governments decide family size? Why are youth rebellious in some countries and not in others? Is demography destiny? This course examines the causes and consequences of population change, with a focus on the policy levers used to regulate fertility, to improve health and child mortality; to protect the environment; and to control immigration. Students learn basic demographic concepts; course readings engage longstanding debates about whether population growth promotes or undermines development.

title: Mind Games
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Topics in Conformal and Cauchy-Rieman (CR) Geometry - Recent Developments in Conformal Geometry
prereqs: Undergraduates require permission of the instructor.
descrip: This course covers current topics in Conformal and Cauchy-Rieman (CR) Geometry. More specific topic details are provided when the course is offered.

title: Seminar on Student Learning and Methods for Teaching
reviews: Great course for anyone interested in education and especially for rising educators!
If you plan to be a future teacher or work in education, this is a must.  This is a time intensive class, but all the work is very carefully designed to be useful for becoming a future teacher.
It is a good course, but there is a lot of work involved. Be prepared!
It's a great course to learn about pedagogy - it definitely prepares you to become  a teacher.
It's a lot of work, but most of it useful to your future as a teacher.

Really great seminar that surveys important topics and issues teachers have to think about in preparation for teaching. Small class and interesting discussions made this seminar one of my favorite classes.
prereqs: The course is required for students in the Program in Teacher Preparation and is open to non-program students provided space is available. Interested non-program students should contact the Teacher Preparation Office for permission to take the course..
descrip: A study of essential methods of learning and teaching, including learner characteristics and needs, organization and structure of educational institutions, development of curriculum and instructional goals, preparation of evaluation and assessment, and design of subject/level specific methodologies and classroom management techniques. Required course work includes 18 hours of site-based field experience and evening laboratory sessions.

title: Multivariable Calculus
reviews: 201 is a computationally heavy course. Work ahead, do problem sets on time and try and work with a group - watch the videos on Khan Academy and Adrian Banner on youtube to get more conceptual understanding. Don't fall behind - make sure you keep up with the pace of the class and go to office hours if you don't understand anything.

201 seems to be a lot less work than 203. Problem sets were pretty short near the start of the year--probably took around 2 hours per week--though got lengthier near the end of the semester (~5 hours). Don't expect the material to be presented in a particularly engaging way, and if you're interested in learning more theory and are willing to put in the extra time, I would suggest considering 203 instead. Would recommend reading the explanations and examples provided in the textbook; while it takes a while to read, the textbook is actually very helpful. Multivariable calculus is pretty useful however, and while the process of learning it wasn't very fun, I'm glad I now know it.
Address concerns as soon as you aren't understanding a topic, or you will fall even further behind. Read the textbook and take advantage of McGraw study halls and office hours.

As you go through the semester, I might recommend making study sheets for each unit as you finish it.  That way, you'll have a resource when it comes time to study for the quizzes, midterm, and final.

Attend all lectures, read the book, do the problem sets, attend office hours, and do practice exams. The quizzes and exams will be extremely difficult. Don't be intimidated. Just draw diagrams when appropriate and make sure you understand the fundamental concepts and how they fit together. Don't be afraid to ask questions of the professor.
Be ahead prior to lecture
Be prepared to be challenged. Only take it if you need to fulfill requirements. I didn't actually need to take it and am questioning why I did.
Be ready to apply the formulas and concepts to harder things than the homework. Other than that, the class itself is not that bad.

Be sure to do the homework on time. Try to get a good teacher, and go to office hours if you don't understand anything. Attend review sessions and always study for tests. It will be difficult, but it is definitely manageable.
Becare of who your teacher is, make sure you try to get a good lecturer. One you can understand, and takes good notes!
Challenging course. Regular practice is a must.
DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS UNLESS YOU HAVE TO.....Literally awful.....Jeffry Case is the only good preceptor
DO NOT TAKE THIS COURSE.  YOU WILL REGRET IT.  IF IT IS A REQUIREMENT FOR A MAJOR, DO NOT CHOOSE THAT MAJOR.
DON'T GET BEHIND

DON'T TAKE IT unless you have to. It has bad reviews on easypce and there is a reason why. (Take it with Professor Case if you have to -- he's the best lecturer.) Do all the psets and go to class. Start spending time on it early on even if you don't want to. Grading isn't too bad if you're just aiming for a B .
Definitely review often.
Definitely review single variable concepts in depth.
Do as many practice tests as you can as preparation for all tests and quizzes. No point in taking it if you don't need to.
Do not take if you do not have to

Do not take this course unless you need it for a requirement or are very interested in mathematical theory.  The course material has little application to other fields and is hard to conceptualize.  The workload is also pretty heavy and overall is a difficult course for little reward.
Do not take unless and engineer, math major, or econ major.  This math is not a joke and will require an obscene amount of effort if you are not mathematically inclined.
Do not underestimate this course and please be thorough with reading, problem sets, and attending McGraw (McGraw was very helpful!)

Do realize that this is a difficult course and if you fall behind, it is difficult to catch up. It moves at a fast pace in comparison to high school math classes, and the expectations are much higher. Don't just know the equations, but know how to apply the material you learn to unfamiliar situations.
Do the practice quizzes and exams!!
Do the problem sets and review material weekly. Otherwise, the tests will be hard- extremely hard- and you must be ready for anything.
Do the readings and ask questions! The course is very difficult if you fall behind early. Put the time in with the assignments because they help a lot later when taking exams.
Do the readings before class and start problem sets early so you have time to ask questions if you don't understand. Don't fall behind because the material builds upon itself.
Don't do the problem sets the day before they're due.
Don't expect plug-and-chug answers on the test (which isn't what you should expect anyway if you want to learn real math).
Don't fall behind, very hard to catch up.
Don't fall behind. It's easy to just do ok on hw's and miss lectures. Quiz or test time you will regret it .
Don't fall behind. This is a very useful course.
Don't get down on yourself if you don't get the grades you want.

Don't procrastinate the problem sets and create unnecessary stress. Do them over the course of the week, and then it's not that bad. Read the book as you go. Just do it. Take practice quizzes. Make time for that.
Don't show up late to your midterm. Set multiple alarms before you sleep because otherwise It sucks.
Don't slack off and cram study. The material is very cumulative. Pre-reading the chapters before hand can help a lot in understanding the professor during class.
Don't take class if you don't need to.
Don't take it if you don't have to and don't like math.
Don't take it if you don't have to.
Don't take it unless required. This class turned me off from math indefinitely.
Dr. Case is extremely smart about the subject.  Keep a rolling study guide with formulas and stuff.
Even though 201 was a challenging course, I would recommend it to others because it helps one to think in different ways.
Exams can be hard. Don't underestimate.

FRESHMAN ENGINEERS LOOK HERE. This class is most likely going to be your first math class at Princeton. There is a reason it gets bad reviews - it is very hard. There isn't really a way around that. Just understand, you will feel overwhelmed at times, but that is Princeton math. You can definitely survive through the class.
Final is way harder than homework

Find the Adrian Banner videos on youtube and watch them; they're a godsend. Also, don't worry if you struggle with this course- everyone that slugged through this course enjoyed Linear Algebra much more.

Go ahead and read the book before lecture otherwise you'll be blindly copying problems and answers having no idea what's going on. You have to teach yourself the material and it's tough but you have no choice. You only take this class because you have to.
Go to class, do the psets, go to office hours, ask questions when you don't understand something. Exams are tough, but the curve helps a lot.
Go to office hours and take the practice exams.
Good luck.

Homework is relatively straightforward, but quizzes and exams require application of concepts beyond the level of homework problems. Definitely use past quizzes/exams to practice, they'll help you get used to the types of questions that you'll encounter. Don't be discouraged if you find the quizzes/exams tough, because everyone does!
I had an amazing instructor, so coupled with good coursework I would easily recommend it. Jeffrey Case is love, Jeffrey Case is life.
I started supplementing class with lectures on Youtube from Adrian Banner when he taught 201 - I wish that I'd started doing that earlier.

I would definitely prepare for the exams by doing old practice exams and by visiting your preceptor during office hours. Do not hesitate to ask questions!! Also, it's important to shop for your preceptor, because it will really determine how much you understand the concepts and material of the course.
I would not recommend they take it unless it is required.
I wouldn't take it unless you need to, I've heard MAT 175 is easier

IF YOU DON'T NEED TO TAKE IT, THEN DON'T TAKE IT. I didn't need it for a requirement and PDFed thinking that it would take minimal effort to pass. I was extremely wrong. Here's to hoping that I get that P...

If you are taking this course, really commit yourself to learning the material and review frequently. It may not seem like a lot in the beginning but the complexity of the material increases as the course goes on in an abstract way most math students are unaccustomed to.
If you don't have to take it, I wouldn't. If you do have to take it, though, make friends and check problem sets with them.
If you don't have to take it, or don't have a great love for math, don't take the class.  Otherwise, it is a pretty hard class that you can get through if you really try.
If you don't have to take this course, don't.  If you do, get ahead on the reading so that you are familiar with the concepts that the instructor brings up in class.
If you don't have to, don't. Extremely difficult class with inadequate preparation.
If you have another option, don't take it. If you don't, good luck
If you have to take it, you have to take it. If you don't, you probably shouldn't unless you really love math.
If you want to learn Multivariable Calculus, this course would do. Just be prepared to spend some time trying to either catch up or stay ahead as lectures are pretty quick-paced.

If you're a freshman, make sure you come in with a solid background. Don't skip lecture; sometimes you might feel like you're getting nothing from it, but trust me you are at least getting exposure, and that is helpful. Do the homework. Curve helps but DO NOT allow yourself to fall behind.
If you're comfortable teaching yourself most of the material and you find it inherently engaging, you'll be fine. Otherwise, this course is fairly uninspiring.
If you're not extremely good at math (by Princeton standards, not your high school), or willing to put in about an hour of work each night, I would not recommend this course.

If you're not getting a BSE degree and you're not interested in multivariable calculus, then do not take this course. If you are very interested in multivariable calculus, take MAT 203 instead. If you need this requirement fulfilled for the BSE degree, then know that you'll have to dedicate a lot of time to this course if you want to actually understand the concepts and get a good grade.
If you're taking this class, it's probably because you need to. It's well-taught, though, so it shouldn't be a problem.

In general, this course's biggest problem was discrepancies between caliber of instructors. Some sections had incredibly clear instructors who understood the material well, made few mistakes, and could give clear explanations. Others had instructors who were difficult to understand, lacked confidence in front of a classroom, made frequent mistakes, and were not capable of explaining the concepts. In addition, the classwork and homework did not effectively prepare students for the exams, as they were much easier. This class is a requirement for many majors--so, many students I've talked to expressed strong dislike of the class, but had to take it. If you enjoy math just for the sake of doing math, however, it is very interesting material. Just try to get a good instructor and don't let your ego take too hard of a hit if you do poorly on  exams!
It is not enough to just do the assigned work. You must do work on your own from the book or from problems online.

It is possible to do well in this course only if you have a really clear professor, and if you've already taken the course before in high school. Other than that, it is exceedingly challenging, and there are very little resources available to students. McGraw, contrary to what professors tell you, is not that helpful, because every at McGraw is trying to complete the arduous homework sets.
It really just depends on your preceptor. I had Hanne Vlaeminck who was amazing at explaining concepts and the formulas. She definitely goes at a reasonable pace and does her best to help students.
It requires a fair bit of conceptual work but is an alright class in the lectures.
It's a math class. There's not much more to say.
It's not too bad, just be ready for tricky integrations and know your trig identities.
It's really really hard!
Its hard! Be proactive about understanding every day's class after you learn it; don't wait for the day before a test to start learning the concepts.
Keep up with the readings. Dont be afraid to ask questions.
Keep your understanding of the material current!

Know that you cannot just "plug and chug"--you have to understand the material so you can apply it on exams. Compared to MAT203 this is incredibly simple. Remember, partial credit is your best friend.

MAT 201 is challenging. If you're not naturally good at math, it requires an enormous commitment to doing the weekly assignments and studying for exams. The exams are extremely difficult. Take if you need to, but be prepared for the difficulty.

MAT 201 is considerably more difficult than MAT 104. I took 103-104 to try to solidify the concepts I had already been exposed to, and I'm glad I was able to do so before taking 201 (although honestly I don't know if it really helped). Unless you're the curve-setter, this is not going to be the math class to take for fun. That being said, the concepts are much more interesting than in 103 and 104. Also, if you're a BSE freshman and you've already taken 103-104 level classes, take 201 ASAP because you'll need it for PHY (it will make things slightly less frustrating and you'll be able to relate the math used in both classes).
Make sure to do a lot of practice exams for the final and midterms; do not rely on the notes you took in class; read the book.
Make sure you are really prepared for the 201 level math
Make sure you have all of the background knowledge first!
Make sure you take practice exams before the midterm/final and read the textbook if you need help.
Math as usual..
Multivariable is a very difficult class. Be prepared to put in lots of work if you want a good grade.
Not a good class. Do not take unless you absolutely have to. Very difficult to perform well. Be prepared to do a lot of self-study and self-teaching.
Not as scary as it seems.

Only take this course if you are content with a surface understanding of the math presented. If you want a better understanding, something like 203 would probably be better. Because of this, I plan to take 204 next semester instead of 202.
Only take this if you need it or really like math.  If not, it would be boring.
Only take this if you really love and are good at math.
Plan to spend a lot of time studying and learning the material on your own using additional resources.
Prepare for the exams, and really try to understand the concepts.

Problem sets are pretty easy, but the midterm and final are much more difficult. Make sure to brush up on integration and differentiation techniques before starting the course, as well as all of the trig identities. It's worth the effort at the beginning of the year.
Put a lot of time into this course. Do the problem sets carefully, read the textbook, and do many many old exams and quizzes.
Put in hours to understand material each week.
Quizzes and exams are exponentially more difficult than homework.
Read the book before class and don't be afraid to ask questions because most likely others have the same question.
Read the book!
