Read the book. This is incredibly helpful, especially if you do it before the course.
Read the chapters as well as doing the homework problems.
Read the chapters you are covering before lecture and not after.
Read the textbook sections before the lectures. Do not skip.
Reading the relevant chapters before lectures would be really helpful.
Really make an effort to understand the concepts and then try solving problems.
Really well taught, but subject matter could be confusing sometimes.

Start your problem sets early, preview for class if you can. It will not be an easy ride, especially if you haven't taken multivariable before. Study early and hard for the midterms and final since they will determine your grade.
Stay caught up on the material
Stay on top of readings, work on problem sets before the day before. This class sucks, no getting around it. Don't take it if you're looking for any QR, obviously.
Stay on track. Do problem sets. Go to office hours. Do the past exams.
Study
Study hard and practice. The exams are not a piece of cake.
Study up for the exams.
Take it if it's a distribution requirement. Definitely take it if you're interested as well. Just be prepared to be extremely challenged.
Take it if it's required. Also take it if you have an acute interest in thinking in 3D.

Take it if you have to. Read sections before class, because class is best used to fill in the gaps in your knowledge, rather than learn the concepts from the ground up. Either way, you will have to pull much of the intellectual weight in learning this material because the concepts are taught so quickly.
Take it if you need it obviously. Find a good study partner to go over exams with.
Take it if you need to, it was pretty well-organized and didn't require that much work.
Take it only if you have to. Otherwise, avoid it like the plague, I took MAT103/104 and aced them both, but this class was just horrible.
Take it only if you really really love math or need it for a requirement. Otherwise, save your time and take something more interesting/try something new!
Take it. It is good class.
Take only if you are fairly confident about calculus
Take this class seriously. There isn't room to mess around.
Take this course extremely seriously from the first class. It is a tough course but if you work at it, you can really do well.
Take this course if you need it!
Take this course only if you have to! Make sure to do a lot of practice problems and visit professors office hours!
Tests do not reflect the psets or class work at all. Avoid at all costs.
The class is pretty fast and confusing, especially towards the end. Keep up. Read the textbook. Also, the exams are much harder than assignments, so be prepared! Do past-year papers!
The course is decent. The teaching is one of the better aspects. However, be prepared for the quizzes and exams. Do the practice tests because the questions are much different than the homework.
The course is fast paced and challenging; so a lot of handwork is needed.
The difficulty of the class increases as the semester goes on. Do not slack off at the end of semester.

The problem sets are nothing like the quizzes and exams, so make sure you do the practice ones that are posted up on Blackboard. Don't blow off studying because you think the homework is easy -- the assessments are going to be trickier. It's useful to attend class because some of the examples given are more complex than what you might find in the book, but you could probably get along just fine by looking at someone's notes.
There's no great way to prepare for tests. Just make sure you know the book material backwards and forwards and pray you're clever enough to find something that looks familiar on the exam.

This class is terrible. If you are required to take it, I suppose you don't have any choice, but be warned?the lectures are useless, since they're basically verbatim from the textbook, and the textbook difficulty is nowhere near the difficulty of the exams. If you want to do well, you WILL have to teach yourself independently. I recommend MIT's OCW lectures and exams for their equivalent course (18.02) as a starting point. The explanations are much clearer and more helpful for getting the basics down than anything you'll find here. The Adrian Banner review videos are also decent but not as in-depth. Other than that, just work through as many sample exam problems as possible and learn to think on your feet. Oh and don't lose perspective?this is Princeton. There will inevitably be a few incredibly mathematically gifted students who will receive most of the very few A grades given on the difficult exams. The average student should consider a B or B  in this course a significant accomplishment.

This course demands a significant amount of independent learning in order to succeed. I recommend studying for the examinations by taking the practice exams posted online. Overall, this course is very useful for many topics in higher level sciences.
This course didn't require that much time throughout the semester, but exams were extremely difficult and often felt impossible to adequately prepare for.
This course is very difficult. The homework and class work is easy and then the assessment are brutally hard. Unless you really love math or have to take this course, I don't suggest it.
This course required a ton of work for people who are new to multivariable calculus, and there are very little helpful resources from professors. The course goes way too fast.
This course should be separated into a lecture and precepts. There seemed to be an imbalance between classes because some received better instruction.
Tread carefully
Try to get a good preceptor.
Try to get an instructor who speaks English as their first language.
Try to learn the material before coming to class, so that in class you can follow along with what the instructor is saying more easily and use it as review to reinforce the ideas.
Try your best to understand the material, take the homework seriously.  It helps to work on problem sets with other students.
Unless you have to, don't.

Unless you really like math this course will probably be pretty meh. And if you like math there are different courses you should be taking anyways. My best advice would probably be to read the relevant portion of the textbook before lecture. The times when I did, the lecture made much more sense and helped really solidify the concepts in my mind.
Use all the resources available. It's a challenging course so go to office hours if you need to.
Very challenging, be prepared
Watch Khan Academy.
When studying for exams, make the most of past exams, as they are much more helpful than the homework.

When studying for quizzes/midterms/finals the most valuable thing is probably just to do a lot of past exams/quizzes because the questions are not like the problem sets or anything you do in class. Also, go to office hours if you're struggling because the professors are very willing to help. Personally, I don't regret taking this course but it definitely solidified my decision not to go into math.
YOU NEED TO DO ALL THE HOMEWORK AND GO OVER TOPICS BEFORE CLASS OR IT WILL BE CONFUSING. ONLY TAKE IF YOU ARE BSE OR ECON MAT TRACK.
You know you're taking it only if you have to. Nevertheless, read the textbook to incite some interest in yourself.
You need to work outside of what they assign. This is not made clear in class--go read the Math department FAQ for what you really need to do.
You should take this course, just keep in mind that it won't be easy.
be ready for a difficult class. don't forget things as you go
do reading ahead of time. even when I did, I didnt fully understand class, but it helped a lot.
go to classes
go to office hours
go to office hours!
if you are having trouble get help
most students have already taken multi in high school, so good luck beating them on the curve
please dont. save yourself.
pre-read the textbook before class to have an idea of the material before you go in to actively learn it in class
study your notes throughout the semester!
take if you have to only.
take this course
well sucks that you have to take it.
prereqs: MAT 104 or equivalent..
descrip: Vectors in the plane and in space, vector functions and motion, surfaces, coordinate systems, functions of two or three variables and their derivatives, maxima and minima and applications, double and triple integrals, vector fields and Stokes's theorem.

title: Race, Gender, and Representation
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website

title: Can Entrepreneurial Innovation Cure What Ails America's Health "System"
descrip: Please see freshman seminars website

title: Los Angeles: Architecture, Mobility and Motion Pictures
reviews: Great course! Make sure Jean-Louis takes you to L.A.!
If you are interested in the subject you will be very satisfied.
Take this course.
descrip: The seminar will discuss both historical texts, designs and plans, and recent interpretations of Los Angeles as a global physical and cultural construct, studying the modes of construction of the main urban systems, from the wider features of the metropolitan landscape to the highways, the typical building programs and the architectural attitudes. The model represented by the city and its diffusion beyond the boundaries of Southern California will be analyzed, as well as the patterns according to which fiction, film, art and architecture have interacted to create specific Angeleno myths and cultures.

title: Problems in Ancient History - Ancient and Medieval Numismatics
descrip: A seminar covering the basic methodology of numismatics, including die, hoard and archaeological analysis. The Western coinage tradition is covered, from its origins in the Greco-Persian world through classical and Hellenistic Greek coinage, Roman imperial and provincial issues, the coinage of Byzantium, the Islamic world and medieval and renaissance Europe. Students research and report on problems involving coinages related to their own areas of specialization. Open to undergraduates by permission of the instructor.

title: Introduction to Chemical Engineering Principles
reviews: Be sure to get your reading done in order to better understand the material. Like most classes, reading prior to lectures is helpful because you've had prior exposure to the material and the lectures serve to reinforce the material so you have a better understanding of what's going on. Take advantage of office hours and be sure not to waste your time at night precepts if they're not working for you. Use your time wisely and attend sessions that preceptors you like and work for you are teaching.
Definitely take it if you're on the dense.
Do not take unless required.
Don't become a CBE major.

Don't make your decision of majoring or not in CBE based on this class. From the advice professors and grad students have given me, this course is not supposed to be the most interesting of chemical engineering, but that it is a very helpful one.
Don't worry about this class
Go to class.
Go to precept.
Go to precepts.

I heard going into this class that it was going to be fairly easy but that is totally false. It requires you to keep up with the readings and practice questions meticulously, which is hard to do if you have other very demanding classes in store.
I would highly recommend a student to take this course and find a good study group early.
I would remind other students that there is no substitute for practice problems when preparing for quizzes and exams.  Doing practice problems helped me the most when studying.

If you are considering CBE as a major then take it, especially if you are a freshmen, because then you'll be able to get a taste of whether you actually want to concentrate in CBE. Regarding difficulty, it's quite challenging, but you'll be just fine.
If you are even considering Chemical Engineering, try this course out.

If you're interested in CBE, you'll have to take this course. Don't take things too seriously and don't consider it your future in the department. Recognize that a lot of this is just about how to look at a problem, break it down, and methodically approach it to solution, not necessarily about teaching you the most fascinating material. If possible, take this freshman year; it's an easy course and fairly well-supported (there are open-book group quizzes for instance). Find a group of people to check answers with, and don't be afraid to ask Professor Priestley for clarification.
If you're taking this class you don't have a choice, so it's hardly relevant. But it's not too hard or too much work, so I think students should get through this class fine.
Make sure you do the homework and practice exams, as they are very representative of the actual tests.
Most people just take it if you are CBE....
Neutral class, not hard, slightly boring

No reason to take this course if you don't have to (CBE major), but if you do take it, realize that it not very interesting and not representative of CBE as a whole. Also, Priestley uses powerpoint slides and very little board work, so be prepared to take notes fast as he goes through the slides fast, although the slides are posted on Blackboard.
Not the most exciting course, but a good grounding!
Read the book before lecture. The book does a great job explaining and giving examples, so the lectures are just review.
Read the book. It is the best way to learn the material. Study the book's example problems. Read the professor's lecture notes. They are also helpful to prepare for quizzes and exams.

Read the textbook thoroughly and the example problems in the textbook to prepare for quizzes and exams. Also, make sure to know the fundamental concepts in addition to applications, even though the problem sets are almost all applications.
Read the textbook! stay up with the work! Try to do well on the quizzes.
Read the textbook.
Recommend
Required so what can one do
Since quizzes are taken in groups of four, and you get to choose the four people, MAKE SURE YOU FIND A GROUP THAT WILL DO THE SAME AMOUNT OF WORK AS YOU.
Take it if you're going to be a CBE major. Be aware that it jumps up in difficulty after midterms.
Take it only if you are CBE.
Take notes in class even though Prof. Priestley says you don't have to.
Take this course as a freshman if you want to be a CBE major (and are able to due to AP placement) - it'll give a good idea of whether the major is the right fit for you.

Take your more difficult engineering requirements the same semester you take this class. I know a lot of freshmen who took this fall, and will be stuck taking thermo, writing sem, and COS 126 as more or less their entire spring semesters.
The readings will greatly clarify the material presented in lecture.
There isn't much reason to take this course if you're not a CBE major, or at least considering it. The course itself is not too challenging.

This class is actually a very good, low stress course. The bad reputation comes from the fact that the material is a little bit dry. You pretty much learn the same thing over and over again with very little new knowledge gained, its just new applications. Students find this very boring because they don't really like chemistry that much and just like the allure of Chemical Engineering. I think this class is definitely good to see how committed  you are to CBE, if it is really boring - don't feel bad about dropping Chemical Engineering. It isn't for everyone, and still you will probably get a fine grade in it anyways. Do it if you are considering being CBE.

This is a good introductory course but not particularly hard. Just don't get cocky and make sure you keep up in the course -- you can't slack off, either. Precept is generally not helpful and can be skipped unless there's a certain concept you're having trouble with some week. Turn the group you work with for the quiz into your study group for this class! You'll be able to work with them better, and it's definitely helpful to be able to catch dumb errors on your problem sets before turning them in.
Use lectures as a time to learn!
Work on problem sets with your quiz group, and make sure to attend precept whenever  you can, because it is very helpful!
Work problems, problems, problems!
Working with others helps a lot. Redoing the examples in the book is also very helpful to test your understanding.
don't take it. its very dry and boring
take it if planning on majoring in CBE
prereqs: CHM 201.
descrip: Introduction to chemical engineering analysis and computations. Course starts with unit conversions and conventions for representing processes and process variables in engineering calculations. Continues with methods for generating flow sheets and analyzing mass balances both with and without chemical reactions. Rules associated with energy conservation and energy balance calculations in non-reacting and reacting systems are also covered. Ultimately, full process calculations, including chemical reactions with energy changes and multiphase systems are covered.

title: Critical Approaches to Literature: Russian Contributions
descrip: This graduate course follows the sequence of topics in COM/SLA 410, "Bakhtin, The Russian Formalists, and Cultural Semiotics," but with additional readings in Russian and different exemplary literary texts. Emphasis is on the evolution of Russian literary and cultural theory through three 20th-century historical periods: the 1920s, the Stalinist 1930-40s, and the post-Stalinist thaws.

title: Topics in American Statesmanship - Science, Technology, and the American Way
reviews: It is unfortunate that you will be unable to take this course.
It's a great course and Professor Rubin is fantastic, but professor/topic vary each semester, so not sure how relevant this feedback is (other than that it's presumably a great series!)

This course has a bit of philosophy, a bit of history, a bit of American politics, etc.  Professor Rubin really knows his stuff.  I would take it if it sounds interesting--look at the readings and see if you would like to read them.
descrip: In the course of United States history, scientists and statesmen have seen science and technology shaping and being shaped by our regime in different ways. Through materials such as autobiographies, campaign speeches, and science fiction, we will examine diverse views of the role scientific and technical expertise has in our republican political system. How do citizen virtues relate to those that produce expertise? With an eye to environmentalism and transhumanism, we will investigate to what extent founding principles of American liberal democracy are consistent with the powers science and technology give us over nature and over ourselves.

title: Doing Good, Doing Well: The Political Lives of NGOs
reviews: Definitely take this course, especially if you're not familiar with anthropology. There are about a few major concepts (governmentality, gift relationships, and others) that you'll pick up, but you won't feel like you're overwhelmed by it. This is a class that intersects theory and application well, especially through the final assignment which is pretty fun!
Definitely take this course. Make sure you give yourself time to do the readings because they are very interesting. Professor Ellison is great. Awesome course overall!

Do you want to learn about NGOs? Are you interested in the history of failed interventions? Does poverty interest you as a problem? If so, then this is the class that will prepare you for that. And it will do a better job than most policy classes you would take on similar topics.
I say take it. It's very interesting material and with putting work into the course, you can get a lot out of it.
I would definitely recommend taking this class. However, understand that the class is very much centered around critically examining NGOs, and understanding why they are often not very effective.

Prof. Ellison is great and this class covers some fascinating topics. However, be aware this is very much an anthropology course and the readings reflect that- long and dry. Take if you are interested in international development and want a new perspective or if you want to work with a fantastic anthro professor.
Take it
Take it with Ellison.
Take this course if you have a background/knowledge of anthropology AS WELL as an interest in NGOs. It is hard to sustain interest if you're interested in NGOs only.

The professor is wonderful! Anthro readings are hard to absorb, but if you've had experience with an anthro class and don't mind the length of readings, take the course! The discussions are interesting.

This course is a great way to develop a critical eye for humanitarian and developmental programs. Most all students walk away with a sense of a practical applications of the ideas we've learned which is great. The class-leading element of this course is also an opportunity to think about tools/skills for public speaking and teaching.
Very good course for non-anth majors. Not exceptionally difficult, and Prof Ellison is really chill and relatable.
descrip: From de-mining countries to rehabilitating child soldiers, from channeling donations for AIDS orphans to coordinating relief efforts in the wake of natural disasters, non-governmental organizations (NGOs) are ubiquitous. They provide essential services once thought to be the purview of the state, and increasingly champion entrepreneurial approaches to poverty reduction. NGOs are also the subject of heated debate. This seminar brings a critical anthropological lens to bear on the work of NGOs, connecting global trends, donor platforms, and aid workers to the everyday experiences of people targeted by NGO projects.

title: Decoding Dress
descrip: See the Princeton Writing Program website.

title: Intermediate Arabic I
reviews: Definitely take this class and take it with Eva if you can. She's very committed to her students.
I would encourage them to choose another language unless Arabic was their absolute first and only choice.
It was fine, better to go abroad and skip 105/107 though.
It's a great class for learning a beautiful language.
Keep an eye and the roots and patterns and you'll be fined
Study the vocab and you'll be fine
Take it. Get Tarek. He's the best. It's impossible to go through his class without a smile on your face and new Arabic vocabulary, grammar rules, and cultural references in your head.

Tarek is an incredible educator. While at the very start of the course he may seem a bit intimidating, he is an extremely passionate and devoted educator. Tarek makes his classes enjoyable and highly participatory, and each student is pushed to his/her maximum potential. I highly encourage talking to Tarek outside of the class. He truly embodies what a true 'teacher' should be, not at all in a strictly academic sense. Students learn a lot of Arabic and also other important lessons when he is teaching.

This semester of Arabic improved my language skills and built on the foundation I had from my first year of instruction. Vocabulary is introduced at a much faster pace but becomes more manageable to learn as you are able to make connections between words with the same roots.
Ustaadha Eva is one of my favorite professors at Princeton.

You know the drill?study the vocabulary, man. Learn the grammar. Maybe try reading Arabic children's books online or visiting that 'learning Arabic' section on the Al Jazeera website to work on your fluency.
be prepared to spend a lot of time on the material both in and out of class, but Tarek was a great teacher (I'd definitely recommend trying to be in his section).
prereqs: ARA 102 or the equivalent, with the permission of the Department..
descrip: This course builds on the skills developed in Elementary Arabic. Students in this course work to improve their proficiency in speaking, listening, reading and writing. We will focus primarily on Modern Standard Arabic in reading and writing, but dialectical forms will be used in informal speaking and listening exercises.

title: Beginner's Italian I
reviews: An easy language to fulfill the requirement.
Be genuinely interested in learning a new and fun language!
Daily participation and preparation for class are very important and should not be overlooked.
Definitely take it! You'll learn a lot and the professors make it fun. The workload is there, but very reasonable.
Do not miss any classes.
Easy and so so fun. Take it with Teardo!!
Get Teardo!
Get a tutor if you have to. Ask a lot of questions in class. Find a friend you can practice Italian with.
Great intro course for Italian to those who are curious about the language.
Great introduction to Italian and the teachers are amazing. Minimal homework and the tests are very straightforward.
Homework is key, do it. Attend classes and ask questions.
I would say to do the homework because it really helps solidify what you learn in class. Also having a friend in the class and speaking italian with them outside of class is helpful too for practice.
If you have any interest in Italian you should take this course. The department is very strong and it's pretty fun. Learn the vocab, but most of the quizzes are on grammar and tenses.
If you have any interest in learning Italian, take this course.
If you want to learn Italian, take this class.
If you've always wanted to learn Italian or you're just looking for an enjoyable fifth class, I'd definitely recommend this course. Professor Weinapple is absolutely awesome.
If your going to do a language, I think the Italian program has some great instructors, and the language itself is a very beautiful one.
It is hard if you don't study, but it is very manageable if you pay attention.
Italian is a beautiful language, and it's taught excellently at Princeton.
Italian is a fun language and the teachers are wonderful.

Italian is by far the best language department. Languages do not come easily to me. I had a background in Latin which is a little helpful for the romance languages, but Italian was very easy to pick up. The teachers and students in Italian are all extremely nice and fun and it ended up being my favorite class.
Italian's an undervalued language. Take this course if you want to get a quick but extremely useful introduction to the fascinating language, culture, and history of Italy and its people.
Make sure you do your homework, because it is what leads to success in the course.

My main piece of advice would be to make flashcards for the vocabulary and do a little bit every day. While the class is not overly difficult, there is a lot of vocal to learn, and doing it a little at a time makes it easier in the long run.
TAKE IT IF YOU WANT TO LEARN ITALIAN WHICH IS SUPER FUN!
Take it if you're interested in learning Italian! The department is great and classes are really fun! Sara Teardo is awesome!!
Take it with Professor Teardo or Dossena.
Take it!

Also, go to Italian table! Everyone there is really nice, even if you are terrible at speaking, like myself. Particularly the dad and his little girl, Virginia.

Take this class!!!! It is absolutely phenomenal. The professors are great and really get to know the students. It is easy (could definitely work as a fifth class), yet you learn a lot of Italian very quickly. One of my favorite classes!
Take this course!
Take this course! The course is fun and a great way to start to learn a new language.
The homework takes less than 20 minutes--do it ahead of time so you don't hold the rest of the class back.
To keep up with the written and workbook assignments, they make a huge difference in understanding. Class attendance is critical!

Vocab isn't super important, enjoy it and have fun with classmates.
best language class to take!
take it!
prereqs: No credit given for ITA 101 unless followed by ITA 102..
descrip: To develop the skills of speaking, understanding, reading and writing Italian. The main emphasis is on oral drill and conversation in the classroom. Aspects of Italian culture and civilization will be touched upon.

title: Political Economy
reviews: I would only take it for the PE certificate. While it's very easy, it is also incredibly boring.

If you're not good with relatively abstract thinking, or you don't have a decent math background, this could be a bit of a slog. However, the concepts themselves (even without the math) are fascinating and extremely clear.
Take this course. My favorite course I've taken.
prereqs: ECO 100, ECO 101, MAT 103.
descrip: Examines the role of political institutions in facilitating or hindering economic prosperity. We start with the basic tools of political economy - collective action, elections, and delegation. These tools are then applied to the problems of controlling rulers, and the persistence of inefficiency.

title: Elektra (and her family) from Homer to Freud
descrip: Please see website

title: Topics in Spanish Civilization of the Golden Age - Gastronomy in Spanish Literature
reviews: Good class. Depends on the chemistry of the people around you. Put effort into being original on the papers.
Take it - Surtz is a wonderful professor and your Spanish will improve!
come to class with points/specific questions you want to ask. And bring food/caffeine to keep up your energy
prereqs: A 200-level Spanish course or equivalent..
descrip: Cuisine is always more than nutrition; it functions as an agent of identity at both the regional and the national level. Moreover, gastronomy intersects with other manifestations of culture such as painting, literature, medicine, and religion. Readings, in addition to cookbooks, handbooks of table manners, and medical treatises, will include literary texts ranging from medieval to Golden Age to modern.

title: The Anthropology of Crime and Punishment
reviews: Actually doing the readings helps a lot, and gives you a better perspective of anthropology as a whole.
Don't take unless you're really into race and you wanna talk about racial stuff more than you've ever talked about it in your life.
Ellison is a great professor and pretty much every topic she teaches is interesting yet broad. Take it!!

Even if you're not interested specifically in the topics of crime and punishment, the anthropological lens is useful to any course of study. Take this class, if only to take a class with Professor Ellison!
Great course

If you have any sort of interest in crime and punishment or are just interested in finding out how anthropologists analyze global issues such as crime, I would strongly recommend taking this course. The material is fascinating and engaging, and Professor Ellison is very sincere and enjoyable.
If you want to be really engaged in this course you really need to read every reading. But the papers were nice to write which reduces stress throughout the semester.
Interesting class. Take it if you like discussions instead of lectures.
Make sure to do the readings and participate in class. Also, don't forget to submit responses on Blackboard,
Make sure you go to office hours and ask questions if you feel like you are not sure where you are going with your papers.
Prof. Ellison is wonderful and I'm only sad that she's leaving. I loved every single discussion in this class. It was writing-heavy for a 200 class but worthwhile for me.

Professor Ellison is really great, and she definitely cares a lot about her students. Most of the readings are on interesting topics. Overall, not too difficult, so worth taking if you are interested in the subject

Professor Ellison is super nice and knows a lot about the subject matter. The course was more like 2 1.5 hour seminars each week, rather than a lecture and precept. There was a good mix of discussion and explanation from the Professor. Out of the 30 students, there were almost no anthro majors so it was very much an intro feel with only a few people in the class who really added to or carried the discussion. The readings were not very long page-wise, but often were very dense.
Relatively easy work, but please participate in class! Introduce yourself to her. Make sure to participate!!!!!
Start the reading response papers early.
Take it!
Take this course if you are interested in anthropology and want to know more about how crime functions in the world.
They must enjoy and understand reading and ethnographical studies. It is a good course if they are interested in learning more about society and punishment.
descrip: How is crime politicized? How is the figure of The Criminal socially constructed? What concerns about disorder and illegality drive (trans)national governance agendas, and with what consequences? How do anthropologists treat crime and punishment? We will examine the politics and practices of criminalization, securitization, and efforts to impose the rule of law as they occur in local communities, along national borders, and in transnational efforts aimed at policing disorderly worlds. We will read ethnographic accounts ranging from the life-worlds of drug traffickers to international customs regimes seeking to regulate contraband economies.

title: Las Ciudades del Boom: Economic Growth, Urban Life and Architecture in the Latin American City
descrip: The research course explores the consequences of the economic growth experienced in Latin America in the past 25 years on the social and spatial organization of cities. We will analyze how the modification of political systems and the parallel neo liberal restructuring of economy have impacted on the production of space. Critical analysis will consider the connections between new phenomena of urban transformation, renewed social articulations and the surge of responses from the design fields. Within the general frame of a contemptuous concept as "Latin America", the research course will explore for local differentiations and particularities.
